Compact Disc

cards.term: Give three examples of output devices.
cards.definition: Three from:\xe2\x97\x8f Speaker\xe2\x97\x8f Monitor\xe2\x97\x8f Printer\xe2\x97\x8f Projector

cards.term: Which has the highest typical storage capacity: CD, DVD or Blu-Ray?
cards.definition: Blu-Ray

cards.term: In a hard disk drive, what is mounted at the end of the actuating arm?
cards.definition: Read / write head

cards.term: Give two types of magnetic storage.
cards.definition: Two from:\xe2\x97\x8f Hard disk drive\xe2\x97\x8f Floppy disk\xe2\x97\x8f Magnetic tape

cards.term: Which storage device has typical capacities in the range 500GB-5TB?
cards.definition: Hard disk drive
\xe2\x97\x8f High cost per GB\xe2\x97\x8f Limited lifespan
Read Only Memory

cards.term: Describe the structure in which information is stored in flash memory
cards.definition: Information is stored in blocks, which are combined to form pages.
A non-volatile storage medium does not lose its information when power is lost.

cards.term: Which two types of logic gate are used in flash storage?
cards.definition: NAND and NOR
\xe2\x97\x8f High transfer speeds\xe2\x97\x8f Lightweight\xe2\x97\x8f No moving parts
Non-volatile

cards.term: Which form of storage device uses silicon semiconductors to store information?
cards.definition: Flash
\xe2\x97\x8f They are easily damaged by scratches\xe2\x97\x8f They have relatively low capacities\xe2\x97\x8f They have relatively slow transfer speeds
Reduced Instruction Set Computer
Complex Instruction Set Computer

cards.term: What are the properties of RISC?
cards.definition: - Small instruction set- Each instruction is one line of machine code- Used in everyday devices

cards.term: What are the properties of CISC?
cards.definition: - A large instruction set- Instructions are built into hardware- Used in embedded systems and microprocessors

cards.term: What are the benefits of RISC processors?
cards.definition: Pipelining is possible since each instruction takes one clock cycle.

cards.term: What are the benefits of CISC processors?
cards.definition: - Compilers have to do less work.- They require less RAM since instructions are smaller.

cards.term: What is a graphics processing unit?
cards.definition: A co-processor made up of lots of independent parallel processors.

cards.term: What are GPUs used for now?
cards.definition: GPUs are used for image processing and machine learning.
Systems where there are multiple cores that separate fetch-execute cycles.
Systems where multiple instructions can be completed at any given time, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t require multiple cores, it can use threading and pipelining instead.

cards.term: What does the Arithmetic and Logic unitdo?
cards.definition: The ALU completes all the arithmeticaland logical operations.
A part of the processor which directsoperations inside the CPU.
Small memory cells that operate at highspeeds.

cards.term: Where do all the arithmetic, logic, or shiftoperations occur?
cards.definition: They occur in registers.
The Program Counter holds the addressof the next instruction.

cards.term: In which part of the CPU do allcalculations take place?
cards.definition: The Arithmetic and Logic Unit (ALU).

cards.term: Where are intermediate arithmetic andlogic results stored?
cards.definition: In the accumulator (ACC).

cards.term: What does the Memory Address Register do?
cards.definition: Holds the address of a location that is to be read from or written to.

cards.term: What does the Memory Data Registerdo?
cards.definition: Temporarily stores the data that has justbeen read from or the data needs to bewritten.

cards.term: What does the Current InstructionRegister do?
cards.definition: Holds the current instruction divided upinto opcode and operand.
A set of parallel wires connecting two or more components together.
The collection of the data bus, address bus, and control bus is called the system bus.

cards.term: What is the width of a bus?
cards.definition: The number of parallel wires it has.
A bidirectional bus used to transport data and instructions between components.
The bi-directional bus used to transmit control signals between internal and external components.

cards.term: What is the address bus used for?
cards.definition: Used to transmit the memory address specifying where data is to be sent from or retrieved from.

cards.term: What does adding a wire to the addressbus do to the number of addressablelocations?
cards.definition: It doubles the number of addressable locations.

cards.term: What does the Bus Request indicate?
cards.definition: indicates a device is requesting access to the data bus.
Indicates the CPU has granted access to the data bus.
Causes the data on the data bus to be written into the addressed location
Causes the data from the addressed location to be placed onto the data bus.

cards.term: What does the interrupt request control signal indicate?
cards.definition: Indicates that a device is requesting access to the CPU.

cards.term: What is the clock control signal used for?
cards.definition: It is used to synchronise instructions.
Assembly Language is a programming language where mnemonics are used to represent instructions.
Opcode is used to determine the type of instruction and what hardware to use to execute it.
The operand is the address of where the operation is performed.

cards.term: What occurs during the fetch phase?
cards.definition: - The address from the PC is copied to the MAR,- Instruction held at that address is copied to theMDR by the data bus, simultaneously thecontents of the PC is increased by 1,- The value of the MDR is copied to the CIR

cards.term: What occurs during the decode phase?
cards.definition: The contents of the CIR is split into operand and opcode.

cards.term: What occurs during the execute phase?
cards.definition: The opcode is executed on the data.
The number of clock cycles completed per second.
Cache memory is the CPU\xe2\x80\x99s onboard memory which can be accessed a lot faster than main memory
The process of completing the fetch, decode and execute of three separate files simultaneously.
Architecture in which there is a single shared memory and shared data bus for both data and instructions.
Architecture in which there is two separate memory and data buses for data and instructions.
Processing in which Von Neumann architecture is used for main memory. Cache uses Harvard architecture, divided into instruction cache and data cache
A special register to temporarily store the results of operationsperformed by the ALU.
Carries the memory location address of the register the data is being carriedto or from.
A part of the CPU that performs arithmetic calculationsand logical operations on data for the computer programs.
A physical set of parallel wires connecting and carrying groups of bits between several components of a computer.
A small and fast but expensive memory in the CPU used to store instructions and data that are accessed regularly.
The frequency at which the internal clock generates signals switching between 0 and 1. It controls how often instructions are executed and data is fetched.
A modern computer architecture combining elements of both Von Neumann and Harvard architectures.
A bi-directional bus carrying control signals from the CU to synchronise access and use of data.
A part of the CPU that controls and manages the execution of instructions. It sends control signals to coordinate execution and controls Fetch-Decode-Execute cycles and buses.
A special register that stores the current instruction being executed and decoded. The instructions are divided into operand and opcode.
A bi-directional bus for carrying data and instructions between the processor and memory.

The process of fetching from memory (supplying the address and retrieving the instruction from memory), decoding (interpreting the instruction and then reading and retrieving the required data from their addresses), and executing the instruction (CPU carries out the required actions).
A computer architecture that stores data and instructions in separate memories to allow the next instruction to be read while data is currently being read or written.
A special register that stores the memory address of the next instruction to load or data to use.
A special register that temporarily stores data to be read from or written to the computer\xe2\x80\x99s memory.
A core is a processing unit that handles instructions with its own fetch-execute-decode cycles. Multi-core processors have multiple cores that can run simultaneously.
The simultaneous decoding of several instructions by decoding the next instruction and fetching the one after while the current one is being decoded.
A special purpose register that stores the address of the next instruction to execute.
Special memory cells that can be accessed quickly. They temporarily store data and control information.
A computer architecture where a single control unit manages program control via a linear sequence of fetch-execute decode cycles.

A more complicated and expensive processor design that can execute a series of tasks in a single complex instruction built into the hardware. The variety of instructions means less RAM is used, but pipelining is not possible.
A specialised processing unit with a huge number of small cores that allow efficient parallel computation for tasks such as computer graphics, machine learning, data mining, etc.
Several CPU cores are incorporated into a single processor chip to help distribute workload.
Splitting a job into several subtasks which are simultaneously carried out by each core in the system.
A simpler processor design that can only execute a single simple instruction each clock cycle. This uses more RAM but allows pipelining.
A solid-state technology that stores data on a collection of memory chips. No moving parts as data is accessed by software.
Peripheral devices that allow the user communicate and to pass readable data into a computer, decode it and send it to the CPU.
Relies on the polarisation of magnetic particles to store bits on a magnetic material which is typically moved mechanically. A high capacity and low cost means of storage.
Data is stored in the reflectivity (pits and lands) of a surface, and is read and written to by a laser.
Peripheral devices that take convert signals from a computer into a human-readable form.
Memory used to store programs and data in use by the computer. Quick access times by all data is lost when the computer is turned off (volatile memory).
Memory used to store information that is permanently required to boot up and run the computer. Cannot be written to and is non-volatile.
Any medium on which data can be stored even when powered off.
Using the hard disk as though it were an extension of memory to free up more RAM for current programs.
Different approaches to using a programming language to solve a problem.

cards.term: Which two broad categories are programming paradigms split into?
cards.definition: - Imperative- Declarative

cards.term: State the advantages of procedural programming
cards.definition: - Can be applied to a wide range of problems.- Relatively easy to write and interpret.

cards.term: State a use of declarative programming
cards.definition: - Expert Systems/ Knowledge-based Systems.- Artificial Intelligence.

cards.term: Identify the four main programming structures used in structured programming.
cards.definition: - Sequence- Selection- Iteration- Recursion

cards.term: How does assembly language differ from machine code?
cards.definition: Assembly language uses mnemonics rather than binary. One line in assembly language is equal to one line in machine code.

cards.term: What is the function of the STA mnemonic?
cards.definition: Storing the value in the Accumulator at the given memory address.

cards.term: What is the function of the BRP mnemonic?
cards.definition: Branches to a given address if the value in the Accumulator is positive. It is a conditional branch.

cards.term: State the function of the opcode and operand.
cards.definition: The opcode specifies the instruction to be performed and the addressing mode. The operand holds a value which is related to the data on which the instruction is to be performed.
- Immediate Addressing- Direct Addressing- Indirect Addressing- Indexed Addressing
A template for an object that defines the state and behaviour of an object. An object is an instance of a class.

cards.term: Give one disadvantage of Object Oriented Languages.
cards.definition: - Requires a different style of thinking which can be difficult for programmers accustomed to other paradigms to pick up.- OOP may not be suited to all types of problems.- Generally unsuitable for smaller problems.

cards.term: Identify the common stages of softwaredevelopment life cycles (SDLCs).
cards.definition: Analysis, Design, Development, Testing, Implementation, Evaluation and Maintenance.
A form of testing carried out by software development teams in which the test plan is based on the internal structure of the program. All of the possible routes through the program are tested.
A method of analysis used by designers to evaluate the feasibility of a project. It considers technical, economic, legal, and operational aspects of the project, as well as scheduling.
A collection of methodologies which aim to improve the flexibility of software development. They respond quickly to changes in user requirements.

cards.term: Identify the advantages of waterfall programming methodologies.
cards.definition: - Straightforward to manage.- Clear structure.- Clearly documented.

cards.term: Give three disadvantages of extremeprogramming methodologies.
cards.definition: - High cost due to two people working on one project.- Teamwork and good communication is essential.- End-user must be present throughout the durationof the project.

cards.term: What type of projects are spiral programming methodologies suited to?
cards.definition: Large, risk-intensive projects with a high budget.

cards.term: What type of projects are RapidApplication Development (RAD) programming methodologies suited to?
cards.definition: Projects where high usability is required and user requirement  may not be clear from the outset or are continually changing. Suited to projects of a small to medium size with a relatively low budget and short time-frame.
A set of instructions used to solve a problem.

cards.term: State three key qualities or considerations good algorithms should make.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Inputs must be clearly defined - what is valid and what is invalid?\xe2\x97\x8f Must always produce a valid output for any defined input.\xe2\x97\x8f Must be able to deal with invalid inputs.\xe2\x97\x8f Must always reach a stopping condition.\xe2\x97\x8f Must be well-documented for reference.\xe2\x97\x8f Must be well-commented so modifications can easily be made.

cards.term: What is the difference between applications and systems software?
cards.definition: Applications software is utilised directly by the end-user whereas systems software ensures the high performance of the computer.
Three from:- Compression- Disk defragmentation- Antivirus- Automatic backup- Automatic updating

cards.term: Give one advantage of using closed source code.
cards.definition: - Thorough, regular and well-tested updates.- Expert support and user manuals from company.- High levels of security as it is developed in a professional, controlled environment.

cards.term: State two features of open source code
cards.definition: - Does not require a license to be used.- Distributed with the source code.- Can be modified and sold on.

cards.term: Give two advantages of using compiled code over interpreted code.
cards.definition: - Faster to execute.- Does not require compiler to run.

cards.term: Give two advantages of using interpreted code over compiled code
cards.definition: Two from:- Is platform independent.- Runs instantly without time waiting for compilation.- Useful for debugging.
A low-level language that has almost a one-to-one relationship with machine code. It is platform specific.

cards.term: What are the stages of compilation?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Lexical analysis\xe2\x97\x8f Syntax analysis\xe2\x97\x8f Code generation\xe2\x97\x8f Optimisation
- Tokens are compared to the rules of the programming language.- Syntax errors are identified.- Symbol table updated with more details.- Semantic analysis (finding logic errors).

cards.term: What are the similarities and differencesbetween static and dynamic linkers?
cards.definition: Similarities: Both link external modules and libraries to main program.Static: Library code copied into the file. File size increased.Dynamic: Addresses of libraries included within file. External updates automatically feed through to main program.

cards.term: Give three advantages of using libraries.
cards.definition: - Error-free- Save time- Re-usable- No need to \xe2\x80\x98reinvent the wheel\xe2\x80\x99- Designed by experts

cards.term: Describe the function of a loader.
cards.definition: Provided by the operating system, a loader retrieves the library or subroutine from the given memory location.

cards.term: What is the purpose of the optimisation stage of compilation?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Reduce execution time\xe2\x97\x8f Reduce inefficient sections of code\xe2\x97\x8f Remove redundant code
A collection of programs that work together to provide an interface between the user and the computer.

cards.term: Give 3 functions of an operating system.
cards.definition: Three from:- Memory management- Resource management- I/Output management- Interrupt management- Security- User interface- Utility software

cards.term: What are the similarities and differences between paging and segmentation?
cards.definition: Both: Are used when RAM space is insufficient, can cause disk thrashing.Paging: Uses equal-sized sections called pages.Segmentation: Uses variable-sized, logical sections called segments.

cards.term: Describe how virtual memory is used when there is not enough RAM.
cards.definition: A section of the hard drive is used to act as RAM. Sections of programs not currently being used are temporarily moved into virtual memory through paging. This frees up memory for other programs in RAM.
A signal generated by software or hardware to indicate to the processor that a process needs attention.

cards.term: Explain the stages of the Interrupt Service Routine.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Interrupt register checked at the end of each Fetch-Decode-Execute cycle.\xe2\x97\x8f If there is an interrupt exists with a higher priority to the current process, the current contents of the registersin the CPU are transferred into a stack.\xe2\x97\x8f The relevant interrupt service routine (ISR) is loaded into RAM.\xe2\x97\x8f A flag is set to signal the ISR has begun.\xe2\x97\x8f The flag is reset once the ISR has finished.\xe2\x97\x8f Interrupt register checked again. If interrupts are of a higher priority, the process is repeated.\xe2\x97\x8f If there are no interrupts with a higher priority, the contents of the stack are popped and place back into the special memory registers.\xe2\x97\x8f The fetch-Decode-Execute cycle renews as before.

cards.term: Are these scheduling algorithms pre-emptive or non pre-emptive?FCFS, SRT, SJF, MLFQ, RR
cards.definition: Pre-emptive: RR, SRT, MLFQNon-preemptive: FCFS, SJF

cards.term: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using Multilevel Feedback Queues for scheduling?
cards.definition: Advantage: Services most urgent interrupts first.Disadvantage: Hard to implement.

cards.term: Define a real-time operating system and when it may be used.
cards.definition: Real-time operating systems perform a task within a guaranteed time frame. They are used in systems were a response within a given time frame is critical eg. life support systems, self-driving cars, power systems.

cards.term: Describe three functions of the BIOS.
cards.definition: Running tests upon the computer\xe2\x80\x99s start-up:\xe2\x97\x8f POST (Power-on self test) which ensures that all hardware is correctly connected and functional.\xe2\x97\x8f Checking the CPU clock, memory and processor.\xe2\x97\x8f Testing for external memory devices.

cards.term: What is the role of a device driver?
cards.definition: Enable the operating system to interact with hardware devices.

cards.term: Describe an instance in which a Virtual Machine may be used.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Testing programs.\xe2\x97\x8f Protection from malware.\xe2\x97\x8f Running software compatible with different versions and types of operating systems.

cards.term: Give one advantage and one disadvantage of intermediate code.
cards.definition: Advantage: Platform independent, portableDisadvantage: Slower execution
A program that initialises and tests whether system hardware is functional and then loads the operating system from the hard disk into RAM when the computer is turned on.
A program supplied with a peripheral device that allows the OS to control and communicate with the device.
The operating system is spread over multiple computer servers on a network, acting as a single system to parallel process a job.
A specialised operating system with limited resources and functionality, built in to control a single machine.
A scheduling algorithm where processes are dealt with in the order they arrive (a queue).
Code partly translated between high-level and machine language produced by a compiler.
A signal from hardware, software or the clock to alert the CPU. If the interrupt is a higher priority than the current task, the  current routine pauses and resumes after the interrupt is executed.
If an interrupt is a higher priority than the current task, register contents are temporarily transferred onto the system stack at the end of the current FDE cycle and the interrupt is handled.
The efficient organisation and allocation of main memory to the programs in use.
A scheduling algorithm that uses multiple queues, each with a different priority. Jobs can be moved between queues.
An operating system capable of running multiple tasks simultaneously.

An operating system consisting of one mainframe computer with multiple terminals that allow multiple users to access the computer\xe2\x80\x99s resources. Each user is given a time slice of the mainframe processor.
A set of programs managing the operation of the computer that is loaded into RAM everytime the computer is turned on. It bridges the user to the hardware.
Partitioning memory into fixed sized physical divisions called pages. Processes in memory will be assigned an appropriate number of pages.
An operating system where data is processed as it comes, with responses generated with a guaranteed timeframe.
A scheduling algorithm where each process is given an equal time slice and is dealt with on a first in first out basis. If a process does not finish within a time slice it joins the end of the queue.
Allocating processor time to each application to ensure processor time is used as efficiently as possible when multitasking.
Partitioning memory into variable sized logical divisions called segments. A large program can be executed by consecutively running its segments.
A scheduling algorithm that picks the process with shortest estimated running time and runs it until it finishes.
A scheduling algorithm that picks the process with shortest estimated time remaining to finish. If a process with a shorter time is added, the scheduler switches processes.
An allocated area of secondary storage where pages of inactive jobs are swapped into to free up enough RAM for the current job.
A program that can be run on a computer, allowing the user to carry out specific tasks.
A translator in low level language, which converts assembly language into machine code.
Proprietary software sold with a licence and restrictions on how and how many users can use it. The source code is not available to users.
The third and final stage of compilation, where an equivalent machine code program is produced.
The process of analysing high level language source code and converting it into machine code.
A translator that converts high level language to machine code.
A translator which checks a source program for syntax errors line by line, translates it to machine code and executes the line.

The first stage of compilation, where extra spaces and comments are removed from the source code and it is searched for simple errors. Keywords, constants and variables are replaced by tokens. Variable names are loaded into the symbol table.
A collection of programs which are already compiled and can be loaded into a program and run whenever required.
A program which places the appropriate machine addresses in the call and returns instructions of a compiled program so all the other required object code files and modules are linked together.
A program that loads the executable object program and its associated libraries into memory before it is run.
Software whose source code is freely available to view, redistribute or modify.
During code generation, the object code is made as efficient as possible by removing redundancies to produce code that gives the same result.
The second stage of compilation, where statements, expressions and tokens are checked for syntax errors using syntax diagrams.
A program which converts code from one computer language to another.
System software with a specific purpose usually related to maintenance such as optimising the performance of the computer, diagnosing issues, backing up files, setting up firewalls etc.

An iterative process that produces incremental prototypes of software over short, fast-paced sprints. Each prototype is user tested and any feedback and change in requirements will be accounted for in future sprints.

A type of Agile Methodology that is more responsive to changing user needs with short development cycles and very frequent software releases. Checkpoints are incorporated to change or add new user requirements.

A method capable of speedy responses to changes in technologies and user requirements through repeated prototyping, continual evaluations, and strict time limits. The user will quickly receive a reduced-functionality mock up of the program.

An iterative version of the Waterfall model where stages are refined and repeated until the final product is complete. The first cycle works towards an initial prototype, and each successive cycle produces a refined prototype.

Each stage of development is completed one at a time in a linear order. Results from a completed stage are input into the next. Any previous stage can be returned to in light of feedback, however the stages that follow need to be worked through again.
A low level language closely related to but more advanced than machine code. It uses descriptive names and mnemonics for instructions, and is related to the design of the computer.
Data recorded as a variable associated with an object.
A template defining the attributes and methods that can be used to create a type of data known as an object.
The simplest addressing mode in assembly language where the operand stores the memory address of the value to be operated on by the operator.
A method of maintaining data integrity by only allowing class methods to access data in an object\xe2\x80\x99s attributes.
An addressing mode in assembly language where the data in the address field is constant and the operand is the value to be operated on by the operator.
An addressing mode in assembly language where the address of the operand required is calculated by adding a constant from the index register to the absolute address in the instruction.
An addressing mode in assembly language where the operand stores the address of the location holding the memory address of the required data.
The concept of subclasses inheriting the methods and attributes of its parent class (a.k.a. its super class).
A program subroutine that represents an action an object can perform.
Programming languages where the code is made of units called objects, which are instances of a class. Objectx have their own attributes and behaviours and can interact with each other.
An instance of a class. The behaviour of this data item depends on how its attributes were defined.
Objects of different classes can use the same method to perform an action.
A high level language where statements are grouped into self-contained blacks known as functions and procedures. They have built in data types and data structures.
A style of computation and programming, chosen according to the problem at hand.
HTML is the language/script that web pages are written in.
HTML allows a browser to interpret and render a webpage.

cards.term: What is a tag in HTML?
cards.definition: HTML code is made up of tags, tags are the names given to values written within angle brackets i.e. <h1>
An identifier selector is a value that follows a hashtag.
A class selector is a value that follows a full stop.
CSS is a script/language like HTML except it\xe2\x80\x99s used to describe the style of a webpage.

cards.term: What are the names of the two methods of applying CSS?
cards.definition: Internal/embedded CSS, External CSS.

cards.term: Where do you write internal CSS?
cards.definition: It\xe2\x80\x99s placed inside the style tags and is entered directly within the HTML document.

cards.term: Where do you write external CSS?
cards.definition: You write it in a separate document.

cards.term: How do you use external CSS in your HTML code?
cards.definition: You use the <link> tag.
JavaScript is a language used on webpages to add interactivity.
Interpreted
A search engine is a program that searches through a database of internet addresses looking for a resource based on a criteria set by the client/user.

cards.term: What software does search engines use?
cards.definition: Web Crawlers

cards.term: What does a Web Crawler do?
cards.definition: Travels across the internet collecting keywords and phrases from a web page and adding it to an index of web resources.
The algorithm used to determine the order used when showing web results for a search engine query.
- The number of incoming links it has from other web pages.- The page rank of the web pages that link to it
Server side processing is when a client sends information to a server for processing.
Client side processing is when information is processed on a local device for processing.
Two or more computers connected together that transmit data.
Physical topology is the physical layout of the network.
The topology that describes the flow of data through a network.
Topology in which all terminals are connected to a backbone cable.

cards.term: Name an advantage of the bus topology.
cards.definition: - Cheaper to set up.- Doesn\xe2\x80\x99t require any additional hardware.

cards.term: Give a disadvantage of the bus topology.
cards.definition: - If backbone cable fails, entire network gets disconnected.- As traffic increases, performance decreases.- All computers can see data transmission.
A network which uses a central node to direct the flow of data, each terminal is connected to the central node.

cards.term: Name two advantages of the star topology.
cards.definition: Two from:- Performance is consistent with heavy network usage,- If one cable fails only that station is affected,- Transmits data faster, so it gives better performance,- It\xe2\x80\x99s not difficult to add new stations,- No data collisions.

cards.term: Name a disadvantage of the star topology.
cards.definition: - Expensive due to switch and cabling.- If the central switch fails the rest of the network fails.
A topology in which every node is connected to every other, most commonly found with wireless technology.

cards.term: Name two advantages of the mesh topology.
cards.definition: Two from:- No cabling cost.- As number of nodes increase, reliability and speed increases.- New nodes automatically get incorporated.- Faster since data doesn\xe2\x80\x99t travel through a central switch.

cards.term: Give a disadvantage of the mesh topology.
cards.definition: - Need to purchase devices with wireless capabilities.- Maintaining the network is difficult.
Sets of rules defining how two devices communicate with each other.
Protocols are standard so devices from different manufacturers don\xe2\x80\x99t have problems communicating.

cards.term: Describe the structure of the Internet.
cards.definition: The Internet is a global network of interconnected networks.
Transmission Control Protocol
Internet Protocol

cards.term: What is the function of the application layer during data transmission?
cards.definition: The Application Layer specifies whatprotocols need to be used to relate the application to what it\xe2\x80\x99s being used for.

cards.term: What is the role of the transport layer during data transmission?
cards.definition: Establishes an end-to-end connection between the source and recipient computers. It also splits up the data into packets.

cards.term: What is the role of the network layer during data transmission?
cards.definition: Adds the source and destination IP address.

cards.term: What does the application layer do when it receives data?
cards.definition: Presents data in the form it was sent.

cards.term: What does the transport layer do when it receives the data?
cards.definition: Removes the port number and reassembles the packets.

cards.term: What does the network layer do when it receives the data?
cards.definition: Removes the IP address.

cards.term: What does the link layer do when it receives the data?
cards.definition: Removes the MAC addresses.

cards.term: What is a Local Area Network?
cards.definition: A network spread over a small geographical area/ positioned on a single site.

cards.term: What is a wide area network?
cards.definition: A network spread over a large geographical area, usually requiring extra hardware.
Domain Name System
The name given to the method of naming internet resources. (.com, .uk etc).
The process of creating a direct link between two devices and transferring data the entire duration of the link.

cards.term: What is a requirement of circuitswitching?
cards.definition: The transfer and download rates must be identical on both devices.
A method of communicating packets of data across a network

cards.term: Give an advantage of packet switching.
cards.definition: - Multiple methods to ensure data arrives correctly.- Multiple methods to arrive to destination, if one breaks you can always go through another route.- Transfer packets over a very large network.

cards.term: Give a disadvantage of packet switching.
cards.definition: Time is spent deconstructing and reconstructing the packets.

cards.term: Give an advantage of circuit switching.
cards.definition: - Data arrives in logical order which results in a quicker reconstruction of data.- Enables two users to hold a call without any delay in speech.

cards.term: Give two disadvantages of circuit switching.
cards.definition: - Bandwidth is wasted during periods when no data is sent.- Devices must transfer and download at the same rate.- Switches introduce electrical interference which can corrupt or destroy data.

cards.term: What does the header of a data packet contain?
cards.definition: - The sender and recipient IP addresses.- Protocols being used.- Order of the packets.- The time to live / hop limit.

cards.term: What does the packet payload contain?
cards.definition: The raw data.

cards.term: What does the packet trailer contain?
cards.definition: The checksum or cyclic redundancy check.
A relationship between terminals (computers) and a single server which allows them to communicate, and share resources.

cards.term: Give an advantage of client-server networking.
cards.definition: - Increased security.- Central single backups.- Data and resources can be shared.

cards.term: Name a disadvantage of client-server networking.
cards.definition: - Expensive to set up.- Trained staff are required to maintain the network.
A network where the terminals are all connected to each other to share resources.

cards.term: Give two advantages of peer-to-peer networks.
cards.definition: Two from:- Cheaper to set up.- Easy to share resources.- Easy to maintain.

cards.term: Give two disadvantages of peer-to-peer networks.
cards.definition: Two from:- Peer-to-Peer networks can be used to contribute towards piracy.- Each computer has to be backed up independently.
A database which recognises the difference between entities and uses different tables for each entity.
An item of interest about which information is stored.
A database that consists of a single file, usually about one entity.
A unique identifier for each record in a table.
The attribute which links two tables together.
An index other than the primary key used to search and sort through the database with more convenience and speed.
The process of getting the information that will be stored in the database.

cards.term: What method do banks use to capture data from cheques?
cards.definition: Magnetic Ink Character Recognition (MICR) is used for all of the details apart from the amount which must be entered manually.
Selecting data is the process of removing excess information to extract only the data you require.

cards.term: What does managing the data mean?
cards.definition: To manipulate the information collected in any type of way such as through sorting through it or selecting certain parts using SQL.

cards.term: What is the most common language used to manipulate data in databases?
cards.definition: SQL (Structured Query Language)

cards.term: What name is given to the public and private keys used in asymmetric encryption?
cards.definition: Key Pair

cards.term: Name the two categories of compression.
cards.definition: Lossy and lossless.

cards.term: In which type of compression is the quality of a file not degraded?
cards.definition: Lossless

cards.term: What is the purpose of encryption?
cards.definition: To keep data secure during transmission.

cards.term: Name one type of lossless compression.
cards.definition: One from:\xe2\x97\x8f Run length encoding.\xe2\x97\x8f Dictionary encoding.

cards.term: In which form of encryption do the sender and receiver share the same private key?
cards.definition: Symmetric Encryption

cards.term: How many keys are used in asymmetric encryption?
cards.definition: Two (one public and one private).

cards.term: If person A wants to send a message to person B using asymmetric encryption, which key should they use to encrypt the message?a) A\xe2\x80\x99s public keyb) A\xe2\x80\x99s private keyc) B\xe2\x80\x99s public keyd) B\xe2\x80\x99s private key
cards.definition: c) B\xe2\x80\x99s public keyA message encrypted with B\xe2\x80\x99s public key can only be decrypted with B\xe2\x80\x99s private key, which only B has access to.

cards.term: What is said to have occurred when two keys map to the same hash?
cards.definition: A collision.

cards.term: In which kind of lossless compression are repeated characters replaced by one occurrence and the number of times to repeat the character?
cards.definition: Run length encoding.

cards.term: What name is given to the process of turning an input into a fixed-size value?
cards.definition: Hashing

cards.term: Which data structure uses hashing to store information with constant lookup time?
cards.definition: Hash Table
The process of reducing the space required to store a file.

cards.term: Name two properties that a hashing algorithm should have.
cards.definition: Two from:\xe2\x97\x8f Low chance of collision.\xe2\x97\x8f Quick to calculate.\xe2\x97\x8f Output smaller than input.
An encryption technique where a public key available to everyone is used to encrypt the data, and the data is decrypted by the paired private key known only by the recipient.
A type of lossless compression where text is searched for entries that match the entries in a dictionary. Entries are substituted by a unique code which can then be translated.

A one-way transformation of data into an abbreviated form called a hash value. The hash value is used to validate login credentials like passwords or PINs without revealing the original data to hackers.
A compression algorithm that retains all the data in the file by only storing the instructions needed to reconstruct the original file. No data is lost.
A compression algorithm that removes non-essential data from a file leading to a noticeable decrease in accuracy of the data. Data lost is non-recoverable.
A type of lossless compression where repeated occurrences of the same data (like several pixels of the same colour in an image) are stored as single data values with their counts.
An encryption technique where the same key is used to encrypt and decrypt data. A copy of the key must be transferred between both parties.
Each transaction must obey the defined validation rules of the database to maintain referential integrity.
Once a transaction has begun, it must be completed under all circumstances.
A method of abstractly describing the data tables and the relationships between them visually. They can be used to reduce redundancy and construct a relational database.
A table with no repeating attributes. The intersection of each record and attribute produces exactly one value.
A database where a single table data structure is used to store all the data.
A linking attribute that joins two tables in a relational database by being a primary key in one and a foreign key in the other.
The process of creating an index of primary keys such that the location of any record can be retrieved given its primary key.
No transaction should overwrite other transactions that are simultaneously occurring. The same results must be obtained if transactions are concurrently or sequentially processed.
The formal process of optimally designing data tables by reducing data redundancy and repetition by converting them into normal forms.
A unique identifier that identifies each record in a table.
A technique used to prevent simultaneous access to data in a database by locking a record when it is being edited or updated. Otherwise, inconsistencies may aries in the database.
The unnecessary repetition of a field in multiple tables. Databases should have redundancy in the form of identical copies if part of the database gets lost and needs to be recovered.
The idea of keeping a database consistent by ensuring that any changes made to data or relationships associated with a table are accounted for in all the linked tables.
A database where separate tables are made for each entity, and relationships between entities are represented by foreign keys.
A key that can be used as an alternative index to access or sort records in the table in a quicker, but less accurate way than the primary key.
A table in 1NF that has data that repeats across multiple records removed and put into a new table with appropriate relationships (no partial dependencies).
A table in 2NF where all attributes that are not the primary key are fully dependent on the primary key (no non-key dependencies).
The idea of making sure that any logical operation or change in state of a database (transaction) conforms to ACID(Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) rules for reliable processing.
A method for sending data between two nodes on a network by creating a dedicated communication channel first. All data follow this same path for the duration of communication.
A type of network organisation where networked computers (clients) connect to one or more powerful central computers ( servers) that handles service requests and has resources.
A hierarchical naming system that maps human-readable domain names to IP addresses that locate and identify resources on a network.
The process of converting the original data (plaintext) into a form which cannot be understood by unauthorised users (ciphertext), using an encryption algorithm (cipher).
A security checkpoint application that monitors incoming and outgoing network traffic, designed to prevent external users from gaining unauthorised access between two networks.
A network connecting a group of computing devices on a single geographical area/site.
A method for sending data over a network by breaking data into several data packets which are sent independently and then reassembled once they all reach their destination.
A type of network organisation where networked computers are connected to each other and share resources and workloads without any central server.

A technique that simplifies network design by dividing a complex system into its component functional layers and assigning protocols for each layer to perform tasks and communicate with adjacent layers.

A server application that intercepts all data packets entering and leaving a network to hide the true network addresses of the source from the recipient. They also restrict authorised users\xe2\x80\x99 access to data and isolates the network from external networks (like the internet).

cards.term: Transmission Control Protocol / Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) Stack
cards.definition: A suite of networking protocols that allow networked computers to communicate, consisting of 4 connected layers. Incoming and outgoing data packets are passed through these layers.
A network connecting a group of computing devices over a large geographical area, typically with the help of third party carriers.
A style language used to define the layout, design and presentation of a webpage written in a markup language.

The data processing and operations performed by the client. The client\xe2\x80\x99s browser runs the processing using the user\xe2\x80\x99s local computer resources. Typically used to run less critical code.
A markup language used to write the contents of webpages on the World Wide Web.
An interpreted, object-oriented programming language used to create interactive elements within web browsers for adding functionality to dynamic web pages.
An algorithm developed by Google to rank websites in their search results by their usefulness. It ranks a webpage\xe2\x80\x99s quality and importance by counting the number of links to that webpage.

A method of collecting, parsing and storing data from websites tofacilitate fast and accurate information retrieval by the search engine. The search engineer relies on an index of webpages to accomplish this.
The data processing and operations performed by the web server. Data is sent from the client\xe2\x80\x99s browser to the web server for secure processing, and the output is sent back to the client.

topics.title: 1.4: Data Types, Data Structures and Algorithms (paper1)

cards.term: What Boolean operation is represented with an overline?
cards.definition: NOT

cards.term: Which has highest order of precedence: AND, OR or NOT?
cards.definition: NOT
C

cards.term: Which Boolean operation is represented with a dot?
cards.definition: AND
B

cards.term: Which Boolean operation is represented with a plus?
cards.definition: OR

cards.term: Apply a distributive rule to the following Boolean expression:B \xe2\x80\xa2 (A + C)
cards.definition: B \xe2\x80\xa2 A + B \xe2\x80\xa2 C
An ordered, finite set of elements of a single type.

cards.term: What type of array is a linear array?
cards.definition: A one dimensional array.

cards.term: How can you visualise a two dimensional array?
cards.definition: You can visualise it as a spreadsheet/table.

cards.term: How can you visualise a three dimensional array?
cards.definition: A three dimensional array can be visualised as a multi-page spreadsheet.

cards.term: What is a record also known as?
cards.definition: A row in a file.

cards.term: What is a record made up of?
cards.definition: A record is made up of fields.

cards.term: How can you identify a field from a record using programming?
cards.definition: recordName.fieldName

cards.term: What is the definition of a list?
cards.definition: A data structure consisting of a number of items, where the items can occur more than once.

cards.term: What are the main differences between arrays and lists?
cards.definition: - Lists can store data non-contiguously whereas arrays store data in order.- Lists can store data of more than one data type.
An immutable, ordered set of values of any type.

cards.term: What is the difference between a tuple and an array?
cards.definition: Tuples are initialised using regular brackets instead of square brackets.
A last in first out data structure, where items can only be removed from and added to the top of the list.

cards.term: Give an example of where stacks may be used.
cards.definition: - Back button in a web page- Undo buttons
A first in first out data structure, where items are added to the end of the queue and removed from the front of the queue.

cards.term: What does the operation isEmpty() do?
cards.definition: Checks to see if the stack is empty

cards.term: What does the operation push(value) do?
cards.definition: Adds a new value to the top of the stack.

cards.term: What does the operation peek() do?
cards.definition: Returns the top value of the stack without removing it.

cards.term: What does the operation pop() do?
cards.definition: Returns and removes the value at the top of the stack.

cards.term: What does the operation size() do?
cards.definition: It returns the size of the stack.

cards.term: What does the operation isFull() do?
cards.definition: Checks to see if the stack is full.

cards.term: What does the operation enQueue(value) do?
cards.definition: Adds the value to the end of the queue.

cards.term: What does the operation deQueue() do?
cards.definition: Removes the item from the end of the queue.

cards.term: What does the operation isEmpty() do?
cards.definition: It checks to see if the queue is empty.

cards.term: What does the operation isFull() do?
cards.definition: Checks to see if the queue is full.

cards.term: What data type should be used for storing a phone number like 07886756443?
cards.definition: StringNumeric types would omit the leading 0.

cards.term: Perform an AND mask on the binary numbers:1010110101011011
Which data type stores a collection of characters?
cards.definition: String

cards.term: Add the two binary numbers:0101101100111010Give your answer in decimal.
What is the decimal 45 in binary? Give your answer as a byte.
What is the hexadecimal 2E in decimal?
What is the hexadecimal 45 in binary? Give your answer as a byte.
Which data type stores just True and False?
cards.definition: Boolean

cards.term: What is -5 in sign magnitude binary? Give your answer as a nybble.
What does the binary 01101100 represent in hexadecimal?
cards.definition: 6C

cards.term: What is the effect of a logical shift left by one place?
cards.definition: The value is doubled.

cards.term: What is the two\xe2\x80\x99s complement binary 10101101 in decimal?
The binary 0011010000110 is a floating point number with a single-bit sign, 8-bit mantissa and 4-bit exponent. What is the number in decimal?
Perform a logical shift right by two places on the binary number 01101010 and convert your result to decimal.
Perform an XOR mask on the binary numbers:0101010110111011
Which of the following is not a character?a) 8b) Rc) %d) 43
The binary 1100110000011 is a floating point number with a single-bit sign, 8-bit mantissa and 4-bit exponent. What is the number in decimal?

cards.definition: A logical operator which returns TRUE (or 1) if and only if all inputs are TRUE (or 1).
A character set used to represent alphanumeric characters or symbols as a set of 8 bits.
A number system that only uses ones and zeros to represent numbers (a base 2 system).
Operations performed on a set of bits.
A data type that can only store one of two possible values(1 or 0, TRUE or FALSE etc.)
A data type for storing a letter, number or special character.
A number system that only uses 10 characters (0 to 9) to represent numbers (a base 10 system).
Performing arithmetic operations on floating point numbers in binary.
A number system that only uses 16 characters (0 to 9 and A to F) to represent numbers (a base 16 system).
A data type for storing whole number values (positive or negative) with no decimal parts.
A logical operator which returns TRUE (or 1) if and only if any one of the inputs are TRUE (or 1).
A basic built-in data type provided by a programming language.
A data type for storing numbers with decimal or fractional parts.
A bitwise manipulation where a set of bits are all moved by one place in a given direction, and the end bit may be taken as a carry or appended to the other end depending on the shift method.
A data type for storing a sequence of alphanumeric characters or symbols, typically within quotation marks.
A method of storing negative numbers in binary. It involves flipping all the bits of the binary representation of the positive number and then adding 1.
A character set that is a superset of ASCII. It is used to represent alphanumeric characters or symbols as an integer code point which is equal to that character\xe2\x80\x99s ASCII code.
A logical operator which returns TRUE (or 1) if and only if exactly 1 of the inputs are TRUE (or 1).
A data structure for storing a finite, ordered set of data of the same data type within a single identifier.
A tree where each node cannot have more than 2 children. The right node and its descendents always have a greater value than the root node (first data item).
A method of traversing an entire graph by visiting all the neighbours of the first node before repeating the same with each neighbour in the order they were visited.
A method of traversing an entire graph by travelling as far as possible along one route before backtracking and trying alternative unexplored routes.
A graph where the order of the vertices paired in an edge matter. The edges are one way.
A data structure consisting of a set of vertices/nodes connected by a set of edges/arcs.
A data structure where a hashing algorithm calculates a value to determine where a data item is to be stored. The data item can then be directly accessed by recalculation, without any search.
A data structure that stores an ordered sequence of data where each item is stored with a pointer to the next item. The items are not stored contiguously (in this same order) in memory.
A data structure that stores a sequence of data values, each with a unique index.
A first-in-first-out (FIFO) data structure. The first item added/pushed onto the queue is the first to be removed/popped off.
Data structure that stores data in elements called fields, organised based on attributes.
A last-in-first-out (LIFO) data structure. The last item added pushed is the first to be removed/popped off.
A data structure that uses a set of linked nodes to form a hierarchical structure starting at a root node. Each node is a child/sub-node of a parent node.
A data structure for storing an immutable (cannot be modified once created), ordered set of data, which can be of different data types, within a single identifier.
A graph where the order of the vertices paired in an edge does not matter. The edges are bidirectional.
A \xe2\x88\xa7 (B\xe2\x88\xa7C) = (A\xe2\x88\xa7B) \xe2\x88\xa7 CA \xe2\x88\xa8 (B\xe2\x88\xa8C) = (A\xe2\x88\xa8B) \xe2\x88\xa8 C
A combination of boolean variables and logical operators which evaluates to either TRUE or FALSE depending on the input.
A type of algebra with logical operators where all values and expressions ultimately reduce to TRUE or FALSE.
A\xe2\x88\xa7B = B\xe2\x88\xa7AA\xe2\x88\xa8B = B\xe2\x88\xa8A
\xc2\xac(A\xe2\x88\xa8B) = \xc2\xacA \xe2\x88\xa7\xc2\xacB
\xc2\xac(A\xe2\x88\xa7B) = \xc2\xacA \xe2\x88\xa8\xc2\xacB

A\xe2\x88\xa7(B\xe2\x88\xa8C) = (A\xe2\x88\xa7B) \xe2\x88\xa8 (A\xe2\x88\xa7C),(A\xe2\x88\xa8B) \xe2\x88\xa7 (C\xe2\x88\xa8D) = (A\xe2\x88\xa7C) \xe2\x88\xa8 (A\xe2\x88\xa7D) \xe2\x88\xa8 (B\xe2\x88\xa7C) \xe2\x88\xa8 (B\xe2\x88\xa7D)
A = \xc2\xac\xc2\xacA
A sequential logic circuit used to store a single bit. It has two stable states, which can be flipped between using an input signal.
A combination of two half adders that takes a carry bit and two other input bits and returns their sum and the new carry as two output bits.
A combinational arithmetic circuit that adds two numbers and produces a sum bit (S) and carry bit (C) as the output.

A method of simplifying boolean expressions by redrawing the truth table and applying a set of visual rules to obtain expressions with (or close to) the minimum logical operators, as a sum of products.
A graphical method of representing boolean expressions using the standard symbols for logic gates.

topics.title: 1.5: Legal, Moral, Cultural and Ethical Issues (paper1)

cards.term: Give two effects on businesses of computers becoming part of the workforce.
cards.definition: - Higher productivity.- Lower unit costs.- Lower costs of renting.- Lower labour costs.

cards.term: Give two uses of automated decision-making.
cards.definition: - Targeted feeds (social media).- Application processes (jobs, mortgages, loans).- Power distribution systems.- Driverless cars.- Stock trading.- Plant automation systems.
The ability of a computer to replicate human intelligence, cognitive ability and grasp abstract concepts.
Expert systems consist of a knowledge base made up of a set of facts and rules. This is used to build an inference engine which is interrogated to find diagnoses.
- Neural networks.- Expert systems.- Voice recognition.

cards.term: State two negative environmental effects of computers.
cards.definition: - Toxic e-waste contaminating water.- E-waste in third world countries.- Greenhouse gases from greater electricity consumption.- Reduced biodiversity.- Impact of climate change on future generation.

cards.term: Give two ways in which technology can be used to protect the environment.
cards.definition: - Smart home systems (sensors).- Sleep and Stand-by features on devices.- Smart engine designs.
The act of suppressing the content that people are able to view, publish and access.
The idea of an Internet where nothing is filtered at all, in line with the principle of freedom of speech.

cards.term: How is censorship used within schools?
cards.definition: Pupils may be prevented from accessing unsuitable material. May be used to maintain high productivity and prevent distractions.

cards.term: Give arguments in favour of surveillance systems.
cards.definition: Useful for social security purposes and detecting crime. Needed to trace and punish criminal activity.

cards.term: What is the name given to the process of analysing large data sets to uncover hidden trends?
cards.definition: Data Mining

cards.term: Name three things web designers must take into account when designing a website.
cards.definition: Colour paradigms, layout, character set.

cards.term: What is meant by personal data?
cards.definition: Any data which can be used to identify a living person or which can be used in combination with other data to identify a living person.

cards.term: Which act concerns the malicious use of computers?
cards.definition: The computer misuse act 1990.

cards.term: Which act protects people\xe2\x80\x99s property online?
cards.definition: The copyright, designs and patents act 1988.

cards.term: Which act covers the use of personal data?
cards.definition: The Data Protection Act 1998.

cards.term: Name two of the three primary offences under the computer misuse act 1990
cards.definition: Two from:1. Unauthorised access to computer materials.2. Unauthorised access with intent to commit further offences.3. Unauthorised modification of computer material.

cards.term: Which act covers investigation and surveillance by public bodies?
cards.definition: The regulation of investigatory powers act 2000.

cards.term: Which act prevents computer programs from being copied?
cards.definition: The copyright, designs and patents act 1988.

cards.term: What name is given to an individual who can be identified by personal data?
cards.definition: Data Subject

Legislation by the UK Parliament to prevent unauthorised access of data by recognising and defining electronic vandalism, unauthorised access or modification to computer systems and information theft.

cards.term: The Copyright Design and Patents Act 1988.
cards.definition: Legislation by the UK Parliament which prevents the illegal copying or redistribution of literary, dramatic, musical or artistic works by establishing that copyright exists until 70 years after the passing of the creator or 70 years after the creation of the work if the creator is unknown.

Legislation by the UK Parliament which requires secure, accurate and concise storage of personal data (both on computer and paper systems) to protect individuals from any unreasonable use of their data.

cards.term: The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000.
cards.definition: Legislation by the UK Parliament to regulate the power of public bodies to carry out surveillance and investigation, and covering the interception of communication.
The capability of a machine to perceive its environment and take the appropriate steps to maximise the success of its programmed goals.
The suppression or control of content that can be accessed, viewed or published on the internet.
The illegal access or use of copyrighted work without the permission of the copyright holder.
Concurrent thinking is completing more than one task at any given time.

cards.term: Are concurrent processing and concurrent thinking the same thing?
cards.definition: No.
Parallel processing is completing multiple tasks simultaneously at any given time.
Concurrent processing is giving a slice of processor time to tasks to give the illusion of parallel processing.

cards.term: What are the benefits of concurrent processing?
cards.definition: - More tasks can be completed in a given time.- Other tasks can be completed while waiting for an input/ user interaction.

cards.term: What are the drawbacks of concurrent processing?
cards.definition: If lots of users are requesting for tasks to be completed, it takes longer for everyone to complete their tasks.
A decision is a result reached after consideration.
A decision is made whenever you have to choice to make.

cards.term: What is the shape used to indicate a decision in a flow chart?
cards.definition: A diamond.

cards.term: In a flow chart how many many options stem from a decision?
cards.definition: 2 different options - yes or no/ true or false.

cards.term: How do you make effective decisions?
cards.definition: By evaluating the importance of different factors and selecting options which satisfy the needs of the task the most appropriately.

cards.term: How does the result of a decision affect the flow of a program?
cards.definition: The program will follow a different route depending on the decision made by the user.

cards.term: What is the first stage of thinking procedurally?
cards.definition: Taking the problem defined by the user and breaking it down into its constituent parts.

cards.term: What is the purpose of problem decomposition?
cards.definition: To make complex problems easier to solve and more manageable by allowing tasks to be divided between a group of people according to individual skill sets.

cards.term: State another name given to top-down design.
cards.definition: Stepwise Refinement

cards.term: What is the purpose of top-down design?
cards.definition: Continually break problems down into subproblems until each subproblem can be represented as a single task and ideally a self-contained subroutine.

cards.term: What are the benefits of using top-down design?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Problems can be solved and modules developed by different people.\xe2\x97\x8f Tasks can be tested separately. Modules are self-contained.

cards.term: What sort of problems is top-down design suited to?
cards.definition: Large, complex problems.

cards.term: What is the second stage of thinking procedurally in software development?
cards.definition: Identifying components of a solution.

cards.term: How can the lowest level subproblems in top-down design in code?
cards.definition: As self-contained modules or subroutines.

cards.term: What do software developers need to consider when recombining components of a solution?
cards.definition: The order in which subroutines are executed, and how they interact with each other, based on their role in solving the problem.

cards.term: What must a software developer do before designing a subroutine to solve aparticular problem?
cards.definition: See whether it is possible for an already existing subroutine or module to be used.

cards.term: State two advantages of utilising reusable components.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f More reliable than newly-coded components, as they have already been tested.\xe2\x97\x8f This saves time, money and resources.

cards.term: What is the purpose of thinking ahead?
cards.definition: To make programs easy and intuitive for users to use.
Any data that is required to solve a problem, usually entered into the system by the user.
The results that are passed back once the inputs have been processed and the problem solved.

cards.term: What three considerations do programmers need to make regarding inputs and outputs when thinking ahead?
cards.definition: - Method of input/output (device used).- Data structures used.- Data types used.- Order of data.
Requirements which must be met before a program can be executed.
Within the code or within documentation.

cards.term: Give an example where preconditions are required.
cards.definition: - Stack functions- Check that a stack is not empty when popping an element from a stack.- Check that a stack is not full when pushing an element onto a stack.- Factorial function- The number passed to the function cannot be negative.

cards.term: State two advantages of including preconditions within the documentation accompanying a subroutine.
cards.definition: - Reduces the length of the program.- Reduces the complexity of the program.- Saves time needed to debug and maintain a longer program.- Makes subroutine more reusable.
The process of storing instructions or values in cache memory after they have been used, as they may be used again.

cards.term: How is caching used in storing web pages?
cards.definition: Web pages that a user frequently accesses are cached, so the next time one of these pages is accessed, content can be loaded without any delay.

cards.term: What are the advantages of caching web pages?
cards.definition: - Content can be loaded without delay.- Images and text do not have to be downloaded again multiple times.- Frees bandwidth for other tasks on a network.- Less time is spent waiting.

cards.term: What is the name given to the technique in which instructions are fetched based on algorithms which predict which instructions are likely to soon be used?
cards.definition: Prefetching
- Accuracy of the algorithms used.- Effectiveness of algorithm in managing the cache.- Size of the cache.

cards.term: Give three advantages of using reusable program components.
cards.definition: - More reliable than new components, as they have already been tested.- As developing from scratch is not required, this saves time, money and resources.

cards.term: Give two examples of reusable program components.
cards.definition: - Abstract data structures eg. queues and stacks.- Classes- Subroutines
A technique in which excessive details are removed to arrive at a representation of a problem that consists of only the key features.

cards.term: Which form of abstraction involves grouping together similarities within a problem to identify what kind of problem it is?
cards.definition: Abstraction by generalisation.

cards.term: What is meant by data abstraction?
cards.definition: A form of abstraction in which details about how data is being stored are hidden.

cards.term: What kind of problems make use of multiple levels of abstraction?
cards.definition: Large, complex problems.

cards.term: How does abstraction allow non-experts to make use of a system?
cards.definition: Hides complex and irrelevant information in abstract models.

cards.term: State two advantages of using abstraction in software development.
cards.definition: Two from:- Easier for programmers to focus on core elements.- Reduces the time needed to be spent on the project.- Prevents program from getting unnecessarily large.

cards.term: Give two applications of layers of abstraction.
cards.definition: - Networking (TCP/IP layer).- Programming languages.

cards.term: State two advantages of using abstraction in programming languages.
cards.definition: - Easier to remember syntax in high-level languages as it is closer to natural language.- Coding becomes accessible to beginners.

cards.term: How does object-oriented programming use abstraction?
cards.definition: Objects are an abstraction for real-world entities. Attributes are an abstraction for the characteristics of an object.Methods are an abstraction for the actions a real-world object is able to perform.

cards.term: What is the difference between abstraction and reality?
cards.definition: Abstraction is a simplified representation of reality
Simplifying a problem by only taking into consideration the necessary details required to obtain a solution, leaving a representation without any unnecessary details.
The storage and representation of data in a computer system along with its logical description and interaction with operators. E.g. Stacks, queues, integers.
A branch of mathematics that can be used to abstractly represent problems using a collection of nodes connected by edges.
The temporary storage of data by the system in cache or memory for the benefit of faster retrieval if it is needed again in future.
Any information relevant to the problem that is required by the system for processing according to an algorithm.
The result returned by a system for a given input after running the entire process or part of a process.
A prerequisite or state of a system and its surroundings required to run a use case return a valid solution.
Components that have already been written, debugged and tested that can be transplanted into new systems to save development time in project completion.
Achieving a task by relying on a procedure of sequential steps.
The smaller, simpler series of tasks and sub-procedures a problem can be broken down into to be completed modularly.
A diagrammatic representation of the flow of a program that includes all the points where a decision needs to be taken in order to obtain a solution.

Conditions which may depend on one or more variables used to determine the next step whenever a system has to make a decision. They are typically implemented using control structures such as sequences, selections and iterations.
Processing where the system appears to perform multiple tasks simultaneously.

cards.term: What is meant by a computable problem?
cards.definition: A problem that can be solved using an algorithm.

cards.term: Give three limiting factors to computable problems
cards.definition: Three from:\xe2\x97\x8f Processing power\xe2\x97\x8f Processor speed\xe2\x97\x8f Computer memory\xe2\x97\x8f Time

cards.term: State two factors which may be considered during the Problem Definition phase
cards.definition: - Strengths and weaknesses of current solution.- Volume/type/frequency/nature of.- Inputs- Outputs- Stored data

cards.term: What is the name given to the process in which problems are continually broken down until each subproblem can be represented as a subroutine?
cards.definition: Problem Decomposition

cards.term: State two purposes of problem decomposition
cards.definition: Two from:- Identify sections which can make use of pre-coded modules or libraries.- Save timecoding.- Simplify project management.- Simplify testing and maintenance.- Faster project delivery.- Develop sections in parallel.

cards.term: Describe how the Divide and Conquer technique works
cards.definition: The problem size is halved with every iteration. Each individual subproblem is then solved recursively. The solutions to the subproblems are then recombined to form the final solution to the problem.

cards.term: Give two applications of divide and conquer
cards.definition: Two from:- Merge sort- Binary search- Quick sort

cards.term: Which programming construct do many problems solved using Divide and Conquer use?
cards.definition: Recursion
A computational technique in which excessive details are removed to simplify a problem.

cards.term: What type of abstraction is used to group together sections of the problem based on their functionality?
cards.definition: Abstraction by generalisation.
Two from:- Backtracking- Data mining- Abstraction- Divide and conquer- Visualisation- Performance modelling- Pipelining- Visualisation

The backtracking algorithm works by methodically visiting each path and building a solution based on the paths found to be correct. If a path is found to be invalid at any point, it backtracks to the previous stage and visits an alternate path.

cards.term: When might heuristics be used in problem-solving?
cards.definition: When the standard way to solve the problem is unreasonably time-consuming or resource-intensive.

cards.term: State two advantages of using performance modelling.
cards.definition: Two from:- Safe- Relatively inexpensive- Less time-consuming
A process in which tasks are developed in parallel. The output of one process in pipelining becomes the input of another, resembling a production line.

cards.term: What is the name given to the technique used to identify patterns and trends in large sets of data?
cards.definition: Data Mining
Sequence, branching and iteration.

cards.term: Which two categories of loop is iteration split up into?
cards.definition: - Count-controlled.- Condition-controlled.

cards.term: Describe how the branching programming construct works
cards.definition: A certain block of code is run if a specific condition is met, using IF statements.
A programming construct in which a subroutine calls itself during its execution until the stopping condition is met.

cards.term: What is the base case in recursion?
cards.definition: A condition that must be met in order for the recursion to end.
\xe2\x97\x8f Can be represented in fewer lines of code.\xe2\x97\x8f Easier to express some functions recursively than using iteration.
- Inefficient use of memory.- Danger of stack overflow.- Difficult to trace.

cards.term: Give two pieces of information that are stored on the call stack.
cards.definition: Two form:- Parameters- Return addresses- Local variables
The section of the program in which a variable is accessible.

cards.term: Give two advantages of using local variables over global variables.
cards.definition: Two from:- Less memory is used.- Self-contained so unaffected by code outside of the subroutine.- Take precedence over global variables with the same name.

A technique used to modularise programs in which the problem is continually broken down into sub-problems, until each can be represented as an individual, self-contained module which performs a certain task.

cards.term: State two advantages of a modular design.
cards.definition: Two from:- Makes a problem easier to understand and approach.- Simpler to divide tasks between a team.- Easier to manage project.- Self-contained modules simplify testing and maintenance.- Greater reusability.

cards.term: Give another name for top-down design.
cards.definition: Stepwise refinement

cards.term: What is the difference between procedures and functions?
cards.definition: Functions must always return a single value while a procedure does not always have to return a value.

cards.term: What does it mean to pass a parameter to a subroutine by reference?
cards.definition: The address in memory of the parameter is passed to the subroutine so its value outside of the subroutine will be updated.
Two from:- Stepping- Variable watch- Breakpoint- Source code editor- Debugging tools
Integrated Development Environment

cards.term: What is encapsulation in object-oriented programming?
cards.definition: When attributes are declared as private so can only be accessed and edited by public methods.

cards.term: Describe the purpose of encapsulation in object-oriented programming.
cards.definition: Describe the purpose of encapsulation in object-oriented programming.
A programming control structure where the code selects one or more alternative paths depending on the evaluation of a boolean expression.
A subroutine that can be called to perform a task or calculation and always return a value. Functions can be called in an expression, or be assigned to a variable.
A variable declared in the main program which exists outside any of the subroutines, but can be used anywhere in the program.
A software package that allows a user to develop and implement code more easily, with features for editing, debugging, version control, testing and compilation.
A programming control structure where a set of statements is repeated either a fixed number of times or until a condition is met.
A variable declared within a subroutine of a program, which only exists and can be used within that subroutine.
The technique of breaking down a complex problem into simpler, self-contained components called modules, where each module is an implementation of a specific subtask required to solve a problem.

A programming paradigm where the system is viewed as a set of objects, each with their own data (attributes) and procedures (methods), that can interact with each other. All processing is done by objects.
Passing the address or pointer of the required value into a procedure.
Creating a temporary local copy of the actual value of a variable and passing it into the procedure.
The data structures required to be passed into a subroutine.
A subroutine that is called by simply writing its name in the code. Procedures do not have to return a value in the program.
A programming subroutine where a section of code calls itself until a base case is met. The base case must be chosen to avoid any possibility of an infinite loop.
A programming control structure in which statements are executed one after another as they appear in the script.
A uniquely named section of code that is written to perform a specific task within a program.
An algorithm that incrementally finds a solution by methodically trying different sequences and abandoning a path when it knows it cannot lead to a valid solution.
A problem for which every instance can be solved in a finite number of steps by means of algorithm.
A method of solving a problem which by some form of computation in devising and implementing an algorithm.
An algorithm that finds a solution by analysing a large data sets to uncover trends and relationships between variables.
An algorithm design technique to decompose and solve problems by reducing the problem size with each iteration, until the sub problem becomes solvable.
A \xe2\x80\x98rule of thumb\xe2\x80\x99 algorithm which can produce a valid albeit sub-optimal solution for a hard (intractable) problem as an approximation.
The process of simulating the behaviour of a model under different virtual user and system loads by mathematical approximation.
The process of splitting a task into parts and then searching for subtasks that can be processed simultaneously to overlap the processing of each part.
The process of splitting a given problem into smaller, solvable sub-problems that are easier to conceive, understand, maintain and program.
The ability to recognise the most effective strategy to solve a problem.
