When a compound and its mirror image are non superimposable (optical isomerism).

Monochromatic light that oscillates only in one plane. By contrast, unpolarised light oscillates in all planes perpendicular to the direction of travel. A polariser is a device that converts the unpolarised light to plane-polarised light.
A device for measuring an angle of rotation caused by a chemical. Plane polarised light passes through the analyser.
Optical isomers that are mirror images of each other. They rotate the plane of polarisation of plane-polarised light.
The ability of a single optical isomer to rotate the plane of polarisation of plane-polarised monochromatic light. An optically active molecule has no planes of symmetry.

An equimolar mixture of enantiomers of a chiral compound. Doesn\xe2\x80\x99t rotate the plane of polarisation of the plane-polarised light, as the two enantiomers cancel out each others light rotating effect.
A molecule consisting of two identical molecules (monomers) linked together.

Reaction of an alcohol with a carboxylic acid in presence of an acid catalyst to form an ester. e.g:CH\xe2\x82\x83OH + CH\xe2\x82\x83COOH \xe2\x87\x8c CH\xe2\x82\x83COOCH\xe2\x82\x83 + H\xe2\x82\x82O (catalysed by conc. H\xe2\x82\x82SO\xe2\x82\x84)The process of breaking down the ester bond with water is a hydrolysis reaction. Acidic hydrolysis is a reversible reaction (see above equation). Hydrolysis under basic conditions results in an irreversible reaction, e.g:CH\xe2\x82\x83COOCH\xe2\x82\x83 + NaOH \xe2\x86\x92 CH\xe2\x82\x83COONa + CH\xe2\x82\x83OH
A reaction in which monomers link together to form a large molecule with the additional formation of small molecule, e.g. H\xe2\x82\x82O, HCl. Forms polyesters and polyamides.
Refers to the process of making soap. In practice, it is a basic hydrolysis of long-chain triglycerides to glycerol and corresponding salts of carboxylic acids.
A mechanism that involves the addition of a nucleophile to the electrophilic polar double bond, e.g. nucleophilic addition of a cyanide anion to ethanal.

A test that differentiates between aldehydes and ketones. It employs the ability of aldehydes to undergo oxidation reactions and the fact that ketones are not easily oxidised. The Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 reagent is a colourless silver (I) complex (Ag(NH\xe2\x82\x83)\xe2\x82\x82\xe2\x81\xba). The positive test results in oxidation of the aldehyde to the corresponding carboxylic acid and reduction of the silver complex to the metallic silver (hence silver mirror can be observed). Ketones do not reduce the Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 reagent.

Same principles as above, but the test reagent is a Cu\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba complex. Aldehyde will undergo a redox reaction to reduce the deep blue copper (II) complex to the brick red precipitate (Cu\xe2\x82\x82O, copper on +I oxidation state).

2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine. Used for testing for a presence of a carbonyl group (a test for aldehydes and ketones). A positive test results in the formation of the bright orange precipitate. The obtained derivative can be purified via recrystallisation and its melting point can be measured. Comparing the result with literature values can help identify the derivative.

A reaction used for identification of ethanol, ethanal, methyl ketones (e.g. propanone) and secondary alcohols bearing a methyl group on the C-OH carbon (e.g. propan-2-ol). Involves warming the compound of interest with iodine in alkaline solution. The positive result is the appearance of a yellow, crystalline precipitate with a characteristic smell.

Benzene is resistant to electrophilic addition reactions, such as bromination, which other compounds with carbon-carbon double bonds, such as alkenes, readily undergo. Benzene does not undergo electrophilic addition since this would involve breaking up the stable delocalised ring of electrons, it instead undergoes electrophilic substitution reactions.

The delocalised ring in benzene is an area of high electron density, making it susceptible to attack from electrophiles. In an electrophilic substitution mechanism, electrophiles attack the electron ring, partially destroying it, before it is then restored to form the aromatic product. This mechanism allows aromatic amines and nitrobenzene to be produced from benzene.
Halogenation is a type of electrophilic substitution reaction in which benzene reacts with halogens in the presence of a catalyst, such as iron(III) bromide (FeBr\xe2\x82\x83).

Nitration is a form of electrophilic substitution, where the electrophile is a NO\xe2\x82\x82\xe2\x81\xba ion. This is a reactive intermediate, produced in the reaction of concentrated sulfuric acid (H\xe2\x82\x82SO\xe2\x82\x84) with concentrated nitric acid (HNO\xe2\x82\x83). Sulfuric acid behaves as a catalyst since it is not used up in the reaction.
The system used for naming organic compounds.

cards.term: What does the term empirical formula mean?
cards.definition: Simplest whole number ratio of atoms in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term molecular formula mean?
cards.definition: It provides the actual number of atoms of different elements in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term displayed formula mean?
cards.definition: It shows every atom and every bond in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term structural formula mean?
cards.definition: It shows the arrangement of atoms in a molecule without showing every bond.
A type of formula which is drawn as lines with each vertex being a carbon atom. Carbon atoms not drawn, assumed each C atom has all unspecified bonds as C-H.
A series of organic compounds having the same functional group but with each successive member differing by CH\xe2\x82\x82.
A group of atoms responsible for characteristic reactions of a compound.

cards.term: Give the suffixes for:a) No double bondsb) At least one double bondc) An alcohold) An aldehydee) A ketonef) A carboxylic acid
cards.definition: a) No double bonds -aneb) At least one double bond -enec) An alcohol -old) An aldehyde -ale) A ketone -onef) A carboxylic acid -oic acid

cards.term: Give the prefixes for:a) CH\xe2\x82\x83 groupb) C\xe2\x82\x82H\xe2\x82\x85 groupc) C\xe2\x82\x83H\xe2\x82\x87 groupd) C\xe2\x82\x84H\xe2\x82\x89 groupe) Cl groupf) Br groupg) I group
cards.definition: a) CH\xe2\x82\x83 group methyl-b) C\xe2\x82\x82H\xe2\x82\x85 group ethyl-c) C\xe2\x82\x83H\xe2\x82\x87 group propyl-d) C\xe2\x82\x84H\xe2\x82\x89 group butyl-e) Cl group chloro-f) Br group bromo-g) I group iodo-

cards.term: What is the general formula of alkanes?
What is the general formula of alkenes?

cards.definition: Organic compounds which only contain single bonds.
Organic compounds that contain at least one carbon carbon double covalent bond.
When molecules have the same molecular formula but different structural formula.

cards.term: What are the 3 ways in which structural isomers can be formed?
cards.definition: 1. Alkyl groups can be in different places2. Functional groups can be bonded to different parts3. There can be different functional groups
Organic compounds with the same molecular formula but have different arrangement of atoms in space.

cards.term: What is E-Z isomerism and how are the E and Z isomers decided?
cards.definition: E-Z isomerism is caused by the limited rotation about C=C double bonds.If the two substituents with the highest molecular mass are on the same side of the double bond, it is the Z (zusammen) isomer.If they are on different sides, it is the E (entgegen) isomer.
Special type of E/Z isomerism where the two substituents on each carbon atom are the same.
It happens when each bonding atom receives one electron from the bonded pair forming two radicals.
When one bonding atom receives both electrons from the bonded pair.
Highly reactive, neutral species.

cards.term: How is a covalent bond formed from two radicals?
cards.definition: The radicals collide and the electrons are involved the bond formation.
A saturated hydrocarbons containing C-H bonds only.

cards.term: What is the general formula of an alkane?

cards.definition: Alkane fuels are obtained from the fractional distillation, cracking and reforming of crude oil.

cards.term: Describe the process of fractional distillation.
cards.definition: 1. The oil is pre-heated then passed into a column.2. The fractions condense at different heights and the temperature of column decreases upwards3. The separation of the fuels depends on boiling point which depends on size of molecules. The larger the molecule the larger the London forces4. Similar molecules (size, bp, mass) condense together and so are collected at the same fraction5. Small molecules condense at the top at lower temperatures and big molecules condense at the bottom at higher temperatures.
It is the process of converting large hydrocarbons to smaller molecules by breakage of C-C bonds.

cards.term: What is the reforming of crude oil?
cards.definition: It is processing of straight-chain hydrocarbons into branched chain alkanes and cyclic hydrocarbons for efficient combustion.

cards.term: What is the shape and angle of an alkane?
cards.definition: Tetrahedral, 109.5\xc2\xb0.
The sigma bond is a covalent bond which has a direct overlap of the electron clouds of the bonding atoms.
Very unreactive.
Combustion and reaction with halogens.

cards.term: What type of reaction is combustion?
cards.definition: Oxidation Reaction
Combustion that occurs with plentiful supply of air.

cards.term: Write an equation for the complete combustion of octane.
What are the products of complete combustion when alkanes are used?
cards.definition: Carbon dioxide and water.

cards.term: What is the colour of the bunsen burner flame during complete combustion?
cards.definition: Blue Flame

cards.term: What is incomplete combustion and what products are formed in the case of alkanes?
cards.definition: Combustion in a limited supply of oxygen.Products: water, carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide

cards.term: Write an equation for the complete combustion of propane.
What type of hydrocarbon are most likely to undergo incomplete combustion?
cards.definition: Longer Chains

cards.term: What are the pollutants formed in the combustion of alkanes?
cards.definition: Carbon monoxide, oxides of nitrogen and sulfur, carbon particulates and unburned hydrocarbons.

cards.term: What is the environmental impact of carbon monoxide?
cards.definition: It is toxic/poisonous.

cards.term: What is the environmental impact of soot (carbon)?
cards.definition: Asthma, cancer, global dimming.

cards.term: What are the environmental impacts of nitrogen oxides?
cards.definition: 1. NO is toxic and can form smog2. NO\xe2\x82\x82 is toxic and acidic and forms acid rain

cards.term: What are the environmental impacts of unbranched hydrocarbons?
cards.definition: They contribute towards formation of smog.

cards.term: What is the importance of catalytic converter?
cards.definition: These remove CO, nitrogen and unburned hydrocarbons (e.g. octane, C\xe2\x82\x88H\xe2\x82\x81\xe2\x82\x88) from the exhaust gases, turning them into less toxic products CO\xe2\x82\x82 , N\xe2\x82\x82 and H\xe2\x82\x82O.
They are fuels developed from renewable resources. Alcohols and biodiesel are two examples of renewable plant- based fuels.

cards.term: What are the advantages and disadvantages of biofuels?
cards.definition: Advantages- Reduces of use of non-renewable fossil fuels- Use of biodiesel is more carbon-neutral- Fossil fuels can be used feedstock for organic compounds- Less large scale pollutionDisadvantages- Less food crops may be grown because crops for biofuel would be grown instead- Reduction of rain forests have to be cut down to provide land- Shortage of fertile soils

cards.term: How are halogenoalkanes formed from alkanes?
cards.definition: Radical Substitution

cards.term: In the presence of what does alkane react with halogens?
cards.definition: UV Light

cards.term: What are the three stages of free radical substitution?
cards.definition: Initiation - breaking halogen bond to form free radicals.Propagation - chain part of the reaction where prod s are formed but free radical remains.Termination - free radicals removed, stable productsformed.

cards.term: Write equations for the reaction of CH\xe2\x82\x84 with Cl\xe2\x82\x82 to form CH\xe2\x82\x83Cl.
cards.definition: Initiation:Cl\xe2\x82\x82 \xe2\x86\x92 2Cl\xe2\x80\xa2 (in presence of UV light)Propagation:Cl\xe2\x80\xa2 + CH\xe2\x82\x84 \xe2\x86\x92 HCl + \xe2\x80\xa2CH\xe2\x82\x83\xe2\x80\xa2CH\xe2\x82\x83 + Cl\xe2\x82\x82 \xe2\x86\x92 CH\xe2\x82\x83Cl + Cl\xe2\x80\xa2Termination:\xe2\x80\xa2CH\xe2\x82\x83 + Cl\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x86\x92 CH\xe2\x82\x83Cl2Cl\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x86\x92 Cl\xe2\x82\x82\xe2\x80\xa2CH\xe2\x82\x83 + \xe2\x80\xa2CH\xe2\x82\x83 \xe2\x86\x92 CH\xe2\x82\x83CH\xe2\x82\x83

cards.term: What are the limitations of free radical substitution?
cards.definition: If there is excess halogen further substitution will take place therefore the desired product will be harder to separate from the others.
Unsaturated hydrocarbons that contain at least one C=C bond made up of a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8b bond and a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8e bond.
Electrons in the adjacent p orbitals overlap above and below the carbon atoms. They can only be made after a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8e bond is formed.

cards.term: What bond restricts the rotation of carbon atoms?
cards.definition: \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8b bond

cards.term: What is the angle and shape of a double bond?
cards.definition: Trigonal planar, 120\xc2\xb0.

cards.term: What is the qualitative test for alkanes?
cards.definition: This tests for C=C double bond using bromine water. If the alkane is present bromine water decolourises.

cards.term: Are they more or less reactive than alkanes? Why?
cards.definition: More reactive due to high electron density of double bond and the fact the pi-bond is slightly easier to break.

cards.term: What intermolecular forces of attraction do they have?
cards.definition: Only London forces due to non-polar bonds.

cards.term: Write an equation for the complete combustion of pent-2-ene.
cards.definition: CH\xe2\x82\x83CH=CHCH\xe2\x82\x82CH\xe2\x82\x83 + 7\xc2\xbdO\xe2\x82\x82 \xe2\x86\x92 5CO\xe2\x82\x82 + 5H\xe2\x82\x82O

cards.term: What are the types of isomers that can be formed using alkenes?
cards.definition: E/Z isomers - due to the restricted rotation.Cis-trans isomers - if two of the same substituents are attached to each carbon.
Species that are electron pair acceptors.

cards.term: What is the most stable type of carbocation intermediate? Why?
cards.definition: Alkyl groups have a positive inductive effect, so the most stable carbocation is the one bonded to the most other carbon atoms i.e. A tertiary carbocation.

cards.term: Major products will be formed from which kinds of carbocations?
cards.definition: Tertiary (or the most stable available).

cards.term: What conditions are needed for the electrophilic addition of H\xe2\x82\x82O to an alkene? What is this type of reaction called?
cards.definition: Steam in the presence of an acid catalyst, usually phosphoric acid.Reaction is called hydration.

cards.term: What are the product(s) of the hydration reaction?
cards.definition: An alcohol.

cards.term: What conditions are needed for the electrophilic addition of a hydrogen halide to an alkene?
cards.definition: Hydrogen halide gases must be at room temperature.

cards.term: What is the reaction called when a halogen is added to alkene?
cards.definition: Halogenation

cards.term: How does a molecule with a non-polar bond react as if it is an electrophile?
cards.definition: C=C double bond with a high electron density induces a temporary dipole in the halogen molecule \xe2\x86\x92 \xce\xb4+ atom attracted to double bond.

cards.term: How can an alkene be converted into alkane? What is the reaction called and what are the required conditions?
cards.definition: Alkene + hydrogen = AlkaneHydrogenationConditions \xe2\x86\x92 150\xc2\xb0C, nickel catalyst
Many monomers bonded together via rearrangement of bonds without the loss of any atom or molecule.

cards.term: What are monomers? What form do they usually take?
cards.definition: Molecules which combine to form a polymer.Usually have a C=C bond which breaks to leave a repeating pattern.

cards.term: What are the ways in which plastics can be disposed?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Landfill\xe2\x97\x8f Combustion\xe2\x97\x8f Electricity generation\xe2\x97\x8f Reuse\xe2\x97\x8f Recycle\xe2\x97\x8f Organic feedstock

cards.term: What are the disadvantages of recycling?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Plastics must be sorted into different types\xe2\x97\x8f Expensive\xe2\x97\x8f Labour intensive\xe2\x97\x8f Requires high technology

cards.term: How can chemists limit the problems caused by polymer disposal?
cards.definition: - Developing biodegradable polymers.- Removing toxic waste gases caused by incineration of plastics.

cards.term: Explain what happens in organic feedstock.
cards.definition: Plastics are separated and broken down into small organic molecules through a series of reaction. The molecules can then be used produce plastics and in other industries.
Saturated organic compounds that contain carbon atoms and at least one halogen atoms.
Insoluble as C-H bonds are non-polar, not compensated for enough by C-X bond polarity.

cards.term: Do halogenoalkanes have a polar bond? Why?
cards.definition: Yes polar, as halogen has a higher electronegativity than C (halogen is \xce\xb4-, carbon is \xce\xb4+).

cards.term: What type of intermolecular forces do they have? Why?
cards.definition: Permanent dipole-dipole and London forces of attraction.C-X bond polarity creates permanent dipoles.

cards.term: When would they have higher boiling points?
cards.definition: Increase Carbon chain length.Halogen further down group 7.

cards.term: How would the mass of a haloalkane compare with the mass of an alkane of the same chain length?
cards.definition: Greater as mass of halogen > Mass of H

cards.term: What is the most important factor in determining halogen reactivity?
cards.definition: The strength of carbon halogen bond.

cards.term: What would bond polarity suggest the order of reactivity would be?
cards.definition: C-F would be most reactive as most polar bond.

cards.term: What would bond enthalpies suggest the order of reactivity would be?
cards.definition: C-I would be most reactive as lowest bond enthalpy.

cards.term: What is the trend in reactivity of primary, secondary and tertiary halogenoalkanes?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f The tertiary halide produces a precipitate almost instantly.\xe2\x97\x8f The secondary halide gives a slight precipitate after a few seconds.\xe2\x97\x8f The primary halide takes considerably longer to produce aprecipitate.
Electron pair donor.
:OH -:CN -:NH\xe2\x82\x83
A reaction where a nucleophile donates a lone pair of electrons to \xce\xb4+ C atom, \xce\xb4\xe2\x88\x92 atom leaves molecule (replaced bynucleophiles).
A reaction where water is a reactant.

cards.term: What reactant often produces hydroxide ions for hydrolysis?
cards.definition: Water

cards.term: What fission does water undergo to produce OH\xe2\x81\xbb?
cards.definition: Heterolytic Fission

cards.term: What are the conditions/ reactants needed for the elimination reaction of haloalkanes?
cards.definition: NaOH or KOH dissolved in ethanol (no water present)Heated.

cards.term: What is formed in the elimination reaction of haloalkanes?
cards.definition: An alkene, water and halogen ion.

cards.term: How can you convert a haloalkane into an amine?
cards.definition: Reagent: NH\xe2\x82\x83 dissolved in ethanolConditions: Heating under pressure in a sealed tubeMechanism: Nucleophilic SubstitutionType of reagent: Nucleophile - ammonia

cards.term: How do you convert halogenoalkane into alkene?
cards.definition: Use ethanolic potassium hydroxide to produce alkenes (where the hydroxide ion acts as a base).

cards.term: How do you produce nitriles from haloalkane?
cards.definition: Use potassium cyanide to produce nitriles (where the cyanide ion acts as a nucleophile).

cards.term: What is the functional group of an alcohol?
cards.definition: Hydroxyl group -OH
Refers to a hydrocarbon ring having delocalised electrons in a \xcf\x80-framework. Aromatic hydrocarbons are called arenes.
Benzene is made up of planar ring of six carbon atoms with alternating single and double bonds between them.
Two ring shaped electron clouds above and below the plane of six carbon atoms due to the presence of extended \xcf\x80-framework arising from the overlap of six p orbitals.
Extra stability gained from the delocalised \xcf\x80-system in benzene.

A Catalyst (a Lewis Acid) which helps to introduce the halogen to the aromatic ring by rendering the formation of the electrophile, e.g. FeBr3 polarises the Br-Br bond making one bromine slightly positive and the other slightly negative. This helps the benzene ring attack the bromine.

Derivatives of ammonia, NH\xe2\x82\x83. In amines, consecutive hydrogens are replaced by a carbon group; for instance, CH\xe2\x82\x83NH\xe2\x82\x82 is methylamine, a primary amine. Secondary amines have a general formula R\xe2\x82\x82NH, and tertiary amines R\xe2\x82\x83N, where R = the carbon group. R\xe2\x82\x84N+ is called a quaternary ammonium salt.

Refers to the extent to which a basic molecule/ion can donate its electron pair to a proton/hydrogen of a water molecule. Structure of a base can dictate basicity, e.g. in ammonia, the lone pair is localised on nitrogen atom. In aniline (C\xe2\x82\x86H\xe2\x82\x85NH\xe2\x82\x82), the lone pair on nitrogen atom can be delocalised to the benzene ring - this reduces its ability to accept a proton and hence aniline is a weaker base than ammonia.
Organic compounds containing a carboxylic acid group (COOH) and an amine group (-NH\xe2\x82\x82).
A molecule that contains a positively charged site and a negative charged site, the overall charge being zero.

Displaying both basic and acidic properties; amino acids can react with acids, as they contain a basic site, the amino group, but also can react with bases, as they contain the acidic site, the carboxylic acid group.
pH at which an amino acid exists as a zwitterion.

A derivative of a carboxylic acid, whereby the -OH group is replaced by a nitrogen-based group. Can be prepared via the reaction of an appropriate acyl chloride with ammonia requisite amine (nucleophilic addition-elimination mechanism).
Covalent chemical bond linking two consecutive amino acid monomers. Essentially, an amide bond found in peptides.

Organometallic reagent of general formula RMgX, where R =  carbon part of the molecule, X = halogen. Used for increasing the length of the carbon chain in a molecule. Reacts via a nucleophilic addition mechanism. Forms alcohols with aldehydes/ketones and carboxylic acids when subjected to CO\xe2\x82\x82. Grignards require dry conditions (dry ether as a solvent), as they react with H\xe2\x82\x82O (they deprotonate water).
A property of a chemical that could cause damage to the user.
A possible effect a chemical may have on a user. This is dependent on factors such as concentration of the chemical. Control measures are used to restrict the risk.

A method for heating a reaction mixture at temperatures above the boiling point of the solvent used in the reaction. It employs a condenser attached to the RB flask. Cold water flows through the glass tubing of the condenser, hence cooling dow the solvent vapour. The condensed vapour returns to the flask where it boils again and so on.
Added to a heated flask to prevent vigorous & uneven boiling.
Refers to the substances that can mix together, i.e. ethanol and water, but not oil and water.

A purification method that utilises the difference in solubilities of the desired compound and its impurities. An impure compound is dissolved in a minimum amount of the boiling hot solvent. The mixture is then cooled down (e.g. using an ice bath). The assumptions are that (1) the compound dissolves well at high temperatures, but has a poor solubility at low temperatures, hence will crystallise upon cooling and (2) impurities dissolve well at all temperatures. Hence requires a careful selection of the solvent.

cards.term: What is the equation used to calculate rate?
cards.definition: Rate = Change in concentration / Time

cards.term: What is the unit for rate of reaction?
cards.definition: mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3\xe2\x80\xa2s\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What must particles do in order to react?
cards.definition: Collide with sufficient energy (activation energy) and the correct orientation.

cards.term: Do most collisions result in a reaction?
cards.definition: No.

cards.term: What are the factors that affect rate of reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Temperature\xe2\x97\x8f Pressure\xe2\x97\x8f Concentration\xe2\x97\x8f Surface area\xe2\x97\x8f Catalyst

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on rate of reaction? why?
cards.definition: Increasing temperature \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate of reactionMuch higher proportion of particles have energy greater than the activation energy \xe2\x86\x92 many more successful collisions per second \xe2\x86\x92increased rate

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing concentration/pressure on rate of reaction and why?
cards.definition: Increased concentration/pressure \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate of reactionThere are more particles in a given volume \xe2\x86\x92 more frequent successful collisions \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate

cards.term: What are the variables in an experiment that can be monitored to calculate the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Concentration of reactant or product\xe2\x97\x8f Gas volume of products\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of substances formed
A substance which increases the rate of reaction but is not used up in the reaction.

cards.term: How do catalysts work and how do they increase the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: They provide an alternate reaction pathway (with a lower activation energy).Due to lower activation energy, more particles have energy > activation energy, so more frequent successful collisions, so increased reaction rate.
A catalyst that is in the same phase as the reactants. E.g. liquid catalyst mixed with liquid reactants.
Catalyst used in the reaction is in different phase to the reactants. E.g. gaseous reactants passed over solid catalyst.

cards.term: What are the economic benefits of the use of catalysts in industrial reactions?
cards.definition: Catalysed reactions can occur at lower temperature so less fuel needed therefore fewer emissions from fuels.Catalysed reaction enables use of an alternative process with higher atom economy so fewer raw materials are needed and less waste products are produced.
The minimum energy that particles must collide with for a reaction to occur.

cards.term: Name some important features of Boltzmann distribution.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Area under the curve = total number of molecules.\xe2\x97\x8f Area under the curve does not change when conditions alter.\xe2\x97\x8f The curve starts at the origin.\xe2\x97\x8f Curve does not touch or cross the energy axis.\xe2\x97\x8f Only the molecules with energy greater than activation energy can react.

cards.term: What are the axis in a Boltzmann distribution?
cards.definition: X axis - energyY axis - number of molecules with a given energy
Minimum amount of kinetic energy the particles need to react.
A substance that provides an alternative reaction route of lower activation energy and hence speeds up the reaction. It is chemically unchanged at the end of the process.

Catalyst that is in a different phase from the reactants (i.e. different physical state). Used in gas phase reactions to provide a surface for the reaction, e.g. hydrogenation of alkenes (gaseous substrates) is catalysed by a transition metal (a solid).
Catalyst in the same physical state as reactants. Usually aqueous, e.g. acid-catalysed esterification.

A distribution of energy among the molecules of a gas in a closed system. The area under the graph indicates the number of particles. The situation below depicts the effect of increasing temperature on the distribution of molecular energies. At higher temperatures, the average energy increases (note how the maximum of the curve shifted between T1 and T2). There is also a higher proportion of molecules with energy equal to or greater than activation energy (note the area under the graph to the right of \xe2\x80\x9cactivation energy\xe2\x80\x9d line). Graph starts at (0,0) - no molecules have zero energy!

cards.term: Factors affecting the rate of a chemical reaction.
cards.definition: Catalyst (see above), surface area (greater surface area increases the number of successful collisions, i.e. powdered metal reacts faster with acid than a block of metal), temperature (see above), pressure/volume applied to gas phase reactions (greater the pressure/smaller the volume, the greater number of collisions), concentration (more concentrated = more successful collisions).
The rate of a reaction shows how fast reactants are converted into products. It depends on the concentrations of the reactants and the rate constant.

The rate constant for a reaction is constant when the reaction temperature is constant. The rate constant relates the concentrations of the species that affect the rate of a reaction to the overall rate of reaction.The rate constant, k, can be calculated by rearranging the rate equation for that reaction. It has varying units depending on the number of species and their orders of reaction. This can be found by substituting the units into the rearranged equation and cancelling.

The orders of reaction (that you need to know about at A-Level) go from zero to second order.This means that changing the concentration of reactants can have different effects on the wholereaction:Zero OrderFirst OrderSecond Order
Using the initial rate of reactions is one way the order of a reaction can be determined. This involves varying the concentrations of reactants and measuring the initial rate of the reaction.

In a first order reaction, the half-life of a reaction is constant throughout the reaction. So the time taken for the reactant concentration to go from 100% to 50% is the same as the time taken for the reactant concentration to go from 50% to 25%, and so on.

If a gas is produced by a reaction, then the mass of the reaction mixture will decrease as the reaction proceeds. Plotting a mass-time graph and drawing a tangent to the curve can be used to find the rate of reaction.

If a gas is produced by a reaction, the rate of reaction can be found by measuring the volume of gas produced over the course of the reaction, and plotting a graph of volume evolved against time. A gas syringe or an underwater upside down measuring cylinder can be used to collect the gas.

Small samples of a reaction mixture can be removed at regular intervals throughout a reaction. These samples can then be titrated to determine the concentration of a given reactant or product at that time. A concentration-time graph can then be plotted.
SN1 and SN2 are types of nucleophilic substitution reactions. The SN1 mechanism occurs in two steps whereas the SN2 reaction occurs in one.

cards.term: What is the equation used to calculate rate?
cards.definition: Rate = Change in concentration / Time

cards.term: What is the unit for rate of reaction?
cards.definition: mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3s\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What must particles do in order to react?
cards.definition: Collide with sufficient energy (activation energy) and the correct orientation.

cards.term: Do most collisions result in a reaction?
cards.definition: No.

cards.term: What are the factors that affect rate of reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Temperature\xe2\x97\x8f Pressure\xe2\x97\x8f Concentration\xe2\x97\x8f Surface area\xe2\x97\x8f Catalyst

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on rate of reaction? why?
cards.definition: Increasing temperature \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate of reactionMuch higher proportion of particles have energy greater than the activation energy \xe2\x86\x92 many more successful collisions per second \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing concentration/pressure on rate of reaction and why?
cards.definition: Increased concentration/pressure \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate of reaction There are more particles in a given volume \xe2\x86\x92 more frequent successful collisions \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate

cards.term: What are the variables in an experiment that can be monitored to calculate the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Concentration of reactant or product\xe2\x97\x8f Gas volume of products\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of substances formed
A substance which increases the rate of reaction but is not used up in the reaction.

cards.term: How do catalysts work and how do they increase the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: They provide an alternate reaction pathway (with a lower activation energy).Due to lower activation energy, more particles have energy > activation energy, so more frequent successful collisions, so increased reaction rate.
A catalyst that is in the same phase as the reactants.Eg. liquid catalyst mixed with liquid reactants.
Catalyst used in the reaction is in different phase to the reactants.Eg. gaseous reactants passed over solid catalyst.

cards.term: What are the economic benefits of the use of catalysts in industrial reactions?
cards.definition: Catalysed reactions can occur at lower temperature so less fuel needed therefore fewer emissions from fuels.Catalysed reaction enables use of an alternative process with higher atom economy so fewer raw materials are needed and less waste products are produced
The minimum energy that particles must collide with for a reaction to occur.

cards.term: Name some important features of Boltzmann distribution.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Area under the curve = total number of molecules.\xe2\x97\x8f Area under the curve does not change when conditions alter.\xe2\x97\x8f The curve starts at the origin.\xe2\x97\x8f Curve does not touch or cross the energy axis.\xe2\x97\x8f Only the molecules with energy greater than activation energy can react.

cards.term: What are the axis in a Boltzmann distribution?
cards.definition: X axis - energyY axis - number of molecules with a given energy

cards.term: Define the term rate of reaction.
cards.definition: Change in concentration (of any reactant or product) per unit time. State what is being monitored (usually production of a product).

cards.term: How could you measure the rate of reaction experimentally (different methods)?
cards.definition: Use a colorimeter at suitable intervals if there is a colour change.If gas is evolved, use a gas syringe to collect volume of gas evolved, or measure the change in mass of the reaction mixture.Use titration to time how long it takes for the end-point to occur

cards.term: At a given instant, how could you calculate the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: Rate of reaction = Change in concentration / Change in time

cards.term: How would you measure reaction rate for really fast reactions?
cards.definition: Use a flash of light to break bonds, use probe flashes to record amount of light absorbed by a species; this can show its concentration. First used for ClO\xe2\x82\x82 \xe2\x86\x92 ClO\xe2\x80\xa2 + O\xe2\x80\xa2.Can now monitor reactions that occur in times as fast as 10-12 seconds.

cards.term: How can you determine the rate constant and rate expression for a reaction?
cards.definition: Only experimentally.

cards.term: What affects the value of the rate constant for a given reaction?
cards.definition: Temperature, nothing else.

cards.term: Write a generic rate expression and state what each term means.
cards.definition: Rate = k [X]\xcb\xa3 [Y]\xca\xb8;k = rate constant for the reaction[X] and [Y] are concentrations of species X and Y respectively x and y are the orders of reaction with respect to X and Y

cards.term: Do species need to be in the chemical equation to be in the rate expression?
cards.definition: No - species in the chemical equation may be excluded and species not in the chemical equation e.g. catalysts, may be included.

cards.term: Define the term order of a reaction with respect to a given product.
cards.definition: The power to which a species\xe2\x80\x99 concentration is raised in the rate equation.

cards.term: Define the term overall order of reaction.
cards.definition: The sum of the orders of reaction of all species in the rate expression e.g. (from earlier), total order = x + y.

cards.term: How would you draw a rate concentration graph?
cards.definition: Plot [A] against time, draw tangents at different values \xe2\x86\x92 draw a secondary graph of rate against [A].

cards.term: How could you find the rate expression using the initial rate method?
cards.definition: Do a series of experiments, during which you vary concentrations, so the concentration of just one reactant changes each time.Plot a graph of concentration against time for each reactant and use a tangent at t = 0 to find the initial rate of reaction.Compare rates and concentrations between each experiment to find order of reactants and overall rate equation.

cards.term: When does the starch turn a blue-black colour in an iodine clock reaction and why?
cards.definition: When all of the Na\xe2\x82\x82S\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x83 has been used up and so I\xe2\x82\x82 is produced, which reacts with starch, leading to a blue black colour.

cards.term: How can you calculate the rate of reaction from the data from an iodine clock reaction?
cards.definition: Record time taken for colour change to occur.Use rate = 1/t. This is effectively the initial rate.

cards.term: What is the effect of a 10K temperature increase on the rate of reaction, roughly?
cards.definition: Doubles rate of reaction.

cards.term: What is true of the half life of a first order reactant (concentration against time graph)?
cards.definition: Half-life is constant.

cards.term: What is the rate determining step?
cards.definition: The slowest step in a reaction mechanism, which determines the overall rate of reaction.

cards.term: How does the rate determining step link to the species involved in the rateexpression?
cards.definition: Any species involved in the rate determining step appear in the rate expression. Species only involved after the rate determining step do not appear in the rate expression.
Change in concentration (amount) of a substance per unit time. Normal units are moldm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3s\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9.
Describes the relationship between the rate of chemical reaction and the concentrations/pressures of reagents. Includes the rate constant.
Relates the rate of a chemical reaction at a given temperature to the product of the concentrations of reactants.
Tells you how the reactant\xe2\x80\x99s concentration will affect the rate of reaction. In the rate equation, it is the appropriate power to which the concentration of the reagent is raised.
Sum of all the individual orders of all the reactants in a chemical reaction.
Time taken for the initial amount of reactant to decrease by half. Constant for 1\xcb\xa2\xe1\xb5\x97 order reactions.
The slowest step in a multi-step reaction. Overall rate is decided by this step - species occurring in the RDS will also occur in the rate equation.
A rate found by drawing the tangent to the line of \xe2\x80\x9cconcentration vs. time\xe2\x80\x9d graph and calculating the gradient of said tangent.

Chlorofluorocarbons. These compounds contribute to the depletion of ozone layer. UV light can break down the C-Cl bond within a CFC and form a chlorine radical. This can then participate in the following process, hence breaking down the ozone layer:Cl \xe2\x8b\x85 + O\xe2\x82\x83 \xe2\x86\x92 ClO \xe2\x8b\x85 + O\xe2\x82\x82ClO \xe2\x8b\x85 + O\xe2\x82\x83 \xe2\x86\x92 Cl \xe2\x8b\x85 + 2O\xe2\x82\x82Note that the Cl radical is regenerated. It acts as catalyst for this process.

The pre-exponential factor occurring in the Arrhenius equation. Measures the rate at which collisions between molecules happen without regard to their energies. Also provides a correction to the equation for the fact that a successful collision requires correct approach and orientation of the molecules.
A device for measuring the absorbance.
Amount of light absorbed by the solution.
Mass spectrometry is an analytical technique used to identify different isotopes and find the overall relative atomic mass of an element.

A sample of an element is vapourised and injected into the mass spectrometer where a high voltage is passed over the chamber. This causes electrons to be removed from the atoms (they are ionised) leaving +1 charged ions in the chamber.
These positively charged ions are then accelerated towards a negatively charged detection plate.
The ions are then deflected by a magnetic field into a curved path. The radius of the path is dependent on the charge and mass of the ion.

When the positive ions hit the negatively charged detection plate, they gain an electron, producing a flow of charge. The greater the current produced, the greater the abundance of that particular ion.
These current values are then used in combination with the flight times to produce a spectra print-out with the relative abundance of each isotope displayed.
If you know the abundances of an isotope you can generate the mass spectra for its molecules, including relative peak heights.

cards.term: What happens when a molecule absorbs infrared radiation?
cards.definition: It makes the covalent bond vibrate more in a stretching or bending motion.

cards.term: What factors affect the amount of vibration of a bond?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Bond strength\xe2\x97\x8f Bond length\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of each atom in the bond

Every bond has a unique vibration frequency in the infrared region of the EM spectrum.Bonds absorb radiation that has the same frequency as their frequency of vibration.Infrared radiation emerged from a sample is missing the frequencies that have been absorbed \xe2\x86\x92 this information can be used to identify the compound\xe2\x80\x99s functional group.

cards.term: What do the peaks on an infrared spectrum represent?
cards.definition: Absorbance of energy from the infrared radiation.

cards.term: What are the 2 peaks that must be present to identify a substance as carboxylic acid?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Very broad peak at 2500 - 3300 cm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 \xe2\x86\x92 O-H group\xe2\x97\x8f Sharp peak at 1680 - 1750 cm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 \xe2\x86\x92 C=O group

cards.term: What happens inside a mass spectrometer?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Organic compound is vaporised and passed through the spectrometer.\xe2\x97\x8f Some molecules lose an electron and forms molecular ions.\xe2\x97\x8f Excess energy from the ionisation makes the bonds vibrate more.\xe2\x97\x8f Vibration causes bond to weaken.\xe2\x97\x8f Molecular ion splits by fragmentation.

cards.term: What is the symbol of molecular ion?
cards.definition: M\xe2\x81\xba
No, because it can happen anywhere in the molecule.

cards.term: In a mass spectrometry how is a molecular ion represented?
cards.definition: It is the peak with the highest mass/charge ratio.

cards.term: The molecular mass of the molecular ion is equal to what?
cards.definition: Relative molecular mass of the compound.

cards.term: Will the molecular ion peaks of two isomers of the same compound be same or different?
cards.definition: Same.

cards.term: What is the m/z value of CH\xe2\x82\x83\xe2\x81\xba?
What is the m/z value of OH\xe2\x81\xbb from alcohol?
What is the m/z value of C\xe2\x82\x82H\xe2\x82\x85\xe2\x81\xba?
What is the m/z value of C\xe2\x82\x83H\xe2\x82\x87\xe2\x81\xba?
What is the m/z value of C\xe2\x82\x84H\xe2\x82\x89\xe2\x81\xba?
What are the advantages of using mass spectrometry?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Cheap\xe2\x97\x8f Small quantities of samples required.

cards.term: What is the main disadvantage of using mass spectrometry?
cards.definition: The sample is completely destroyed.

cards.term: What do the troughs on an infrared spectrum show?
cards.definition: The frequencies where radiation has been absorbed - match to table to find out which bonds they represent.

Area of the infrared spectrum below wavenumber of 1500cm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9.Many peaks, caused by complex vibrations of the whole molecule. Unique to every compound, so can be used to identify compounds.

cards.term: How is the fingerprint region used to identify compounds?
cards.definition: The fingerprint region\xe2\x80\x99s pattern is matched to a database on a computer to identify the compound accurately.
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance

cards.term: What are the basicprinciples of NMR?
cards.definition: You can find the structures of complex molecules by placing them in a magnetic field and applying EM waves of radio frequency to them. If radio waves of the right frequency are absorbed, the nuclei flips from parallel to applied magnetic to field to anti-parallel. This energy change can be monitored and recorded. Uses the resonance of nuclei with spin.
MRI Scans

cards.term: What kind of nuclei does NMR work with (and examples)?
cards.definition: Those with an uneven number of nucleons, meaning they will spin e.g. \xc2\xb9H, \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C.

cards.term: What percentage of carbon atoms are \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C?
cards.definition: 1% - but modern instruments are sensitive enough to detect this.

cards.term: What defines the resonant frequency of a \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C atom?
cards.definition: The chemical environment that it is in; the amount of electron shielding it has.

cards.term: What graph is produced by NMR spectroscopy?
cards.definition: Energy absorbed against chemical shift.

cards.term: What is chemical shift? What is its symbol? What are its units?
cards.definition: The resonant frequency of the nuclei, compared to that of a \xc2\xb9H atom in TMS. Symbol \xce\xb4. Parts per million (ppm)

cards.term: What is the range of chemical shift for \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C NMR?
What means \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C atoms show a different chemical shift value?
cards.definition: Having different chemical environments (but equivalent atoms show the same peak).

cards.term: What kind of environment leads to a greater chemical shift?
cards.definition: A C atom next to more electronegative atom has a greater chemical shift.

cards.term: Summarise what these mean for \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C NMR:Number of signals?Chemical shift?Area under peak?Splitting?
cards.definition: Number of signals: One signal for each carbon environment(each set of inequivalent \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C atoms)Chemical shift: Greater \xe2\x96\xa1 from atoms closer to electronegative atoms or C=CArea under peak: no meaning Splitting: there is no splitting for \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C NMR

cards.term: Why is it easier to get a spectrum of \xc2\xb9H NMR than \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C NMR?
cards.definition: Most H atoms are \xc2\xb9H- it is much more abundant than \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C. This means almost all H atoms have spin so show up.

cards.term: What is the range of chemical shift for \xc2\xb9H NMR?
cards.definition: 0-10 ppm

cards.term: What leads to a lower chemical shift value for H NMR?
cards.definition: \xc2\xb9H with more electrons around them i.e. further from electronegative groups/atoms.

cards.term: On a low resolution spectrum, what peaks would you expect to see for H NMR?
cards.definition: One peak for each set of inequivalent H atoms (each chemical environment shows 1 peak).

cards.term: What does the area under the peak represent (for H NMR)?
cards.definition: The area under the peak is proportional to the number of \xc2\xb9H atoms represented by the peak.
A stepped line that makes it easier to measure the area under the curve (height of line = area under that peak).

cards.term: What state is TMS at room temperature?
cards.definition: liquid
Can be added to sample to calibrate the NMR equipment. It provides a peak at exactly \xce\xb4 = 0ppm. It is the reference point against which all \xce\xb4 are measured.

cards.term: What are other advantages of using TMS?
cards.definition: Inert, non-toxic, easy to remove from the sample (as relatively volatile).
Neighbouring hydrogen atoms (3 or fewer bonds away, or on the adjacent carbon) affect the magnetic field of \xc2\xb9H atoms and causes their peaks to split.
If there are n inequivalent \xc2\xb9H atoms on the neighbouring carbon then the peak will split into (n+1) smaller peaks.

cards.term: Why must solvents used for \xc2\xb9H NMR not contain any hydrogen atoms?
cards.definition: Signals from the solvent would swamp signals from the sample, as there is much more solvent than sample.
Deuterated solvents: CDCl\xe2\x82\x83, D\xe2\x82\x82O, C\xe2\x82\x86D\xe2\x82\x86CCl\xe2\x82\x84 - tetrachloromethane

cards.term: Summarise what these indicate for \xc2\xb9H NMR:Number of signals?Chemical shift?Splitting?Area under peak?
cards.definition: Number of signals: One main signal for each set of inequivalent \xc2\xb9H atoms (for each hydrogen environment).Chemical shift: Larger \xe2\x96\xa1 for \xc2\xb9H atoms closer to electronegative atoms or C=C.Splitting: Number of smaller peaks = 1 + number of equivalent hydrogen atoms 3 bonds away.Area under peak: Proportional to the number of atoms represented by that peak.

cards.term: Why does the peak from O-H bonds disappear if D\xe2\x82\x82O is used as a solvent?
cards.definition: O-D bond is formed in preference to O-H due to labile protons that move/swap from one molecule to another.

cards.term: How would you carry out NMR spectroscopy?
cards.definition: Dissolve the liquid sample in suitable solvent, put in a tube along with a small amount of TMS and put the tube into an NMR machine. The sample is spun to even out any imperfections in the magnetic field and the spectrometer is zeroed against the TMS. Radiation with different radio frequencies but a constant magnetic field is applied to the sample and any absorptions (due to resonance) are detected.

cards.term: What percentage of carbon atoms are \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C?
cards.definition: 1% - but modern instruments are sensitive enough to detect this

cards.term: What defines the resonant frequency of a \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C?atom?
cards.definition: The chemical environment that it is in; the amount of electron shielding it has.
The peak with the highest m/z value. This is the molecular mass of the molecule being tested in the mass spectrometer.
The peak which occurs due to the isotope \xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3C.
When molecular ion is fragmented to smaller molecules/ions.
Has frequencies below that of red light.
When a bond absorbs infrared radiation and therefore changes its length.
A value in the IR spectrum that shows the amount of radiation absorbed at a particular frequency (the wavenumber).
A technique used to determine the presence of certain functional groups within the molecule, such as -OH, C=O, -NH2.
A technique that gives you information about the mass of a molecule and its fragments.

High resolution mass spectrometry is a much more sensitive form of mass spectrometry (seen in Topic 7) which allows the Mr of a substance to be determined to several decimal places. Precise atomic masses can then be used to calculate the molecular formula of the compound being tested.Once a molecular formula has been determined, you can predict possible structures of the compound. Knowledge of general formulas and functional groups aids this prediction.

NMR is an analytical technique that allows the structure of a molecule to be determined by analysing the energy of each bond environment. Different bond environments within a molecule absorb different amounts of energy so they are displayed as different peaks on a spectra print out.
C\xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3 NMR spectroscopy analyses the different carbon environments in a molecule. The different environments are shown as peaks at different \xce\xb4 values.

Molecules that have symmetry may display fewer \xce\xb4 peaks than the number of carbon atoms in the molecule. Therefore in these cases, it is important to look at the given molecular formula of the compound in order to decipher its displayed structure.
Chromatography is an analytical technique used to separate and identify component molecules of a mixture. It involves a mobile phase and a stationary phase.

An Rf value is a value that is unique to each different component molecule in the mixture being analysed. This is because different molecules within the mixture will have different affinities for the mobile and stationary phase and so will move at different rates within the mobile phase. It is calculated by comparing the distance moved by the component molecule to the distance moved by the mobile phase.

For column and HPL chromatography, a vertical column is packed with a solid, powdered substance which acts as the stationary phase. A solvent containing the mixture being analysed is then added and moves down the column as the mobile phase.

In gas chromatography, a thin tube is packed with a solid, powdered substance that acts as the stationary phase. Instead of a solvent, a high pressure gas is passed through this tube and acts as the mobile phase. This method is used to separate mixtures of volatile liquids which are fed into the gas chromatography machine as vapours.
Chromatography can be used to determine the identity of compounds within a mixture. This makes it useful for drug testing in sports and in forensics, where specific compounds may be screened for.
