cards.term: What are other advantages of using TMS?
cards.definition: Inert, non-toxic, easy to remove from the sample (as relatively volatile).
Neighbouring hydrogen atoms (3 or fewer bonds away, or on the adjacent carbon) affect the magnetic field of \xc2\xb9H atoms and causes their peaks to split.
If there are n inequivalent \xc2\xb9H atoms on the neighbouring carbon then the peak will split into (n+1) smaller peaks.

cards.term: Why must solvents used for \xc2\xb9H NMR not contain any hydrogen atoms?
cards.definition: Signals from the solvent would swamp signals from the sample, as there is much more solvent than sample.
Deuterated solvents: CDCl\xe2\x82\x83, D\xe2\x82\x82O, C\xe2\x82\x86D\xe2\x82\x86CCl\xe2\x82\x84-  tetrachloromethane

cards.term: Summarise what these indicate for \xc2\xb9H NMR:Number of signals?Chemical shift?Splitting?Area under peak?
cards.definition: Number of signals: One main signal for each set of inequivalent \xc2\xb9H atoms (for each hydrogen environment)Chemical shift: Larger \xe2\x96\xa1  for \xc2\xb9H atoms closer to electronegative atoms or C=CSplitting: Number of smaller peaks = 1 + number of inequivalent hydrogen atoms 3bonds awayArea under peak: Proportional to the number of atoms represented by that peak

cards.term: Why does the peak from O-H bonds disappear if D\xe2\x82\x82O is used as a solvent?
cards.definition: O-D bond is formed in preference to O-H due to labile protons that move/swap from one molecule to another.

cards.term: What are the basic principles of NMR?
cards.definition: You can find the structures of complex molecules by placing them in a magnetic field and applying EM waves of radio frequency to them. If radio waves of the right frequency are absorbed, the nuclei flips from parallel to applied magnetic to field to anti-parallel. This energy change can be monitored and recorded. Uses the resonance of nuclei with spin.

cards.term: What leads to a lower chemical shift value for H NMR?
cards.definition: \xc2\xb9H with more electrons around them i.e. further from electronegative groups/atoms.
A stepped line that makes it easier to measure the area under the curve (height of line = area under that peak).
Neighbouring hydrogen atoms (3 or fewer bonds away, or on the adjacent carbon) affect the magnetic field of \xc2\xb9H atoms and causes their peaks to split.

cards.term: Why must solvents used for \xc2\xb9H NMR not contain any hydrogen atoms?
cards.definition: Signals from the solvent would swamp signals from the sample, as there is much more solvent than sample.
High Resolution Mass Spectrometry. It gives information about M peaks to >4 decimal places.
Refers to whether atoms of a particular element are positioned identically or differently within a molecule.
Provides information about the number of different carbon environments in a molecule.

Provides information about the number of different hydrogen environments in a molecule and relative numbers of hydrogens within these environments. Sample should be dissolved in CDCl\xe2\x82\x83 or other inert, deuterated solvent (so as not to interfere with the hydrogen signals).

Used as a standard state/reference peak in NMR. All peaks caused by the other substances are measured as chemical shifts relative to the TMS. Inert to chemicals, produces a clear, single peak (12 hydrogens in the same environment), volatile - easy to remove.
Number measured in parts per million (ppm) that shows the behaviour of a particular compound in a magnetic field relative to TMS.
Provides the relative number of protons in a particular chemical environment.

A technique which separates components of a mixture between a mobile phase and a stationary phase due to different affinities of the components for different phases. Works because of intermolecular forces.
A phase in which molecules can move (liquid or gas). Moves through or over the stationary phase.
Phase where molecules can\xe2\x80\x99t move (solid or liquid on a solid support).

Same as paper chromatography, but instead of using chromatography paper you use a plate covered in a thin layer of Silica (SiO\xe2\x82\x82) or Alumina (Al\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x83) as a stationary phase.
Small particles of solid packed into a column, e.g. silica bonded to a hydrocarbon.
Polar liquid mixture, e.g. water. Forced through the column under high pressure.
Time taken for substance to pass through the column and reach the detector.
Stationary: Liquid or a solid.Mobile: Inert Gas.
The "carrier" portion of the mobile phase. It moves the analytes through the chromatograph.In liquid chromatography, the eluent is the liquid solvent; in gas chromatography, it is the carrier gas.
An element which forms at least one stable ion with a partially full d-shell of electrons.

cards.term: Where are the transition metals located in the periodic table?
cards.definition: In the middle (block from Ti to Cu) - part of the d-block.

cards.term: What are some characteristic physical properties of transition metals?
cards.definition: Metallic, good conductors of heat and electricity, hard, strong, shiny, high m.p., high b.p., low reactivity.
Vehicle bodies, to reinforce concrete.
Jet engine parts.
Water pipes.

cards.term: What are the characteristic chemical properties of transition metals (4)?
cards.definition: 1. Variable oxidation states \xe2\x86\x92 take part in many redox reactions2. Coloured compounds/ions in solution3. Good catalysts4. Form complex ions
Central transition metal ion surrounded by ligands (other ions/molecules) that are co-ordinated bonded to it.

cards.term: Give some example of transition metals catalysts and the processes/reactions they catalyse (3)?
cards.definition: 1. Iron - Haber process2. Vanadium (V) oxide - Contact process3. MnO\xe2\x82\x82 - decomposition of H\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x82

cards.term: Which electrons do transition metals lose first when forming ions?
cards.definition: 4s
An ion or molecule with at least one lone pair of electrons, that donates them to a transition metal ion to form a co-ordinate bond and thus a complex ion.
A ligand that forms one co-ordinate bond to the central metal ion (one lone pair to donate).
A ligand that forms two co-ordinate bonds to the central metal ion (2 lone pairs to donate).
A ligand that forms three or more co-ordinate bonds to the central metal ion.

cards.term: Give some examples of common monodentate ligands (4).
cards.definition: H\xe2\x82\x82O, NH\xe2\x82\x83, OH\xe2\x81\xbb

cards.term: How many co-ordinate bonds does EDTA\xe2\x81\xb4\xe2\x81\xbb form?
cards.definition: Six (6)

cards.term: How many coordinate bonds does this ligand form NH\xe2\x82\x82CH\xe2\x82\x82CH\xe2\x82\x82NH\xe2\x82\x82
cards.definition: Two (2). Therefore it is a bidentate ligand.
The number of co-ordinate bonds the metal ion has formed to surrounding ligands.
Chelate complexes with multidentate ligands are favoured over monodentate ligands or ligands that form fewer coordinate bonds per molecule.

cards.term: Explain the Chelate effect in terms of entropy and the reaction that is occurring.
cards.definition: Number of molecules increases when multidentate ligands,e.g. EDTA, displacee ligands that form fewer co-ordinate bonds per molecule.Significant increase in entropy \xe2\x86\x92 Gibbs\xe2\x80\x99 free energy change< 0 \xe2\x86\x92 feasible reaction.A more stable complex ion is formed.

cards.term: If a transition metal ion has 2 ligands, what shape is it usually?
cards.definition: Linear

cards.term: If a transition metal ion has 4 ligands, what shape is it usually?
cards.definition: Tetrahedral

cards.term: Name an exception to the general rule that ions with 4 ligands is generally tetrahedral. What shape is it?
cards.definition: Platin is square planar \xe2\x86\x92 forms cisplatin.

cards.term: What shape is a complex ion if it has 6 ligands?
cards.definition: Octahedral

cards.term: How can complex ions display E-Z or cis-trans isomerism? What shapes of ion does this apply to?
cards.definition: Ligands differ in the way in which they are arranged in space.Two (2_) ligands of the same type can be on the same side of the metal ion (next to each other), which forms the E or cis-isomer. Two (2) ligands of the same type can be on opposite sides of the metal ion (not next to each other), which forms the Z or trans-isomer. Applies to square planar and octahedral complex ions.

cards.term: What conditions are needed for a complex ion to display optical isomerism?
cards.definition: Usually applies to octahedral molecules with two (2) or more bidentate ligands, so that the mirror images are non superimposable.

cards.term: What happens to Co\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba, Cu\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba and Fe\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xba \xe2\x80\x98s coordination numbers when Cl\xe2\x81\xbb ligands replace NH\xe2\x82\x83 or H\xe2\x82\x82O ligands?
cards.definition: Decreases from 4 to 6 as Cl\xe2\x81\xbb is a much larger ligand than H\xe2\x82\x82O and NH\xe2\x82\x83.

cards.term: What is haem - its metal ion, coordination number and ligands?
cards.definition: A molecule which makes up protein chains, with an Fe\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba central metal ion, which has a coordination number of 6. 4 of these bonds are to a ring system called porphyrin. One (1) is to the nitrogen of a globin (protein) molecule and one is to an oxygen in an O\xe2\x82\x82 molecule.
O\xe2\x82\x82 forms a weak coordinate bond to the metal ion, then is transported around the body. The bond breaks when haemoglobin reaches cells and oxygen is released.

CO also coordinately bonds to the Fe\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba, and is a better ligand, so bonds more strongly than O\xe2\x82\x82.Stops O\xe2\x82\x82 from bonding to haemoglobin, so O\xe2\x82\x82 cannot be transported around the body.

cards.term: Why are transition metal compounds coloured?
cards.definition: They have partially filled d-orbitals and electrons are able to move between the d-orbitals.In compounds (when ligands coordinately bond to the ion), the d-orbitals split into different energy levels.Electrons can absorb energy in the form of photons to become excited and move to a higher energy level (excited state). Energy of photon = energy difference between levels Energy of photon is related to frequency of light by E = hf.The colour corresponding to the frequency of the energy change is missing from the spectrum, so we see a combination of all the colours that aren\xe2\x80\x99t absorbed.

cards.term: What affects the colour of a transition metal compound?
cards.definition: \xce\x94E affects the frequency of absorbed photons, so determines the colour.\xce\x94E is changed by oxidation state of the metal, number and type of ligands, shape, co-ordination number.

cards.term: Why is there a lack of colour in some aqueous ions and other complex ions?
cards.definition: Ions that have completely filled 3d energy levels (such as Zn\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba) and ions that have no electrons in their 3d energy levels (such as Sc\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xba) are not coloured those that have partially filled 3d energy levels are coloured.

cards.term: What can you use to reduce Vanadium?
cards.definition: Zinc

cards.term: What colour is Fe\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba \xe2\x80\x99s aqua ion?
cards.definition: Green

cards.term: What colour is Fe\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xba\xe2\x80\x99s aqua ion?
cards.definition: Pale Brown

cards.term: What colour is Cr\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba\xe2\x80\x99s aqua ion?
cards.definition: Blue

cards.term: What colour is Cr\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xba\xe2\x80\x99s aqua ion?
cards.definition: Red/Violet

cards.term: What colour is Co\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba\xe2\x80\x99s aqua ion?
cards.definition: Brown

cards.term: What colour is Co\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xba\xe2\x80\x99s aqua ion?
cards.definition: Yellow
Measures the absorbance of a particular wavelength of light by a solution.

cards.term: How would you use colorimetry experimentally?
cards.definition: Use solutions of known concentration to create a calibration graph; find unknown concentration.

cards.term: What information can a colorimeter give you?
cards.definition: The concentration of a certain ion in the solution.

cards.term: Why can transition metals have variable oxidation states?
cards.definition: They have partially filled d-orbitals, so can lose 4s and 3d electrons.

cards.term: Which oxidation states do all transition metals have? (except Sc). Why?
cards.definition: +2 due to loss of electrons from 4s orbital.

cards.term: When oxidation state is high, do the transition metals exist as simple ions?
cards.definition: No, after oxidation state of about III, metal ions covalently bond to other species.

cards.term: What is the use of the complex [Ag(NH\xe2\x82\x83)\xe2\x82\x82)] + ion?
cards.definition: Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 reagent to test for aldehydes/ketones (silver mirror formed with aldehyde, no visible change with ketone).
Deep Purple
Pink

cards.term: Why are redox titrations with transition metal compounds said to be self-indicating?
cards.definition: They usually involve a colour change as the metal is changing oxidation state; sometimes an indicator is still needed/useful.
Orange
Green

cards.term: What happens to aqua metal ions in acidic conditions?
cards.definition: They get reduced.

cards.term: What happens to aqua metal ions in alkaline conditions?
cards.definition: They get oxidised.

cards.term: What happens to aqua metal ions in neutral conditions?
cards.definition: No change.

cards.term: What does whether reduction/oxidation occurs and the readiness of the reaction depend on?
cards.definition: E\xc2\xb0 values.

cards.term: What can change these E\xc2\xb0 values?
cards.definition: pH, ligands involved.
A substance that increases the rate of a reaction without being chemically changed at the end of the reaction.
Provide an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy.

cards.term: Why are transition metals good catalysts?
cards.definition: They can exist in variable oxidation states, so can provide alternative pathways easily.

cards.term: Why are group 1, 2 and 3 metals not as good catalysts?
cards.definition: Only exist in one oxidation state.

cards.term: What are advantages of using a catalyst for a reaction?
cards.definition: Allows reactions to proceed at lower temperatures and pressures \xe2\x86\x92 saves valuable energy and resources.

cards.term: How do catalytic converter decrease carbon monoxide and nitrogen monoxide emissions from internal combustion engines?
cards.definition: - Adsorption of CO and NO molecules onto the surface of the catalyst.- Weaken of bonds and chemical reaction.- Desorption of CO\xe2\x82\x82 and N\xe2\x82\x82 product molecules from the surface of the catalyst.

cards.term: What metals are used in a catalytic converter and which reactions do they catalyse?
cards.definition: Pt, Rd, PdCatalyse CO, NO \xe2\x86\x92 CO\xe2\x82\x82, N\xe2\x82\x82 and C\xe2\x82\x93H\xe2\x82\x82\xe2\x82\x93\xe2\x82\x8a\xe2\x82\x82 \xe2\x86\x92 H\xe2\x82\x82O, CO\xe2\x82\x82

A catalyst that is present in the reaction in a different phase to the reactants (usually a solid, with gas/liquid reactants).Catalytic activity occurs on the solid surface as the reactants pass over it.

cards.term: What is an advantage of using a heterogeneous catalyst?
cards.definition: No need for separation of products from catalyst.

Reactants adsorb to the catalyst\xe2\x80\x99s surface at active sites. Thisweakens bonds within the reactants, holds reactants close together on the surface and/or in the correct orientation to react. Once the reaction has occurred, products desorb from the active sites.

cards.term: What properties does the catalyst need to have to make it a good catalyst?
cards.definition: Can\xe2\x80\x99t adsorb too strongly, otherwise the products will not desorb. Can\xe2\x80\x99t adsorb too weakly as reactant would not be held in place for long enough and bonds would not be sufficiently weakened. Need a good balance between desorption and adsorption.

cards.term: How can you increase the efficiency of heterogeneous catalysts?
cards.definition: Increase the surface area to increase the number of active sites that are present. Also spread onto an inert support medium, e.g. ceramic, to increase the surface/mass ratio. Use ceramic honeycomb matrix/mesh/sponge.
Unwanted impurities adsorb to the catalyst\xe2\x80\x99s active sites and do not desorb. This blocks the active sites on the catalyst\xe2\x80\x99s surface.

cards.term: What effect does catalyst poisoning have on catalytic activity?
cards.definition: Decreases the effectiveness of the catalyst over time.

cards.term: How else can a catalyst be degraded?
cards.definition: Finely divided catalysts can be gradually lost from their support medium.

cards.term: What is the Haber process? What catalyst is used?
cards.definition: N\xe2\x82\x82 (g) + 3H\xe2\x82\x82 (g) \xe2\x86\x92 2NH\xe2\x82\x83 (g) Makes ammonia, uses iron (Fe) catalyst.
A catalyst that is in the same phase as the reactants.
Form intermediates to give a different reaction pathway with lower EA.

cards.term: What is the reaction between S\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x88\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb ions and I\xe2\x81\xbb ions?
cards.definition: S\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x88\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb + 2I\xe2\x81\xbb \xe2\x86\x92 2SO\xe2\x82\x84\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb + I\xe2\x82\x82 (all aq)

cards.term: Why does the reaction between S\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x88\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb ions and I\xe2\x81\xbb ions have a high EA in normal conditions?
cards.definition: Two negative ions are reacting. They repel each other so EA is high.
When the product of a reaction is also a catalyst for that reaction.

cards.term: Write a half equation for the conversion of C\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x84\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb ions into CO\xe2\x82\x82.
cards.definition: C\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x84\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb \xe2\x86\x92 2CO\xe2\x82\x82 + 2e\xe2\x81\xbb

cards.term: How can you monitor the concentration of MnO\xe2\x82\x84\xe2\x81\xbb ions?
cards.definition: Using a colorimeter.
Transition metals form complexes, consisting of a central metal ion surrounded by ligands.

A ligand is a molecule or ion with a lone electron pair that is able to form a dative (coordinate) bond to the central metal ion by donating this electron pair. Common ligands include:\xe2\x97\x8f Cl\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x97\x8f H\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x97\x8f NH\xe2\x82\x83

The coordination number of a transition metal complex is the total number of coordinate bonds formed with the central metal ion. Silver complexes have a coordination number of 2 and platinum complexes commonly have a coordination number of 4.

Transition metal complexes with H\xe2\x82\x82O and NH\xe2\x82\x83 ligands commonly form octahedral complexes with a bond angle of 90\xc2\xb0. Octahedral complexes are formed when there is six-fold coordination with monodentate ligands.
When complexes form with larger ligands such as Cl\xe2\x81\xbb, they form tetrahedral complexes with a bond angle of 109.5\xc2\xb0. Tetrahedral complexes can show optical isomerism.
Platinum and nickel complexes form in a square planar shape. This consists of four coordinate bonds with a bond angle of 90\xc2\xb0.

This is the cis isomer of a square planar complex of platinum. It is commonly used as a cancer therapy drug. Drugs like cisplatin target components of cells that are chiral, so only one isomer of the drug will be the correct orientation to \xe2\x80\x98fit\xe2\x80\x99 the cells. Therefore only this single isomer will work and cure the disease.

Ligands in a transition metal complex can be exchanged for other ligands.Haem, a component of haemoglobin, is another common multidentate ligand. It consists of six coordinate bonds around a central Fe\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba ion. Its shape and structure allow it to transport oxygen around the body.

One of the key chemical properties of transition metals is their variable oxidation states. Vanadium has four possible oxidation states from +5 to +2 each of which produces a different coloured compound. These different species can be produced from the reduction of vanadium by zinc in acidic solution.

The pH of the reaction conditions determines whether a transition metal is oxidised or reduced. For ions to be reduced (the oxidation state becomes more negative), acidic conditions are required.For ions to be oxidised (the oxidation state becomes more positive), they react with water to produce OH\xe2\x81\xbb ions and therefore alkaline conditions are required.

The enthalpy change (\xe2\x88\x86H) for ligand substitution reactions is very small as the bonds being formed are very similar to the bonds that were broken. Therefore, overall enthalpy change is near to zero.

A catalyst is a substance that speeds up the rate of a reaction without being used up in the reaction. It provides an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy. Catalysts don\xe2\x80\x99t affect the position of equilibrium but allow it to be reached faster. Transition metals make good catalysts due to their variable oxidation states.
1. Heterogeneous2. Homogeneous
d-block elements that form one or more stable ions with incompletely filled d orbitals.

Have their origin in electronic transitions. A complex containing a transition metal ion with incompletely filled d orbitals will have the set of d orbitals split into two sets of orbitals of different energies. An electron can be excited from a lower energy level to a higher energy level by absorbing some energy. The amount of energy needed depends on the energy difference between the two energy levels. This energy difference is proportional to the frequency of the absorbed light (and hence inversely proportional to the wavelength of the absorbed light). This tells us what is the colour of the radiation absorbed. By looking at the electromagnetic spectrum and complimentary colours, we can deduce the colour that is transmitted (e.g. yellow absorbed, violet transmitted).
A central metal cation surrounded by ligands, e.g. Cu(H\xe2\x82\x82O)\xe2\x82\x86\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba.
tom, ion or molecule that donates a pair of electrons to a central metal ion, e.g. H\xe2\x82\x82NCH\xe2\x82\x82CH\xe2\x82\x82NH\xe2\x82\x82 (called en - ethylenediamine)

Sometimes molecules display square planar geometry around the central atom. This could be due to the presence of the lone pairs (XeF\xe2\x82\x84), or d orbitals (Pt(NH\xe2\x82\x83)\xe2\x82\x83Cl\xe2\x82\x83 - also displays cis/trans isomerism).

Pt(NH\xe2\x82\x83)\xe2\x82\x82Cl\xe2\x82\x82 with cis geometry. An anticancer compound that binds to the two strands of DNA during cell division process. This prevents them from separating and hence stops the cell division. On the other hand, the trans isomer is not useful.

Describes how many dative bonds a ligand can form. Monodentate ligand (e.g. NH\xe2\x82\x83) forms one. Bidentate (e.g. C\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x84\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb) forms two, etc. In general, multidentate ligands have more than one electron pair to donate to the metal centre.

Number of dative covalent bonds that ligands form with the central metal ion. Common coordination numbers are 2 (linear, e.g. Ag(NH\xe2\x82\x83)\xe2\x82\x82\xe2\x81\xba), 4 (tetrahedral, e.g. CuCl\xe2\x82\x84\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb and square planar, e.g. cisplatin), and 6 (octahedral, e.g. Cr(H\xe2\x82\x82O)\xe2\x82\x86\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xba).
A reaction in which a ligand is substituted by another ligand.

The process of forming weak bonds by reactants to a surface of a solid catalyst. In hydrogenation (heterogeneous catalysis), gases (alkene and hydrogen) adsorb on the surface of solid nickel, where the reaction takes place.
The reverse process to adsorption. Adsorbed molecules leave the surface.
When a product catalyses the reaction, e.g. Mn\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba in oxidation of oxalate with permanganate under acidic conditions.

A protein responsible for oxygen transport in human blood. Contains an Fe\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba site. Four haem groups (made of N,C, and H atoms) bind to iron (II) in a square planar fashion via a coordinate bond from nitrogens\xe2\x80\x99 lone pairs. Fifth bond is made from protein part (globin) to the iron (II) centre. Sixth site (this now adds up to the octahedral geometry) can be occupied by an oxygen molecule - one of the O\xe2\x80\x99s acts as a ligand. The process of O\xe2\x82\x82 binding is reversible. On the other hand, the process of binding CO is irreversible - that\xe2\x80\x99s why the carbon monoxide is dangerous. CO can easily replace O\xe2\x82\x82 at the iron (II) site via a ligand exchange reaction.

These are long calculations that use acid-base calculations. There are two types:Acid + Base - Find the number of moles of each species.- Calculate their concentration when at equilibrium using the total volume.- Use Ka to find [H+] and therefore pH.Acid + Salt- Find the moles of the salt.- Use Ka to find pH.
A Br\xc3\xb8nsted-Lowry acid is a proton donor. For example, ammonium ions (NH\xe2\x82\x84\xe2\x81\xba).
A Br\xc3\xb8nsted-Lowry base is a proton acceptor. For example, hydroxide ions (OH\xe2\x81\xbb).
A conjugate acid is the species formed when a base accepts a proton.
A conjugate base is the species formed when an acid donates a proton.
Acid strength doesn\xe2\x80\x99t refer to the concentration of a solution. A strong acid is defined as being:An acid that completely dissociates to ions when in solution with pH 0-1.

pH is a measure of acidity and alkalinity. It is a logarithmic scale from 0 to 14 that gives the concentration of H\xe2\x81\xba ions in a solution. 0 is an acidic solution with a high concentration of H\xe2\x81\xba ions whereas 14 is a basic solution with a low concentration of H\xe2\x81\xba ions. The pH can be calculated using the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H\xe2\x81\xba], as follows:pH = - log\xe2\x82\x81\xe2\x82\x80[H\xe2\x81\xba]
Weak acids and bases only slightly dissociate in solution to form an equilibrium mixture.Therefore, the reaction has an equilibrium dissociation constant, K\xe2\x82\x90.
Proton Donor
Proton Acceptor

cards.term: Complete the sentence:Acid-base reaction involve the transfer of _______.
cards.definition: Protons

cards.term: What ion causes a solution to be acidic? (2 answers) Name and formula.
cards.definition: H\xe2\x81\xba (hydrogen ion) or, more accurately, H\xe2\x82\x83O\xe2\x81\xba (oxonium ion), as protons react with H\xe2\x82\x82O to form it.

cards.term: What ion causes a solution to be alkaline?
cards.definition: \xe2\x81\xbbOH (Hydroxide Ion)

cards.term: Write an equation for the ionisation of water.
cards.definition: 2H\xe2\x82\x82O (l) \xe2\x87\x8c H\xe2\x82\x83O\xe2\x81\xba (aq) + \xe2\x81\xbbOH (aq)OR H\xe2\x82\x82O (l) \xe2\x87\x8c H\xe2\x81\xba (aq) +\xe2\x81\xbbOH (aq)

cards.term: What is the value of Kw at 298 K?
cards.definition: 1.0 x 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb4

cards.term: What physical factors affect the value of Kw? How do they affect it?
cards.definition: Temperature only - if temperature is increased, the equilibrium moves to the right so Kw increases and the pH of pure water decreases.
Sometimes pKw is used instead of Kw to make numbers more manageable.pKw = -log KwKw = 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe1\xb5\x96\xe1\xb4\xb7\xca\xb7

cards.term: Why is pure water still neutral, even if pH does not equal 7?
cards.definition: [H\xe2\x81\xba] = [\xe2\x81\xbbOH]

cards.term: Give an expression for pH in terms of H\xe2\x81\xba.
cards.definition: pH = -log\xe2\x82\x81\xe2\x82\x80[H\xe2\x81\xba]

cards.term: What is the relationship between pH and concentration of H\xe2\x81\xba?
cards.definition: Lower pH = Hgher concentration of H\xe2\x81\xba

cards.term: If two solutions have a pH difference of 1, what is the difference in [H\xe2\x81\xba]?
cards.definition: A factor of 10.

cards.term: How do you find [H\xe2\x81\xba] from pH?
cards.definition: [H\xe2\x81\xba] = 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe1\xb5\x96\xca\xb0

cards.term: What is different when finding [H\xe2\x81\xba] from the concentration of diprotic and triprotic acids?
cards.definition: Need to multiply the concentration of the acid by the number of protons to find [H\xe2\x81\xba].

cards.term: How do you calculate the pH of a strong alkaline solution?
cards.definition: Use Kw to calculate [H\xe2\x81\xba] from [OH\xe2\x81\xbb]Use pH=-log[H\xe2\x81\xba]
One which fully dissociates in water ( HX \xe2\x86\x92 H\xe2\x81\xba + X\xe2\x81\xbb).

cards.term: How do you calculate the pH of a strong acid?
cards.definition: pH = -log[H\xe2\x81\xba]
One which fully dissociates in water (XOH \xe2\x86\x92 X\xe2\x81\xba + \xe2\x81\xbbOH).

cards.term: What is the difference between concentrated and strong?
cards.definition: Concentrated means many mol per dm\xc2\xb3, strong refers to amount of dissociation.

cards.term: What is a weak acid and a weak base?
cards.definition: Weak acids and bases do not fully dissociate in water. They only partially dissociate into their ions.

cards.term: Give some examples of strong acids.
cards.definition: HCl, H\xe2\x82\x82SO\xe2\x82\x84, H\xe2\x82\x83PO\xe2\x82\x84

cards.term: Give some examples of strong bases.
cards.definition: NaOH, CaCO\xe2\x82\x83, Na\xe2\x82\x82CO\xe2\x82\x83

cards.term: Give some examples of weak acids.
cards.definition: CH\xe2\x82\x83COOH (ethanoic),any organic acid.

cards.term: Give some examples of weak bases.
cards.definition: NH\xe2\x82\x83

cards.term: How would you work out the pH of a weak acid?
cards.definition: Use the equation for K\xe2\x82\x90, subbing in values for [A\xe2\x81\xbb] and [HA].Use pH=-log[H\xe2\x81\xba] equation to find pH.
pKa is sometimes used to make Ka values more manageable.pKa = -log KaKa = 10-pKa
The addition of an acid/base of know titration to a base/acid of unknown titration to determine the concentration. An indicator is used to show that neutralisation has occurred, as is a pH meter.
The point at which the exact volume of base has been added to just neutralise the acid, or vice-versa.

cards.term: What generally happens to the pH of the solution around the equivalence point?
cards.definition: There is a large and rapid change in pH, except in the weak-weak titration.

cards.term: How would you calculate the concentration of a reactant if you know the volume and conc of the other reactant and the volume of that reactant added.
cards.definition: Calculate mols of one reactant use balanced equation to work out mols of the other.Use conc = mol/vol to calculate concentration.
The volume of acid or alkali added when the indicator just changes colour. If the right indicator is chosen, equivalence point = end point.

cards.term: What are the properties of a good indicator for a reaction?
cards.definition: Sharp colour change (not gradual) - no more than one drop of acid/alkali needed for colour change.End point must be the same as the equivalence point, or titration gives wrong answer.Distinct colour change so it is obvious when the end point has been reached.

cards.term: What indicator would you use for a strong acid-strong base titration?
cards.definition: Phenolphthalein or methyl orange, but phenolphthalein is usually used as clearer colour change.

cards.term: What indicator would you use for a strong acid-weak base titration?
cards.definition: Methyl Orange

cards.term: What indicator would you use for a strong base-weak acid titration?
cards.definition: Phenolphthalein

cards.term: What indicator would you use from a weak acid-weak base titration?
cards.definition: Neither methyl orange or phenolphthalein is suitable, as neither give a sharp change at the end point.

cards.term: What colour is methyl orange in acid? In alkali? At what pH does it change?
cards.definition: Red in acid; yellow in alkali. Changes at about pH = 4-5. Approx same as pK\xe2\x82\x90 value.

cards.term: What colour is phenolphthalein in acid? In alkali? At what pH does it change?
cards.definition: Colourless in acid; red in alkali. Changes at about pH = 9-10. Approx same as pK\xe2\x82\x90 value.
When volume = half the volume that has been added at the equivalence point
A solution that resist changes in pH when small amount of acid/alkali are added.

cards.term: What do acidic buffer solutions contain in general terms?
cards.definition: A weak acid and a soluble salt of that acid that fully dissociates.

cards.term: Write a reaction for anacid ic buffer with added acid.
cards.definition: A\xe2\x81\xbb + H\xe2\x81\xba \xe2\x86\x92 HA, opposes addition of H\xe2\x81\xba

cards.term: Write a reaction for an acidic buffer with added alkali.
cards.definition: HA + OH\xe2\x81\xbb \xe2\x86\x92 H\xe2\x82\x82O + A\xe2\x81\xbb

cards.term: How else can you achieve an acidic buffer solution other than just mixing the constituents?
cards.definition: Neutralise half of a weak acid (meaning the acid must be in excess) with an alkali - this forms a weak acid / soluble salt mixture.

cards.term: What do basic buffer solutions contain in general terms?
cards.definition: Weak base and soluble salt of that weak base.

cards.term: How can you calculate the pH of buffer solutions?
cards.definition: Use the K\xe2\x82\x90 of the weak acid, sub in [A\xe2\x81\xbb and [HA], calculate [H\xe2\x81\xba] \xe2\x86\x92 pH.

cards.term: How can you calculate the new pH of a buffer solution when acid or base is added?
cards.definition: Calculate number of moles of H\xe2\x81\xba and A - and HA before acid or base is added. Use equations to work out new moles of A\xe2\x81\xbb and HA \xe2\x86\x92 find [H\xe2\x81\xba] \xe2\x86\x92 pH.

cards.term: Which buffer system maintains blood pH at 7.4? What happens when acid/alkali is added?
cards.definition: H\xe2\x81\xba + HCO\xe2\x82\x83\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xbb \xe2\x87\x8c CO\xe2\x82\x82 + H\xe2\x82\x82OAdd OH\xe2\x81\xbb \xe2\x86\x92 reacts with H\xe2\x81\xba to form H\xe2\x82\x82O, then shifts equilibrium left to restore H\xe2\x81\xba lost Add H\xe2\x81\xba \xe2\x86\x92 equilibrium shifts to the right, removing excess H\xe2\x81\xba

cards.term: What products are buffers found in?
cards.definition: Shampoos, detergents \xe2\x86\x92 important to keep pH right to avoid damage to skin, hair, fabrics.

cards.term: Why is there a difference in enthalpy changes of neutralisation values for strong and weak acids?
cards.definition: Enthalpy changes of neutralisation are always exothermic. The value for this enthalpy change is similar for strong acids and alkalis because the same reaction is occurring H\xe2\x81\xba + OH\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x86\x92 H\xe2\x82\x82O.Weak acids have a less exothermic enthalpy change of neutralisation because energy is absorbed to ionise the acid and break the bond to the hydrogen in the un-dissociated acid.
A proton donor, e.g. CH\xe2\x82\x83COOH + H\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x81\xba \xe2\x87\x8c H\xe2\x82\x83O+ + CH\xe2\x82\x83COO\xe2\x81\xbb.
A proton acceptor, e.g. C\xe2\x82\x86H\xe2\x82\x85NH\xe2\x82\x82 + H\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x81\xba \xe2\x87\x8c C\xe2\x82\x86H\xe2\x82\x85NH\xe2\x82\x83\xe2\x81\xba + OH\xe2\x81\xbb.

Two species that differ by H\xe2\x81\xba. We can have an acid and its conjugate base (e.g. H\xe2\x82\x83O\xe2\x81\xba and H\xe2\x82\x82O), or a base and its conjugate acid (e.g. NH\xe2\x82\x83, NH4\xe2\x81\xba).

A figure expressing the acidity or alkalinity of a solution on a logarithmic scale on which 7 is neutral, lower values are more acidic and higher values more alkaline.H = \xe2\x88\x92log\xe2\x82\x81\xe2\x82\x80 [H\xe2\x81\xba]
The acidic dissociation constant, Ka = ([H\xe2\x81\xba][A\xe2\x81\xbb])/[HA]. Taking the negative logarithm and rearranging for pH gives: pH = pKa + log([A\xe2\x81\xbb]/[HA]).
\xe2\x88\x92log\xe2\x82\x81\xe2\x82\x80[Ka], the lower the value, the stronger the acid (as equilibrium is shifted more towards ionised products).
The ionic product of water, Kw = [H\xe2\x81\xba][OH\xe2\x81\xbb], at 298 K, Kw = 1.0 x 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb4 mol\xc2\xb2\xe2\x8b\x85dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb6.
\xe2\x88\x92log\xe2\x82\x81\xe2\x82\x80[Kw], and so pH + pOH = 14 at 298 K.
Electron pair acceptor.

Electron pair donor.e.g. NH\xe2\x82\x83 (Lewis base, donates a free electron pair) + BH\xe2\x82\x83 (Lewis acid, has no electron pairs, accepts an electron pair from ammonia) \xe2\x86\x92 H\xe2\x82\x83N---BH\xe2\x82\x83
Acid which completely dissociates in water. e.g. HCl \xe2\x86\x92 H\xe2\x81\xba + Cl\xe2\x81\xbb
Base which completely dissociates in water. e.g. NaOH \xe2\x86\x92 Na\xe2\x81\xba + OH\xe2\x81\xbb
Acid which dissociates only slightly in water (reversible reaction). e.g. HCN \xe2\x87\x8c H\xe2\x81\xba + CN\xe2\x81\xbb
Base which is only slightly protonated in water (reversible reaction). e.g. NH\xe2\x82\x83 + H\xe2\x82\x82O \xe2\x87\x8c NH\xe2\x82\x84\xe2\x81\xba + OH\xe2\x81\xbb

Can be calculated from the Ka. We define Ka as:Ka = ([H\xe2\x81\xba][A\xe2\x81\xbb])/[HA]Then, if the H+ produced by dissociation of water |(H2O \xe2\x87\x8c H\xe2\x81\xba + OH\xe2\x81\xbb) are negligible, we can assume:[H\xe2\x81\xba] = [A\xe2\x81\xbb].In addition, we can postulate that the acid is weak, so the concentration of undissociated acid molecules, [HA], will be approximately the same as the initial acid concentration, c. These two assumptions lead to:Ka = [H+]\xc2\xb2/cfrom this, [H\xe2\x81\xba] = (Ka x c)\xe2\x81\xb0.\xe2\x81\xb5And pH = \xe2\x88\x920.5log(Ka x c).

Refers to a substance that can act as an acid or a base, e.g. HCO\xe2\x82\x83\xe2\x81\xbb; it can accept a proton and form H\xe2\x82\x82O and CO\xe2\x82\x82, or donate a proton and form CO\xe2\x82\x83\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb.
Can release only one H\xe2\x81\xba upon dissociation, e.g. HCl.
Can release more than one H\xe2\x81\xba upon dissociation, e.g. H\xe2\x82\x82SO\xe2\x82\x84.
The point when full neutralisation occurs, e.g. when titrating an acid with a base, it is the point when all acid has been neutralised, and so [H\xe2\x81\xba]=[OH\xe2\x81\xbb].

The point during the titration when the indicator changes the colour. A suitable indicator should change colour near the equivalence point (so should have a pH range within the pH change during the equivalence point).
A solution which resists change in pH when small amounts of strong acid/base are added.
A buffer containing a weak acid and its conjugate base, e.g. a solution of acetic acid and sodium acetate.
A buffer containing a weak base and its conjugate acid, e.g. a solution of ammonia and ammonium chloride.

E.g. when preparing an acetate buffer (CH\xe2\x82\x83COOH/CH\xe2\x82\x83COONa), one can either add a suitable amount of salt to the suitable solution of the acid, or react an acid with a strong base as a limiting reagent.
Reversible reactions are reactions in which the products of a reaction can react together to reform the original reactants. They are represented using a double arrow.

Le Chatelier\xe2\x80\x99s principle is used to predict how an equilibrium mixture will change if the reaction conditions are altered.It states:When a system is subject to change, the system will alter to lessen the effect of that change.

Increasing temperature favours the endothermic reaction (+ve \xe2\x88\x86H) as the excess heat needs to be removed from the system to lessen the effect of the initial increase. It will increase the yield of the endothermic products.

Increasing pressure favours the side of the reaction with fewer moles of gas, as this will help to release the built up in pressure. It will increase the yield of the products on the side of the reaction with the fewest moles of gas.Likewise, decreasing pressure favours the side of the reaction with more moles as pressure has been lost. The yield of the products on this side of the reaction will be increased.

Increasing the concentration of the reactants will favour the reaction direction that produces the products as more molecules are available to react. It will increase the yield of the products.Likewise, decreasing the concentration of products will favour the reaction that reforms the reactants.
Catalysts appear not to affect the equilibrium position as they affect the forward and backward reaction equally. However, they do allow equilibrium to be reached faster.
The rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction. (Hence, the concentrations of reactants and products do not change.)

cards.term: Give an essential condition for an equilibrium mixture.
cards.definition: Equilibrium occurs in a closed system where reactants and products cannot escape. Or, macroscopic properties do not change with time.
If a system at equilibrium is altered, the position of equilibrium moves in the direction that reduces the effect of the initial change.

cards.term: What effect does a catalyst have on the position of equilibrium?
cards.definition: No effect. (This is because a catalyst affects rate of forward and reverse reactions equally rsulting in no overall effect.)

cards.term: What type of system is K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8 relevant for?
cards.definition: Homogeneous systems in equilibrium.

cards.term: What does K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8 being greater or less than 1 suggest for the position of equilibrium?
cards.definition: Greater than 1 = shifted to the rightLesser than 1 = shifted to the left

cards.term: What effect does decreasing the temperature in an endothermic reaction have on K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8?
cards.definition: K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8 decreases (The endothermic reaction isn\xe2\x80\x99t favoured so equilibrium shifts to the left.)

cards.term: What effect does increasing the temperature in an endothermic reaction have on K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8?
cards.definition: K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8 increases (The endothermic reaction is favoured so equilibrium shifts to the right.)

cards.term: What effect does decreasing the temperature in an exothermic reaction have on K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8?
cards.definition: K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8 increases (The exothermic reaction is favoured so equilibrium shifts to the right.)

cards.term: What effect does increasing the temperature in an exothermic reaction have on K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8?
cards.definition: K\xf0\x9d\x92\xb8 decreases (The exothermic reaction isn\xe2\x80\x99t favoured so equilibrium shifts to the left.)
Each gas\xe2\x80\x99s contribution to the total pressure.

cards.term: How would you calculate the partial pressure of a gas?
cards.definition: Partial pressure p = Mole fraction x Total pressure
Mole fraction of gas X = number of moles of gas X in the mixture \xc3\xb7 total number of moles of gas in the mixture.

cards.term: How do you calculate the units for Kp and Kc?
cards.definition: Write out the units for the partial pressures/ concentrations in the same arrangement as the Kp/Kc equation and cancel out/multiply together.For Kp usually in Pa, kPa, atm etc. DO NOT CHANGE UNITSFor Kc units for concentration is mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on Kp/Kc for an endothermic reaction?
cards.definition: Equilibrium shifts to the right, so partial pressures of products increase, so Kp increases.

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on Kp/Kc for an exothermic reaction?
cards.definition: Equilibrium shifts to the left, so partial pressures/concentration of reactants increase, so Kp decreases.

cards.term: What will be the kinetic effect of increasing the temperature and pressure for any reaction?
cards.definition: Increasing both will increase the rate of reaction as:Temperature - many more particles have energy greater than or equal to the activation energy \xe2\x86\x92 more successful collisions per secondPressure - more particles in the same volume \xe2\x86\x92 more successful collisions per second.

cards.term: What is the effect of changing concentration or pressure or by the addition of a catalyst on the  value of equilibrium constant?
cards.definition: There is no effect.
A system, where all the chemicals are in the same phase.
A system, where not all the chemicals are in the same phase.

If there\xe2\x80\x99s a small change in concentration, pressure/volume or temperature (disruption to equilibrium) to a closed system in dynamic equilibrium, the equilibrium will shift to minimise the change (to restore the equilibrium).
A method of production of H\xe2\x82\x82SO\xe2\x82\x84. The key step involves the conversion of SO\xe2\x82\x82 to SO\xe2\x82\x83 in presence of oxygen, catalysed by V\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x85.

Kc is equal to the concentration of the products divided by the concentration of the reactants. The concentration terms are raised to a power of the same value as the number of moles of that substance.

Kp is the equilibrium constant used for gaseous equilibria. Kp is calculated from gaseous reactants and products. If all reactants and products are in the gaseous state, the system is said to be homogeneous.

Within a gaseous system, each gas has a partial pressure. The partial pressures add up to give the total system pressure. This partial pressure of a substance is found using the molar fraction of that substance and the total pressure of the system.

Partial pressures allow the value of Kp for a gaseous equilibrium to be found. Kp is equal to the product of the partial pressures of products over the product of the partial pressure of reactants. It is similar to Kc in that any variation in moles raises the partial pressure to a power of equal quantity to the number of moles.
Similarly to Kc, the gaseous equilibrium constant, Kp, can be found for both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions.
The rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction. (Hence, the concentrations of reactants and products do not change.)

cards.term: Give an essential condition for an equilibrium mixture.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Equilibrium occurs in a closed system where reactants and products cannot escape.OR\xe2\x97\x8f Macroscopic properties do not change with time.
If a system at equilibrium is altered, the position of equilibrium moves in the direction that reduces the effect of the initial change.

cards.term: What effect does a catalyst have on the position of equilibrium?
cards.definition: No effect. (This is because a catalyst affects rate of forward and reverse reactions equally rsulting in no overall effect.)

cards.term: What condition affects the value of Kc?a. Concentrationb. Catalystc. Pressured. Temperature
cards.definition: d. Temperature

cards.term: For the reaction below, deduce an expression for Kc.
Deduce units for the value of Kc.
cards.definition: mol\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x8b\x85dm\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What type of system is  Kc relevant for?
cards.definition: Homogeneous systems in equilibrium.

cards.term: What does Kc being greater or less than 1 suggest for the position of equilibrium?
cards.definition: Greater than 1 = Shifted to the rightLesser than 1 = Shifted to the left

cards.term: What effect does decreasing the temperature in an endothermic reaction have on Kc?
cards.definition: Kc decreases (The endothermic reaction isn\xe2\x80\x99t favoured so equilibrium shifts to the left.)

cards.term: What effect does increasing the temperature in an endothermic reaction have on Kc?
cards.definition: Kc increases (The endothermic reaction is favoured so equilibrium shifts to the right.)

cards.term: What effect does decreasing the temperature in an exothermic reaction have on Kc?
cards.definition: Kc increases (The exothermic reaction is favoured so equilibrium shifts to the right.)

cards.term: What effect does increasing the temperature in an exothermic reaction have on Kc?
cards.definition: Kc decreases (The exothermic reaction isn\xe2\x80\x99t favoured so equilibrium shifts to the left.)
Each gas\xe2\x80\x99s contribution to the total pressure.

cards.term: How would you calculate the partial pressure of a gas?
cards.definition: Partial pressure p = Mole fraction x Total pressure
Mole fraction of gas X = Number of moles of gas X in themixture \xc3\xb7 Total number of moles of gas in the mixture

cards.term: How do you calculate the units for Kp and Kc?
cards.definition: Write out the units for the partial pressures/ concentrations in the same arrangement as the Kp/Kc equation and cancel out/multiply together.For Kp usually in Pa, kPa, atm etc. DO NOT CHANGE UNITSFor Kc units for concentration is mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on Kp/Kc for an endothermic reaction?
cards.definition: Equilibrium shifts to the right, so partial pressures of products increase, so Kp increases.

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on Kp/Kc for an exothermic reaction?
cards.definition: Equilibrium shifts to the left, so partial pressures/concentration of reactants increase, so Kp decreases.

cards.term: What will be the kinetic effect of increasing the temperature and pressure for any reaction?
cards.definition: Increasing both will increase the rate of reaction as:Temperature - many more particles have energy greater thanor equal to the activation energy \xe2\x86\x92 more successful collisionsper second.Pressure - more particles in the same volume \xe2\x86\x92 more successful collisions per second.

cards.term: What is the effect of changing concentration or pressure or by the addition of a catalyst on the value of equilibrium constant?
cards.definition: There is no effect.
Number of moles of particular gas / Total number of moles of all gases in the mixture.
The pressure exerted by a particular gas in a mixture in a closed system. Relation to mole fraction: Mole fraction x Total pressure = Partial pressure.
Sum of all partial pressures.

The important point to note is that the values appearing in the reaction quotient may not be the values corresponding to the system in equilibrium. Only at equilibrium is the reaction quotient the same as the equilibrium constant.

Enthalpy change is heat energy change and is represented by the symbol \xe2\x88\x86H\xc2\xb0. Enthalpy is measured under standard conditions of 100 kPa pressure and a specified temperature, generally 298 K.
The enthalpy change when quantities of substances in standard states react completely under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of a substance is produced from its elements under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of a substance is burned completely in oxygen under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when solutions of acid and alkali react together under standard conditions to produce one mole of water.

cards.term: What does system mean in a chemical reaction?
cards.definition: The atoms and bonds involved in the chemical reaction.
The amount of energy in an isolated system remains the same. Energy cannot be destroyed or created, It can only be transferred from one form to another.

cards.term: What energy change is breaking bonds associated with?
cards.definition: Energy is taken in to break bonds \xe2\x86\x92 endothermic reaction.

cards.term: What energy change is making bonds associated with?
cards.definition: Energy is released to make bonds \xe2\x86\x92 exothermic reaction.
A reaction with an overall positive enthalpy change (+\xce\x94H) \xe2\x86\x92 enthalpy of products > enthalpy of reactants.
A reaction with an overall negative enthalpy change (-\xce\x94H) \xe2\x86\x92 enthalpy of products < enthalpy of reactants.
The minimum energy required for a reaction to take place.

cards.term: Which way does the arrow for activation energy point on an enthalpy profile diagram?
cards.definition: Always points upwards.
100 kPa298 K
The state an element / compound exists at in standard conditions (100 kPa, 298 K).
The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of a compound is formed from its constituent elements in their standard state under standard conditions.

cards.term: Give an example of an equation which represents standard enthalpy of formation.
cards.definition: There are many e.g. H\xe2\x82\x82 (g) + \xc2\xbd O\xe2\x82\x82 (g) \xe2\x86\x92 H\xe2\x82\x82O (l)
The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of a substance is completely combusted.

cards.term: Give an example of an equation which represents standard enthalpy of combustion.

cards.definition: The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of water is formed from a neutralisation reaction.

cards.term: What does enthalpy change of reaction mean?
cards.definition: The energy change associated with a given reaction.

cards.term: How can you calculate enthalpy change from experimental data?
cards.definition: Use the equation Q = mc\xce\x94T, where m is the mass of the substance being heated (usually water), c is the specific heat capacity of that substance (water\xe2\x80\x99s SHC = 4.18 J\xe2\x8b\x85g^-1\xe2\x8b\x85K^-1) and \xce\x94T is the change in temperature.

cards.term: Why might experimental methods for enthalpy determination not be accurate?
cards.definition: 1. Heat is lost to the surroundings2. Not in standard conditions3. Reaction may not go to completion

cards.term: What does average bond enthalpy mean?
cards.definition: The mean energy required to break 1 mole of bonds in gaseous molecules.

cards.term: Why will using bond enthalpies not be as accurate as using standard enthalpy of combustion/formation?
cards.definition: Bond enthalpies are a mean for the same bond across different molecules whereas standard enthalpy of combustion and formation apply just to that molecule, therefore they are more accurate.

cards.term: How to calculate enthalpy change of reaction using average bond enthalpies?
cards.definition: \xce\x94H = \xce\xa3 (bond enthalpies of reaction) - \xce\xa3 (bond enthalpies of products)
States that the enthalpy change for a reaction is the same regardless of the route taken.
The enthalpy change for a reaction is independent of the route taken.
Enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous atoms is formed from a compound in its standard state in standard conditions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is removed from one mole of gaseous atoms to form one mole of gaseous 1+ ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is removed from one mole of gaseous 1+ ions to form one mole of gaseous 2+ ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous atoms gains one mole of electrons to form one mole of gaseous 1- ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous 1- ions gains one mole of electrons to form one mole of gaseous 2- ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of solid ionic lattice is formed from its constituent gaseous ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous ions become hydrated/dissolved in water to infinite dilution [water molecules totally surround the ion].
Enthalpy change when one mole of solute dissolves completely in a solvent to infinite dilution.
Enthalpy change when one mole of (a certain type of) covalent bonds is broken, with all species in the gaseous state.

cards.term: Write example equations for:Standard enthalpy of formationStandard enthalpy of combustionStandard enthalpy of atomisationFirst ionisation energySecond ionisation energyFirst electron affinity

cards.definition: Second electron affinity: O\xe2\x81\xbb (g) + e\xe2\x81\xbb \xe2\x86\x92 O\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb (g)Lattice enthalpy of formation: Na\xe2\x81\xba (g) + Cl\xe2\x81\xbb (g) \xe2\x86\x92 NaCl (s)Lattice enthalpy of dissociation: NaCl (s) \xe2\x86\x92 Na\xe2\x81\xba (g) + Cl\xe2\x81\xbb (g)Enthalpy of hydration: Na\xe2\x81\xba (g) \xe2\x86\x92 Na\xe2\x81\xba (aq)Enthalpy of solution: NaCl (s) \xe2\x86\x92 Na\xe2\x81\xba (aq) + Cl\xe2\x81\xbb (aq)Mean bond dissociation enthalpy: Br\xe2\x82\x82 (g) \xe2\x86\x92 2Br (g)
Thermochemical cycle showing all the enthalpy changes involved in the formation of an ionic compound. Start with elements in their standard states (enthalpy of 0).

cards.term: What factors affect the lattice enthalpy of an ionic compound?
cards.definition: Size of the ions, charge on the ions.

cards.term: How can you increase the lattice enthalpy of a compound? Why does this increase it?
cards.definition: Smaller ions, since the charge centres will be closer together.Increased charge, since there will be a greater electrostatic force of attraction between the oppositely charged ions. N.B. Increasing the charge on the anion has a much smaller effect than increasing the charge on the cation, since increasing anion charge also has the effect of increasing ionic size.

cards.term: How can Born-Haber cycles be used to see if compounds could theoretically exist?
cards.definition: Use known data to predict certain values of theoretical compounds, and then see if these compounds would be thermodynamically stable. Was used to predict the existence of the first noble gas containing compound.

cards.term: What actually happens when a solid is dissolved in terms of interactions of the ions with water molecules?
cards.definition: Break lattice \xe2\x86\x92 gaseous ions; dissolve each gaseous ion in water. The aqueous ions are surrounded by water molecules(which have a permanent dipole due to polar O-H bond).

cards.term: What is the perfect ionic model?
cards.definition: Assumes that ions are perfectly spherical and that there is an even charge distribution (100% polar bonds). Act as point charges.

cards.term: Why is the perfect ionic model often not accurate?
cards.definition: Ions are not perfectly spherical. Polarisation often occurs when small positive ions or large negative ions are involved, so the ionic bond gains covalent character. Some lattices are not regular and the crystal structure can differ.

cards.term: Which kind of bonds will be the most ionic? Why?
cards.definition: Between large positive ions and small negative ions, e.g. CsF.

cards.term: Define the terms spontaneous and feasible.
cards.definition: If a reaction is spontaneous and feasible, it will take place of its own accord; does not take account of rate of reaction.

cards.term: Is a reaction with a positive or negative enthalpy change more likely to be spontaneous?
cards.definition: Negative - Exothermic
A measure of the dispersal of energy in a system which is greater when the system is more disordered.

cards.term: What is the symbol of entropy?
cards.definition: S

cards.term: Solid or gas, which is more disordered?
cards.definition: Gas

cards.term: What is the unit of standard entropy?
cards.definition: J \xe2\x80\xa2 K\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 \xe2\x80\xa2 mol\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9
Greater the temperature, particles have more energy and move more. Thus the arrangement of particles become more randon. More random arrangement = higher entropy.

cards.term: When a solid ionic lattice is dissolved in solution what happens to entropy?
cards.definition: Entropy increases because the ions are more disordered.

cards.term: How does change in number of gas molecules in a reaction affect entropy?
cards.definition: Increase in number of gas molecules = increase in entropyDecrease in number of gas molecules = decrease in entropy

cards.term: Write the Gibbs\xe2\x80\x99 free energy equation.
cards.definition: \xce\x94G = \xce\x94H - T\xce\x94S

cards.term: What units is entropy measured in?
cards.definition: J \xe2\x80\xa2 K\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 \xe2\x80\xa2 mol\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is the second law of thermodynamics?
cards.definition: Entropy (of an isolated system) always increases, as it is overwhelmingly more likely for molecules to be disordered than ordered.

cards.term: What does the value for Gibbs free energy for a reaction show?
cards.definition: If G < 0, reaction is feasible. If G = 0, reaction is JUST feasible. If G > 0, reaction is not feasible.

cards.term: What is the significance of the temperature at which G = 0?
cards.definition: This is the temperature (in Kelvin) at which the reaction becomes feasible.

cards.term: How would you calculate the temperature at which a reaction becomes feasible?
cards.definition: Rearrange to T = (\xce\x94H)/(\xce\x94S) since G = 0

cards.term: What are the limitations of using G as an indicator of whether a reaction will occur?
cards.definition: Gibbs free energy only indicates if a reaction is feasible. It does not take into account the rate of reaction (the kinetics of the reaction). In reality, many reactions that are feasible at a certain temperature have a rate of reaction that is so slow that effectively no reaction is occurring.

cards.term: What is another equation for Gibbs free energy?
cards.definition: \xce\x94G = \xe2\x88\x92RT ln K

cards.term: Why is entropy zero at 0 K?
cards.definition: No disorder - molecules/atoms are not moving or vibrating and cannot be arranged in any other way. Maximum possible state of order.

cards.term: What are the two key things to look out for to decide if entropy increases/decreases/stays relatively constant?
cards.definition: Number of moles - more moles made \xe2\x86\x92 increase in entropyGoing from solid \xe2\x86\x92 liquid/gas or liquid \xe2\x86\x92 gas

cards.term: How is it possible for the temperature of a substance undergoing an endothermic reaction to stay constant?
cards.definition: The heat that is given out escapes to the surroundings.
Heat energy change in a reaction at constant pressure (kJ\xe2\x80\xa2mol\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9).
100 kPa, 298 K, 1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 concentrations of ions.
Heat given off; \xe2\x81\xbbve value of enthalpy change.
Heat absorbed; +ve value of enthalpy change.
Enthalpy change when reaction occurs in the molar quantities shown in the chemical equation under standard conditions.
Enthalpy change when 1 mole of a compound is formed from its elements in their standard states under standard conditions.
Enthalpy change when 1 mole of a substance is completely burned in oxygen under standard conditions.
Enthalpy change when an acid and alkali react together under standard conditions to form 1 mole of water.
Heat change Q = mC\xce\x94Twhere:m = mass, C = specific heat capacity, \xce\x94T = change in temperature.
The amount of energy needed to raise a temperature of 1 g of a substance by 1 degree.
The total enthalpy change is independent of the reaction pathway taken.

Amount of energy required to break 1 mole of the stated bond in the gas phase. In terms of bond enthalpies:Enthalpy Change of reaction = Sum of bond enthalpies of reactants \xe2\x80\x93 Sum of bond enthalpies of products.
Average amount of energy needed to break a specific type of bond, measured over a variety of different molecules.
Lattice enthalpies are used for ionic substances.

Lattice dissociation enthalpy is an endothermic process and is defined as:The enthalpy change when one mole of a solid ionic compound is completely dissociated into its gaseous constituent ions under standard conditions.

Lattice formation enthalpy is an exothermic process and is defined as:The enthalpy change when one mole of a solid ionic compound is formed from its gaseous constituent ions under standard conditions.
Atomisation enthalpy is defined as:The energy required for the formation of one mole of gaseous atoms from an element under standard conditions.
Enthalpy of electron affinity is defined as:The enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is added to a mole of gaseous atoms to form one mole of gaseous 1- ions under standard conditions.
Born-Haber cycles are similar to the cycles used with Hess\xe2\x80\x99s Law. They allow enthalpy changes to be determined which cannot be measured directly.
The enthalpy change when one mole of ionic solid is dissolved in water to infinite dilution so that the ions no longer interact under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous ions I dissolved in water to form one mole of aqueous ions under standard conditions.

Gibbs free-energy quantifies the balance between entropy and enthalpy in a system, acting as an indicator of reaction feasibility. It also allows \xe2\x88\x86S to be found without needing to measure the effects on the surroundings:\xe2\x88\x86G = \xe2\x88\x86H - T\xe2\x88\x86S\xe2\x82\x9by\xe2\x82\x9b\xe2\x82\x9c\xe2\x82\x91\xe2\x82\x98

cards.term: What does system mean in a chemical reaction?
cards.definition: The atoms and bonds involved in the chemical reaction.
The amount of energy in an isolated system remains the same. Energy cannot be destroyed or created, it can only be transferred from one form to another.

cards.term: What energy change is breaking bonds associated with?
cards.definition: Energy is taken in to break bonds \xe2\x86\x92 Endothermic reaction

cards.term: What energy change is making bonds associated with?
cards.definition: Energy is released to make bonds \xe2\x86\x92 Exothermic reaction
A reaction with an overall positive enthalpy change (+\xce\x94H) \xe2\x86\x92 Enthalpy of products > Enthalpy of reactants
A reaction with an overall negative enthalpy change (-\xce\x94H) \xe2\x86\x92 Enthalpy of products < Enthalpy of reactants
The minimum energy required for a reaction to take place.

cards.term: Which way does the arrow for activation energy point on an enthalpy profile diagram?
cards.definition: Always points upwards.
100 kPa298 K
The state an element / compound exists at in standard conditions (100 kPa, 298 K).
The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of a compound is formed from its constituent elements in their standard state under standard conditions.

cards.term: Give an example of an equation which represents standard enthalpy of formation.
cards.definition: There are many. e.g. H\xe2\x82\x82 (g) + \xc2\xbd O\xe2\x82\x82 (g) \xe2\x86\x92 H\xe2\x82\x82O (l)
The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of a substance is completely combusted.

cards.term: Give an example of an equation which represents standard enthalpy of combustion.

cards.definition: The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of water is formed from a neutralisation reaction.

cards.term: What does enthalpy change of reaction mean?
cards.definition: The energy change associated with a given reaction.

cards.term: How can you calculate enthalpy change from experimental data?
cards.definition: Use the equation Q = mc\xce\x94T, where m is the mass of the substance being heated (usually water), c is the specific heat capacity of that substance (water\xe2\x80\x99s SHC = 4.18 J\xe2\x8b\x85g\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x8b\x85K\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9) and \xce\x94T is the change in temperature.

cards.term: Why might experimental methods for enthalpy determination not be accurate?
cards.definition: 1. Heat is lost to the surroundings.2. Not in standard conditions.3. Reaction may not go to completion.

cards.term: What does average bond enthalpy mean?
cards.definition: The mean energy required to break 1 mole of bonds in gaseous molecules.

cards.term: Why will using bond enthalpies not be as accurate as using standard enthalpy of combustion/formation?
cards.definition: Bond enthalpies are a mean for the same bond across different molecules whereas standard enthalpy of combustion and formation apply just to that molecule, therefore they are more accurate.

cards.term: How to calculate enthalpy change of reaction using average bond enthalpies?
cards.definition: \xce\x94H = \xce\xa3 (bond enthalpies of reaction) - \xce\xa3 (bond enthalpies of products)
States that the enthalpy change for a reaction is the same regardless of the route taken.
The enthalpy change for a reaction is independent of the route taken.
Enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous atoms is formed from a compound in its standard state in standard conditions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is removed from one mole of gaseous atoms to form one mole of gaseous 1+ ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is removed from one mole of gaseous 1+ ions to form one mole of gaseous 2+ ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous atoms gains one mole of electrons to form one mole of gaseous 1- ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous 1- ions gains one mole of electrons to form one mole of gaseous 2- ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of solid ionic lattice is formed from its constituent gaseous ions.
Enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous ions become hydrated/dissolved in water to infinite dilution [water molecules totally surround the ion].
Enthalpy change when one mole of solute dissolves completely in a solvent to infinite dilution.
Enthalpy change when one mole of (a certain type of) covalent bonds is broken, with all species in the gaseous state.

cards.definition: Assumes that ions are perfectly spherical and that there is an even charge distribution (100% polar bonds). Act as point charges.

cards.term: Which kind of bonds will be the most ionic? Why?
cards.definition: Between large positive ions and small negative ions. e.g. CsF

cards.definition: If a reaction is spontaneous and feasible, it will take place of its own accord; does not take account of rate of reaction.

cards.definition: Negative - Exothermic

cards.definition: S

cards.definition: Gas.

cards.definition: Increase in number of gas molecules = Increase in entropy.Decrease in number of gas molecules = Decrease in entropy.

cards.term: Write the Gibbs\xe2\x80\x99 free energy equation.
cards.definition: \xce\x94G = \xce\x94H - T\xce\x94S

cards.term: What units is entropy measured in?
cards.definition: J\xe2\x80\xa2K\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x80\xa2mol\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is the second law of thermodynamics?
cards.definition: Entropy (of an isolated system) always increases, as it is overwhelmingly more likely for molecules to be disordered than ordered.

cards.term: What does the value for Gibbs free energy for a reaction show?
cards.definition: If G < 0, reaction is feasible. If G = 0, reaction is JUST feasible. If G > 0, reaction is not feasible.

cards.term: What is the significance of the temperature at which G = 0?
cards.definition: This is the temperature (in Kelvin) at which the reaction becomes feasible.

cards.term: How would you calculate the temperature at which a reaction becomes feasible?
cards.definition: Rearrange to T = (\xce\x94H)/(\xce\x94S) since G = 0
