cards.term: What is another equation for Gibbs free energy?
cards.definition: \xce\x94G = \xe2\x88\x92RT ln K

cards.term: Why is entropy zero at 0 K?
cards.definition: No disorder - molecules/atoms are not moving or vibrating and cannot be arranged in any other way. Maximum possible state of order.

cards.term: What are the two key things to look out for to decide if entropy increases/decreases/stays relatively constant?
cards.definition: Number of moles - more moles made \xe2\x86\x92 increase in entropyGoing from solid \xe2\x86\x92 liquid/gas or liquid \xe2\x86\x92 gas

cards.term: How is it possible for the temperature of a substance undergoing an endothermic reaction to stay constant?
cards.definition: The heat that is given out escapes to the surroundings.
Energy change when 1 mole of an ionic solid is formed from its constituent gaseous ions under standard conditions.
Enthalpy change when 1 mole of gaseous atoms is formed from the elements in its standard states. Always endothermic.
The enthalpy change that takes place when one electron is added to each atom in one mole of gaseous atoms to form one mole of gaseous 1- ions (could be asked for successive electron affinities).
The enthalpy change when 1 mole of a gaseous ion is completely dissolved in water under standard conditions.
Enthalpy change when 1 mole of ionic solid completely dissolves in water under standard conditions to form an infinitely dilute solution.

Distortion of a charge distribution, e.g. in covalently bonded HF, the bond is polarised towards fluorine, as fluorine is more electronegative than hydrogen. The consequence is the partial negative charge on fluorine and the partial positive charge on hydrogen. Similarly, in \xe2\x80\x9cionic\xe2\x80\x9d NaI, sodium cation is more charge dense than iodide anion (both have a charge of 1 +/-, but sodium is smaller) and hence will attract some of the electron density of iodide, thus disrupting the electron distribution; sodium cation polarises the iodide anion - this allows us to understand the covalent character of some molecules which display ionic bonding.

A measure of the disorder of a system. The units of entropy are J\xe2\x80\xa2K\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x80\xa2mol\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9. On molecular level, gases are more disordered than liquids, which are more disordered than solids (compare their structures). A reaction that produces the greater number of molecules than the number of reactants molecules will have a positive entropy change, as there will exist more random arrangements of these molecules, i.e. the system will become more disordered.

A measure of a feasibility of a chemical reaction. This is solely a thermodynamic understanding - it does not take into account the kinetics of a chemical reaction - remember that some thermodynamically feasible reactions may have a significant activation energy barrier!
The number of electrons an atom uses to bond with any other atom.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of an uncombined element such as C, H, O2?
What is the oxidation number of combined oxygen such as in H2O?
What is the oxidation number of oxygen in peroxides?
What is the oxidation number of combined hydrogen such as in NH3, H2S?
What is the oxidation number of combined hydrogen in metal hydrides such as LiH?
What is the oxidation number of a simple ion?
cards.definition: Charge on the ion.E.g Na + \xe2\x86\x92 +1; Cl - \xe2\x86\x92 -1

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of combined fluorine such as in NaF, CaF2?
When an element has more than one stable oxidation number how is it indicated?
cards.definition: Written as a Roman numeral.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of Fe in iron (III) chloride?

cards.definition: Negative ions that have an element along with oxygen.

cards.term: Define oxidation in terms of electron transfer and oxidation number.
cards.definition: Oxidation is:\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of electrons,\xe2\x97\x8f An increase in oxidation number.

cards.term: Define reduction in terms of electron transfer and oxidation number.
cards.definition: Reduction is:\xe2\x97\x8f Gain of electrons,\xe2\x97\x8f A decrease in oxidation number.
A reaction in which both oxidation and reduction takes place.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of a metal?
cards.definition: 0, because it is an uncombined element.
Species that gains electrons.
Species that lose electrons.

cards.term: What is the oxidation state of chlorine in NaClO?
cards.definition: [Cl] = +1 (Otherwise [Cl] = -1 in most other compounds. NaClO is formed in a disproportionation reaction.)
Where in a redox reaction, the oxidation states of atoms of the same element, increase for some atoms, whereas decrease for some atoms.

cards.term: What is the oxidation state of phosphorus in PCl5?
What is the oxidation state of nitrogen in ammonia?
What is the oxidation state of iron in K4Fe(CN)6?

cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f The loss of electrons or\xe2\x97\x8f Gain of Oxygen or\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of Hydrogen
\xe2\x97\x8f The gain of electrons or\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of Oxygen or\xe2\x97\x8f Gain of Hydrogen

cards.term: What is oxidation in terms of oxidation number?
cards.definition: Oxidation is an increase of oxidation number. E.g if the oxidation number of Cl goes from 0 to 1+ it has been oxidised.

cards.term: What is reduction in terms of oxidation number?
cards.definition: Reduction is a decrease in oxidation number. E.g if the oxidation number of F goes from 1- to 0 it has been reduced.

cards.term: What happens when a rod of a metal is dipped into a solution of its own ions?
cards.definition: An equilibrium is set up between the solid metal and the aqueous metal ions.

cards.term: What are the two methods to measure standard electrode potential (E\xc2\xb0)?
cards.definition: 1. Metals or non-metals in contact with their ions in aqueous solution.2. Ions of the same element with different oxidation numbers.

cards.term: What is the simplest salt bridge made of?
cards.definition: Filter paper soaked in a saturated solution of KNO3 (potassium nitrate).
They complete the circuit allowing a flow of charge through ion movement. They also contain inert ions so they don\xe2\x80\x99t react with the electrodes.

cards.term: What symbol is used to represent a salt bridge in standard notation?
cards.definition: II

cards.term: What type of species goes on the outside (furthest from the salt bridge) in standard cell notation?
cards.definition: The most reduced species.

cards.term: What does | indicate in standard cell notation?
cards.definition: Phase boundary (solid/liquid/gas).

cards.term: What happens at the left-hand electrode?
cards.definition: Oxidation occurs. The left-hand electrode is the half cell with the most negative E\xc2\xb0 value.

cards.term: What happens at the right-hand electrode?
cards.definition: Reduction occurs.The right-hand electrode is the half cell with the most positive E\xc2\xb0 value.

cards.term: Which side of the cell has the most negative E\xc2\xb0 value and what happens to the metal with the most negative E\xc2\xb0 value?
cards.definition: The left-hand electrode is most negative.The metal will be oxidised.

cards.term: What conditions are required to use the standard hydrogen electrode?
cards.definition: Temperature = 298 KPressure = 100 kPa[H + ] = 1.00 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm^-3

cards.term: What is the standard hydrogen electrode used for?
cards.definition: Used as a standard for comparing other cells against. E\xc2\xb0 of SHE is defined as 0, so all other E\xc2\xb0 values are compared to it.

cards.term: Why might you occasionally use other standard electrodes?
cards.definition: They are cheaper, easier and quicker to use and can provide just as good a reference.  Platinum electrodes of the SHE are expensive.

cards.term: If an E\xc2\xb0 value is more negative, what does it mean in terms of oxidising/reducing power?
cards.definition: It means it is a better reducing agent. (ie. easier to oxidise)

cards.term: If an E\xc2\xb0 value is more positive, what does it mean in terms of oxidising/reducing power?
cards.definition: It means it is a better oxidising agent. (ie. easier to reduce)

cards.term: What factors will change E\xc2\xb0 values?
cards.definition: 1. Concentration of ions2. Temperature

cards.term: What happens if you reduce the concentration of the ions in the left-hand half cell?
cards.definition: Equilibrium moves to the left to oppose the change of removing ions; this releases more electrons, the E o of the left hand cell becomes more negative, so the e.m.f. of the cell increases.

cards.term: When would you use a Platinum electrode?
cards.definition: When both the oxidised and reduced forms of the metal are in aqueous solution.
1. It is inert so does not take part in the electrochemistry.2. It is a good conductor that completes the circuit.

cards.term: How would you predict if a reaction would occur?
cards.definition: 1. Take the 2 half equations.2. Identify the species that is being reduced (this is effectively the right hand electrode).3. Calculate its E\xc2\xb0 value minus the E\xc2\xb0 value of the species that is being oxidised (effectively the left hand cell).4. If E\xc2\xb0 cell > 0, a reaction will occur.

cards.term: What was the first commercial cell made from (Daniell cell)?
cards.definition: Zinc/copper (II)

cards.term: What are zinc/carbon cells more commonly known as?
cards.definition: Disposable Batteries

cards.term: How are some cells able to be recharged?
cards.definition: If the cell reactions are reversible, they can be reversed by running a higher voltage through the cell than the cell\xe2\x80\x99s EIf the cell reactions are reversible, they can be reversed by running a higher voltage through the cell than the cell\xe2\x80\x99s E\xc2\xb0.

cards.term: Where are lithium-ion cells commonly used?
cards.definition: Mobile phones and laptops.
A cell that is used to generate electric current; it does not require electrical recharging.

cards.term: Why is it better to use a fuel cell than to burn H 2 in air, even though the same overall reaction occurs?
cards.definition: In combustion, sulfur and nitrogen containing compounds are produced due to the high temperatures and the S and N in air. These are bad for the environment.This does not occur in a fuel cell; the only product is water. They are also more efficient.

Hydrogen is a flammable gas with a low b.p. meaning it is hard and dangerous to store and transport. It is also expensive to buy.Fuel cells have a limited lifetime and use toxic chemicals in their manufacture.

cards.term: How do you find the weakest reducing agent from a table of electrode potential data?
cards.definition: The weakest reducing agent will have the most positive E^\xce\xb8value.The species is the product of the reduction equation i.e. when the equation goes from right to left.

cards.term: What is the reason that some cells cannot be recharged?
cards.definition: When the reaction of the cell is not reversible. The product produced either dissipates or cannot be converted back into the reactants.

cards.term: Why might the e.m.f. of a cell change after a period of time?
cards.definition: The concentrations of the ions change as the reagents are used up.

cards.term: How can the e.m.f. of a cell be kept constant?
cards.definition: If the reagents are supplied constantly, the concentrations of the ions will be constant meaning E\xc2\xb0 remains constant.
The charge of an ion or a theoretical charge of an atom in a covalently bonded compound assuming the bond becomes ionic.
Loss of electron, increase in oxidation number.
Gain in electrons, decrease in oxidation number.
A reaction that involves oxidation and reduction.
Accepts electrons and gets reduced in a redox reaction (causes the oxidation of other species).
Donates electrons and gets oxidised in a redox reaction (causes the reduction of other species).
A redox reaction involving an element in a single species being simultaneously oxidised and reduced, e.g. Cl2 + H2O \xe2\x87\x8c HClO + HCl.

Electrochemical cells use redox reactions since the electron transfer between products creates a flow of electrons. This flow of charged particles is an electrical current that flows between electrodes in the cell. A potential difference is produced between the two electrodes which can be measured using a voltmeter.

The standard hydrogen electrode is the measuring standard for half-cell potentials. It has a cell potential of 0.00 V, measured under standard conditions. These conditions are:\xe2\x97\x8f Solutions of 1.0 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3 concentration\xe2\x97\x8f A temperature of 298 K\xe2\x97\x8f 100 kPa pressure

Cells are represented in a simplified way so that they don\xe2\x80\x99t have to be drawn out each time. This representation has specific rules to help show the reactions that occur:\xe2\x97\x8f The half-cell with the most negative potential goes on the left.\xe2\x97\x8f The most oxidised species from each half-cell goes next to the salt bridge.\xe2\x97\x8f A salt bridge is shown using a double line.\xe2\x97\x8f State symbols are always included.

Standard cell potential values are used to calculate the overall cell emf. This is always calculated as the potential of the right of the cell minus the potential of the left of the cell, when looking at the conventional cell representation.Emf\xe2\x82\x8d\xea\x9c\x80\xe2\x82\x91\xe2\x82\x97\xe2\x82\x97\xe2\x82\x8e = E\xc2\xb0(\xca\x80\xc9\xaa\xc9\xa2\xca\x9c\xe1\xb4\x9b) - E\xc2\xb0(\xca\x9f\xe1\xb4\x87\xea\x9c\xb0\xe1\xb4\x9b)

The conditions are important when measuring the standard cell potential because changing the conditions will change the emf value obtained.\xe2\x97\x8f Increasing the concentration of the solutions used in the electrochemical cell makes the cell emf more positive as fewer electrons are produced in the reaction.\xe2\x97\x8f Increasing the pressure of the cell will make the cell emf more negative as more electrons are produced.
In a disproportionation reaction, a species is both oxidised and reduced. This is indicated by both an increase and decrease in the oxidation number for that species.
Electrochemical cells can be a useful source of energy for commercial use. They can be produced to be non rechargeable, rechargeable or fuel cells.

Fuel cells are a type of electrochemical cell used to generate an electrical current without needing to be recharged. In fuel cells, a fuel undergoes combustion in oxygen and the energy released is used to generate a voltage.

1. Balance all atoms except for oxygen and hydrogen.2. Add H\xe2\x82\x82O to balance oxygens (if needed).3. Add H\xe2\x81\xba ions to balance hydrogens (if needed).4. Add e\xe2\x81\xbb to balance charges.
The number of electrons an atom uses to bond with any other atom.

What is the oxidation number of combined oxygen such as in H\xe2\x82\x82O?
What is the oxidation number of oxygen in peroxides?
What is the oxidation number of combined hydrogen such as in NH\xe2\x82\x83, H\xe2\x82\x82S?
What is the oxidation number of combined hydrogen in metal hydrides such as LiH?
What is the oxidation number of a simple ion?
cards.definition: Charge on the ion, E.g Na\xe2\x81\xba \xe2\x86\x92 +1 ; Cl\xe2\x81\xbb \xe2\x86\x92 -1

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of combined fluorine such as in NaF, CaF\xe2\x82\x82?
When an element has more than one stable oxidation number how is it indicated?
cards.definition: Written as a Roman numeral.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of Fe in iron (III) chloride?

cards.definition: Negative ions that have an element along with oxygen.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of S in SO\xe2\x82\x84\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb?
cards.definition: +6Because, combined oxygen has an oxidation number of -2.4 x -2 = -8.The charge on the compound is -2. Sum of oxidation numbers must equal -2.So, -2 -(-8) = +6

cards.term: Define oxidation in terms of electron transfer and oxidation number.
cards.definition: Oxidation is:\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of electrons\xe2\x97\x8f An increase in oxidation number

cards.term: Define reduction in terms of electron transfer and oxidation number.
cards.definition: Reduction is:\xe2\x97\x8f Gain of electrons\xe2\x97\x8f A decrease in oxidation number
A reaction in which both oxidation and reduction takes place.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of a metal?
cards.definition: 0, because it is an uncombined element.
Species that gains electrons.
Species that lose electrons.

cards.term: What is the oxidation state of chlorine in NaClO?
cards.definition: [Cl] = +1 (Otherwise [Cl] = -1 in most other compounds. NaClO is formed in a disproportionation reaction.)

Where in a redox reaction, the oxidation states of atoms of the same element, increase for some atoms, whereas decrease for some atoms. e.g. See topic 2.3 - Group 7(17), the halogens for examples in Uses of Chlorine)

cards.term: What is the oxidation state of phosphorus in PCl5?
What is the oxidation state of nitrogen in ammonia?
cards.definition: [N] = -3(As ammonia is NH 3 )

cards.term: What is the oxidation state of arsenic in As\xe2\x82\x84O\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xbb?
What is the oxidation state of iron in K\xe2\x82\x84Fe(CN)\xe2\x82\x86?
Why is, 2CrO\xe2\x82\x84\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb + 2H\xe2\x81\xba \xe2\x86\x92 Cr\xe2\x82\x82O\xe2\x82\x87\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbb + H\xe2\x82\x82O, not a redox reaction?
cards.definition: Chromium is oxidised whereas hydrogen remains the same oxidation state (no element is reduced).

cards.term: What are the half equations and the ionic equation for: SnO + Zn \xe2\x86\x92 ZnO + Sn
cards.definition: Half Equations:\xe2\x97\x8f Sn\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba + 2e\xe2\x81\xbb \xe2\x86\x92 Sn\xe2\x97\x8f Zn \xe2\x86\x92 Zn\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba + 2e\xe2\x81\xbbIonic Equation:Sn\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba + Zn \xe2\x86\x92 Sn + Zn\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba
\xe2\x97\x8f The loss of electronsOR\xe2\x97\x8f Gain of OxygenOR\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of Hydrogen
\xe2\x97\x8f The gain of electronsOR\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of OxygenOR\xe2\x97\x8f Gain of Hydrogen

cards.term: What is oxidation in terms of oxidation number?
cards.definition: Oxidation is an increase of oxidation number. E.g if the oxidation number of Cl goes from 0 to 1+ it has been oxidised.

cards.term: What is reduction in terms of oxidation number?
cards.definition: Reduction is a decrease in oxidation number. E.g if the oxidation number of F goes from 1- to 0 it has been reduced.

cards.term: What happens when a rod of a metal is dipped into a solution of its own ions?
cards.definition: An equilibrium is set up between the solid metal and the aqueous metal ions.

cards.term: What are the two methods to measure standard electrode potential (E\xc2\xb0)?
cards.definition: 1. Metals or non-metals in contact with their ions in aqueous solution.2. Ions of the same element with different oxidation numbers.

cards.term: Write a half-equation for zinc (s) to zinc (II).
cards.definition: Zn (s) \xe2\x87\x8c Zn\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba (aq) + 2e\xe2\x81\xbb

cards.term: What is the simplest salt bridge made of?
cards.definition: Filter paper soaked in a saturated solution of KNO\xe2\x82\x83 (potassium nitrate).
They complete the circuit allowing a flow of charge through ion movement. They also contain inert ions so they don\xe2\x80\x99t react with the electrodes.

cards.term: What symbol is used to represent a salt bridge in standard notation?
cards.definition: II

cards.term: What type of species goes on the outside (furthest from the salt bridge) in standard cell notation?
cards.definition: The most reduced species.

cards.term: What does | indicate in standard cell notation?
cards.definition: Phase boundary (solid/liquid/gas).

cards.term: How would an Aluminium/Copper cell be represented using standard cell representation?
cards.definition: Al(s) | Al\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xba (aq) || Cu\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xba (aq) | Cu(s)

cards.term: What happens at the left-hand electrode?
cards.definition: Oxidation occurs. The left-hand electrode is the half cell with the most negative E\xc2\xb0 value.

cards.term: What happens at the right-hand electrode?
cards.definition: Reduction occurs. The right-hand electrode is the half cell with the most positive E\xc2\xb0 value.

cards.term: Which side of the cell has the most negative E\xc2\xb0 value and what happens to the metal with the most negative E\xc2\xb0 value?
cards.definition: The left-hand electrode is most negative. The metal will be oxidised.

cards.term: What conditions are required to use the standard hydrogen electrode?
cards.definition: Temperature = 298 KPressure = 100 kPa[H\xe2\x81\xba] = 1.00 mol dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is the standard hydrogen electrode used for?
cards.definition: Used as a standard for comparing other cells against.. E\xc2\xb0 of SHE is defined as 0, so all other E\xc2\xb0 values are compared to it.

cards.term: Why might you occasionally use other standard electrodes?
cards.definition: They are cheaper, easier and quicker to use and can provide just as good a reference. Platinum electrodes of the SHE are expensive.

cards.term: If an E\xc2\xb0 value is more negative, what does it mean in terms of oxidising/reducing power?
cards.definition: It means it is a better reducing agent. (ie. easier to oxidise)

cards.term: If an E\xc2\xb0 value is more positive, what does it mean in terms of oxidising/reducing power?
cards.definition: It means it is a better oxidising agent (ie. easier to reduce)

cards.term: What factors will change E\xc2\xb0 values?
cards.definition: 1. Concentration of ions2. Temperature

cards.term: What happens if you reduce the concentration of the ions in the left-hand half cell?
cards.definition: Equilibrium moves to the left to oppose the change of removing ions; this releases more electrons, the E\xc2\xb0 of the left hand cell becomes more negative, so the e.m.f. of the cell increases.

cards.term: When would you use a Platinum electrode?
cards.definition: When both the oxidised and reduced forms of the metal are in aqueous solution.
1. It is inert so does not take part in the electrochemistry.2. It is a good conductor that completes the circuit.

cards.definition: 1. Take the 2 half equations.2. Identify the species that is being reduced (this is effectively the right hand electrode).3. Calculate its E o value minus the E\xc2\xb0 value of the species that is being oxidised (effectively the left hand cell).4. If E o cell > 0, a reaction will occur.

cards.term: What was the first commercial cell made from (Daniell cell)?
cards.definition: Zinc/copper (II)

cards.term: What are zinc/carbon cells more commonly known as?

cards.definition: Zn is oxidised to Zn\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xbaNH\xe2\x82\x84\xe2\x81\xba is reduced to NH\xe2\x82\x83 at carbon electrode

cards.definition: In combustion, sulfur and nitrogen containing compounds are produced due to the high temperatures and the S and N in air. These are bad for the environment.This does not occur in a fuel cell; the only product is water. They are also more efficient.

Hydrogen is a flammable gas with a low b.p. meaning it ishard and dangerous to store and transport. It is also expensive to buy.Fuel cells have a limited lifetime and use toxic chemicals in their manufacture.

cards.term: How do you find the weakest reducing agent from a table of electrode potential data?
cards.definition: The weakest reducing agent will have the most positive E\xe1\xb6\xbf value.The species is the product of the reduction equation i.e. whenthe equation goes from right to left.

cards.term: What is the reason that some cells cannot be recharged?
cards.definition: When the reaction of the cell is not reversible.The product produced either dissipates or cannot be converted back into the reactants.

cards.term: Why might the e.m.f. of a cell change after a period of time?
cards.definition: The concentrations of the ions change as the reagents are used up.

Positive electrode \xe2\x86\x92 Site of the oxidation.
Negative electrode \xe2\x86\x92 Site of the reduction.
A platinum foil immersed in 1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3 HCl, enclosed in a tube containing hydrogen gas at standard pressure.
298 K, 100 kPa , 1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3 concentration of ions.

A porous substance soaked with a solution of an inert, strong electrolyte, e.g. a filter paper soaked in KNO\xe2\x82\x83(aq). The salt ions flow through the bridge to complete the cell and balance charges in solutions.
Produces electricity from a chemical reaction (a combination of two half cells, e.g. voltaic cell).
(battery) a cell that can be recharged when the current is passed in the opposite way to the current generated by a chemical reaction in the cell.
A cell used to harness electricity from a chemical reaction (fuel + oxygen). Chemicals are stored separately outside the cell and fed in when electricity is required.

cards.term: What are the main steps in producing a pure organic solid?
cards.definition: 1. Synthesis of the compound (usually using reflux, distillation etc.)2. Filtration (usually vacuum filtration)3. Purification (recrystallisation)

cards.term: How do you use laboratory equipment to heat under reflux?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Quickfit apparatus is used to heat a substance under reflux.\xe2\x97\x8f The substance is boiled in a pear-shaped or round-bottomed flask.\xe2\x97\x8f As it evaporates, it is cooled by the water in the liebig condenser and so condenses back into a liquid and drips back down into the flask to be heated again.

cards.term: Why is heating under reflux used?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Allows heating for a long period of time.\xe2\x97\x8f Prevents the flask from boiling dry.\xe2\x97\x8f Prevents volatile reactants / products escaping.\xe2\x97\x8f Ensures even heating.

cards.term: Why are anti-bumping granules used when heating under reflux and distillation?
cards.definition: To allow smooth boiling- preventing bubbles (caused by vapour) in the hot liquid from bubbling up the sides of the flask.

cards.term: What compounds are heated under reflux together in the first step to create aspirin?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f 2-hydroxybenzoic and ethanoic anhydride with a few drops of sulfuric acid.\xe2\x97\x8f Filter the product using vacuum filtration.

cards.term: How do you use laboratory equipment to filter under reduced pressure?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Using a Buchner funnel and Buchner flask, connected by rubber tubing to the vacuum source.\xe2\x97\x8f The funnel contains a layer of filter paper.\xe2\x97\x8f Pour the substance onto the filter paper and the liquid will be sucked through via vacuum filtration into the flask.\xe2\x97\x8f The solid will remain on the paper.

cards.term: How do you purify a solid product?
cards.definition: By recrystallisation:\xe2\x97\x8f Add minimum amount of warm solvent to the impure sample until it has dissolved.\xe2\x97\x8f Allow to cool, crystals should form.\xe2\x97\x8f When no more form you can filter under reduced pressure, washing the solid with solvent, to obtain a dry crystalline solid.

cards.term: How do you determine the melting point of a substance and why can this information be useful?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Place a small sample of the solid in a capillary tube.\xe2\x97\x8f Melt using the melting apparatus available, measuring the temperature with a thermometer.\xe2\x97\x8f A pure substance will usually melt at a single temperature (or a very small range) but an impure substance will melt over a range of temperatures (usually lower than that of the pure substance).\xe2\x97\x8f Record the starting and ending points of the melting, when the first crystal can be seen to melt and when the last crystal becomes liquid respectively.\xe2\x97\x8f You can then compare the melting point to known values to identify the substance.

cards.term: How do you calculate the percentage yield of a product?
cards.definition: Percent yield = (Actual yield / Theoretical yield) x 100
The minimum energy required to break all chemical bonds in the reactants for the reaction to then occur.

cards.term: What is an example method to determine the activation energy of a reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Repeat for various temperatures 15\xe2\x84\x83 to 75\xe2\x84\x83 (in water baths):\xe2\x97\x8f Add equal volumes of bromide/bromate solution and phenol. Add methyl red indicator.\xe2\x97\x8f Add H2SO4 solution and time how long it takes for the solution to go colourless.

cards.term: How do you measure the gradient of a line?
cards.definition: Gradient = Change in y-coordinate \xc3\xb7 Change in x-coordinate

cards.term: Why sometimes is a log scale used?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f To show a large range of values without compressing the scale.\xe2\x97\x8f To show percentage change or multiplication factors.

cards.term: What is meant by \xe2\x80\x98rate of reaction\xe2\x80\x99?
cards.definition: The change in concentration of reactants or products over time.

cards.term: How can rate of reaction be measured?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Initial rates method- i.e. the iodine clock reaction\xe2\x97\x8f A continuous monitoring method- i.e. measuring the volume of gas released in a reaction over time.

cards.term: What is a continuous monitoring method?
cards.definition: This involves measuring the change in concentration of a reactant or product over time (or measuring volume of gas released) as the reaction progresses.

cards.term: Give an example of a continuous monitoring method.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Mix propanone with sulfuric acid and iodine in a beaker. Start a stopwatch.\xe2\x97\x8f Using a pipette, remove a sample of the mixture and add NaHCO3. This stops the reaction. Note the time at which it is added.\xe2\x97\x8f Titrate the remaining iodine present in the sample with sodium thiosulfate(VI) solution, using starch as the indicator.\xe2\x97\x8f Repeat titrations with samples taken every 3 minutes (treat with NaHCO3)

cards.term: How would you analyse the results from this reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Plot a graph of titre against time. Concentration of iodine is proportional to titre.\xe2\x97\x8f By comparing the shape of the graph to known order concentration-time graphs, determine the order of reaction with respect to I2.

cards.term: What is an initial rates method?
cards.definition: The method involves measuring the initial rate of reaction for multiple different concentrations to observe how rate of reaction varies.

cards.term: What are the issues with this experiment?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Some low I - concentrations may take too long to react.\xe2\x97\x8f Delayed stopwatch reactions.\xe2\x97\x8f Concentrations may not be exact due to measuring apparatus.

cards.term: What is the method of preparing a transition metal complex?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Weigh out the mass of copper sulphate accurately and dissolve in water.\xe2\x97\x8f In a fume cupboard, add conc. NH3. Stir the mixture and pour into ethanol. Then, cool the mixture in ice bath. Crystals of product will form.\xe2\x97\x8f Filter the crystals via vacuum filtration.\xe2\x97\x8f Record the mass and calculate the percentage yield.

cards.term: How do you use laboratory equipment to filter under reduced pressure?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Using a Buchner funnel and Buchner flask, connected by rubber tubing to the vacuum source.\xe2\x97\x8f The funnel contains a layer of filter paper.\xe2\x97\x8f Pour the substance onto the filter paper and the liquid will be sucked through via vacuum filtration into the flask. Wash the solid with cold solvent.\xe2\x97\x8f The solid will remain on the paper.

cards.term: How do we prevent solid being lost in vacuum filtration?
cards.definition: Wash the transferring flask / tube with solvent (i.e. ethanol) and pour onto the filter paper in the buchner funnel.

cards.term: How do you calculate the percentage yield of a product?
cards.definition: Percentage yield = (Actual yield / Theoretical yield) x 100

cards.term: What is a fume cupboard used for?
cards.definition: To capture and then remove hazardous substances generated during experiments in the laboratory.
A titration of a reducing agent by an oxidising agent (or vice versa).

cards.term: What equipment is used to carry out a titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f A pipette and pipette filler are used to accurately measure out the volume of a reactant before transferring it to a conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f A burette is a controlled way to add small volumes of one reactant to the other reactant (until the reaction has reached completion).

cards.term: How do you carry out a titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Once the pipette has been used to place one reactant into the conical flask, fill the burette with the other reactant. Record initial volume.\xe2\x97\x8f Add a few drops of indicator to the conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f Open the burette tap and allow the reactant to flow into the conical flask, swirling it to mix the contents.\xe2\x97\x8f Close the burette tap once the expected colour change occurs. Use a white tile so the colour change is easy to identify.\xe2\x97\x8f Record final burette volume.\xe2\x97\x8f Repeat until you get concordant results, then calculate a mean titre.
Titres that are within 0.1 cm^3 of each other.

cards.term: How do you do a titration with potassium manganate (VII)?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Add the potassium manganate(VII) solution into the burette.\xe2\x97\x8f The other reactant solution is acidified with dilute H2SO4 and placed into a conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f The potassium manganate(VII) solution flows into the flask and as it reacts, it becomes colourless. When there is the first trace of a permanent pale pink solution, close the burette tap.

cards.term: How would you reduce the uncertainty in this experiment?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Use a balance with a greater resolution.\xe2\x97\x8f Use pipettes and burettes etc. with a greater resolution.\xe2\x97\x8f Use greater masses and volumes so percentage uncertainty is reduced.

cards.term: What is the weighing by difference technique (used to measure mass of the iron tablets)?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f It is a method to weigh materials accurately.\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of substance = Mass of weighing dish and substance - Mass of dish after substance has been transferred.

\xe2\x97\x8f Two different half cells are connected by a salt bridge, with their electrodes connected to a voltmeter (measures EMF/cell potential). This allows the flow of electrons.\xe2\x97\x8f The electrical energy generated is from the chemical redox reactions.

cards.term: What does a half cell consist of?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f A half cell contains the chemical species present in a redox half equation.\xe2\x97\x8f Half cells are usually metal / metal ion (metal electrode in the metal ion solution) or ion / ion (ions of the same element but different oxidation states, in solution).

\xe2\x97\x8f A salt bridge allows the transfer of ions.\xe2\x97\x8f It is typically a strip of filter paper soaked in a concentrated solution of an electrolyte i.e. KNO3(aq) that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t react with either half cell solution.

cards.term: Why may a graphite or platinum electrode be used?
cards.definition: They are very unreactive - i.e. will not react with the half cell solutions and will not affect the voltmeter readings. Usually used in ion/ion half cells.

cards.term: Why do you need to file / sand away the outer layer of the metal?
cards.definition: It removes the oxide layer on the outside of the metal.
An acid that only partially dissociates in solution.
To detect when a reaction reaches its equivalence point. The indicator should be chosen so that its end point (point of colour change) matches the equivalence point of the reaction.

cards.term: Why does a pH probe need to be calibrated?
cards.definition: So that for each pH reading, the pH value is accurate.

cards.term: How do you calibrate a pH probe?
cards.definition: Submerge pH probe in buffer solutions of three different pHs including pH 7 and usually pHs around 4 and 10. Each time pressing the calibrate button.
The more accurate the data, the closer it is to the actual value.

cards.term: What equipment is used to carry out a titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f A pipette and pipette filler are used to accurately measure out the volume of a reactant before transferring it to a conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f A burette is a controlled way to add small volumes of one reactant to the other reactant (until the reaction has reached completion).

cards.term: How do you carry out a titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Once the pipette has been used to place one reactant into the conical flask, fill the burette with the other reactant. Record initial volume.\xe2\x97\x8f Add a few drops of indicator to the conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f Open the burette tap and allow the reactant to flow into the conical flask, swirling it to mix the contents.\xe2\x97\x8f Close the burette tap once the expected colour change occurs. Use a white tile so the colour change is easy to identify.\xe2\x97\x8f Record final burette volume.\xe2\x97\x8f Repeat until you get concordant results, then calculate a mean titre.

cards.term: How do you carry out a titration to calculate pH?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Into a conical flask, add 25 cm^3 of 0.1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm^\xe2\x88\x923 ethanoic acid solution with a few drops of phenolphthalein.\xe2\x97\x8f The sodium hydroxide solution goes in the burette.\xe2\x97\x8f Titrate the solutions together until the mixture just turns pink.\xe2\x97\x8f Add another 25 cm^3 of 0.1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm^\xe2\x88\x923 ethanoic acid solution into the conical flask, using a pipette\xe2\x97\x8f Record the pH of the resulting solution.

\xe2\x97\x8f The enthalpy change for a chemical reaction is the same no matter which route is chosen to get from reactants to products.\xe2\x97\x8f (For a Hess cycle, the total enthalpy change clockwise = the total enthalpy change anticlockwise).

cards.term: What is the weighing by difference technique?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f It is a method to weigh materials accurately.\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of substance = Mass of weighing dish and substance - Mass of dish after substance has been transferred.

cards.term: How can you reduce the uncertainty in the mass measurement?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Use a balance with a greater resolution.\xe2\x97\x8f Use a larger mass.

cards.term: What is percentage uncertainty and how do you calculate it?
cards.definition: Percentage uncertainty in a measurement = (absolute uncertainly / Calculated value) x 100

cards.term: Why can the enthalpy change of a thermal decomposition reaction not be measured directly?
cards.definition: As thermal energy must be supplied for the reaction to occur, the temperature change measured is not only due to decomposition.

cards.term: How do you calculate enthalpy change experimentally?
cards.definition: q = mc\xf0\x9d\x9a\xabT\xe2\x97\x8f Where m is the mass of the solution that changes temperature (1g = 1 cm^3), c is the specific heat capacity (usually of water) and \xf0\x9d\x9a\xabT is the temperature change, measured using a thermometer and q is the heat energy taken in or released (in joules).\xe2\x97\x8f Divide this number, in kJ, by the number of moles of the limiting reactant.\xe2\x97\x8f Add a sign to show whether \xf0\x9d\x9a\xabH_r^\xe2\xa6\xb5 is exothermic or endothermic.

cards.term: Why may an experimental value for enthalpy change be different to the theoretical value?
cards.definition: 1. Heat loss to apparatus/surroundings.2. Incomplete combustion.3. Non-standard conditions.4. Evaporation of alcohol/water.

cards.term: How do you prevent heat loss to surroundings/apparatus?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Insulate by placing the reactants in a polystyrene cup with a lid, into the beaker.\xe2\x97\x8f Avoid large temperature differences between surroundings and calorimeter.\xe2\x97\x8f Use a bomb calorimeter

cards.term: Other than preventing heat loss, how can the accuracy of this experiment be improved?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Read the thermometer at eye level to avoid parallax errors.\xe2\x97\x8f Stir the solution so the temperature is evenly distributed.\xe2\x97\x8f Use a digital thermometer and data logger for more accurate and faster readings.\xe2\x97\x8f Use greater concentrations and masses, leading to a greater temperature change and thus smaller uncertainty.
The more accurate the data, the closer it is to the actual value.

cards.term: How can a flame test be used to identify metal ions?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Clean wire loop with H2SO4 or HCl.\xe2\x97\x8f Dip the loop into the sample.\xe2\x97\x8f Place the loop into a blue flame (using a bunsen burner).\xe2\x97\x8f Record the colour of the flame.

cards.term: How can you use sodium hydroxide to identify cations?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Dissolve the unknown substance in water.\xe2\x97\x8f Add aqueous NaOH dropwise, until in excess and no further change occurs.

cards.term: How do you test for a saturated hydrocarbon?
cards.definition: Add bromine water to the sample. If the solution turns from brown to colourless then a unsaturated hydrocarbon was present.

cards.term: How do you test for an aldehyde?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Add Tollen\xe2\x80\x99s reagent to a sample of the suspected aldehyde. Warm \xe2\x86\x92 The presence of a silver mirror confirms an aldehyde was present.\xe2\x97\x8f Add Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s/Benedict\xe2\x80\x99s solution \xe2\x86\x92 aldehyde turns clear blue solution to brick red ppt.\xe2\x97\x8f Add dichromate ions (eg. K2Cr2O7 / Na2Cr2O7) acidified eg. with H2SO4 & heat \xe2\x86\x92 turns orange solution green.

cards.term: How do you test for a carboxylic acid?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Add an alcohol & acid (eg. H2SO4) \xe2\x86\x92 glue or pear-drop smell (formation of an ester).\xe2\x97\x8f Add a metal carbonate \xe2\x86\x92 effervescence as CO2 is released (test with limewater).\xe2\x97\x8f Add a reactive metal \xe2\x86\x92 effervescence as H2 is released.\xe2\x97\x8f Add an acyl chloride \xe2\x86\x92 misty fumes (HCl).

cards.term: How do you test for group 7 / halide ions?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f To the compound being tested, add nitric acid and silver nitrate. Record observations.\xe2\x97\x8f To samples of this solution, add dilute and then concentrated ammonia.

cards.term: What is the order of testing ions?(Carbonate, halide and sulfate)
cards.definition: Carbonate \xe2\x86\x92 Sulfate \xe2\x86\x92 HalideThis prevents false positive results occurring i.e. Unexpected insoluble precipitates such as Ag2SO4 , Ag2 CO3 and BaCO3 could form.

cards.term: How do you form the crude product?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Add conc. HCl and 2-methylpropan-2-ol to a conical flask. Put the rubber bung in and swirl the flask.\xe2\x97\x8f Open the bung to release the pressure. Repeat this regularly over 20 minutes.\xe2\x97\x8f Add some anhydrous CaCl2 and shake.\xe2\x97\x8f At this point, there should be two distinct layers.\xe2\x97\x8f Upper layer = Organic product.\xe2\x97\x8f Lower layer = Aqueous layer.

cards.term: How do you separate the organic layer from the aqueous layer?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Transfer the contents of the flask to a separatingfunnel.\xe2\x97\x8f Allow the layers to separate and remove the lower (aqueous) layer by opening the tap.\xe2\x97\x8f Keep the organic layer in the separating funnel.

cards.term: How do you remove the unreacted HCl?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Add a solution of NaHCO 3 to remove the unreacted HCl. Swirl. Stopper the separating funnel and shake it.\xe2\x97\x8f Invert and open the tap to release pressure. Repeat a few times.\xe2\x97\x8f Remove the stopper and run off the aqueous layer. Then, run the organic layer into a clear conical flask.

cards.term: How do you remove any water from the organic liquid?
cards.definition: Add some anhydrous Na2SO4 because it acts as a drying agent.

cards.term: How do you purify the product?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Distillation\xe2\x97\x8f This separates the products based on boiling point.\xe2\x97\x8f Collect the liquid boiling between 50\xc2\xb0C and 52\xc2\xb0- this should be the pure product.

\xe2\x97\x8f Distillation is a technique where the heating of a liquid to create a vapour is cooled by a condenser, causing the gas to condense into a liquid and drip into a separate flask.\xe2\x97\x8f The different substances will be separated by boiling point/volatility.

cards.term: What equipment is used for distillation?
cards.definition: Quickfit apparatus:Pear-shaped or round-bottomed flask with a liebig condenser, still head, stopper, receiver adaptor, fitted with a thermometer and collection vessel.

cards.term: Why are anti-bumping granules used in distillation?
cards.definition: To allow smooth boiling. They prevent the appearance of bubbles caused by vapour in the hot liquid which would cause splashing up the sides of the flask.
\xe2\x97\x8f Oxidation is loss of electrons.\xe2\x97\x8f If an element is oxidised, it\xe2\x80\x99s oxidation number increases.

\xe2\x97\x8f Distillation is a technique where the heating of a liquid to create a vapour is cooled by a condenser, causing the gas to condense into a liquid and drip into a separate flask.\xe2\x97\x8f The different substances will be separated by boiling point/volatility.

cards.term: What equipment is used for distillation?
cards.definition: Quickfit apparatus:Pear-shaped or round-bottomed flask with a liebig condenser, still head, stopper, receiver adaptor, fitted with a thermometer and collection vessel.

cards.term: What happens when you oxidise ethanol by distillation?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Ethanol is distilled with acidified potassium dichromate (VI) and is oxidised into an aldehyde, ethanal.\xe2\x97\x8f This is shown by a colour change from orange to green.

cards.term: How do you use laboratory equipment to heat under reflux?
cards.definition: Quickfit apparatus is used to heat a substance under reflux.- The substance is boiled in a pear-shaped or round-bottomed flask.- As it evaporates, it is cooled by the water in the liebig condenser and so condenses back into a liquid and drips back down into the flask to be heated again.

cards.term: Why is heating under reflux used?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Allows heating for a long period of time\xe2\x97\x8f Prevents the flask from boiling dry\xe2\x97\x8f Prevents volatile reactants/products escaping\xe2\x97\x8f Ensures even heating

cards.term: Why are anti-bumping granules used when heating under reflux/in distillation?
cards.definition: To allow smooth boiling. They prevent the appearance of bubbles caused by vapour in the hot liquid which would cause splashing up the sides of the flask.

cards.term: What happens when you oxidise ethanol under reflux?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Ethanol is refluxed with acidified potassium dichromate (VI) and is oxidised into a carboxylic acid, ethanoic acid.\xe2\x97\x8f This is shown by a colour change from orange to green.
Hydrolysis is a type reaction where water is used to break (hydrolyse) chemical bonds and split a reactant into two.

cards.term: How do you test the rate of hydrolysis of different haloalkanes? (chloro-, bromo-, iodo-)
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f In 3 different test tubes add 4 drops of 1-chlorobutane, 1 bromobutane and 1-iodobutane.\xe2\x97\x8f To each test tube add 5 cm 3 of ethanol. Place all test tubes in a 50\xe2\x84\x83 water bath.\xe2\x97\x8f Pour about 5 cm 3 of silver nitrate into 3 test tubes. Place the test tubes in the water bath.\xe2\x97\x8f When all the solutions have reached 50\xe2\x84\x83, add the silver nitrate to the haloalkane\xe2\x80\x93ethanol solutions.\xe2\x97\x8f Start the stop clock. Measure the time taken for each precipitate to appear.

cards.term: How do you test the rate of hydrolysis of different haloalkanes? (primary, secondary, tertiary)
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f In 3 different test tubes add 4 drops of 1-bromobutane, 2 bromobutane and 2-bromo-2-methylpropane.\xe2\x97\x8f To each test tube add 5 cm 3 of ethanol. Place all test tubes in a 50\xe2\x84\x83 water bath.\xe2\x97\x8f Pour about 5 cm^3 of silver nitrate into 3 test tubes. Place the test tubes in the water bath.\xe2\x97\x8f When all the solutions have reached 50\xe2\x84\x83, add the silver nitrate solution to the haloalkane\xe2\x80\x93ethanol solutions.\xe2\x97\x8f Start the stop clock. Measure the time taken for each precipitate to appear.

cards.term: What kind of reaction is the hydrolysis of haloalkanes?
cards.definition: Nucleophilic Substitution
To keep the temperature constant (as temperature is a control variable) so it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t interfere with the rate of hydrolysis.
The uncertainty in a measurement is the interval within which the true / actual value is expected to lie.

cards.term: What is percentage uncertainty and how do you calculate it?
cards.definition: Percentage uncertainty in a measurement = (Absolute uncertainly / Calculated value) x 100

cards.term: How can you decrease the uncertainty in time taken?
cards.definition: Use a lower temperature to reduce the rate of reaction. This will make the time aken longer and so the percentage uncertainty will be lower.
A standard solution is a solution of known concentration.

cards.term: How do you make a diluted solution of hydrochloric acid?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Add 25 cm^3 of the hydrochloric acid solution into the volumetric flask using a pipette.\xe2\x97\x8f Make the solution up to the line by adding distilled water.

cards.term: What equipment is used to carry out a titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f A pipette and pipette filler are used to accurately measure out the volume of a reactant before transferring it to a conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f A burette is a controlled way to add small volumes of one reactant to the other reactant (until the reaction has reached completion).

cards.term: How do you carry out this titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Once the pipette has been used to place HCl into the conical flask, fill the burette with NaOH (known concentration). Record initial volume.\xe2\x97\x8f Add a few drops of phenolphthalein indicator to the conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f Open the burette tap and allow the NaOH to flow into the conical flask, swirling it to mix the contents.\xe2\x97\x8f Close the burette tap once the expected colour change occurs (Colourless to pink). Use a white tile so the colour change is easy to identify.\xe2\x97\x8f Record final burette volume.\xe2\x97\x8f Repeat until you get concordant results, then calculate a mean titre.
To detect when a reaction reaches completion, usually by the presence of a colour change.
Titres that are within 0.1 cm^3 of each other.

cards.term: How would you analyse the results from this titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Calculate the mean titre using concordant results.\xe2\x97\x8f Calculate the number of moles of NaOH in the mean titre (n = c x v).\xe2\x97\x8f Calculate the number of moles of HCl that were present in the 250 cm^3 diluted solution.\xe2\x97\x8f Use this to calculate the concentration of the original solution of HCl.
A standard solution is a solution of known concentration.

cards.term: How do you make a standard solution?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Measure, using a balance, the mass of solid required.\xe2\x97\x8f Transfer this to a volumetric flask and rinse the remaining weighing bottle content (with distilled water) into the flask so no solid is lost.\xe2\x97\x8f Add a volume of distilled water to dissolve the solid. Swirl to mix.\xe2\x97\x8f Then add more distilled water up to the line on the neck of the volumetric flask. Invert multiple times to mix.

cards.term: What is the standard solution for this practical? How is it made?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Diluted sulfamic acid.\xe2\x97\x8f Dissolve 2.5g solid sulfamic acid in 100 cm 3of distilled water.\xe2\x97\x8f Transfer to 250 cm 3 volumetric flask and fillup to line with distilled water.

cards.term: What is the weighing by difference technique?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f It is a method to weigh materials accurately.\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of substance = Mass of weighing dish and substance - Mass of dish after substance has been transferred.

cards.term: What equipment is used to carry out this titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f A pipette and pipette filler are used to accurately measure out the volume of NaOH before transferring it to a conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f A burette is used to add small volumes of sulfamic acid solution to the NaOH until the reaction has reached completion.

cards.term: How do you carry out this titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Once the pipette has been used to place NaOH into the conical flask, fill the burette with the acid solution. Record initial volume.\xe2\x97\x8f Add a few drops of methyl orange to the conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f Open the burette tap and allow the sulfamic acid to flow into the conical flask, swirling it to mix the contents.\xe2\x97\x8f Close the burette tap once the expected colour change occurs. Use a white tile so the colour change is easy to identify.\xe2\x97\x8f Record final burette volume.\xe2\x97\x8f Repeat until you get concordant results, then calculate a mean titre.
To detect when a reaction reaches completion, usually by the presence of a colour change.
Titres that are within 0.1 cm^3 of each other.

cards.term: How would you analyse the results from this titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Calculate the concentration of the sulfamic acid solution (If not already known).\xe2\x97\x8f Calculate the mean titre using concordant results.\xe2\x97\x8f Calculate the concentration of the burette solution.
Equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure will contain an equal number of molecules.

cards.term: How can you measure the volume of gas released from a reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Using a gas syringe connected to a bung (via a tube) which stoppers the conical flask containing the reactants.\xe2\x97\x8f As gas is released it pushes the syringe outwards.

cards.term: What is the weighing by difference method?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f It is a method to weigh materials accurately.\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of substance = Mass of weighing dish and substance - Mass of dish after substance has been transferred.

cards.term: How would you carry out an experiment to measure the molar volume of a gas?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f React ethanoic acid and solid calcium carbonate together.\xe2\x97\x8f Using a gas syringe, measure the volume of gas released.\xe2\x97\x8f Repeat for increasing masses of CaCO3.

cards.term: What are some issues with this experiment?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Some gas may escape before the bung is added.\xe2\x97\x8f A solid reactant may be of different mass, surface area etc. for each repeat which will affect the rate of reaction.\xe2\x97\x8f CO2 is slightly soluble in water, so the exact volume is not measured as some may dissolve in solution.

cards.term: How do you prevent gas escaping?
cards.definition: Place the solid reactant upright inside a sample tube in the conical flask, tipping the tube over by moving the conical flask around to start the reaction.

cards.term: How would you analyse this data?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Plot a graph of mass of CaCO3 (x-axis) against volume of CO2 collected (y-axis).\xe2\x97\x8f Draw a line of best fit that passes through the origin.\xe2\x97\x8f In this reaction, CaCO3 to CO2 is a 1:1 ratio. You could calculate the number of moles of CaCO3 in 0.25g and use this to calculate the volume of 1 mol of carbon dioxide gas in dm^3.

topics.title: Formulae, Equations and Amounts of Substance

cards.definition: The mean mass of an atom of an element, divided by one twelfth of the mean mass of an atom of the carbon-12 isotope.
The mean mass of a molecule of a compound, divided by one twelfth of the mean mass of an atom of the carbon-12 isotope.
Empirical formula is the simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element in a compound. It is found using molar ratios of each element.

Molecular formula is the actual number of each atom in the molecule. It can be determined using the Mr of the empirical formula and the true Mr of the molecule. This gives a multiplier value which can be used to scale up the empirical formula.
R is the ideal gas constant, equal to 8.31 J\xe2\x80\xa2K^-1\xe2\x80\xa2mol-1.
\xe2\x97\x8f (s) - solid\xe2\x97\x8f (l) - liquid\xe2\x97\x8f (g) - gas\xe2\x97\x8f (aq) - aqueous (dissolved in water)

Ionic equations show just the reacting particles that undergo a change during the reaction and not the spectator species. As with normal chemical equations, it must be balanced. The reacting species are shown as dissociated ions.

The percentage yield indicates how much of the maximum amount of product you obtained during an experiment. A low percentage yield could indicate an incomplete reaction, or the loss of product during purification.% Yield = Experiment mass / Theoretical mass x 100

The atom economy is a measure of efficiency since it measures the proportion of reactant atoms which are converted into the desired product.% Atom Economy = Mr of desired product / Total Mr of reactants x 100
Experimental data can be used to work out empirical and molecular formulas and reaction stoichiometries. These calculations require use of the equations given in this section, along with some others.

A titration is a practical method where a standard solution of known concentration is reacted with a solution of unknown concentration in order to determine its concentration. For this, there is a standard method to make up the standard solution and carry out the titration.

The equipment used in a titration all comes with their own uncertainty values. These must be combined to find the overall uncertainty in the final answer.The percentage uncertainty of a measurement can be calculated if the uncertainty of the instrument is known.Percentage uncertainly = instrument uncertainly / Measurement x 100

cards.term: What is the symbol for amount of substance?
cards.definition: n

cards.term: What is the unit used to measure amount of substance?
cards.definition: Mole

cards.term: What does the Avogadro constant represent?
cards.definition: The number of atoms per mole of the carbon-12 isotope.

cards.term: How to calculate the mass of 1 mole of the element?
cards.definition: Mass of 1 mole = Relative atomic mass in grams

cards.term: How to calculate moles when mass and molar mass are given?
cards.definition: Moles (mol) = Mass (g) / molar mass (g\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-1)
Simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present in a compound.

\xe2\x97\x8f Divide the amount of each element by its molar mass.\xe2\x97\x8f Divide the answers by the smallest value obtained.\xe2\x97\x8f If there is a decimal, divide by a suitable number to make it into a whole number.
Under the same temperature and pressure, one mole of any gas would occupy the same volume.

cards.term: How much volume does a gas occupy, at room temperature and pressure?

cards.definition: The volume per mole of gas molecules.

cards.term: Why do different gas particles occupy the same volume?
cards.definition: The gas particles are very spread out, hence individual differences has no effect.

cards.term: How to calculate moles when gas volume is given?
cards.definition: Moles (mol) = volume (dm^3 ) / 24 or Moles (mol) = volume (cm^3 ) / 24,000.

cards.term: What are the ideal ways in which gases behave?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f They are in continuous motion.\xe2\x97\x8f No intermolecular forces experienced.\xe2\x97\x8f Exert pressure when they collide with each other or container.\xe2\x97\x8f No kinetic energy is lost in the collisions.\xe2\x97\x8f When temperature increases, kinetic energy of gases also increase.

cards.term: Write down the ideal gas equation (in words and symbols, including the units)
cards.definition: pV = nRTPressure (Pa) x Volume (m^3 ) = Number of moles (mol) x Gas Constant (8.314 J\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-1) x Temperature (K)

cards.term: 1 atmospheric pressure is equal to how many pascal?
0\xe2\x84\x83 is equal to how many kelvin?
What does concentration of a solution mean?
cards.definition: It is the amount of solute dissolved in 1 dm^3 of solvent.

cards.term: How do you calculate moles when concentration and volume are given?
cards.definition: Moles (mol) = Concentration (mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm^-3) x Volume (dm 3)
A solution of known concentration.

cards.term: Write down the steps to prepare a standard solution.
cards.definition: 1. Weigh the solute using the weigh by difference method.2. In a beaker dissolve the solute using the solvent.3. Pour the solution into a volumetric flask.4. Rinse the beaker using the solution and add it to the flask.5. Add solvent to the flask carefully until it reaches the graduation line.6. Mix the solution thoroughly to ensure complete mixing.

cards.term: What does the terms concentrated and dilute mean?
cards.definition: Concentrated - large amount of solute per dm^3 of solvent.Dilute - small amount of solute per dm^3 of solvent.

cards.term: What is a species in a chemical reaction?
cards.definition: Any particle that takes part in a reaction.

cards.term: What are the four common state symbols?
cards.definition: 1. Solid (s)2. Liquid (l)3. Gaseous (g)4. Aqueous (aq)

cards.term: What does the percentage yield mean?
cards.definition: The efficiency of which reactants are converted into products.

cards.term: What are the reasons for not obtaining 100% yield?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Reaction may be at equilibrium\xe2\x97\x8f The reactants may be impure\xe2\x97\x8f Side reactions could happen\xe2\x97\x8f Reactants or products may be left behind while transferring\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of products during separation and purification
Percentage Yield = (Actual amount of product (mol) / Theoretical amount of product (mol)) x 100

cards.term: What does atom economy tell us about?
cards.definition: The proportion of desired products compared with all the products formed in the reaction.
Atom Economy = (Molecular mass of desired product / Sum of the molecular masses of all products) x 100
No, even if all the reactants are converted into products, not all products of the reaction will be the required products.

cards.term: Which type of reaction has 100% atom economy?
cards.definition: Addition reactions (two or more reactants are combined to form a product).
The same error appears in each measurement.

cards.term: The error of mass measurement can be reduced by using which method?
cards.definition: Weighing by difference method.

cards.term: Explain how to measure using the weighing by difference method.
cards.definition: 1. Measure the mass of the container.2. Add the chemical to the container and weigh the container.3. Calculate the mass of the chemical.4. Transfer the chemical and remeasure the empty container.5. Calculate the mass of the chemical transferred.

cards.term: Is the percentage error higher or lower, when the quantity measured has been reduced?
cards.definition: Higher.
Mass of one mole of the substance expressed in g\xe2\x8b\x85mol^\xe2\x88\x921.
Smallest whole number ratio of atoms of each element in a compound, e.g. the empirical formula of benzene (C6H6), cyclobutadiene (C4H4) and acetylene (C2H2) is simply \xe2\x80\x9cCH\xe2\x80\x9d.
The actual number of atoms of each element in a molecule.
Ions that do not take part in the reaction.
A compound that has molecules of water of crystallisation, e.g. MgSO4\xe2\x8b\x857 H2O.
Solute (is dissolved) + Solvent (dissolves the solute).Standard solution is the one with accurately known concentration.
Mass of solute per volume of solution, g\xe2\x8b\x85dm^\xe2\x88\x923.
Moles of solute per volume of solution, mol\xe2\x8b\x85dm^\xe2\x88\x923.
A substance used for preparation of a standard solution by weighing.
Provided the conditions of temperature and pressure are the same, equal volume of gases contain the same number of molecules.
The volume of 1 mol of a gas.
More reactive element reacts to take place of less reactive element in a compound, e.g. Zn + 2HCl \xe2\x86\x92 ZnCl2 + H2.
The one that produces an insoluble solid.
A discrepancy between the value obtained in the experiment and an actual value.
Refers to how close to each other are the values obtained in an experiment.
Refers to how close these values are to the actual value.
Results that lie close to each other. In titration, these are titres that usually lie within +/\xe2\x88\x92 0.20 cm^3.
The range in which the true value of a measurement could lie, e.g. for burettes +/\xe2\x88\x92 0.05 cm^3.
They occur when conditions are varied in an unpredictable manner.

Errors which are constant when you repeat an experiment. They usually are a result of the apparatus used.Percentage uncertainty = (Uncertainty/Reading) x 100%Percentage yield = (Actual yield/Theoretical yield) x 100%

Measure of the proportion of reaction atoms that become part of the desired product in the balanced chemical equation.Atom Economy = (Molar mass of desired product/Total molar mass of all products ) x 100%

topics.title: Inorganic Chemistry and The Periodic Table

cards.term: What is a common name given to group 2 metals?
cards.definition: Alkaline earth metals.

cards.term: What is the most reactive metal of group 2?
cards.definition: Barium

cards.term: List 3 physical properties of group 2 metals.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f High melting and boiling points\xe2\x97\x8f Low density metals\xe2\x97\x8f Form colourless (white) compounds

cards.term: The highest energy electrons of group 2 metals are in which subshell?
cards.definition: S subshell

cards.term: Does reactivity increase or decrease down group 2? Why?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Increases\xe2\x97\x8f Electrons are lost more easily because larger atomic radius and more shielding.

cards.term: What happens to the first ionisation energy as you go down group 2? Why?
cards.definition: Decreases because:- Number of filled electron shells increases down the group \xe2\x86\x92 increased shielding.- Increased atomic radius \xe2\x86\x92 weaker force between outer.- Electron and nucleus \xe2\x86\x92 less energy needed to remove electron.

cards.term: What type of reaction is the reaction between group 2 elements and oxygen?
cards.definition: Redox Reaction

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction of calcium and oxygen.
cards.definition: 2Ca (s) + O 2 (g) \xe2\x86\x92 2CaO (s)

cards.term: What are the products when group 2 elements react with water?
cards.definition: Hydroxide and hydrogen gas.

cards.term: Which group 2 element doesn\xe2\x80\x99t react with water?
cards.definition: Beryllium

cards.term: Which group 2 element reacts very slowly with water?
cards.definition: Magnesium

cards.term: What type of reaction is the reaction between group 2 metal and water?
cards.definition: Redox Reaction

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction of barium and water.
cards.definition: Ba (s) + 2H\xe2\x82\x82 O (l) \xe2\x86\x92 Ba(OH)\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + H\xe2\x82\x82 (g)

cards.term: What is oxidised and what is reduced in a reaction between group 2 metal and water?
cards.definition: Metal \xe2\x86\x92 oxidisedOne hydrogen atom from each water \xe2\x86\x92 reduced

cards.term: What are the products when a group 2 oxide reacts with an dilute acid?
cards.definition: Salt and water.

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction of calcium oxideand hydrochloric acid.
cards.definition: CaO (s) + 2HCl (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 CaCl\xe2\x82\x82 (s) + H\xe2\x82\x82O (l)

cards.term: What is formed when group 2 oxides react with water?
cards.definition: Metal Hydroxide

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction between a group 2 oxide and water.
cards.definition: MO (s) + H2O (l) \xe2\x86\x92 M(OH)2 (aq)

cards.term: What group 2 metal oxide is insoluble in water?
cards.definition: Beryllium Oxide

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction between Mg(OH)2 and nitric acid.
cards.definition: 2HNO3 (aq) + Mg(OH)2 (aq) Mg(NO3)2 (aq) + 2H2O (l)

cards.term: What is the trend in hydroxide solubility down group 2?
cards.definition: - Increases down the group- Mg(OH)\xe2\x82\x82 is slightly soluble- Ba(OH)\xe2\x82\x82 creates a strong alkaline solution

cards.term: What is the trend in sulphate solubility down group 2?
cards.definition: Group 2 sulphates become less soluble down the group with BaSO4 being the least soluble.

cards.term: Explain the reasons for the trend of thermal stability in group 1 and 2 carbonates.
cards.definition: Group 2 carbonates are more thermally stable as you go down the group this is because the cations get bigger so therefore have less of a polarising effect distorting the carbonate ion less. As C-O bond is not weakened as much it harder to break down.Group 1 carbonates do not decompose except for lithium. This is because they don\xe2\x80\x99t have a big enough charge density to polarise the carbonate ion as they only form 1+ ions. However Lithium ion is small enough to have a polarising effect so therefore lithium carbonate can decompose.

cards.term: Explain the reasons for the trend of thermal stability in group 1 and 2 nitrates.
cards.definition: The ease of thermal decomposition decreases down group 2 and this is because down the group the ions get larger and therefore has less charge density = less polarisation of nitrate anion and less weakening of the N\xe2\x80\x95O bond.Group 1 nitrate do not decompose with the exception of Lithium nitrate. Lithium ion is smaller enough to charge polarisation of the nitrate anion and thus weakening the N-O bond.

cards.term: How do you carry out a flame test?
cards.definition: 1. Use a nichrome wire.2. Sterilise the wire by dipping in concentrated hydrochloric acid and then heating in Bunsen flame.3. Make sure the sample powdered or grinded.4. Dip wire in solid and put in Bunsen flame and observe flame.

cards.term: How are the colours from the flame test formed?
cards.definition: The heat causes the electron to get excited and thus move to a higher energy level but at this higher level the electron is unstable so then moves back down. As it moves from a higher to lower energy level energy is emitted in the form of visible light energy which is the colour you see.

cards.term: What group elements are referred to as halogens?
cards.definition: Group 7
\xe2\x97\x8f Low melting and boiling points\xe2\x97\x8f Exist as diatomic molecules

cards.term: What is the trend in boiling point down group 7? Why?
cards.definition: Increases down the group because:- Size of atom increases as more occupied electron shells \xe2\x86\x92 stronger London forces of attraction between molecules, take more energy to break.

cards.term: What is the trend in reactivity down group 7? Why?
cards.definition: Reactivity decreases because:\xe2\x97\x8f Atomic radius increases\xe2\x97\x8f Electron shielding increases\xe2\x97\x8f Ability to gain an electron and form 1- ions decreases

cards.term: Explain the trend of electronegativity down group 7.
cards.definition: Down the group the electronegativity of the elements decreases. This is because the atomic radii increases due to the increasing number of shells so there is reduced nuclear attraction between the outermost electron and the nucleus.

cards.term: What is the trend in oxidising ability down the group? Why?
cards.definition: Decreases down group (Cl strongest, I weakest).This is because Cl has the fewest occupied electron shells, greatest force of attraction between outer electrons and nucleus and thus is the easiest to gain electrons and be reduced \xe2\x86\x92 best oxidising agent.

cards.term: What is the trend in reducing ability of the halides down the group? Why?
cards.definition: Increases down the group (Cl - weakest, I - strongest)This is because I - has the most occupied electron shell so outer electrons are further from the nucleus, weakest force of attraction between outer electrons and positive charge of nucleus and thus is the easiest to be oxidised and lose electrons \xe2\x86\x92 best reducing agent.

cards.term: Which species is oxidised in this reaction: Br2 (l) + 2Na (s) 2NaBr (s)
cards.definition: Na has been oxidised. Oxidation state of 0 to +1.

cards.term: When a more reactive halogen displaces a less reactive halide, what is the reaction called?
cards.definition: Displacement Reaction

cards.term: What is the colour of chlorine in water?
cards.definition: Pale Green

cards.term: What is the colour of bromine in water?
cards.definition: Orange

cards.term: What is the colour of iodine in water?
cards.definition: Brown

cards.term: What is the colour of chlorine in cyclohexane?
cards.definition: Pale Green

cards.term: What is the colour of bromine in cyclohexane?
cards.definition: Orange

cards.term: What is the colour of iodine in cyclohexane?
cards.definition: Violet

cards.term: Write the equation for chlorine oxidising bromide ions in water and associated colour change.
cards.definition: Cl\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2Br- (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 2Cl- (aq) + Br\xe2\x82\x82 (aq)Yellow solution

cards.term: Write the equation for Cl2 oxidising 2I- in cyclohexane and associated colour change.
cards.definition: Cl\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2I- (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 2Cl- (aq) + I\xe2\x82\x82 (aq)Purple solution

cards.term: Write the equation for bromine oxidising iodide ions in water and associated colour change.
cards.definition: Br\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2I- (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 2Br- (aq) + I\xe2\x82\x82 (aq)Brown solution
The oxidation and reduction of the same element in a redox reaction.

cards.term: What is the equation for the reaction of Cl\xe2\x82\x82 with water?
cards.definition: Cl\xe2\x82\x82 (g) + H\xe2\x82\x82O (l) \xe2\x86\x92 HClO (aq) + HCl (aq)

cards.term: What type of reaction is the reaction of chlorine with water?
cards.definition: Disproportionation; chlorine is both oxidised and reduced.

cards.term: Why is chlorine added to drinking water?
cards.definition: It kills the bacteria in the water and makes it safer to drink.

cards.term: What are the two forms of the chlorate ion?
cards.definition: ClO- is chlorate (I)ClO\xe2\x82\x83- is chlorate (V)

cards.term: What is the equation for forming bleach and conditions?
cards.definition: Cold dilute alkaliCl\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2NaOH (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 NaCl (aq) + NaClO (aq) + H\xe2\x82\x82O (l)NaClO is bleach

cards.term: Show that the reaction of chlorine with hot dilute NaOH is a disproportionation reaction.
cards.definition: 3Cl2 (aq) + 6 NaOH(aq) 5 NaCl (aq) + NaClO3 (aq) + 3H2 O (l)Chlorine is been reduced and oxidised.Oxidation state of chlorine has gone from:0 to -1 in NaCl = reduction0 to +1 in NaClO3 = oxidation

cards.term: What do you use to test for halide ions?
cards.definition: Acidified AgNO3

cards.term: What is the trend in oxidising ability down the group? Why?
cards.definition: Decreases down group (Cl best, I worst) because:Cl has fewest occupied electron shells, greatest force of attraction between outer electrons and nucleus, easiest to gain electrons and be reduced \xe2\x86\x92 best oxidising agent.

cards.term: What is the trend in reducing ability of the halides down the group? Why?
cards.definition: Increases down the group (Cl- worst, I- best) because:I - has the most occupied electron shells, so outer electrons are further from the nucleus, weakest force of attraction between outer electrons and positive charge of nucleus \xe2\x86\x92 easiest to be oxidised and lose electrons \xe2\x86\x92 best reducing aget.
No, not a powerful enough reducing agent; only HCl is formed.

cards.term: What are anions also known as?
cards.definition: Negative Ions

cards.term: What do you use to test for halide ions?
cards.definition: Acidified AgNO3

cards.term: When testing for carbonate, sulfate and halide ions, in which order should the tests be carried out and why?
cards.definition: 1. Carbonate test2. Sulfate test3. Halide testBecause barium ions forms insoluble precipitate of BaCO3 and silver ions form insolube precipitate of Ag2SO4.

cards.term: What are cations also known as?
cards.definition: Positive Ions

cards.term: What are the observations for positive ammonium ions test?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Red litmus paper turns blue\xe2\x97\x8f Ammonia has a pungent smell
Refers to the extent to which a compound decomposes when subjected to heating.

Movement of electrons between energy levels. When an electron in a ground state (a state when atom has all the electrons in lowest possible energy levels) absorbs some energy (e.g. thermal, from a flame), it can move to the excited state (a state of higher energy).When electrons get back from the excited state to the ground state, energy is released. If this energy corresponds to a particular wavelength in the visible light spectrum, we can observe colours (this is the explanation behind the flame test for Group I and Group II metal cations).
Ionic bonding occurs between a metal and a non-metal. Electrons are transferred from the metal to the non-metal to form full outer shells.
The average distance between two nuclei in a covalent bond.
The angle between two covalent bonds from the same atom.
The negative charge around a covalent bond is not evenly spread around the orbitals of the bonded atoms.

Polar molecules arise when there is an overall difference in polarity across the molecule, due to the arrangement of polar bonds and the geometry of the molecule. Polar molecules must have polar bonds, however a molecule with polar bonds may not necessarily be a polar molecule.

Hydrogen bonding is the strongest type of intermolecular force. Hydrogen bonds only act between hydrogen and the three most electronegative atoms: nitrogen, oxygen and fluorine. The lone pair on these atoms form a bond with a + hydrogen atom from another molecule,\xce\xb4 shown with a dotted line. H2O, NH3 and HF all have hydrogen bonds between molecules.

Water is a popular choice of solvent. Its hydrogen bonding capabilities allow it to dissolve some ionic compounds by solvating the individual ions, and to dissolve some alcohols by forming hydrogen bonds with their hydroxyl group.
Non-aqueous solvents are often used for compounds which have the same type of intermolecular force.

Hydrogen fluoride is the only hydrogen halide that forms hydrogen bonds between molecules. This gives it the highest boiling point because hydrogen bonds are much stronger than van der waals and permanent dipole forces.

Metallic bonding consists of a lattice of positively charged ions surrounded by a \xe2\x80\x98sea\xe2\x80\x99 of delocalised electrons. There are very strong electrostatic forces of attraction between these oppositely charged particles.

The physical properties of a substance include its boiling point, melting point, solubility and conductivity. They are different depending on the type of bonding present, the types of particle present and the crystal structure of the compound.

cards.term: Four main types of crystal structure.
cards.definition: 1. Ionic2. Metallic3. Simple molecular4. Macromolecular
Macromolecular covalent substances are covalently bonded into a giant lattice structure. Each atom has multiple covalent bonds which are very strong, giving the substance a very high melting point.

Diamond is a macromolecular structure made up of carbon atoms each bonded to four other carbon atoms. This forms a rigid tetrahedral structure, making diamond one of the hardest, strongest materials known - which is why it is often used on the tips of drills.
