Graphite is another macromolecular structure made up of carbon atoms. However, in graphite, each carbon atom is bonded to three others in flat hexagonal sheets. This means there is one delocalised electron per carbon atom. These electrons can move freely, allowing graphite to conduct electricity. Graphite can therefore be used in an electrode.
Graphene consists of single, 2D sheets of graphite that are just one atom thick.
Charged particles that is formed when an atom loses or gains electrons.

cards.term: What is the charge of the ion when electrons are gained?
cards.definition: NegativeN.B - positive charge when electrons are lostE.g. 3 + ion has lost 3 electrons
Covalently bonded atoms that lose or gain electrons.

cards.term: Which electrons are lost when an atom becomes a positive ion?
cards.definition: Electrons in the highest energy levels.

cards.term: Do metals usually gain or lose electrons?
cards.definition: Lose electronsN.B - non-metals generally gain electrons

cards.term: Which are the 4 elements that don\xe2\x80\x99t tend to form ions and why?
cards.definition: The elements are beryllium, boron, carbon and silicon. Requires a lot of energy to transfer outer shell electrons.

cards.term: What are the 3 main types of chemical bonds?
cards.definition: 1. Ionic2. Covalent3. Metallic
The electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions.

cards.term: Give an example of a ionically bonded substance.
cards.definition: NaCl (Sodium Chloride - Salt)

cards.term: What determines the strength of an ionic bond?
cards.definition: - Ionic radius and ionic charge.- Ionic bonding is stronger and the melting points higher when the ions are smaller and/ or have higher charges.

cards.term: Explain the trend in ionic radius down a group.
cards.definition: Ionic radii increases going down the group. This is because down the group the ions have more shells of electrons and thus the outermost electron experience less pull from positive nucleus.

cards.term: What are the physical properties of ionic compounds?
cards.definition: 1. High melting points2. Non-conductor of electricity when solid3. Conductor of electricity when in solution or molten4. Brittle
Electrostatic attraction between a shared pair of electrons and the nuclei.
Electrostatic attraction between the positive metal ions and the sea of delocalised electrons.

cards.term: Electrons in which shell are represented in a dot and cross diagram?
cards.definition: The outer shell.

cards.term: Why does giant ionic lattices conduct electricity when liquid but not when solid?
cards.definition: In solid state the ions are in fixed positions and thus cannot move. When they are in liquid state the ions are mobile and thus can freely carry the charge.

cards.term: Giant ionic lattices have high or low melting and boiling point? Explain your answer.
cards.definition: They have high melting and boiling point because a large amount of energy is required to overcome the electrostatic bonds.

cards.term: In what type of solvents do ionic lattices dissolve?
cards.definition: Polar solventsE.g water

cards.term: What is it called when atoms are bonded by a single pair of shared electrons?
cards.definition: Single Bond

cards.term: How many covalent bonds does carbon form?
How many covalent bonds does oxygen form?
What is the effect of multiple covalent bonds on bond length and strength?
cards.definition: Double/triple bonds exert greater electron density therefore the attraction between nucleus and electron is greater resulting in a shorter and stronger bond.
Electrons in the outer shell that are not involved in the bonding.

cards.term: What is formed when atoms share two pairs of electrons?
cards.definition: Double Bond

cards.term: What is formed when atoms share three pairs of electrons?
cards.definition: Triple Bond

cards.term: What is a dative covalent bond?
cards.definition: A bond where both of the shared electrons are supplied by one atom.

cards.term: What does expansion of the octet mean?
cards.definition: When a bonded atom has more than 8 electrons in the outer shell.

cards.term: What are the types of covalent structure?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Simple molecular lattice\xe2\x97\x8f Giant covalent lattice

cards.term: Describe the bonding in simple molecular structures.
cards.definition: Atoms within the same molecule are held by strong covalent bonds and different molecules are held by weak intermolecular forces.

cards.term: Why do simple molecular structures have low melting and boiling point?
cards.definition: Small amount of energy is enough to overcome the intermolecular forces.

cards.term: Can simple molecular structures conduct electricity?
cards.definition: No, they are non conductors.

cards.term: Why do simple molecular structures not conduct electricity?
cards.definition: The have no free charged particles to move around.

cards.term: Simple molecular structures dissolve in what type of solvent?
cards.definition: Non polar solvents.

cards.term: Give examples of giant covalent structures.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Diamond\xe2\x97\x8f Graphite\xe2\x97\x8f Silicon dioxide, SiO 2

cards.term: List some properties of giant covalent structures?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f High melting and boiling point\xe2\x97\x8f Non conductors of electricity, except graphite\xe2\x97\x8f Insoluble in polar and non polar solvents
Delocalised electrons present between the layers are able to move freely carrying the charge.

cards.term: Why do giant covalent structures have high melting and boiling point?
cards.definition: Strong covalent bonds within the molecules need to be broken which requires a lot of energy.

cards.term: What does the shape of a molecule depend on?
cards.definition: Number of electron pairs in the outer shell Number of these electrons which are bonded and lone pairs.

cards.term: By how many degrees does each lone pair reduce the bond angle?

cards.definition: The ability of an atom to attract the pair of electrons (the electron density) in a covalent bond.

cards.term: What scale is electronegativity measured on?
cards.definition: Pauling Scale

cards.term: In which direction of the periodic table does electronegativity increase?
cards.definition: Top right, towards fluorine

cards.term: What does it mean when the bond is non-polar?
cards.definition: The electrons in the bond are evenly distributed.

cards.term: What is the most electronegative element?
cards.definition: Fluorine

cards.term: How is a polar bond formed?
cards.definition: Bonding atoms have different electronegativities.

cards.term: Why is H2O polar, whereas CO2 is non polar?
cards.definition: CO2 is a symmetrical molecule, so there is no overall dipole.

cards.term: What is meant by intermolecular force?
cards.definition: Attractive force between neighbouring molecules.

cards.term: What are the 3 types of intermolecular forces?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Hydrogen bonding\xe2\x97\x8f Permanent dipoles\xe2\x97\x8f London forces
When a molecule with a permanent dipole is close to other non-polar molecules it causes the non-polar molecule to become slightly polar leading to attraction.
Some molecules with polar bonds have permanent dipoles \xe2\x86\x92 forces of attraction between those dipoles and those of neighbouring molecules.

\xe2\x97\x8f London forces are caused by random movements of electrons\xe2\x97\x8f This leads to instantaneous dipoles\xe2\x97\x8f Instantaneous dipole induces a dipole in nearby molecules\xe2\x97\x8f Induced dipoles attract one another

cards.term: Are London forces greater in smaller or larger molecules?
cards.definition: Larger due to more electrons.

cards.term: Does boiling point increase or decrease down the noble gas group? Why?
cards.definition: Boiling point increases because the number of electrons increases and hence the strength of London forces also increases.

cards.term: What conditions are needed for hydrogen bonding to occur?
cards.definition: O-H, N-H or F-H bond, lone pair of electrons on O, F, N Because O, N and F are highly electronegative, H nucleus is left exposed.Strong force of attraction between H nucleus and lone pair of electrons on O, N, F

cards.term: Why is ice less dense than liquid water?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f In ice, the water molecules are arranged in a orderly pattern. It has an open lattice with hydrogen bonds.\xe2\x97\x8f In water, the lattice is collapsed and the molecules are closer together.

cards.term: Why does water have a melting/ boiling point higher than expected?
cards.definition: Hydrogen bonds are stronger than other intermolecular forces so extra strength is required to overcome the forces.

cards.term: What type of intermolecular forces do alkanes have? Why?
cards.definition: London force \xe2\x86\x92 Induced dipole-dipole interaction, because the bonds are non-polar.

cards.term: What happens to the boiling point as alkane chain length increases? Why?
cards.definition: The boiling point increases because there is more surface area and so more number of induced dipole- dipole interaction. Therefore more energy required to overcome the attraction.

cards.term: Does a branched molecule have lower or higher boiling point compared to equivalent straight chain? Why?
cards.definition: The branched molecule has a lower boiling point because they have fewer surface area and hence less induced dipole -dipole interactions.

cards.term: Are alkanes soluble in water? why?
cards.definition: Insoluble because hydrogen bonds in water are stronger than alkanes\xe2\x80\x99 London forces of attraction.

cards.term: What kind of intermolecular forces do alcohols have? Why?
cards.definition: Hydrogen bonding, due to the electronegativity difference in the OH bond.

cards.term: How do alcohols\xe2\x80\x99 melting point and boiling point compare to other hydrocarbons\xe2\x80\x99 of similar C chain lengths? Why?
cards.definition: Higher, because they have hydrogen bonding (strongest type of intermolecular force) \xe2\x86\x92 Stronger than London Forces

cards.term: Are alcohols soluble in water? Why does solubility depend on chain length?
cards.definition: Soluble when short chain - OH hydrogen bonds to hydrogen bond in water.Insoluble when long chain - non-polarity of C-H bond takes precedence.
Strong electrostatic attraction between two oppositely charged ions. Strength of attraction depends on the relative sizes and charges of ions.
A positively charged ion.
A negatively charged ion.

Chemical species that have the same number of electrons, e.g. N^3\xe2\x88\x92, O^2\xe2\x88\x92, F^\xe2\x88\x92 ions are isoelectronic - they all have ten electrons. CO and N2 are isoelectronic molecules - they both have 14 electrons.

The strong electrostatic attraction between two nuclei and the shared pair of electrons between them. Polar covalent bond occurs when there is an asymmetric electron distribution within the covalent bond due to difference in electronegativities.

A bond that results from a direct (end-on) overlap of two orbitals, e.g. a sigma bond in H2 molecule is formed by overlap of two 1s orbitals. Similarly, a sigma bond in HCl is a result of the end-on overlap of 1s orbital of hydrogen with 3p orbital of chlorine.
A bond that is formed when two orbitals overlap sideways, e.g. a pi bond in C2H4.
Occurs when one atom donates both electrons in a bond.
Shapes adopted by the molecules so as to minimise the electronic replusions.
Different forms of the same element, e.g. allotropes of carbon are: diamond, graphite, graphene, fullerenes, carbon nanotubes etc.
A malleable substance can be shaped.
A ductile substance can be drawn into a wire.
Forces between the molecules (cf. bonding, an intramolecular force).
The ability of atom to attract the bonding electrons in a covalent bond. The most electronegative elements (N, O, F) are small and have a relatively high nuclear charge.
Difference in charge between the two atoms of a covalent bond caused by a shift in electron density in the bond due to the electronegativity difference between elements participating in bonding.
Strong electrostatic attraction between metal ions and the sea of delocalised electrons that surround them.
The electrons that are not contained within a single atom or a covalent bond.
Internuclear distance between two covalently bonded atoms.

Weak intermolecular forces arising due to fluctuations of electron density within a nonpolar molecule. These fluctuations may temporarily cause the asymmetric electron distribution: the molecule becomes an instantaneous dipole. This dipole can induce a dipole in another molecule, and so on. The attraction increases with size/shape (points of contact between the molecules) and number of electrons (more fluctuations = more instantaneous/induced dipoles).
Dipole-dipole attractions between polar molecules. Stronger than London forces.

A type of intermolecular force (with some bonding character) between a hydrogen bonded to a more electronegative atom than hydrogen (usually N, O, F) and other atom in a same different molecule. Directional nature - the bond angle is often 180\xc2\xb0. Responsible for anomalous properties of water, e.g. the density of ice < density of water. Ice occupies greater volume than water due to the directional nature of hydrogen bonds within the solid structure.
Isotopes are atoms of the same element with the same atomic number, but with a different number of neutrons, resulting in a different mass number.
The mean mass of an atom of an element, relative to one twelfth of the mean mass of an atom of the carbon-12 isotope.
The isotopic mass of an isotope relative to one twelfth of the mean mass of an atom of the carbon-12 isotope.
The mean mass of a molecule of a compound, relative to one twelfth of the mean mass of an atom of the carbon-12 isotope.
Relative formula mass is similar to Mr but is used for compounds with giant structures.

A sample of an element is vapourised and injected into the mass spectrometer where a high voltage is passed over the chamber. This causes electrons to be removed from the atoms (they are ionised) leaving +1 charged ions in the chamber.
These positively charged ions are then accelerated towards a negatively charged detection plate.
The ions are then deflected by a magnetic field into a curved path. The radius of their path is dependent on the charge and mass of the ion.
When the positive ions hit the negatively charged detection plate, they gain an electron producing a flow of charge. The greater the abundance, the greater the current produced.
These current values are then used in combination with the flight times to produce a spectra print-out with the relative abundance of each isotope displayed.
The minimum energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of atoms in a gaseous state. It is measured in kJ\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-1.

Successive ionisation energies occur when further electrons are removed. This usually requires more energy because as electrons are removed, the electrostatic force of attraction between the positive nucleus and the negative outer electron increases.
First ionisation energy increases due to a decreasing atomic radius and greater electrostatic forces of attraction.
First ionisation energy decreases due to an increasing atomic radius and electron shielding which reduces the effect of the electrostatic forces of attraction.

cards.term: What was stated in Dalton\xe2\x80\x99s atomic theory?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Atoms are tiny particles made of elements\xe2\x97\x8f Atoms cannot be divided\xe2\x97\x8f All the atoms in a element are the same\xe2\x97\x8f Atoms of one element are different to those of other elements

cards.term: What did Thompson discover about electrons?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f They have a negative charge\xe2\x97\x8f They can be deflected by electromagnetic fields\xe2\x97\x8f They have very small mass

cards.term: Explain the current model of the atom.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Protons and neutrons are found in the nucleus\xe2\x97\x8f Electrons orbit the nucleus in shells\xe2\x97\x8f The nucleus is tiny compared to the total volume of atom\xe2\x97\x8f Most of atom\xe2\x80\x99s mass is in the nucleus\xe2\x97\x8f Most of the atom is empty space between the nucleus and the electrons

cards.term: What is the charge of a proton and an electron?
cards.definition: Proton = +1Electron = -1

cards.term: Which particle has the same mass as proton?
cards.definition: Neutron

cards.term: Which two particles make up most of an atom\xe2\x80\x99s mass?
cards.definition: Protons and neutrons.

cards.term: What does the atomic number show about an element?
cards.definition: Atomic number = Number of protons in an atom
Mass number = Number of protons + Number of neutrons

cards.term: How to calculate the number of neutrons?
cards.definition: Number of neutrons = Mass number - Atomic number
Atoms of the same element with different number of neutrons and therefore different mass number.

cards.term: Why do different isotopes of the same element react in the same way?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Neutrons have no impact on the chemical reactivity\xe2\x97\x8f Reactions involve electrons, isotopes have the same number of electrons in the same arrangement
The weighted mean mass of an atom of an element compared with one-twelfth of the mass of an atom of carbon -12.
The mass of an atom of an isotope compared with one twelfth of the mass of an atom of carbon-12.

cards.term: The relative isotopic mass is same as which number?
cards.definition: Mass Number

cards.term: What two assumptions are made when calculating mass number?
cards.definition: 1. Contribution of the electron is neglected.2. Mass of both proton and neutron is taken as 1.0 u.

cards.term: How to calculate the relative molecular mass and relative formula mass?
cards.definition: Both can be calculated by adding the relative atomic masses of each of the atom making up the molecule or the formula.

cards.term: What are the uses of mass spectrometry?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Identify unknown compounds\xe2\x97\x8f Find relative abundance of each isotope of an element\xe2\x97\x8f Determine structural information

cards.term: What does the principal quantum number indicate?
cards.definition: The shell occupied by the electrons.
A group of orbitals with the same principal quantum number.

cards.term: How many electrons can the 1st shell hold?
How many electrons can the 2nd shell hold?
How many electrons can the 3rd shell hold?
How many electrons can the 4th shell hold?

cards.definition: A region around the nucleus that can hold up to two electrons with opposite spins.

cards.term: How many electrons can an orbital hold?
What are the 4 types of orbitals?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f s orbital\xe2\x97\x8f p orbital\xe2\x97\x8f d orbital\xe2\x97\x8f f orbital

cards.term: What is the shape of a s-orbital?
cards.definition: Spherical

cards.term: What is the shape of a p-orbital?
cards.definition: Dumb-bell Shape

cards.term: How many orbitals are found in a S subshell?
How many electrons can be held in a S subshell?
How many orbitals does P subshell have?
How many electrons can be held in a P subshell?
How many orbitals are present in a D subshell?
How many electrons can be held in a D subshell?
How many orbitals are found in a F subshell?
How many electrons can fill F subshell?
What letter used to represent shell number?
cards.definition: n

cards.term: From which shell onwards is S orbital present?
From which shell onwards is P-orbital present?
From which shell onwards is D-orbital present?
From which shell onwards is F-orbital present?
What are the rules by which electrons are arranged in the shell?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Electrons are added one at a time\xe2\x97\x8f Lowest available energy level is filled first\xe2\x97\x8f Each energy level must be filled before the next one can fill\xe2\x97\x8f Each orbital is filled singly before pairing\xe2\x97\x8f 4s is filled before 3d

cards.term: Why does 4s orbital fill before 3d orbital?
cards.definition: 4s orbital has a lower energy than 3d before it is filled.

cards.term: How can the electron configuration be written in short?
cards.definition: The noble gas before the element is used to abbreviate.

cards.term: How are the elements arranged in a periodic table?
cards.definition: Group number = number of electrons in the outer shell

cards.term: What is a period on a periodic table?
cards.definition: The horizontal rows.

cards.term: What is a group on a periodic table?
cards.definition: The vertical columns.

cards.term: How is the group number related to the number of electrons?
cards.definition: They are arranged in the order of increasing atomic numbers.

cards.term: Does the group number indicate horizontal or vertical columns in the periodic table?
cards.definition: Vertical Column
The repeating trends in chemical and physical properties.

cards.term: What change happens across each period?
cards.definition: Elements change from metals to non-metals.
The energy required to remove a mole of electrons from a mole of gaseous atoms to form one mole of gaseous 1+ ions under standard conditions.

cards.term: What are the factors that affect ionisation energy?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Atomic radius\xe2\x97\x8f Nuclear charge\xe2\x97\x8f Electron shielding or screening

cards.term: Why does first ionisation energy decrease between group 2 to 3?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Decreases between 2 to 3 because in group 3 the outermost electrons are in p orbitals.\xe2\x97\x8f Whereas in group 2 they are in s orbital, so the electrons are easier to be removed.

cards.term: Why does first ionisation energy decrease between group 5 to 6?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f The decrease between 5 to 6 is due to the group 5 electrons in p orbital which are single electrons.\xe2\x97\x8f In group 6 the outermost electrons are spin paired, with some repulsion.\xe2\x97\x8f Therefore the electrons are slightly easier to remove.

cards.term: Does first ionisation increase or decrease between the end of one period and the start of next? Why?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Decrease\xe2\x97\x8f There is increase in atomic radius\xe2\x97\x8f Increase in electron shielding

cards.term: Does first ionisation increase or decrease down a group? Why?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Decrease\xe2\x97\x8f Shielding increases \xe2\x86\x92 weaker attraction\xe2\x97\x8f Atomic radius increases \xe2\x86\x92 distance between the outer electrons and nucleus increases \xe2\x86\x92 weaker attraction\xe2\x97\x8f Increase in number of protons is outweighed by increase in distance and shielding

cards.term: Describe the structure, forces and bonding in every element across period 2.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Li & Be \xe2\x86\x92 giant metallic ; strong attraction between positive ions and delocalised electrons ; metallic bonding\xe2\x97\x8f B & C \xe2\x86\x92 giant covalent ; strong forces between atoms ; covalent\xe2\x97\x8f N2, O2, F2, Ne \xe2\x86\x92 simple molecular ; weak intermolecular forces between molecules ; covalent bonding within molecules and intermolecular forces between molecules

cards.term: Describe the structure, forces and bonding in every element across period 3.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Na, Mg, Al \xe2\x86\x92 giant metallic; strong attraction between positive ions and delocalised electrons; metallic bonding\xe2\x97\x8f Si \xe2\x86\x92 giant covalent; strong forces between atoms; covalent\xe2\x97\x8f P4, S8, Cl2, Ar \xe2\x86\x92 simple molecular; weak intermolecular forces between molecules; covalent bonding within molecules and intermolecular forces between molecules
Number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.
Sum of number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom.
Total charge of all the protons in the nucleus. It has the same value as the atomic number. Increases as you go across the periodic table.
Atoms of the same element with the same number of protons but different number of neutrons in the nucleus.
Average mass of an atom of an element, relative to 1/12th of the mass of an atom of carbon-12.
Average mass of an atom of an isotope relative to 1/12th of the mass of an atom of carbon-12.
Average mass of a molecule relative to 1/12th of the mass of an atom of carbon-12.
Same as electron shells. They specify the energy level of an electron.
The energy required to remove 1 mole of electrons from each atom in 1 moles of gaseous atoms to from 1 mole of gaseous 1+ ions.
The energy required to remove 1 mole of electrons from each ion in 1 moles of gaseous 1+ ions to form 1 moles of gaseous 2+ ions (could be asked for any successive ionisation energy).
A region in an atom that can hold up to two electrons with opposite spins.
Trends in element properties with increasing atomic number.
Electrons within the same orbital must have opposite spins.
As the atomic number increases, the electrons are added to the orbitals in order of increasing orbital energy until all electrons are accommodated. Notable exceptions: Cr, Cu.
A decrease in the nuclear charge experienced by an outer shell electron caused by electron-electron repulsion between the outer shell electron and electrons from adjacent quantum shells.

cards.term: What is the role of manganese dioxide in the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide?
cards.definition: Catalyst

cards.term: What is the purpose of catalysts?
cards.definition: 1. Provide an alternative reaction route with a lower activation energy.2. Increase the rate of reaction.

cards.term: What is meant by term \xe2\x80\x98half-life\xe2\x80\x99 for a reaction?
cards.definition: The time taken for the reactant concentration to half.

cards.term: Briefly describe how to find the half-life of the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide.
cards.definition: 1. Set up the apparatus to collect any gas produced during the reaction.2. Record the volume of O2 collected at regular intervals and calculate [H2O2].3. Plot a graph of [H2O2] against time and use it to find 2 values for the half-life.

cards.term: Why is it important to rapidly put the bung in the conical flask after H2O2 and the catalyst have been combined?
cards.definition: The reaction will have started so O2 will be produced. If the bung is not in place, oxygen will be escape (this won\xe2\x80\x99t be included in the volume measurement).

cards.term: Why might the volume of gas be measured in a burette rather than a measuring cylinder?
cards.definition: To obtain more precise measurements.
A variable that is kept constant throughout the experiment.
A factor that is changed during the experiment to see the effect it has on another factor.
A factor that is measured or observed in the experiment due to the changing of the independent variable.

cards.term: When plotting a graph what variables go on what axis?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f The independent variable is on the x-axis.\xe2\x97\x8f The dependent variable is on the y-axis.

cards.term: How do you measure the gradient of either a tangent or line of best fit?
cards.definition: Gradient = Change in y-coordinate \xc3\xb7 Change in x-coordinate
The deviation of a value from its expected value (i.e. a value that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t fit the trend).

cards.term: Why should anomalies be ignored when calculating a mean?
cards.definition: Not including anomalies in the mean value will make it much more accurate.

\xe2\x97\x8f A set of precise measurements will have very little spread about the mean.\xe2\x97\x8f However precision gives no idea of how close values are to the actual, true value- only how close values are to each other.
The more accurate the data, the closer it is to the actual value.
The uncertainty in a measurement is the interval within which the actual value is expected to lie.

cards.term: What is percentage uncertainty and how do you calculate it?
cards.definition: Percentage uncertainty in a measurement = 100 x absolute uncertainly / calculated value

cards.term: What are different ways you can improve apparatus to give more accurate results?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Increase the number of readings.\xe2\x97\x8f Control external variables.\xe2\x97\x8f Use measuring devices/equipment with greater precision.

cards.term: How do you use laboratory equipment to carry out a titration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f A pipette is used to accurately measure out the volume of a reactant before transferring it to a conical flask.\xe2\x97\x8f A burette is a measured, controlled and easy way to add small volumes of one reactant to another reactant.

cards.term: How do you use laboratory equipment to heat under reflux?
cards.definition: Quickfit apparatus is used to heat a substance under reflux.1. The substance is boiled in a pear-shaped or round-bottomed flask.2. As it evaporates, it is cooled by the water in the liebig condenser and so condenses back into a liquid and drips back down into the flask to be heated again.

cards.term: Why is heating under reflux used?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Allows heating for a long period of time.\xe2\x97\x8f Prevents the flask from boiling dry.\xe2\x97\x8f Prevents volatile reactants/products escaping.\xe2\x97\x8f Ensures even heating.

cards.term: How do you use laboratory equipment to carry out distillation?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f The substance you want to distill is heated in a pear-shaped or round-bottomed flask, causing it to evaporate.\xe2\x97\x8f When it reaches the condenser it will cool and condense back into a liquid which will then drip out into the collecting flask.

cards.term: How do you use laboratory equipment to filter under reduced pressure?
cards.definition: Using a Buchner funnel and Buchner flask, connected byrubber tubing to the vacuum source.\xe2\x97\x8f The funnel contains a layer of filter paper.\xe2\x97\x8f Pour the substance onto the filter paper and the liquid will be sucked through via vacuum filtration into the flask.\xe2\x97\x8f The solid will remain on the paper.
A standard solution is a solution of known concentration.

cards.term: How do you make a standard solution?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Measure, using a balance, the mass of solid required.\xe2\x97\x8f Transfer this to a volumetric flask and rinse the remaining weighing bottle content into the flask so no solid is lost.\xe2\x97\x8f Add a volume of distilled water to dissolve the solid. Swirl to mix.\xe2\x97\x8f Then add more distilled water up to the line on the neck of the volumetric flask. Invert multiple times to mix.

cards.term: When doing a titration, what are concordant results?
cards.definition: Titres that are within 0.1 cm^3 of each other.
To detect when a reaction reaches completion/becomes neutral, usually by the presence of a colour change.

cards.term: How do you purify a solid product?
cards.definition: By recrystallisation.\xe2\x97\x8f Add minimum amount of warm solvent to the impure sample until it has dissolved.\xe2\x97\x8f Allow to cool, crystals should form.\xe2\x97\x8f When no more form you can filter under reduced pressure to obtain a dry crystalline solid.

cards.term: How do you purify a liquid product?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f You can use a separating funnel to isolate the organic layer from the aqueous layer.\xe2\x97\x8f You can then purify the liquid by distillation, which separates the substances by boiling point.

cards.term: How do you determine the melting point of a substance and why can this information be useful?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Place a small sample of the solid in a capillary tube.\xe2\x97\x8f Melt using the melting apparatus available, measuring the temperature with a thermometer.\xe2\x97\x8f A pure substance will usually melt at a single temperature (or a very small range) but an impure substance will melt over a range of temperatures (usually lower than that of the pure substance).\xe2\x97\x8f Record the starting and ending points of the melting, when the first crystal can be seen to melt and when the last crystal becomes liquid respectively.\xe2\x97\x8f You can then compare the melting point to known values to identify the substance.

cards.term: What are the uses of thin layer or paper chromatography?
cards.definition: To separate a mixture into its constituent components for analysis. This allows identification by the calculation and comparison of R_f values.

cards.term: How do you calculate an R_f value?
cards.definition: R_f value = Distance travelled by component \xc3\xb7 Distance travelled by solvent

cards.term: How do you set up an electrochemical cell?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Two half cells are set up and connected to each other via a salt bridge (which allows the flow of ions).\xe2\x97\x8f Each electrode is then connected to avoltmeter which will measure the cell potential.

cards.term: How can rate of reaction be measured?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Initial rates method- i.e. the iodine clock reaction.\xe2\x97\x8f A continuous monitoring method- i.e. measuring the volume of gas released in a reaction over time.

cards.term: What is the weighing by difference method?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f It is a method to weigh materials accurately.\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of substance = Mass of weighing dish and substance - Mass of dish after substance has been transferred.

cards.term: Why may an experimental value for enthalpy change be different to the actual value?
cards.definition: 1. Heat loss to apparatus/surroundings.2. Incomplete combustion.3. Non-standard conditions.4. Evaporation of alcohol/water.

cards.term: What is heating to constant mass?
cards.definition: The repeated heating and weighing of a substance until the mass no longer changes.

cards.term: How do you measure the volume of gas given off from a reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Using a gas syringe.\xe2\x97\x8f The plunger is pushed out of the syringe as more and more gas is collected.\xe2\x97\x8f You can read the volume of gas from the scale along the side of the syringe.
Using:\xe2\x97\x8f pH charts\xe2\x97\x8f A pH meter,\xe2\x97\x8f A pH probe with a data logger

cards.term: How can we keep a substance at a constant temperature?
cards.definition: By using a water bath. This allows us to control temperature and keep it constant.

cards.term: How can the percentage of iron in iron tablets be found?
cards.definition: 1. Prepare a standard solution of iron (II) using the tablets and sulfuric acid.2. Titrate a set volume of this iron(II) solution against a solution of KMnO4.3. Repeat until you obtain concordant results and calculate a mean titre.4. Calculate the number of moles of KMnO4 that reacted.5. Use the ratio in the chemical equation to calculate the number of moles of iron that reacted.6. Calculate the percentage mass of iron using the mass present in the standard solution.

cards.term: What is a prediction using scientific knowledge called?
cards.definition: Hypothesis

cards.term: What is meant by the term accuracy?
cards.definition: How close the measurement is to the true value.
Factors that can affect the outcome of the experiment.
A factor that is changed during the experiment to see the effect it has on another factor.
A factor that is measured or observed in the experiment.
A factor that is kept constant throughout the experiment.
The loss of electrons or increase in oxidation state.
The gain of electrons or decrease in oxidation state.
A reaction in which some atoms are oxidised and others are reduced.

cards.term: Describe how to make a standard solution of acidified iron(II) sulfate.
cards.definition: 1. Grind up some iron tablets. Measure the total mass of the iron tablets in a weighing boat.2. Add the powdered tablets to a conical flask and reweigh the weighing boat. The difference between the masses is the mass of iron tablets in the solution.3. Add a 50 cm^3 of sulfuric acid to the conical flask to dissolve the iron. Stopper the flask and shake well. Leave the flask for the residue to settle.4. Filter the solution into a volumetric flask without disturbing the residue. Rinse the filter paper with a small volume of distilled water.5. Fill the volumetric flask up to the graduation mark with sulfuric acid then stopper and invert the flask to mix.

cards.term: When making a standard solution, what method should be used to find the mass of solute?
cards.definition: Weighing-by-difference method.

cards.term: In a titration, what are concordant results?
cards.definition: Titres that are within 0.1 cm^3 of each other.

cards.term: Give 3 possible sources of error in this experiment.
cards.definition: 1. The iron may not completely dissolve - warming may help.2. Some iron may not be transferred between containers - take washings.3. The end point may be hard to see - place a white tile underneath the conical flask to make the colour change easier to observe.

cards.term: What equation links concentration, moles and volume?
cards.definition: n = V x CWhere:n - molesV  - volumeC - concentration

cards.term: What equation links mass, molecular mass and number of moles?
cards.definition: m = M x nwhere:m - mass (g)M - molecular massn - mole
A new set of data that has been collected. Conclusions are drawn from this new data.

cards.term: Give two examples of primary research.
cards.definition: 1. Surveys2. Experiments
Data from other studies that are used to draw conclusions.

cards.term: What is the difference between qualitative and quantitative data?
cards.definition: Qualitative - descriptions of observationsQuantitative - numerical data

cards.term: Online and offline resources can be used for what?
cards.definition: Research

Full references are numbered at the end of a document (with numbers linked to the appropriate reference in they order they appear in the text).E.g. 1. Author (year of publication), titleOther information such as the page number, volume/ issue number, web address or date of access (online only) may also need to be recorded.

The authors name and the date of the work are put in brackets at an appropriate point in the text.E.g. Universal indicator can be used to measure pH (author, date).The references are listed at the end of the document in alphabetical order without numbers. If there are more than 3 authors, write the first name followed by \xe2\x80\x98et al.\xe2\x80\x99.

cards.term: What is the general reference format for books?
cards.definition: Author (year), Title, edition (if relevant), publisher\xe2\x80\x99s location, publisher.

cards.term: What is the general reference format for journal articles?
cards.definition: Author (year), \xe2\x80\x98Article title\xe2\x80\x99, Journal title, volume number, issue number, pp.xxx-xxx(where pp. xxx-xxx is the range of pages)

cards.term: What is the general reference format for websites?
cards.definition: Author (year), Title. [online] Last accesseddate: URLIf the author is not listed on the webpage, name the organisation.

cards.term: Give 3 ways you could identify whether a solution was acidic or basic.
cards.definition: 1. Litmus paper2. Indicator (e.g. universal indicator) and comparison to a colour scale3. pH meter

cards.term: How can litmus paper be used to identify an alkali?
cards.definition: Red litmus paper will turn blue.Blue litmus paper will remain blue.

cards.term: How can litmus paper be used to identify an acid?
cards.definition: Blue litmus paper will turn red.Red litmus paper will remain red.

cards.term: Why might a pH meter be used rather than universal indicator to measure pH?
cards.definition: 1. Gives a numerical value for pH.2. More accurate (typically read to 2 decimal places.

cards.term: What is meant by the term \xe2\x80\x98accuracy\xe2\x80\x99?
cards.definition: How close the measurement is to the true value.

cards.term: Briefly outline how to carry out a titration.
cards.definition: 1. Use a pipette to measure the first solution into a conical flask.2. Add a few drops of a suitable indicator.3. Add the other solution into a burette and record the initial volume.4. Slowly add the solution in the burette into the conical flask.5. Swirl the mixture continuously until the end point is reached.6. Repeat until concordant results are obtained.

cards.term: What colour is methyl orange in:a) Acid?b) Alkali?c) Neutral solution?
cards.definition: a) Redb) Yellowc) Orange

cards.term: What is the colour of phenolphthalein in:a) Acid?b) Alkali?
cards.definition: a) Colourlessb) Pink
A substance that donates protons (H+).
A substance that accepts protons (H+).

cards.term: What is the difference between a strong and weak acid?
cards.definition: A strong acid completely dissociates in solution (readily releases H+ ions) whereas a weak acid only partially dissociates.

cards.term: A solution has a pH of 1.00 when measured using a pH meter. Suggest the characteristics of this solution.
cards.definition: 1. Acidic.2. Likely to contain a strong acid.
A reaction in which the concentration of a reagent quickly changes after a certain time period, causing a colour change.

cards.term: Briefly describe a method that could be followed to find the order of reaction with respect to iodide ions in the iodine clock reaction
cards.definition: 1. Mix potassium iodide, sodium thiosulfate and starch solutions in a conical flask.2. Add potassium peroxodisulphate and start the timer.3. Record the time taken for the solution to turn blue-black.4. Repeat steps 1-3 with varying concentrations of KI.

cards.term: How can the order of a reactant be deduced from the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: The rate of reaction is proportional to 1/time. Use changes in the rate of reaction and concentrations to deduce the order with respect to each reagent.

cards.term: What equation links moles, volume and concentration?
cards.definition: n = V x Cwhere:n - molesV - volumeC - concentration

cards.term: How can the initial rate be calculated for an iodine clock reaction?
cards.definition: Initial rate = Moles of iodine (mol) / Time taken for colour change (s)

cards.term: Give 2 possible sources of error in an iodine clock experiment.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Inaccurate timing of the appearance of blue colour:\xe2\x86\x92 Could have two students timing the experiment and calculate an average value.\xe2\x97\x8f Adding starch slightly increases the volume which affects the concentrations of the reactants and thus the amount they change over time.

cards.term: Suggest some control variables for this experiment.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Total volume of reactants.\xe2\x97\x8f Volume of starch and thiosulfate used.\xe2\x97\x8f The concentrations of all the reagents (except potassium iodide solution).\xe2\x97\x8f Temperature (as this can also affect the rate of reaction).

cards.term: What is the overall order of the reaction between iodide ions and peroxodisulphate ions?
What must a half cell contain?
cards.definition: An element in 2 oxidation states.

cards.term: Define the terms oxidation and reduction.
cards.definition: Oxidation - loss of electronsReduction - gain of electrons

cards.term: Why must metal electrodes be cleaned with sandpaper before creating an electrochemical cell?
cards.definition: To remove any metal oxide that has formed on the surface and improve electrical conductivity.

cards.term: Describe the movement of electrons in an electrochemical cell.
cards.definition: Electrons flow through the wire from the positive electrode to the negative electrode.

cards.term: In an standard Zn/Zn^2+ cell, what is the role of potassium nitrate solution?
cards.definition: Potassium nitrate is used to saturate a piece of filter paper so that it can be used as a salt bridge.

cards.term: Why is a salt bridge used in an electrochemical cell?
cards.definition: To maintain the charge balance and complete the circuit.This is because negative electrons are moving from one half-cell to another. Without the salt bridge, positive charge would build up in the half cell containing the anode and negative charge would build up in the half cell containing the cathode. This would cause the reaction to stop.

cards.term: Why must an inert salt be used in the salt bridge?
cards.definition: So that the salt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t react with the solutions and alter their concentrations. If a reactive salt was used, the cell potential would change.

cards.term: What moves across the salt bridge?
cards.definition: Ions

cards.term: In an electrochemical cell, each metal electrode is placed in a solution containing what?
cards.definition: Its ionsE.g. solid copper is placed in a solution of copper(II) sulfate

cards.term: After setting up an electrochemical cell, the reading on the voltmeter is negative. What should be done?
cards.definition: Switch the connection of the wires so the electrodes are the right way round.

cards.term: What is the formula for the electromotive force (EMF)?
cards.definition: EMF = E_R \xe2\x88\x92 E_Lwhere:E_R - right hand cell, where the reduction occurs, and E_L - left hand cell, where oxidation occurs.

cards.term: For a reaction to be thermodynamically feasible, what must the value of the EMF be?
cards.definition: Positive

cards.term: What reagent is used to test for the presence of an alkene?
cards.definition: Bromine Water

cards.term: What is observed when bromine water is added to an alkene?
cards.definition: The solution will change from orange to colourless.

cards.term: What is observed when bromine water is added to a saturated hydrocarbon?
cards.definition: The solution remains orange.

cards.term: Briefly describe how to test for haloalkanes
cards.definition: 1. Heat the sample with a solution of sodium hydroxide under reflux to releases any halide ions2. Add some dilute nitric acid3. Add silver nitrate solution and observe the colour of any precipitate formed

cards.term: What colour precipitate forms when silver nitrate solution reacts with chloride ions?
cards.definition: White

cards.term: What colour precipitate forms when silver nitrate solution reacts with bromide ions?
cards.definition: Cream

cards.term: What colour precipitate forms when silver nitrate solution reacts with iodide ions?
cards.definition: Yellow

cards.term: Describe the solubilities of the silver halide precipitates in dilute and concentrated ammonia.
cards.definition: AgCl - soluble in dilute and concentrated ammoniaAgBr - soluble in concentrated ammoniaAgI - insoluble in ammonia

cards.term: Briefly describe how to test for carboxylic acids.
cards.definition: Add some sodium carbonate solution to the sample. If a carboxylic acid is present, there will be effervescence and CO_2 will be produced.To test the gas, bubble it through limewater. CO_2 will cause the limewater to turn cloudy.

cards.term: What reagent can be used to test for the presence of an alcohol?
cards.definition: Acidified potassium dichromate solution.

cards.term: What is observed when a primary or secondary alcohol is heated under reflux with acidified potassium dichromate solution?
cards.definition: There is a colour change from orange to green.

cards.term: What is observed when a tertiary alcohol is heated under reflux with acidified potassium dichromate solution?
cards.definition: No colour change - solution remains orange.

cards.term: What 2 reagents can be used to distinguish between an aldehyde and a ketone?
cards.definition: 1. Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s solution2. Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 solution

cards.term: What is observed when Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s reagent is heated with:a) An aldehyde?b) A ketone?
cards.definition: a) Brick red precipitate forms.b) No precipitate forms, solution remains a deep blue colour.

cards.term: What is observed when Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 solution is heated with:a) An aldehyde?b) A ketone?
cards.definition: a) Silver mirror forms on the surface of the test tube.b) No change observed.

cards.term: What is Brady\xe2\x80\x99s reagent used to identify?Describe the positive result for this test.
cards.definition: Used to identify carbonyls (aldehydes or ketones).A yellow-orange precipitate forms in the presence of a carbonyl.

cards.term: Briefly describe the test for phenol and the positive result for this test.
cards.definition: Add bromine water.If phenol is present, the solution will change from orange to colourless and a white precipitate will form.

cards.term: When would a water bath or electric heater be used instead of a Bunsen burner to heat a sample?
cards.definition: 1. When the temperature needs to be controlled more.2. When the chemicals being heated are highly flammable.

cards.term: What two reactants are used to synthesis methyl 3-nitrobenzoate?
cards.definition: Methyl benzoateNitric acid

cards.term: What is the purpose of concentrated sulfuric acid in the synthesis methyl 3-nitrobenzoate?
cards.definition: Catalyst (speeds up the rate of reaction).

cards.term: In the preparation stage of methyl 3-nitrobenzoate, what should the temperature be kept below? Why?
cards.definition: Below 10\xc2\xb0C, to maximise yield.

cards.term: Describe the process of filtration under reduced pressure.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Place a piece of filter paper in a B\xc3\xbcchner funnel.\xe2\x97\x8f Place the funnel in a B\xc3\xbcchner flask. Connect the side arm of the flask to a water pump.\xe2\x97\x8f Connect the water pump to a tap and turn the tap on to create the vacuum. Pour the solution into the funnel.\xe2\x97\x8f Once the solution has drained through, rinse the solid on the filter paper with a small volume of solvent.

\xe2\x97\x8f Dissolve the solid in the minimum volume of hot solvent.\xe2\x97\x8f Filter to remove insoluble impurities.\xe2\x97\x8f Cool the filtrate.\xe2\x97\x8f Filter to remove soluble impurities (the product remains on the filter paper).

cards.term: Why is ethanol used for the recrystallisation of methyl 3-nitrobenzoate?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Methyl 3-nitrobenzoate is soluble in ethanol but not water.\xe2\x97\x8f Ethanol is a cheap and relatively safe solvent.

cards.term: During recrystallisation, why is the product dissolved in a minimum amount of solvent?
cards.definition: If there is a large volume of solvent when the mixture is cooled (and solubility decreased), some of the product may remain in solution.

cards.term: How does recrystallisation improve the purity of a product?
cards.definition: The desired product is dissolved in an appropriate solvent that the impurities are insoluble in. Subsequent filtration leaves the insoluble impurities on the filter paper while the solution flows through.

cards.term: Why is the solution cooled in ice immediately after recrystallisation?
cards.definition: To decrease the solubility of the product so that it crystallises. Lower temperatures increase the size of crystals formed.

cards.term: Why must the crystals be completely dry before measuring their mass to calculate the percentage yield?
cards.definition: Excess solvent on the crystals could falsely increase the yield.

cards.term: How can percentage yield be calculated?
cards.definition: (Actual yield \xc3\xb7 Maximum theoretical yield) x 100

cards.term: Give 3 reasons why the yield may be lower than 100%
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Product may be lost when filtering/ transferring between apparatus.\xe2\x97\x8f Some product may stay in solution after recrystallisation.\xe2\x97\x8f Other side reactions may occur.

cards.term: What technique could be used to investigate the purity of the productbefore and after recrystallisation?
cards.definition: Thin layer chromatography - comparison of Rf values from the product before and after recrystallisation to a pure lab sample.

cards.term: What piece of apparatus is used to transfer a small amount of each liquid onto the chromatography plate?
cards.definition: Capillary tube

cards.term: During chromatography, why should the beaker containing the solvent and the TLC plate be covered with a clear watch glass?
cards.definition: To prevent the evaporation of the solvent. The watch glass should be clear to allow the plate to be monitored.

cards.term: In chromatography, what is the solvent front?
cards.definition: The furthest distance travelled by the solvent up the TLC plate.

cards.term: Why should the baseline be drawn in pencil on a TLC plate?
cards.definition: Pencil is insoluble in solvent so it won\xe2\x80\x99t travel up the plate and obscure the results.

cards.term: When using chromatography to assess the purity of a sample of methyl 3-nitrobenzoate, what is used to make the spots visible?
cards.definition: Iodine Crystals

cards.term: How do you calculate an Rf value?
cards.definition: Rf = Distance travelled by the substance / Distance travelled by the solvent

cards.term: Without using chromatography, how can the purity of a sample be assessed?
cards.definition: Use melting point apparatus, pure substances have a specific melting point whereas impure substances will melt over a larger range of temperatures. The smaller the range, the purer the sample.

cards.term: What safety precautions should be taken during this practical?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Methyl 3-nitrobenzoate is an irritant so wear safety goggles and avoid contact with skin.\xe2\x97\x8f Iodine crystals are harmful if in contact with skin or when inhaled so avoid contact with skin and keep away from your face.\xe2\x97\x8f Methyl benzoate is an irritant so wear safety goggles and avoid contact with skin.\xe2\x97\x8f Ethanol is highly flammable so keep away from naked flames.

cards.term: What type of reaction occurs when a haloalkane is formed from an alcohol?
cards.definition: Nucleophilic substitution

cards.term: Write the word and chemical equations for the formation of 2-chloro-2-methylpropane from 2-methylpropan-2-ol
cards.definition: 2-methylpropan-2-ol + hydrochloric acid \xe2\x86\x92 2-chloro-2 methylpropane + water

cards.term: What are the 3 main stages in the synthesis of a haloalkane from an alcohol?
cards.definition: 1. Preparation2. Separation3. Distillation

cards.term: Why do 2 layers form in the separating funnel when synthesising a haloalkane from an alcohol?
cards.definition: The aqueous and organic layers have different densities and they are immiscible.

cards.term: What is the purpose of anti-bumping granules?
cards.definition: To prevent the formation of large gas bubbles that cause violent boiling.During distillation, anti-bumping granules prevents the mixture boiling over into the condenser meaning impurities won\xe2\x80\x99t contaminating the product.

cards.term: When producing a haloalkane from an alcohol, why is sodium hydrogen carbonate added to the organic layer after it has been separated from the aqueous layer?
cards.definition: To react with any leftover hydrochloric acid.

cards.term: Why is it important to open the stopper of the separating funnel regularly?
cards.definition: To release the build up of pressure and reduce the risk of apparatus breaking.

cards.term: When producing a haloalkane from an alcohol, why is anhydrous sodium sulfate added to the organic mixture after separation?
cards.definition: To remove water (small amounts only) - acts as a drying agent.

cards.term: Why is distillation used when synthesising a haloalkane from an alcohol?
cards.definition: To separate and purify the organic product.

cards.term: Describe the key features of the apparatus set-up for distillation
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Tilt the condenser down so any liquids flow into the beaker.\xe2\x97\x8f The water must enter at the bottom of the condenser and leave at the top for efficient cooling.\xe2\x97\x8f The collection flask should not be sealed to the condenser it should not be airtight as the hot air in the system could cause the apparatus to crack.\xe2\x97\x8f Use a thermometer to identify when the desired product has evaporated from the reaction mixture.

cards.term: Why might a water bath or electric heater be used instead of a Bunsen burner to heat a reaction mixture?
cards.definition: If the reactants are flammable as using a Bunsen burner would be a safety risk.

cards.term: What safety precautions should be taken when carrying out this practical?
cards.definition: 1. 2-methylpropan-2-ol is highly flammable and harmful if inhaled. Keep away from naked flames and keep the lab well ventilated.2. Concentrated sulfuric acid causes severe skin burns and eye damage. Use a fume cupboard and wear safety goggles and gloves.3. Take care when heating apparatus. Move hot apparatus with tongs to avoid burns.
Calorimetry is a process used to find the amount of energy released or used in a chemical reaction.

cards.term: What type of reaction releases energy to the surroundings?
cards.definition: Exothermic

cards.term: What type of reaction takes in energy from the surroundings?
cards.definition: Endothermic
A reaction between an acid and a base, form a salt and water.

cards.term: What is meant by the term standard enthalpy change of neutralisation?
cards.definition: The enthalpy change that accompanies the formation of 1 mole of water from a neutralisation reaction under standard conditions.

cards.term: Write the word and chemical equations for the neutralisation reaction between sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid.
cards.definition: Hydrochloric acid + sodium hydroxide \xe2\x86\x92 sodium chloride + waterHCl + NaOH \xe2\x86\x92 NaCl + H2O

cards.term: The enthalpy change of a neutralisation reaction is being investigated. Why might this reaction carried out in a styrofoam cup?
cards.definition: A styrofoam cup is a better thermal insulator than a glass beaker so the less heat will be lost to the surroundings meaning the calculated temperature change is more accurate.

cards.term: What equation is used to calculate the energy absorbed by the solution?
cards.definition: Q = mc\xce\x94Twhere:m - mass of the solution (g)c - specific heat capacity of the solution (the value for water is used)\xce\x94T - temperature change (\xc2\xb0C or K)Q - heat energy (J)

cards.term: How is the enthalpy change of neutralisation calculated from Q, the energy absorbed by the solution?
cards.definition: The number of moles can be calculated by using mol = volume x concentration for the hydrochloric acid used.

cards.term: How can you find the maximum temperature reached during a neutralisation reaction?
cards.definition: Plot a graph of temperature (y axis) against time (x axis) and extrapolating to the time that the reactants were combined.

cards.term: Suggest 3 possible sources of error when investigating the enthalpy change of neutralisation. How could these errors be reduced?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Heat transfer to and from surroundings.\xe2\x97\x8f Incomplete combustion if using fuel.     \xe2\x97\x8b Bomb calorimeter could be used to combat these two errors.\xe2\x97\x8f Inaccuracy in temperature measurement.     \xe2\x97\x8b Use an electronic thermometer.

cards.term: Describe and experiment to investigate the enthalpy change of neutralisation of a reaction between hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide.
cards.definition: 1. Add 25 cm^3 HCl(aq) to a polystyrene cup. Place the cup in a glass beaker. Measure 25 cm^3 NaOH(aq).2. Start the timer. Record the initial temperature of the HCl at minute intervals for 3 minutes.3. At the fourth minute, add the sodium hydroxide. Do not record the temperature.4. Continue recording the temperature at minute intervals from 5 to 10 minutes. Stir the solution when measuring the temperature.

cards.term: What apparatus is used in a titration to accurately measure volumes?
cards.definition: - Burette to measure the volume of solution added- Pipette and pipette filler to measure a specific volume of solution into the conical flask

- Add roughly the desired mass of a substance to a weighing bottle and weigh- Transfer the substance to a beaker / conical flask- Reweigh the weighing bottle- The difference between the masses is the mass of solid

cards.term: Describe how to carry out an acid-base titration.
cards.definition: 1. Use a pipette to add 25 cm^3 of acid to a conical flask. Add a few drops of indicator.2. Pour alkali into the burette. Record the initial burette volume.3. Complete a trial titre. The conical flask should be swirled constantly above a white tile. Stop adding the alkali as soon as the end point is reached. Record the final burette volume.4. Repeat the titration until two concordant results are obtained. Add alkali drop by drop near the end point. (25 cm^3 of alkali may initially be put into the conical flask if the burette is filled with acid)

cards.term: When transferring a solution from one beaker to another, how can you ensure as much of the dissolved substance has been transferred as possible?
cards.definition: Use distilled water to wash any leftover solution from the old apparatus into the new beaker.

cards.term: How do you accurately fill a volumetric flask to the graduated mark?
cards.definition: Fill so the bottom of the meniscus rests on the graduated mark.The meniscus is the curve of the liquid.
A solution of a known concentration.

cards.term: Describe how to make a standard solution of NaHCO_3.
cards.definition: 1. Weigh out a specified amount of NaHCO_32. Add a small volume of distilled water to the beaker containing the NaHCO_3 to dissolve it.3. Use a funnel to add the solution to a 250 cm^3 volumetric flask4. Rinse the beaker with distilled water and add the washings to the flask5. Make the flask up to the graduation mark with distilled water6. Stopper and shake the flask

cards.term: Suggest 2 indicators that could be used in an acid-base titration.
cards.definition: 1. Phenolphthalein2. Methyl orange

cards.term: State the colour of phenolphthalein in:a) Acidic conditionsb) Basic conditions
cards.definition: a) Pinkb) Colourless

cards.term: State the colour of methyl orange in:a) Acidic conditionsb) Basic conditions
cards.definition: a) Redb) Yellow(Orange at the end point of a titration)

cards.term: What are concordant results in a titration?
cards.definition: Titres that are within 0.1 cm^3 of each other.

cards.term: What degree of precision should burette readings be recorded to?
cards.definition: To the nearest 0.05 cm^3.

cards.term: Which results are used when calculating a mean titre?
cards.definition: 2 concordant results (within 0.10 cm 3 of each other).

cards.term: When completing a titration, what piece of apparatus is used to make the colour change easier to observe?
cards.definition: A white tileThis is placed underneath the conical flask.

cards.term: What 3 things are required to take an accurate burette reading?
cards.definition: 1. Read from the bottom of the meniscus2. Allow any liquid on the walls of the burette to settle before taking a reading3. Ensure there are no air bubbles

cards.term: What is the end point of a titration?
cards.definition: The first point at which the indicator changes colour (permanently)

cards.term: Why is the conical flask swirled during a titration?
cards.definition: To ensure all the reactants are combined so that the reaction is complete.

cards.term: Why is it better to have a titre volume of 25 cm^3 than 10 cm^3?
cards.definition: The larger the titre volume, the smaller the percentage error.

cards.term: What equation links number of moles and concentration?
cards.definition: Number of moles = concentration x volumen = C x V

cards.term: If you know the volume of acid required to neutralise an alkali, how could youcalculate the concentration of the acid, given the alkali concentration and volume?
cards.definition: - Calculate the number of moles of the alkali using the known volume and concentration (n = C x V)- Use the chemical equation to work out the ratio of acid and alkali that react and hence work out how many mole of acid have reacted- Divide the moles of acid by the volume used in neutralisation

cards.term: How can the number of moles of CO2 be calculated from the volume of CO2 collected during an experiment?
cards.definition: - If at room temperature and pressure (RTP), use the equation n = V/24 where V is the volume in dm^3 .- If not at RTP, rearrange the ideal gas law PV = nRT and plug in the numbers for R (8.31), T in Kelvin, P in Pascals and V in m^3.

cards.term: What is used to accurately measure mass?
cards.definition: A digital balance that records mass to 2 decimal places.

cards.term: Give 3 possible sources of error when investigating the volume of gas produced in a reaction.
cards.definition: 1. Some gas could have escaped before the bung is put in the conical flask.2. The reaction may be incomplete.3. Some gas may dissolve in the water meaning a smaller volume would collected than was released.

cards.term: How can measuring the volume of gas produced during the reaction between magnesium and sulfuric acid be used to determine the relative atomic mass of magnesium?
cards.definition: - Measure the mass of some magnesium then react it with sulfuric acid.- Measure the volume of hydrogen gas produced in a gas syringe or an upturned water-filled measuring cylinder.- Calculate the number of moles of H_2 produced (number of moles = volume / 24 dm^3).- Use the ratio in the chemical equation to find the number of moles of magnesium.- Since the original mass of magnesium is known, the relative atomic mass can be calculated by dividing mass of magnesium by the number of moles.

cards.term: Give 2 possible causes of sources in this experiment.
cards.definition: - Some hydrogen gas may escape before the bung is put in the conical flask.- Some magnesium may not react.

cards.term: Why is it important to rapidly put the bung in the conical flask after adding the sulfuric acid?
cards.definition: The reaction starts as soon as the acid is added so H_2 will start to be produced. To reduce the amount of H_2 that escapes, the bung should be inserted rapidly.

cards.term: What equation links moles, molecular mass and mass?
cards.definition: Mass (grams) = molecular mass x number of moles (mol)m = M x n

cards.term: What safety precautions should be taken when conducting an experiment with magnesium and sulfuric acid?
cards.definition: - Sulfuric acid cause skin and eye irritation so wear safety goggles and avoid contact with skin.- Magnesium is highly flammable so keep away from naked flames.

cards.term: What are the 3 main types of chemical bonds?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Ionic\xe2\x97\x8f Covalent\xe2\x97\x8f Metallic
The electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions.

cards.term: Give an example of a ionically bonded substance.
cards.definition: NaCl (Sodium Chloride - salt)
Electrostatic attraction between a shared pair of electrons and the nuclei.
Electrostatic attraction between the positive metal ions and the sea of delocalised electrons.

cards.term: Electrons in which shell are represented in a dot and cross diagram?
cards.definition: The outer shell.

cards.term: Why does giant ionic lattices conduct electricity when liquid but not when solid?
cards.definition: In solid state the ions are in fixed positions and thus cannot move. When they are in liquid state the ions are mobile and thus can freely carry the charge.

cards.term: Giant ionic lattices have high or low melting and boiling point? Explain your answer.
cards.definition: They have high melting and boiling point because a large amount of energy is required to overcome the electrostatic bonds.

cards.term: In what type of solvents do ionic lattices dissolve?
cards.definition: Polar SolventsE.g water

cards.term: What is it called when atoms are bonded by a single pair of shared electrons?
cards.definition: Single Bond

cards.term: How many covalent bonds does carbon form?
How many covalent bonds does oxygen form?

cards.definition: Electrons in the outer shell that are not involved in the bonding.

cards.term: What is formed when atoms share two pairs of electrons?
cards.definition: Double Bond

cards.term: What is formed when atoms share three pairs of electrons?
cards.definition: Triple Bond
Measure of average energy needed to break the bond.

cards.term: What is a dative covalent bond?
cards.definition: A bond where both of the shared electrons are supplied by one atom.
Formed when acid is added to water, H3O+.

cards.term: What does expansion of the octet mean?
cards.definition: When a bonded atom has more than 8 electrons in the outer shell.

cards.term: What are the types of covalent structure?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Simple molecular lattice\xe2\x97\x8f Giant covalent lattice

cards.term: Describe the bonding in simple molecular structures.
cards.definition: Atoms within the same molecule are held by strong covalent bonds and different molecules are held by weak intermolecular forces.

cards.term: Why do simple molecular structures have low melting and boiling point?
cards.definition: Small amount of energy is enough to overcome the intermolecular forces.

cards.term: Can simple molecular structures conduct electricity?
cards.definition: No, they are non conductors.

cards.term: Why do simple molecular structures not conduct electricity?
cards.definition: The have no free charged particles to move around.

cards.term: Simple molecular structures dissolve in what type of solvent?
cards.definition: Non polar solvents.

cards.term: Give examples of giant covalent structures.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Diamond\xe2\x97\x8f Graphite\xe2\x97\x8f Silicon dioxide, SiO2

cards.term: List some properties of giant covalent structures?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f High melting and boiling point.\xe2\x97\x8f Non conductors of electricity, except graphite.\xe2\x97\x8f Insoluble in polar and non polar solvents.
Delocalised electrons present between the layers are able to move freely carrying the charge.

cards.term: Why do giant covalent structures have high melting and boiling point?
cards.definition: Strong covalent bonds within the molecules need to be broken which requires a lot of energy.

cards.term: What does the shape of a molecule depend on?
cards.definition: Number of electron pairs in the outer shell. Number of these electrons which are bonded and lone pairs.

cards.term: By how many degrees does each lone pair reduce the bond angle?

cards.definition: The ability of an atom to attract the pair of electrons (the electron density) in a covalent bond.

cards.term: In which direction of the periodic table does electronegativity increase?
cards.definition: Top right, towards fluorine.

cards.term: What does it mean when the bond is non-polar?
cards.definition: The electrons in the bond are evenly distributed.

cards.term: What is the most electronegative element?
cards.definition: Fluorine

cards.term: How is a polar bond formed?
cards.definition: Bonding atoms have different electronegativities.

cards.term: Why is H2O polar, whereas CO2 is non polar?
cards.definition: CO2 is a symmetrical molecule, so there is no overall dipole.

cards.term: What is meant by intermolecular force?
cards.definition: Attractive force between neighbouring molecules.

cards.term: What are the 2 types of intermolecular forces?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Hydrogen bonding\xe2\x97\x8f Van der Waals\xe2\x80\x99 Forces

cards.term: What is the strongest type of intermolecular force?
cards.definition: Hydrogen Bonding

cards.term: What are the 2 interactions that can be referred as Van der Waals\xe2\x80\x99 forces?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Permanent dipole - induced dipole interaction\xe2\x97\x8f Permanent dipole - permanent dipole interaction
When a molecule with a permanent dipole is close to other nonpolar molecules it causes the nonpolar molecule to become slightly polar leading to attraction.

cards.term: Describe permanent dipole- permanent dipole interactions.
cards.definition: Some molecules with polar bonds have permanent dipoles \xe2\x86\x92 forces of attraction between those dipoles and those of neighbouring molecules.

\xe2\x97\x8f London forces are caused by random movements of electrons.\xe2\x97\x8f This leads to instantaneous dipoles.\xe2\x97\x8f Instantaneous dipole induces a dipole in nearby molecules.\xe2\x97\x8f Induced dipoles attract one another.

cards.term: Are London forces greater in smaller or larger molecules?
cards.definition: Larger due to more electrons.

cards.term: Does boiling point increase or decrease down the noble gas group? Why?
cards.definition: Boiling point increases because the number of electrons increases and hence the strength of London forces also increases.

cards.term: What conditions are needed for hydrogen bonding to occur?
cards.definition: O-H, N-H or F-H bond, lone pair of electrons on O, F, NBecause O, N and F are highly electronegative, H nucleus is left exposed.Strong force of attraction between H nucleus and lone pair of electrons on O, N, F.

cards.term: Why is ice less dense than liquid water?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f In ice, the water molecules are arranged in a orderly pattern. It has an open lattice with hydrogen bonds.\xe2\x97\x8f In water, the lattice is collapsed and the molecules are closer together.

cards.term: Why does water have a melting/boiling point higher than expected?
cards.definition: Hydrogen bonds are stronger than other intermolecular forces so extra strength is required to overcome the forces.

cards.term: What does the principal quantum number indicate?
cards.definition: The shell occupied by the electrons.
A group of orbitals with the same principal quantum number.

cards.term: How many electrons can the 1st shell hold?
How many electrons can the 2nd shell hold?
How many electrons can the 3rd shell hold?
How many electrons can the 4th shell hold?

cards.definition: A region around the nucleus that can hold up to two electrons with opposite spins.

cards.term: How many electrons can an orbital hold?
What are the 4 types of orbitals?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f s orbital\xe2\x97\x8f p orbital\xe2\x97\x8f d orbital\xe2\x97\x8f f orbital

cards.term: What is the shape of a s-orbital?
cards.definition: Spherical

cards.term: What is the shape of a p-orbital?
cards.definition: Dumb-bell Shape

cards.term: How many orbitals are found in a S subshell?
How many electrons can be held in a S subshell?
How many orbitals does P subshell have?
How many electrons can be held in a P subshell?
How many orbitals are present in a D subshell?
How many electrons can be held in a D subshell?
How many orbitals are found in a F subshell?
How many electrons can fill F subshell?
What letter used to represent shell number?
cards.definition: n

cards.term: From which shell onwards is S orbital present?
From which shell onwards is P-orbital present?
From which shell onwards is D-orbital present?
From which shell onwards is F-orbital present?
What are the rules by which electrons are arranged in the shell?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Electrons are added one at a time.\xe2\x97\x8f Lowest available energy level is filled first.\xe2\x97\x8f Each energy level must be filled before the next one can fill.\xe2\x97\x8f Each orbital is filled singly before pairing.\xe2\x97\x8f 4s is filled before 3d.

cards.term: Why does 4s orbital fill before 3d orbital?
cards.definition: 4s orbital has a lower energy than 3d before it is filled.

cards.term: Which electrons are lost when an atom becomes a positive ion?
cards.definition: Electrons in the highest energy levels.
The number of electrons an atom uses to bond with any other atom.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of an uncombined element such as C, H, O2 ?
What is the oxidation number of combined oxygen such as in H2O?
What is the oxidation number of oxygen in peroxides?
What is the oxidation number of combined hydrogen such as in NH3 , H2S?
What is the oxidation number of combined hydrogen in metal hydrides such as LiH?
What is the oxidation number of a simple ion?
cards.definition: Charge on the ion.E.g Na^+ \xe2\x86\x92 +1 ; Cl - \xe2\x86\x92 -1

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of combined fluorine such as in NaF, CaF2 ?
When an element has more than one stable oxidation number how is it indicated?
cards.definition: Written as a Roman numeral.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of Fe in iron (III) chloride?

cards.definition: Negative ions that have an element along with oxygen.

cards.term: Define oxidation in terms of electron transfer and oxidation number.
cards.definition: Oxidation is:\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of electrons.\xe2\x97\x8f An increase in oxidation number.

cards.term: Define reduction in terms of electron transfer and oxidation number.
cards.definition: Reduction is:\xe2\x97\x8f Gain of electrons.\xe2\x97\x8f A decrease in oxidation number.
A reaction in which both oxidation and reduction takes place.

cards.term: What is the oxidation number of a metal?
cards.definition: 0, because it is an uncombined element.

cards.term: When an acid is added to water what ion is released into the solution?
cards.definition: Hydrogen Ion, H+
Proton Donor

cards.term: Describe the dissociation of a strong acid.
cards.definition: Full Dissociation
Proton Acceptor

cards.term: Which base is used to treat acid indigestion?
cards.definition: Magnesium Hydroxide
Bases that can dissolve in water to form aqueous hydroxide ions.
Substances that can act as acids and bases.

cards.term: What is formed when acid reacts with carbonate?
cards.definition: Salt, carbon dioxide and water.
A compound that is formed when H+ of an ion is replaced by a metal ion or positive ion.

cards.term: What is formed when acids react with metal oxide?
cards.definition: Salt and water.

cards.term: What is formed when acid reacts with alkali?
cards.definition: Salt and water.

cards.term: What is formed when acids react with metal?
cards.definition: Salt and hydrogen.

cards.term: Why are the products same when acid reacts with alkali or metal oxides?
cards.definition: Both alkali and metal oxides are types of bases.
When acid reacts with aqueous ammonia.
A crystalline structure containing water.
Crystalline form that contains no water.

cards.term: What does a dot formula indicate?
cards.definition: The amount of water present in a crystalline structure.

cards.term: Write down the methods to carry out a titration.
cards.definition: 1. Using a pipette, measure the volume of a solution2. Add the solution into a conical flask and add an indicator into it3. Add the other solution into a burette and record the volume4. Slowly add the solution in the burette into the conical flask5. Swirl the mixture continuously until the end point is reached6. Repeat until concordant results are obtained

cards.term: What is the colour of methyl orange in an acid, base and at end point?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Acid - red\xe2\x97\x8f Base - yellow\xe2\x97\x8f End point - orange

cards.term: What is the symbol for amount of substance?
cards.definition: n

cards.term: What is the unit used to measure amount of substance?
cards.definition: Mole

cards.term: What does the Avogadro constant represent?
cards.definition: The number of atoms per mole of the carbon-12 isotope.

cards.term: How to calculate the mass of 1 mole of the element?
cards.definition: Mass of 1 mole = Relative atomic mass in grams

cards.term: How to calculate moles when mass and molar mass are given?
cards.definition: Moles (mol) = mass (g) / molar mass (g\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-1)
Under the same temperature and pressure, one mole of any gas would occupy the same volume.

cards.term: How much volume does a gas occupy, at room temperature and pressure?

cards.definition: The volume per mole of gas molecules.

cards.term: Why do different gas particles occupy the same volume?
cards.definition: The gas particles are very spread out, hence individual differences has no effect.

cards.term: How to calculate moles when gas volume is given?
