cards.definition: Moles (mol) = Volume (dm^3 ) / 24 or  Moles (mol) = Volume (cm^3 ) / 24,000

cards.term: What are the ideal ways in which gases behave?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f They are in continuous motion.\xe2\x97\x8f No intermolecular forces experienced.\xe2\x97\x8f Exert pressure when they collide with each other or container.\xe2\x97\x8f No kinetic energy is lost in the collisions.\xe2\x97\x8f When temperature increases, kinetic energy of gases alsoincrease.

cards.term: Write down the ideal gas equation (in words and symbols, including the units).
cards.definition: pV = nRTPressure (Pa) x Volume (m^3) = Number of Moles (mol) x Gas Constant (8.314 J mol^-1) x Temperature (K)

cards.term: 1 atmospheric pressure is equal to how many pascal?
0\xe2\x84\x83 is equal to how many kelvin?
What does concentration of a solution mean?
cards.definition: It is the amount of solute dissolved in 1 dm^3 of solvent.

cards.term: How do you calculate moles when concentration and volume are given?
cards.definition: Moles (mol) = Concentration (mol\xe2\x8b\x85dm^-3) \xc3\x97 Volume (dm^3)
A solution of known concentration.

cards.term: Write down the steps to prepare a standard solution.
cards.definition: 1. Weigh the solute using the weigh by difference method.2. In a beaker dissolve the solute using the solvent.3. Pour the solution into a volumetric flask.4. Rinse the beaker using the solution and add it to the flask.5. Add solvent to the flask carefully until it reaches the graduation line.6. Mix the solution thoroughly to ensure complete mixing.

cards.term: What does the terms concentrated and dilute mean?
cards.definition: Concentrated - large amount of solute per dm 3 of solvent.Dilute - small amount of solute per dm 3 of solvent.

cards.term: What is a species in a chemical reaction?
cards.definition: Any particle that takes part in a reaction.

cards.term: What are the four common state symbols?
cards.definition: 1. Solid (s)2. Liquid (l)3. Gaseous (g)4. Aqueous (aq)

cards.term: What does the percentage yield mean?
cards.definition: The efficiency of which reactants are converted into products.

cards.term: What are the reasons for not obtaining 100% yield?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Reaction may be at equilibrium.\xe2\x97\x8f The reactants may be impure.\xe2\x97\x8f Side reactions could happen.\xe2\x97\x8f Reactants or products may be left behind while transferring.\xe2\x97\x8f Loss of products during separation and purification.
Percentage yield = [Actual amount of product (mol) / Theoretical amount of product (mol)] x 100

cards.term: What does atom economy tell us about?
cards.definition: The proportion of desired products compared with all the products formed in the reaction.
Atom economy = [Molecular mass of desired product / Sum of the molecular masses of all products] x 100
No, even if all the reactants are converted into products, not all products of the reaction will be the required products.

cards.term: Which type of reaction has 100% atom economy?
cards.definition: Addition reactions (two or more reactants are combined to form a product).

cards.term: What was stated in Dalton\xe2\x80\x99s atomic theory?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Atoms are tiny particles made of elements.\xe2\x97\x8f Atoms cannot be divided.\xe2\x97\x8f All the atoms in an element are the same.\xe2\x97\x8f Atoms of one element are different to those of other elements.

cards.term: What did Thompson discover about electrons?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f They have a negative charge.\xe2\x97\x8f They can be deflected by magnet and electric field.\xe2\x97\x8f They have very small mass.
Atoms are made up of negative electrons moving around in a sea of positive charge.

cards.term: What were Rutherford\xe2\x80\x99s proposal after the gold leaf experiment?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Most of the mass and positive charge of the atom are in the nucleus.\xe2\x97\x8f Electrons orbit the nucleus.\xe2\x97\x8f Most of atom\xe2\x80\x99s volume is the space between thenucleus and the electrons.\xe2\x97\x8f Overall positive and negative charges must balance.

cards.term: Explain the current model of the atom.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Protons and neutrons are found in the nucleus.\xe2\x97\x8f Electrons orbit in shells.\xe2\x97\x8f Nucleus is tiny compared to the total volume of atom.\xe2\x97\x8f Most of atom\xe2\x80\x99s mass is in the nucleus.\xe2\x97\x8f Most of the atom is empty space between the nucleus and the electrons.

cards.term: What is the charge of a proton?
What is the charge an electron?
Which particle has the same mass as proton?
cards.definition: Neutron

cards.term: Which two particles make up most of atom\xe2\x80\x99s mass?
cards.definition: Protons and neutrons.

cards.term: Which letter is used to represent the atomic number of an atom?
cards.definition: Z

cards.term: What does the atomic number tell about an element?
cards.definition: Atomic number = number of protons in an atom.

cards.term: Which letter represents the mass number?
cards.definition: A
Mass number = Number of protons + Number of neutrons

cards.term: How to calculate the number of neutrons?
cards.definition: Number of neutrons = Mass number - Atomic number
Atoms of the same element with different number of neutrons.

cards.term: Why does different isotopes of the same element react in the same way?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Neutrons have no impact on the chemical reactivity.\xe2\x97\x8f Reactions involve electrons, isotopes have the same number of electrons in the same arrangement.
Charged particles that is formed when an atom loses or gains electrons.

cards.term: What is the charge of the ion when electrons are gained?
cards.definition: NegativeN.B. - positive charge when electrons are lostE.g. 3+ ion has lost 3 electrons

cards.term: What is the unit used to measure atomic masses called?
cards.definition: Unified Atomic Mass Unit, u
The weighted mean mass of an atom of an element compared with one twelfth of the mass of an atom of carbon -12.

cards.term: What is the unit of relative atomic mass?
cards.definition: No units.
The mass of an atom of an isotope compared with one twelfth of the mass of an atom of carbon-12.

cards.term: The relative isotopic mass is same as which number?
cards.definition: Mass Number

cards.term: What two assumptions are made when calculating mass number?
cards.definition: 1. Contribution of the electron is neglected.2. Mass of both proton and neutron is taken as 1.0 u.

cards.term: How to calculate the relative molecular mass and relative formula mass?
cards.definition: Both can be calculated by adding the relative atomic masses of each of the atom making up the molecule or the formula.

cards.term: What are the uses of mass spectrometry?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Identify unknown compounds.\xe2\x97\x8f Find relative abundance of each isotope of an element.\xe2\x97\x8f Determine structural information.

cards.term: How does a mass spectrometer work?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f The sample is made into positive ions.\xe2\x97\x8f They pass through the apparatus and are separated according to mass to charge ratio.\xe2\x97\x8f A computer analyses the data and produces mass spectrum.

cards.term: How is the group number related to the number of electrons?
cards.definition: Group number - number of electrons in the outer shell.

cards.term: Does the group number indicates horizontal or vertical column in the periodic table?
cards.definition: Vertical Column

cards.term: Do metals usually gain or lose electrons?
cards.definition: Lose ElectronsN.B. - non metals generally gain electrons.

cards.term: Which are the 4 elements that don\xe2\x80\x99t tend to form ions and why?
cards.definition: The elements are beryllium, boron, carbon and silicon. Requires a lot of energy to transfer outer shell electrons.
Covalently bonded atoms that lose or gain electrons.
Simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present in a compound.

\xe2\x97\x8f Divide the amount of each element by its molar mass.\xe2\x97\x8f Divide the answers by the smallest value obtained.\xe2\x97\x8f If there is a decimal, divide by a suitable number to make it into a whole number.
Ionic bonding is an electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions.

Physical properties of a substance include the boiling point, melting point, solubility and conductivity. These properties are different depending on the type of bonding and the crystal structure of the compound.
A covalent bond is the strong electrostatic attraction between a shared pair of electrons and the nuclei of the bonded atoms.
Dative or coordinate bonds form when both of the electrons in the shared pair are supplied from a single atom. It is indicated using an arrow from the lone electron pair.
Pauling electronegativity values can be used to compare the electronegativity of atoms. A higher value on the pauling scale indicates a greater electronegativity.
An induced dipole can form when the electron orbitals around a molecule are influenced by the distributions of electrons on another particle.
Van der Waals forces are the weakest type of intermolecular force. They act as an induced dipole between molecules.
Permanent dipoles are a type of intermolecular force which acts between molecules with a polar bond.
Hydrogen bonds are the strongest type of intermolecular forces. Hydrogen bonds only act between hydrogen and the three most electronegative atoms: nitrogen, oxygen and fluorine.
Graphite is a macromolecular structure made up of carbon atoms. However, in graphite, each carbon atom is bonded to three others in flat sheets.
Graphene is a relatively recent material consisting of single, 2D sheets of graphite that are just one atom thick.
Isotopes are atoms of the same element with the same atomic number, but with a different number of neutrons, resulting in a different mass number.
The weighted mean mass of an atom of an element, relative to one twelfth of the mean mass of an atom of the carbon-12 isotope.
The isotopic mass of an isotope relative to one twelfth of the mean mass of an atom of the carbon-12 isotope.
The weighted mean mass of a molecule of a compound, relative to one twelfth of the mean mass of an atom of the carbon-12 isotope.
Mass spectrometry is used to identify different isotopes and find the overall relative atomic mass of an element. Ions are very useful in the analytical technique of mass spectrometry.
Ionic bonding occurs between a metal and a nonmetal. Electrons are transferred from the metal to the non-metal to achieve full outer shells.
Amount of substance defines the number of particles in a substance. It is measured in moles.
Molar mass is the mass per mole and has units g\xe2\x8b\x85mol\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9.
Molar gas volume is the gas volume per mole and has units dm\xc2\xb3\xe2\x8b\x85mol\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9.
Empirical formula is the simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present in a compound.
Molecular formula is the number and type of atoms of each element in a molecule. It is the true number of each atom in the molecule.
Water of crystallisation is water that is part of the crystalline structure. The molecules are stoichiometrically chemically bonded into the crystal structure.
An anhydrous substance contains no water of crystallisation.
A hydrated substance contains water of crystallisation.
A standard solution is a solution of known concentration. This can be prepared by dissolving a known mass of solid in solvent and making it up to an exact volume.

The limiting reagent in a reaction is the reactant that is not in excess. It will be used up first, causing the reaction to stop. In calculations, you must use the moles of the limiting reagentalong with the stoichiometric ratios of reactant to product to calculate the moles of product formed.
Roman numerals are used to indicate the magnitude of an oxidation number. For example, iron has two common oxidation states, iron(II) and iron(III).
Atoms of the same element w/ different no of neutrons + different masses.
Small amount of mass lost due to strong nuclear force holding together protons/neutrons
Mass of an isotope relative to 1/12 mass of an atom carbon-12.
Weighted mean mass of an atom of an element relative to 1/12 mass of an atom of carbon-12.
The electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions.
Attraction of a bonded atom for the pair of electrons in a covalent bond.
Bonded atoms are same element.
Weak interactions between dipoles of different molecules.
Dipole in a polar covalent bond which doesn\xe2\x80\x99t change.
The number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.
Describes an atom as a small dense nucleus with electrons orbiting around the nucleus. This model explains different periodic properties of atoms.
A negatively charged subatomic particle which orbits the nucleus at various energy levels. The relative mass of an electron is 1/1836.
A charged atom or molecule.
Atoms of the same element with the same number of protons and electrons but different numbers of neutrons. Isotopes of an element have different masses.
The total number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom.
An instrument which gives accurate information about relative isotopic mass and the relative abundance of isotopes.
A neutral subatomic particle found in the nucleus of an atom. The relative mass of a neutron is 1.
A positively charged subatomic particle found in the nucleus of an atom. The relative mass of a proton is 1.
The amount of one substance compared with another.
The weighted mean mass of an atom compared with 1/12th mass of an atom of carbon-12.
The mass of an atom of an isotope compared with 1/12th mass of an atom of carbon-12.
The mass of the formula unit of a compound with a giant structure. For example, NaCl has a relative formula mass of 58.44 g\xe2\x8b\x85mol^-1.
The mass of a simple molecule.
A compound which is made up of oppositely charged ions that are held together by electrostatic forces.
Symbols within a chemical equation which indicate the state of each compound under the reaction conditions. (g) gaseous, (l) liquid, (s) solid and (aq) aqueous.
A crystalline compound containing no water.
The relative mass of each element in a compound.
The simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present in a compound.
A crystalline compound that contains water.
A gas which has molecules that occupy negligible space with no interactions between them. The ideal gas equation is: pV = nRT.
The volume of 1 mole of gas.
Mass per mole of a substance.
The amount of any substance containing as many particles as there are carbon atoms in exactly 12 g of carbon-12 isotope.
The number and type of atoms of each element in a molecule.
The percentage ratio of the actual yield of product from a reaction compared with the theoretical yield.Percentage yield = Actual yield / Theoretical yield
The average mass of one molecule of an element or compound compared to 1/12th the mass of an atom of carbon-12.
The relative quantities of substances in a reaction.
Water molecules that form part of the crystalline structure of a compound.
A substance that can accept H+ ions from another substance.
A reaction between H+ and OH-, forming water. This may be a reaction between an acid and a base to form a salt (types of bases include carbonates, metal oxides and alkalis).
An acid that completely dissociates in solution
A technique used to determine the amount of one solution of a known concentration required to completely react with a known volume of another solution of unknown concentration.
Loss of electrons/Increase in oxidation number

A number that represents the number of electrons lost or gained by an atom of an element. A positive oxidation number indicates the loss of electrons. Roman numerals are typically used to indicate the oxidation number of elements that may have different oxidation states (e.g. iron(II) and iron(III)).
A reaction in which one element is oxidised and another is reduced.
Gain of electrons / decrease in oxidation number.

A region of space around the nucleus that can hold up to 2 electrons with opposite spins. There is 1 orbital in the s subshell, 3 orbitals in the p subshell and 5 orbitals in the d subshell. Orbitals are filled in order of increasing energy, with orbitals of the same energy occupied singly before pairing.
The arrangement of electrons into orbitals and energy levels around the nucleus of an atom / ion.
The shell that an electron is in.
The orbit that an orbital is in around the nucleus of an atom. The shell closest to the nucleus is the first shell. The outermost shell that is occupied by electrons is the valence shell.
A subdivision of the electronic shells into different orbitals. The types of subshell are s, p, d and f.
The average energy required to break a bond, used as a measurement of the strength of a covalent bond. The average bond enthalpy is measured using a variety of molecules that contain a specific bond.
A pair of outer-shell electrons involved in bonding.
a strong bond formed between 2 atoms due to the electrostatic attraction between a shared pair of electrons and the atomic nuclei.
A type of covalent bond in which both of the electrons in the shared pair come from one atom.

The ability of an atom to attract bonding electrons in a covalent bond. This is often quantified using Pauling\xe2\x80\x99s electronegativity values. Electronegativity increases towards F in the periodic table.

Pairs of electrons around a nucleus repel each other so the shape that a molecule adopts has these pairs of electrons positioned as far apart as possible. Lone pairs offer more repulsion than bonding pairs as they are closer to the nucleus of the central atom.

A type of intermolecular bonding that occurs between molecules containing N, O or F and a H atom of -NH, -OH or HF. A lone pair on the electronegative atom (N, O or F) allows the formation of a hydrogen bond.

Interactions between different molecules. Types of intermolecular forces including permanent dipole-dipole interactions and induced dipole-dipole interactions (both of these are also known as van der Waals\xe2\x80\x99 forces) as well as hydrogen bonding.
Electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions.

Compounds made up of oppositely charged ions. These compounds generally have high melting and boiling points. Typically, ionic compounds are soluble and can conduct electricity when liquid or aqueous (but not when solid).
A giant structure in which oppositely charged ions are strongly attracted in all directions.
The shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 2 bonding pairs.
Induced dipole-dipole interactions caused when the random movement of electrons creates a temporary dipole in one molecule which then induces a dipole in a neighbouring molecule.
A pair of outer-shell electrons not involved in bonding.
Properties of a bulk material rather than the individual atoms/ molecules that make up the material.
The shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 2 bonding pairs and 2 lone pairs.
The shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 6 bonding pairs.
A permanent uneven distribution of charge.
A covalent bond that has a permanent dipole due to the different electronegativities of the atoms that make up the bond.
A molecule that contains polar bonds with dipoles that don\xe2\x80\x99t cancel out due to their direction (must be unsymmetrical).
The shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 3 bonding pairs and 1 lone pair.

A solid structure made up of covalently bonded molecules attracted by intermolecular force (e.g. I_2 and ice). These compounds generally have relatively low melting and boiling points and are typically insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents. Molecular substances don\xe2\x80\x99t conduct electricity.
The shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 4 bonding pairs.
the shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 5 bonding pairs.
The shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 3 bonding pairs.
The mass of an atom compared to carbon-12 on a scale where carbon is exactly 12.
The mass of an isotope compared to carbon-12 on a scale where carbon is exactly 12.
An atom of an element with different number of neutrons.
A mole is a measure of the amount of any substance. It contains the same number of particles, equal to the number of carbon-12 atoms in exactly 12 g of the isotope.
The empirical formula of a substance is the simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present.
The Avogadro constant , NA, is the number of atoms per mole of the carbon-12 isotope (6.02 x 10^23 mol^\xe2\x88\x921 ).
Water molecules form an essential part of the crystal structure of some compounds, known as water of crystallisation.
Molar gas volume is the volume per mole of a gas. The units of molar volume are dm^3 mol^-1. At room temperature and pressure, the molar volume is 24 dm^3 mol^-1.
It occurs when the rate of forward reaction equals the rate of reverse reaction and the concentration of reactants and products remain constant in a closed system.

cards.term: Changing what factors can alter the position of equilibrium?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Concentration of reactants or products\xe2\x97\x8f Pressure\xe2\x97\x8f temperature
If a system at equilibrium is disturbed, the equilibrium moves in the direction that tends to reduce the disturbance.

cards.term: What effect does a catalyst have on the position of equilibrium?
cards.definition: No effect.(because catalyst affects rate of forward and reverse reactions equally)

cards.term: What condition affects the value of K_c?\xe2\x9d\x91 Concentration\xe2\x9d\x91 Catalyst\xe2\x9d\x91 Pressure\xe2\x9d\x91 Temperature
cards.definition: Temperature

cards.term: What type of system is Kc relevant for?
cards.definition: Homogeneous systems in equilibrium.

cards.term: What does K_c being greater or less than 1 suggest for the position of equilibrium?
cards.definition: Greater than 1 = over to the rightLess than 1 = over to the left

cards.term: What effect does decreasing the temperature of an endothermic reaction have on Kc?
cards.definition: Kc decreases

cards.term: What effect does increasing the temperature of an endothermic reaction have on Kc?
cards.definition: Kc increases

cards.term: What effect does decreasing the temperature of an exothermic reaction have on Kc ?
cards.definition: Kc increases

cards.term: What is the equation used to calculate rate?
cards.definition: Rate = Change in concentration/Time

cards.term: What is the unit for rate of reaction?
cards.definition: mol \xe2\x80\xa2 dm^-3 \xe2\x80\xa2 s^-1

cards.term: What must particles do in order to react?
cards.definition: Collide with sufficient energy (activation energy) and the correct orientation.

cards.term: Do most collisions result in a reaction?
cards.definition: No.

cards.term: What are the factors that affect rate of reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Temperature\xe2\x97\x8f Pressure\xe2\x97\x8f Concentration\xe2\x97\x8f Surface area\xe2\x97\x8f Catalyst

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on rate of reaction? why?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Increasing temperature \xe2\x86\x92 Increased rate of reaction\xe2\x97\x8f Much higher proportion of particles have energygreater than the activation energy \xe2\x86\x92 Many more\xe2\x97\x8f  Successful collisions per second \xe2\x86\x92 Increased rate

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing concentration/pressure on rate of reaction and why?
cards.definition: Increased concentration/pressure \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate of reactionThere are more particles in a given volume \xe2\x86\x92 more frequent successful collisions \xe2\x86\x92 increased rate

cards.term: What are the variables in an experiment that can be monitored to calculate the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Concentration of reactant or product\xe2\x97\x8f Gas volume of products\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of substances formed

cards.term: How to calculate rate from a concentration time graph?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Draw a tangent.\xe2\x97\x8f Work out the gradient of the tangent using the equation.\xe2\x97\x8f Gradient = change in y/change in x.
A substance which increases the rate of reaction but is not used up in the reaction.

cards.term: How do catalysts work and how do they increase the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: They provide an alternate reaction pathway (with a lower activation energy) Due to lower activation energy, more particles have energy > activation energy, so more frequent successful collisions, so increased reaction rate.
A catalyst that is in the same phase as the reactants.Eg. liquid catalyst mixed with liquid reactants
Catalyst used in the reaction is in different phase to the reactants.Eg. gaseous reactants passed over solid catalyst.
They are present in vehicles to reduce toxic emission and prevent photochemical smog.
The minimum energy that particles must collide with for a reaction to occur.

cards.term: Name some important features of Boltzmann distribution.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Area under the curve = total number of molecules\xe2\x97\x8f Area under the curve does not change when conditions alter\xe2\x97\x8f The curve starts at the origin.\xe2\x97\x8f Curve does not touch or cross the energy axis.\xe2\x97\x8f Only the molecules with energy greater than activation energy can react.

cards.term: What are the axis in a Boltzmann distribution?
cards.definition: X axis - energyY axis - number of molecules with a given energy

cards.term: What does system mean in a chemical reaction?
cards.definition: The atoms and bonds involved in the chemical reaction.
The amount of energy in an isolated system remains the same. Energy cannot be destroyed or created, It can only be transferred from one form to another.

cards.term: What energy change is breaking bonds associated with?
cards.definition: Energy is taken in to break bonds \xe2\x86\x92 Endothermic reaction

cards.term: What energy change is making bonds associated with?
cards.definition: Energy is released to make bonds \xe2\x86\x92 Exothermic reaction
A reaction with an overall positive enthalpy change (+\xce\x94H) \xe2\x86\x92 enthalpy of products > enthalpy of reactants.
A reaction with an overall negative enthalpy change (-\xce\x94H) \xe2\x86\x92 enthalpy of products < enthalpy of reactants.
The minimum energy required for a reaction to take place.

cards.term: Which way does the arrow for activation energy point on an enthalpy profile diagram?
cards.definition: Always points upwards.
100 kPa298 K
The state an element/compound exists at in standard conditions (100 kPa, 298 K).
The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of a compound is formed from its constituent elements in their standard state under standard conditions.

cards.term: Give an example of an equation which represents standard enthalpy of formation.
cards.definition: There are many e.g. H2 (g) + \xc2\xbd O2 (g) \xe2\x86\x92 H2O (l).
The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of a substance is completely combusted.

cards.term: Give an example of an equation which represents standard enthalpy of combustion.
cards.definition: E.g. C (s) + O2 (g) \xe2\x86\x92 CO2 (g)
The energy change that takes place when 1 mole of water is formed from a neutralisation reaction.

cards.term: What does enthalpy change of reaction mean?
cards.definition: The energy change associated with a given reaction.

cards.term: How can you calculate enthalpy change from experimental data?
cards.definition: Use the equation Q = mc\xce\x94T, where m is the mass of the substance being heated (usually water), c is the specific heat capacity of that substance (water\xe2\x80\x99s SHC = 4.18g\xe2\x8b\x85J^-1\xe2\x8b\x85K^-1) and \xce\x94T is the change in temperature.

cards.term: What are the advantages of using a bomb calorimeter?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Minimises heat loss.\xe2\x97\x8f Pure oxygen used \xe2\x86\x92 ensures complete combustion.

cards.term: Why might experimental methods for enthalpy determination not be accurate?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Heat is lost to the surroundings.\xe2\x97\x8f Not in standard conditions.\xe2\x97\x8f Reaction may not go to completion.

cards.term: What does average bond enthalpy mean?
cards.definition: The mean energy required to break 1 mole of bonds in gaseous molecules.

cards.term: Why will using bond enthalpies not be as accurate as using standard enthalpy of combustion/formation?
cards.definition: Bond enthalpies are a mean for the same bond across different molecules whereas standard enthalpy of combustion and formation apply just to that molecule, therefore they are more accurate.

cards.term: How to calculate enthalpy change of reaction using average bond enthalpies?
cards.definition: \xce\x94H = \xce\xa3(bond enthalpies of reaction) - \xce\xa3(bond enthalpies of products)

cards.term: What are anions also known as?
cards.definition: Negative Ions

cards.term: What do you use to test for halide ions?
cards.definition: Acidified AgNO3

cards.term: Why do you add HNO3 to test for halide ions and why not HCl?
cards.definition: To remove CO\xe2\x82\x83^2-, adding HCl would add Cl- ions, giving a false positive result.

cards.term: How can you test for a halide ion?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Dissolve the sample in water.\xe2\x97\x8f Add aqueous silver nitrate.\xe2\x97\x8f Record the colour change.\xe2\x97\x8f If difficult to distinguish the colour, add aqueous ammonia, first dilute ammonia then concentrated ammonia.\xe2\x97\x8f Note the solubility of precipitate.

cards.term: Write the result and equation for Cl- test.
cards.definition: White precipitate, soluble in dilute aqueous ammonia.Ag + (aq) + Cl - (aq)\xe2\x86\x92 AgCl (s)

cards.term: Write the result and equation for Br- test.
cards.definition: Cream ppt, soluble in concentrated aqueous ammonia only.Ag + (aq)+ Br - (aq)\xe2\x86\x92 AgBr (s)

cards.term: Write the result and equation for I - test.
cards.definition: Yellow precipitate, insoluble in concentrated and dilute aqueous ammonia.Ag + (aq)+ I - (aq)\xe2\x86\x92 AgI (s)

cards.term: When testing for carbonate, sulfate and halide ions, in which order should the tests be carried out and why?
cards.definition: 1. Carbonate test2. Sulfate test3. Halide testBecause barium ions forms insoluble precipitate of BaCO3 and silver ions form insolube precipitate of Ag2SO4.

cards.term: What are cations also known as?
cards.definition: Positive Ions

cards.term: What are the observations for positive ammonium ions test?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Red litmus paper turns blue.\xe2\x97\x8f Ammonia has a pungent smell.

cards.term: What group elements are referred to as halogens?
cards.definition: Group 7
\xe2\x97\x8f Low melting and boiling points.\xe2\x97\x8f Exist as diatomic molecules.

cards.term: What is the trend in boiling point down group 7? Why?
cards.definition: Increases down the group because:\xe2\x97\x8f Size of atom increases as more occupied electron shells \xe2\x86\x92 stronger London forces of attraction between molecules, take more energy to break.

cards.term: What is the trend in reactivity down group 7? Why?
cards.definition: Reactivity decreases because:\xe2\x97\x8f Atomic radius increases.\xe2\x97\x8f Electron shielding increases.\xe2\x97\x8f Ability to gain an electron and form 1- ions decreases.

cards.term: What is the trend in oxidising ability down the group? Why?
cards.definition: Decreases down group (Cl strongest, I weakest) This is because Cl has the fewest occupied electron shells, greatest force of attraction between outer electrons and nucleus and thus is the easiest to gain electrons and be reduced \xe2\x86\x92 best oxidising agent.

cards.term: What is the trend in reducing ability of the halides down the group? Why?
cards.definition: Increases down the group (Cl - weakest, I - strongest)This is because I - has the most occupied electron shell so outer electrons are further from the nucleus, weakest force of attraction between outer electrons and positive charge of nucleus and thus is the easiest to be oxidised and lose electrons \xe2\x86\x92 best reducing agent.

cards.term: When a more reactive halogen displaces a less reactive halide, what is the reaction called?
cards.definition: Displacement Reaction

cards.term: What is the colour of chlorine in water?
cards.definition: Pale Green

cards.term: What is the colour of bromine in water?
cards.definition: Orange

cards.term: What is the colour of iodine in water?
cards.definition: Brown

cards.term: What is the colour of chlorine in cyclohexane?
cards.definition: Pale Green

cards.term: What is the colour of bromine in cyclohexane?
cards.definition: Orange

cards.term: What is the colour of iodine in cyclohexane?
cards.definition: Violet

cards.term: Out of the 3 halides Cl- , Br- & I- , which one of these can be oxidised by chlorine?
cards.definition: Br- & I- ions

cards.term: Write the equation for chlorine oxidising bromide ions
cards.definition: Cl\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2Br- (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 2Cl- (aq) + Br\xe2\x82\x82 (aq)

cards.term: Write the equation for Cl2 oxidising 2I-
cards.definition: Cl\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2I- (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 2Cl- (aq) + I\xe2\x82\x82 (aq)

cards.term: Write the equation for bromine oxidising iodide ions
cards.definition: Br\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2I- (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 2Br- (aq) + I\xe2\x82\x82 (aq)

cards.term: Out of the 3 halides Cl- , Br- & I- , which one of these can be oxidised by iodine?
cards.definition: Does not oxidise Cl- or Br-.
The oxidation and reduction of the same element in a redox reaction.

cards.term: What is the equation for the reaction of Cl2 with water?
cards.definition: Cl\xe2\x82\x82 (g) + H\xe2\x82\x82O (l) \xe2\x86\x92 HClO (aq) + HCl (aq)

cards.term: What type of reaction is the reaction of chlorine with water?
cards.definition: Disproportionation; chlorine is both oxidised and reduced.

cards.term: Why is chlorine added to drinking water?
cards.definition: It kills the bacteria in the water and makes it safer to drink.

cards.term: What are the two forms of the chlorate ion?
cards.definition: ClO- is chlorate (I)ClO\xe2\x82\x83- is chlorate (V)

cards.term: What is the equation for forming bleach?
cards.definition: Cl\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2NaOH (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 NaCl (aq) + NaClO (aq) + H\xe2\x82\x82O (l)NaClO is bleach

cards.term: What is a common name given to group 2 metals?
cards.definition: Alkaline Earth Metals

cards.term: What is the most reactive metal of group 2?
cards.definition: Barium

cards.term: List 3 physical properties of group 2 metals
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f High melting and boiling points.\xe2\x97\x8f Low density metals.\xe2\x97\x8f Form colourless (white) compounds.

cards.term: The highest energy electrons of group 2 metals are in which subshell?
cards.definition: S subshell

cards.term: Does reactivity increase or decrease down group 2? Why?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Increases.\xe2\x97\x8f Electrons are lost more easily because largeratomic radius and more shielding.

cards.term: What happens to the first ionisation energy as you go down group 2? Why?
cards.definition: Decreases because:\xe2\x97\x8f Number of filled electron shells increases down the group \xe2\x86\x92 increased shielding.\xe2\x97\x8f Increased atomic radius \xe2\x86\x92 weaker force between outer .\xe2\x97\x8f Electron and nucleus \xe2\x86\x92 less energy needed to remove electron.

cards.term: What type of reaction is the reaction between group 2 elements and oxygen?
cards.definition: Redox Reaction

cards.term: What are the products when group 2 elements react with water?
cards.definition: Hydroxide and hydrogen gas.

cards.term: Which group 2 element doesn\xe2\x80\x99t react with water?
cards.definition: Beryllium

cards.term: Which group 2 element reactsvery slowly with water?
cards.definition: Magnesium

cards.term: What type of reaction is the reaction between group 2 metal and water?
cards.definition: Redox Reaction

cards.term: What is oxidised and what is reduced in a reaction between group 2 metal and water?
cards.definition: Metal \xe2\x86\x92 oxidisedOne hydrogen atom from each water \xe2\x86\x92 reduced

cards.term: What are the products when a group 2 element reacts with an dilute acid?
cards.definition: Salt and hydrogen gas.

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction of calcium and hydrochloric acid.
cards.definition: Ca(s) + 2HCl(aq) \xe2\x86\x92 CaCl2(s) + H\xe2\x82\x82(g)

cards.term: What is formed when group 2 oxides react with water?
cards.definition: Metal Hydroxide

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction between a group 2 oxide and water.
cards.definition: MO(s) + H2O(l) \xe2\x86\x92 M(OH)2(aq)

cards.term: What group 2 metal oxide is insoluble in water?
cards.definition: Beryllium Oxide

cards.term: What is the trend in hydroxide solubility down group 2?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Increases down the group\xe2\x97\x8f Mg(OH)\xe2\x82\x82 is slightly soluble\xe2\x97\x8f Ba(OH)\xe2\x82\x82 creates a strong alkaline solution

cards.term: What is Ca(OH)2 used for? Write an equation related to one of its uses.
cards.definition: Used to neutralise soil:Ca(OH)\xe2\x82\x82 (aq) + 2HCl (aq) \xe2\x86\x92 2H\xe2\x82\x82O (l) + CaCl\xe2\x82\x82 (aq)
Milk of magnesia - antacid to treat indigestion, heartburn, etc.

cards.term: What is calcium carbonate used for?
cards.definition: Present in limestone and marble. Used in building construction.

cards.term: How are the elements arranged in a periodic table?
cards.definition: They are arranged in the order of increasing atomic numbers.

cards.term: What is a period on a periodic table?
cards.definition: The horizontal rows in the periodic table.

cards.term: What is a group on a periodic table?
cards.definition: The vertical columns.
The repeating trends in chemical and physical properties.

cards.term: What change happens across each period?
cards.definition: Elements change from metals to non metals.
The energy required to remove one electron from each atom in one mole of the gaseous element to form one mole of gaseous 1+ ions.

cards.term: Write an equation for the first ionisation energy of magnesium.
cards.definition: Mg (g) \xe2\x86\x92 Mg+ (g) + e-

cards.term: What are the factors that affect ionisation energy?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Atomic radius\xe2\x97\x8f Nuclear charge\xe2\x97\x8f Electron shielding or screening

cards.term: Why does first ionisation energy decrease between group 2 to 3?
cards.definition: Decrease between 2 to 3 because in group 3 the outermost electrons are in p orbitals whereas in group 2 they are in s orbital, so the electrons are easier to be removed.

cards.term: Why does first ionisation energy decrease between group 5 to 6?
cards.definition: The decrease between 5 to 6 is due to the group 5 electrons in p orbital are single electrons and in group 6 the outermost electrons are spin paired, with some repulsion. Therefore the electrons are slightly easier to remove.

cards.term: Does first ionisation increase or decrease between the end of one period and the start of next? Why?
cards.definition: Decrease:\xe2\x97\x8f There is increase in atomic radius.\xe2\x97\x8f Increase in electron shielding.

cards.term: Does first ionisation increase or decrease down a group? Why?
cards.definition: Decrease:\xe2\x97\x8f Shielding increases \xe2\x86\x92 weaker attraction\xe2\x97\x8f Atomic radius increases \xe2\x86\x92 distance between the outer electrons and nucleus increases \xe2\x86\x92 weaker attraction\xe2\x97\x8f Increase in number of protons is outweighed by increase in distance and shielding.

cards.term: What are the properties of giant metallic lattices?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f High melting and boiling point\xe2\x97\x8f Good electrical conductors\xe2\x97\x8f Malleability\xe2\x97\x8f Ductility
The metal can be made stretched. E.g, can be made into wires.
The metal can be shaped into different forms.

cards.term: Describe the structure, forces and bonding in every element across period 2.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Li & Be \xe2\x86\x92 giant metallic ; strong attraction between positive ions and delocalised electrons; metallic bonding.\xe2\x97\x8f B & C \xe2\x86\x92 giant covalent ; strong forces between atoms; covalent.\xe2\x97\x8f N2, O2, F2 & Ne \xe2\x86\x92 simple molecular; weak intermolecular forces between molecules; covalent bonding within molecules and intermolecular forces between molecules.

cards.term: Describe the structure, forces and bonding in every element across period 3.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Na, Mg & Al \xe2\x86\x92 giant metallic; strong attraction between positive ions and delocalised electrons; metallic bonding\xe2\x97\x8f Si \xe2\x86\x92 giant covalent; strong forces between atoms; covalent.\xe2\x97\x8f P4, S8, Cl2 & Ar \xe2\x86\x92 simple molecular; weak intermolecular forces between molecules; covalent bonding within molecules and intermolecular forces between molecules.
Enthalpy change is heat energy change and is represented by the symbol \xe2\x88\x86H^\xd3\xa8.
Enthalpy is measured under standard conditions of 100 kPa pressure and a specified temperature, generally 298 K.
Activation energy is the minimum energy required for a reaction to take place between two colliding reactant particles.
Calorimetry is an experimental method for finding enthalpy change, which works by measuring temperature change over time.
Hess\xe2\x80\x99s law can be used to calculate an enthalpy change using given enthalpies of formation.
Catalysts are used in industry because they lower the energy costs of the reaction process.
Homogeneous catalysts are catalysts that are in the same phase as the reactants.
Heterogeneous catalysts are catalysts that are in a different phase to the species in the reaction.
Reversible reactions are reactions in which the products of a reaction can react together to reform the original reactants.
Involve removing one mole of electrons from one mole of gaseous ions.

Consists of a lattice of positively charged ions surrounded by a \xe2\x80\x98sea\xe2\x80\x99 of delocalised electrons. There are very strong electrostatic forces of attraction between the oppositely charged particles.
A solid giant covalent lattice is a network of atoms bonded by many strong covalent bonds.

Diamond is a macromolecular structure made up of carbon atoms, each of which are bonded to four further carbon atoms. This provides a very rigid structure, making diamond one of the hardest materials.
Graphite is another macromolecular structure made up of carbon atoms.
Graphene is a relatively new material consisting of single, 2D sheets of graphite that are just one atom thick.
Silicon is macromolecular meaning it has a very strong covalent structure.
The number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.
Describes an atom as a small dense nucleus with electrons orbiting around the nucleus. This model explains different periodic properties of atoms.
Positively charged ions.
The part of the periodic table in which the elements have their highest energy electron in a d-orbital.
The arrangement of electrons into orbitals and energy levels around the nucleus of an atom/ion.

The removal of one mole of electrons from one mole of gaseous atoms. Factors which affect the first ionisation energy are: the strength of attraction between the electron and the nucleus, the nuclear charge and the atomic radius. There is a small decrease in first ionisation energy due to s- and p subshell energies (between Be and B) and p-orbital repulsion (between N and O).

A network of atoms bonded by strong covalent bonds (e.g. carbon (diamond, graphite and graphene) and silicon). Giant covalent lattices typically insoluble with a high melting and boiling point due to the presence of strong covalent bonds. They are also poor electrical conductors as they don\xe2\x80\x99t contain mobile charged particles.

The structure of all metals, made up of cations and delocalised electrons. Giant metallic structures are typically insoluble with a high melting and boiling points due to strong electrostatic forces of attraction between cations and electrons. Metals are good electrical conductors due to the presence of delocalised electrons (mobile charges).
A column in the periodic table.
The temperature at which a solid melts and becomes a liquid. This increases from giant metallic to giant covalent structures then decreases to simple molecular structures.
Strong electrostatic attraction between cations and delocalised electrons.
The part of the periodic table in which the elements have their highest energy electron in a p-orbital.
A row in the periodic table.
A repeating trend in physical and chemical properties across the periods of the periodic table.
The part of the periodic table in which the elements have their highest energy electron in an s-orbital.
The energy required to remove each electron one-by-one from one mole of gaseous atoms/ions.

A substance that can accept H+ ions from another substance. Group 2 compounds can be used as bases: Ca(OH)2 is used to neutralise acidic soils in agriculture and Mg(OH)2 and CaCO3 are used as antacids to treat indigestion.
A compound with the general formula MO, where M is a group 2 element. When group 2 oxides react with water, they form an alkaline solution, with alkalinity increasing down the group.
The loss of electrons / increase in oxidation number.

A reaction in which oxidation of one element and reduction of another occurs. During a redox reaction involving group 2 elements, 2 electrons are lost to form 2+ ions. Group 2 elements undergo redox reactions with water, oxygen and dilute acids.
The gain of electrons/decrease in oxidation number.
The removal of one mole of electrons from one mole of gaseous 1+ ions to form one mole of 2+ ions.
The temperature at which a liquid boils and becomes a gas. Boiling point increases down group 7 due to the increasing strength of London Forces between the halogen molecules.
Molecules that are made up of 2 atoms. Halogens are diatomic.

A reaction in which one atom is replaced by another. Halogens can undergo displacement reactions as their reactivity decreases down the group. The more reactive halogen will displace the less reactive halogen from a solution of its salt.

The oxidation and reduction of the same element. Examples include the water treatment (reacting chlorine with water) and bleach formation (reacting chlorine with cold, dilute aqueous sodium hydroxide).
Forces of attraction between molecules caused when the random movement of electrons creates a temporary dipole in one molecule which then induces a dipole in a neighbouring molecule.
Another name for induced dipole-dipole interactions.
A reaction in which two aqueous solutions are combined to form an insoluble salt (a precipitate). Halide anions undergo precipitation reactions with aqueous silver ions.
A reaction in which oxidation of one element and reduction of another occurs. During a redox reaction involving group 7 elements, 1 electron is gained to form 1- ions.

The addition of chlorine to water to kill bacteria. The risks associated with the use of chlorine to treat water are the hazards of toxic chlorine gas and the possible risks from the formation of chlorinated hydrocarbons.
A negatively charged ion.
A positively charged ion.

Salt containing a group 7 anion. Cl-, Br- and I- can be tested for using a solution of silver ions as this reaction forms a coloured precipitate. The solubility of the precipitate is then tested using dilute and concentrated ammonia.
Identifies the elements present in a substance, typically using test-tube reactions.
The minimum energy required for a reaction to take place.
The energy required to break one mole of gaseous bonds. Actual bond enthalpies may differ from the average as the average bond enthalpy considers a particular bond in a range of molecules.
A reaction which takes in energy (\xce\x94H is positive). More energy is required to break bonds than is released by making bonds.
A value that represents the heat content of a system.

The change in the heat content of a system during a reaction. This can be determined from experimental results using q = mc\xce\x94T (where q is the heat change of the surroundings, m is the mass of the surroundings, c is the specific heat capacity and \xce\x94T is the change in temperature).
The enthalpy change that takes place when one mole of a substance is completely combusted.
The enthalpy change that takes place when one mole of a compound is formed from its elements.
The enthalpy change that takes place when one mole of water is formed from a neutralisation reaction.
The enthalpy change that is associated with a particular chemical equation.
Shows the difference in the enthalpy of reactants and products as well as the activation energy of a reaction.
A reaction which gives out energy (\xce\x94H is negative). More energy is released by bond making than is used in bond breaking.
the enthalpy change of a reaction is independent of the route it takes.
A pressure of 100 kPa and a temperature of 298 K.
The physical state (s, l, g, aq) of a substance under standard conditions.

A graph showing the distribution of the energies of molecules in relation to the activation energy. Increasing temperature will increase the proportion of molecules with energy above the activation energy. A catalyst lowers the activation energymeaning more molecules will have sufficient energy to react.

A substance that speeds up the rate of a reaction without being used up. A catalyst allows the reaction to proceed via a different route with a lower activation energy. Catalysts are important in terms of economics and sustainability as they enable processes to take place at lower temperatures meaning less energy is required (this decreases the combustion of fossil fuels so CO2 emissions are reduced).
The theory which states that molecules must collide with sufficient energy at the correct orientation for a reaction to occur.

The amount of a substance that is dissolved per unit volume of solution. Increasing the concentration increases the rate of reaction as there are more molecules in the same volume meaning more frequent successful collisions.
A catalyst that is in a different state to the reactants (e.g. a solid catalyst with gaseous reactants).
A catalyst which is in the same state as the reactants.

The force that a gas exerts on the walls of a container. Increasing the pressure increases the rate of reaction as there are more molecules in the same volume (or the same number of molecules in a smaller volume) meaning more frequent successful collisions.
A measure of how quickly a reactant is used up/ a product is formed. Rate can be determined by measuring concentration, the volume of gas produced or the mass lost over time.

Balancing several different factors in order to get the best possible outcome. In industry, the position of the equilibrium and rate of reaction must be considered when deciding the conditions for the reaction. These factors must also be balanced with safety and economics.
A closed system in which the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equivalent. The concentrations of reactants and products don\xe2\x80\x99t change.
An equilibrium in which all reactants are in the same state.

When a system in dynamic equilibrium is subject to change, the position of equilibrium will shift to minimise the change. This principle is used to determine the effect of changing pressure, temperature or concentration on the position of equilibrium.

The equilibrium constant that is equal to the concentration of products raised to their stoichiometric coefficients divided by the concentration of reactants to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients. When KC is greater than 1, the equilibrium favours the products. When KC is less than 1, the equilibrium favours the reactants.

cards.term: What happens when a molecule absorbs infrared radiation?
cards.definition: It makes the covalent bond vibrate more in a stretching or bending motion.

cards.term: What factors affect the amount of vibration of a bond?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Bond strength\xe2\x97\x8f Bond length\xe2\x97\x8f Mass of each atom in the bond

Every bond has a unique vibration frequency in the infrared region of the EM spectrum.Bonds absorb radiation that has the same frequency as their frequency of vibration.Infrared radiation emerged from a sample is missing the frequencies that have been absorbed \xe2\x86\x92 this information can be used to identify the compound\xe2\x80\x99s functional group.

cards.term: What do the peaks on an infrared spectrum represent?
cards.definition: Absorbance of energy from the infrared radiation.

cards.term: What are the 2 peaks that must be present to identify a substance as carboxylic acid?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Very broad peak at 2,500 - 3,300 cm-1 \xe2\x86\x92 O-H group\xe2\x97\x8f Sharp peak at 1680 - 1,750 cm-1 \xe2\x86\x92 C=O group

cards.term: What happens inside a mass spectrometer?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Organic compound is vaporised and passed through the spectrometer.\xe2\x97\x8f Some molecules lose an electron and forms molecular ions.\xe2\x97\x8f Excess energy from the ionisation makes the bonds vibrate more.\xe2\x97\x8f Vibration causes bond to weaken.\xe2\x97\x8f Molecular ion splits by fragmentation.

cards.term: What is the symbol of molecular ion?
cards.definition: M+
No, because it can happen anywhere in the molecule.

cards.term: In a mass spectrometry how is a molecular ion represented?
cards.definition: It is the peak with the highest mass/charge ratio.

cards.term: The molecular mass of the molecular ion is equal to what?
cards.definition: Relative molecular mass of the compound.

cards.term: Will the molecular ion peaks of two isomers of the same compound be same or different?
cards.definition: Same.

cards.term: What is the m/z value of OH- from alcohol?
What are the advantages of using mass spectrometry?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Cheap.\xe2\x97\x8f Small quantities of samples required.

cards.term: What is the main disadvantage of using mass spectrometry?
cards.definition: The sample is completely destroyed.

cards.term: Describe how a Quickfit apparatus is connected.
cards.definition: Grease the joints using some petroleum jelly on the inside of the joints before connecting the pieces together.

cards.term: In a distillation setup, why is it necessary to have a continuous water flow around the condenser?
cards.definition: So that the water remains cool in order for the mixture to be distilled.

cards.term: Describe a method that can be used to separate immiscible liquids.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Pour the mixture into a separating funnel and some distilled water.\xe2\x97\x8f Add the stopper and invert the flask to mix the mixture.\xe2\x97\x8f Equalise the pressure by opening the stopper as required.\xe2\x97\x8f Continue shaking until there is no \xe2\x80\x98whistle\xe2\x80\x99 sound.\xe2\x97\x8f To collect the water in the lower layer, open the stopper and place a beaker under the spout.\xe2\x97\x8f Use another beaker to collect the desired organic layer.\xe2\x97\x8f Shake the liquid with some drying agent.
1. Magnesium sulphate 2. Calcium chloride

\xe2\x97\x8f Add a selected drying agent to the organic product.\xe2\x97\x8f If the drying agent forms clumps add some more until they are moving freely.\xe2\x97\x8f Use gravity filtration to collect the dry product.\xe2\x97\x8f Filtrate is the product.
When a liquid is purified by using multiple distillations.

cards.term: How can unsaturated hydrocarbon be tested? What are the observations?
cards.definition: Use bromine water. Add few drops of bromine water to the sample and mix well. Positive test - bromine water turns colourless.

cards.term: What are the reagents used to test haloalkanes and what are the observations?
cards.definition: Reagents - silver nitrate, ethanol and waterObservations - chloro- : white precipitateBromo - : cream precipitate iodo- : yellow precipitate

cards.term: What are the 3 reagents that can be used to test carbonyls?
cards.definition: 1. Acidified potassium dichromate.2. Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s solution.3. Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 reagent.

cards.term: What are the observations when acidified potassium dichromate reacts with ketones and aldehydes?
cards.definition: Ketones - no changeAldehyde - turns from orange to green colour

cards.term: What are the observations when Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s solution is reacted with ketones and aldehydes?
cards.definition: Ketones - no changeAldehyde - dark red precipitate

cards.term: What are the observations when Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 reagent is reacted with ketones and aldehydes?
cards.definition: Ketones - no silver mirrorAldehydes - silver mirror

cards.term: What are the reagents that can be used to test carboxylic acid? What are the corresponding observations?
cards.definition: Universal indicator - pH of weak acidReactive metal - hydrogen effervescenceMetal carbonate - carbon dioxide effervescence
Saturated organic compounds that contain carbon atoms and at least one halogen atoms.
Insoluble as C-H bonds are non-polar, not compensated for enough by C-X bond polarity.

cards.term: Do halogenoalkanes have a polar bond? Why?
cards.definition: Yes polar, as halogen has a higher electronegativity than C (halogen is \xce\xb4-, carbon is \xce\xb4+).

cards.term: What type of intermolecular forces do they have? Why?
cards.definition: Permanent dipole-dipole and London forces of attraction C-X bond polarity creates permanent dipoles.

cards.term: When would they have higher boiling points?
cards.definition: Increase Carbon chain length. Halogen further down group 7.

cards.term: How would the mass of a haloalkane compare with the mass of an alkane of the same chain length?
cards.definition: Greater as mass of halogen > mass of H

cards.term: What is the most important factor in determining halogen reactivity?
cards.definition: The strength of carbon halogen bond.

cards.term: What would bond polarity suggest the order of reactivity would be?
cards.definition: C-F would be most reactive as most polar bond.

cards.term: What would bond enthalpies suggest the order of reactivity would be?
cards.definition: C-I would be most reactive as lowest bond enthalpy.
The halogen atom is present at the end of the chain.
Electron pair donor.
:OH-:CN-:NH3
A reaction where a nucleophile donates a lone pair of electrons to \xce\xb4+ C atom, \xce\xb4\xe2\x88\x92 atom leaves molecule (replaced by nucleophiles).
A reaction where water is a reactant.

cards.term: What reactant often produces hydroxide ions for hydrolysis?
cards.definition: Water

cards.term: What fission does water undergo to produce OH-?
cards.definition: Heterolytic fission.
Chlorine-fluoro-carbons - haloalkanes containing C, F and Cl only (no H).

cards.term: What is the problem with CFCs?
cards.definition: Although unreactive under normal conditions, they catalyse the breakdown of ozone in the atmosphere via free radical substitution.

cards.term: What is the main function of ozone layer?
cards.definition: Provides protection from harmful UV radiation.

cards.term: Does ozone play a protection role in all layers of the atmosphere?
cards.definition: No, in the troposphere it contributes towards photochemical smog.

cards.term: How do CFCs break the ozone layer down?
cards.definition: Free radical substitution.

cards.term: Write an equation for the overall decomposition of ozone into oxygen (O2).
What is the functional group of an alcohol?
cards.definition: Hydroxyl group -OH

cards.term: What is the general formula of an alcohol?
cards.definition: CnH2n+1OH

cards.term: How do you name alcohols (one prefix, one suffix)?
cards.definition: Hydroxyl- OR -ol.

cards.term: What kind of intermolecular forces do alcohols have? Why?
cards.definition: Hydrogen bonding, due to the electronegativity difference in the OH bond.

cards.term: How do alcohols\xe2\x80\x99 melting point and boiling point compare to other hydrocarbons\xe2\x80\x99 of similar C chain lengths? Why?
cards.definition: Higher, because they have hydrogen bonding (strongest type of intermolecular force) \xe2\x86\x92 stronger than London forces.

cards.term: Are alcohols soluble in water? Why does solubility depend on chain length?
cards.definition: Soluble when short chain - OH hydrogen bonds to hydrogen bond in water.Insoluble when long chain - non-polarity of C-H bond takes precedence.
C bonded to OH is only bonded to one other C atom.
C bonded to OH is bonded to two other C atoms.
C bonded to OH is bonded to three other C atoms.

cards.term: Write an equation for the combustion of ethanol.
What forms if you partially oxidise a primary alcohol?
cards.definition: An aldehyde.

cards.term: What conditions are needed to partially oxidise a primary alcohol?
cards.definition: Dilute sulphuric acid, potassium dichromate (VI), distill product as it\xe2\x80\x99s produced, gentle heating.

cards.term: Write an equation for the partial oxidation of ethanol.
cards.definition: CH3CH2OH (l) + [O] \xe2\x86\x92 CH3CHO (g) + H2O (l)

cards.term: What forms if you fully oxidise a primary alcohol?
cards.definition: A carboxylic acid.

cards.term: What conditions are needed to fully oxidise a primary alcohol?
cards.definition: Concentrated sulphuric acid, potassium dichromate (VI), reflux, strong heating.

cards.term: Write an equation for the full oxidation of ethanol.
cards.definition: CH3CH2OH (l) + 2[O] \xe2\x86\x92 CH3COOH (g) + H2O (l)

cards.term: What forms if you oxidise a secondary alcohol?
cards.definition: A ketone.

cards.term: What conditions are needed for the oxidation of a secondary alcohol?
cards.definition: Concentrated sulphuric acid, potassium dichromate (VI), strong heating.

cards.term: Write an equation for the oxidation of propan-2-ol.
cards.definition: CH3CH(OH)CH3 (l) + [O] \xe2\x86\x92 CH3COCH3 (g) + H2O (l)

cards.term: Is it possible to oxidise tertiary alcohol?
cards.definition: No.
A reaction where water is lost to form an organic compound.

cards.term: What are the products of dehydration reaction of alcohol?
cards.definition: Alkene and water.

cards.term: What are the conditions required for dehydration of alcohol?
cards.definition: Concentrated sulfuric acid or concentrated phosphoric acid and 170\xc2\xb0C.

cards.term: What are the products of the halide substitution reaction with alcohol?
cards.definition: Haloalkane and water.

cards.term: In what form is the halide used in halide substitution reaction?
cards.definition: In the form of hydrogen halide, e.g HBr.

cards.term: How is hydrogen halide made in situ? Give examples.
cards.definition: A salt is reacted with acid to form the hydrogen halide. E.g sodium bromide reacts with sulfuric acid to form HBr. When iodine is reacted phosphoric acid is used as sulfuric acid oxidises iodide ions into iodine.
Unsaturated hydrocarbons that contain at least one C=C bond made up of a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8b bond and a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8e bond.

cards.term: What is the general formula of alkenes?
cards.definition: CnH2n
Electrons in the adjacent p orbitals overlap above and below the carbon atoms. They can only be made after a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8e bond is formed.

cards.term: What bond restricts the rotation of carbon atoms?
cards.definition: \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8b bond

cards.term: What is the angle and shape of a double bond?
cards.definition: Trigonal planar: 120\xc2\xb0

cards.term: Are they more or less reactive than alkanes? Why?
cards.definition: More reactive due to high electron density of double bond and the fact the pi-bond is slightly easier to break.

cards.term: What intermolecular forces of attraction do they have?
cards.definition: Only London forces due to non-polar bonds.

cards.term: Are they soluble in water? Why?
cards.definition: No, non-polar bonds.

cards.term: What are the types of isomers that can be formed using alkenes?
cards.definition: E/Z isomers - due to the restricted rotation.Cis-trans isomers - if two of the same substituents are attached to each carbon.
Species that are electron pair acceptors.

cards.term: What is the most stable type of carbocation intermediate? Why?
cards.definition: Alkyl groups have a positive inductive effect, so the most stable carbocation is the one bonded to the most other carbon atoms. i.e. A tertiary carbocation.

cards.term: Major products will be formed from which kinds of carbocations?
cards.definition: Tertiary (or the most stable available)

cards.term: What conditions are needed for the electrophilic addition of H2O to an alkene? What is this type of reaction called?
cards.definition: Steam in the presence of an acid catalyst, usually phosphoric acid. Reaction is called hydration.

cards.term: What are the product(s) of the hydration reaction?
cards.definition: An alcohol.

cards.term: What conditions are needed for the electrophilic addition of a hydrogen halide to an alkene?
cards.definition: Hydrogen halide gases must be at room temperature.

cards.term: What is the reaction called when a halogen is added to alkene?
cards.definition: Halogenation

cards.term: How does a molecule with a non-polar bond react as if it is an electrophile?
cards.definition: C=C double bond with a high electron density induces a temporary dipole in the halogen molecule \xe2\x86\x92 \xce\xb4+ atom attracted to double bond.

cards.term: How can an alkene be converted into alkane? What is the reaction called and what are the required conditions?
cards.definition: Alkene + hydrogen = AlkaneHydrogenationConditions \xe2\x86\x92 150\xc2\xb0C, nickel catalyst
Many monomers bonded together via rearrangement of bonds without the loss of any atom or molecule.

cards.term: What are monomers? What form do they usually take?
cards.definition: Molecules which combine to form a polymer. Usually have a C=C bond which breaks to leave a repeating pattern.

cards.term: What are the ways in which plastics can be disposed?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Landfill\xe2\x97\x8f Combustion\xe2\x97\x8f Electricity generation\xe2\x97\x8f Reuse\xe2\x97\x8f Recycle\xe2\x97\x8f Organic feedstock

cards.term: What are the disadvantages of recycling?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Plastics must be sorted into different types\xe2\x97\x8f Expensive\xe2\x97\x8f Labour intensive\xe2\x97\x8f Requires high technology

cards.term: How does photodegradable polymers break down?
cards.definition: They are broken down chemically using energy with wavelengths similar to light. Once the break down begins it is not possible to stop the process.

cards.term: Explain what happens in organic feedstock.
cards.definition: Plastics are separated and broken down into small organic molecules through a series of reaction. The molecules can then be used produce plastics and in other industries.

cards.term: Give a disadvantage of photodegradable polymers.
cards.definition: May not be exposed to sufficient light.
A saturated hydrocarbons containing C-H bonds only.

cards.term: What is the general formula of an alkane?
cards.definition: CnH2n+2

cards.term: Are alkane bonds polar? Why/why not?
cards.definition: Nonpolar because carbon and hydrogen have similar electronegativities.

cards.term: What is the shape and angle of an alkane?
cards.definition: Tetrahedral: 109.5\xc2\xb0
The sigma bond is a covalent bond which has a direct overlap of the electron clouds of the bonding atoms.

cards.term: What type of intermolecular forces do alkanes have? Why?
cards.definition: London force \xe2\x86\x92 induced dipole-dipole interaction, because the bonds are nonpolar.

cards.term: What happens to the boiling point as alkane chain length increases? Why?
cards.definition: The boiling point increases because there is more surface area and so more number of induced dipole- dipole interaction. Therefore more energy required to overcome the attraction.

cards.term: Does a branched molecule have lower or higher boiling point compared to equivalent straight chain? Why?
cards.definition: The branched molecule has a lower boiling point because they have fewer surface area and hence less induced dipole -dipole interactions.

cards.term: Are alkanes soluble in water? why?
cards.definition: Insoluble because hydrogen bonds in water are stronger than alkanes\xe2\x80\x99 London forces of attraction.
Very unreactive.
Combustion and reaction with halogens.

cards.term: What type of reaction is combustion?
cards.definition: Oxidation reaction
Combustion that occurs with plentiful supply of air.

cards.term: What are the products of complete combustion when alkanes are used?
cards.definition: Carbon dioxide and water.

cards.term: What is the colour of the bunsen burner flame during complete combustion?
cards.definition: Blue Flame

cards.term: What is incomplete combustion and what products are formed in the case of alkanes?
cards.definition: Combustion in a limited supply of oxygen.Products : water, carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide

cards.term: Write an equation for the complete combustion of propane.
What type of hydrocarbon are most likely to undergo incomplete combustion?
cards.definition: Longer Chains

cards.term: What is the environmental impact of carbon monoxide?
cards.definition: It is toxic/poisonous.

cards.term: What is the environmental impact of soot (carbon)?
cards.definition: Asthma, cancer, global dimming.

cards.term: How are halogenoalkanes formed from alkanes?
cards.definition: Radical Substitution.

cards.term: In the presence of what does alkane react with halogens?
cards.definition: UV light

cards.term: What are the three stages of free radical substitution?
cards.definition: Initiation - breaking halogen bond to form free radicals.Propagation - chain part of the reaction where prod s are formed but free radical remains.Termination - free radicals removed, stable products formed.
The system used for naming organic compounds.

cards.term: What does the term empirical formula mean?
cards.definition: Simplest whole number ratio of atoms in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term molecular formula mean?
cards.definition: It provides the actual number of atoms of different elements in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term displayed formula mean?
cards.definition: It shows every atom and every bond in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term structural formula mean?
cards.definition: It shows the arrangement of atoms in a molecule without showing every bond.
A type of formula which is drawn as lines with each vertex being a carbon atom. Carbon atoms not drawn, assumed each C atom has all unspecified bonds as C-H.
A series of organic compounds having the same functional group but with each successive member differing by CH2.
A group of atoms responsible for characteristic reactions of a compound.
Hydrocarbon with carbon atoms joined together in a straight line or branched chain.
Hydrocarbons arranged in non aromatic rings with or without side chains.
Hydrocarbon that contains at least one benzene ring.

cards.term: Give the suffixes for:a) No double bondsb) At least one double bondc) An alcohold) An aldehydee) A ketonef) A carboxylic acid
cards.definition: a) No double bonds -aneb) At least one double bond -enec) An alcohol -old) An aldehyde -ale) A ketone -onef) A carboxylic acid -oic acid

cards.term: Give the prefixes for:a) CH3 groupb) C2H5 groupc) C3H7 groupd) C4H9 groupe) Cl groupf) Br groupg) I group
cards.definition: a) CH3 group methyl-b) C2H5 group ethyl-c) C3H7 group propyl-d) C4H9 group butyl-e) Cl group chloro-f) Br group bromo-g) I group iodo-

cards.term: What is the general formula of alkanes?
cards.definition: CnH2n+2

cards.term: What is the general formula of alkenes?
cards.definition: CnH2n

cards.term: What is the general formula of alcohols?
cards.definition: CnH2n+OH
Organic compounds which only contain single bonds.
Organic compounds that contain at least one carbon carbon double covalent bond.
When molecules have the same molecular formula but different structural formula.

cards.term: What are the 3 ways in which structural isomers can be formed?
cards.definition: 1. Alkyl groups can be in different places.2. Functional groups can be bonded to different parts.3. There can be different functional groups.
Organic compounds with the same molecular formula but have different arrangement of atoms in space.

cards.term: What is E-Z isomerism and how are the E and Z isomers decided?
cards.definition: E-Z isomerism is caused by the limited rotation about C=C double bonds.If the two substituents with the highest molecular mass are on the same side of the double bond, it is the Z (zusammen) isomer.If they are on different sides, it is the E (entgegen) isomer.
Special type of E/Z isomerism where the two substituents on each carbon atom are the same.
It happens when each bonding atom receives one electron from the bonded pair forming two radicals.
When one bonding atom receives both electrons from the bonded pair.
Highly reactive, neutral species.

cards.term: How is a covalent bond formed from two radicals?
cards.definition: The radicals collide and the electrons are involved the bond formation.

Alcohols contain an -OH group and follow the general formula CnH2n+1OH. They can be produced via two main methods of fermentation or hydration.Alcohols are named according to IUPAC rules and have the suffix -ol.Alcohols can be primary (1o), secondary (2o) or tertiary (3o), depending on the position of the hydroxyl group.
Hydrogen bonds are a much stronger intermolecular force than van der Waals forces so more energy is required to overcome them.
When burned in air, alcohols react with oxygen to form carbon dioxide and water. Alcohols make good fuels by reacting in this way as lots of energy is also released.
PCl5 is used to produce chloroalkanes.
Alkenes can be formed from the dehydration of alcohols, where a molecule of water is removed from the molecule. In order to do this, the alcohol is heated with concentrated phosphoric acid.
Primary and secondary alcohols can be oxidised to produce various products but tertiary alcohols are not easily oxidised.
A nucleophile is an electron pair donor. These species are \xe2\x80\x98positive liking\xe2\x80\x99. They contain a lone electron pair that is attracted to \xe2\x88\x82+ regions of molecules.

cards.term: Some of the most common nucleophiles.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f CN:-\xe2\x97\x8f :NH3\xe2\x97\x8f -:OH

Nucleophilic substitution is the reaction mechanism that shows how nucleophiles attack haloalkanes. Aqueous potassium hydroxide is used to produce alcohols, potassium cyanide is used to produce nitriles and ammonia is used to produce amines.

Reflux apparatus is used to continually heat the contents of the flask to allow reactions like the oxidation of primary alcohols to proceed all the way to the formation of carboxylic acids. The condenser helps ensure the vapours condense and return to the flask for further heating. This ensures the product vapours can not escape.

Distillation apparatus is used to separate liquids with different boiling points. The round-bottomed flask is heated and the liquid with the lower boiling point will evaporate first. It rises out of the flask and into the attached tubing which is surrounded by a condenser. The condenser causes the vapour to cool and condense back into a liquid, which is then collected in a separate flask.
A separating funnel is used to separate two liquids with different densities.
Subsequent distillations can be carried out to obtain a purer product.

A compound can be dried by the addition of an anhydrous (contains no water) salt. The anhydrous salt will absorb moisture and water present, thus drying and purifying the compound. Common anhydrous salts used for drying are magnesium sulphate and calcium chloride.

Synthetic routes are the routes which can be used to produce a certain product from a starting organic compound. It is important that you understand the different methods and conditions required to convert compounds to other products.
Renewable reagents with few safety concerns are preferred.
Less harmful by-products are favoured as there would be fewer safety and environmental concerns. If the by-products can be used in another industry, the process is more sustainable.
Choose the reaction with the most energy efficient and safe conditions.
Mass spectrometry is an analytical technique used to identify different molecules and find the overall relative molecular mass.

A sample is vaporised and injected into the mass spectrometer where a high voltage is passed over the chamber. This causes electrons to be removed from the atoms (they are ionised) leaving +1 charged ions in the chamber.
These positively charged ions are then accelerated towards a negatively charged detection plate.
The ions are then deflected by a magnetic field into a curved path. The radius of the path is dependent on the charge and mass of the ion.

When the positive ions hit the negatively charged detection plate, they gain an electron, producing a flow of charge. The greater the current produced, the greater the abundance of that particular ion.
The current values are then used in combination with the flight times to produce a spectra print-out with the relative abundance of each isotope displayed.

Organic chemistry mainly concerns the properties and reactions of hydrocarbons, compounds that contain only carbon and hydrogen atoms. Hydrocarbons form series of compounds with similar structures and formulas that can be represented in many different ways
Nomenclature is the set of rules that outline how different organic compounds should be named and how their formulas are represented.

Compounds are named according to rules laid out by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC). This ensures each compound is universally named the same - which helps to avoid potentially dangerous confusion.
The simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element in a compound.
The true number of atoms of each element in a compound.
The simplest algebraic formula of a member of a homologous series. All members of a homologous organic series follow the general formula.
- The minimal detail that shows the arrangement of atoms in a molecule.- The carboxyl group will be represented as COOH and the ester group as COO.
- The relative positioning of atoms and the bonds between them. Shows every atom and every bond in an organic compound.

- The simplified organic formula of just a carbon skeleton and functional groups.- Shows only the bonds in a compound and any non-carbon atoms.- Vertices are carbon atoms.- Hydrogen is assumed to be bonded to them unless stated otherwise.
- These compounds are represented by the symbols below.- Benzene can be represented in two equivalent ways.
A homologous series is a series of organic compounds with the same functional group but with each successive member differing by CH2.
Organic compounds are often part of a homologous series, in which all members follow a general formula and react in a very similar way.

An alkyl group is a hydrocarbon chain with the general formula CH\xe2\x82\x82\xe2\x82\x8a\xe2\x82\x81. Sometimes R may be used to represent alkyl groups, as well as other fragments of organic compounds not involved in reactions.
An aliphatic compound is a compound containing carbon and hydrogen joined together in straight chains, branched chains or non-aromatic rings.
An alicyclic compound is an aliphatic compound arranged in non-aromatic rings, with or without side chains.
An aromatic compound is a compound containing a fully conjugated ring. Benzene is aromatic.
