A compound is described as being saturated if it contains single carbon-carbon bonds only.
A compound is described as being unsaturated if it contains multiple carbon\xe2\x80\x93carbon bonds, including C=C, C\xe2\x89\xa1C, and aromatic rings.
Isomers are molecules with the same molecular formula but a different arrangement of atoms within the molecule. This gives the isomers a different structural formula.

Chain isomers have the same molecular formula but a different arrangement of the carbon skeleton. The isomers\xe2\x80\x99s carbon chain will differ - they can be straight chains or branched chains, however they will always have the same molecular formula.
Position isomers have the functional group of the molecule in a different position on the carbon chain.
Functional group isomers have the same molecular formula, but the molecules have a different functional group.
A \xe2\x80\x98curly arrow\xe2\x80\x99 is used to describe the movement of an electron pair during a reaction. It can show either heterolytic fission or the formation of a covalent bond.
1. Addition2. Substitution3. Oxidation4. Reduction5. Polymerisation6. Elimination
The reactants combine to form a single product.
One functional group is replaced by a different functional group.
A species loses at least one electron, and is oxidised.
A species gains at least one electron, and is reduced.
A reaction in which many small molecules, known as monomers, join together to form a long, repeating molecule called a polymer.
A small molecule is removed from a larger molecule.

Carbon monoxide is a toxic, gaseous product that is especially dangerous to humans as it is odourless and colourless. Carbon monoxide is dangerous because it replaces oxygen in the blood, starving the brain and other organs of oxygen and causing people to suffocate.

cards.term: Unsaturated hydrocarbons with at least one carbon-carbon double bond. They are part of a homologous series with the general formula CnH2n.
cards.definition: Alkenes and cycloalkenes.

The carbon-carbon double bond is an area of high electron density, making it susceptible to attack from electrophiles (species that are attracted to electron dense areas). It consists of a normal covalent \xcf\x83 bond and a \xcf\x80 bond.
The \xcf\x80-bond is formed by sideways overlap of adjacent p orbitals above and below the bonding C atoms.
The \xcf\x83-bond is formed by overlap of orbitals directly between the bonding atoms.

The C-H bonds are in the same plane as the C-C \xcf\x83 bond. There is trigonal planar geometry around the carbon atom and a bond angle of 120\xc2\xb0. This angle minimises electron-electron repulsion between bonding pairs.
Bromine water is used to identify an alkene double bond and other unsaturated compounds. Alkenes cause bromine water to change colour from orange-brown to colourless.
Stereoisomers are compounds with the same structural formula but with a different arrangement of atoms in space.
E-Z isomerism is a type of stereoisomerism, which occurs due to the limited rotation around a double carbon bond.
The limited rotation means that \xe2\x80\x98high priority\xe2\x80\x99 groups attached to the C=C can either be \xe2\x80\x98together\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98opposite\xe2\x80\x99.
Haloalkanes are organic compounds with single carbon bonds only and halogen functional groups.
Br\xe2\x82\x82 is present in bromine water in the test for unsaturation. This is an electrophilic addition reaction, forming a dihaloalkane.
Alcohols are organic compounds with a hydroxyl functional group, -OH. Alkenes undergo addition reactions with steam to form alcohols. This reaction requires an acid catalyst, such as phosphoric acid.
Electrophiles are electron pair acceptors and are attracted to areas of high electron density.
\xe2\x97\x8f HBr\xe2\x97\x8f Br2\xe2\x97\x8f H2SO4

Electrophilic addition is the reaction mechanism that shows how electrophiles attack the double bond in alkenes. When the double bond is broken, a carbocation intermediate forms. This is a carbon atom with only three bonds, so it has a positive charge.
Hydrogen bromide is polar due to the difference in the electronegativities of hydrogen and bromine.
Addition polymers are produced from alkenes which are short chain monomers which join together to form long chain polymers.
The energy and resources used to make polymers are large.

Polymers are made from alkenes which are obtained from crude oil, a non-renewable resource.Polymers are unreactive hydrocarbon chains with multiple strong, non-polar covalent bonds. This makes them useful for manufacturing many everyday plastic products such as poly(ethene) shopping bags.
A compound containing carbon and hydrogen only.
Has single bonds only.
Contains carbon-carbon multiple bonds.
A series of organic compounds having the same functional group but with each successive member differing by a CH2.
Part of molecule largely responsible for molecule\xe2\x80\x99s chemical properties.
Carbon atoms joined in unbranched/branched chains, or non aromatic rings.
An aliphatic compound arranged in non-aromatic ring, with without branches.
Some/all carbon atoms found in a benzene ring.
Contains at least one triple carbon-carbon bond.
Shows number of + type of atoms of each element in a molecule.e.g. C2H6O.
Simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present in a compound.e.g. C4H8 \xe2\x86\x92 CH2
Simplest algebraic formula for any member of a homologous series.
Shows relative positioning of all the atoms in a molecule and the bonds between them.
Uses the smallest amount of detail necessary to show the arrangement of atoms in a molecule.
Compounds with same molecular formula but different structural formula, can have same functional group at different point/different functional group.
Each of the covalently bonded atoms takes one of the shared electrons, forms 2 radicals.
One of covalently bonded atoms takes both the electrons, one becomes -ve ion and one becomes +ve ion.
Two reactants join to make one product.
Atom or group of atoms is replaced by a different atom/group of atoms.
Removal of a small molecule from a larger molecule.
The result of overlapping of 2 orbitals, one from each bonding atom, positioned on line directly between bonding atoms.
Have same structural formula but a different arrangement atoms in space.
A type of E/Z isomerism where one of groups on each carbon must be a hydrogen.

Groups of higher priority same side double bond=Z, groups of higher priority diagonally placed=E. highest priority determined by Mr of atoms attached directly to carbons in double bond (if atom is same, go along chain until 1st different).
An electron pair acceptor (usually a +ve ion or a molecule with atom with \xce\xb4+ charge).
Toys, guttering, windows etc.
Packaging material/food trays + cups.
Coating non-stick pans, cable insulation.
Conserves fossil fuels + decreases waste going in landfill. Have to be sorted by type, chopped into flakes, washed, dried, melted then cut into pellets + used to make new products.
Produced from plant starch, cellulose, plant oils + proteins- renewable & sustainable (protects environment & conserves oil reserves).
Broken down by microorganisms into water, carbon dioxide + biological compounds. Can be used as bin liners for food waste so both compost.
(Oil based) contain bonds weakened by absorbing light to start degradation OR light absorbing additives used.
An electron pair donor.
A chemical reaction involving water/aq solution of a hydroxide causing breaking of a bond in a molecule.
An aliphatic compound that is arranged in non-aromatic rings (with or without side chains).
A compound containing carbon and hydrogen atoms joined in straight or branched chains or in non-aromatic rings.
A homologous series with the general formula CnH2n+2.
A group with the general formula CnH2n+1.
An organic compound containing a benzene ring.
Shows the movement of a pair of electrons. Curly arrows must start from a bond, a lone pair of electrons or a negative change.
A partial charge on an atom which is caused by the differing electronegativities of atoms in a covalent bond.
The relative positions of atoms and the bonds between them.
The simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present in a compound.
A group of atoms responsible for the characteristic reactions of a compound.
The simplest algebraic formula of a member of a homologous series. E.g. Alkane: CnH2n+2.
When a covalent bond breaks, one bonding atom receives both electrons from the bonded pair.
A series of organic compounds containing the same functional group with successive members differing by -CH2.
When a covalent bond breaks, each bonding atom receives one electron from the bonding pair, forming 2 radicals.
International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry.
The number and type of atoms of each element in a molecule.
The naming system for compounds.
A carbon-containing compound.
A species with an unpaired electron.E.g. Cl\xe2\x80\xa2.
A series of steps that represent the overall reaction by showing the breaking and forming of bonds using curly arrows.
An organic compound which only contains C-C single bonds.
The simplified organic formula, is shown by removing hydrogen atoms from alkyl chains, leaving the carbon skeleton and the functional groups.
The minimal detail that shows the arrangement of atoms in a molecule.E.g. butane: CH3(CH2)2CH3.
Compounds with the same molecular formula but different structural formulae.
An organic compound which contains at least one C=C double bond, a C\xe2\x89\xa1C triple bond or an aromatic ring.
A type of covalent bond which forms when atomic orbitals overlap head-on. Sigma (\xcf\x83) bonds can rotate freely.

The temperature at which a liquid boils and becomes a gas. Shorter, more branched alkanes have higher boiling points as there are weaker London forces between the molecules which require less energy to overcome.
the energy required to break one mole of gaseous bonds. Actual bond enthalpies may differ from the average as the average bond enthalpy considers a particular bond in a range of molecules.
When a compound is burnt in a plentiful supply of oxygen. When alkanes are completely combusted, the only products are water and carbon dioxide.
A strong bond formed between 2 atoms due to the electrostatic attraction between a shared pair of electrons and the atomic nuclei.

Pairs of electrons around a nucleus repel each other so the shape that a molecule adopts has these pairs of electrons positioned as far apart as possible. As a result, carbon atoms in alkanes have a tetrahedral shape and a bond angle of 109.5\xc2\xb0.
A compound which contains hydrogen and carbon atoms only.
When a compound is burnt in a limited supply of oxygen. When alkanes are incompletely combusted, water, carbon monoxide, particulates and some carbon dioxide may be produced.
The first step in a radical substitution mechanism, involving the formation of the radicals.
Induced dipole-dipole interactions caused when the random movement of electrons creates a temporary dipole in one molecule which then induces a dipole in a neighbouring molecule.
A covalent bond that has a permanent dipole due to the different electronegativities of the atoms that make up the bond.
The intermediate steps in a radical substitution mechanism where a radical reacts with another species.

A type of substitution reaction in which a radical replaces another atom/ group of atoms in a compound. Alkanes can undergo radical substitution reactions with chlorine or bromine in the presence of UV light, forming a mixture of organic products (further substitution or reactions at different positions may occur).
The final steps in a radical substitution mechanism in which 2 radicals react together to form a species which only contains paired electrons.
The shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 4 bonding pairs of electrons.

A type of covalent bond formed when adjacent p orbitals overlap sideways above and below the bonding C atoms. Pi (\xcf\x80) bonds can\xe2\x80\x99t be rotated. As \xcf\x80-bonds have low bond enthalpy, alkenes are more reactive than alkanes.
The formation of a long chain molecule when many monomers join together (the polymer is the only product).
A reaction in which molecules combine to form a single product.
An organic compound containing at least one C=C double bond.
A substance that can be decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms.

A set of rules used to identify whether a stereoisomer is E or Z. Atoms with a higher atomic number have a higher priority. If the highest priority substituents on the same side of the double bond (both above or below), it\xe2\x80\x99s the Z isomer whereas if the highest priority groups are on the opposite sides (one above and one below), it\xe2\x80\x99s the E isomer.
A substance which increases the rate of a reaction without being used up.

A type of E/Z isomerism in which the two substituent groups attached to the cabon atoms are the same. According to the CIP priority rules, cis isomers have the highest priority substituents on the same side of the double bond (both above or below) while trans isomers have them on the opposite sides (one above and one below)
An electron pair acceptor.
A reaction in which a \xcf\x80 bond is broken and 2 new \xcf\x83 bonds form as a result of the addition of an electron pair acceptor (electrophile).

A type of stereoisomerism caused by the restricted rotation of \xcf\x80 bonds. Two different groups must be attached to each carbon atom of the C=C group. According to the CIP priority rules, Z isomers have the highest priority substituents on the same side of the double bond (both above or below) while E isomers have them on the opposite sides (one above and one below).

Used to predict what the major product of an addition reaction will be when H-X is added to an unsymmetrical alkene. H attaches to the less substituted carbon to generate the more stable carbocation intermediate.
A small molecule that is used to form polymers.
A substance that can be broken down by light.
A large molecule made from many small units that have been bonded together.
A molecule in which the carbon with the positive charge is only attached to one alkyl group. This is the least stable carbocation.
A structure within a polymer that appears over and over again. Joining many repeat units together would form the polymer.
A molecule in which the carbon with the positive charge is attached to two alkyl groups. This is more stable than a primary carbocation but less stable than a tertiary carbocation.
Compounds with the same structural formula but a different arrangement of atoms in space.
A molecule in which the carbon with the positive charge is attached to three alkyl groups. This is the most stable type of carbocation.
The shape of a molecule in which the central atom has 3 bonding pairs of electrons.

An organic compound containing the OH functional group. The polarity of the OH functional group means that alcohols can form hydrogen bonds and are soluble in water (when the alkyl chain is short). In addition to this, alcohols have a relatively low volatility compared with alkanes.
A rapid exothermic reaction of a substance with oxygen.
A type of reaction in which 2 atoms/ groups of atoms are removed from a molecule.
An organic compound containing a halogen atom (F/ Cl/ Br/ I) bound to an alkyl chain. Haloalkanes can be formed from alcohols via a substitution reaction with halide ions in the presence of acid.
An organic compound containing the C=O functional group in the middle of an alkyl chain. Ketones can be formed by the oxidation of a secondary alcohol.
A substance that can oxidise another species while being reduced.
An alcohol in which the OH is attached to a primary carbon atom (i.e. RCH2OH). Primary alcohols can be oxidised to form either an aldehyde or a carboxylic acid, depending on the conditions.
An alcohol in which the OH is attached to a tertiary carbon atom (i.e. R3COH). Tertiary alcohols cannot be oxidised.

A class of compound made up of carbon, fluorine and chlorine, used as refrigerants and aerosol propellants. CFCs can be broken down by UV light in the upper atmosphere to form chlorine radicals which catalyse the breakdown of ozone.
An organic compound containing a halogen atom (F/ Cl/ Br/ I) bound to an alkyl chain.

The breakdown of a compound as a result of a reaction with water. The rate of haloalkane hydrolysis for different carbon halogen bonds can be determined via a reaction with water in the presence of AgNO3 and ethanol.
An electron pair donor.
A reaction in which an electron pair donor attacks an electrophilic atom (an atom with a partial or full positive charge) to replace an atom / group of atoms.
A molecule with the formula O3, which absorbs UV light in the atmosphere. The breakdown of ozone can be catalysed by chlorine radicals as well as other radicals such as \xe2\x80\xa2NO.

A reaction in which one atom/ group of atoms replaces another. Haloalkanes can undergo substitution reactions with aqueous alkali or with water. The rate of reaction increases from C-F to C-I due to the decreasing bond enthalpy of the carbon-halogen bond.
A salt such as MgSO4 or CaCl2 which is used to remove traces of water from an organic solution.
A technique in which a liquid is heated then the vapour is cooled and collected in a separate flask to the reaction mixture. During distillation, the condenser must be positioned horizontally.
Glassware that easily fits together in a variety of arrangements.
A technique used to purify an organic liquid using multiple distillations.
The continual boiling and condensing of a reaction mixture. This is to ensure that the reaction goes to completion. During reflux, the condenser must be positioned vertically.
A piece of apparatus that is used to purify an organic liquid by removing the organic layer from an aqueous layer.
A series of steps that are followed to make a specific compound.
A sample is analysed to determine the proportion of elements that make up the compound present. This is done by converting a known amount of an unknown sample into simple known compounds.
During mass spectrometry, unstable molecular ions break down into smaller fragments.
Smaller ions formed when an unstable molecular ion breaks down during mass spectrometry.
A type of electromagnetic radiation that is absorbed by covalent bonds, causing them to vibrate at a specific frequency.

A technique used to identify particular bonds and functional groups within a molecule. This technique has been used to link global warming with increased energy usage as atmospheric gases containing C=O, O-H and C-H bonds (such as CO2, H2O and CH4) show distinct peaks on IR spectra. IR spectroscopy is used to monitor gases causing air pollution (CO and NO from car emissions) and to measure alcohol in the breath in modern breathalysers.
A small peak on a mass spectrum caused by the presence of a small proportion of carbon-13.
The mass to charge ratio on a mass spectrum. This is equivalent to the mass of an ion.
A technique used to identify compounds and determine relative molecular mass.
The peak on a mass spectrum with the highest m/z value, used to determine molecular mass of a compound.
The total number of atoms of each element in the compound.

topics.title: Module 5: Physical Chemistry and Transition Elements

cards.definition: A d block element that forms at least one stable ion with partially filled d subshel.

cards.term: Where are the transition metals located in the periodic table?
cards.definition: In the middle block from Ti to Cu.

cards.term: What are the 2 elements in d block that are not considered as transition metals?
cards.definition: Scandium and zinc.

cards.term: Why is scandium and zinc not considered as transition metals?
cards.definition: Scandium only forms Sc ^3+ , where the d orbitals are empty.Zinc only forms Zn^2+ where the d orbitals are full.

cards.term: Which electrons do transition metals lose first when forming ions?
cards.definition: 4s

cards.term: What are some characteristic physical properties of transition metals?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Metallic\xe2\x97\x8f High density\xe2\x97\x8f High melting and boiling point\xe2\x97\x8f Shiny\xe2\x97\x8f Good conductors of heat and electricity

cards.term: What are the characteristic chemical properties of transition metals (4)?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Variable oxidation states \xe2\x86\x92 take part in many redox reactions\xe2\x97\x8f Coloured compounds/ions in solution\xe2\x97\x8f Good catalysts\xe2\x97\x8f Form complex ions

cards.term: In potassium manganate (VII), what is the oxidation number of Mn?
cards.definition: Mn = +7

cards.term: What are the 2 main ways in which transition metals act as an effective catalyst?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f They provide a surface on which reaction can take place.\xe2\x97\x8f They change oxidation states to form intermediates required for pathways with lower activation energy.

cards.term: Give some examples of transition metal catalysts and the processes/reactions they catalyse (4)?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Iron - Haber process\xe2\x97\x8f Vanadium (V) oxide - contact process\xe2\x97\x8f Nickel - hydrogenation of alkenes\xe2\x97\x8f Manganese (IV) oxide - decomposition of hydrogen peroxide\xe2\x97\x8f Copper sulfate - hydrogen production
Transition metal ion bonded to one or more ligands by coordinate bonds.
Molecule or an ion that can donate a pair of electrons to the metal to form a coordinate bond.
A bond in which one of the atom provides both the electrons required for bonding, also known as dative bonding.

cards.term: What does the coordination number indicate?
cards.definition: The number of coordinate bonds formed between the metal ion and its ligands.
A ligand that forms one co-ordinate bond to the central metal ion (one lone pair to donate).
A ligand that forms two coordinate bonds to the central metal ion (2 lone pairs to donate).
A ligand that forms three or more coordinate bonds to the central metal ion.

cards.term: Name the most common bidentate ligand.
cards.definition: Ethane-1,2-Diamine

cards.term: How many coordinate bonds does EDTA^4- form?
cards.definition: Six (6)

cards.term: EDTA is a chelating agent, what does that mean?
cards.definition: EDTA decreases the concentration of metal ions in the solution by binding to them and forming complex ions.

cards.term: If a transition metal ion has 2 ligands, what shape is it usually?
cards.definition: Linear

cards.term: If a transition metal ion has 4 ligands, what shape is it usually?
cards.definition: Tetrahedral

cards.term: Name an exception to the general rule that ions with 4 ligands is generally tetrahedral. What shape is it?
cards.definition: Platin is square planar \xe2\x86\x92 Forms cisplatin

cards.term: What shape is a complex ion if it has 6 ligands?
cards.definition: Octahedral

cards.term: How can complex ions display E-Z or cis-trans isomerism? What shapes of ions does this  apply to?
cards.definition: Ligands differ in the way in which they are arranged in space 2 ligands of the same type can be on the same side of the metal ion (next to each other), which forms the E or cis isomer 2 ligands of the same type can be on opposite sides of the metal ion (not next to each other), which forms the Z or trans isomer Applies to square planar and octahedral complex ions.

cards.term: What conditions are needed for a complex ion to display optical isomerism?
cards.definition: Usually applies to octahedral molecules with 2 or more bidentate ligands, so that the mirror images are non superimposable.

cards.term: What is cis-platin used for? Describe its mechanism of action.
cards.definition: It is used as an anti-cancer drug. It binds to DNA of fast-growing cancer cells and prevents cell division, hence reducing the growth of cancer.

cards.term: Which metal ion is present in a haem group?
cards.definition: Fe^2+

cards.term: What is the coordination number of a haem group?
What are the ligands in haem group?
cards.definition: 4 nitrogen forming the porphyrin ring1 oxygen1 globin
A reaction where soluble ions in separate solutions are mixed to form an insoluble compound.

cards.term: Why are redox titrations with transition metal compounds said to be self-indicating?
cards.definition: They usually involve a colour change as the metal is changing oxidation state; sometimes an indicator is still needed/useful.

cards.term: Describe how to test for metal ions.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Fill half of the test tube with the sample.\xe2\x97\x8f Add aqueous ammonia or sodium hydroxide drop by drop.\xe2\x97\x8f Colour of precipitate indicates the ion present.

cards.term: Write the method used to test for ammonium ions.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Fill half the test tube with sample.\xe2\x97\x8f Add sodium hydroxide and warm gently.\xe2\x97\x8f Smelly gas is produced; damp red litmus paper turns blue.

cards.term: Why does lime water turn milky in the presence of carbon dioxide?
cards.definition: When carbon dioxide is bubbled in calcium hydroxide (lime water), calcium carbonate precipitate is formed.
A species that is reduced in a reaction and causes another species to be oxidised.
A species that is oxidised in a reaction and causes another species to be reduced.
- Loss of electrons.- An increase in the oxidation number.
- Gain of electrons.- Decrease in the oxidation number.

cards.term: What happens in a redox reaction?
cards.definition: Electrons are transferred from one species to another. One element is oxidised whilst the other is reduced.
The E.M.F. of a half cell compared with a standard hydrogen half cell measured at 298 K with solution concentration of 1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm^-3 and a gas pressure of 100 kPa.

cards.term: What happens when a rod of a metal is dipped into a solution of its own ions?
cards.definition: An equilibrium is set up between the solid metal and the aqueous metal ions.

cards.term: Write a half-equation for zinc (s) to zinc (II).
cards.definition: Zn (s) \xe2\x87\x8c Zn^2+ (aq) + 2e^-

cards.term: Write a half-equation for copper (II) to copper (III).
cards.definition: Cu^2+ (aq) \xe2\x87\x8c Cu^3+ (aq) + e^-

cards.term: What is a standard hydrogen half cell made of?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Hydrochloric acid 1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm^-3\xe2\x97\x8f Hydrogen gas at 100 kPa\xe2\x97\x8f Inert platinum electrode

cards.term: Why is hydrogen half cell used as a standard half cell?
cards.definition: Easy to control its purity and reproducibility.

cards.term: How to make a simple salt bridge?
cards.definition: Soak a piece of filter paper in an aqueous solution of KNO3 or NH4NO3.
To complete the circuit by connecting the two solutions. This enables charge to be transferred between the half cells. They do not react with the electrodes.

cards.term: Why might you use other standard electrodes occasionally?
cards.definition: They are cheaper/easier/quicker to use and can provide just as good a reference. Platinum is expensive.

cards.term: If an E\xc2\xb0 value is more negative, what does it mean in terms of oxidising/reducing power?
cards.definition: Better reducing agent (easier to oxidise).

cards.term: If an E\xc2\xb0  value is more positive, what does it mean in terms of oxidising/reducing power?
cards.definition: Better oxidising agent (easier to reduce).

cards.term: When would you use a Platinum electrode?
cards.definition: When both the oxidised and reduced forms of the metal are in aqueous solution.
Inert and good conductor to complete circuit.

cards.term: How would you predict if a reaction would occur?
cards.definition: 1. Take the 2 half equations.2. Find the species that is being reduced.3. Calculate its E\xc2\xb0 value minus the E\xc2\xb0 value of the species that is being oxidised.4. If E\xc2\xb0 overall > 0.4V , reaction will occur.

cards.term: What are the 3 main types of electrochemical cells?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Non rechargeable cells\xe2\x97\x8f Rechargeable cells\xe2\x97\x8f Fuel cells

cards.term: Describe how non rechargeable cells work.
cards.definition: They provide electrical energy until all the chemicals have reacted.
Chemicals in the cell provide electrical energy. When recharging the reactions of the cells can be reversed.

cards.term: Give some examples of rechargeable cells.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Nickel and cadmium batteries\xe2\x97\x8f Lithium ion batteries\xe2\x97\x8f Lithium polymer batteries

cards.term: Explain why lithium is used in laptop batteries.
cards.definition: Lithium has low density so the electrode is light and it is very reactive.

cards.term: What are the drawbacks of using lithium batteries?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f They are toxic if ingested.\xe2\x97\x8f Rapid discharge of current can cause fire or even explosions.
The cell uses external supplies of fuel and an oxidant. These external supplies need to be continuously supplied.

cards.term: Modern fuel cells are based on what type of fuels?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Hydrogen\xe2\x97\x8f Hydrogen rich fuels e.g methanol

cards.term: What are the disadvantages of fuel cells?
cards.definition: 1. Hydrogen is a flammable gas with a low b.p. \xe2\x86\x92 hard anddangerous to store and transport \xe2\x86\x92 expensive to buy2. Fuel cells have a limited lifetime and use toxic chemicals in their manufacture.

cards.term: What is the reason that some cells cannot be recharged?
cards.definition: Reaction of the cell is not reversible - a product is produced that either dissipates or cannot be converted back into the reactants.

cards.term: Why might the e.m.f. Of a cell change after a period of time?
cards.definition: Concentrations of the ions change - the reagents are used up.

cards.term: How can the E.M.F. of a cell be kept constant?
cards.definition: Reagents are supplied constantly, so the concentrations of the ions are constant; E\xc2\xb0 remains constant.
A measure of the dispersal of energy in a system which is greater when the system is more disordered.

cards.term: What is the symbol of entropy?
cards.definition: S

cards.term: Solid or gas, which is more disordered?
cards.definition: Gas

cards.term: What is the unit of standard entropy?
cards.definition: J\xe2\x80\xa2K^-1\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-1
The greater temperature particles have more energy and move more. Thus the arrangement of particles become more random.More random arrangement = Higher entropy

cards.term: When a solid ionic lattice is dissolved in solution what happens to entropy?
cards.definition: Entropy increases because the ions are more disordered.

cards.term: How does change in number of gas molecules in a reaction affect entropy?
cards.definition: Increase in number of gas molecules = Increase in entropyDecrease in number of gas molecules = Decrease in entropy

cards.term: For a reaction to occur spontaneously \xce\x94G must be positive or negative?
cards.definition: Negative

cards.term: What are the limitations of the predictions of feasibility made by using \xce\x94G?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Reaction may have high activation energy\xe2\x97\x8f Rate of reaction may be very slow
Formation of 1 mole of ionic lattice from gaseous ions under standard conditions.

cards.term: What does a more exothermic lattice enthalpy mean?
cards.definition: More exothermic = More stronger ionic bonds

cards.term: Why is it not possible to measure lattice enthalpy directly?
cards.definition: It is not possible to form 1 mole of ionic solid from its gaseous ions.
Enthalpy change that takes place when 1 mole of a solute is completely dissolved in water under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change that takes place when dissolving one mole of gaseous ions in water.

cards.term: What are the factors that impact the size of lattice enthalpy?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Size of ions involved\xe2\x97\x8f Charges on the ions\xe2\x97\x8f Ionic bond strength

cards.term: Which ions have more negative lattice enthalpy values? smaller / larger ions?Why?
cards.definition: Smaller ions because they can get closer hence more stronger attraction.
When a ionic lattice is broken the ions become part of the solution.Positive ions get attracted towards slightly negative oxygen and negative ions get attracted towards slightly positive hydrogen.

cards.term: What are the factors that impact the magnitude of the enthalpy of hydration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Size of the ion\xe2\x97\x8f Charge on the ions
Proton donor.
Proton acceptor.
Electron pair donor.
Electron pair acceptor.

cards.term: What ion causes a solution to be alkaline?
cards.definition: -OH (hydroxide ion)

cards.term: Write an equation for the ionisation of water.
cards.definition: 2H2O (l) \xe2\x87\x8c H3O + (aq) + -OH (aq)OR H2O (l) \xe2\x87\x8c H + (aq) + -OH (aq)

cards.term: Give example of a monobasic acid.
cards.definition: HCl

cards.term: Give example of a dibasic acid.
cards.definition: H2SO4

cards.term: Give example of a tribasic acid.
cards.definition: H3PO4
Acids dissociate completely.

cards.term: Give some examples of strong acids.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Hydrochloric acid\xe2\x97\x8f Sulfuric acid\xe2\x97\x8f Nitric acid

cards.term: What is the difference between concentrated and strong?
cards.definition: Concentrated means many mol per dm3, strong refers to amount of dissociation.
Acids that only partially dissociate.

cards.term: Give some examples of weak acid.
cards.definition: Methanoic acid, any organic acid.

cards.term: What is constant that is used to measure the extent of acid dissociation called?
cards.definition: Acid dissociation constant.

cards.term: What is the symbol of acid dissociation constant?
cards.definition: Ka

cards.term: What does a larger Ka value mean?
cards.definition: Larger the Ka - greater the extent of dissociation.

cards.term: Write the equation used to convert Ka into pKa
cards.definition: p\xe2\x80\xa2Ka = -log10\xe2\x80\xa2Ka

cards.term: What is the relationship between pKa and strength of the acid?
cards.definition: Smaller the pKa stronger the acid.

cards.term: Write the equation used to convert concentration of H + into pH.
cards.definition: pH = -log[H+]

cards.term: Write the equation used to convert pH into concentration of H+.
Why is a pH scale usefulcompared to concentration of H+?
cards.definition: pH scale allows a wide range of H + concentration to be expressed as simple positive values.

cards.term: What is the relationship between pH and [H+]?
cards.definition: High pH value means a small [H+].

cards.term: If two solutions have a pH difference of 1, what is the difference in [H+]?
cards.definition: A factor of 10.

cards.term: [H+] of a strong acid is equal to what?
What is the assumption made when calculating pH of weak acids?
cards.definition: It is assumed that the concentration of acid at equilibrium is equal to the concentration of acid after dissociation. This is because only very little of the acid dissociates

cards.term: Write the expression for ionic product of water, Kw.
cards.definition: Kw = [H+][OH-]

cards.term: What is the units for Kw?
cards.definition: mol^2\xe2\x80\xa2dm^-6

cards.term: What is the value of Kw at 298 K?
What physical factors affect the value of Kw? How do they affect it?
cards.definition: Temperature only - if temperature is increased, the equilibrium moves to the right so Kw increases and the pH of pure water decreases.

cards.term: Indices of of [H + ] and [OH-] always adds up to what value?

cards.definition: Base that dissociates 100% in water.

cards.term: Give examples of some strong bases.
cards.definition: NaOHKOHCa(OH) 2

cards.term: Give example of a weak base.
cards.definition: Ammonia

cards.term: Write the equation used to calculate [H+] of strong bases.

cards.definition: A mixture that minimises pH change on addition of small amounts of an acid or a base.

cards.term: What are the 2 ways in which buffers can be made?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Weak acid and its conjugate base.\xe2\x97\x8f Weak acid and a strong alkali.

cards.term: In which direction does the equilibrium shift when an acid is added to a buffer solution? Why?
cards.definition: Equilibrium shifts to the left because [H+] increases and the conjugate base reacts with the H+ to remove most of the H+.

cards.term: In which direction does the equilibrium shift when an alkali is added to a buffer solution? Why?
cards.definition: Equilibrium shifts to the right, because [OH-] increases and the small concentration of H+ reacts with OH-. To restore the H+ ions HA dissociates shifting the equilibrium.
The addition of an acid/base of known concentration to a base/acid to determine the concentration. An indicator is used to show that neutralisation has occurred, as is a pH meter.
The point at which the exact volume of base has been added to just neutralise the acid, or vice-versa.
The point at which pH changes rapidly.

cards.term: What are the properties of a good indicator for a reaction?
cards.definition: Sharp colour change (not gradual) - no more than one drop of acid/alkali needed for colour change End point must be the same as the equivalence point otherwise titration gives wrong answer. Distinct colour change so it is obvious when the end point has been reached.

cards.term: What indicator would you use for a strong acid-strong base titration?
cards.definition: Phenolphthalein or methyl orange, but phenolphthalein is usually used as clearer colour change.

cards.term: What indicator would you use for a strong acid-weak base titration?
cards.definition: Methyl Orange

cards.term: What indicator would you use for a strong base-weak acid titration?
cards.definition: Phenolphthalein

cards.term: What indicator would you use from a weak acid-weak base titration?
cards.definition: Neither methyl orange or phenolphthalein is suitable, as neither give a sharp change at the end point.

cards.term: What colour is methyl orange in acid?In alkali?
cards.definition: Red in acid; yellow in alkali.

cards.term: What colour is phenolphthalein in acid? In alkali?
cards.definition: Colourless in acid; red in alkali.

cards.term: What colour is bromothymol blue in acid? In alkali?
cards.definition: Yellow in acid and blue in alkali.

cards.term: Describe how to use a pH metre.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Remove the pH probe from storage solution and rinse with distilled water.\xe2\x97\x8f Dry the probe and place it into the solution with unknown pH.\xe2\x97\x8f Let the probe stay in the solution until it gives a settled reading.

cards.term: What does it mean when a reaction is at equilibrium?
cards.definition: The rate of forward and reverse reactions are equal.

cards.term: What are the methods that can be used to measure equilibrium?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Measure change in colour or colour intensity using colorimeter.\xe2\x97\x8f Use pH probe.\xe2\x97\x8f Measure electrical conductivity.\xe2\x97\x8f Titration - used when equilibrium is slow so that titration can be completed before there is much change in equilibrium mixture.
The amount of a given component in a given reaction mixture.

cards.term: Write the equation used to calculate mole fraction.
cards.definition: Mole fraction = number of moles of substance A / total number of moles of all substances
The pressure exerted by a single species in a reaction vessel.

cards.term: What is the symbol for partial pressure?
cards.definition: P

cards.term: Write the equation used to calculate partial pressure.
cards.definition: Partial pressure = Mole fraction x total pressure

cards.term: What is the relationship between concentration of a substance and its partial pressure?
cards.definition: Concentration of a substance is proportional to its partial pressure.

cards.term: What are the 3 common units of pressure used in chemistry?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Pascals\xe2\x97\x8f Atmospheres\xe2\x97\x8f Newtons per square metre

cards.term: What type of brackets are used in Kc expressions?
cards.definition: Square Brackets

cards.term: What type of brackets are used in Kp expressions?
cards.definition: Round Brackets

cards.term: How do you calculate the units for Kp?
cards.definition: Write out the units for the partial pressures in the same arrangement as the Kp equation and cancel out/multiply together. Usually in Pa, kPa, atm etc. DO NOT CHANGE UNITS.

cards.term: What is the symbol of equilibrium constant?
cards.definition: K

cards.term: What does it mean when K is greater than 1?
cards.definition: Reaction favours product.

cards.term: What does it mean when K is lesser than 1?
cards.definition: The reaction favours reactants.

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on K?
cards.definition: Equilibrium shifts to the direction of endothermic reaction.

cards.term: What is the effect of decreasing temperature on K?
cards.definition: Equilibrium shifts to the direction of exothermic reaction.

cards.term: What is the only factor that affects K?
cards.definition: Temperature

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on K for a forward endothermic reaction?
cards.definition: K increases as temperature increases.

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing temperature on K for a forward exothermic reaction?
cards.definition: K decreases as temperature increases.

cards.term: What effect does catalyst have on K ?
cards.definition: Catalysts does not affect the position of equilibrium, they only have an effect on the rate of reaction.
Change in concentration of a reactant or a product per unit time.

cards.term: At a given instant, how could you calculate the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: Rate of reaction = Change in concentration of reactants or products / Time

cards.term: If the order is zero with respect to a reactant, what does that mean?
cards.definition: Changing the concentration of the reactant has no effect on the rate.

cards.term: What is the effect on rate in a first order reaction?
cards.definition: Rate is directly proportional to the concentration.

cards.term: What is the effect on rate in a second order reaction?
cards.definition: Change in rate = Change in concentration squared

cards.term: Write a generic rate equation and state what each term means.
cards.definition: Do zero order reactants appear on rate equation? Why?

cards.term: Do zero order reactants appear on rate equation? Why?
cards.definition: No, because they don\xe2\x80\x99t have an effect on the rate.

cards.term: How is overall order of a reaction calculated?
cards.definition: Sum of individual orders.

cards.term: When the overall order is 3, what would be the units for rate constant?
cards.definition: dm^6\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-2\xe2\x80\xa2s^-1

cards.term: How could you measure the rate of reaction experimentally (different methods)?
cards.definition: Use a colorimeter at suitable intervals if there is a colour change.If gas is evolved, use a gas syringe to collect volume of gas evolved, or measure the change in mass of the reaction mixture.
The time taken for concentration of a reactant to decrease by half.

cards.term: What is the symbol for half life?
What is the relationship between first order reactions and half life?
cards.definition: First order reactants have constant half lifes.

cards.term: What is the equation that is used to determine rate constant using half life in a first order reaction?
How would you draw a rate concentration graph?
cards.definition: Plot [A] against time, draw tangents at different values \xe2\x86\x92 draw a secondary graph of rate against [A]

cards.term: What is the relationship between rate and time?
cards.definition: Rate \xe2\x88\x9d 1/t

cards.term: How to determine the rate constant from a rate concentration graph of first order?
cards.definition: k = rate / concentration
The slowest step in a reaction with multiple steps.

cards.term: How does the rate determining step link to the species involved in the rate equation?
cards.definition: Any species involved in the rate determining step appear in the rate equation. Species only involved after the rate determining step do not appear in the rate equation.

cards.term: For a reactant in the rate equation, what indicates how many molecules of that reactant are involved in the rate determining step?
cards.definition: The order of the reactant.

cards.term: The rate equation of a reaction is rate = k[NO]^2 . How many molecules of NO will be present in the rate determining equation?
What affects the value of the rate constant for a given reaction?
cards.definition: Temperature, nothing else.

cards.term: What is the effect of a 10\xe2\x84\x83 temperature increase on the rate of reaction, roughly?
cards.definition: Doubles rate of reaction.

The transition metals are elements in the d-block of the periodic table that form one or more stable ions with a partially filled d-orbital. Transition metals lose electrons to form positive ions, with the s-orbital electrons being removed first.
Copper and chromium are exceptions to the rule that the 4s subshell is filled before the 3d subshell.

A ligand is a molecule or ion with a lone electron pair that is able to form a dative (coordinate)bond to the central metal ion by donation of this electron pair. Common ligands include:\xe2\x97\x8f Cl-\xe2\x97\x8f H2O\xe2\x97\x8f NH3
Monodentate ligands each form one coordinate bond.Examples: H2O, Cl-, NH3.
Bidentate ligands each form two coordinate bonds. Example: NH2CH2CH2NH2.

The coordination number of a transition metal complex is the total number of coordinate bonds formed with the central metal ion. Silver complexes have a coordination number of 2 and platinum complexes commonly have a coordination number of 4. The coordination number determines the shape of the complex ion.

Some metal ions and complexes are colourless. Colour arises when some wavelengths of light are absorbed while others are reflected. This involves the excitation of electrons. Ions and complexes where there are no available electrons to excite cannot absorb light and are therefore colourless.
Transition metal complexes with H2O and NH3 ligands commonly form octahedral complexes with a bond angle of 90\xc2\xb0. Octahedral complexes are formed when there is six-fold coordination.
When complexes form with larger ligands such as Cl-, they form tetrahedral complexes with a bond angle of 109.\xc2\xb0 and 4 ligands coordinated. Tetrahedral complexes can show optical isomerism.
Platinum and nickel complexes form in a square planar shape. This consists of four coordinate bonds with a bond angle of 90\xc2\xb0.
Optical isomerism is seen in some octahedral complexes with bidentate ligands. These complexes have non-superimposable mirror images.

In ligand substitution reactions, a positive entropy change is favourable as it means a more stable complex is being formed. Therefore, it is favourable to have more moles on the right of the reaction than on the left. This is achieved by substituting monodentate ligands with bidentate or polydentate ligands. This is known as the chelate effect.

The enthalpy change (\xe2\x88\x86H) for ligand substitution reactions is very small as the bonds being formed are very similar to the bonds that were broken. Therefore, overall enthalpy change isnear to zero.
The most stable oxidation states of iron are Fe^2+ and Fe^3+.
The most stable oxidation states of copper are Cu^+ and Cu^2+.
Can be reduced to Cu by zinc.
Readily disproportionates to Cu and Cu^2+.

If ammonium ions are present, adding NaOH and gently warming results in the formation of ammonia gas, which is basic. Therefore, the presence of ammonium ions can be tested by holding damp red litmus paper over a petri dish of the substance being tested. It will turn blue if ammonium ions are present.

Transition metals form coloured compounds. This property can be used to determine which transition metal ions are present in a compound. The previous section explores the colours of chromium(III), iron(II), iron(III), manganese(II) and copper (II) metal-aqua ions and their precipitation reactions with sodium hydroxide and ammonia.
Lattice enthalpies are used for ionic substances. Lattice enthalpy is a measure of the strength of ionic bonding in a giant ionic lattice.
The enthalpy change when one mole of a solid ionic compound is completely dissociated into its gaseous constituent ions under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of a solid ionic compound is formed from its gaseous constituent ions under standard conditions.
The energy required for the formation of one mole of gaseous atoms from an element under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is added to a mole of gaseous atoms to form one mole of gaseous 1- ions under standard conditions.
Born-Haber cycles are similar to the cycles used with Hess\xe2\x80\x99s Law.
The enthalpy change when one mole of ionic solid is dissolved in water to infinite dilution so that the ions no longer interact under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous ions is dissolved in water to form one mole of aqueous ions under standard conditions.
1. Balance all atoms except for oxygen and hydrogen.2. Add H2O to balance oxygens (if needed).3. Add H+ ions to balance hydrogens (if needed).4. Add e- to balance charges (if needed).

Electrochemical cells use redox reactions since the electron transfer between products creates a flow of electrons. This flow of charged particles is an electrical current that flows between electrodes in the cell. A potential difference is produced between the two electrodes which can be measured using a voltmeter.

The standard hydrogen electrode is the measuring standard for half-cell potentials. It has a cell potential of 0.00V, measured under standard conditions. These conditions are:\xe2\x97\x8f Solutions of 1.0 mol dm^-3 concentration\xe2\x97\x8f A temperature of 298K\xe2\x97\x8f 100 kPa pressure
There are limitations to both calculating a standard cell potential using the SHE and using the calculated value to determine reaction feasibility.
Electrochemical cells can be a useful source of energy for commercial use. They can be produced to be non rechargeable, rechargeable or fuel cells.

Fuel cells are a type of electrochemical cell which continuously produces a voltage when supplied with a fuel and oxygen. The fuel donates electrons at one electrode and oxygen gains electrons at the other electrode. The energy released is used to generate a voltage.
Lithium ion batteries are a commonly used example of an electrochemical cell. They are rechargeable, however, their benefits are counteracted by risks of toxicity and fire.
The rate of a reaction shows how fast reactants are converted into products. It depends on the concentrations of the reactants and the rate constant.

The rate constant for a reaction is constant when the reaction temperature is constant. The rate constant relates the concentrations of the species that affect the rate of a reaction to the overall rate of reaction. The rate constant, k, can be calculated by rearranging the rate equation for that reaction.
Using the initial rate of reactions is one way the order of a reaction can be determined. This involves varying the concentrations of reactants and measuring the initial rate of the reaction.
No change to the initial rate.
Initial rate doubles.
Initial rate quadruples (2^2).

If a gas is produced by a reaction, then the mass of the reaction mixture will decrease as the reaction proceeds. Plotting a mass-time graph and drawing a tangent to the curve can be used to find the rate of reaction.

If a gas is produced by a reaction, the rate of reaction can be found by measuring the volume of gas produced over the course of the reaction, and plotting a graph of volume evolved against time. A gas syringe or an underwater upside down measuring cylinder can be used to collect the gas.

Small samples of a reaction mixture can be removed at regular intervals throughout a reaction. These samples can then be titrated to determine the concentration of a given reactant or product at that time. A concentration-time graph can then be plotted.

Colorimetry can be used to determine the rate of reaction for a reaction that involves the formation or depletion of a coloured species. A colorimeter is a device that measures the amount of light that is absorbed by a solution. The amount of light absorbed by the solution is proportional to the concentration of the coloured species.
A mole fraction shows the proportion that a molecule accounts for of the total moles present. It is calculated by dividing moles of substance A by the total moles present.

K_c is the equilibrium constant of a reversible reaction. Kc is equal to the concentration of the products divided by the concentration of the reactants at equilibrium. The concentration terms are raised to a power of the same value as the number of moles of that substance.

Kp is the equilibrium constant used for gaseous equilibria. Kp is calculated from gaseous reactants and products. If all reactants and products are in the gaseous state, the system is said to be homogeneous.
A Br\xc3\xb8nsted-Lowry acid is a proton donor. For example, ammonium ions (NH4+).
A Br\xc3\xb8nsted-Lowry base is a proton acceptor. For example, hydroxide ions (OH-).
A conjugate acid is the species formed when a base accepts a proton.
A conjugate base is the species formed when an acid donates a proton.
Spectator ions are ions that do not change in the reaction and are left out of the ionic equation.
pH is a measure of acidity and alkalinity.

If you dilute a strong acid 10 times its pH will increase by one unit, because pH is a logarithmic scale. Diluting it 100 times and 1000 times would, therefore, increase the pH by two units and three units, respectively.

1. Acid + Base - Find the number of moles of each species.- Calculate their concentration when at equilibrium using the total volume.- Use Ka to find [H+] and therefore pH.2. Acid + Salt - Find the moles of the salt.- Use Ka to find pH.
pH increases rapidly on the addition of a small volume of base. acid/base concentration is similar.
Continuous measurements taken during the course of a reaction.
Instantaneous rate at the start of a reaction when time=0, found by measuring.
A convenient way of obtaining initial rate with single measurement.
Electrode (dipped into solution), connected to meter displaying reading.
The volume of one solution that exactly reacts with the volume of the other solution (at the centre of the vertical section).
Weak acid with distinctively different colour to conjugate base (e.g. methyl orange: weak acid is red, conjugate base is yellow, end point colour between two so orange).
The enthalpy change that accompanies the formation of one mole of an ionic compound from its gaseous ions under standard conditions (always exothermic).
Dispersal of energy within the chemicals making up the chemical system (units J\xe2\x80\xa2K^-1\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-1).
The entropy of one mole of a substance under standard conditions (+ve).
Whether a reaction is able to happen and is energetically feasible.
Overall energy change during a chemical reaction. Made up of enthalpy change and entropy change.
Converts chemical energy into electrical energy. Made by connecting 2 different half cells, allowing electrons to flow (not made by mixing cells- would produce heat energy.
Contains the species present in a redox half equation.
Phase boundary where metal in contact with its ions, equilibrium is set up.
Ions of same element in different oxidation states. Inert metal electrode (Pt) used.
High melting/boiling point, shiny, conduct electricity/heat.
A reaction in which the time taken for an abrupt visible change to occur is measured. The abrupt change typically indicates the formation of the product.

A technique used to measure the amount of light absorbed by a solution, used to determine the rate of a reaction. Typically, a calibration curve is plotted and used to relate the absorbance recorded by the colorimeter to the concentration of the solution.
A graph in which concentration is plotted on the y axis and time on the x axis. The gradient of the line is equal to the rate of reaction.
During a rate experiment, continuous measurements are taken as the reaction progresses. The results can then be plotted on a concentration-time graph.
Doubling the concentration of a first order reactant will double the rate (if all other conditions remain the same).
Change in y \xc3\xb7 Change in x
The rate of a reaction at t = 0.
A number that relates the rate of a reaction to the concentrations of each reactant.
The sum of the orders with respect to each reactant.

A constant value that relates the rate of a reaction at a given temperature to the concentrations of the reactants. For a first order reaction, this can be determined using the relationship k = ln 2/t_1/2.
A graph that has concentration plotted on the x-axis and rate on the y-axis.
The slowest step of a reaction.
Relates rate to the concentrations of the reactants multiplied by the rate constant. Each concentration is raised to the power of the order with respect to that reactant.
A measure of how quickly a reactant is used up / a product is formed.
A step-by-step sequence of the individual reactions that make up the overall reaction.
Foubling the concentration of a first order reactant will quadruple the rate (if all other conditions remain the same).
Doubling the concentration of a first order reactant will have no impact on the rate (if all other conditions remain the same).
A substance which speeds up the rate of a reaction without being used up.
The amount of a substance that is dissolved per unit volume of solution.
A reaction that takes in energy from the surroundings. The energy of the products is higher than the reactants.
The forward and reverse reactions of a process occur at exactly the same rate meaning there is no overall change.

A value that relates the amount of products and reactants at equilibrium in a reversible reaction at a specific temperature. K is unaffected by pressure and presence of a catalyst but is affected by temperature.
A reaction that gives out energy into the surroundings. The energy of the reactants is higher than the products.
An equilibrium reaction that involves substances in different states (solid, liquid gaseous or aqueous).
An equilibrium reaction that involves substances all in the same state (solid, liquid gaseous or aqueous).

The equilibrium constant that is equal to the concentration of products raised to their stoichiometric coefficients divided by the concentration of reactants to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients. Liquids and solids are not included in heterogeneous Kc expressions as their concentrations effectively remain constant.

The equilibrium constant that is equal to the partial pressures of the products raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients divided by the partial pressures of the reactants raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients.
A proton donor.
A proton acceptor.

A system that minimises pH change on addition of small amounts of an acid or base. A buffer solution can be formed from a weak acid and a salt of the weak acid or from excess weak acid and a strong alkali.
The buffer system present in blood plasma, used to maintain blood pH between 7.35 and 7.45.
A pair of compounds that transform into each other by the transfer of a proton. Conjugate acid-base pairs are important in the formation of buffers to control pH.
An acid that can donate 2 hydrogen atoms per molecule of the acid.

The point during a titration when the indicator changes colour. A suitable indicator should change colour near the equivalence point (it should have a pH range within the vertical section of the titration curve).

The point during a titration when the amount of acid is exactly equal to the amount of base (full neutralisation occurs). When titrating an acid with a base, [H+] is equal to [OH\xe2\x88\x92] at this point.

A weak acid that changes colour with changing pH due to an equilibrium shift between HA and A-. For an indicator to be suitable, its pH range must be within the vertical section of the titration curve (there is no suitable indicator for weak acid weak base titration as the titration curve does not have a vertical section).
A chemical equation that involves dissociated ions.
The temperature dependent constant that represents the dissociation of water into H+ and OH-.
An acid that can donate 1 hydrogen atom per molecule of acid.
An instrument used to measure the pH of a solution.
A measure of the relative degree of dissociation of an acid or base (where strong means complete dissociation and weak means partial dissociation).
A technique used to determine the amount of one solution of a known concentration required to completely react with a known volume of another solution of unknown concentration.
A graph which shows the change in pH over the course of a titration.
An acid that can donate 3 hydrogen atoms per molecule of acid.

The vertical part of a titration curve which contains the equivalence point for the titration. During this section, there is a very large change in pH but a small change in the volume of acid or alkali added.
A cycle which can be used to calculate the lattice enthalpy of an ionic compound using other enthalpy changes.
The total energy of an isolated system remains constant (energy cannot be lost or created).
A value that represents the heat content of a system.
The change in the heat content of a system during a reaction.
The enthalpy change that takes place when one mole of gaseous atoms is formed from an element in its standard state.
The enthalpy change that takes place when one mole of a compound is formed from its elements.

The enthalpy change that takes place when one mole of gaseous ions are dissolved in water (exothermic). Increasing ionic charges and decreasing ionic radii make this value more negative as there would be greater attraction between the water molecules and the ions.
The enthalpy change that takes place when one mole of solute is dissolved.
The amount of energy released when one mole of electrons is added to one mole of gaseous atoms, forming one mole of 1- ions.
The removal of one mole of electrons from one mole of gaseous atoms to form one mole of 1+ ions.
Electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions.
A regular repeating structure made up of oppositely charged ions.

The formation of one mole of an ionic lattice from gaseous ions. Lattice enthalpy is used as a measure of the strength of ionic bonds in a giant lattice, with a more negative value meaning stronger bonds. Increasing ionic changes and decreasing ionic radii make this value more negative as there would be greater attraction between the ions.
A value that represents the heat content of a system.

A measure of the dispersal of energy in a system. The greater the entropy, the more disordered the system. The order of entropy for different states is solids < liquids < gases. Increasing the number of gaseous molecules in a reaction results in an increase in entropy.

The feasibility of a process depends on entropy change, temperature and enthalpy change. The equation for Gibbs free energy is: \xe2\x88\x86G = \xe2\x88\x86H - T\xe2\x88\x86S.A process is spontaneous/ feasible when \xe2\x88\x86G is negative. Gibbs free energy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t consider kinetics.
The part of chemistry relating to rates of reaction.

A measure of the potential difference between two half cells, calculated by combining 2 standard electrode potentials. The calculated cell potential can be used to predict feasibility of a reaction, although this doesn\xe2\x80\x99t consider concentration or kinetics.

Contains electrodes in an electrolyte and is used to generate current. A cell could be made up of either a metal or non metal in contact with a solution of its ions or a solution of ions of the same element in different oxidation states with a Pt electrode. If the cell is a standard cell, ions of the same element should have concentrations of 1 mol dm^-3 or they should be equimolar.
Electromotive force, measured in volts.
A solution of ions in which there is an equal number of moles of each ion.
A type of cell that requires a constant supply of fuel and oxygen in order to generate a potential difference.
An equation which shows the number of electrons that are transferred during a reaction.
The loss of electrons/ increase in oxidation number.
A number that represents the number of electrons lost or gained by an atom of an element. A positive oxidation number indicates the loss of electrons.
A substance that can oxidise another substance.
A reaction in which oxidation of one element and reduction of another occurs.

A type of titration which involves the reduction of one substance and the oxidation of another. The exact volume of titrant required to react with the analyte is determined using an indicator which shows the end point of the reaction.
A substance that can reduce another substance.
The gain of electrons/ decrease in oxidation number.
The e.m.f. of a half cell compared with a standard hydrogen half cell. This is measured under standard conditions (1 mol dm^-3 solution concentrations, 298K and 1 atm).
A type of cell that can store energy. Storage cells convert chemical energy into electrical energy by a reaction and they may be recharged by reversing the chemical reaction.
A negatively charged ion.
A positively charged ion.
The cis-isomer of Pt(NH3)2Cl2, used as an anticancer drug. Cis-platin binds to DNA, preventing cell replication.

A type of stereoisomerism that can occur within transition metal complexes. Substituents are either on the same side/ next to each other (cis) or on opposite sides (trans). Cis-trans isomerism occurs in Pt(NH3)2Cl2.
An ion which has a central metal atom (typically a transition element) surrounded by ligands. The ligands are bound to the transition metal centre by dative coordinate bonds.
The number of dative covalent bonds formed between ligands and a metal ion centre.
A type of covalent bond in which one bonding atom provides both electrons in the bonding pair.
The part of the periodic table containing elements in which the highest energy electron is in a d orbital.
A reaction in which the same element is both oxidised and reduced.
The arrangement of electrons into orbitals and energy levels around the nucleus of an atom/ion.
A protein which is important for oxygen transport in blood. The iron ion in haemoglobin undergoes a ligand substitution reaction involving CO2 and O2.
A reaction in which one ligand in a transition metal complex is replaced by another. Typically, these reactions are associated with a colour change.
A number that represents the number of electrons lost or gained by an atom of an element. A positive oxidation number indicates the loss of electrons.
A reaction in which 2 aqueous solutions are combined to form a solid (a precipitate).
Techniques that are used to identify whether or not an element, functional group or ion is present in a sample.
One of the possible shapes of a transition metal complex with a coordination number of 4.E.g, Pt(NH3)2Cl2.
A type of isomerism in which compounds have the same structural formula but a different arrangement of atoms in space.
One of the possible shapes of a transition metal complex with a coordination number of 4.
d-block elements that can form an ion with an incomplete d subshell. Transition elements have more than one oxidation state, form coloured ions and can act as catalysts.
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance

cards.term: What are the basic principles of NMR?
cards.definition: You can find the structures of complex molecules by placing them in a magnetic field and applying EM waves of radio frequency to them. If radio waves of the right frequency are absorbed, the nuclei flips from parallel to applied magnetic to field to anti-parallel. This energy change can be monitored and recorded. Uses the resonance of nuclei with spin.
MRI scans

cards.term: On a low resolution spectrum, what peaks would you expect to see for H NMR?
cards.definition: One peak for each set of inequivalent H atoms (each chemical environment shows 1 peak).
A stepped line that makes it easier to measure the area under the curve (height of line = area under that peak).

cards.term: What are other advantagesof using TMS?
cards.definition: Inert, non-toxic, easy to remove from the sample (as relatively volatile).
If there are n inequivalent 1 H atoms on the neighbouring carbon then the peak will split into (n+1) smaller peaks

cards.term: Why must solvents used for 1H NMR not contain any hydrogen atoms?
cards.definition: Signals from the solvent would swamp signals from the sample, as there is much more solvent than sample.
Deuterated solvents: CDCl3, D2O, C6D6CCl4 -tetrachloromethane

cards.term: Why does the peak from O-H bonds disappear if D 2 O is used as a solvent?
cards.definition: O-D bond is formed in preference to O-H due to labile protons that move/swap from one molecule to another.

cards.term: What are the basic principles of all kinds of chromatography?
cards.definition: A family of separation techniques that depend on the principle that a mixture is separated if it is dissolved in a solvent and this mobile phase is passed over a solid (the stationary phase).
Carries the soluble components of the mixture.

cards.term: What relationship between a sample and the mobile phase makes the sample move faster?
cards.definition: More soluble components / components with more affinity to the solvent move faster.

cards.term: What does the stationary phase do?
cards.definition: Holds back components of the mixture that are attracted to it.

cards.term: What relationship between a sample and the stationary phase that makes the sample move slower? What kind of bonding does this often involve?
cards.definition: More affinity for the stationary phase means that a component moves slower; often attracted by hydrogen bonding.

cards.term: How are substances separated by chromatography?
cards.definition: If suitable stationary/mobile phases are chosen, the balance between affinity for the mobile phase and affinity for the stationary phase is different for each component of the mixture. Thus, they move at different rates and are separated over time.

cards.term: Why will different substances show different Rf values?
cards.definition: They are bonded differently and have different polarities - more polar bonds mean longer retention time or smaller R f value, since hydrogen bonding/dipoles are attracted more strongly to the stationary phase.
Thin Layer Chromatography.

cards.term: What are the advantages of TLC over paper chromatography?
cards.definition: Runs fasterSmaller amounts of a mixture can be separatedTLC plates are more robust that paper

cards.term: How can you observe colourless spots?
cards.definition: Shine UV light on them. Or spray with a developing agent (e.g. ninhydrin turns amino acid spots from colourless to purple, so they can be seen) (heating needed with ninhydrin).

cards.term: How do you calculate the Rf value?
cards.definition: Measure the distance from the initial line (that the mixture was spotted onto) to the solvent front, and the distance from the initial line to the spot. Calculate R f using: Rf = distance moved by spot \xe2\x9e\x97 distance moved by solvent front.

cards.term: What does Rf value stand for?
cards.definition: Retention factor; a measure of the rate of movement of a component through the chromatography apparatus; a ratio between the rate of movement of the solvent and that component

cards.term: How could you confirm the identity of a substance from its Rf value?
cards.definition: Compare your Rf value to accepted values Rf for that substance run in the same solvent and set-up; if they match, then identity is confirmed.

cards.term: What is the stationary phase in gas-liquid chromatography?
cards.definition: Powder, coated with oil. Packed into a long, thin, capillary tube (100m long, 0.5mm diameter). Coiled and placed in an oven, the temperature of which can be varied.

cards.term: What is the mobile phase in gas-liquid chromatography?
cards.definition: Carrier gas, inert e.g. N2 or He.

cards.term: What do you measure in gas-liquid chromatography?
cards.definition: Retention time; different components of the mixture take different amounts of time to move through.

cards.term: What are the advantages of GLC?
cards.definition: Very sensitive; GC can detect minute traces of substances in foodstuffs, and link oil pollution on beaches to the specific tanker the oil came from.
Test athletes\xe2\x80\x99 and horses\xe2\x80\x99 blood and urine for drugs.

cards.term: How can you use GC or GCMS to identify substances?
cards.definition: Match Gas Chromatograph to that of a known substance under the same conditions; retention time should exactly match. Substance\xe2\x80\x99s identity can be confirmed by mass spectrometry, NMR or infrared spectroscopy.
Gas Chromatography is run, retention time is recorded, then mixture is run through a Mass Spectrometer. Fragmentation pattern/molecular ion peak confirms identity.

cards.term: How do you test for alkenes? What is the result?
cards.definition: Shake with bromine water, result is bromine water is decolourised (orange to colourless).

cards.term: How do you test for haloalkanes? What is the result?
cards.definition: Add NaOH (aq) and warm, acidify with HNO3, add AgNO3(aq)Result: precipitate of AgX (for Cl=white, for Br=cream, for I=yellow).

cards.term: How do you test for aldehydes? What is the result? (2 ways)
cards.definition: 1. Warm with Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s solution, result: brick red ppt forms (from blue solution)2. Warm with Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 reagent, result: \xe2\x80\x9csilver mirror\xe2\x80\x9d (Ag(s) ppt) forms

cards.term: How do you test for carboxylic acids? What is the result?
cards.definition: Add Na 2 CO3(aq), result: CO2 (g) given off -effervescence.

cards.term: How do you test for carbonyl compounds?
cards.definition: React with 2,4- DNP and an orange precipitate should form.

cards.term: When purifying by recrystallisation, why is the minimum volume of hot solvent used?
cards.definition: So that a saturated solution is created, so that as many crystals will fall out of solution as possible when it is cooled.

cards.term: Why is the solution filtered hot when purifying by recrystallisation?
cards.definition: To remove insoluble impurities and ensure that the crystals do not form in the filter paper.

cards.term: Why is the solution cooled in an ice bath when purifying by recrystallisation?
cards.definition: To ensure that as many crystals as possible fall out of solution - yield is higher.

cards.term: Why are the crystals washed with cold water when purifying by recrystallisation?
cards.definition: To remove soluble impurities.

cards.term: How would you separate the crystals from the reaction mixture when purifying by recrystallisation?
cards.definition: Filter under reduced pressure using a Buchner funne.

cards.term: Why might percentage yield be below 100% (practical reasons)?
cards.definition: Product is lost during filtration, drying and weighing - spills, not all transferred from one piece of apparatus to the other. Product is left dissolved in the solution - some does not crystallise. Some left on filter paper. Sample still wet.

cards.term: Describe how Quickfit apparatus is connected.
cards.definition: Grease the joints using some petroleum jelly on the inside of the joints before connecting the pieces together.

cards.term: In a distillation setup, why is it necessary to have a continuous water flow around the condenser?
cards.definition: So that the water remains cool in order for the mixture to be distilled.

cards.term: Describe a method that can be used to separate immiscible liquids.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Pour the mixture into a separating funnel and some distilled water\xe2\x97\x8f Add the stopper and invert the flask to mix the mixture\xe2\x97\x8f Equalise the pressure by opening the stopper as required\xe2\x97\x8f Continue shaking until there is no \xe2\x80\x98whistle\xe2\x80\x99 sound\xe2\x97\x8f To collect the water in the lower layer, open the stopper and place a beaker under the spout\xe2\x97\x8f Use another beaker to collect the desired organic layer\xe2\x97\x8f Shake the liquid with some drying agent
Magnesium sulphate and Calcium chloride.

cards.term: How is a drying agent used?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Add a selected drying agent to the organic product\xe2\x97\x8f If the drying agent forms clumps add some more until they are moving freely\xe2\x97\x8f Use gravity filtration to collect the dry product.\xe2\x97\x8f Filtrate is the product
When a liquid is purified by using multiple distillations.

cards.term: What are the three key steps to purify an organic solid?
cards.definition: 1. filtration under reduced pressure2. recrystallisation3. measurement of melting points

cards.term: What type of reaction is involved in the reaction between carbonyl compounds and cyanide ions?

cards.definition: Use a halogenoalkane and AlCl3 to create an electrophile that can attack benzene.

cards.term: What is condensation in terms of polymers?
cards.definition: Small molecule eliminated (usually H2O) to form a larger molecule.

cards.term: How many monomers are condensation polymers usually formed from?
cards.definition: Two (2)

cards.term: What properties do these monomers forming condensation polymers have?
cards.definition: Each has two functional groups.

cards.term: What molecule is eliminated in formation of a polyester?

cards.term: What are the two monomers used to form a polyamide (generic names and structures)?

In body armour (bullet proof vests, stab vests), helmets (e.g. F1 drivers\xe2\x80\x99), oven gloves.
Non-polar C-H and C-C bonds.

cards.term: Why is it bad to burn poly(alkenes)?
cards.definition: Releases CO2, CO, C (soot) and other toxicchemicals from monomers.

cards.term: Where do most poly(alkenes) end up?
cards.definition: Landfill Sites

cards.term: Why can condensation polymers be broken down?

cards.term: How are condensation polymers broken down?
cards.definition: Hydrolysis (opposite of condensation)

cards.term: What is the difference between addition and condensation polymerisation?
cards.definition: Condensation makes the polymer and eliminates a small molecule; addition polymerisation breaks C=C to form only one product (just the polymer).

cards.term: Why do polyesters not show hydrogen bonding?
cards.definition: All O-H bonds are removed during polymerisation.

cards.term: What are the two functional groups of amino acids?
cards.definition: NH2 and COOH (amine and carboxylic acid).
Yes, one carbon has 4 different substituents.Except glycine, where R = H.
Ions which have both a permanent positive and negative charge, but are neutral overall.

cards.term: What property must a carbon atom have for the molecule to display optical isomerism about that carbon atom?

cards.term: What are the similarities and differences between two optical isomers?
cards.definition: Same atoms and bonds, but they are non-superimposable mirror images of one another. NOT IDENTICAL in chemical properties necessarily.Differ in the way they rotate plane polarised light - rotate plane of polarisation by the same angle but in different directions.

cards.term: What word is used to describe optically active molecules?
cards.definition: Chiral
