cards.term: What shape are amines around the N? Bond angle?
cards.definition: What shape are amines around the N? Bond angle? Trigonal pyramidal, 107\xc2\xb0 due to lone pair on N.

cards.term: What kind of intermolecular forces do they have? Why?
cards.definition: Hydrogen bonding due to polar N-H bond and lone pair of electrons on N atom.

cards.term: Do amines have intermolecular forces which are stronger than or weaker than alcohols? Why?
cards.definition: Weaker, as N has a lower electronegativity than O \xe2\x86\x92 Weaker hydrogen bonding

cards.term: How can/when do amines act as bases?

cards.term: How can/when do amines act as nucleophiles?

cards.term: In order to be the strongest base, what must a particular amine have (out of a set of amines)?

cards.term: How can primary amines then form 2\xc2\xb0, 3\xc2\xb0 amines and 4\xc2\xb0 ammonium ions?

cards.term: Is benzene soluble in water? Explain why?

cards.term: Nitration of benzene is what type of reaction?

cards.term: What type of catalyst is used for a Friedel-Crafts reaction?

cards.term: Why does benzene not react directly with halogens?

cards.term: How could you use a Friedel-Crafts mechanism to add a methyl group to a benzene ring?
cards.definition: Use a halogenoalkane and AlCl3 to create an electrophile that can attack benzene.

cards.term: What is the relative ease of electrophilic substitution of phenol compared to benzene and why?
cards.definition: It is easier for electrophilic substitution to occur with phenol because oxygen lone pair of electrons from the -OH group are partially delocalised into ring therefore this increases the electron density of the ring thus electrophiles are more attracted phenol.

cards.term: What is the directing effect of electron donating groups OH and NH2?

cards.term: What is the directing effect of electron withdrawing group NO2?

Chromatography is an analytical technique used to separate and identify component molecules of a mixture. Separation of the mixture depends on distribution between a mobile phase and a stationary phase.

The mobile phase is a fluid that allows molecules to move over or through the stationary phase. It can be in the form of a liquid or a gas depending on the type of chromatography being carried out. Species that are more soluble in the mobile phase move further and/or faster within the mobile phase.

The stationary phase is a substance that has affinity to molecules in the mixture being analysed. The greater the affinity of a molecule to the stationary phase, the shorter the distance and/or the slower it moves within the mobile phase.

An Rf value is a retention factor that is unique to each different component molecule in the mixture being analysed. This is because different molecules within the mixture will have different affinities for the mobile and stationary phase and so will move at different rates within the mobile phase. It is calculated by comparing the distance moved by the component molecule to the distance moved by the mobile phase.

In TLC chromatography, a metal plate is coated with a thin layer of silica and the sample being analysed is dotted on the plate. These initial samples must be placed above the level of the solvent in the container.

In gas chromatography, a thin coiled tube is packed with a solid, powdered substance that acts as the stationary phase. Instead of a solvent, a high pressure gas is passed through this tube and acts as the mobile phase. This method is used to separate mixtures of volatile liquids which are fed into the gas chromatography machine as vapours. The analysis machine records a retention time for each component in the mixture, allowing them to be identified.

Carbon-12 is the most common isotope of carbon but is not detected by NMR spectroscopy. This is why carbon-13 is used, however, carbon-13 only has an abundance of roughly 1.1%, so a greater quantity of sample will be needed to obtain a well resolved spectra.
The process of hydrogen/deuterium exchange can be used to identify N-H and O-H peaks in an NMR spectra.
The analytical techniques covered throughout the course can be used together to predict the structure of unknown compounds.
This is an analytical technique used to identify different molecules and find the overall relative molecular mass.

High resolution mass spectrometry is a much more sensitive form of mass spectrometry which allows the Mr of a substance to be determined to several decimal places. Precise atomic masses can then be used to calculate the molecular formula of the compound being tested.
Infrared spectroscopy is an analytical technique that uses infrared (IR) radiation to determine the functional groups present in organic compounds.

Amines react with water to form an alkaline solution. The lone pair of electrons on the amine\xe2\x80\x99s nitrogen atom can accept a hydrogen from a water molecule, therefore acting as a base. This releases OH- ions into the solution.
Amines react with acids to form an ammonium salt. Again, the amine acts as a base and accepts a proton to form a quaternary ammonium salt.

Aliphatic amines can be produced from the nucleophilic substitution reaction between a halogenoalkane and ammonia in a sealed tube. One mole of halogenoalkane reacts with two moles of ammonia, producing a primary amine and an ammonium salt (ammonium ion bonded to a halide ion).
Aliphatic amines can also be produced by the reduction of nitriles by hydrogenation. This reduction requires a combination of hydrogen with a nickel catalyst (catalytic hydrogenation).
Aromatic amines can be produced from the reduction of nitrobenzene using concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl) and a tin catalyst. Aromatic amines consist of an amine group and a benzene ring.

Zwitterions are dipolar ions with a positive charge in one part of the molecule and a negative charge in another part of the molecule. The zwitterionic form of an amino acid is the state in which the amine group has a positive charge (+NH3) and the carboxyl group has a negative charge (COO-).Zwitterions form at the isoelectric point, which is the pH at which the overall charge of the molecule is zero.
Amines can also undergo nucleophilic addition-elimination reactions with acyl chlorides to produce amides and N substituted amides.
Secondary amides are also known as N-substituted amides. They have an additional carbon chain bonded to the nitrogen atom.
A chiral centre is a carbon atom with four different groups bonded around it, so that the molecule has no line of symmetry.

Optical isomerism is a type of stereoisomerism where molecules have the same molecular formula but a different spatial arrangement of atoms. The presence of a chiral centre leads to two possible isomers that are non-superimposable mirror images of each other. These are called optical isomers.
Condensation polymers form when a water molecule is removed from the species of a reaction. Polyesters and polyamides can be formed in this way.
Polyesters are formed when a dicarboxylic acid and a diol react together, producing an ester linkage, -COO-.
Terylene (PET) is a common polyester made from ethane-1,2 diol and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid.
Polyamides are condensation polymers generally formed in a reaction between a dicarboxylic acid and a diamine. A molecule of water is removed, producing an amide linkage.
Kevlar is another common polyamide made from benzene-1,4 dicarboxylic acid and 1,4-diaminobenzene.

The ester groups in polyesters and the amide groups in polyamides can be broken down by acid or base hydrolysis. The ester and amide linkages are polar, so they can be broken in the presence of water.Ester hydrolysis is the reverse reaction to esterification, converting esters back into alcohols and carboxylic acids. This process is done by adding water, but can be carried out under different conditions to produce different products. For polymers, the ester linkage is broken and the polyester is converted back into the diol and dicarboxylic acid.

The carbon chain in organic molecules can be extended by C C bond formation. This is useful in synthesis to form new molecules. Nitriles can be used to add in the extra carbon, and then other reactions can be carried out to change the nitrile group into another functional group.

The nitriles formed above can be used as a precursor to other products. Amines can be produced by the reduction of nitriles.This reduction reaction is called hydrogenation. The reaction requires a combination of hydrogen with a nickel catalyst (catalytic hydrogenation).

A C-C bond can be introduced into an aromatic compound using Friedel-Crafts Alkylation or Friedel-Crafts Acylation. Both reactions occur in the presence of a halogen carrier to make the strong electrophile and allow electrophilic substitution to occur.

Friedel-Crafts acylation substitutes an acyl group for a hydrogen atom on the benzene ring. The electrophilic reactive intermediate is produced from a reaction between the acyl chloride and an aluminium chloride catalyst.

Friedel-Crafts alkylation substitutes an alkyl group for a hydrogen atom on the benzene ring. The electrophilic reactive intermediate is produced from a reaction between a haloalkane and an aluminium chloride catalyst.

Synthesis pathways are used to make organic compounds. They involve a variety of preparatory and purification techniques that have been introduced throughout this course. These include:\xe2\x97\x8f Reflux\xe2\x97\x8f Distillation\xe2\x97\x8f Melting point determination\xe2\x97\x8f Boiling point determination\xe2\x97\x8f Washing and drying\xe2\x97\x8f Recrystallisation\xe2\x97\x8f Solvent extraction
The first step of synthesis is to prepare your organic compound. Common techniques for preparation are reflux and distillation.

Reflux apparatus is used to continually heat the contents of the flask to allow reactions like the oxidation of primary alcohols to proceed all the way to the formation of carboxylic acids. The condenser helps ensure the vapours condense and return to the flask for further heating. This ensures the product vapours can not escape.

Distillation apparatus is used to separate liquids with different boiling points. The round-bottomed flask is heated and the liquid with the lower boiling point will evaporate first. It rises out of the flask and into the attached tubing which is surrounded by a condenser. The condenser causes the vapour to cool and condense back into a liquid, which is then collected in a separate flask.
Recrystallisation is a purification technique that uses the differing solubilities of solid and impurities in different solvents.

Determining the melting point of a compound and comparing it to a databook value is a way of testing its purity. The purer a substance, the closer to the databook melting point value it will be. If a sample has a low purity, the melting point will take place over a range of temperatures.

Synthesis pathways are needed to convert starting materials into a target product. This can sometimes be achieved through single-step reactions, but other times multistep pathways are required. The functional groups in a desired product can be identified and then different transformations between functional groups can be used to get to the desired product.
Arenes are aromatic compounds that contain a benzene ring as part of their structure.
Benzene is an arene consisting of a ring of six carbon atoms each bonded to one hydrogen atom, giving it the molecular formula C6H6.

X-ray diffraction experiments have shown that all the bond lengths between carbon atoms in benzene are the same. If the cyclohexatriene structure was correct, three of the bond lengths would be the length of a single carbon bond and three would be the length of a double carbon bond. In reality, each bond in the benzene ring has an intermediate length in between that of a double and single bond.

Benzene is resistant to electrophilic addition reactions, such as bromination, which other compounds with carbon-carbon double bonds, such as alkenes, readily undergo. Benzene does not undergo electrophilic addition since this would involve breaking up the stable delocalised ring of electrons. Benzene instead undergoes electrophilic substitution reactions.
Halogenation is a type of electrophilic substitution reaction in which benzene reacts with halogens in the presence of a catalyst, such as iron(III) bromide (FeBr3).

Nitration is a form of electrophilic substitution, where the electrophile is an NO2 + ion. This is a reactive intermediate, produced in the reaction of concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4) with concentrated nitric acid (HNO3). Sulfuric acid behaves as a catalyst since it is not used up in the reaction.
The delocalised electron ring in benzene can also act as a nucleophile, leading to their nucleophilic attack on acyl chlorides. This reaction is known as Friedel-Crafts acylation.

The test for unsaturation would be expected to work for benzene like it does for alkenes, however, benzene is resistant to bromination. This is due to the delocalised electron density of the \xcf\x80-system in benzene compared with the localised electron density of the \xcf\x80-bond in alkenes. The delocalised model makes benzene relatively stable and hence not reactive enough to decolourise bromine water.

Phenols are organic compounds containing a benzene ring with an OH alcohol group. This makes them aromatic alcohols. Phenols are weak acids. They can be neutralised in a reaction with NaOH but will not react with carbonates.

Phenol, an aromatic compound with the formula C6H5OH, is produced in electrophilic substitution reactions with benzene. Phenol can react with bromine water via multiple substitutions to produce 2,4,6-tribromophenol which forms as a white precipitate with a distinct smell of antiseptic. This reaction decolourises bromine water.

Electron donating groups such as OH and NH\xe2\x82\x82 direct electrophiles to substitute at the 2- and 4- positions. Electron-withdrawing groups such as NO\xe2\x82\x82 are 3-directing in electrophilic substitution of aromatic compounds. These effects occur to favour the most stable charged intermediate.
Directing effects can be used to predict substitution products. This is very important in organic synthesis as it allows you to control the structure of the products.
Carbonyl compounds are organic compounds containing a carbonyl group, C=O. This gives them the functional group -CO. The most common carbonyl compounds are aldehydes and ketones.

Aldehydes are produced from the initial oxidation and distillation of primary alcohols. Aldehydes have a carbonyl group on a carbon atom at the end of the carbon chain (only attached to one other carbon atom).

Ketones are recognised by the functional group -C=O, a carbonyl group. They are produced from the oxidation of secondary alcohols with acidified potassium dichromate(VI). Ketones have a carbonyl group on a carbon atom that is attached to two other carbon atoms.
Primary and secondary alcohols can be oxidised to produce various products, but tertiary alcohols are not easily oxidised.

Potassium dichromate(VI) is used as an oxidising agent in the oxidation of alcohols. As the alcohol is oxidised, potassium dichromate(VI) is reduced. This reduction is observed as a colour change from orange to green, which indicates the alcohol has undergone oxidation. The colour change occurs due to the change in oxidation state of the chromium ion.
All of the oxidation reactions involved in the production of carbonyl compounds from alcohols can be reversed via reduction reactions.

NaCN (sodium cyanide) is often used as the reagent along with a H\xe2\x81\xba source to provide the HCN (hydrogen cyanide). This is because HCN is hard to store and is a toxic gas which reacts to produce dangerous byproducts.

Hydroxynitriles commonly contain a chiral carbon centre meaning optical isomers of the product are produced. The :CN- nucleophile can attack from either above or below the planar double bond, causing different enantiomers to be produced.

Carboxylic acids are organic compounds identified by the functional group -COOH, which contains a carbonyl group (C=O) and an -OH acid group. When naming carboxylic acids, the suffix -anoic acid is used. For example, a carboxylic acid containing a chain of four carbon atoms would be called butanoic acid.
Carboxylic acids are weak acids and therefore react with bases in a neutralisation reaction to produce a salt.

Esters have the functional group -COO-. They are named after the alcohol and carboxylic acid from which they are formed. For example, the ester formed from methanol and propanoic acid is methyl propanoate and the ester formed from butanol and ethanoic acid is butyl ethanoate.

Carboxylic acids can react with alcohols in the presence of a strong acid catalyst to form esters. Concentrated sulfuric acid is often used as the acid catalyst. This reaction is called esterification and is carried out under reflux.

Ester hydrolysis is the reverse reaction to esterification, converting esters back into alcohols and carboxylic acids. This process is done by adding water, but can be carried out under different conditions to produce different products.
Acyl chlorides have the functional group -COCl and have the suffix -oyl chloride, with the stem of their name representing the longest chain of carbon atoms.
Carboxylic acids have derivative molecules where the -OH group is replaced by another group. Acyl Chlorides are one such derivative that reacts violently due to the very polar  COCl group.
Acyl chlorides react via nucleophilic addition-elimination reactions. In these reactions, the addition of a nucleophile leads to the elimination of a product under aqueous conditions.
The breaking of a covalent bond when one of the bonded atoms takes both of the electrons.
The breaking of a covalent bond when each of the bonded atoms takes one electron.
Two reactants join together to form one product.
Two reactants where one atom or group of atoms replaces another set of atoms.
A reaction which involves the removal or a small molecule from a larger one.
An atom or compound that are electron pair acceptors.
An atom or compound that are electron pair donors.
A compound containing at least one benzene ring.

The p-orbitals of the 6 carbon atoms overlap to form a delocalised \xcf\x80 system. This model is supported by experimental evidence: all the C-C bond lengths in benzene are the same, the enthalpy change of hydrogenation is less exothermic than would be expected for cyclohex-1,3,5-triene and the benzene does not undergo addition reactions.

A representation of the probability of finding an electron at a specific point around an atom/ molecule. Benzene has a lower electron density than an alkene. In benzene, the electron density is delocalised into the \xcf\x80 system across 6 carbon atoms while in an alkene, the pair of electrons is localised between 2 carbon atoms in a \xcf\x80 bond.

Groups which donate electrons into the aromatic ring when they are attached to a carbon in the ring. OH, an electron donating group, is 2- and 4-directing, meaning that substituents will be substituted at positions 2 and 4 during an electrophilic substitution reaction.

Groups which pull electron density away from the delocalised \xcf\x80 system of benzene. NO2, an electron withdrawing group, is 3-directing meaning that substituents will be substituted at carbon 3 during an electrophilic substitution reaction.
A reaction in which an electrophile (an electron pair acceptor) reacts with another compound to replace an atom / group of atoms.
An organic compound containing a halogen atom (F/Cl/Br/I) bound to an alkyl chain.

A Lewis acid that can bind to a halogen molecule, weakening the halogen bond and allowing the halogen to function as an electrophile and attack electrons in an aromatic ring. Examples of halogen carriers include iron, iron halides and aluminium halides.
A model of benzene which contains alternating C=C double and C-C single bonds in a hexagonal ring, with each carbon atom bound to one hydrogen atom.

A weak acid that reacts with NaOH but not carbonates. Phenol has an aromatic ring with an OH group attached. Phenol can undergo electrophilic substitution reactions more easily than benzene as the lone pair in the p-orbital of oxygen is donated into the \xcf\x80 system of phenol, increasing its electron density. As a result of this electron donation, phenol is more susceptible to electrophilic attack than benzene.

Also known as Brady\xe2\x80\x99s reagent, this compound forms an orange precipitate in the presence of aldehydes and ketones. The melting point of the 2,4-DNP derivative of a carbonyl can be used to identify the carbonyl compound.
The C=O group. Aldehydes and ketones are carbonyl compounds.
An electron pair donor.

A reaction in which an electrophilic \xcf\x80 bond reacts with a nucleophile, breaking the \xcf\x80 bond and forming 2 new \xcf\x83 bonds. Examples include carbonyl compounds reacting with NaBH4 to form alcohols or with HCN to form hydroxynitriles.
The loss of electrons/ increase in oxidation number.

Also known as ammoniacal silver nitrate, this reagent forms a silver mirror in the presence of an aldehyde and can be used to distinguish between aldehydes and ketones. An aldehyde is oxidised to a carboxylic acid while silver ions in Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 are reduced to silver.
A compound containing the functional group shown below. Acyl chlorides can be made from carboxylic acids and SOCl2 and they are used to form esters, carboxylic acids and primary and secondary amides.
A proton donor.
A proton acceptor.
An organic compound containing the -COOH functional group. Carboxylic acids react with metals as well as bases such as carbonates, metal oxides and alkalis.
A compound containing the R-COO-R\xe2\x80\x99 functional group (where R and R\xe2\x80\x99 are alkyl groups).
The process of making esters. Esters can be made by a reaction between carboxylic acids and alcohols in the presence of an acid catalyst or by a reaction between acid anhydrides and alcohols.

A reaction in which water is used to break down a compound. Esters can either be hydrolysed with hot aqueous acid (forming carboxylic acids and alcohols) or with hot aqueous alkali (forming carboxylate salts and alcohols).
A compound that can dissolve in water. Carboxylic acids are water soluble as they can form hydrogen bonds with the H2O molecules.
An amine which only contains straight or branched alkyl chains. Aliphatic amines can be formed via a substitution reaction of haloalkanes with either ammonia or amines in ethanol solvent.

Compounds that contain the NR3 functional group (where R could be hydrogen atoms or alkyl chains). Amines are basic as the nitrogen lone pair allows the acceptance of a proton. In a reaction between amines and dilute acids, salts are formed.
An amine which contains a benzene ring directly attached to the nitrogen atom. Aromatic amines can be formed by reducing nitroarenes with tin and concentrated HCl.

A compound with the general formula RCH(NH2)COOH, where an amino group and a carboxylic acid group are bonded to the same carbon atom. The carboxylic acid group of an amino acid reacts with alkalis or can be used to form esters. The amine group of an amino acid reacts with acids.
The -NH2 group in an organic compound.
The -COOH group in an organic compound.
A carbon atom which is bonded to 4 different groups.
A type of stereoisomerism in which compounds are non superimposable mirror images of one another (caused by the presence of a chiral centre).
An organic compound which contains the functional group RNH2 (where R is an alkyl chain).
An organic compound which contains the functional group R2NH (where R is an alkyl chain).
Compounds with the same structural formula but a different arrangement of atoms in space.
The formation of a long chain molecule when many monomers join together (the polymer is the only product).

Amides can either be hydrolysed under acidic conditions (forming carboxylic acids and ammonium salts) or under alkaline conditions (forming carboxylate salts and either ammonia or an amine). Polyamides can be hydrolysed in a similar way.

A long chain molecule formed when monomers react together with the release of small molecules such as water. Types of condensation polymers are polyamides (formed from carboxylic acids / acyl chlorides and amines) and polyesters (formed from carboxylic acids/ acyl chlorides and alcohols).

Esters can either be hydrolysed with hot aqueous acid (forming carboxylic acids and alcohols) or with hot aqueous alkali (forming carboxylate salts and alcohols). Polyesters can be hydrolysed in a similar way.
A small molecule that is used to form polymers.
A large molecule made from many small units that have been bonded together.
The process of making a polymer from its monomers. There are two types: addition polymerisation and condensation polymerisation.
A structure within a polymer that appears over and over again. Joining many repeat units together would form the polymer.
A reaction that is used to form substituted aromatic compounds, using an acyl chloride to form a C-C bond in the presence of a halogen carrier.
The breakdown of a compound using aqueous acid. Nitriles can be hydrolysed to form carboxylic acids.
A reaction which is used to form substituted aromatic compounds, using a haloalkane to form a C-C bond in the presence of a halogen carrier.
A compound which contains the C=O functional group.
Reactions which were developed to attach substituents to anaromatic ring. Acylation and alkylation are the 2 main types of Friedel-Craft reactions.
An organic compound which contains a -C\xe2\x89\xa1N group bound to an alkyl chain.

A reaction in which an electron pair donor attacks an electrophilic atom (an atom with a partial or full positive charge) to replace an atom/ group of atoms. One example is the reaction of haloalkanes with CN- and ethanol to form nitriles.
Gain of electrons/ decrease in oxidation number. Nitriles can be reduced to amines with H2/Ni.
A technique in which a liquid is heated then the vapour is cooled and collected in a separate flask to the reaction mixture. During distillation, the condenser must be positioned horizontally.

A technique used to separate and dry an organic solid.A B\xc3\xbcchner funnel is inserted into the top of a side-arm flask and a vacuum is applied. The solution is poured onto filter paper in the B\xc3\xbcchner funnel so that the solid product can be separated.
A group of atoms responsible for the characteristic reactions of a compound.
A piece of apparatus used to determine the melting point of a sample. The recorded melting point range is compared with known values to determine whether the sample is pure.
Alassware that easily fits together in a variety of arrangements.

A technique used to purify an organic solid. The sample is dissolved in the minimum volume of hot solvent and filtered. The filtrate is then cooled before being filtered under reduced pressure. The purified solid will collect on the filter paper in the B\xc3\xbcchner funnel.
The continual boiling and condensing of a reaction mixture. This is to ensure that the reaction goes to completion. During reflux, the condenser must be positioned vertically.
A series of steps that are followed to make a specific compound.

An organic compound containing the C=O functional group at the end of an alkyl chain. Aldehydes form a silver mirror when reacted with Tollens\xe2\x80\x99 reagent. Aldehydes can be oxidised to carboxylic acids with acidified potassium dichromate, causing a colour change from orange to green.
An organic compound containing the C=C functional group. Alkenes decolourise bromine water.

A technique used to separate and identify components in a mixture.There are several different types of chromatography, including: thin layer chromatography, and gas chromatography. Separation during chromatography depends on the balance between solubility in the mobile phase and retention by the stationary phase.

A type of chromatography in which a column is packed with a solid (or a solid coated in a liquid) and a gas is passed through the column under pressure at high temperature. Mass spectrometry may be used to analyse components separated by GC.
A substance that moves through the chromatography system to separate the mixture. This may be a gas (GC) or a liquid (TLC).
An organic compound with the general formula RCH2OH. Primary alcohols can be oxidised with acidified dichromate, causing a colour change from orange to green.
Techniques that are used to identify whether or not an element,functional group or ion is present in a sample.
The time taken for a sample to travel from the inlet to the detector in GC. The recorded retention time can be compared with standards to identify the substances in the mixture.
An organic compound with the general formula R2CHOH. Secondary alcohols can be oxidised with acidified dichromate, causing a colour change from orange to green.
A substance through which the mobile phase moves in chromatography. This is typically a solid although a solid coated in a liquid may be used in GC.
A type of chromatography in which a plate is coated with a solid and a solvent moves up the plate.
A type of NMR spectroscopy which analyses 13C nuclei.The number of peaks in the spectrum shows the number of different environments and the chemical shifts show what environments are present.
The shift of a carbon or proton environment relative to standard (TMS). The chemical shift value (\xce\xb4) depends on the molecular environment of the proton/ carbon atom.
Interaction between adjacent non-equivalent protons during NMR spectroscopy.

As O-H and N-H peaks can appear across a wide range of chemical shift values on a proton NMR spectrum, D2O exchange can be used to identify which peaks are caused by O-H and N-H protons. Firstly, a proton NMR is run on a sample. The sample is then shaken with D2O and a second proton NMR is run. Any peaks that are due to O-H or N-H protons will disappear on the second spectrum as these protons will be exchanged for deuterium.
A sample is analysed to determine the proportion of elements that make up the compound present. This is done by converting a known amount of an unknown sample into simple known compounds.

In NMR spectroscopy, a proton or carbon environment considers the atoms/ groups that are adjacent to that hydrogen/ carbon atom. If 2 protons / carbons are surrounded by different groups of atoms, they are in different environments.
Protons that are in the same environment.
A technique used to identify particular bonds and functional groups within a molecule. Infrared radiation is absorbed by covalent bonds in molecules, causing them to vibrate at a specific frequency.
A technique used to identify compounds and determine relative molecular mass by measuring their mass to charge ratio.
An interaction between adjacent non-equivalent protons. When protons couple (interact with one another), the signal on the 1H NMR spectrum is split into a multiple according to the n+1 rule.
The standard for chemical shift measurement in NMR spectroscopy.

cards.term: What provides the energy of the X-rays in an X-ray tube?
cards.definition: The kinetic energy of the accelerated electrons.
A photon produced by the deceleration of a fast moving electron

cards.term: What is the typical p.d. of an X-ray tube for medical imaging?
What causes the emission of electrons from the cathode in an X-ray tube?
cards.definition: It is heated to produce thermionic emission.

cards.term: What name is given to the anode in an X-ray tube?
cards.definition: The target metal.

cards.term: What is an essential property for the target metal in an X-ray tube?
cards.definition: High melting point.

cards.term: What causes the production of X-rays in an X-ray tube?
cards.definition: The deceleration of electrons when they hit the target metal/anode.

cards.term: In an X-ray tube what happens to most of the kinetic energy lost by the electrons when they hit the anode?
cards.definition: It is transferred to thermal energy of the anode.

cards.term: What measures can be taken to prevent an anode melting in an X-ray tube?
cards.definition: It is cooled by oil or rotated

cards.term: What feature of X-ray tubes protects the radiographer?
cards.definition: Lead lining.

cards.term: What determines the maximum frequency of X-rays produced in an X-ray tube?
cards.definition: The maximum kinetic energy of a single electron.

cards.term: When is the equation \xce\xbb = hc/eV used?
cards.definition: To find the minimum wavelengths of X-ray produced (by an X-ray tube)

cards.term: What is V in the equation \xce\xbb = hc/eV?
cards.definition: The accelerating potential difference.

cards.term: Describe the beam used by CAT scanners.
cards.definition: A thin (1-10mm) fan.

cards.term: What happens to the position of the X-ray tube during a CAT scan?
cards.definition: It rotates around the patient.

cards.term: What are the key advantages of CAT scans over conventional X-rays?
cards.definition: They produce a 3D image and can distinguish between tissues with similar attenuation coefficients.

cards.term: What are the disadvantages of CAT scans compared to conventional X-rays?
cards.definition: The radiation dose is greater and they are more expensive and take more time.

cards.term: How does a CAT scan produce a 3D image?
cards.definition: A series of slices are imaged and processed via a computer.
The decrease in intensity as X-rays pass through matter.

cards.term: What are the four mechanisms of X-ray attenuation?
cards.definition: Simple scatter, Photoelectric Effect, Compton Scattering, Pair Production

cards.term: What occurs during simple scatter of X-rays?
cards.definition: The X-ray interacts with an electron in an atom and changes direction but not energy.

cards.term: Which method of attenuation is most significant with X-rays with energy in the range 1-20keV?
cards.definition: Simple scatter

cards.term: What occurs during the photoelectric effect attenuation of X-rays?
cards.definition: The X-ray is absorbed by an electron in an atom which gains the energy of the photon and leaves the atom.

cards.term: Which method of attenuation is significant with X-rays with energies up to 100keV?
cards.definition: Photoelectric effect

cards.term: Which method of attenuation is most significant to medical X-ray imaging?
cards.definition: The photoelectric effect.

cards.term: What occurs during Compton scattering attenuation of X-rays?
cards.definition: The X-ray interacts with an electron in the atom causing the electron to be ejected and the photon to be scattered with reduced energy.

cards.term: Which method of attenuation is significant with X-rays with energy in the range 0.5-5MeV?
cards.definition: Compton scattering.

cards.term: What occurs during pair production with X-rays?
cards.definition: An X-ray interacts with the nucleus of an atom converting the energy of the photon to and electron and a positron.

cards.term: Which method of attenuation occurs with X-rays with energies 1.02MeV?
cards.definition: Pair production

cards.term: What is I in the equation I = I\xe2\x82\x80e^(-\xc2\xb5x)?
cards.definition: Transmitted intensity

cards.term: What is I\xe2\x82\x80 in the equation I = I\xe2\x82\x80e^(-\xc2\xb5x)?
cards.definition: Intensity before absorption

cards.term: What is \xc2\xb5 in the equation I = I\xe2\x82\x80e^(-\xc2\xb5x)?
cards.definition: Attenuation/absorption coefficient.

cards.term: What is x in the equation I = I\xe2\x82\x80e^(-\xc2\xb5x)?
cards.definition: Thickness of the absorbing substance

cards.term: What are the SI units of attenuation coefficient?
cards.definition: m\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is a contrast medium in X-rays?
cards.definition: A material with a high attenuation coefficient used to image soft tissue.

cards.term: What contrast medium is typically to examine blood flow?
cards.definition: Iodine

cards.term: What contrast medium is typically used to image the digestive system?
cards.definition: Barium sulfate

cards.term: How are X-rays used for cancer therapy?
cards.definition: A linear accelerator produces high energy X-rays that destroy cells.

cards.term: Why are high energy X-rays prefereable to gamma radiation for cancer therapy?
cards.definition: An X-ray source can be turned off.

cards.term: Which radionuclide is used for imaging with a gamma camera?
cards.definition: Technitium-99m

cards.term: Which radionuclide is used in PET scanning?
cards.definition: Fluorine-18

cards.term: Why are gamma emitting sources useful for imaging inside the body?
cards.definition: They are the least ionising and can penetrate through a patient to be detected externally.

cards.term: Why are short half-lives necessary for the radioisotopes used for medical imaging?
cards.definition: To ensure a large activity from a small amount and to minimise radiation dose after the procedure.
A compound containing a radioisotope that is put into the patients body.

cards.term: What is the function of a collimator in a gamma camera?
cards.definition: To absorb any photons not travelling along the axis of the tubes so the source location of gamma radiation can be idenitifed.

cards.term: How is a collimator in a gamma camera constructed?
cards.definition: It is a honeycomb of long, thin lead tubes.

cards.term: What is the function of a scintillator in a gamma camera?
cards.definition: It produces many photons of visible light when a gamma photon interacts with it.

cards.term: What is the function of the photomultiplier tubes in a gamma camera?
cards.definition: They convert visible light photons to an electrical pulse.

cards.term: What is the function of the computer in a gamma camera?
cards.definition: It processes the signals from the photomultipliers to locate where the gamma ray originated to produce an image showing the concentrations of medical tracer.

cards.term: What type of radiation is detected in a PET scan?
cards.definition: Gamma

cards.term: What type of radiation is emitted by Fluorine-18 nucleus in a PET scan?
cards.definition: Beta plus/positron

cards.term: What process produces gamma photons in a PET scan?
cards.definition: Electron and positron annihilation.

cards.term: How is the the source of the gamma photons located in a PET scan?
cards.definition: By the time delay between the arrival of diametrically opposite gamma photons.

cards.term: What is the typical time delay between the arrival of gamma photons in PET scan?
cards.definition: Nanoseconds

cards.term: Why is medical imaging using gamma emitting tracers useful?
cards.definition: It can measure the function of organs in the body rather than just the structure.

cards.term: What are the disadvantages of a PET scan?
cards.definition: They are expensive and require facilities to prepare tracers local to the scanner.

cards.term: What is the range of human hearing?
cards.definition: 20Hz-20kHz
A device for emitting and detecting ultrasound.

cards.term: What is the minimum frequency of ultrasound?
cards.definition: 20 kHz
When a crystal produces an EMF when it is distorted.

cards.term: What happens to a piezoelectric crystal when. p.d. is applied across opposite faces?
cards.definition: It is compressed or stretched.

cards.term: What are the main advantages of ultrasound imaging?
cards.definition: It is non-invasive and does not require ionising radiation.

cards.term: What range of frequencies are typically used for ultrasound scans?
cards.definition: 1-15MHz

cards.term: How is an ultrasound pulse generated by a transducer?
cards.definition: A high frequency p.d. is applied at the natural frequency of the piezoelectric crystal causing the crystal to resonate.

cards.term: How is an ultrasound pulse detected by a transducer?
cards.definition: Sound incident on the crystal causes it to vibrate generating an EMF across its faces.

cards.term: What is the purpose of the damping material in an ultrasound scanner?
cards.definition: It prevents reflection of the pulse from behind the piezoelectric crystal.
A single transducer produce pulses that travel along a single path through the patient?

cards.term: How does an ultrasound A-scan calculate the distance to boundaries between tissues?
cards.definition: 2 x Distance = v x t, where v is the speed of the ultrasound and t is the time interval between the emitted and reflected pulse.

cards.term: What is an ultrasound B scan?
cards.definition: The signal from an array of transducers is processed by computer to build up a 2D image.

cards.term: What determines the brightness of the dots on a B scan display?
cards.definition: The amplitude of the reflected ultrasound from that point.

cards.term: What determines the acoustic impedence of a substance?
cards.definition: The density and the speed of sound in the substance.

cards.term: What are the units of acoustic impedance?
cards.definition: kgm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2s\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is the intensity reflection coefficient for ultrasound?
cards.definition: The ratio (reflected intensity of ultrasound \xc3\xb7 incident intensity of ultrasound)

cards.term: What factor determines the refelction intensity coefficient for ultrasound at a boundary?
cards.definition: The difference between the acoustic impedances of the two substances.

cards.term: Why does a coupling gel need to be used when performing an ultrasound?
cards.definition: Air pockets between the transducer and skin cause reflection of nearly all of the ultrasound at the skin-air boundary.

cards.term: What is an ultrasound coupling gel?
cards.definition: A substance applied to the skin and transducer with an impedance similar to skin.
When two substances havce similar acoustic impedances so negligible reflection of ultrasound occurs.

cards.term: What causes ulatrasound to undergo doppler shift?
cards.definition: Reflection from moving blood cells.

cards.term: What is doppler ultrasound used for?
cards.definition: Measuring the speed (and volume) of blood flow.

cards.term: What is measured in doppler ultrasound to determine the velocity of the blood?
cards.definition: The observed change in frequency of the reflected ultrasound pulse.

cards.term: How is blood flow viewed during a doppler ultrasound?
cards.definition: The signal is processed by computer and displayed as a colour coded image on a screen.

cards.term: Why does the transducer have to placed away from the normal during a doppler ultrasound?
cards.definition: To ensure there is a component of the blood flow\'s velocity in the direction of the ultrasound pulse.
Change in the observed frequency of the reflected ultrasound.

cards.term: What is v in the equation? \xe2\x88\x86f = (2fvcos\xce\xb8)/c
cards.definition: Blood flow speed.
The angle between the tranducer axis and the blood flow.

cards.term: What is c in the equation? \xe2\x88\x86f = (2fvcos\xce\xb8)/c
cards.definition: The speed of ultrasound in blood.

cards.term: What is the value of the prefix T (tera)
cards.definition: 10\xc2\xb9\xc2\xb2

cards.term: What is the value of the prefix G (giga)
What is the value of the prefix M (mega)
What is the value of the prefix k (kilo)
cards.definition: 10\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is the value of the prefix d (deci)
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is the value of the prefix c (centi)
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2

cards.term: What is the value of the prefix m (milli)
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is the value of the prefix \xce\xbc (micro)
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb6

cards.term: What is the value of the prefix n (nano)
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb9

cards.term: What is the value of the prefix p (pico)
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xc2\xb2

cards.term: What six base units of the SI system are used in A Level Physics?
cards.definition: metre, kilogram, second, Ampere, Kelvin, Mole

cards.term: What six base quantities of the SI system are used in A Level Physics?
cards.definition: length, mass, time, electric current, absolute temperature, amount of substance.

cards.term: What is the base unit of mass?
cards.definition: kg

cards.term: What is the base unit of length?
cards.definition: m

cards.term: What is the base unit of time?
cards.definition: s

cards.term: What is the base unit of current?
cards.definition: A

cards.term: What is the base unit of absolute temperature?
cards.definition: K

cards.term: What is the Unit of potential difference?
cards.definition: V

cards.term: What are the Units of density?
cards.definition: kgm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is the SI unit of energy?
cards.definition: J

cards.term: What is the SI unit of power?
cards.definition: W

cards.term: What is the SI unit of charge?
cards.definition: C

cards.term: What units are equivalent to the volt?
cards.definition: JC\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What base units are equivalent to the Newton?
cards.definition: kgms\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2

cards.term: What base units are equivalent to the Joule?
cards.definition: kgm\xc2\xb2s\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2

cards.term: What units are equivalent to the Pascal?
cards.definition: Nm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2

cards.term: What are the units of momentum?
cards.definition: kgms\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What are the units of resistivity?
cards.definition: \xce\xa9m

cards.term: What units are equivalent to a Watt?
cards.definition: Js\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What are the units of angular velocity (\xcf\x89)?
cards.definition: rad. s\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9
10\xe2\x81\xb6mm\xc2\xb2
10\xe2\x81\xb6cm\xc2\xb3
1x10\xe2\x81\xb6m\xc2\xb2
10\xc2\xb3mm\xc2\xb3

cards.term: There are 10\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xb4 free charge carriers per m\xc2\xb3 of a material. How many are there per mm\xc2\xb3?
cards.definition: 10\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb5

cards.term: 10\xe2\x81\xb6 particles strike each mm\xc2\xb2 of a surface per second. How many strike 1m\xc2\xb2 of the surface per second?
cards.definition: 10\xc2\xb9\xc2\xb2

cards.term: If there is 1 particle per mm\xc2\xb3, how many are there per m\xc2\xb3?
Water has a density of 1000kgm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3. What is this in kgcm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3?
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: Water has a density of 1000kgm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3. What is this in gcm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3?

cards.definition: Something that must be kept constant to prevent it affecting the dependent variable

cards.term: What is meant by the repeatability of results?
cards.definition: Similar results would be obtained from repeats of the same measurement from the same experimental set up.

cards.term: What is meant by the reproducibility of results
cards.definition: Similar results would be obtained from repeats by different people with different equipment.

cards.term: How can you ensure a metre rule is held vertically?
cards.definition: Use a plumb line, set square or spirit level

cards.term: How do you avoid parallax error?
cards.definition: Ensure eye, object and scale are all in line with each other OR ensure object and scale are directly adjacent to each other

cards.term: What is meant by the term random error?
cards.definition: Errors that cause the measurement to vary in unpredictable ways.
An error that causes the measurements to differ from the true value by a consistent amount.
An error that occurs due to the measuring instrument reading a non-zero reading when the measured quantity is zero.

cards.term: What is meant by the accuracy of a result?
cards.definition: How close a measurement is to the \'true\' or accepted value

cards.term: What is meant by the precision of results?
cards.definition: How close repeated measurements are to each other.

cards.term: What is meant by the resolution of a measuring instrument?
cards.definition: The smallest change in quantity that can be measured.

cards.term: What determines the resolution when using a multimeter?
cards.definition: The scale selected.

cards.term: What is the resolution of a metre rule?
cards.definition: 1mm

cards.term: What is the resolution of vernier calipers?
cards.definition: 0.1mm

cards.term: What is the resolution of a micrometer
How do you find the absolute uncertainty from repeated readings?
cards.definition: \xc2\xb1 \xc2\xbd the range of the repeats

cards.term: How do you estimate uncertainty when repeated results are identical?
cards.definition: \xc2\xb1 \xc2\xbd the resolution of the instrument

cards.term: How do you calculate percentage uncertainty?
cards.definition: (Absolute uncertainty \xc3\xb7 \'calculated OR measured\' value) \xc3\x97 100

cards.term: What do you do to the uncertainties when quantities are added or subtracted?
cards.definition: The absolute uncertainties are added together

cards.term: What do you do to the uncertainties when quantities are multiplied or divided?
cards.definition: The percentage uncertainties are added together

cards.term: What do you do to the uncertainties when a quantity is raised to a power?
cards.definition: The percentage uncertainty is multiplied by that power

cards.term: How do you find the uncertainty in a gradient?
cards.definition: \xc2\xb1 (gradient of the line of best fit \xe2\x88\x92 gradient of the line of worst fit)

cards.term: What is a line of worst fit?
cards.definition: The steepest or shallowest line that passes through the error bars.
Lines to show the range of the absolute uncertainty of each data point on a graph

cards.term: How do you find uncertainty in a y-intercept?
cards.definition: \xc2\xb1 (y-intercept of the line of best fit \xe2\x88\x92 y-intercept of the line of worst fit)
A charged particle capable of transferring electric current.

cards.term: What do we mean when we say charge is quantised?
cards.definition: It can only take certain values (always ne)

cards.term: If n electrons are removed from a neutral object what is its charge?
cards.definition: ne
A liquid containing charged ions.
A material comprising a lattice of positive ions and delocalised electrons that carry electrical current

cards.term: Which direction does conventional current flow?
cards.definition: From positive to negative.

cards.term: Which direction do electrons flow in a circuit?
cards.definition: From negative to positive.
A non-neutral atom or molecule.
A positively charged ion
A negatively charged ion.
A positive electrode.
A negative electrode.
In series

cards.term: What is the resistance of an ideal ammeter?
cards.definition: Zero.
At any point in a circuit the sum of the currents entering that point is equal to sum of the currents leaving.

cards.term: What is n in the equation I = nAve and what are its units?
cards.definition: Number density of free charge carriers m\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is A in the equation I = nAve?
cards.definition: Cross-sectional area of the conductor.

cards.term: What is e in the equation I = nAve?
cards.definition: The elementary charge (1.6x10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb9C)

cards.term: What is v in the equation I = nAve?
cards.definition: The drift velocity of the charge carriers.
A material with a large number density of charge carriers ~10\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xb8m\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3
A material with a low number density of charge carriers.
A material with an intermediate number density of charge carriers ~10\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb7m\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3
The work done per unit charge between two points

cards.term: What is the SI unit for potential difference?
cards.definition: Volt (V)

cards.term: What units are equivalent to the volt?
cards.definition: Joules per Coulomb (JC\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 )
The work done per unit charge supplied to the charge carriers
In parallel.

cards.term: What is the resistance of an ideal voltmeter?
cards.definition: Infinite.
The emission of electrons from the surface of a heated metal.

cards.term: What is the work done on an electron when it passes through a p.d. of V volts?
cards.definition: eV where e is the charge on the electron.
For a metallic conductor at constant temperature the p.d. is proportional to current.
The opposition of an object to a flow of current through it.
V/I

cards.term: What units are equivalent to an Ohm?
cards.definition: VA\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: Why does resistance increases with temperature?
cards.definition: The amplitude of lattice ion vibrations increases causing more frequent collisions between electrons and lattice ions, leading to the electrons doing more work as they move through the wire.

cards.term: Why does current flow lead to heating in components?
cards.definition: Electrons collide with the lattice ions and transfer some of their kinetic energy to the lattice ion\'s vibrations.

cards.term: What is the relationship between charge stored and pd across a capacitor?
cards.definition: Charge is proportional to voltage

cards.term: Describe what happens to the two plates of an uncharged capacitor when a p.d. is applied to it?
cards.definition: Electrons/charge flows off of one plate and flows on to the other causing one to become positive and the other negative.

cards.term: What units are equivalent to a Farad?
cards.definition: CV^-1 or coulombs per volt

cards.term: How do you calauclte the total capacitance for capacitors in parallel?
How do you calculte the total capacitance for capacitors in series?
If capcitors are connected in series what quantitiy is the same for all capacitors?
cards.definition: Charge stored

cards.term: If capcitors are connected in parallel what quantitiy is the same for all capacitors?
cards.definition: p.d.

cards.term: What is representd by the area under a p.d. - charge graphs?
cards.definition: Electrical energy transferred OR work done.

cards.term: What is represented by the gradient of a charge-p.d. graph for a capacitor?
cards.definition: Capacitance

cards.term: What is the relationship between energy stored and p.d. on a capcitor?
cards.definition: Energy stored is proportional to p.d. squared

cards.term: What is the relationship between energy stored and charge on a capcitor?
cards.definition: Energy stored is proportional to charge squared

cards.term: Out of Q, V and I which variable(s) follow the relationship x = x0 e^-(t/RC) when discharging a capacitor?
cards.definition: Q, V and I

cards.term: Out of Q, V and I which variable(s) follow the relationship x = x0 e^-(t/RC) when charging a capacitor?
cards.definition: I

cards.term: Out of Q, V and I which variable(s) follow the relationship x = x0 (1 - e^-(t/RC) ) when charging a capacitor?
cards.definition: Q and V

cards.term: How do you calculate time constant in a capcitor circuit?
cards.definition: RC

cards.term: What is meant by the constant-ratio nature of exponential decay?
cards.definition: In equal time intervals the quantity decreases by equal factors.

cards.term: How much charge remains after one time constant when discharging a capacitor?
How much charge remains after n time constants when discharging a capacitor?
cards.definition: e^-n

cards.term: What is represented by the gradient of charge-time graph when charging a capacitor?
cards.definition: Charging current.

cards.term: State a two uses of capacitors.
cards.definition: Energy storage e.g. for camera flashes, spot welding..., timing circuits, voltage smoothing, audio filters.
A region of space where a charge will experience an electrostatic force.

cards.term: What is the definition of electric field strength?
cards.definition: The force per unit charge on a positive test charge placed at that point

cards.term: What are the units of electric field strength?
cards.definition: NC\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 (or Vm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9)
permittivity of free space
Relative permittivity (of a dielectric).

cards.term: What does the direction of an electric field line show?
cards.definition: The direction of the force exerted on a positive test charge.

cards.term: What does the spacing of electric field lines show?
cards.definition: Field strength.

cards.term: Are test charges positive or negative?
cards.definition: positive
N C\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: When is the equation E = V/d used?
cards.definition: To find the uniform field strength between two parallel plates.
A pair of opposite sign charges separated by a small distance (e.g. a polar molecule like HCl)
The force between two point charges is proportional to the product of the two charges and inversely proportional to the square of their separation distance.
The work done per unit positive charge in moving between two points

cards.term: What is the definition of absolute electric potential of a point?
cards.definition: The work done per unit positive charge to move from infinity to that point in the field.

cards.term: What is the absolute electric potential an infinite distance from a 1C charge?
What units are equivalent to a V?
cards.definition: J C\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is the relationship between the electrostatic force between two point charges and their seperation distance?
cards.definition: It is inversely proportional to the square of separation OR inverse square law

cards.term: What is the relationship between potential and distance from a point charge?
cards.definition: Potential \xce\xb1 1/distance

cards.term: What is a uniform electric field?
cards.definition: A region of space in which the electric field strength is the same at all points
An electric field generated by a point charge OR a field that obeys the inverse square law.

cards.term: What is a neutral point in an electric field?
cards.definition: A point at which the resultant field strength is zero

cards.term: Is electric field strength a vector or a scalar quantity?
cards.definition: Vector

cards.term: Is electrical potential a vector or scalar quantity?
cards.definition: Scalar

cards.term: State a similarity between electric and gravitational fields.
cards.definition: Both obey inverse square law for field strength (around a point mass/charge). Both have infinite range. Both act between two objects at a distance.

cards.term: State two differences between electric and gravitational fields?
cards.definition: Gravitational fields act on masses, electric fields on charges: electric fields are much stronger that gravitational fields: electric fields can be attractive or repulsive, gravitational fields are always attractive: potential is always negative in a gravitational field.

cards.term: When is the equation V = Q / (4 pi \xce\xb50 r) used?
cards.definition: To find the potential around a point charge/in a radial field.

cards.term: When is the equation C = 4 x pi x \xce\xb50 x R used?
cards.definition: To calculate the capacitance on an isolated sphere.

cards.term: What is represented by R in the equation C = 4 x pi x \xce\xb50 x R used?
cards.definition: The radius of an isolated sphere.

cards.term: What is the relationship between electric potential energy and electric potential?
cards.definition: EPE = V x q where q is the charge in the field.

cards.term: What material was used as a target in Rutherford\'s scattering experiment?
cards.definition: Gold foil, a few atoms thick

cards.term: What was measured in Rutherford\'s scattering experiment?
cards.definition: The angle of deflection of the alpha particles.

cards.term: What happened to most of the alpha particle in Rutherford\'s scattering experiment?
cards.definition: They passed straight through the foil (with very little scattering).

cards.term: What proportion of alpha particles were scattered in Rutherford\'s scattering experiment?
cards.definition: Around 1 in 2000

cards.term: What proportion of alpha particles were deflected by more than 90\xc2\xb0 in Rutherford\'s scattering experiment?
cards.definition: Around 1 in 10,000

cards.term: What was concluded due to most of the alpha particles passing straight through the gold foil Rutherford\'s scattering experiment?
cards.definition: Most of the atom is empty space with most of the mass concentrated in a small nucleus.

cards.term: What was concluded due to some alpha particles being scattered in Rutherford\'s scattering experiment?
cards.definition: The nucleus is positively charged.

cards.term: How did Rutherford estimate the maximum radius of the nucleus?
cards.definition: He equated the KE of the alpha particle to the electric potential energy at closest approach to the nucleus.
A proton or neutron.
A nucleus of an element with the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons.

cards.term: What is an atomic mass unit?
cards.definition: One twelfth of the mass of a neutral carbon 12 atom.

cards.term: How has the radius of the nucleus been measured?
cards.definition: By the diffraction of fast moving electron.

cards.term: What is R in R = r\xe2\x82\x80A^(1/3)?
cards.definition: The radius of the nucleus.

cards.term: What is r\xe2\x82\x80 in R = r\xe2\x82\x80A^(1/3) roughly equivalent to?
cards.definition: The radius of a proton.

cards.term: What is A in R = r\xe2\x82\x80A^(1/3)
cards.definition: Nucleon number.

cards.term: What force holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus?
cards.definition: The strong nuclear force.

cards.term: What is the maximum range of the strong nuclear force?
cards.definition: ~3fm

cards.term: Below what distance is the strong nuclear force repulsive?
cards.definition: 0.5fm

cards.term: Which group of particles are subject to the weak nuclear force but not the strong nuclear force?
cards.definition: Leptons

cards.term: What is the quark composition of a meson?
cards.definition: A quark and an antiquark.

cards.term: Which force do Hadrons decay by?
cards.definition: The weak nuclear force.

cards.term: What is the quark composition of a Baryon
cards.definition: Three quarks
A lepton with no charge and a tiny mass.

cards.term: Why doesn\'t a neutrino experience the electromagnetic force?
cards.definition: They have no charge..

cards.term: What is the quark composition of a neutron?
cards.definition: up down down (udd)

cards.term: What is the quark composition of a proton?
cards.definition: up up down (uud)

cards.term: What is the quark composition of an anti-baryon?
cards.definition: Three antiquarks

cards.term: Name the two types of hadron.
cards.definition: baryons and mesons

cards.term: What force hold quarks together in hadrons?
cards.definition: The strong nuclear force.

cards.term: What is the family of particles that are subject to both the strong and weak nuclear force?
cards.definition: Hadrons

cards.term: What type of particle are nucleons?
cards.definition: Baryons

cards.term: How does a proton compare to an antiproton?
cards.definition: The have the same mass but opposite charge.

cards.term: How does an electron compare to a positron?
cards.definition: The have the same mass but opposite charge.

cards.term: What is the antiparticle of the electron?
cards.definition: Positron.

cards.term: What type of particle are there millions of passing through your body every second?
cards.definition: Neutrinos
A neutron in an unstable nucleus decays into a proton and emits an electron and an antineutrino.
A proton in an unstable nucleus decays into a neutron and emits a positron and a neutrino

cards.term: What quark transformation occurs during beta minus decay?
cards.definition: A down quark (in a neutron) turns into an up quark (in a proton)

cards.term: What quark transformation occurs during beta plus decay
cards.definition: An up quark (in a proton) turns into an down quark (in a neutron)

cards.term: What is meant by ionising radiation?
cards.definition: Radiation with sufficient energy to ionise atoms by removing electrons.

cards.term: What is the charge of gamma radiation?
What is a Beta minus particle?
cards.definition: A fast moving electron (emitted from a nucleus)

cards.term: What is a Beta plus particle?
cards.definition: A fast moving positron (emitted from a nucleus)
2 protons and 2 neutrons OR a helium nucleus

cards.term: What is the speed of gamma radiation?
cards.definition: 3x10\xe2\x81\xb8ms\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What type of nuclear radiation has the greatest rest mass
cards.definition: Alpha radiation
A high energy photon (emitted by the nucleus)

cards.term: What is the charge of an Alpha particle?
cards.definition: +3.2x10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb9C OR +2e

cards.term: What is the charge of a beta minus particle
cards.definition: -1.6x10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb9C OR -e

cards.term: What type of nuclear radiation is not deflected by electric and magnetic fields?
cards.definition: Gamma rays

cards.term: What type of nuclear radiation is deflected the most by electric and magnetic fields?
cards.definition: Beta radiation

cards.term: When measuring the count rate of a radioactive source what must be taken into account?
cards.definition: The background count rate / count rate with no source present

cards.term: How do you find the corrected count rate for a radioactive source from the measured count rate.
cards.definition: measured count rate - background count rate

cards.term: How far do alpha particles typically travel in air?
cards.definition: A few cm

cards.term: What type of ionising radiation is stopped by a sheet of paper?
cards.definition: Alpha radiation

cards.term: Why are alpha particles strongly ionising?
cards.definition: They have a relatively large mass and charge.

cards.term: What is the range of beta particles in air?
cards.definition: Around 1m

cards.term: What type of radiation requires around 1-3mm of aluminium to stop it?
cards.definition: Beta radiation

cards.term: What type of radiation is the least ionising?
cards.definition: Gamma rays

cards.term: Why is gamma the least ionising form of radiation?
cards.definition: It has no charge.

cards.term: What thickness of lead will stop a significant proportion of gamma rays?
cards.definition: 3-4cm
It can damage living cells and DNA.

cards.term: What procedure is routinely used to minimise the dose when handling radioactive sources in the lab?
cards.definition: Use tongs and hold it away from your body.

cards.term: What are the three key steps for reducing radiation dose?
cards.definition: Maximise distance from source, minimise exposure time and use shielding.
It is the total component of the magnetic flux density passing at right angles through a surface of area A OR \xe2\x88\x85 = BA cos\xce\xb8

cards.term: What are the SI units of flux?
cards.definition: Wb (Weber)

cards.term: What is represented by \xe2\x88\x85 in the equations \xe2\x88\x85 = BA cos\xce\xb8?
cards.definition: Flux

cards.term: What is the relationship between flux and flux linkage?
cards.definition: Flux linkage is flux multiplied by the number of turns on the coil

cards.term: What is represented by \xce\xb8 in the equations \xe2\x88\x85 = BA cos\xce\xb8?
cards.definition: The angle between the flux/field and the normal/perpendicular to the surface.
N\xe2\x88\x85 where N is the number of turns on the coil and \xe2\x88\x85 is the flux passing through the coil.

cards.term: What is the relationship between flux and flux density?
cards.definition: Flux density is the flux per unit area perpendicular to the field.

cards.term: How is flux represented in a field line diagram?
cards.definition: The total number of field lines passing through the object/surface.

cards.term: How is flux density represented in a field line diagram?
cards.definition: The spacing of field lines.

cards.term: What other units are Tesla commonly expressed in?
cards.definition: Wbm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2 (or Nm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9A\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9)
The magnitude of an induced EMF is directly proportional to the rate of change of flux linkage.

cards.term: What is represented by \xce\xb5 in the equation \xce\xb5 = -\xe2\x88\x86(N\xe2\x88\x85)/\xe2\x88\x86t?
cards.definition: Induced EMF.

cards.term: What is law is represented by the proportionality \xce\xb5 \xce\xb1 \xe2\x88\x86(N\xe2\x88\x85)/\xe2\x88\x86t?
cards.definition: Faraday\'s Law (of electromagnetic induction).
The direction of an induced EMF or current is always in such a direction as to oppose the change that created it.

cards.term: What principle leads to Lenz\'s law?
cards.definition: Conservation of energy.

cards.term: Why is there a negative sign in the equation \xce\xb5 = -\xe2\x88\x86(N\xe2\x88\x85)/\xe2\x88\x86t?
cards.definition: It is due to Lenz\'s law OR conservation of energy.

cards.term: What type of transformer has more turns on its primary coil?
cards.definition: A step down transformer.

cards.term: What type of transformer has more turns on its secondary coil?
cards.definition: A step down transformer.

cards.term: State two ways in which energy losses are transformers reduced?
cards.definition: Low resistance primary and secondary windings/laminated core/soft iron core

cards.term: Why is a laminated core used in a transformer?
cards.definition: To reduce the heating effect of (induced) eddy currents.
A core made up of layers that are separated by an insulator.

cards.term: What is meant by soft iron?
cards.definition: Iron that can be easily magnetised and demagnetised.

cards.term: What is an eddy current in a transformer?
cards.definition: A current induced by the changing flux in the core.
A progressive wave that transfers energy through space.
A wave in which the oscillations are perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation
A wave in which the oscillations are parallel to the direction of wave propagation

cards.term: Give an example of a longitudinal wave
cards.definition: Sound, primary seismic waves

cards.term: Give an example of a transverse waves
cards.definition: Waves on a stretched string, secondary seismic waves, electromagnetic radiation

cards.term: What are the regions of high pressure in a longitudinal wave called?
cards.definition: Compressions

cards.term: What are the regions of low pressure in a longitudinal wave called?
cards.definition: Rarefactions

cards.term: What is the displacement of a wave?
cards.definition: The distance of a particle in the medium from it\'s equilibrium position in a particular direction.

cards.term: What is the equilibrium position in wave motion?
cards.definition: The position of the medium when undisturbed by a wave.

cards.term: What is the amplitude of a wave?
cards.definition: Maximum displacement of the medium from the equilibrium position.

cards.term: What is the frequency of a wave?
cards.definition: The number of wave cycles per second OR the number of waves passing a point per unit time

cards.term: What is the time period of a wave?
cards.definition: Time taken for one complete oscillation OR time for a whole wavelength to pass a fixed point.

cards.term: What is the relationship between frequency and time period?
cards.definition: f = 1/T or inverse proportionality

cards.term: How many radians of phase are there in one complete wave cycle?
cards.definition: 2\xcf\x80 rad

cards.term: What term describes a phase difference of zero between two points on a wave?
cards.definition: In phase

cards.term: What term describes a phase difference of pi radians between two points on a wave?
cards.definition: In antiphase

cards.term: What is the phase difference between points half a wavelngth apart?
cards.definition: 180 degrees OR \xcf\x80 rad

cards.term: What is the phase difference between points quarter of a wavelngth apart?
cards.definition: 90 degrees OR \xcf\x80/2 rad
A displacement one way and then the other about an equilibrium position.
The spreading out of waves after passing through a slit/around an obstacle.

cards.term: What effect does reducing the size of a single slit have on diffraction?
cards.definition: Diffracted waves spread out more

cards.term: What is the effect of decreasing the wavelength on diffraction?
cards.definition: Diffracted waves spread out less

cards.term: What is meant by the intensity of a wave?
cards.definition: Intensity is the energy delivered by the wave per second per square metre normal to the wave

cards.term: How is the intensity of a wave related to the amplitude?
cards.definition: Intensity is proportional to amplitude squared.

cards.term: How does intensity vary with distance from a point source of waves?
cards.definition: Inverse square law or I = P / 4\xcf\x80r\xc2\xb2
A wave that requires a medium.

cards.term: What is the difference between mechanical waves and electromagentic waves?
cards.definition: EM waves don\'t require a medium.
An oscillation of the electric and magentic fields at right angles to each other.

cards.term: What is the speed of all EM waves in a vacuum/air?
cards.definition: 3x10\xe2\x81\xb8ms\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: List the regions of the EM spectrum in order of incresasing wavelength.
cards.definition: Radio waves, Microwaves, Infrared, Visible Light, Ultraviolet, X-rays, Gamma rays

cards.term: Which two regions of the EM spectrum overlap?
cards.definition: X-rays and gamma rays.

cards.term: State the range of wavelengths (in powers of 10) of radio waves
cards.definition: >10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: State the range of wavelengths (in powers of 10) of microwaves
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 - 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: State the range of wavelengths (in powers of 10) of infrared
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3 - 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb6

cards.term: State the range of wavelengths of visible light
cards.definition: 7x10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb7 - 4x10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb7

cards.term: State the range of wavelengths (in powers of 10) of ultraviolet
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb7 - 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb8

cards.term: State the range of wavelengths (in powers of 10) of X-rays
cards.definition: 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xe2\x81\xb8 - 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xc2\xb3

cards.term: State the range of wavelengths (in powers of 10) of gamma rays
cards.definition: <10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb0

cards.term: Why can\'t longitudinal waves be polarised?
cards.definition: Longitudinal waves already only have a single driection of oscillation.

cards.term: What is the effect of a polarising filter?
cards.definition: It only transmits the component of the oscillations parallel to the filter

cards.term: What is the effect of perpendicular polarising filters
cards.definition: No light is transmitted

cards.term: Give a use of polarising filters.
cards.definition: LCD screens, 3D TV, polarimetry in manufacturing, anti-glare sunglasses

cards.term: What effect does reflection have on the polarisation of light?
cards.definition: Reflected light is partially polarised in the plane of the surface.

cards.term: What effect does scattering light have on polarisation?
cards.definition: Scattered light is polarised

cards.term: Which wave property always remains constant when a wave travels from one medium to another?
cards.definition: Frequency

cards.term: When entering a material with a higher refractive index what happens to wave speed?
cards.definition: decreases

cards.term: When entering a material with a lower refractive index what happens to wavelength?
cards.definition: increases

cards.term: What is the definition of the refractive index of a material
cards.definition: Speed of light in a vacuum/Speed of light in material

cards.term: What are the angles of incidence and refraction measured relative to?
cards.definition: The normal to the boundary

cards.term: Which way do waves refract when entering a material with a higher refractive index?
cards.definition: Toward the normal

cards.term: Which way do waves refract when entering a material with a lower refractive index?
cards.definition: Away from the normal

cards.term: What is the angle of refraction at the critical angle?
cards.definition: Ninety degrees

cards.term: What are the conditions required for total internal reflection?
cards.definition: Wave must be travelling in a material with a higher index and meeting a boundary with a material of lower refractive index.The angle of incidence must be greater than the critical angle.

cards.term: What two phenomena occur when a wave goes from a higher to a lower refractive index at an angle of incidence less than the critical angle?
cards.definition: The ray is refracted and partially reflected.

cards.term: What is the principle of superposition
cards.definition: When two waves meet at a point the resultant displacement is the (vector) sum of the displacements of the individual waves.
When two waves superpose in phase causing an increase amplitude.
When two waves superpose in antiphase causing a decreased amplitude.

cards.term: What are coherent sources of waves?
cards.definition: Sources that emit waves with a constant phase difference (and the same frequency).
A pattern of regions of constructive and destructive interference produced by coherent sources of waves.

cards.term: What path difference is required for waves to be in phase?
cards.definition: A whole number of wavelengths

cards.term: What path difference is required for waves to be in antiphase?
cards.definition: An odd number of half wavelengths

cards.term: What is the relationship between path difference and phase difference for coherent sources?
cards.definition: (Path difference/wavelength) x 2\xcf\x80

cards.term: What term describes a phase difference of zero between two waves?
cards.definition: In phase

cards.term: What term describes a phase difference of \xcf\x80 radians between two waves?
cards.definition: In antiphase

cards.term: What is x in the double slit equation (\xce\xbb = ax/D)?
cards.definition: Fringe seperation

cards.term: What is D in the double slit equation (\xce\xbb = ax/D)?
cards.definition: Distance between the double slits and the screen

cards.term: What is a in the double slit equation (\xce\xbb = ax/D)?
cards.definition: Distance between the double slits

cards.term: What occurs to cause a dark fringe in the double slit experiment?
cards.definition: Destructive interference of the light from each slit

cards.term: What occurs to cause a bright fringe in the double slit experiment?
cards.definition: Constructive interference of the light from each slit

cards.term: What did Young\'s double slit experiment demonstrate about the nature of light?
cards.definition: That light exhibits wave behaviour.

cards.term: What name is given to light of a single frequency/wavelength?
cards.definition: Monochromatic

cards.term: Why did Young place a single slit before the double slit?
cards.definition: To ensure the light from each of the double slits was in phase.

cards.term: What are the condition required for a stationary wave to form?
cards.definition: Two waves travelling/propagating in opposite directions superpose with the same frequency and similar amplitudes

cards.term: What is an antinode on a stationary wave?
cards.definition: A point where the progressive waves are in phase and constructively interfering resulting in maximum amplitude

cards.term: What is an node on a stationary wave?
cards.definition: A point where the progressive waves are in antiphase and are destructively interfering resulting in minimum amplitude

cards.term: How many wavelengths are there between adjacent nodes of a standing wave?
cards.definition: Half a wavelength

cards.term: What is the phase difference between points either side of a node in a standing wave?
cards.definition: Pi Rad/180 degrees

cards.term: What is the phase difference of points that are between two adjacent nodes of a standing wave?
cards.definition: Zero

cards.term: How does phase vary along a progressive wave?
cards.definition: Changes continuously across each wave cycle.
