cards.term: How does amplitude vary in a stationary wave?
cards.definition: It varies continuously along the wave. It is a maximum at antinodes and a minimum at nodes.

cards.term: How does amplitude vary in a progressive wave?
cards.definition: It is the same at every point along the wave.

cards.term: What type of wave doesn\'t tranfer energy?
cards.definition: Stationary waves

cards.term: What is the fundamental frequency of a string?
cards.definition: The lowest frequency which produces a stationary wave on the string.

cards.term: What factors determine the fundamental frequency on a string
cards.definition: Length, tension and the thickness of the string.

cards.term: What determines the pitch produced by a stationary wave in a musical instrument?
cards.definition: The frequency of the 1st harmonic

cards.term: What determines the loudness of sound?
cards.definition: The amplitude of the sound wave

cards.term: Why can only certain frequency stationary waves be produced on a stretched string?
cards.definition: There must be nodes at the fixed ends and only certain frequencies/wavelengths allow this.

cards.term: What feature of a stationary wave is always formed at an open end of a tube?
cards.definition: (Displacement) Antinode

cards.term: What feature of a stationary wave is always formed at a closed end of a tube?
cards.definition: (Displacement) Node
A quantity with magnitude but no direction.
A quantity with magnitude and direction.

cards.term: When adding two perpendicular vectors what can you use to find the direction of the resultant?
cards.definition: Trigonometry

cards.term: When adding two perpendicular vectors what can you use to find the magnitude of the resultant?
cards.definition: Pythagoras\' Theorem
The process of splitting a vector into two perpendicular components.
The sum of two or more individual vectors.

cards.term: How is the resultant found in a vector diagram when adding several vectors together?
cards.definition: Join the vectors nose to tail and the resultant is from the tail of the first to the nose of the last vector.
The distance of an object from a point in a specific direction (vector)
Rate of change of displacement (vector) \xe2\x88\x86s/\xe2\x88\x86t if constant
Change in distance traveled per unit time (scalar)
Rate of change of velocity (vector) \xe2\x88\x86v/\xe2\x88\x86t if constant

cards.term: What are the units of acceleration?
cards.definition: ms\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2

cards.term: What is meant by constant velocity?
cards.definition: Speed and direction of motion don\'t change

cards.term: What is represented by the gradient of a distance-time graph?
cards.definition: Speed

cards.term: What is represented by the gradient of a displacement-time graph?
cards.definition: Velocity

cards.term: What is represented by the gradient of a velocity-time graph?
cards.definition: Acceleration

cards.term: What is represented by the area under a velocity-time graph?
cards.definition: Change in displacement

cards.term: What is represented by the area under an acceleration-time graph?
cards.definition: Change in velocity

cards.term: When can the suvat equations by used?
cards.definition: When there is constant acceleration and motion along a straight line.

cards.term: What is the effect of mass on the acceleration for an object in free-fall?
cards.definition: None

cards.term: What is the relationship between displacement and time for an object falling freely from rest?
cards.definition: Displacement is proportional to time squared (s\xce\xb1t\xc2\xb2)
An object acted upon only by the force of gravity

cards.term: What shape is the path of a projectile?
cards.definition: Parabolic

cards.term: What is the initial vertical velocity of an object projected horizontally?
cards.definition: Zero

cards.term: What angle of projection that results in maximum range
cards.definition: 45\xc2\xb0

cards.term: Ignoring air resistance what is the acceleration of a projectile?
cards.definition: Always g downwards

cards.term: How does horizontal velocity vary in projectile motion?
cards.definition: It is constant

cards.term: How do the initial and final velocities compare if a projectile returns to its starting height?
cards.definition: They have the same magnitude but opposite direction/sign.

cards.term: What equation used for the horizontal component of projectile motion?
cards.definition: Displacement = Velocity x time (since horizontal velocity is constant)

cards.term: What aspect links the vertical and horizontal motion of a projectile
cards.definition: Time taken to fall

cards.term: Why can SUVAT equations can be used for the vertical component of projectile motion
cards.definition: Since the motion is in a single direction with a constant acceleration

cards.term: What is the vertical velocity at the peak of projectile motion?
cards.definition: Zero

cards.term: What is the centre of mass of an object?
cards.definition: The point at which the weight can be assumed to act.

cards.term: What does the weight of an object depend on?
cards.definition: It\'s mass and the gravitational field strength (W=mg)
It is a diagram showing the set of forces acting on a single object.
The force due to gravity that acts through an objects centre of mass.
The force that acts between two surfaces in contact to oppose motion.
The resistive force that acts on an object moving through a fluid
The force within a stretched object such as a cable or rope.
The upward buoyant force that acts on an object in a fluid.

cards.term: What is a normal contact force?
cards.definition: A force that acts perpendicular to a surface when an object rests on it.

cards.term: How do you calculate the component of weight down a slope?
cards.definition: W sin (\xce\xb8) where \xce\xb8 is the angle between the slope and horizontal.

cards.term: How do you calculate the component of weight acting perpendicular to a slope?
cards.definition: W cos (\xce\xb8) where \xce\xb8 is the angle between the slope and horizontal.

cards.term: What are the key factors in determining the magnitude of drag force acting on an object in a fluid?
cards.definition: Speed and cross-sectional area
The maximum speed reached by a falling object when drag and weight are equal.
The turning effect produced by a force.
Nm

cards.term: How do you calculate a moment about a point?
cards.definition: Force x perpendicular distance to the line of action of the force

cards.term: What is meant by a body being in equilibrium?
cards.definition: The net force and the net moment acting on the body are both zero.

cards.term: What is the principle of moments?
cards.definition: For an object in rotational equilibrium the sum of the clockwise moments about any point is equal to the sum of anticlockwise moments about that point.
A pair of equal and opposite forces acting on an object with different lines of action.

cards.term: How do you calculate the moment of a couple?
cards.definition: Force x perpendicular distance between the lines of action of the forces.

cards.term: What is a triangle of forces?
cards.definition: A vector diagram of the three forces acting on an object in equilibrium.
The vector sum of forces acting on an object

cards.term: What is the density of a substance?
cards.definition: mass per unit volume.

cards.term: What are the units of density?
cards.definition: kgm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3
Normal force acting per unit area
The upthrust exerted on an object is equal to the weight of fluid displaced

cards.term: What is p in the equation p = h\xcf\x81g
cards.definition: Pressure exerted by a fluid

cards.term: What is \xcf\x81 in the equation p = h\xcf\x81g
cards.definition: Density of the fluid

cards.term: What is h in the equation p = h\xcf\x81g
cards.definition: Depth of the fluid

cards.term: What is work done equivalent to?
cards.definition: Energy Transferred

cards.term: What are the SI base units equivalent to the Joule?
cards.definition: kgm\xc2\xb2s\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2
W = F x cos\xce\x98 (distance moved x component of the force in the direction of motion)

cards.term: What is \xce\x98 in W = F x cos\xce\x98?
cards.definition: The angle between the force and motion.
The capacity of one object or system to do work (or cause a change) on another.

cards.term: What is represented by the area under a force-distance graph?
cards.definition: Work done.

cards.term: What is the principle of conservation of energy?
cards.definition: The energy of a closed system always remains constant. Energy can never be created or destroyed, only transferred.

cards.term: What form of energy is due to the motion of a mass?
cards.definition: kinetic energy

cards.term: What form of energy is due to the position of a mass in a gravitational field?
cards.definition: gravitational potential energy

cards.term: What form of energy is due to the bonds between atoms in a substance?
cards.definition: chemical energy

cards.term: What form of energy is due to a reversible change in shape of an object?
cards.definition: elastic potential energy

cards.term: What form of energy is due to the position of a charge in an electric field?
cards.definition: electrical potential energy

cards.term: What form of energy is due to the forces between protons and neutrons in an atom?
cards.definition: nuclear energy

cards.term: What form of energy is due to electromagnetic waves?
cards.definition: Radiant energy

cards.term: What form of energy is due to the mechanical wave motion of atoms?
cards.definition: Sound energy

cards.term: What form of energy is due to randomly distributed potential and kinetic energies of the atoms within a system?
cards.definition: Thermal energy

cards.term: What effect does friction have on the energy of a moving object?
cards.definition: Transfers kinetic energy primarily to thermal energy

cards.term: Describe the energy transformations for an object sliding downhill at constant speed.
cards.definition: Gravitational potential energy decreases at the same rate as work is done by friction.

cards.term: Describe the energy transformations for a vehicle travelling uphill at constant speed.
cards.definition: Work is being done by the driving force and the is equal to the gain in gravitational potential energy plus work done by friction
Power is the rate at which work is done P = W/t

cards.term: What is the derived unit of Power?
cards.definition: Watt (W)

cards.term: What are the equivalent SI base units of the Watt?
cards.definition: kgm\xc2\xb2s\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is the equation P = Fv used for?
cards.definition: The power developed by an object moving at constant speed against a constant resistive force.
(Useful output energy/total input energy) x 100

cards.term: What is Newton\'s 1st Law of motion?
cards.definition: An object will remain at rest of move at a constant velocity unless acted upon by a resultant force

cards.term: What is Newton\'s 3rd Law of motion?
cards.definition: When two objects interact they exert forces on each other that are equal in magnitude, opposite in direction and of the same type of force.

cards.term: What is Newton\'s 2nd Law of motion?
cards.definition: Resultant force acting on an object is proportional to its rate of change of momentum, and is in the same direction.

cards.term: What two sets of units can be used for momentum?
cards.definition: Ns OR kgms\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: How is the momentum of an object calculated?
cards.definition: Mass \xc3\x97 velocity (p=mv)

cards.term: What is the principle of conservation of momentum?
cards.definition: The total momentum in a system of interacting objects is constant provided no external force acts.
A collision in which kinetic energy is conserved
A collision in which some kinetic energy is transferred to other forms
Force \xc3\x97 time

cards.term: What is the relationship between impulse and momentum?
cards.definition: Impulse is equal to change in momentum.

cards.term: What is represented by the area under a force time graph
cards.definition: Impulse

cards.term: What is reprsented by the gradient of a momentum-time graph?
cards.definition: Resultant force

cards.term: What is the change in momentum when an object of momentum p collides elastically at right angles with a wall?

cards.definition: When an object has constant mass.
A charged particle capable of transferring electric current.

cards.term: What do we mean when we say charge is quantised?
cards.definition: It can only take certain values (always ne)

cards.term: If n electrons are removed from a neutral object what is its charge?
cards.definition: ne
A liquid containing charged ions.
A material comprising a lattice of positive ions and delocalised electrons that carry electrical current

cards.term: Which direction does conventional current flow?
cards.definition: From positive to negative.

cards.term: Which direction do electrons flow in a circuit?
cards.definition: From negative to positive.
A non-neutral atom or molecule.
A positively charged ion
A negatively charged ion.
A positive electrode.
A negative electrode.
In series

cards.term: What is the resistance of an ideal ammeter?
cards.definition: Zero.
At any point in a circuit the sum of the currents entering that point is equal to sum of the currents leaving.

cards.term: What is n in the equation I = nAve and what are its units?
cards.definition: Number density of free charge carriers m\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3

cards.term: What is A in the equation I = nAve?
cards.definition: Cross-sectional area of the conductor.

cards.term: What is e in the equation I = nAve?
cards.definition: The elementary charge (1.6x10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb9C)

cards.term: What is v in the equation I = nAve?
cards.definition: The drift velocity of the charge carriers.
A material with a large number density of charge carriers ~10\xc2\xb2\xe2\x81\xb8m\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3
A material with a low number density of charge carriers.
A material with an intermediate number density of charge carriers ~10\xc2\xb9\xe2\x81\xb7m\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3
The work done per unit charge between two points

cards.term: What is the SI unit for potential difference?
cards.definition: Volt (V)

cards.term: What units are equivalent to the volt?
cards.definition: Joules per Coulomb (JC\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 )
The work done per unit charge supplied to the charge carriers
In parallel.

cards.term: What is the resistance of an ideal voltmeter?
cards.definition: Infinite.
The emission of electrons from the surface of a heated metal.

cards.term: What is the work done on an electron when it passes through a p.d. of V volts?
cards.definition: eV where e is the charge on the electron.
For a metallic conductor at constant temperature the p.d. is proportional to current.
The opposition of an object to a flow of current through it.
V/I

cards.term: What units are equivalent to an Ohm?
cards.definition: VA\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: Why does resistance increases with temperature?
cards.definition: The amplitude of lattice ion vibrations increases causing more frequent collisions between electrons and lattice ions, leading to the electrons doing more work as they move through the wire.

cards.term: Why does current flow lead to heating in components?
cards.definition: Electrons collide with the lattice ions and transfer some of their kinetic energy to the lattice ion\'s vibrations.
An object for which p.d. is proportional to current.

cards.term: What is meant by the threshold pd of a diode?
cards.definition: The pd at which resistance starts to fall rapidly as pd increases.

cards.term: What are the units of resistivity?
cards.definition: \xce\xa9m
The resitivity of the material.

cards.term: What is L in R = \xcf\x81L / A?
cards.definition: The length of the wire.

cards.term: What is A in R = \xcf\x81L / A?
cards.definition: The cross-sectional area of the wire

cards.term: As a metal gets hotter what happens to its resitivity?
cards.definition: It increases.

cards.term: What is meant by a negative temperature coefficient component?
cards.definition: One in which the resistance drops as temperature increases.

cards.term: Why does resistance of a thermistor fall as temperature increases?
cards.definition: The number density of charge carriers increases.

cards.term: What are thermistors commonly used in?
cards.definition: Temperature sensors.

cards.term: Why does the resistance of an LDR as light intensity changes?
cards.definition: Light increases the number density of charge carriers in the LDR.

cards.term: What are LDRs commonly used in?
cards.definition: Light intensity sensors.

cards.term: What happens to the resistance of an LDR as light intensity increases?
cards.definition: It decreases.
The energy supplied when 1kW of power is supplied for 1 hour.

cards.term: How many Joules are equavlent to a kWh
cards.definition: 3.6MJ
Sum of the EMFs is equal to the sum of the potential drops around a closed circuit loop.

cards.term: What law is Kirchoff\'s second law a consequence of?
cards.definition: Conservation of Energy

cards.term: What can we say about the current through components in series?
cards.definition: Same for each component

cards.term: What can we say about the current on different parallel branches?
cards.definition: It depends on the resistance of each branch.

cards.term: What can we say about the pd across parallel branches in a circuit?
cards.definition: It is the same for each branch

cards.term: How do find the total pd across several components in series?
cards.definition: It is equal to the sum of the pds across each component

cards.term: How do you find the total EMF from cells connected in series with the same polarity?
cards.definition: Their EMFs are added

cards.term: How do you find the total EMF from cells connected in series with opposite polarity?
cards.definition: The total EMF is the difference between their EMFs

cards.term: How do you calculate the total resistance of resistors in series?
cards.definition: Sum of the individual resistances

cards.term: What is the total resistance of n identical resistors in series?
cards.definition: n x R

cards.term: What is the total resistance of n identical resistors in parallel?
cards.definition: R \xc3\xb7 n

cards.term: How do you calculate the resistance of resistors in parallel?
How does the total resistance change when a resistor is added in series?
cards.definition: It always increases

cards.term: How does the total resistance change when a resistor is added in parallel?
cards.definition: It always decreases

cards.term: What is the effect of connecting two identical resistors in parallel?
cards.definition: Resistance is halved

cards.term: What is the effect of connecting two identical resistors in series?
cards.definition: Resistance is doubled
The opposition to current created by the charge carriers having to flow through the source of EMF

cards.term: What are the lost volts for a power supply?
cards.definition: The pd dropped across the internal resistance OR the difference between the EMF and the terminal pd.

cards.term: What happens to the terminal pd of a source as the current supplied increases?
cards.definition: It falls due to the increasing lost volts to the internal resistance.

cards.term: How do you calculate lost volts for a supply?
cards.definition: Ir where r is the internal resistance.

cards.term: What is the relationship between EMF, terminal pd and lost volts?
cards.definition: EMF = terminal pd + lost volts

cards.term: How do you find the internal resistance from a graph or terminal pd against current?
cards.definition: -gradient

cards.term: How do you find the EMF from a graph or terminal pd against current?
cards.definition: y-intercept
Two or resitances in series with a fixed source of EMF.

cards.term: What determines the ratio of the pd across the resistors in a potential divider?
cards.definition: It is equal to the ratio of their resistances.

cards.term: How can a light sensor be made?
cards.definition: By creating a potential divider containing an LDR.

cards.term: How can a temperature sensor be made?
cards.definition: By creating a potential divider containing a thermistor.

cards.term: What component can be used to supply an adjustable output pd?
cards.definition: A potentiometer.
A force produces an extension of the object.
A force that reduces the length of an object.
Force is proportional to extension so long as the elastic limit is not exceeded.
When an object will return to its original shape when the load is removed.
A permanent change in shape that remains once the load is removed.

cards.term: What is k in F = kx
cards.definition: The force constant.

cards.term: What are the units of force constant (k)
cards.definition: Nm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is represented by the area under a force-extension graph?
cards.definition: The work done stretching the object.

cards.term: What is meant by an elastic material?
cards.definition: A material which can be significantly deformed and will return to it\'s original shape.
The force applied per unit cross sectional area.
The fractional change in length of an object.
A material which ccan be drawn into a wire of hammered into thin sheets.

cards.term: What is the limit of proportionality of a material?
cards.definition: The point at which a material stops obeying Hooke\'s Law

cards.term: What is the elastic limit of a material?
cards.definition: The point at which a material starts to plastically deform.

cards.term: What is the yield point of a material?
cards.definition: The point at which the material starts to extend rapidly as stress increases.

cards.term: What is the ultimate tensile strength of a material?
cards.definition: The maximum stress a material can withstand before breaking.

cards.term: What is the breaking strength of a material?
cards.definition: The stress at the point of fracture.
One with a high ultimate tensile strength.

cards.term: What are the units of Young Modulus?
cards.definition: Pa OR Nm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2

cards.term: When does the Young Modulus apply to a material?
cards.definition: When stress is proportional to strain OR when it is obeying Hooke\'s law

cards.term: How do you find the Young Modulus from a stress-strain graph?
cards.definition: The gradient of the initial straight line region.

cards.term: What material property does Young Modulus measure?
cards.definition: The stiffness.
A material the show only elastic behaviour up to its breaking point, without plastically deforming.
A material made from long chain molecules.

cards.term: What determines the energy of a photon?
cards.definition: The frequency/wavelength
A quantum of energy of electromagnetic radiation

cards.term: How do you calculate the energy of a photon?
cards.definition: E = hf OR E =hc/\xce\xbb
The energy gained or lost by an electron passing through a potential difference of 1V

cards.term: How do convert from eV to J?
cards.definition: multiply by 1.6x10^-19

cards.term: How do convert from J to eV?
cards.definition: divide by 1.6x10^-19

cards.term: What is the threshold p.d. of an LED?
cards.definition: The minimum potential difference required for the LED to produce light.

cards.term: How can the threshold p.d. of an LED be used to find photon energy?
cards.definition: The energy transferred by the electrons (e x V) is equal to the energy of the photons produced (hf).

cards.term: What is meant by wave particle duality?
cards.definition: It describes how all matter can display both wave and particle properties.

cards.term: What is the key piece of evidence for wave particle duality?
cards.definition: When an electron beam passes through polycrystaline graphite it produces a diffraction and interference pattern pattern.

cards.term: What does the De Broglie wave equation apply to?
cards.definition: Everything

cards.term: What is the relationship between momentum and wavelength?
cards.definition: Inverse proportionality
The emission of electrons from a metal surface when illuminated with light.

cards.term: What is the atomic structure of a metal?
cards.definition: A lattice of positive ions surrounded by a sea of free electrons.
An electron that has been removed from a metal by absorbing a photon
The minimum energy required to remove an electron from the surface of a metal
The minimum frequency of light required to produce photoelectrons from a metal
Light of a single frequency/wavelength

cards.term: What is the relationship between work function and threshold frequency?
What is required for a photon to be able to produce photoelectrons?
cards.definition: Its frequency is greater than the threshold frequency

cards.term: Why can\'t light sources below the threshold frequency produce photoelectrons?
cards.definition: The photon energy is less than the work function

cards.term: How do photons and electrons interact?
cards.definition: A single photon can be absorbed/emitted by a single electron which gains/loses the energy of the photon.

cards.term: What is the effect on an electron of absorbing a photon?
cards.definition: The electron gains the energy of the photon

cards.term: What effect does increasing the frequency of a monochromatic light source have on photoelectrons produced?
cards.definition: Photoelectrons will have a greater maximum kinetic energy

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing the intensity of a monochromatic light source on photoelectrons produced?
cards.definition: More photoelectrons will be produced but they will have the same maximum kinetic energy

cards.term: Why does the kinetic energy of photoelectrons from monochromatic light vary in the photoelectric effect?
cards.definition: The work function is a minimum energy. Some electrons are liberated from deeper into the metal and require more energy to be liberated.

cards.term: What two factors that determine the maximum kinetic energy of photoelectrons?
cards.definition: The frequency of the light and the work function of the metal

cards.term: What determines the rate at which energy is delivered by a wave?
cards.definition: Intensity/amplitude of the wave

cards.term: What is hf in Einstein\'s photoelectric effect equation (hf = \xf0\x9d\x9c\x99 + KE(max))
cards.definition: The energy of the incident photon.

cards.term: What is \xf0\x9d\x9c\x99 in Einstein\'s photoelectric effect equation (hf = \xf0\x9d\x9c\x99 + KE(max))
cards.definition: The work function of the metal.

cards.term: What is KE(max) in Einstein\'s photoelectric effect equation (hf = \xf0\x9d\x9c\x99 + KE(max))
cards.definition: The maximum kinetic energy of the photoelectrons

cards.term: According to the wave model how is energy transferred from light to electrons in a metal?
cards.definition: It is delivered continuously and builds up over time

cards.term: If light is above the threshold frequency, how long will it take for photoelectrons to start being produced?
cards.definition: It is instantaneous

cards.term: What happens if very intense light that is below the threshold frequency is used?
cards.definition: No photoelectrons are produced, regardless of intensity.
When two objects at the same temperature so no heat flows between them.
The temperature at which the internal energy of a system is at its lowest possible value

cards.term: What is the relationship between absolute temperature and the average KE of particles in a substance?
cards.definition: Absolute temperature is proportional to average kinetic energy of the particles in a substance.

cards.term: What is the triple point of a substance?
cards.definition: The temperature and pressure at which a substance can exist in all three phases in thermal equilibrium.

cards.term: Describe the kinetic model of a solid.
cards.definition: A regular arrangement of particles that are strongly attracted to each other. Particles vibrate but can\'t change positions in the structure.

cards.term: Describe the kinetic model of a liquid.
cards.definition: Particles are attracted to each other but are free to move around.

cards.term: Describe the kinetic model of a gas.
cards.definition: Particles are far apart and there are no forces of attraction between them.

cards.term: What is the internal energy of a substance?
cards.definition: The sum of the randomly distributed kinetic and potential energy of the particles in an object

cards.term: Why doesn\'t the temperature of a substance change whilst it is changing state?
cards.definition: The electrostatic potential of the particles is changing rather than the kinetic energy.

cards.term: Why is the electrostatic potential energy of liquids and solids negative?
cards.definition: Energy must be supplied to the substance to break the bonds between particles.

cards.term: What effect does increasing the temperature have on the particles in a substance?
cards.definition: It increases their average kinetic energy.

cards.term: What is the specific heat capacity (c) of a material?
cards.definition: The energy needed to raise the temperature of 1kg of the material by 1 degree Celsius/Kelvin without any change of state.

cards.term: What are the units of specific heat capacity (c)
cards.definition: J kg\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 K\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9
Thermal energy gained (or lost if negative) by an object (provided no change in state).

cards.term: How do you calculate the total energy supplied to an electrical heater.
cards.definition: W = IVt

cards.term: What is the specific heat capacity of water
cards.definition: 4200 J kg\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 K\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is the specific latent heat of vaporisation (L) of a substance?
cards.definition: The energy required to change 1kg of a liquid to a gaseous state with no change in temperature

cards.term: What is the specific latent heat of fusion (L) of a substance?
cards.definition: The energy required to change 1 kg of solid to liquid with no change in temperature.

cards.term: What are the units of latent heat (L)?
cards.definition: J kg\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9
The mass of substance which has changed state

cards.term: When would you use the equation \xe2\x88\x86Q = mc\xe2\x88\x86T + mL?
cards.definition: If an object changes temperature and changes state during heating.
A number of particles equal to the number of atoms in 12 grams of carbon-12

cards.term: What is one mole of a substance?
cards.definition: An amount in which the number of atoms/molecules is equal to Avogadro\'s constant.

cards.term: What is the molar mass of a substance?
cards.definition: The mass of one mole of a substance.

cards.term: How do you find the mass of one atom from its nucleon number?
cards.definition: Multiply nucleon number by the atomic mass unit (u) in kg.

cards.term: How is the atomic mass unit defined?
cards.definition: It is 1/12th the mass of a Carbon-12 atom

cards.term: How do you calculate the number of particles from the number of moles of a substance?
cards.definition: Number of particles = number of moles \xc3\x97 Avagadro\'s constant

cards.term: How do you find the molar mass of a substance from the molecular mass?
cards.definition: Molar mass = Molecular mass x Avagadro\'s Number

cards.term: How do you find the total mass of a substance from the number of moles?
cards.definition: number of moles x molar mass

cards.term: How do you calculate the number of moles of a substance from the number of particles?
cards.definition: Number of particles\xc3\xb7Avagadro\'s number

cards.term: How do you find the molar mass of an element from its nucleon number?
cards.definition: Molar mass is equal to nucleon number in grams.

cards.term: Boyle\'s law: Pressure is inversely proportional to...
cards.definition: Volume for a fixed mass of gas at constant temperature

cards.term: Charles\' law: Volume is proportional to...
cards.definition: Absolute temperature for a fixed mass of gas at constant pressure.

cards.term: Gay Lassac\'s Law: Pressure is proportional to...
cards.definition: Absolute temperature for a fixed mass of gas at constant volume

cards.term: Avogadro\'s law: Volume occupied by a gas is proportional to...
cards.definition: Number of particles/moles if pressure and temperature are constant.

cards.term: How do you find absolute zero from a pressure temperature graph?
cards.definition: Extrapolate the line to find the x-intercept.

cards.term: What is R in pV = nRT?
cards.definition: Molar Gas Constant

cards.term: What is N in pV = NkT?
cards.definition: Number of particles

cards.term: What is n in pV = nRT?
cards.definition: Number of moles

cards.term: What is k in pV = NkT?
cards.definition: Boltzmann constant

cards.term: What units of temperature should be used in the ideal gas equation?
cards.definition: Kelvin

cards.term: What is the equation of state for an ideal gas?
cards.definition: pV = NkT OR pV = nRT
A theoretical gas that obeys the gas laws at all pressures and temperatures

cards.term: What are the SI units of pressure?
cards.definition: Pascal (Pa or Nm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb2)

cards.term: What is the definition of pressure?
cards.definition: The force per unit area exerted normally to a surface

cards.term: What is the relationship between root mean square speed of particles in a gas and absolute temperature?
cards.definition: rms speed is proportional \xe2\x88\x9a(absolute temperature)

cards.term: Why does increasing the temperature of an ideal gas increase pressure?
cards.definition: Particles have greater kinetic energy so there is a greater rate of collisions and greater change in momentum per collision.

cards.term: Why does increasing the volume of an ideal gas decreases pressure?
cards.definition: P=F/A. Force exerted decreases as the rate of collisions with the container decreases and the surface area increases.

cards.term: According to Newton\'s second law if a particle experiences a change in momentum...
cards.definition: There must be a force acting on the particle.

cards.term: According to Newton\'s third law if a container exerts a force on a particle...
cards.definition: The particle must exert a force on the container.

cards.term: How do you calculate the mean square speed of gas particles from their velocity?
cards.definition: Square the magnitude of the velocity of each individual gas molecule and then take the average of these values.

cards.term: How do you calculate root mean square speed of a gas?
cards.definition: Square the magnitude of the velocity of each individual gas molecule, take the average of these values and then take the square root.

cards.term: Why is root mean square speed used instead of velocity?
cards.definition: Average velocity is zero.

cards.term: What is N in pV = \xc2\xb9/\xe2\x82\x83 N m (c)\xc2\xb2
cards.definition: Number of particles

cards.term: What is (c)\xc2\xb2 in pV = \xc2\xb9/\xe2\x82\x83 N m (c)\xc2\xb2
cards.definition: Mean square speed
The mean kinetic energy of a gas particle

cards.term: What form is the internal energy of an ideal gas?
cards.definition: Purely kinetic (i.e. no potential energy)

cards.term: Why is there no potential energy in an ideal gas?
cards.definition: Becuase there are no force between particles (except during collisions).
Total internal energy of an ideal gas.
The volume of the particles in a gas is negligible compared to the volume of the container
There are no electrostatic forces between particles except during collisions
Particles are in continuous, rapid, random motion.
The collisions particles undergo with each other and the container are all elastic
The duration of collisions is negligible compared to the time between collisions

cards.term: What is the relationship between absolute temperature and the average KE of particles in a substance?
cards.definition: Absolute temperature is proportional to average kinetic energy of the particles in a substance.

cards.term: How many radians are there is 360 degrees?
cards.definition: 2 pi

cards.term: What are the SI units of angular velocity?
cards.definition: Radians per second.

cards.term: What is the definition of angular velocity?
cards.definition: The rate of change of angle.

cards.term: How do you calculate angular velocity from time period (T)?
cards.definition: Angular velocity = 2 pi / T

cards.term: How do you calculate angular velocity from frequency (f)?
cards.definition: Angular velocity = 2 pi f

cards.term: What is required for uniform circular motion?
cards.definition: A force that always acts perpendicular to velocity.

cards.term: Why doesn\'t a centripetal force do any work on an object in circular motion!
cards.definition: The force has no component in the dircetion of motion/is always perpendicular to motion.

cards.term: How do you calculate linear velocity from the time period (T) of an object in circular motion?
cards.definition: v = 2 pi r / T

cards.term: How do you calculate linear velocity from angular velocity?
cards.definition: v = angular velocity x radius

cards.term: How is it possible for an object to experience an acceleration but travel at a constant speed?
cards.definition: If acceleration is perpendicular to velocity, the velocity will change direction whilst speed is constant.

cards.term: What provides the centripetal force for a car turning a corner?
cards.definition: Friction from the road on the tyres.

cards.term: What provides the centripetal force on the moon?
cards.definition: The gravitational attraction of the Earth.

cards.term: Apart from friction what contributes to the centripetal force on a banked track?
cards.definition: The horizontal component of the normal reaction.

cards.term: If a mass on a string is swung in a vertical circle where is the tension greatest?
cards.definition: At the bottom of the circle.

cards.term: If a mass on a string is swung in a vertical circle where is the tension least?
cards.definition: At the top of the circle.

cards.term: What is the equilibrium position in an oscillation?
cards.definition: The point at which an object experiences no resultant force and thus no acceleration (the \'rest\' position of an object).

cards.term: How many radians of phase are there in one complete oscillation?
cards.definition: 2 x pi

cards.term: How do you calculate the angular frequency of an oscillation?
cards.definition: 2 x pi x the frequency of the oscillation

cards.term: What are the conditions required for SHM?
cards.definition: The acceleration of an object is proportional, to its displacement from equilibrium and always in the opposite direction.

cards.term: What is the acceleration of an object undergoing SHM when it\'s displacement is zero?
cards.definition: Zero
An oscillator with a period/frequency that is not dependent on amplitude.
A pin or pointer placed at the equilibrium position of an oscillation.

cards.term: What measures can be taken to improve the accuracy when measuring the time period of SHM?
cards.definition: Time over multiple oscillations and calculate the average of several repeats.

cards.term: What is the kinetic energy of an SHM oscillator at maximum displacement?
cards.definition: Zero

cards.term: How does the total energy in an SHM oscillator vary with time?
cards.definition: It is constant.

cards.term: At what displacement is the potential energy of an SHM oscillator at a maximum?
cards.definition: At maximum displacement (x=\xc2\xb1A).

cards.term: How do you calculate the total energy of an SHM oscillator from its amplitude?
cards.definition: E = \xc2\xbd k A\xc2\xb2
An oscillation in which no external driving force is present

cards.term: What causes damping of an oscillation?
cards.definition: An external force opposing motion.

cards.term: What effect does damping of an oscillation have in terms of energy?
cards.definition: It transfers the KE of the oscillation to other forms, usually thermal energy.

cards.term: What is light damping of an oscillation?
cards.definition: A small damping force causing the amplitude of the oscillations to decrease slowly.

cards.term: What is heavy damping of an oscillation?
cards.definition: A damping force that results in a rapid decrease in the amplitude of oscillations.

cards.term: What is very heavy damping of an oscillation?
cards.definition: A large damping force that prevents any oscillations of the system when its displaced.

cards.term: What is the natural frequency of an oscillator?
cards.definition: The frequency at which osicllation will occur in a system with no external driving forces (free oscillations)
An oscillation in which a (periodic) external driving force is present

cards.term: What is a driving frequency in oscillations?
cards.definition: The frequency of the external driving force in a forced oscillation
When the driving frequency of a forced oscillation is close to the natural frequency of the system resulting in large amplitude oscillations.

cards.term: What is likely to occur when a mechanical system with little or no damping resonates?
cards.definition: The amplitude of the oscillations will increase until the object breaks.

cards.term: What occurs in terms of energy during resonance?
cards.definition: There is the greatest possible transfer of energy from the driver to the forced oscillation.

cards.term: What effects does increasing damping have on resonance?
cards.definition: It reduces the maximum amplitude and it reduces the frequency of maximum amplitude.
A region in which a mass will experience a gravitational force.
The force per unit mass exerted on test mass at that point in the field.

cards.term: What are the units of gravitational field strength?
cards.definition: N kg\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What does the direction of a gravitational field line show?
cards.definition: The direction of force on a test mass at that point in the field.

cards.term: What is represented by the spacing of field lines in a field line diagram?
cards.definition: Field strength.

cards.term: What is a radial gravitational field?
cards.definition: A gravitational field produced by a spherical (or point) mass in which the field lines all point towards the centre of mass of the object causing the field.

cards.term: What is a uniform gravitational field?
cards.definition: A region in which the gravitational field strength is constant.

cards.term: How is a uniform gravitational field shown in a field line diagram?
cards.definition: Parallel, equally spaced field lines.
A idealised mass with zero size. The field outside a spherical mass can be modelled as the field around a point mass.
The gravitational attraction between two objects is proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the sqaure of the distance between their centres of mass
A planet\'s orbit is an ellipse with the Sun at one of the two foci
The point in an orbit when an object is furthest from the sun and travelling slowest.
The point in an orbit when an object is closest to the sun and travelling fastest.
A line segment joining the planet to the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal time intervals.
For planets in the solar system the square of the orbital period is proportional to the cube of the average orbital radius.

cards.term: How does graviational field strength vary with distance from a point mass?
cards.definition: It follows an inverse square law.
A satellite with an orbital period of 24 hours which orbits above the equator in the same direction as the Earth\'s rotation so its apparent position in the sky remains unchanged.
An object which orbits planet.

cards.term: What is the absolute gravitational potential of a point?
cards.definition: The work done per unit mass to move an object from an infinite distance away to that point in the field.

cards.term: How does graviational potential vary with distance from a point mass?
cards.definition: It is inversely proportional to distance.
The velocity at which the magnitude of an object\'s kinetic energy is larger than the magnitude of its gravitational potential energy.
The work done to move an object from infinity to a point in the gravitational field.
Everything that exists.
A large cloud of gas (mainly hydrogen) and dust in space
A hot dense sphere of gas prior to the ignition of nuclear fusion in the core that creates a star

cards.term: What provides the energy required for a protostar to begin fusion?
cards.definition: Gravitation energy is transferred to thermal energy.
The fusing of light nuclei to produce heavier nuclei releasing energy in the process.

cards.term: What is required for nuclear fusion to occur?
cards.definition: Extremely high temperatures and pressures.

cards.term: What prevents gravity from causing stars to collapse?
cards.definition: The radiation and gas pressure pushing outward.

cards.term: Why do large stars tend to remain stable for less time than smaller starts?
cards.definition: The pressure and temperature in the core is higher so they fuse hydrogen more quickly.

cards.term: What is radiation pressure in a star?
cards.definition: Pressure from the photons created by fusion in the core of a star.

cards.term: What is the gas pressure in a stars?
cards.definition: Pressure of the nuclei in the star\'s core pusing outwards.

cards.term: What is a main sequence star?
cards.definition: A stable star fusing hydrogen in helium.

cards.term: What causes a star to leave the main sequence?
cards.definition: It runs low on hydrogen, affecting the stability of the star.
The stage after the main sequence for a star with insufficient mass to go supernova.

cards.term: Describe the structure of a red giant.
cards.definition: An inert core surronded by shells fusing elements heavier then Hydrogen.
The very hot, dense remnant core of a red giant star.
The mass of a star\'s core below which the star will form a white dwarf.
A quantum mechanical effect (due to Pauli exlcusion) which prevents the collapse of a stellar core to create a neutron star in white dwarves.
A huge star in the last stages of its life prior to undergoing a supernova explosion. Elements up to iron may be produced by fusion in layers around its core
The process of collapse of a red supergiant (at the end of its life) into a neutron star and the associated ejection of large amounts of stellar material into space.
The extremely dense remnant core of a red supergiant star made almost entirely of neutrons.
The outer layers of a red giant star driven off in the shockwave produced by the final collapse of the star.
The end stage of a stellar core with sufficient mass and density for its escape velocity to exceed the speed of light.

cards.term: What is the typical mass of a stellar core that creates a black hole?
cards.definition: 3 solar masses.
A log-log plot of luminosity (on the y-axis) against average surface temperature (backwards on the x-axis) for a group of stars.

cards.term: What is the Luminosity of a star?
cards.definition: The total radiant power output of a star (Energy radiated per second).
An object that absorbs all radiation incident upon it.

cards.term: What is a black body spectrum?
cards.definition: The characteristic spectrum of radiation emitted by all black bodies in thermal equilibriun with their surroundings.
The peak emission wavelength of a black body spectrum is inversely proportional to the body\'s absolute temperature.
The total power emitted per unit surface area by a black body is proportional to the 4th power of the absolute temperature

cards.term: What are electron energy levels in an atom?
cards.definition: Discrete energy levels within an atom in which electrons can exist.

cards.term: What is the ground state (of an atom)?
cards.definition: The lowest allowed electron energy level in an atom.

cards.term: What is the excited state of an atom?
cards.definition: An atom in which electrons have been raised to an energy level above the ground state.

cards.term: What is an emission line spectrum
cards.definition: The spectrum of bright lines

cards.term: What is an absorption line spectrum?
cards.definition: The spectrum containing dark lines in a continuous spectrum produced by light passing through a gas.

cards.term: What is meant by a discrete quantity?
cards.definition: Occuring only at particular values (as opposed to continous)
A large number of closely spaced alternating transparent and opaque \'lines\' used as a tool to produce spectra via interference.

cards.term: What is grating spacing for a diffraction grating?
cards.definition: The spacing between adjacent \'lines\' in a grating.

cards.term: What occurs in excitation of an atom?
cards.definition: The atom gains energy and an electron moves up to a higher energy level.

cards.term: What processes can lead to the excitation of an atom?
cards.definition: A collision with a charged particle The absorption of a photon by an electron in the atom.

cards.term: What occurs during de-excitation of an atom?
cards.definition: An excited electron drops down energy levels and emits a photon.

cards.term: What determines the frequency photons can be absorbed or emitted by an atom?
cards.definition: The size of a gaps between energy levels in the atom.

cards.term: What determines the frequency of photons that can be absorbed or emitted by an atom?
cards.definition: The energy of the photon must be equal to a gap between energy levels.
Distance between slits in a diffraction grating
Order of the maximum

cards.term: What name is given to the central maximum formed by a diffraction grating?
cards.definition: Zero-order

cards.term: What is the path length difference between adjacent slits along the nth order maximum?
cards.definition: n wavelengths

cards.term: How do you find slit spacing of a diffraction grating from the number of lines per m?
cards.definition: 1 / number of lines per m

cards.term: How do you find the highest order maximum for a diffraction grating?
cards.definition: d/\xce\xbb (rounded down to the nearest whole number)

cards.term: How do you calculate the number of maxima produced by a diffraction grating?
cards.definition: 2n+1 where n is the highest order of a maximum.

cards.term: What is the effect of reducing the spacing of slits in a diffraction grating?
cards.definition: It increases the angles of each maximum.

cards.term: What is the effect of increasing the wavelength incident on a diffraction grating?
cards.definition: It increases the angles of each maximum.
The average distance from Earth to the Sun
The distance that light travels in a vacuum in one year.
An angle equal to 1/60th of 1\xc2\xb0
An angle equal to 1/60th or an arcminute (1/3600th of a degree)
The apparent shift of \'nearby\' stars against the background of \'distant\' stars due to the Earth\'s motion around the Sun
The distance of an object with a parallax angle one arcsecond.

cards.term: What is the maximum distance that can be measured by parallax?
cards.definition: 100 parsecs

cards.term: What is the parallax angle of a star?
cards.definition: Half the angular shift observed in the apparent position of a nearby star from Earth over a period of six months. (using the largest shift in any six month period)

cards.term: What is d in the equation d = 1/p ?
cards.definition: Distance to a nearby star in parsecs.

cards.term: What is p in the equation d = 1/p ?
cards.definition: Parallax angle of a nearby star in arcseconds.
The apparent change in frequency of waves measured by an observer due to relative motion of the source and the observer.

cards.term: How is the red/blue shift of a galaxy measured?
cards.definition: The absorption spectrum of the galaxy is compared to those of elements observed on the Earth.
The shift towards shorter wavelengths of absorption lines of a galaxy moving towards the Earth.
The shift towards longer wavelengths of absorption lines of a galaxy moving away from the Earth.

cards.term: How is the velocity of a galaxy calculated from its red shift?
cards.definition: v = c x (\xce\x94f/f) OR (\xce\x94\xce\xbb/\xce\xbb)

cards.term: What observations did Hubble make about distant Galaxies?
cards.definition: Most galaxies are red shifted and that red shift tends to incease with distance.
The recessional speed of distant galaxies is approximately proportional to their distance from us
The idea that the universe is homogenous and isotropic on a large scale and that the laws of physics are the same everywhere in the Universe.

cards.term: What is meant by the homogeneous nature of the Universe.
cards.definition: The idea that matter (on a large scale) is distributed uniformly across the universe, which therfore has approximately constant density.

cards.term: What is meant by the isotropic nature of the Universe?
cards.definition: The idea that (on a large scale) the universe looks the same in all directions to every observer (there is no centre or edge to the Universe).
The leading theory to describe the origin of the Universe in which space and time expanded from a singularity approximately 13.7 billion years ago.

cards.term: What is Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation (CMBR)?
cards.definition: The largely uniform microwave radiation with the blackbody spectrum of an object at 2.7K detected in every direction in the sky.

cards.term: How does the the Big Bang theory explain the Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation (CMBR)?
cards.definition: When it was young the Universe was very hot and filled with short wavelength photons. These photons have been red shifted as space has expanded.

cards.term: How can Hubble constant be determined?
cards.definition: The gradient of the best-fit line for a plot of recessional speed (y-axis) vs distance (x-axis)

cards.term: How can the age of the Universe be estimated using the Hubble Constant?
cards.definition: age of the Universe = 1 / Hubble constant

cards.term: Approximately what percentage of the Universe is thought to be comprosed of normal matter?
Approximately what percentage of the Universe is thought to be composed of dark matter?
Approximately what percentage of the Universe is thought to be composed of dark energy?

cards.definition: A period very early on (10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xb5 - 10\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb3\xe2\x81\xb0s) in the evolution of the universe during which an unknown mechanism appears to have caused a very rapid expansion of the universe.

cards.term: What process leads to the conversion of radiation to matter in the early Universe?
cards.definition: The conversion of high energy photons into particle-antiparticle pairs (pair production).

cards.term: What was the composition of the early Universe after fusion ended at around 100s.
cards.definition: 75% Hydrogen, 25% Helium and trace amounts of lithium and berylllium.

cards.term: Why was light able to freely propagate in the Universe from around 380,000 years?
cards.definition: Nuclei captured electrons forming neutral atoms.
A hypothetical form of matter that doesn\'t emit or absorb light postulated to explain the difference between the expected and observed orbits of stars around the galactic centres.

cards.term: What evidence suggests the expansion of the Universe is accelerating?
cards.definition: Light from very distant type 1a supernova are less intense than predicted.
A hypothetical form of energy postulated to explain the apparent acceleration in the expansion of the Universe.
Moving charges and permanent magnets.

cards.term: What is shown by the direction of a magnetic field line?
cards.definition: The direction of force on a free north pole.

cards.term: Which direction do magnetic field lines flow in?
cards.definition: From north to south.

cards.term: How is a uniform magnetic field represented by field lines?
cards.definition: Parallel

cards.term: What does the spacing of magnetic field lines show?
cards.definition: Magnetic field strength/flux density.

cards.term: How do you find the direction of the field lines around a current?
cards.definition: Using the right hand grip rule.

cards.term: How is a field line or current running into the paper shown?
cards.definition: \xe2\x8a\x97

cards.term: How is a field line or current running out of the paper shown?
cards.definition: . in a circle

cards.term: Why does a current experience a force in a magnetic field?
cards.definition: The current\'s magnetic field interacts with the external one.

cards.term: What is represented by the thumb in Fleming\'s Left Hand rule.
cards.definition: (Direction of) force

cards.term: What is represented by the first finger in Fleming\'s Left Hand rule.
cards.definition: (Direction of the) magnetic field

cards.term: What is represented by the second finger in Fleming\'s LHR?
cards.definition: (Direction of) current

cards.term: When is Fleming\'s Left Hand Rule used?
cards.definition: To find the direction of a current/moving charge in a magnetic field.

cards.term: When is the equation F = BIL sin\xce\xb8 used?
cards.definition: To find the magnitude of force on a wire (carrying current) in a magnetic field.

cards.term: What is represented by \xce\xb8 in the equation F = BIL sin\xce\xb8?
cards.definition: The angle between the current and the field direction.

cards.term: What is the SI unit of flux density?
cards.definition: Tesla (T)

cards.term: How is a magnetic flux density defined?
cards.definition: The field strength that would cause a wire carrying a current of 1A perpendicular to the field to experience a force of 1N per m of length.

cards.term: What experiment can be done to find flux density in the lab?
cards.definition: Set up a current carrying wire between the poles of a magnet on top of a top-pan balance.

cards.term: When is the equation F = Bqv used?
cards.definition: To find the force acting on a particle moving (at right angles) to a magnetic field?

cards.term: When is the equation r = mv/BQ used?
cards.definition: To find the radius of the path of a particle moving in a uniform magnetic field.

cards.term: Why does a charged particle describe circular motion in a uniform magnetic field?
cards.definition: (There is a constant) force always acting at right angles to motion.

cards.term: Why do only particles with the correct velocity travel in a straight line in a velocity selector?
cards.definition: The electric force balance the magnetic force (at this velocity).
A definition of abnormality by Jahoda, whoproposed that the absence of 6 indicators of ideal mental health are a sign of "dysfunction". This is the way in which physical health is assessed.

- Positive self attitude- Self-actualisation- Autonomy- Resisting stress- Accurate perception of reality- Environmental mastery: abnormality is failure to meet criteria such as autonomy, resisting from stress, environmental mastery.

cards.term: Evaluation of the validity of the deviation from ideal mental health definition
cards.definition: It is subjective as it relies on self-report, unlike the measurement of physical health.It is over-demanding as at a given moment, most people would not meet all of the ideals.It is not cross culturally generalisable, as in collectivist cultures "autonomy" is not seen as a desirable trait to have.It is subject to change over time e.g. in the 13th century, seeing visions was seen as desirable (a sign of religious commitment).

Rosenhan and Seligman argued that a "dysfunctional" person is one whose behaviour suggests they can\'t cope with everyday life.This definition focuses on the individual\'s experience, and permits judgement by others via observable/measurable behaviour.E.g. the DSM definition of depression states that the symptoms must cause distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

cards.term: 7 features of failing to function adequately
cards.definition: - Personal distress, -Maladaptive behaviour, -Unpredictability, -Irrationality, -Observer discomfort,-Violation of moral standards & -Unconventionality.

cards.term: Evaluation of the validity of the failure to function adequately definition
cards.definition: It doesn\'t take into account times when it\'s normal to suffer distress e.g. mourning.It doesn\'t take into account how behaviour may not cause an individual distress, even though it may cause others discomfort.It doesn\'t take into account conditions where people maintain their success e.g. psychopaths, who can commit murder to lead successful lives (e.g. Dr Harold Shipman).It doesn\'t take into account the fact that some so called "dysfunctional" behaviour may actually be personally rewarding e.g. an eating disorder may bring with it affection and attention.

A definition of abnormality: abnormality is behaviour which violates the often unwritten rules for acceptable behaviour which society sets.Once identified, social deviants can then be helped.E.g. Antisocial personality disorder (psychopathy) is defined by the DSM as a "failure to conform to social norms with respect to lawful behaviours as indicated by repeatedly performing acts that are grounds for arrest".

cards.term: Evaluation of the validity of the deviation from social norms definition
cards.definition: It is subject to change over time e.g. homosexuality was classified as abnormal until relatively recently.It can label eccentric people as abnormal, even though their behaviour may cause no problems or, actually be beneficial e.g. the Suffragettes.It is subjective as it\'s based on the opinions of the elite, who can then use the label of "dysfunctional" to discriminate against people who don\'t conform.It may be affected by culture bias and therefore lead to discrimination of ethnic minorities as they don\'t conform to western norms: e.g. black people are diagnosed more often with schizophrenia than white/Asian people in the UK.

A person\'s behaviour is classified as dysfunctional if it is statistically unusual. This definition requires clarification of how rare behaviour needs to be before we class it as abnormal.E.g. as many traits in the population demonstrate a normal distribution curve, the 2% that are at either end of the curve could be considered "dysfunctional".This works on characteristics which can be quantified such as IQ- 96% of all people fall within 30 IQ points of the mean (100).

cards.term: Evaluation of the validity of the statistical infrequency definition
cards.definition: It doesn\'t take into account the desirability of behaviour, just its frequency e.g. having an IQ of 150 is rare, but highly desirable.There is no objectively defined cut off point when a behaviour becomes rare enough to be classified as "dysfunctional"- any decision will be arbitrary.Some disorders that are considered psychologically abnormal are quite common e.g. mild depression.Some disorders may appear rare in a culture simply because they are not reported due to the stigma surrounding it e.g. few mental illnesses are reported in India.

Irresistible and repetitive physical or mental actions that people feel compelled to carry out (compulsions). Time consuming nature of repeating actions leads to hindrance of performing everyday functions/conducting relationships.
Extreme anxiety/ guilt/ disgust caused by intrusive thoughts (obsessions).Sense of urgency to complete compulsion, followed by temporary relief, then distress
Recurrent and intrusive thoughts/ideas/images/impulses(obsessions). Selective attention towards source of obsessionRealisation of irrationality of thoughts/behaviour

OCD is inherited through genetic transmission. e.g. The COMT gene is associated with the production of dopamine. One variation of the COMT gene results in higher levels of dopamine and this variation is more common in patients with OCD vs. people without OCD.e.g. A second gene which has been implicated in OCD is the SERT gene which affects the transport of the serotonin, causing lower levels of serotonin which is associated with OCD.It is unlikely that single genes cause OCD, more that it is a combination of genes that determines an individuals level of vulnerability to develop the disorder.

cards.term: Twin study evidence for biological explanation of OCD.
cards.definition: Nestadt et al review: on average, if one of a pair of identical (MZ) twins had OCD, the other had a 68% of having it too. Non-identical twins have a lower "concordance" for OCD at 31%. As MZ twins share more genes than DZ twins (100% vs 50%), this supports that genetics are influential in the development of OCD.

cards.term: Gene mapping evidence for biological explanation of OCD.
cards.definition: Taylor: review of gene mapping studies to find the genes which OCD patients display more often than non-OCD controls. There are up to 230 such "candidate genes", particularly ones which control the action of neurotransmitters in the brain such as dopamine and serotonin. This suggests that there are multiple specific genes which are involved in the development of OCD.

cards.term: Evaluation of genetic explanation of OCD
cards.definition: X MZ concordance for OCD is not 100% = cause of OCD isn\'t solely genetic e.g. they may be some environmental influence too.X Some argue MZ twins are treated more similarly than DZ twins = could b an EV in twin study data e.g. it may be this rather than a higher proportion of shared genes which cause MZ concordance to be higher than DZ for OCD...X Evidence suggests that childhood OCD/ obsessions relating to contamination/ aggression & compulsions relating to washing/ ordering/ are more likely to be genetic than others = the influence of genes may vary depending on the age of onset and pattern of OCD symptoms demonstrated...

OCD may be caused by abnormalities in the brain. This may involve neuroanatomical (brain structure) abnormalities in the "worry circuit" of the brain. The orbitofrontal cortex converts sensory information into thoughts and actions. Damage to the caudate nucleus (which usually inhibits impulses from the OFC relating to environmental stimuli) may lead to hyperactivation of the OFC. This increases the conversion of sensory information to actions i.e. compulsions in OCD. Additionally, the brains of OCD patients may have higher levels of dopamine/ lower levels of serotonin.

cards.term: Evidence for neural explanation of OCD (neuroanatomical)
cards.definition: Saxena and Rauch: review of studies that used neuroimaging techniques e.g. PET and MRI. Across all studies, there was a consistent correlation between high levels of activity in the OFC and OCD symptoms. This is evidence that the caudate nucleus is damaged, with could otherwise regulate OFC activity.

cards.term: Evidence for neural explanation of OCD (neurochemical)
cards.definition: Antidepressant drugs which increase levels of serotonin in the brain have been found to be effective in treating the symptoms of OCD.This suggests that OCD is associated with low baseline levels of serotonin.

cards.term: Evaluation of neural explanation of OCD
cards.definition: X The evidence for the neural explanations is correlational = cause and effect cannot be established e.g. does abnormal neural activity cause OCD, or does OCD cause abnormal brain activity, or are the 2 related to an underlying 3rd variable?...X Not all sufferers of OCD respond well to serotonin enhancing drugs = not all P\'s OCD symptoms are related to low levels of serotonin...X Biological explanations don\'t take into account the person\'s environment =they are reductionist e.g. in some cases OCD is known to be a response to trauma..
SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors). A type of antidepressant e.g. fluoxetine. An alternative drug treatment is antipsychotic drugs which reduce dopamine levels in the brain.

SSRIs block the serotonin receptors on the pre-synaptic neurone which usually allow serotonin to be reabsorbed, so serotonin stays in the synapse longer, allowing it to stimulate the post-synaptic neurone for longer. SSRIs affect the neurones in the orbitofrontal cortex, causing the activity of this area to become closer to normal. They are usually taken for 12-16 weeks.

cards.term: Evidence for SHORT TERM effect of drug treatments for OCD
cards.definition: Soomro et al: reviewed 17 studies involving 3,097 adult patients comparing the effectiveness of drugs vs placebos. All studies showed SSRIs to be more effective than placebos up to 3 months after the treatment. This suggests that SSRIs can reduce the symptoms of OCD in the short term.

cards.term: Evidence for LONG TERM effect of drug treatments for OCD
cards.definition: Simpson et al:Up to 45% of patients treated with clomipramine (another SSRI) relapsed back into the disorder within 12 weeks of finishing the medication, compared to 12% of those who\'d been receiving psychological therapy. This suggests that SSRIs are merely a quick fix, and don\'t constitute a cure as effectiveness doesn\'t extend to the long term.

cards.term: Evaluation of drug therapy for OCD
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 Drugs are cost effective and non-disruptive = a practical treatment e.g. they are cheaper to prescribe than talking therapy, and can fit into Ps daily routine with ease.X Drugs can produce unpleasant side effects = the risk of non-adherence to treatment is increased because of their impact on wellbeing e.g. nausea, headaches, anxiety, blurred vision, loss of sex drive...IN ADDITION...X Most patients report improvement rather than cessation of symptoms = drugs are not a cure e.g. increasing serotonin may not be tackling the underlying cause of OCD...X Not all SSRIs are effective in treating all OCD patients- around 70% will improve significantly. = the underlying cause of all OCD patients\' symptoms cannot be reduced to low levels of serotonin...X There is controversy attached to the sponsorship by drug companies of research to support the use of drug treatments = evidence for drug treatments may be unreliable e.g. it could be the case that such companies suppress evidence that does not support the effectiveness of certain drugs to maximise their economic gain.
Reduced levels of energyIncreased or need for sleepIncrease/ decrease in appetite
SadnessLoss of pleasure in normal activities Irritability/ aggression
Low self-esteemAttending to/dwelling on negative aspects of a situationNegative beliefs about the selfPoor concentration/ memoryThoughts of death

cards.term: The cognitive approach to explaining depression
cards.definition: This approach focuses on people\'s beliefs rather than their behaviour. Depression results from systematic negative bias in thinking processes.

cards.term: Becks\' cognitive explanation (cognitive explanation of depression 2)
cards.definition: 3 factors create a \'cognitive vulnerability\' to depression:a) Negative Self-Schemas: Mental structures which help us organise/ interpret information relating to ourselves. This may lead to biased info. processing if a person\'s self-schema contains negative beliefs because of frequent experiences of criticism... b) Faulty Information Processing: A person will readily process info. which confirms negative beliefs, whilst ignoring evidence against them- e.g. "magnification and minimisation" (overestimating the extent of failure whilst underestimating success).c)The Cognitive Triad: Negative thoughts will be in relation to the self, world and future.

cards.term: Ellis\' ABC model (cognitive explanation of depression 1)
cards.definition: The cause of depression is way in which we process information:  Activating event \xe2\x86\x92 Beliefs \xe2\x86\x92 ConsequenceThe beliefs (B) we hold cause the emotional response (C) we have to events rather than the events themselves (A).

cards.term: Evidence for the cognitive explanation of depression
cards.definition: 1) Beck gave the dysfunctional attitude scale (DAS) to depressed and non-depressed people. Those with depression scored higher on the DAS, showing that they thought more negatively about events and situations than non-depressed people.However it is not clear from this study that negative thoughts CAUSED depression. In contrast...2) Alloy et al identified students as either "optimistic" or "hopeless" thinkers. They were interviewed regularly over 2\xc2\xbd years. 1% of O thinkers developed depression compared to 17% of the H thinkers,suggesting that negative thinking precedes the development of depression.

cards.term: Evaluation of the cognitive explanation of depression
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 Practical applications = knowledge of how depression develops can be used to help Ps change their behaviour e.g. by teaching them new thinking patterns using CBT...X Doesn\'t take biological factors into account = it is a reductionist theory e.g. particularly as it is known that drugs which increase serotonin levels also improve symptoms, suggesting depression is associated with low levels.X Much of the evidence for the explanation is correlational = impossible to establish a cause effect relationship e.g. do negative thoughts cause depression, or does depression lead to negative thinking?...X Client is blamed rather than the situation = ethical issues with the explanation e.g. failing to acknowledge that the P may have developed thought patterns which reflect negative life experiences...
Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), tackling the negative thoughts of depressed Ps in order to change their behaviour

Education phase: Involves teaching P about the link between thoughts and emotions.Behavioural activation: P is encouraged to do activities which they find enjoyable in order to improve mood.Cognitive factors are now addressed: the Ps beliefs about themselves are identified and challenged.Hypothesis testing: Ps are set HW tasks which will provide evidence against their faulty beliefs, therefore causing them to change.

cards.term: Evidence for the effectiveness of CBT vs no treatment for depression
cards.definition: Embling: 38 patients receiving 12 CBT sessions/ 2 months vs. control group. CBT mean depression score reduced over time (although Ps with certain traits e.g. perfectionism didn\'t improve) vs. control groups\' stayed the same, suggesting that except for a subset of Ps, CBT improves the condition of Ps.

cards.term: Evidence for the effectiveness of CBT vs drugs for depression
cards.definition: Hollon et al: Moderate to severely depressed Ps treated for 16 weeks with CBT , drugs or a placebo.Over the next 6 months 40% of CBT group relapsed vs. 45% of drug group vs 80% of placebo group suggesting that in contrast to drugs, CBT tackles the underlying cause of depression rather than merely masking symptoms.

cards.term: Evaluation of CBT to treat depression
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 CBT is relatively quick to administer = more practical than previous talking therapies e.g. psychoanalysis for depression takes years rather than 2 months to improve symptoms...X CBT is more effective with articulate, motivated Ps = its effectiveness may not generalise to all subgroups e.g. Ps need to be able to express themselves well and engage fully in the homework tasks...X CBT is more effective with skilled therapists. Th= administering CBT isn\'t guaranteed to lead to improvements e.g. if 2 therapists have received different training, the outcomes they achieve with patients may not be consistent... X CBT ignores the context of the P = may demotivate people to change their situation e.g. in some cases apparently "pessimistic" thought patterns may be realistic assessments of the P\'s impoverished/ abusive living circumstances.
Altering behaviour to avoid feared stimulus.Freezing in the presence of the feared stimulus.Attempts to escape from the feared stimulus.
Anxiety in anticipation of being in the presence of the feared stimulus.Anxiety in the presence of the feared stimulus.
Irrational beliefs about the stimulus.Difficulty concentrating due to preoccupation with irrational thoughts.Awareness that anxiety levels are out of proportion to the stimulus.

cards.term: The behavioural approach to explaining phobias
cards.definition: Phobias are learned through conditioning: the 2 process model.
The perception of phobias as acquired through classical conditioning, with their maintenance upheld through operant conditioning
When a naturally feared stimulus (UCS) becomes associated with a neutral stimulus, making the NS a conditioned stimulus producing fear (CR)

cards.term: Evidence for the role of classical conditioning in the acquisition of phobias
cards.definition: Watson & Rayner exposed Little Albert to a loud noise & a white rat at the same time. He consequently developed a phobia of rats & other white furry objects. This suggests phobias can be learned by C.C. if a previously NS becomes associated with a fear producing UCS. In this case the phobia is acquired because the rat became a CS for the CR of fear.
The reduction in fear from avoiding or escaping from a feared object/ situation acts as negative reinforcement, maintaining the phobia.

cards.term: Evidence for the role of operant conditioning in the maintenance of a phobia
cards.definition: DiGallo: It was found that around 20% of people who had experienced a traumatic car accident developed a phobia of travelling in cars, especially travelling at speed. Many then avoided making car journeys in future. This suggests that avoiding a CS leads to negative reinforcement of the escape behaviour by making fear subside, thus maintaining the fear.

cards.term: Evaluation of the behavioural explanation of phobias
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 Practical applications= knowledge of how phobias are acquired can be used to help Ps "unlearn" their fear response e.g. providing experiences to allow new associations to form with the CS/ preventing escape from the CS...X Conditioning isn\'t necessary to develop phobias = phobias occur without Ps having any bad experience with the CS e.g. DiNardo found only 60% relate their dog phobia to a traumatic experience...X Conditioning isn\'t sufficient to develop phobias = it is possible to have a bad experience with a stimulus without developing a phobia e.g. DiNardo found 60% of a non-phobic control group had also had a traumatic experience with a dog...X The behavioural explanation doesn\'t take into account evolutionary factors = it\'s a reductionist explanation e.g. humans appear to be predisposed to form fear associations with stimuli which posed a threat to survival in our evolutionary history such as snakes and spiders more readily than cars...
Systematic desensitisationFlooding

P has relaxation training.They construct an anxiety hierarchy.They experience gradual exposure to the anxiety hierarchy whilst practising relaxation, and only move on once the fear at that stage has subsided.

cards.term: Evidence for systematic desensitisation to treat phobias
cards.definition: Jones used SD to eradicate "Little Peter\'s" phobia of white fluffy objects. The 3 year old boy was first presented to a rabbit in a cage as he ate his lunch in his play pen, and built up from there. After 40 sessions he would stroke the rabbit and other, similar white fluffy objects. This suggests that that S.D is an appropriate treatment to use to extinguish the fear response in childhood phobias.
P has direct full exposure to the feared stimulus.They are prevented from escaping until they are calm and fear is extinguished.

cards.term: Evidence for flooding to treat phobias
cards.definition: Wolpe forced his female patient into a car and drove her around for 4 hours until her hysteria at being in the car was eradicated. This removed the girl\'s phobia of being in cars. This suggests that flooding can successfully eradicate a phobia preventing reinforcing escape behaviour.

cards.term: Evaluation for the behavioural approach in treating phobias
