1. Transcription
2. Translation
The formation of mRNA from a DNA template.

1. DNA double helix unwinds.
2. RNA polymerase binds to a specific base sequence of non-coding DNA in front of a gene and moves along the DNA strand.
3. RNA polymerase joins free RNA nucleotides to complementary bases on the coding DNA strand.
4. mRNA formation complete. mRNA detaches and leaves the nucleus.
A ribosome joins amino acids in a specific order dictated by mRNA to form a protein.

1. mRNA attaches to a ribosome.
2. Ribosome reads the mRNA bases in triplets. Each triplet codes for one amino acid which is brought to the ribosome by a tRNA molecule (carrier molecule).
3. A polypeptide chain is formed from the sequence of amino acids which join together.

A random change in the base sequence of DNA which results mostly in no change to the protein coded for, or genetic variants of the protein (slight alteration but appearance and function remain). Mutations occur continuously.

cards.term: Effect of a gene mutation in coding DNA
cards.definition: If a mutation changes the amino acid sequence, protein structure and function may change (an enzyme may no longer fit its substrate binding site or a structural protein may lose its strength). If a mutation does not change the amino acid sequence, there is no effect on protein structure or function.
DNA which does not code for a protein but instead controls gene expression.

cards.term: Effect of a gene mutation in non-coding DNA
cards.definition: Gene expression may be altered, affecting protein production and the resulting phenotype.
Different versions of the same gene.

1. Chromosome pairs line up along the cell equator.
2. The pair of chromosomes are pulled apart so one chromosome is in each cell.

1. Chromosomes line up again in each cell.
2. Arms of the chromosomes are pulled apart.

cards.term: Importance of the random alignment of chromosomes during meiosis
cards.definition: Genetic variation increases as the chromosomes from each parent are randomly assorted into gametes.

cards.term: Structure of DNA in a chromosome
cards.definition: Long double helix strands are wound around proteins called histones. The histones and DNA wind around each other to form chromatin.
Two identical strands formed by the replication of a chromosome during interphase.

cards.term: Formation of a homologous pair of chromosomes
cards.definition: One chromosome is from the mother and one from the father, and they have the same genes at the same loci but can have different alleles of those genes.
They carry the same genes but potentially different alleles so can cause variation in the offspring.
The process by which a parent cell divides into two or more daughter cells.

cards.term: Levels of organisation in an ecosystem
cards.definition: Individual, population, community, ecosystem.
The interaction between the living components and non-living components.

cards.term: Reason light intensity affects an ecosystem
cards.definition: Different species of plants may have different optimum light intensities for growth.
Different species of plants and animals may have different optimum temperatures for growth and survival.

cards.term: Effect of soil pH on an ecosystem
cards.definition: Certain plants may grow better in either alkaline or acidic soil. Soil pH may affect the appearance of the plant, e.g., color of hydrangea.

cards.term: Effect of moisture level on an ecosystem
cards.definition: Many plants cannot survive in waterlogged soil as their roots cannot respire. Certain plants are adapted to high moisture levels.

cards.term: Effect of wind intensity on an ecosystem
cards.definition: Plant seeds are more likely to germinate in locations with lower wind intensity, which may also attract animals that depend on the plant to live nearby.

cards.term: Effect of soil mineral content on an ecosystem
cards.definition: Most plants require a high level of soil minerals to grow well.

cards.term: Example of plants adapted to low soil mineral content
cards.definition: Carnivorous plants catch insects to compensate for the low level of soil mineral content.

cards.term: Effect of carbon dioxide concentration on an ecosystem
cards.definition: Higher carbon dioxide concentration leads to more plant growth.

cards.term: Effect of oxygen concentration on an ecosystem
cards.definition: Aquatic animals cannot survive in areas with low oxygen concentration.
Food, New predators, New pathogens, Competition.

cards.term: Factors that plants may compete for
cards.definition: Light, Space, Water, Mineral ions from soil.
Features that enable organisms to survive in their living environment.
Extremophiles.
High temperature, High pressure, High salt concentration.

cards.term: Example of where extremophile bacteria can be found
cards.definition: In deep sea vents.

cards.term: Factors that animals might compete for
cards.definition: Food, Mates, Territory.
Competition within a species.
Competition between different species.
Different species in an ecosystem depend on each other for various resources; if one species is removed, the whole community may be affected.
A community in which all the biotic factors (the different species) and all abiotic factors are balanced so that population sizes remain relatively constant.
Non-living factors.

cards.term: Abiotic factors that may affect an ecosystem
cards.definition: Light intensity, Temperature, Moisture, Soil pH and mineral content, Wind intensity and direction, Carbon dioxide level, Oxygen level.
A species that occupies the same habitat.
The place in which an organism lives.

cards.term: Types of organisms that are primary producers
cards.definition: Photosynthetic organisms like green plants and algae that trap energy from the sun.
An organism that feeds on producers.
An organism that feeds on primary consumers.
An organism that feeds on secondary consumers.
A consumer that kills and eats other animals.
An animal that is killed and eaten by another animal.

cards.term: Pattern of predators and prey in a stable community
cards.definition: The numbers of predators and prey rise and fall in cycles.

cards.term: Reason producers are the first trophic level
cards.definition: Producers provide all biomass for the food chain (production of glucose via photosynthesis). The rest of the food chain involves the transfer of this biomass.

cards.term: Apparatus used to measure the abundance and distribution of organisms in an area
cards.definition: Quadrat.

cards.term: Apparatus used to study the distribution of organisms across a gradient
cards.definition: Belt transect.
Populations of different species interacting.
The average number of organisms.
Sum of each number of each organism divided by the total number of each type of organism.
The most populous organism.
The organism that represents the middle value when the numbers of each organism are arranged from lowest to highest.

cards.term: How materials cycle through living and non-living components of an ecosystem
cards.definition: Organisms take in elements from their surroundings e.g. soil, air. Elements are converted to complex molecules which become biomass. Elements are transferred along food chains. Elements are returned to the environment during excretion and decomposition of dead organisms.
Oxygen, carbon dioxide, and water.

Plants fix carbon dioxide into organic molecules during photosynthesis. The organic carbon-containing molecules are passed onto organisms that eat the plants. Carbon dioxide is released back into the atmosphere by respiration from animals and plants. Burning fossil fuels also releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
Carbon-containing molecules such as glucose are important for living organisms to grow and provide energy for vital functions within cells.

Water from lakes and oceans evaporates. The evaporated water condenses into clouds and returns to earth as precipitation. The water from precipitation is useful for life on land. The water then returns to rivers and oceans through surface runoff.
Living organisms require water, and the water cycle provides organisms on land with a continuous supply of water.
The interactions between the biotic and abiotic factors in an area.

cards.term: Importance of microorganisms for cycling materials through an ecosystem
cards.definition: Microorganisms (bacteria and fungi) return carbon to the environment by releasing carbon dioxide through respiration while they decompose dead matter. The decomposition of dead matter in soil returns mineral ions to the environment for other organisms to use e.g. plants use mineral ions for growth.
The breakdown of dead materials into simpler organic matter.

cards.term: How decomposers break down dead matter (biology only)
cards.definition: Decomposers release enzymes which catalyze the breakdown of dead material into smaller molecules.
Aerobic decomposition (with oxygen), Anaerobic decomposition (without oxygen).

cards.term: Factors affecting the rate of decomposition (biology only)
cards.definition: Oxygen availability, Temperature, Water content.

cards.term: Importance of oxygen for decomposition (biology only)
cards.definition: Most decomposers require oxygen for aerobic respiration.

cards.term: Effect of oxygen availability on the rate of decomposition (biology only)
cards.definition: As oxygen levels increase, the rate of decomposition increases. As oxygen levels decrease, the rate of decomposition decreases.

cards.term: Why decomposition can occur in the absence of oxygen (biology only)
cards.definition: Some decomposers respire anaerobically. However, the rate of decomposition is slower as anaerobic respiration produces less energy.

cards.term: Effect of soil water content on the rate of decomposition (biology only)
cards.definition: Decomposers require water to survive. In moist conditions, the rate of decomposition is high. In waterlogged soils, there is little oxygen for respiration, so the rate of decomposition decreases.
Water is required for the secretion of enzymes and absorption of dissolved molecules.
Food chains show the feeding relationships of different organisms and the flow of energy between the organisms.

cards.term: Effect of temperature on the rate of decomposition (biology only)
cards.definition: Decomposers release enzymes: Rate is highest at 50C (optimum temperature for enzymes). Lower temperatures result in slower enzyme activity, decreasing the rate. High temperatures cause enzymes to denature, stopping decomposition.

cards.term: Calculation of rate of change for decay of biological material (biology only)
cards.definition: Rate of change = Change in value / Change in time, where value is a measurable variable associated with the decay of the material.
The nutrient-rich product of the rapid decay of waste biological material (dead plants and animal waste) in optimum conditions set by gardeners and farmers.
Used as natural fertilizer to promote growth of crops or garden plants.
Biogas generators provide methane gas for fuel through anaerobic decomposition that occurs in animal waste.

cards.term: How environmental conditions affect communities (biology only)
cards.definition: Environmental conditions e.g. temperature, soil pH, light intensity affect the abundance and distribution of organisms within communities. For example, rising global temperatures have been linked to the extinction of frog species (their thin skin makes them more vulnerable to temperature changes).

If the temperature is too low, growth will be slower as organisms will use more energy to stay warm. If the temperature is too high, organisms can die, and water will become limited as evaporation increases.

cards.term: Effect of changes in water levels on ecosystems
cards.definition: Animals may have to migrate to find water. Melting ice caps may destroy the habitats of some animals (either animals living in icy regions or by sea level rise).

cards.term: Effect of atmospheric gases on ecosystems
cards.definition: Some organisms cannot survive when certain gases are present. Polluted water can cause illness to animals that drink it.

cards.term: Detrimental impacts of sulfur dioxide on the environment
cards.definition: Formed when fossil fuels containing impurities are burnt. Sulfur dioxide can dissolve in water to form acid rain which can erode buildings and pollute water sources.
The total mass of living material.

cards.term: Detrimental impacts of carbon monoxide on the environment
cards.definition: Carbon monoxide is formed from the incomplete combustion of fossil fuels. It binds irreversibly to hemoglobin which prevents it from carrying oxygen. Too much exposure can cause unconsciousness and death.
Water vapor, Carbon dioxide, Nitrous oxide, Methane, CFCs.

cards.term: Human activities contributing to greenhouse gases
cards.definition: Burning fossil fuels, Deforestation, Large-scale livestock farming.

cards.term: How greenhouse gases lead to global warming
cards.definition: Greenhouse gases allow heat from the sun to enter the atmosphere. The gases act as a blanket and trap the heat in the atmosphere.
Sea level rise caused by melting icebergs, Disrupted farming and agriculture, Increased spread of diseases in warmer climates, Extinction of species.
The stages in a food chain.
The direction of biomass transfer.
producer  primary consumer  secondary consumer  tertiary consumer.
An organism that makes its own food.
The variety of the different species on earth or within an ecosystem.
To maintain the stability of an ecosystem.

cards.term: Reasons for destruction of peat bogs
cards.definition: To produce compost to increase food production.

cards.term: Contribution of peat bogs to the greenhouse effect
cards.definition: Peat bogs are stores of carbon (carbon sinks), and burning them releases a large volume of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
To provide land for cattle or rice fields, To grow crops to produce biofuels.
Greenhouse gases trap energy from the Sun as heat in the atmosphere, keeping the temperature on earth suitable for life.
The increase in levels of greenhouse gases e.g. carbon dioxide and methane, causing the temperature on earth to increase.
Destruction of many animals habitats, Releases large amounts of greenhouse gases.
Rising sea levels, Melting polar ice caps, Changing weather patterns, Migration of animals to find suitable habitats, Tropical diseases becoming more common, Extinction of species.

Breeding programs for endangered species, Protection and rebuilding habitats, Replanting field margins and hedgerows, Reduce deforestation, Reduce carbon dioxide emissions, Recycling rather than disposing in landfills.

cards.term: Purpose of replanting hedgerows and field margins
cards.definition: There is higher biodiversity in the margins than the fields that they surround.

cards.term: How biodiversity ensures the stability of an ecosystem
cards.definition: It reduces the dependence on particular species for resources e.g. food and shelter, so that even if one species is removed other species can still survive.

cards.term: Reasons for increased human consumption of resources and waste production
cards.definition: Rapid rise in human population, Increase in standard of living.
Air, Land, Water.
Sewage, Fertilizer, Chemicals.

Fertilizer from farms pollutes the water, causing excessive algae growth, depleting the oxygen in the water, causing other plants and animals to die. Dead plants are decomposed by bacteria and the oxygen level decreases further.
Smoke, Acidic gases.
Landfill waste, Chemicals.

cards.term: Human activities reducing land available for animals and plants
cards.definition: Building, Farming, Quarrying, Disposing of waste.
It describes the feeding relationships between organisms and the resultant stages of biomass transfer.
The stages in a food chain

cards.term: Reason for using dry mass in biomass
cards.definition: Because the wet mass varies as the volume of water in the organism varies.
Efficiency = (energy transferred / total energy available) x 100.

cards.term: Percentage of light energy for photosynthesis transferred by producers
Percentage of biomass transferred between trophic levels
cards.definition: Approximately 10%

Energy is lost through: Egestion (removal of faeces), Excretion (removal of waste products e.g. urine containing urea and water), Respiration (loss of carbon dioxide and water) in which large amounts of glucose are used, The production of inedible bones and shells.

cards.term: Effect of biomass transfer efficiency on trophic levels
cards.definition: The less efficient the transfers, the fewer trophic levels and the fewer organisms in higher trophic levels.
A pyramid that shows the total dry mass of organisms at each trophic level Trophic level 1 is at the bottom of the pyramid
A pyramid of numbers shows the number of organisms at each trophic level

cards.term: Producer in a pyramid of biomass
cards.definition: D is the producer

cards.term: Explanation for a pyramid of numbers not being pyramid-shaped
cards.definition: Pyramids of numbers don't take size and mass of organisms into account.
Trophic levels are represented by numbers, starting from 1. After 1, trophic levels are numbered according to how far along the organism is in the food chain.
Efficiency = (energy transferred / total energy available) x 100. Total energy available = 800 kJ + 4000 kJ = 4800 kJ Energy transferred = 800 kJ 800/4800 x 100 = 16.67%
Plants and algae which make their own food (through photosynthesis) - called producers.
Herbivores which eat producers - called primary consumers.
Carnivores that eat herbivores - called secondary consumers.
Carnivores that eat other carnivores - called tertiary consumers.
A cell type found in animals and plants that contains a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles.
A cell type that does not contain a nucleus or membrane-bound organelles.

cards.term: Components of plant and animal cells
cards.definition: Nucleus, Cytoplasm, Cell membrane, Mitochondria, Ribosomes.

cards.term: Genetic information storage in eukaryotic cell
cards.definition: Within the nucleus, arranged in chromosomes.
Controls cellular activities.
Fluid component of the cell containing organelles, enzymes, dissolved ions, and nutrients.
Site of cellular reactions, such as the first stage of respiration.
Controls the entry and exit of materials into and out of the cell.
Site of later stages of aerobic respiration in which ATP is produced.
Joins amino acids in a specific order during translation.

cards.term: Organelles found in plant cells only
cards.definition: Large, permanent vacuole, Cell wall, Chloroplasts.
Made of cellulose.
Provides strength and prevents the cell from bursting when water enters by osmosis.
A solution of salts, sugars, and organic acids.
Supports the cell, maintaining its turgidity.
Site of photosynthesis.

cards.term: Reason for chloroplasts appearing green under a light microscope
cards.definition: Contain chlorophyll, a green pigment.
Chromosomal DNA, Plasmid DNA, Cell wall, Cell membrane, Ribosomes, Flagella.

cards.term: Genetic information storage in prokaryotic cell
cards.definition: Found free within the cytoplasm as chromosomal DNA (single large loop of circular DNA) and plasmid DNA.
Small, circular loops of DNA found free in the cytoplasm and separate from the main DNA. They carry genes that provide genetic advantages, e.g., antibiotic resistance.

cards.term: Composition of the prokaryotic cell wall
cards.definition: Peptidoglycan.
Long, rotating, whip-like protrusion that enables bacteria to move.
A cell that contains a single copy of each chromosome, half the number of chromosomes, e.g., 23 chromosomes in humans.
A cell that contains two copies of each chromosome, a full set of chromosomes, e.g., 46 chromosomes in humans.
Reproductive cells, e.g., egg and sperm cells, which are haploid cells.

cards.term: Sexual reproduction in terms of chromosome number
cards.definition: Two haploid gametes fuse, resulting in an embryo with two chromosomes for each gene and two copies of each allele, making it diploid.

Haploid nucleus contains genetic material, mitochondria in cytoplasm produce energy for the developing embryo, cytoplasm contains nutrients for the developing embryo, and the cell membrane hardens after fertilization, preventing the entry of other sperm and ensuring the zygote is diploid.
Haploid nucleus contains genetic information, tail enables movement, mitochondria provide energy for tail movement, and acrosome contains enzymes that digest the egg cell membrane.
Found lining the surface of structures such as the respiratory tract and uterus.

cards.term: Function of ciliated epithelial cells in airways
cards.definition: Move in synchronised waves to beat mucus (containing dirt and pathogens) up to the back of the throat where it can be swallowed.
The number of times bigger an image appears compared to the size of the specimen.
Total magnification = eyepiece lens magnification  objective lens magnification.
Magnification = size of image / size of specimen.
The smallest distance between two objects that can be distinguished.
Passes a beam of light through a specimen which travels through the eyepiece lens, allowing the specimen to be observed.
Inexpensive, easy to use, portable, and can observe both dead and living specimens.
Limited resolution.
It uses a beam of electrons which are focused using magnets. The electrons hit a fluorescent screen which emits visible light, producing an image.
Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM).
Greater magnification and resolution.

cards.term: Reason for greater magnification and resolution in electron microscopes
cards.definition: They use a beam of electrons which has a shorter wavelength than photons of light.

cards.term: Contribution of electron microscopes to cell understanding
cards.definition: Allows small sub-cellular structures (e.g., mitochondria, ribosomes) to be observed in detail and enables scientists to develop more accurate explanations about how cell structure relates to function.
Expensive, large so less portable, require training to use, and only dead specimens can be observed.
Biological catalysts that increase the rate of a chemical reaction without being permanently altered themselves.

cards.term: Advantage of enzymes in the body
cards.definition: They enable cellular reactions to take place at lower temperatures.
The region of an enzyme to which a substrate molecule binds and where the reaction takes place.

cards.term: Specificity of enzymes for their substrate
cards.definition: Only substrates with a specific, complementary shape can fit into an enzyme's active site.

cards.term: Lock and key model of enzyme action
cards.definition: Substrate collides with the active site of an enzyme, substrate binds, enzyme-substrate complex forms, substrate converted to products, products released from the active site which is now free to bind to another substrate.

cards.term: Factors affecting rate of enzyme-controlled reactions
cards.definition: Temperature, pH, substrate concentration.

cards.term: Effect of increasing temperature initially on enzyme-controlled reaction rate
cards.definition: As temperature increases, molecules have more kinetic energy, movement of molecules increases, probability of a successful collision increases, more enzyme-substrate complexes form, and the rate of reaction increases.

cards.term: Effect of increasing temperature above the optimum on enzyme-controlled reaction rate
cards.definition: Temperature increases above the optimum, increased vibrations break bonds in the enzyme's structure, active site changes shape, enzyme is denatured, no more enzyme-substrate complexes can form, and the rate of reaction decreases.

cards.term: Effect of pH on enzyme-controlled reaction rate
cards.definition: Enzymes have an optimum pH, deviation from the optimum alters bonds in the enzyme's structure, active site changes shape, enzyme is denatured, and the rate of reaction decreases.

cards.term: Effect of substrate concentration on enzyme-controlled reaction rate
cards.definition: Substrate concentration increases, number of substrate molecules in the same volume increases, probability of a successful collision increases, more enzyme-substrate complexes form, and the rate of reaction increases. Once all active sites become full, the rate of reaction plateaus.

cards.term: Calculation of enzyme-controlled reaction rate from given time
cards.definition: Rate = amount of product formed / time.
Seconds to the power of -1.

cards.term: Reason for breaking down large organic molecules in the body
cards.definition: Large molecules are too big to be absorbed across the surface of the gut wall, so they are broken down into smaller molecules for absorption into the bloodstream.

cards.term: Example of breakdown of large molecules in plants
cards.definition: Starch is broken down by enzymes into simpler sugars which are respired to release energy.

cards.term: Type of molecules proteins and carbohydrates are
cards.definition: Polymers.
Simple sugars.

cards.term: Group of enzymes catalyzing the breakdown of carbohydrates
cards.definition: Carbohydrases.

cards.term: Type of carbohydrase catalyzing the breakdown of starch
cards.definition: Amylase.
Amino acids.

cards.term: Type of enzyme catalyzing the breakdown of proteins
cards.definition: Proteases.
Enzymes which catalyze the breakdown of lipids into fatty acids and glycerol.

cards.term: Reason for synthesizing small molecules into larger organic molecules in the body
cards.definition: Large molecules are used for storage (e.g., glycogen) or are used to build structures (e.g., organelles).

cards.term: Enzyme catalyzing the formation of glycogen from glucose
cards.definition: Glycogen synthase.

cards.term: Measurement of energy contained in food
cards.definition: Measured using calorimetry.
A method of measuring the heat transfer during a chemical reaction.

cards.term: Method to measure the amount of energy in a food sample
cards.definition: Add a set volume of water to a boiling tube, record initial temperature. Record the mass of a small sample of food (e.g., bean). Stick the sample onto a mounted needle. Using a Bunsen burner, light the food sample. Hold the sample under the boiling tube until it burns up. Record the maximum temperature reached by the water. Record the final mass of the food sample.

cards.term: Calculation of energy in the food sample
cards.definition: Energy (J/g) = mass of food burnt (g)  temperature change (C)  4.2.
The net movement of molecules from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration down a concentration gradient.

cards.term: Molecules entering and leaving cells via simple diffusion
cards.definition: Small molecules such as oxygen, water, glucose, and amino acids.

cards.term: Factors affecting the rate of diffusion
cards.definition: Temperature, concentration gradient, surface area of cell membrane.
The net movement of water molecules from an area of high water concentration to an area of low water concentration through a partially permeable membrane.
The movement of molecules across a cell membrane from an area of low concentration to an area of high concentration, against the concentration gradient, using energy.

cards.term: Calculation of percentage change in mass
cards.definition: (final mass - initial mass) / initial mass  100.
A series of events that take place in a cell involving cell growth, DNA replication and cell division. It is described as the lifecycle of a cell.

cards.term: State the three stages of the cell cycle
cards.definition:
Stage 1 - interphase
Stage 2 - mitosis
Stage 3 - cytokinesis
The longest stage of the cell cycle that involves cell growth, the synthesis of new organelles and DNA replication.
Double helix 'unzips' exposing two strands. DNA bases align next to complementary bases on the DNA strands. Complementary base pairs join. Two identical DNA molecules formed.
A linear DNA molecule tightly coiled around proteins.
A form of cell division that produces two diploid 'daughter' cells, both genetically identical to the parent cell.

cards.term: Why is mitosis important in organisms?
cards.definition: Asexual reproduction. Growth. Repair of damaged cells. Cell replacement.

cards.term: State the four stages of mitosis
cards.definition: Prophase. Metaphase. Anaphase. Telophase.
DNA condenses, chromosomes become visible. Nuclear membrane disappears.
Chromosomes line up along the cell equator.
Spindle fibres attach to each chromosome. 'Arms' of each chromosome pulled to opposite poles. Chromatids separated.
Nucleus of the cell divides. New membrane forms around each set of chromosomes.
Division of the cell membrane and cytoplasm. Two genetically identical 'daughter' cells produced.

cards.term: A cell divides by mitosis once every 2 minutes. Calculate the number of identical cells present after 10 minutes.
cards.definition: 10  2 = 5. 5 cell divisions have taken place. 2^5 = 32 cells.
Non-communicable disease. Uncontrolled cell division (due to damaged DNA) results in the formation of a primary tumour. Tumour cells break off and spread to other tissues forming secondary tumours.
A chart used to monitor growth. Measurements (e.g. fetal length or head circumference) can be compared to the expected values at a certain age.
95% of measurements will be below the value of the 95th percentile.

cards.term: What can doctors determine from percentile charts?
cards.definition: Slower growth than normal (below the bottom line). Faster growth than normal (above the top line). Abnormal growth (irregular growth patterns).

Cell division occurs in all body cells. It occurs at a slower rate in adults that in younger animals as growth stops and cell division is only required for replacement and repair. Most cells differentiate at an early stage and become specialised. Some adult stem cells retain their ability to differentiate.

Cell division can only occur in meristematic tissue. The rate of cell division remains the same throughout a plant's life. Meristematic stem cells can differentiate into any cell type for as long as the plant lives. Cell elongation occurs in all cells. Cells expand and enlarge enabling growth of the plant.
Cells that are unspecialised and capable of differentiating into a range of different cell types.
The process by which stem cells become specialised (have a specific function). Some genes switch on or off, determining cell type.
It enables the formation of specialised tissues with specific functions e.g. muscle tissue.
Stem cells found in very early embryos that are unspecialised and capable of differentiating into any cell type.

cards.term: What is the function of embryonic stem cells?
cards.definition: Enable the growth and development of tissues in human embryos.
Stem cells that can differentiate into a limited range of cell types e.g. bone marrow stem cells.

cards.term: What is the primary function of adult stem cells?
cards.definition: Replacement of dead cells e.g. replacement of red blood cells which only live for 120 days.

cards.term: Where are stem cells found in plants?
cards.definition: Meristems.
In regions of the plant where cells are continuously dividing e.g. root tips, shoot tips.
Stem cells found in meristems that are unspecialised and capable of differentiating into any cell type during the life of a plant.

cards.term: How can stem cells be used in medicine?
cards.definition: Stem cells collected. Stem cells stimulated to differentiate into specific cell types e.g. heart muscle cells. Specialised cells transplanted into the patient. Used to treat damage or disease e.g. heart disease.

cards.term: Where can embryonic stem cells be collected from?
cards.definition: Donor stem cells removed from embryos grown in vitro. Patient's own stem cells removed from the umbilical blood before birth.

cards.term: What are the benefits of using stem cells in medicine?
cards.definition: Treat damage or disease e.g. heart disease, type 1 diabetes. Treat diseases that would otherwise be untreatable. Used in scientific research. Growing organs for transplants.

cards.term: What are the risks of stem cell use in medicine?
cards.definition: Transplanted stem cells could cause tumours. Finding suitable stem cell donors is a difficult task. Stem cells may be rejected by the body (immunosuppressants taken). Potential side effects. Long term risks of using stem cells unknown. Stem cells may become contaminated during preparation and when transplanted transmit infections to the patient, making them sicker.

cards.term: What are the ethical issues related to the use of stem cells in medicine?
cards.definition: The embryos that were used to provide stem cells are destroyed which is seen as unethical and a waste of potential human life. May lead to the reproductive cloning of humans.

cards.term: What is the central nervous system?
cards.definition: Brain and spinal cord.

cards.term: What is the spinal cord? (biology only)
cards.definition: A long, thin structure composed of neurones that extends from the medulla oblongata down the spine.

cards.term: What is the function of the spinal cord? (biology only)
cards.definition: Connects the peripheral nervous system (nerves outside of the CNS) to the brain.

cards.term: Describe the structure of the brain (biology only)
cards.definition: Consists of three main regions: Cerebrum, Cerebellum, Medulla oblongata.

cards.term: Describe the structure of the cerebrum (biology only)
cards.definition: Largest region of the brain. Divided into two hemispheres.

cards.term: What is the function of the cerebrum? (biology only)
cards.definition: Involved in: Intelligence, Language, Memory, Emotion, Visual and sensory processes.

cards.term: What is the function of each cerebral hemisphere? (biology only)
cards.definition: Left hemisphere receives sensory information from the right side of the body and controls muscle coordination on the right. Right hemisphere receives sensory information from the left side of the body and controls muscle coordination on the left.

cards.term: Where is the cerebellum located? (biology only)
cards.definition: Lower region of the brain.

cards.term: What is the function of the cerebellum? (biology only)
cards.definition: Involved in: Coordination of muscles, Voluntary movement e.g. walking, Non-voluntary movement e.g. balance.

cards.term: What is the function of the medulla oblongata? (biology only)
cards.definition: Controls automatic processes in the body e.g. breathing rate, heart rate, peristalsis.

cards.term: What methods, other than surgery, are used by doctors to observe the brain? (biology only/higher)
cards.definition: CT scan, PET scan.

cards.term: What is a CT scan? (biology only/higher)
cards.definition: A procedure that uses X-rays to produce 3D cross-sectional images of the brain.

cards.term: Describe how CT scans are useful to investigate brain function (biology only/higher)
cards.definition: CT scans show damaged regions of the brain e.g. areas of swelling, bleeding. Observations of the patient's symptoms can enable scientists to determine the function of the damaged region.

cards.term: What does a PET scan involve? (biology only/higher)
cards.definition: Radioactive substance injected into a patients bloodstream and taken up by tissues in the brain. Radiation emitted by tissues detected, enabling the identification of active and inactive regions of the brain.

cards.term: Describe how PET scans are useful to investigate brain function (biology only/higher)
cards.definition: Show which areas of the brain are active and which areas are not. Comparisons of brain activity in healthy patients and patients with brain damage allow scientists to determine the functions of inactive regions.

cards.term: Why is it difficult to treat damage to the CNS? (biology only/higher)
cards.definition: Damage to neurones is permanent and cannot be repaired (as nerve cells dont divide by mitosis). Hard to reach some areas of the brain. Risk of further permanent damage to other areas of the CNS during surgery.

cards.term: What is the function of the nervous system?
cards.definition: Allows an organism to rapidly react to environmental and internal changes.
Nerve cells adapted to quickly transmit nerve impulses. They are the functional units of the nervous system.

cards.term: What is the function of the axon?
cards.definition: Carries impulses away from the cell body. Enables the transmission of nerve impulses over long distances.

cards.term: What is the function of the dendrites and dendrons?
cards.definition: Carry impulses towards the cell body. Dendrites provide a large surface area to receive impulses.

cards.term: What is the role of the myelin sheath?
cards.definition: Electrically insulating layer. Surrounds the axon and increases the speed of impulses.

cards.term: Outline the function of a sensory neurone
cards.definition: Carries impulses from receptors to the central nervous system.

cards.term: Describe the structure of a sensory neurone
cards.definition: Long dendron carries impulses from receptors to the cell body. Cell body found part way along the neurone. Short axon carries impulses from the cell body to the CNS.

cards.term: Outline the function of a motor neurone
cards.definition: Carries impulses from the central nervous system to effectors.

cards.term: Describe the structure of a motor neurone
cards.definition: Short dendrites carry impulses from the CNS to the cell body. Cell body found at one end of the neurone. Long axon carries impulses from the cell body to the effectors.

cards.term: Outline the function of a relay neurone
cards.definition: Carries impulses from sensory neurones to motor neurones within the central nervous system.

cards.term: Describe the structure of a relay neurone
cards.definition: Short dendrites carry impulses from sensory neurones to the cell body. Short axon carries impulses from the cell body to motor neurones.

cards.term: Describe how the central nervous system coordinates a response to a stimulus
cards.definition: Stimulus  Sensory receptor detects stimulus  Sensory receptor sends impulses along sensory neurone to CNS  CNS coordinates response  CNS sends information to effector along motor neurone  Effector produces a response to the stimulus.
A small gap between neurones across which a nerve impulse is transmitted via neurotransmitters.

cards.term: How are nerve impulses transmitted across a synapse?
cards.definition: Nerve impulse reaches presynaptic neurone. This triggers the release of neurotransmitters. Neurotransmitters diffuse across the synapse. They bind to receptors on the postsynaptic neurone. This stimulates an impulse in the postsynaptic neurone.

cards.term: Why do synapses slow down the transmission of nerve impulses?
cards.definition: It takes time for the neurotransmitters to diffuse across the synapse and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic neurone.

Automatic response to a stimulus by the body. Involuntary - does not involve conscious part of the brain. Protective mechanism e.g. a withdrawal reflex is initiated when a hot object is touched to prevent burns.
Stimulus  Sensory receptor  Sensory neurone  Relay neurone  Motor neurone  Effector  Response

cards.term: Outline the structure and function of the cornea
cards.definition: Transparent outer covering of the eye. Refracts light entering the eye.

cards.term: Outline the structure and function of the iris
cards.definition: Pigmented ring of circular muscles and radial muscles. Controls the size of the pupil to alter how much light enters the eye.
A hole in the iris center that allows light rays to enter the eye.

cards.term: Outline the structure and function of the lens
cards.definition: Transparent, bi-convex structure. Suspensory ligaments attach the lens to a ring of ciliary muscle. Refracts light, focusing it onto the retina.

cards.term: What is the function of the ciliary muscles and suspensory ligaments?
cards.definition: Change the shape of the lens (accommodation) to focus light onto the retina.

cards.term: Outline the structure and function of the retina
cards.definition: Light-sensitive layer composed of rod and cone cells. Converts light energy into neural signals which are sent to the brain via the optic nerve.
Cells in the retina that are sensitive to low light intensity (dim light).
Cells found in the retina that are sensitive to high light intensity (bright light) and can detect different colors.

cards.term: What is the function of the optic nerve?
cards.definition: It transmits nerve impulses to the brain from the retina.

cards.term: Describe how dim light affects the size of the pupil
cards.definition: Light receptors detect dim light. Circular muscles relax. Radial muscles contract. Pupil dilates. More light enters the pupil.

cards.term: Describe how bright light affects the size of the pupil
cards.definition: Light receptors detect bright light. Circular muscles contract. Radial muscles relax. Pupil contracts. Less light enters the pupil.

cards.term: Why is the iris reflex important?
cards.definition: It prevents bright light from damaging the retina.
Process by which the elastic lens changes its shape (with the aid of ciliary muscles and suspensory ligaments) to focus on near or distant objects. Light is focused onto the retina.

cards.term: Describe how the eye focuses on near objects
cards.definition: Near object. Ciliary muscles contract. Suspensory ligaments slacken. Lens becomes more convex (more rounded). Light is refracted more. Light rays focused onto the retina.

cards.term: Describe how the eye focuses on distant objects
cards.definition: Distant object. Ciliary muscles relax. Suspensory ligaments tighten. Lens becomes less convex (less rounded). Light is refracted less. Light rays focused onto the retina.
Can focus on distant objects clearly. Cannot focus on near objects.

cards.term: What are the causes of long-sightedness?
cards.definition: Eyeball is too short. Lens is less elastic (usually age-related). Light rays are not focused onto the retina, instead converging behind the retina.
Using a convex lens (causes light rays to converge) in glasses or contact lenses. Replacement lenses. Laser eye surgery.
Can focus on near objects clearly. Cannot focus on distant objects.

cards.term: What are the causes of short-sightedness?
cards.definition: Eyeball is too long. Lens is too convex. Light rays converge before they reach the retina.
Using a concave lens (causes light rays to diverge) in glasses or contact lenses. Replacement lenses. Laser eye surgery.
System of glands that produce and secrete hormones.
Chemical messengers that travel through the bloodstream to target cells. Regulate various processes in the body e.g. metabolism, growth, reproduction.

cards.term: What is the difference between endocrine and exocrine glands?
cards.definition: Endocrine glands secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream. Exocrine glands secrete substances onto body surfaces or into body cavities.

cards.term: Outline the function of the pituitary gland
cards.definition: Master gland. Produces and secretes many hormones that regulate body processes including growth and development, metabolism, and reproduction.

cards.term: Outline the function of the thyroid gland
cards.definition: Produces and secretes thyroxine which regulates metabolic rate and growth and development.

cards.term: Outline the function of the adrenal glands
cards.definition: Produces and secretes adrenaline which is involved in the 'fight or flight' response.

cards.term: Outline the function of the pancreas
cards.definition: Produces and secretes insulin and glucagon which regulate blood sugar levels.

cards.term: Outline the function of the ovaries
cards.definition: Produce and secrete oestrogen and progesterone which regulate the menstrual cycle and are involved in the development of secondary sexual characteristics.

cards.term: Outline the function of the testes
cards.definition: Produce and secrete testosterone which regulates the production of sperm and is involved in the development of secondary sexual characteristics.

cards.term: What are the effects of adrenaline on the body?
cards.definition: Increases heart rate. Dilates the pupils. Dilates bronchioles. Increases breathing rate. Increases blood glucose concentration.
The maintenance of a constant internal environment despite external changes.
A mechanism that maintains homeostasis by counteracting changes to the internal environment, returning it to its set point.

cards.term: Give an example of negative feedback in the human body
cards.definition: Body temperature regulation: If body temperature rises, receptors in the skin detect the change. Information sent to the thermoregulatory centre in the brain. Brain sends impulses to effectors e.g. sweat glands and blood vessels. Sweat glands produce sweat. Blood vessels dilate. Body temperature decreases.
A condition where blood sugar levels cannot be properly regulated by insulin.

cards.term: What are the two main types of diabetes?
cards.definition: Type 1 diabetes: The body's immune system destroys insulin-producing cells in the pancreas. Type 2 diabetes: The body becomes resistant to the effects of insulin or the pancreas does not produce enough insulin.

cards.term: What are the symptoms of diabetes?
cards.definition: Frequent urination. Excessive thirst. Weight loss. Extreme tiredness.

cards.term: What are the long-term complications of diabetes?
cards.definition: Cardiovascular disease. Blindness. Kidney failure. Nerve damage. Amputations.
Type 1 diabetes: Insulin injections. Type 2 diabetes: Lifestyle changes (diet, exercise), oral medication, insulin injections.
A hormone produced by the pancreas that raises blood glucose levels.

cards.term: How does glucagon raise blood glucose levels?
cards.definition: Stimulates the conversion of glycogen to glucose in the liver. Stimulates the conversion of amino acids and glycerol to glucose in the liver.
A hormone produced by the pancreas that lowers blood glucose levels.

cards.term: How does insulin lower blood glucose levels?
cards.definition: Increases the rate of glucose uptake by cells. Stimulates the liver to convert glucose to glycogen for storage.

cards.term: What are the causes of obesity?
cards.definition: Excessive calorie intake. Lack of physical activity. Genetic factors. Medical conditions (e.g. hypothyroidism). Medications.

cards.term: What are the health risks associated with obesity?
cards.definition: Type 2 diabetes. Cardiovascular disease. Hypertension. Some cancers. Sleep apnea. Osteoarthritis. Fatty liver disease.
Lifestyle changes (diet, exercise). Medication. Surgery (e.g. gastric banding).

cards.term: What are the effects of malnutrition?
cards.definition: Stunted growth. Delayed wound healing. Hair loss. Muscle weakness. Increased risk of infection.

cards.term: What are the causes of malnutrition?
cards.definition: Inadequate intake of nutrients. Poor absorption of nutrients due to diseases (e.g. coeliac disease). Increased nutrient needs (e.g. during pregnancy or illness).
Improving diet. Nutritional supplements. Treating underlying medical conditions.

cards.term: Outline the consequences of an unbalanced diet
cards.definition: Nutrient deficiencies. Weight gain/obesity. Increased risk of chronic diseases (e.g. type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease).
Diseases caused by pathogens that can be transmitted from one person to another.
Diseases that cannot be transmitted from one person to another. They often develop over a long period of time and are caused by a combination of genetic, lifestyle, and environmental factors.
Influenza, Tuberculosis, HIV/AIDS, Malaria, Cholera, COVID-19.
Cancer, Cardiovascular disease, Chronic respiratory diseases (e.g. chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma), Diabetes, Obesity.
Diseases of the heart and blood vessels.

cards.term: What are the risk factors for cardiovascular disease?
cards.definition: High blood pressure, High cholesterol levels, Smoking, Poor diet, Lack of exercise, Obesity.

cards.term: How can cardiovascular disease be prevented?
cards.definition: Healthy diet, Regular exercise, Not smoking, Maintaining a healthy weight.
A group of diseases characterized by the uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells.

cards.term: What are the causes of cancer?
cards.definition: Genetic mutations, Carcinogens (e.g. tobacco smoke, UV radiation), Viral infections (e.g. HPV, hepatitis B and C), Immune system deficiencies, Hormonal imbalances.
Surgery, Radiation therapy, Chemotherapy, Immunotherapy, Hormone therapy, Targeted therapy.
A microorganism that causes disease.

cards.term: What are the main types of pathogens?
cards.definition: Bacteria, Viruses, Fungi, Protozoa, Parasitic worms.
Bacteria can produce toxins that damage host tissues. They can also invade host tissues directly and disrupt normal bodily functions.
Viruses infect host cells and use the host's cellular machinery to replicate. This can cause cell damage or death, and trigger immune responses that contribute to disease symptoms.
Fungi can infect various parts of the body, particularly the skin, nails, and lungs. They can cause diseases ranging from superficial skin infections to serious systemic infections.

Protozoa are single-celled organisms that can cause diseases such as malaria, amoebiasis, and giardiasis. They often enter the body through contaminated food or water and target specific tissues or organs.

cards.term: How do parasitic worms cause disease?
cards.definition: Parasitic worms, also known as helminths, can cause diseases such as schistosomiasis, filariasis, and tapeworm infections. They often reside in the intestines, blood vessels, or other tissues, causing inflammation, malnutrition, and organ damage.

cards.term: What are the modes of transmission for infectious diseases?
cards.definition: Direct contact, Indirect contact (e.g. via contaminated objects), Droplet transmission (e.g. respiratory droplets), Airborne transmission, Foodborne transmission, Vector-borne transmission.

cards.term: How can the spread of infectious diseases be prevented?
cards.definition: Vaccination, Hand hygiene, Food safety practices, Safe water and sanitation, Vector control measures, Isolation and quarantine, Health education.
A substance containing antigens that stimulate the immune system to produce an acquired immunity to a specific disease, usually without causing the disease itself.

Vaccines introduce a weakened or killed form of a pathogen or its antigens into the body. This triggers an immune response, leading to the production of memory cells that provide long-term protection against future infections.

A form of indirect protection from infectious diseases that occurs when a large percentage of a population becomes immune to an infection, either through vaccination or previous infections, reducing the spread of the disease.

The ability of bacteria, viruses, and other microorganisms to resist the effects of antibiotics, making infections harder to treat and increasing the risk of disease spread, severe illness, and death.

cards.term: What are the main factors contributing to antibiotic resistance?
cards.definition: Overuse and misuse of antibiotics, Incomplete courses of antibiotics, Use of antibiotics in agriculture, Poor infection control practices, Lack of new antibiotic development.

cards.term: How can antibiotic resistance be prevented?
cards.definition: Using antibiotics only when necessary and as prescribed by a healthcare professional, Completing the full course of antibiotics, Avoiding the use of antibiotics in agriculture whenever possible, Practicing good hygiene, Developing new antibiotics and alternative treatments.

cards.term: What is the function of the reproductive system?
cards.definition: To produce, store, nourish, and transport gametes (sperm and eggs), as well as to facilitate fertilization and support the development of offspring.

cards.term: What is the male reproductive system?
cards.definition: The system of organs involved in the production, storage, and release of sperm cells.

cards.term: What are the main organs of the male reproductive system?
cards.definition: Testes, Epididymis, Vas deferens, Seminal vesicles, Prostate gland, Bulbourethral glands, Penis, Scrotum.
Male reproductive organs that produce sperm cells and secrete testosterone.

cards.term: What is the function of testosterone?
cards.definition: It stimulates the development of male secondary sexual characteristics and regulates sperm production.

cards.term: What is the role of the epididymis?
cards.definition: To store sperm cells and facilitate their maturation.
A duct that transports sperm from the epididymis to the urethra.
Glands that produce a fluid rich in fructose and other substances that nourish and promote the motility of sperm.
A gland that produces a fluid that forms part of the semen.
Glands that produce a clear, lubricating fluid that cleanses and lubricates the urethra prior to ejaculation.
The male organ of copulation and urination.
A sac of skin and muscle that houses the testes and helps regulate their temperature.

cards.term: What is the female reproductive system?
cards.definition: The system of organs involved in the production, storage, and release of egg cells and in the preparation of the uterus for the implantation of a fertilized egg.

cards.term: What are the main organs of the female reproductive system?
cards.definition: Ovaries, Fallopian tubes, Uterus, Cervix, Vagina, Vulva.
Female reproductive organs that produce egg cells and secrete estrogen and progesterone.

cards.term: What is the role of estrogen and progesterone?
cards.definition: They regulate the menstrual cycle, maintain pregnancy, and promote the development of female secondary sexual characteristics.
Ducts that transport egg cells from the ovaries to the uterus and provide the site for fertilization.
A muscular organ where implantation of a fertilized egg occurs and where a fetus develops during pregnancy.
The lower part of the uterus that connects to the vagina.
A muscular tube that connects the uterus to the external genitals.
The external female genitalia.

A series of hormonal and physiological changes that occur in the female reproductive system each month, leading to ovulation and either the preparation of the uterus for pregnancy or the shedding of the uterine lining during menstruation.
The release of a mature egg cell from an ovary.

cards.term: What happens if fertilization does not occur after ovulation?
cards.definition: The egg cell degenerates, and the uterine lining is shed during menstruation.

cards.term: What happens if fertilization occurs after ovulation?
cards.definition: The fertilized egg implants in the uterus, and pregnancy begins.
The shedding of the uterine lining that occurs if fertilization does not occur.
Infections that are spread through sexual contact, including vaginal, anal, and oral sex.

cards.term: Give examples of sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
cards.definition: Chlamydia, Gonorrhea, Syphilis, HIV/AIDS, Genital herpes, Genital warts (HPV), Trichomoniasis.

cards.term: How can sexually transmitted infections (STIs) be prevented?
cards.definition: Abstinence from sexual activity, Mutual monogamy, Correct and consistent use of condoms, Regular testing and treatment, Avoiding sharing needles or other drug paraphernalia.
The deliberate use of artificial methods or other techniques to prevent pregnancy as a result of sexual intercourse.

cards.term: What are the main types of contraception?
cards.definition: Barrier methods (e.g. condoms), Hormonal methods (e.g. birth control pills), Intrauterine devices (IUDs), Sterilization (e.g. tubal ligation, vasectomy), Emergency contraception.
Technologies used to achieve pregnancy in procedures such as in vitro fertilization (IVF), intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), and gamete intrafallopian transfer (GIFT).

cards.term: What are the ethical concerns associated with assisted reproductive technology (ART)?
cards.definition: Issues related to the status of the embryo (personhood), concerns about the health and well-being of the mother and child, the commercialization of reproduction, and access to treatment.
A procedure in which egg cells are fertilized by sperm outside the body, typically in a laboratory setting. The resulting embryos are then transferred to the uterus to establish a pregnancy.
A technique used in assisted reproductive technology (ART) in which a single sperm cell is injected directly into an egg cell to facilitate fertilization.
A technique used in assisted reproductive technology (ART) in which egg and sperm cells are collected and placed into a woman's fallopian tubes, allowing fertilization to occur inside the body.
Type of reproduction involving the production of gametes by meiosis. A gamete from each parent fuses to form a zygote. Genetic information from each gamete is mixed so the resulting zygote is unique.
Sex cells (Sperm cells, egg cells). Haploid (half the number of chromosomes).
Form of cell division involved in the formation of gametes. Chromosome number is halved. Involves two divisions.
Must occur prior to meiosis.

Chromosome pairs line up along the cell equator. The pair of chromosomes are separated and move to opposite poles of the cell (the side to which each chromosome is pulled is random, creating variation). Chromosome number is halved.
Chromosomes line up along the cell equator. The chromatids are separated and move to opposite poles of the cell. Four unique haploid gametes are produced.

cards.term: Importance of meiosis for sexual reproduction
cards.definition: 1. It increases genetic variation. 2. It ensures that the resultant zygote is diploid.
It creates genetic variation, increasing the probability of a species adapting to and surviving environmental changes.

1. Two parents are required. This makes reproduction difficult in endangered populations or in species which exhibit solitary lifestyles. 2. More time and energy is required so fewer offspring are produced.
Type of reproduction involving mitosis. Produces genetically identical offspring known as daughter cells.

1. Only one parent is required. 2. Lots of offspring can be produced in a short period of time, enabling the rapid colonization of an area and reducing competition from other species. 3. Requires less energy.
No genetic variation (except from spontaneous mutations) reducing the probability of a species being able to adapt to environmental change.
A double-stranded polymer of nucleotides, wound to form a double helix.
Nucleotides.
Common sugar, Phosphate group, One of four bases: A, T, C or G.

cards.term: Full names of the four bases found in nucleotides
cards.definition: Adenine, Thymine, Cytosine, Guanine.

cards.term: Interaction of nucleotides to form a molecule of DNA
cards.definition: Sugar and phosphate molecules join to form a sugar-phosphate backbone in each DNA strand. Base connected to each sugar. Complementary base pairs (A pairs with T, C pairs with G) joined by weak hydrogen bonds.
The entire genetic material of an organism.
A long, coiled molecule of DNA that carries genetic information in the form of genes.
A section of DNA that codes for a specific sequence of amino acids which undergo polymerization to form a protein.

cards.term: Method used to extract DNA from fruit
cards.definition: Place a piece of fruit in a beaker and crush it. Add detergent and salt, mix. Filter the mixture and collect the liquid in a test tube. Pour chilled ethanol into the test tube. DNA precipitates forming a fibrous white solid. Use a glass rod to collect the DNA sample.

cards.term: Reason for adding detergent to the crushed fruit
cards.definition: It disrupts the cell membranes, releasing DNA into solution.

cards.term: Reason for adding salt to the crushed fruit
cards.definition: Salt encourages the precipitation of DNA.

cards.term: Reason for using chilled ethanol rather than water
cards.definition: DNA is insoluble in ethanol, encouraging its precipitation.

cards.term: Explanation of how a gene codes for a protein
cards.definition: A sequence of three bases in a gene forms a triplet. Each triplet codes for an amino acid. The order of amino acids determines the structure (i.e. how it will fold) and function of protein formed.

cards.term: Importance of the folding of amino acids in proteins such as enzymes
cards.definition: The folding of amino acids determines the shape of the active site which must be highly specific to the shape of its substrate.
The formation of a protein from a gene.
1. Transcription. 2. Translation.
Involves the formation of mRNA from a DNA template.

1. DNA double helix unwinds. 2. RNA polymerase binds to a specific base sequence of non-coding DNA in front of a gene and moves along the DNA strand. 3. RNA polymerase joins free RNA nucleotides to complementary bases on the coding DNA strand. 4. mRNA formation complete. mRNA detaches and leaves the nucleus.
mRNA is single stranded whereas DNA is double stranded. mRNA uses U whereas DNA uses T.

cards.term: Reason mRNA is used in translation rather than DNA
cards.definition: DNA is too large to leave the nucleus so cannot reach the ribosome.
Involves a ribosome joining amino acids in a specific order dictated by mRNA to form a protein.

1. mRNA attaches to a ribosome. 2. Ribosome reads the mRNA bases in triplets. Each triplet codes for one amino acid which is brought to the ribosome by a tRNA molecule. 3. A polypeptide chain is formed from the sequence of amino acids which join together.

cards.term: Adaptation of a tRNA molecule to its function
cards.definition: Each tRNA molecule has an anticodon which is specific to the codon of the amino acid that it carries.
A random change in the base sequence of DNA which results in genetic variants.

cards.term: Effect of a gene mutation in coding DNA
cards.definition: If a mutation changes the amino acid sequence, protein structure and function may change. If a mutation does not change the amino acid sequence, there is no effect on protein structure or function.
DNA which does not code for a protein but instead controls gene expression.

cards.term: Effect of a gene mutation in non-coding DNA
cards.definition: A mutation may affect the ability of RNA polymerase to bind to non-coding DNA. This may affect protein production and the resulting phenotype of the organism.

cards.term: How Mendel's work contributed to the understanding of genetics
cards.definition: Mendel studied the inheritance of different phenotypes of pea plants. He established a correlation between parent and offspring phenotypes. He noted that inheritance was determined by 'units' passed on to descendants. Using gene crosses, he devised the terms 'dominant' and 'recessive'.

cards.term: Reason Mendel's work was initially overlooked
cards.definition: Scientists didn't understand Mendel's work as there was no knowledge of genes or DNA at the time.
Different versions of the same gene.
An organism's genetic composition, describes all alleles.
An organism's observable characteristics due to interactions of the genotype and environment (which can modify the phenotype).
Having two identical alleles of a gene, e.g. FF or ff.
Having two different alleles of a gene, e.g. Ff.
Describes an allele that is always expressed. Represented with a capital letter e.g. F.
An allele that is only expressed in the absence of a dominant allele. Represented with a small letter e.g. f.
The inheritance of a single gene.
Most characteristics are controlled by multiple alleles rather than just one.
A pair of chromosomes that determine sex: Males have an X and a Y chromosome, Females have two X chromosomes.

cards.term: Reason inheritance of a Y chromosome leads to male development
cards.definition: Testes development in an embryo is stimulated by a gene present on the Y chromosome.
Using a family pedigree.
A characteristic that is coded for by an allele found on a sex chromosome.

cards.term: Reason majority of genes are found on the X chromosome rather than the Y chromosome
cards.definition: The X chromosome is bigger than the Y chromosome so more genes are carried on it.

cards.term: Reason men are more likely to show the phenotype for a recessive sex-linked trait than women
cards.definition: Many genes are found on the X chromosome that have no counterpart on the Y chromosome. Women (XX) have two alleles for each sex-linked gene whereas men (XY) often only have one allele - only one recessive allele is required to produce the recessive phenotype in males.

cards.term: Example of a characteristic determined by more than one allele
cards.definition: Blood group is determined by three alleles: IA, IB, i.
A, B, AB, O.
Alleles that equally contribute to an organism's phenotype. They are expressed to an equal extent.
IA and IB are codominant. IA IB gives the blood group AB.

cards.term: Reason IA IB gives blood group A
cards.definition: IA is dominant and is expressed giving blood group A. IB is recessive to IA.

cards.term: Possible genotypes for blood group B
cards.definition: IB IB or IB i.
i i.

cards.term: Causes of variation within a species
cards.definition: Genetics, Environment.
Variations in the genotypes of organisms of the same species due to the presence of different alleles. Creates differences in phenotypes.

cards.term: Causes of genetic variation in a species
cards.definition: Spontaneous mutations, Sexual reproduction.
A random change to the base sequence in DNA which results in genetic variants.
Insertion, Deletion, Substitution.

cards.term: Effects of a gene mutation on an organism's phenotype
cards.definition: 1. Neutral mutation does not change the sequence of amino acids. Protein structure and function remain the same. No effect on phenotype. 2. Mutation may cause a minor change in an organism's phenotype e.g. change in eye color. 3. Mutation may completely change the sequence of amino acids. This may result in a non-functional protein. Severe changes to phenotype.
Variations in phenotype that are acquired during the lifespan of an organism. Due to environmental factors e.g. diet, lifestyle, climate, exposure to light etc.

Scientific research project involving thousands of scientists across the globe which successfully mapped the entire human genome. Scientists now aim to identify the function of every gene in the human genome.

cards.term: Application of the results of the Human Genome Project to medicine
cards.definition: Enables scientists to understand how lifestyle factors interact with genes - identifying predisposition to disease and possible preventions. Disease-causing alleles identified more rapidly and the appropriate treatments prescribed earlier on. Scientists can predict an individuals response to certain drugs. New drugs can be developed which are tailored to a specific allele.

cards.term: Drawbacks associated with the discoveries of the Human Genome Project
cards.definition: Knowledge of predisposition to a disease can be stressful. Societal pressure influencing the decision to have children. Discrimination by employers, insurance firms etc.
A gradual change in the inherited traits within a population over time. Occurs due to natural selection.

Genetic variation exists due to spontaneous mutations. Selection pressures (e.g. competition, disease) exist. Random mutation gives an organism a selective advantage. Organism is better adapted to the environment and survives. Organism reproduces, passing on its beneficial alleles. Frequency of advantageous alleles increases.
Competition between organisms in a habitat exists because the resources required for survival are limited.

cards.term: Examples of competition within a habitat
cards.definition: Competition between animals for food, shelter, mates, etc. Competition between plants for light, water, minerals, etc.

1. Genetic variation exists due to spontaneous mutations. 2. Antibiotics act as a selection pressure. 3. Mutations give a bacterium antibiotic-resistance. 4. If an antibiotic is administered, the bacterium is better adapted and survives, while other bacteria are killed. 5. Bacterium reproduces, passing on its resistant variant. 6. Frequency of antibiotic-resistant allele increases.

cards.term: Significance of studying antibiotic resistance in bacteria for evolution
cards.definition: Bacteria reproduce very rapidly, allowing first-hand observation of evolution.

Older fossils (found in rocks deeper in the ground) contain simpler organisms. Newer fossils (found closer to the surface) contain more complex organisms. Comparisons of fossils show that simple organisms evolved into more complex life forms. Fossils can be organized into chronological order, allowing the changes in organisms over time to be observed.

cards.term: Darwin's role in the development of the theory of evolution by natural selection
cards.definition: Studied a variety of organisms while traveling around the world on the HMS Beagle. Noted that traits can be passed from parents to offspring. Proposed the idea of 'survival of the fittest'. Established the theory of natural selection and published his ideas in 'On the Origin of Species'.

cards.term: Wallace's role in the development of the theory of evolution by natural selection
cards.definition: He proposed a theory of natural selection that was similar to Darwin's, although the mechanisms were different. He gathered greater evidence (e.g. studying warning coloration in butterflies) to support the theory.

cards.term: Impact of the theory of evolution by natural selection on modern biology and society
cards.definition: Enables the classification of organisms into taxa. Influences modern medicine by emphasizing the importance of finishing antibiotic treatments and the need for the constant production of new antibiotics. Highlights the importance of high genetic diversity in habitats, which aids conservation projects.

cards.term: Fossils providing evidence for human evolution
cards.definition: Ardi - 4.4 million years old. Lucy - 3.2 million years old. Leakey discovered 1.6 million-year-old fossils.

Female hominid fossil showing phenotypic traits encompassing characteristics of both humans and apes. Ape-like characteristics (e.g., long arms, large big toes). Human-like characteristics (e.g., bone structure suggesting upright walking).

Female hominid fossil showing phenotypic traits more human-like than that of 'Ardi'. The structure of bones in her legs and feet is more adapted to walking than climbing. However, her brain size is closer to that of an apes.

cards.term: Leakey's findings and evidence for human evolution
cards.definition: He discovered many hominid fossils. The 1.6 million-year-old fossil Turkana Boy showed traits comparable to that of modern-day humans, e.g., similar brain size.

cards.term: Evidence from stone tools for human evolution
cards.definition: Correlation between the development of more complex tools and an increase in brain size. Primitive tools are older than more complex tools. Brain size has increased over time - as brain size increased, advancements in tool use were made.

cards.term: Methods used by scientists to date tools
cards.definition: Carbon-14 dating - estimating the age of carbon-containing material found in or alongside tools. Stratigraphy - using the age of layers of sediment surrounding the tool as an indication of the tool's age.
A limb with five digits present in animals, birds, reptiles, and amphibians.

cards.term: Evidence for evolution from the pentadactyl limb
cards.definition: The presence of the pentadactyl limb suggests that all species possessing it have descended from a common ancestor.
The organization of organisms into groups.
The classification of organisms into taxa: kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species.
Animals, plants, fungi, protists, prokaryotes.

cards.term: Change in number of organisms in each taxon down the hierarchy
cards.definition: The number of organisms in each taxon group decreases.

cards.term: Problem with traditional classification based on anatomy and behavior
cards.definition: Organisms that are not closely related may look alike and behave similarly if they live in the same environment. Some closely related species may look very different if they live in different habitats.

cards.term: Advancements leading to reconsideration of the five kingdoms classification system
cards.definition: Microscopes, Biochemistry, DNA and RNA analysis.
Organisms are initially divided into three groups: Archaea, Bacteria, Eukarya.
Eukarya.
Archaea and Bacteria.
Consists of true bacteria (e.g., E.coli).
Consists of primitive microorganisms, including extremophiles adapted to live in extreme conditions (e.g., hot springs).
The process by which humans artificially select organisms with desirable characteristics and breed them to produce offspring with similar phenotypes.

1. Identify a desired characteristic (e.g., disease resistance). 2. Select parent organisms that show the desired traits and breed them together. 3. Select offspring with the desired traits and breed them together. 4. Repeat the process until all offspring have the desired traits.
Creates organisms with desirable features, such as higher crop yields, increased milk production in cows, larger fruit in plants, and domesticated animals.
In medical research and sports (e.g., horse racing).

Reduction in the gene pool, which can be harmful during sudden environmental changes. Inbreeding resulting in genetic disorders. Development of physical problems (e.g., respiratory problems in bulldogs). Potential selection of harmful recessive alleles.
Taking plant cuttings or using tissue culture.
A method of growing living tissue in a suitable medium.

cards.term: Process of growing plants using tissue culture
cards.definition: Select a plant showing desired characteristics. Cut multiple small sample pieces from meristem tissue. Grow in a petri dish containing growth medium. Transfer to compost for further growth.
Ensure aseptic conditions to prevent contamination by microorganisms.
Nutrients and growth hormones.

cards.term: Advantages of growing plants by tissue culture
cards.definition: Fast and simple process. Requires little space. Enables the growth of many plant clones with the same desirable characteristics. Useful in the preservation of endangered plant species.

cards.term: Disadvantages of growing plants by tissue culture
cards.definition: Reduction in the gene pool. Plant clones often have a low survival rate. Could unknowingly increase the presence of harmful recessive alleles.
Useful in preparing tissue samples for medical research. Enables investigation of how different factors may affect a specific animal tissue without harming the animal itself.
Extract a sample of tissue from an animal. Use enzymes to separate cells within the sample. Grow in a culture vessel containing growth medium. Once grown, store the sample.
The modification of the genome of an organism by the insertion of a desired gene from another organism, enabling the formation of an organism with beneficial characteristics.

1. DNA is cut at specific base sequences by restriction enzymes to create sticky ends. 2. Vector DNA is cut using the same restriction enzymes to create complementary sticky ends. 3. Ligase enzymes join the sticky ends of the DNA and vector DNA, forming recombinant DNA. 4. Recombinant DNA is mixed with and 'taken up' by target cells.
A structure that delivers the desired gene into the recipient cell, e.g., plasmids, viruses.
Increased crop yields, useful in medicine (e.g., insulin-producing bacteria), production of scarce resources (e.g., GM golden rice producing beta-carotene).

Long-term effects of consumption of GM crops unknown. Negative environmental impacts (e.g., reduction in biodiversity, contamination of non-GM crops forming 'superweeds'). Late-onset health problems in GM animals. Expensive GM seeds leading to dependency in LEDCs.
A bacterium that secretes a toxin lethal to insect larvae.

cards.term: Use of genetic engineering to protect crops against insects
cards.definition: The gene for toxin production in Bt can be isolated and inserted into the DNA of crops. Bt crops now secrete the toxin, killing any insect larvae that feed on them.
Increased crop yields (fewer crops damaged), lessens the need for artificial insecticides, Bt toxin is specific to certain insect larvae and not harmful to other organisms that ingest it.
Long-term effects of consumption unknown, insect larvae may become resistant to the Bt toxin, killing insect larvae reduces biodiversity.

cards.term: Agricultural methods of increasing food production
cards.definition: Intensive farming methods (e.g., 'battery' farming, fertilizers, pesticides) and biological control.
Increases crop yields.
Fertilizers can cause eutrophication. Use of herbicides and insecticides reduces biodiversity. 'Battery' farming is often seen as unethical.
Introducing a new organism (often a predator) into an ecosystem to control a pest or pathogen.

cards.term: Advantages of using biological control to increase food production
cards.definition: The results generally last for a long period of time. Effects on wildlife are less severe.
Risk of the control organism becoming a pest itself.

topics.title: Health, Disease, and the Development of Medicines (paper1)

cards.definition: A state of complete physical, mental and social well-being (as defined by the World Health Organization, WHO)
A disorder of the body or mind that negatively affects an individual's health
Communicable and Non-communicable
A disease that is passed directly between individuals, caused by a pathogen
A disease-causing organism e.g. virus, fungi, bacteria, protists
A disease that cannot be transmitted between individuals, generally long-lasting with a slow onset, caused by lifestyle, environmental conditions, genetic mutations etc.
A change experienced by an organism that indicates disease

cards.term: Illness and susceptibility to other diseases
cards.definition: A disease may weaken an individual's immune system making them increasingly susceptible to other infections.
Caused by Vibrio cholerae bacterium, spread by drinking or washing in contaminated water, symptoms include diarrhea, vomiting
Access to clean water, improved sanitation (sewage disposal etc.)
Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacterium, spread by droplet infection, symptoms include lung damage, chesty cough, wheezing
Improved hygiene, infected individuals should avoid crowded areas, increased ventilation in the individual's home
Caused by a fungus infecting ash trees, spread via airborne spores, causes dark lesions on bark and blackened leaves

cards.term: Reducing transmission of Chalara Ash Dieback
cards.definition: Control the movement of ash trees, kill infected plants, replant with a different species
Caused by plasmodium protist, spread by mosquito vectors, symptoms include flu-like symptoms, damage to red blood cells, liver damage
Mosquito nets, insect repellent, covering arms and legs
Caused by Helicobacter pylori bacterium, transmitted orally by eating or drinking infected substances, symptoms include stomach pain, vomiting, nausea
Access to clean water, improved hygiene, improved sanitation (sewage disposal etc.)
Caused by Ebola virus, spread by direct contact with infected body fluids, symptoms include fever, diarrhea, vomiting, internal bleeding
Improved hygiene, isolating infected individuals, sterilization of outbreak areas
