They enter host cells and replicate inside of them. The host cells rupture, releasing new viruses.

cards.term: Difference between viruses and other microorganisms
cards.definition: Viruses are not living organisms. They do not reproduce and can only replicate inside a host cell.
Lytic pathway and Lysogenic pathway

1. Virus binds to specific receptors on host cell. 2. Virus injects its DNA into host cell and replicates its DNA using host cell machinery. 3. New viral structures are produced and assembled. 4. Host cell ruptures, releasing new viruses.

1. Virus binds to specific receptors on host cell. 2. Viral DNA injected into host cell and becomes integrated into host cell genome. 3. Viral DNA replicates each time the host cell divides. However, the cell remains normal. 4. Trigger causes the activation of viral DNA. It enters lytic pathway.

Caused by human immunodeficiency virus, spread by direct contact with infected body fluids, destroys white blood cells making the individual immunodeficient and increasingly susceptible to other diseases, leads to AIDS.
Use of condoms and protected sex, needle exchange, screening blood for HIV, deterring infected mothers from breastfeeding
Caused by Chlamydia bacterium, spread through sexual contact or direct contact with infected genital fluids, can result in infertility
Use of condoms and protected sex, screening
Waterproof waxy cuticle as a surface barrier, cellulose cell wall as a further barrier against pathogens
Secretion of toxins to reduce damage by pests, production of antibacterial chemicals that kill bacterial pathogens
They produce physiological effects on the body so can be used in medicines to treat disease.
Quinine - antimalarial, bark of Cinchona sp., Aspirin - painkiller, bark/leaves of Salix alba
Plants are producers so all organisms higher up in food chains rely upon their survival and ability to fight disease. They are also important in maintaining human food security.
Observation of symptoms, analysis of distribution of infected plants, changing environmental conditions to eliminate other causes

cards.term: Difficulty in identifying diseases using symptoms alone
cards.definition: Many diseases may have similar symptoms.

cards.term: Detection of plant diseases in the lab
cards.definition: Detection of foreign antigens in a sample of plant tissue using monoclonal antibodies, analysis of DNA to identify any pathogen DNA in a tissue sample
Always present, same for all organisms, prevents pathogens from entering the body

cards.term: Physical defense system in the body
cards.definition: Skin as a protective surface barrier, blood clotting, respiratory tract

cards.term: Chemical defense system in the body
cards.definition: Tears containing lysozyme, hydrochloric acid in the stomach
The body's defense against pathogens once they have entered the body, aims to prevent or minimize disease caused by pathogens

cards.term: How white blood cells detect pathogens
cards.definition: Pathogens have unique antigens on their surface which are detected by specialized receptors on white blood cells.

cards.term: How the immune system destroys pathogens
cards.definition: B-lymphocytes produce antibodies in response to a particular antigen, each antibody is specific to an antigen and binds to it, antibodies 'tag' pathogens or clump them together, disabling them so that they can be killed by other white blood cells.

White blood cells produced in response to a foreign antigen that remain in the body after a pathogen has been destroyed, provide immunity - if the body is re-infected, antibodies are produced more rapidly and the pathogen is destroyed before it can produce disease symptoms

Deliberate exposure of an individual to foreign antigens, triggers an immune response (produces antibodies) and provides immunity (due to memory cells), the individual does not contract the disease that they are being immunized against
Dead, weakened or inactivated pathogens with their surface antigens still present
Herd immunity - vaccination of a significant proportion of the population gives some protection to individuals who are not immune, helps to prevent epidemics and pandemics

High mutation rate of viruses changes the structure of viral antigens, making vaccines that are already available ineffective, not guaranteed to work, inactivated pathogens may mutate and become pathogenic, may cause an adverse reaction, vaccination programs are costly
A substance that kills or inhibits the growth of bacteria (no effect on viruses), no effect on cells in the host organism, produced by living organisms e.g. fungi

cards.term: Identification of target molecules for new medicines
cards.definition: Comparisons of the genomes of unaffected individuals and those who are affected by a disease to identify potential disease-causing alleles, the alleles themselves or the proteins that they code for can be used as a target
Screening for potential drugs, preclinical trials, clinical trials, approval by a medical agency

Uses a machine to test large libraries of chemical substances, enables identification of pre-existing chemicals which may affect the target molecule, chemicals may be altered, allowing scientists to produce a drug that reacts with target molecules in a specific way

Drug tested on cultured human cells and using computer models to determine its toxicity (potential to cause damage) and efficiency, drug then tested on live animals to establish a safe dose for humans and observe any side effects

The drug is first tested on healthy human volunteers to ensure that it is safe to use and has no other unwanted effects on the body, drug then tested on patients with the disease to determine its efficacy, dosage is slowly increased until an upper limit is established, optimum dosage is found
A substance that appears just like the real drug but has no effect on the recipient
Where the participants don't know whether they are receiving the new drug or the placebo, prevents the patient's bias affecting the results
Neither the participants nor the doctors know who is receiving the new drug or the placebo, prevents bias from doctors when analyzing the results
Is it ethical to prescribe a sick patient with a placebo knowing that it will not help their condition improve?
Antibodies that are clones from one parent cell, specific to one type of antigen

Specific antigen injected into an animal, B-lymphocytes producing complementary antibodies extracted, B-lymphocytes fuse with myeloma cells to form hybridoma cells, hybridoma cells cultured, monoclonal antibodies collected and purified
Type of tumour cell
Detection of pathogens, location of cancer cells and blood clots, treatment of cancer, used in pregnancy test kits
Test for hCG in urine
A stick containing monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) specific to hCG: mAbs attached to a blue bead (free to move), mAbs fixed to the test stick

cards.term: Negative Result on Pregnancy Test Kits
cards.definition: No hCG in urine so a blue line is not formed

cards.term: Advantages of Monoclonal Antibodies in Pathogen Testing
cards.definition: Specific to one particular antigen, very accurate, quick results

cards.term: Use of Monoclonal Antibodies in Cancer Targeting
cards.definition: Cancer cells have specific antigens called 'tumour markers' on their membranes, mAbs are specific to one type of antigen so can be targeted to 'tumour markers' without damaging other cells

cards.term: Diagnosis of Cancer using Monoclonal Antibodies
cards.definition: mAbs tagged to a radioactive substance, mAbs injected into the patient's bloodstream, mAbs bind to 'tumour markers' on cancer cells, emitted radiation is detected using a specialized scanner enabling doctors to determine the location of cancer cells

cards.term: Targeted Drug Delivery using Monoclonal Antibodies
cards.definition: mAbs attached to an anti-cancer drug, mAbs injected into the patient's bloodstream, mAbs bind to 'tumour markers' on cancer cells, anti-cancer drug destroys cancer cells

cards.term: Advantages of Monoclonal Antibody Cancer Treatments
cards.definition: Radiotherapy and chemotherapy target rapidly dividing cells, healthy cells (e.g. hair follicle cells, bone marrow cells) are damaged as a consequence, producing unpleasant side effects, mAbs only target cancer cells, reducing damage to normal cells

cards.term: Detection of Blood Clots using Monoclonal Antibodies
cards.definition: mAbs tagged to a radioactive substance, mAbs target and bind to specific proteins in blood clots, radiation emitted by mAbs is detected, enabling the location of blood clots to be identified
Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular diseases, Chronic respiratory diseases e.g. asthma
A variable associated with a greater chance of developing a disease or infection

cards.term: Factors affecting the risk of non-communicable diseases
cards.definition: Lifestyle factors e.g. diet, exercise, alcohol, smoking, environmental factors e.g. exposure to pollution, genetics e.g. alleles that increase the risk of cancer
Correlation between a risk factor and a disease does not mean that the risk factor causes the disease. Other factors may be involved and some may be linked.

cards.term: Effects of Exercise on Non-communicable Diseases
cards.definition: Regular exercise decreases fat stores, reducing obesity (a risk factor of CVD and type 2 diabetes), it decreases heart rate, recovery time and blood pressure, lowering the risk of CVD

cards.term: Effects of Diet on Non-communicable Diseases
cards.definition: Diet high in saturated fat raises blood cholesterol levels, increasing the deposition of fatty deposits in the arteries - greater risk of CVD, obesity and the consumption of large amounts of simple-sugars increases the risk of type 2 diabetes, malnourishment increases the risk of deficiency diseases
Scurvy (vitamin C deficiency), Anaemia (iron deficiency)
A value based on height and mass used to categorize an individual as underweight, normal weight, overweight or obese
mass (kg) / (height (m))^2
Fat and muscle tissue cannot be distinguished so athletes may be incorrectly categorized as obese
waist circumference (cm) / hip circumference (cm)
A waist-to-hip ratio higher than 1.0 in males or 0.85 in females indicates abdominal obesity and increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes

cards.term: Effects of Alcohol on Non-communicable Diseases
cards.definition: Alcohol broken down into toxic products in the liver which build-up and cause cirrhosis (scarring of liver tissue), alcohol raises blood pressure thus increasing the risk of CVD, toxic products in alcohol can cause mutations to DNA, increasing the risk of cancer (mouth, throat, liver etc.)

cards.term: Effects of Smoking on Non-communicable Diseases
cards.definition: Nicotine raises heart rate, increasing the risk of CVD, carbon monoxide lowers the ability of red blood cells to carry oxygen, heart rate increases, increasing the risk of CVD, carcinogens in tar can cause mutations to DNA, increasing the risk of cancer (mouth, throat, lung etc.), smoking increases the risk of lung diseases e.g. chronic bronchitis

cards.term: Effects of Environmental Factors on Non-communicable Diseases
cards.definition: Long-term exposure to pollution damages the airways, increasing the risk of lung diseases and lung cancer, exposure to UV radiation damages DNA, increasing the risk of DNA mutations and skin cancer

cards.term: Effects of Genetics on Non-communicable Diseases
cards.definition: The risks of Some diseases such as type 2 diabetes, lung cancer and CVD are increased if a family member has had these conditions, faulty genes can be inherited which increase the risk of conditions such as breast cancer

Some diseases may cause other infections to develop e.g. HIV weakens the immune system, making the individual more susceptible to infections such as TB, some diseases may weaken the body, making it more susceptible to other diseases e.g. cancer treatment may weaken the immune system, increasing the risk of infection

cards.term: Prevention and Treatment of Non-communicable Diseases
cards.definition: Education on lifestyle choices e.g. diet, exercise, alcohol, smoking, vaccination (where appropriate), early detection e.g. regular check-ups, mammograms, treatments e.g. chemotherapy, radiotherapy, surgery
A chemical reaction that takes place inside photosynthetic organisms (e.g. plants, algae) converting light energy into chemical energy.

cards.term: Write the word equation for photosynthesis
cards.definition: carbon dioxide + water  glucose + oxygen

cards.term: Write the symbol equation for photosynthesis
cards.definition: 6CO2 + 6H2O  C6H12O6 + 6O2

It produces glucose which has a wide range of uses: Used in respiration to release energy, Converted to starch and stored - broken down to glucose when the plant requires energy, Used to make complex organic molecules which are used for growth, making up an organism's biomass (transferred through food chains).
Within chloroplasts

cards.term: What type of reaction is photosynthesis?
cards.definition: An endothermic reaction that takes in energy (in the form of light).
A pigment found in chloroplasts that absorbs light.

cards.term: Describe the two main stages of photosynthesis
cards.definition: 1. Chlorophyll absorbs light energy which is used to split water into oxygen gas (waste product) and hydrogen ions. 2. Carbon dioxide combines with hydrogen ions to form glucose.

cards.term: What factors affect the rate of photosynthesis?
cards.definition: Temperature, Light intensity, Carbon dioxide concentration.
A variable that limits the rate of a particular reaction.

cards.term: Explain how temperature affects the rate of photosynthesis
cards.definition: Higher temperatures provide more kinetic energy for enzymes involved in photosynthesis so the rate increases as temperature rises. The optimum temperature is usually 25C. If the temperature becomes too high (around 45C), enzymes become denatured and the rate of photosynthesis decreases.

cards.term: Explain how light intensity affects the rate of photosynthesis
cards.definition: Rate of photosynthesis is directly proportional to light intensity - as light intensity increases, the rate of photosynthesis increases.

cards.term: Why does the rate of photosynthesis eventually plateau even if light intensity continues to increase?
cards.definition: Another factor (temperature or CO2 concentration) becomes limiting.

cards.term: How can the effect of light intensity on the rate of photosynthesis be measured in the lab?
cards.definition: Using a light meter, Using the inverse square law where: light intensity  1/distance^2.

cards.term: Why does the rate of photosynthesis decrease as the distance from a light source increases?
cards.definition: Light intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the light source. Thus, as the distance increases, light intensity decreases and the rate of photosynthesis decreases.

cards.term: Explain how carbon dioxide concentration affects the rate of photosynthesis
cards.definition: As carbon dioxide concentration increases, the rate of photosynthesis increases.

cards.term: Why does the rate of photosynthesis eventually plateau even if CO2 concentration continues to increase?
cards.definition: Another factor (temperature or light intensity) becomes limiting.
Photosynthesis, Maintenance of structure (turgidity), Cooling effect.

cards.term: Why do plants require mineral ions?
cards.definition: For growth e.g. nitrates are required to produce proteins.

cards.term: Which structure in plants is adapted for the uptake of water and minerals?
cards.definition: Root hairs

cards.term: How is water transported into root hairs?
cards.definition: Lower concentration of water in root hair cells than in the soil. Water diffuses down its concentration gradient into root hair cells by osmosis.

cards.term: How are minerals transported into root hairs?
cards.definition: Lower concentration of mineral ions in the soil than in the root. Root hair cells take up mineral ions by active transport.

cards.term: Outline how plant roots are adapted for the absorption of water and minerals
cards.definition: Plant roots are composed of millions of root hair cells which have: Long hairs that extend from the cell body, increasing the surface area for absorption. Many mitochondria which produce ATP for active transport of mineral ions.

cards.term: Name the two plant transport tissues
cards.definition: Xylem, Phloem

cards.term: What is the function of the xylem?
cards.definition: Transports water and minerals up the plant, from the roots to the leaves via the transpiration stream.

cards.term: Describe how the xylem is adapted to its function
cards.definition: Composed of dead cells laid end-to-end to form a long, hollow, continuous column. No end walls which provide little resistance to the passage of water. Thick cell wall strengthened with lignin to provide support.

cards.term: What is the function of the phloem?
cards.definition: Transports sugars up and down the stem from photosynthetic tissues (e.g. mature green leaves) to non-photosynthetic tissues (e.g. developing seeds) via translocation.

cards.term: What are the two cell types that make up the phloem?
cards.definition: Sieve tube elements, Companion cells

cards.term: Describe how the phloem is adapted to its function
cards.definition: Sieve tube elements are long, thin cells, laid end-to-end with perforated end plates to enable the flow of sugars. They contain no nucleus and little cytoplasm to allow sugars to flow easily. Companion cells (adjacent to sieve tube elements) contain a dense cytoplasm, nucleus, and mitochondria. They provide energy for processes in both cell types.
The loss of water vapor from the parts of a plant exposed to the air due to evaporation and diffusion.

cards.term: Where does the majority of transpiration take place?
cards.definition: Leaves

Water evaporates from the mesophyll cell surfaces and diffuses out of the stomata. Water molecules (which have cohesive properties) are drawn up the xylem vessels to replace the water that has been lost. This causes more water molecules to be absorbed from the soil into root hair cells.

cards.term: How does the transpiration stream transport mineral ions?
cards.definition: Mineral ions are dissolved in the water that is carried by the transpiration stream.
They are pores found in the lower epidermis of a leaf which allow gas exchange.
Specialized cells surrounding the stoma that change shape to control the size of the pore.

cards.term: How do guard cells control the size of stomata?
cards.definition: To open the stomata: Water enters guard cells. They swell and become turgid. They bend and draw away from each other, opening the stomata. To close the stomata: Water leaves guard cells. They become flaccid, closing the stomata.

cards.term: What factors affect the rate of transpiration?
cards.definition: Light intensity, Temperature, Air movement

cards.term: Describe how high light intensity affects the rate of transpiration
cards.definition: High light intensity leads to a greater number of stomata open to allow gas exchange for photosynthesis. Rate of photosynthesis increases so more water is taken up from the soil, pushing water up the xylem. More water vapor diffuses out of the stomata, increasing the rate of transpiration.

cards.term: Describe how low light intensity affects the rate of transpiration
cards.definition: At low light intensity, fewer stomata are open so the rate of transpiration decreases.

cards.term: Describe how temperature affects the rate of transpiration
cards.definition: As temperature increases, water molecules have more kinetic energy so the rate of diffusion increases. Photosynthesis also increases so more water is taken up from the soil, pushing water up the xylem. More water vapor diffuses out of the stomata, increasing the rate of transpiration.

cards.term: Describe how air movement affects the rate of transpiration
cards.definition: Air movement increases, maintaining a high water concentration gradient between the air spaces in the leaf and atmosphere. Increased rate of diffusion of water molecules out of the stomata leads to an increase in the rate of transpiration.

cards.term: What apparatus is used to measure the rate of transpiration?
cards.definition: Potometer

cards.term: What is assumed when measuring the rate of transpiration using a potometer?
cards.definition: Rate of water uptake = rate of transpiration

cards.term: How can the rate of transpiration be calculated using a potometer?
cards.definition: rate of transpiration = distance moved by bubble / time taken
The movement of Sugars (Sucrose, amino acids etc.) up and down a plant, from the source to the sink, via the phloem. Requires ATP.

cards.term: Describe how leaves are adapted for photosynthesis and gas exchange (biology only)
cards.definition: Broad - large surface area for light absorption, Thin - short diffusion distance for gases, allows light to reach all cells, Vascular bundles (xylem and phloem) form a network to deliver water and remove glucose. Also provide support, Photosynthetic pigments (e.g. chlorophyll) absorb light.

cards.term: Describe how tissues of the leaves are adapted for photosynthesis and gas exchange (biology only)
cards.definition: Palisade mesophyll layer - receives most light so contains the greatest concentration of chloroplasts, Upper epidermis - transparent, allows light to reach palisade layer, Spongy mesophyll layer - air spaces increase the rate of diffusion, Lower epidermis - contains many stomata for gas exchange.

cards.term: Describe how plants are adapted to live in hot, dry conditions (biology only)
cards.definition: Small leaves/spines - reduce surface area for water loss, Thick waxy cuticle - reduces evaporation, conserving water, Thick stem - provides a storage of water, Shallow but widespread roots - large surface area to absorb water, Stomata sunken in pits and leaves curled - reduces air flow, lowering diffusion gradient and reducing water loss by evaporation, Stomata close to reduce water loss.
The growth of a plant in response to a stimulus.
The growth of a plant towards a stimulus.
The growth of a plant away from a stimulus.

cards.term: What are the two main types of plant tropism?
cards.definition: Phototropism, Gravitropism
A plant's growth response to light.
A plant's growth response to gravity.
A group of plant hormones involved in plant tropisms. Control growth in plant roots and shoot tips.

cards.term: Compare the effect of auxins in plant shoots and roots
cards.definition: Auxins stimulate growth in plant shoots. Auxins inhibit growth in plant roots.
Root and shoot tips

cards.term: How do auxins move through a plant?
cards.definition: They diffuse through the plant in solution.

cards.term: Are plant shoots positively or negatively phototropic? How does this affect shoot growth?
cards.definition: Positively phototropic. Plant shoots grow towards the light.

cards.term: Explain why plant shoots are positively phototropic
cards.definition: Shoot tip exposed to light. On the shaded side of the shoot, auxin accumulates. Elongation of cells on the shaded side. Shoot tip bends towards the light.

cards.term: Are plant shoots positively or negatively gravitropic? How does this affect shoot growth?
cards.definition: Negatively gravitropic. Plant shoots grow upwards, away from gravity.

cards.term: Explain why plant shoots are negatively gravitropic
cards.definition: Shoot placed horizontally. Due to gravity, auxin accumulates on the lower side of the shoot. Elongation of cells on the lower side. Shoot bends upwards, growing away from gravity.

cards.term: Are plant roots positively or negatively phototropic? How does this affect root growth?
cards.definition: Negatively phototropic. Plant roots grow away from the light.

cards.term: Explain why plant roots are negatively phototropic
cards.definition: Root exposed to light. On the shaded side of the root, auxin accumulates. Inhibition of cell growth on the shaded side. Root grows away from the light.

cards.term: Are plant roots positively or negatively gravitropic? How does this affect root growth?
cards.definition: Positively gravitropic. Plant roots grow downwards, towards gravity.

cards.term: Explain why plant roots are positively gravitropic
cards.definition: Root placed horizontally. Due to gravity, auxin accumulates on the lower side of the root. Inhibition of cell growth on the lower side. Root bends downwards, growing towards gravity.

cards.term: Explain how plant tropisms increase the chance of survival
cards.definition: They enable plants to respond to their environment. Shoot growth towards the light maximizes light absorption. Root growth downwards increases the uptake of water and minerals from the soil and enables anchorage of the plant body to the ground.

cards.term: Describe the role of auxins in commercial plant cultivation
cards.definition: Rooting powders contain auxins that stimulate the growth of roots in cuttings. Enables rapid plant cloning. Used in selective weedkillers that target and alter growth patterns in broad-leaved plants (most weeds), killing them.
Plant hormones that control germination and flowering.

cards.term: Describe the role of gibberellins in commercial plant cultivation
cards.definition: Initiate germination in seeds at times of the year when they naturally wouldn't. Ensure all seeds in a batch germinate. Trigger flowering in plants under irregular conditions. Also increase fruit size by reducing the number of flowers produced by plants. Produce seedless fruits by stimulating the growth of fruit from unpollinated flowers.
In the presence of water, gibberellins break seed dormancy, initiating germination.

cards.term: Why is ethene important in commercial plant cultivation?
cards.definition: Ethene stimulates enzymes that control fruit ripening. Enables fruits to be picked while they are unripe and less easily damaged. They can be stimulated to ripen during transportation to shops.
A network of glands that produce and secrete hormones into the bloodstream.
A cell signaling molecule produced by endocrine glands and released into the blood. Travels to a target organ and binds to receptors on effectors, initiating a response.
Described as the 'master gland', it is an endocrine gland that produces hormones which control other glands (e.g., adrenal glands).
Endocrine glands that produce adrenaline.
Above the kidneys.
A hormone produced by the adrenal glands that is involved in the 'fight or flight' response, where the body prepares to confront danger or flee from it.

cards.term: Effects of Adrenaline on the Body
cards.definition:
1. Increases heart rate.
2. Increases blood pressure.
3. Increases blood flow to muscles.
4. Increases blood glucose levels.

cards.term: Mechanism of Adrenaline on Heart Rate and Blood Pressure
cards.definition: Adrenaline is secreted by the adrenal glands and travels in the blood to the heart. It binds to specific receptors on cells in the heart, causing the heart muscle to contract more forcefully and frequently, resulting in an increase in heart rate and blood pressure.

cards.term: Mechanism of Adrenaline on Respiration at Muscle Tissues
cards.definition: Adrenaline binds to specific receptors on cells in the liver, triggering the breakdown of glycogen stores and release of glucose, leading to increased blood glucose levels. Increased heart rate causes greater blood flow to muscles, providing more oxygen and glucose for respiration.

A corrective mechanism that allows only small shifts from a set point. It reverses a change in conditions, for example, if the concentration of a hormone increases, negative feedback systems work to reduce the concentration back to a normal level.
Endocrine gland that produces thyroxine.
In the neck.
A hormone secreted by the thyroid gland that controls metabolic rate, heart rate, and temperature.
The rate at which biochemical reactions occur in cells.

1. Hypothalamus secretes TRH.
2. TRH stimulates secretion of TSH from pituitary gland.
3. TSH stimulates the release of thyroxine from the thyroid gland.
Thyrotropin releasing hormone.
Thyroid-stimulating hormone.

cards.term: Negative Feedback System for Blood Thyroxine Levels
cards.definition: If blood thyroxine levels increase above a set point, TRH and TSH secretion is inhibited, resulting in less thyroxine production by the thyroid gland, thus returning thyroxine levels to normal. If blood thyroxine levels decrease below a set point, TRH and TSH secretion is increased, leading to more thyroxine production by the thyroid gland, thus returning thyroxine levels to normal.
They secrete estrogen into the bloodstream.
They secrete testosterone into the bloodstream.
The cycle in women (typically lasting 28 days) that involves shedding of uterus lining (menstruation), repair of uterus lining, release of an egg (ovulation), and maintenance of uterus lining.

Days 1-4: Menstruation.
Days 4-14: Uterus lining thickens and prepares for implantation.
Day 14: Ovulation.
Days 14-28: Uterus lining maintained for implantation.

1. Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH).
2. Estrogen.
3. Luteinising Hormone (LH).
4. Progesterone.
Secreted by the pituitary gland, FSH triggers the development of a follicle in the ovaries, which releases estrogen.
Secreted by the ovaries, estrogen repairs and thickens the uterus lining, inhibits secretion of FSH from the pituitary gland, and stimulates secretion of LH from the pituitary gland.
Secreted by the pituitary gland, LH triggers ovulation and stimulates follicle remains to develop into a corpus luteum, which then secretes progesterone.
A temporary endocrine structure, a mass of cells that releases progesterone, and degenerates after a few days.

Secreted by the corpus luteum, progesterone stimulates the growth of blood vessels in the uterus lining in preparation for implantation, inhibits the release of FSH and LH, and if no implantation occurs, decreases, leading to shedding of the uterus lining and restarting of the cycle.

cards.term: Progesterone Levels in Fertilisation and Implantation
cards.definition: If fertilization and implantation occur, the placenta produces progesterone, maintaining high levels to prevent further ovulation and maintain the uterus lining.
A method or device utilized to prevent pregnancy.

1. Progesterone taken on its own.
2. Progesterone combined with estrogen.

cards.term: Mechanism of Progesterone in Preventing Pregnancy
cards.definition:
1. Thickens cervical mucus, making it difficult for sperm to enter the uterus.
2. Thins uterine lining, reducing likelihood of egg implantation.
3. Prevents ovulation in some women.

cards.term: Mechanism of Estrogen in Preventing Pregnancy
cards.definition: Inhibits FSH, preventing ovulation.

1. Mini-pill taken daily.
2. Injection.

cards.term: Administration of Progesterone and Estrogen as Contraceptive
cards.definition:
1. Combined pill (taken continuously for 21 days then paused for 7 days).
2. Skin patch (worn continuously for 3 weeks then without for 1 week).

1. 99% effective when used properly.
2. Generally longer-lasting than non-hormonal methods.
3. Used to treat other conditions like painful/heavy periods.

1. Side effects such as mood changes, acne, bloating.
2. Do not protect against STIs.
3. May involve uncomfortable medical procedures.
4. Not effective if used incorrectly.
Methods that prevent the sperm and egg meeting, e.g., condoms, diaphragms (fit over cervix).

cards.term: Benefits of Barrier Methods of Contraception
cards.definition:
1. Condoms are simple and quick to use.
2. Condoms prevent the spread of STIs.
3. No side effects.

cards.term: Main Risk of Barrier Methods of Contraception
cards.definition: Less effective than hormonal methods, e.g., condom may split while in use.

1. Clomifene therapy.
2. IVF (In vitro fertilization).

1. FSH and LH given to a woman to stimulate egg production and ovulation.
2. Eggs retrieved from the woman's ovaries and fertilized in vitro.
3. Resultant embryo transferred to the woman's uterus.
Prescription of clomifene drug to women who do not ovulate regularly. Stimulates secretion of more FSH and LH, which triggers egg production and ovulation.
The maintenance of a stable internal environment in the body despite fluctuations in internal and external conditions.
To ensure optimum conditions for enzymes and cellular processes in the body.

1. Temperature.
2. Blood glucose concentration.
3. Water levels.
The maintenance of core body temperature.
Enzymes work best at their optimum temperature. Deviations from this optimum temperature decrease the rate of enzyme-controlled reactions.

cards.term: Optimum Temperature for Enzymes in the Human Body
Factors Involved in Maintaining Ideal Body Temperature
cards.definition: A negative feedback system involving receptors, hypothalamus, and effectors like sweat glands and hair erector muscles.
Skin - epidermis (outer layer) and dermis (below epidermis), and hypothalamus.

cards.term: Function of Receptors in Skin and Hypothalamus
cards.definition: They detect changes in blood temperature and send information to the hypothalamus.
It coordinates information from the receptors and sends instructions to the effectors.
They produce a response to counteract the change in blood temperature and return it to the set point.

1. Vasodilation.
2. Sweating.
3. Relaxation of erector muscles, causing hairs to lie flat.
Sweat glands found in the dermis.
Pores in the epidermis release sweat onto the skin's surface, which then evaporates.

cards.term: How Sweating Helps Reduce Body Temperature
cards.definition: Heat energy is used to evaporate sweat, increasing heat transfer from the skin to the environment, thus decreasing body temperature.
Dilation of blood vessels near the skin surface, leading to greater heat loss to the surroundings.

1. Vasoconstriction.
2. Shivering.
3. Contraction of hair erector muscles.
4. Little sweat production.
Involuntary contraction of muscles generates heat energy from respiration.

cards.term: Role of Hair Erector Muscles in Increasing Body Temperature
cards.definition: Hairs stand on end, creating pockets of air between hairs and a layer of insulation.
Constriction of blood vessels near the skin surface, leading to less heat loss to the surroundings.

cards.term: Organ Responsible for Maintaining Blood Glucose Concentrations
cards.definition: Pancreas.
Controlled by the hormones insulin and glucagon, which are secreted by the pancreas.
Hormones with opposite effects that counteract one another.

cards.term: Role of Insulin in Blood Sugar Regulation
cards.definition: Causes liver and muscle cells to increase their uptake of glucose from the blood, which is then converted into glycogen, a storage molecule.

cards.term: Role of Glucagon in Blood Sugar Regulation
cards.definition: Causes the breakdown of glycogen to glucose in the liver, releasing glucose into the blood.

cards.term: Control of Blood Glucose Concentration as Negative Feedback
cards.definition: A negative feedback system.

cards.term: Response to High Blood Glucose Concentration
cards.definition:
1. Pancreas secretes insulin and stops producing glucagon.
2. Liver and muscle cells increase uptake of glucose.
3. Glucose is converted to glycogen and stored. Some glucose may be stored as lipid in tissues.
4. Blood glucose concentration decreases, returning to normal level.

cards.term: Response to Low Blood Glucose Concentration
cards.definition:
1. Blood glucose concentration decreases below a set point.
2. Pancreas secretes glucagon and stops producing insulin.
3. Liver cells convert glycogen into glucose, which is released into the blood.
4. Blood glucose concentration increases, returning to normal level.
A condition where the homeostatic control of blood glucose levels stops working.
Pancreas does not produce enough insulin.

1. Daily insulin injections at meal times.
2. Limiting intake of refined sugars.
3. Regular exercise.
Person develops insulin resistance or doesn't produce enough insulin (often due to obesity).

1. Balanced diet (eating fewer simple sugars and replacing them with more complex carbohydrates).
2. Exercise.
3. Medication or insulin injections (however, these are less effective).
Exercise increases respiration in muscle cells. Excess glucose is removed from the blood to produce energy in the form of ATP.

cards.term: Advantage of Complex Carbohydrates over Simple Carbohydrates for Type 2 Diabetics
cards.definition: Simple carbohydrates are broken down quickly so can raise blood glucose levels rapidly. Complex carbohydrates take longer to break down so have a reduced effect on blood glucose levels.
A value based on height and mass used to categorize an individual as underweight, normal weight, overweight, or obese.
mass (kg) / (height (m))^2

cards.term: BMI Values Indicating Obesity and Increased Risk of Type 2 Diabetes
cards.definition: BMI value larger than 30.
waist circumference (cm) / hip circumference (cm)
A waist-to-hip ratio higher than 1.0 in males or 0.85 in females indicates abdominal obesity and an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
The maintenance of constant water levels in the body fluids of an organism.
Prevents cells bursting or shrinking when water enters or leaves by osmosis.

cards.term: Effect of Higher Water Concentration Solution on Animal Cell
cards.definition: Higher concentration of water in surrounding solution leads to water molecules moving down their concentration gradient into the cell by osmosis, causing pressure inside the cell to increase, resulting in cell bursting (lysis).

cards.term: Effect of Lower Water Concentration Solution on Animal Cell
cards.definition: Lower concentration of water in surrounding solution leads to water molecules moving down their concentration gradient out of the cell by osmosis, causing pressure inside the cell to decrease, resulting in cell shrinking (crenation).

cards.term: Effect of Equal Water Concentration Solution on Animal Cell
cards.definition: No net movement of water molecules into or out of the cell.
Removes toxic waste substances from the body, alters blood water levels, and alters blood ion levels.
Waste product of the kidney that contains urea, excess water, and excess ions.
In the liver, urea is produced from the breakdown of excess amino acids.
Supplies blood to the kidneys.
Drains blood from the kidneys.
Takes urine to the bladder from the kidneys.
Releases urine from the bladder, out of the body.
Functional unit of the kidney where filtration and selective reabsorption take place.
Blood flows through the glomerulus under high pressure. Small molecules (e.g., urea, glucose), water, and ions are filtered out of the blood and into the Bowman's capsule of the nephron.

cards.term: Exclusion of Large Molecules in Filtration
cards.definition: Large molecules (e.g., red blood cells, proteins) remain in the blood as they are too large to fit through the pores in the capillary walls.

cards.term: Substances Selectively Reabsorbed from Nephron Tubule
cards.definition: All sugars, some water, and some ions.

cards.term: Fate of Molecules Not Selectively Reabsorbed
cards.definition: They travel down the kidney tubule as urine and are transported to the bladder via the ureter, where they are stored and eventually excreted from the body.

cards.term: Regulation of Water Content in Urine
cards.definition: Controlled by the release of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH) from the pituitary gland, which increases the permeability of the collecting duct walls to water, allowing more water to be reabsorbed into the blood.
Occurs when more water is reabsorbed from the collecting ducts, leaving behind a more concentrated solution of urea and ions.
Occurs when less water is reabsorbed from the collecting ducts, resulting in a higher concentration of urea and ions in the urine.

ADH binds to receptors on the cells of the collecting duct, causing them to become more permeable to water. This allows more water to be reabsorbed from the urine into the bloodstream, reducing urine volume and increasing its concentration.

cards.term: Regulation of Blood Ion Levels by Kidneys
cards.definition: Regulated by the selective reabsorption and secretion of ions (e.g., sodium, potassium) in the nephron tubules.

cards.term: Role of Aldosterone in Blood Ion Regulation
cards.definition: Secreted by the adrenal glands, aldosterone stimulates the reabsorption of sodium ions and water from the nephron tubules back into the bloodstream, while increasing the secretion of potassium ions into the urine.
A hormone system that regulates blood pressure and water balance.

1. Decreased blood pressure detected by juxtaglomerular apparatus in kidney.
2. Juxtaglomerular apparatus secretes renin into bloodstream.
3. Renin converts angiotensinogen (from liver) into angiotensin I.
4. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) converts angiotensin I into angiotensin II.
5. Angiotensin II stimulates secretion of aldosterone from adrenal glands.
Increases blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction of blood vessels and stimulates the release of aldosterone.
Increases reabsorption of sodium ions and water in the nephron tubules, leading to increased blood volume and pressure, while promoting the excretion of potassium ions.

cards.term: Why do large multicellular organisms require specialised exchange surfaces?
cards.definition:
Large SA/V ratio

Diffusion insufficient to provide all cells with the required oxygen and nutrients, and to remove all waste products

Exchange surfaces increase rate of diffusion and shorten diffusion distance

cards.term: Why do some multicellular organisms (e.g. trees) not require specialised exchange surfaces?
cards.definition:
Trees have a large number of leaves

which provide a large SA/V ratio for diffusion.

cards.term: How does the size of an organism affect its surface area to volume ratio?
cards.definition: The larger the organism, the smaller the SA/V ratio.

cards.term: Calculate the surface area to volume ratio of a cube that is 1x 1x 1 cm
cards.definition: Surface area : Volume = 6:1

cards.term: Calculate the surface area to volume ratio of a cube that is 2x3x4 cm
cards.definition: Surface area : Volume = 13:6

cards.term: Name some of the substances transported into and out of the human body
cards.definition:
Oxygen

Carbon dioxide

Water

Dissolved food molecules
Urea

cards.term: How does oxygen enter and carbon dioxide leave cells?
cards.definition: They diffuse into and out of cells.
It diffuses into cells by osmosis.

cards.term: How do food molecules and mineral ions enter cells?
cards.definition: They are dissolved in water which diffuses into cells.

cards.term: Why must urea be excreted from the body?
cards.definition: It is a waste product so must be excreted.

cards.term: How is urea excreted from the body?
cards.definition:
Urea diffuses out of cells into the blood plasma

The kidney filters urea out of the blood

Urea is excreted in urine

cards.term: Why must the human body exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide with the environment?
cards.definition:
Oxygen is required for respiration so diffuses into the body

Carbon dioxide is a toxic waste product of respiration so diffuses out of the body

cards.term: How does oxygen enter and carbon dioxide leave the bloodstream?
cards.definition:
Oxygen diffuses from air in the alveoli (high O, conc) into blood in the capillaries (low O, conc)

Carbon dioxide diffuses from blood in the capillaries (high CO, conc) into air in the alveoli (low CO, conc)

cards.term: How are alveoli adapted for gaseous exchange? (6)
cards.definition:
Large surface area

Network of capillaries provide a good blood supply

Rapid blood flow maintains a steep concentration gradient

Thin walls give a short diffusion distance

Cell walls have partially permeable membranes enabling diffusion

Moist lining, enables gases to dissolve

cards.term: What factors affect the rate of diffusion? (3) (biology only)
cards.definition:
Diffusion distance

Concentration gradient

Surface area

cards.term: How does diffusion distance affect the rate of diffusion? (biology only)
cards.definition: The greater the diffusion distance, the further the molecules must travel and the slower the rate of diffusion.

cards.term: How does concentration gradient affect the rate of diffusion? (biology only)
cards.definition: The steeper the concentration gradient, the faster the rate of diffusion.

cards.term: How does surface area affect the rate of diffusion? (biology only)
cards.definition: The larger the surface area, the greater the number of molecules that can diffuse across in a given time, so the faster the rate of diffusion.

cards.term: How can the rate of diffusion be calculated? (biology only)
cards.definition:
Using Ficks law:

surface area x concentration gradient

rate of diffusion  thickness of membrane

Network of organs and vessels

Enables the flow of blood and transport of oxygen, carbon dioxide, nutrients and other molecules around the body

cards.term: What are the main components of blood?
cards.definition:
Red blood cells
White blood cells
Platelets
Plasma

cards.term: What are red blood cells also known as?
cards.definition: Erythrocytes

cards.term: What is the function of red blood cells?
cards.definition:
Transport O2 from lungs to tissues
Transport CO2 from tissues to lungs

cards.term: How do red blood cells transport oxygen to body cells?
cards.definition:
Lungs, haemoglobin in RBCs binds reversibly with oxygen to form oxyhaemoglobin
Tissues, oxyhaemoglobin breaks down to form haemoglobin and oxygen which diffuses into cells

cards.term: How are red blood cells adapted to their function?
cards.definition:
Biconcave disk gives large SA/V ratio, increasing diffusion rate
Lack nucleus, allowing more space for haemoglobin molecules (increases oxygen carrying capacity of the cell)
Small and flexible so they can squeeze through capillaries
Thin giving a short diffusion distance

cards.term: What is the function of white blood cells?
cards.definition: Provide immunological protection

cards.term: Name two types of white blood cell
cards.definition:
Phagocytes
Lymphocytes

Type of WBC
Engulf pathogens and digest them in a process known as phagocytosis

Type of WBC
Produce antibodies specific to a pathogen
Produce antitoxins to neutralise toxins

cards.term: What is the function of platelets?
cards.definition: Role in blood clotting

Pale-yellow liquid portion of the blood
Contains proteins, nutrients, waste products, hormones, antibodies etc.

cards.term: How is plasma adapted to its function?
cards.definition: Plasma consists mainly of water. This acts as a solvent, enabling the transport of materials around the body.

cards.term: What are the three main types of blood vessel?
cards.definition:
Arteries
Capillaries
Veins

cards.term: What is the function of the arteries?
cards.definition: Carry blood away from the heart under high pressure

cards.term: Describe how the arteries are adapted to their function (6)
cards.definition:
Narrow lumen maintains high pressure
Thick wall to withstand high pressure
Thick layer of smooth muscle provides strength
Thick layer of elastic fibres allow stretch and recoil
Smooth inner lining to reduce friction
No valves

cards.term: What is the function of the veins?
cards.definition: Return blood to the heart under low pressure

cards.term: Describe how the veins are adapted to their function (4)
cards.definition:
Large lumen eases blood flow
Thin wall as blood at low pressure
Thin layer of smooth muscle and elastic fibres
Valves prevent backflow of blood

cards.term: What is the function of the capillaries?
cards.definition: Allow the exchange of materials at tissues

cards.term: Describe how the capillaries are adapted to their function (4)
cards.definition:
Form large network - greater surface area for diffusion
Walls one cell thick giving a short diffusion distance
Walls permeable allowing the exchange of substances
Narrow lumen decreases diffusion distance

cards.term: Describe the double circulatory system in humans
cards.definition:
Blood flows through the heart twice in two circuits:
Pulmonary circuit
Systemic circuit

Part of the circulatory system involving the right side of the heart
Deoxygenated blood is transported to the lungs
Gaseous exchange occurs between the alveoli and capillaries in the lungs
Oxygenated blood is returned to the left side of the heart

Part of the circulatory system involving the left side of the heart
Oxygenated blood is pumped to tissues and organs around the body
Exchange of materials occurs at tissues
Deoxygenated blood returns to the right side of the heart

cards.term: Name the four chambers of the heart
cards.definition:
Left atrium
Left ventricle
Right atrium
Right ventricle

cards.term: Describe the pathway of blood around the body, naming the structures of the heart
cards.definition: Pulmonary vein - Left atrium - Left ventricle - Aorta - Body - Vena cava - Right atrium - Right ventricle - Pulmonary artery - Lungs

cards.term: Why is the left ventricle thicker than the right ventricle?
cards.definition:
It pumps blood a further distance
It must generate a greater force of contraction so blood can be pumped at a higher pressure

cards.term: What is the function of valves in the heart?
cards.definition: Prevent the backflow of blood
The volume of blood pumped out of a ventricle in one minute
The volume of blood pumped out of a ventricle in one contraction
The number of times the heart contracts in one minute
A process that releases energy in the form of ATP from the breakdown of organic compounds (e.g. glucose)

Short term energy store in all cells
Universal energy carrier

cards.term: Why must respiration occur continuously in living cells?
cards.definition: ATP is required for many essential processes in living cells e.g. movement, homeostasis and active transport.

cards.term: What type of reaction is respiration?
cards.definition: It is an exothermic reaction that releases energy in the form of heat.

cards.term: Where do plants get the glucose required for respiration?
cards.definition: They produce their own glucose during photosynthesis.

cards.term: Where do animals get the glucose required for respiration?
cards.definition: From the breakdown of carbohydrates that they have ingested

cards.term: What are the two types of respiration?
cards.definition:
Aerobic respiration
Anaerobic respiration
Respiration in the presence of oxygen that forms ATP from the breakdown of glucose

cards.term: Write the word equation for aerobic respiration
cards.definition: glucose + oxygen  carbon dioxide + water (+ATP)

cards.term: Write the symbol equation for aerobic respiration
cards.definition: C6H12O6 + 6O2  6CO2 + 6H2O (+ATP)
Respiration that takes place without oxygen and forms ATP from the breakdown of glucose

cards.term: When may anaerobic respiration take place in human cells?
cards.definition: During vigorous exercise

cards.term: When may anaerobic respiration take place in plant cells?
cards.definition: If the soil becomes waterlogged

cards.term: Write the word equation for anaerobic respiration in muscle cells
cards.definition: glucose  lactic acid (+ ATP)

cards.term: Why may anaerobic respiration in muscle cells eventually stop?
cards.definition: Lactic acid build-up inhibits anaerobic respiration

cards.term: What are the symptoms of lactic acid build-up?
cards.definition: Cramp and fatigue

cards.term: Write the word equation for anaerobic respiration in plant and yeast cells
cards.definition: glucose  ethanol + carbon dioxide (+ATP)

cards.term: Is aerobic or anaerobic respiration more efficient? Explain why
cards.definition: Aerobic respiration is more efficient as it produces more molecules of ATP than anaerobic respiration.
All organisms of the same species living with one another in a habitat
All organisms of the same species living with one another in a habitat
All of the populations of different species living together in a habitat
The community of organisms and non-living components of an area and their interactions
Organisms are dependent upon each other. A change in the population of one species can affect other populations within a community

cards.term: Examples of interdependence in a community
cards.definition: Plants depend on pollinators (e.g., bees), herbivores are dependent on plants, animals are dependent on mates
The interaction between two organisms where both benefit as a result of their relationship
The interaction between two organisms where only one organism, the parasite, benefits whilst the host does not
The non-living aspects of an ecosystem, e.g., temperature, water availability, light intensity, pollutants

cards.term: How communities are affected by environmental conditions
cards.definition: Environmental conditions (e.g., temperature, light intensity, water availability) affect the abundance and distribution of organisms within communities. For example, light intensity affects the rate of photosynthesis in producers, which serve as a source of food and shelter for other organisms.

cards.term: How communities are affected by pollutants
cards.definition: Toxic chemicals (e.g., pesticides) bioaccumulate in food chains to deadly concentrations at higher trophic levels, killing tertiary and quaternary consumers. Fertilizers that contaminate water sources can cause eutrophication, killing multiple populations within a community. Air pollution can affect the ability of some plant species to survive.
The living components of an ecosystem, e.g., competition, predation

The presence of competitors affects population distribution and size. If one species is better adapted to survive in a certain environment, it will outcompete other species, causing their populations to decline.

Predation affects prey populations within a community. For example, if the number of predators decreases, the number of prey will increase as fewer are killed. Populations of all other organisms within the food chain will also be affected.
The piece of apparatus used to measure the abundance and distribution of organisms in an area
The piece of apparatus used to study the distribution of organisms across a gradient
It describes the feeding relationships between organisms and the resultant stages of biomass transfer
The total mass of living material
The stages in a food chain
They represent the direction of biomass transfer
Producer  primary consumer  secondary consumer  tertiary consumer

cards.term: Why producers are the first trophic level
cards.definition: Producers provide all biomass for the food chain (via photosynthesis). The rest of the food chain involves the transfer of this biomass.
It represents the dry mass of living material at each trophic level of a food chain.

cards.term: Why a pyramid of biomass is almost always pyramid-shaped
cards.definition: Producers (at the bottom of the pyramid) have the greatest biomass, so they have the longest bar. As you move along the food chain (and up the pyramid), biomass is lost, so the bars decrease in length.

cards.term: Why biomass is lost between each trophic level in a food chain
cards.definition: Glucose is immediately used for respiration in plants. Respiration to generate heat energy, energy for movement, etc. Some parts of organisms are indigestible, leading to egestion and excretion.

cards.term: Why there are rarely more than four or five trophic levels in a food chain
cards.definition: Above this, there is insufficient energy to support another breeding population.
Carbon cycle, Water cycle, Nitrogen cycle
Carbon, water, and nitrogen are essential to life. There is a fixed amount of nutrients on Earth which must be constantly recycled.

cards.term: How materials cycle through the living and non-living components of an ecosystem
cards.definition: Organisms take in elements from their surroundings (e.g., soil, air). Elements are converted to complex molecules, which become biomass. Elements are transferred along food chains. Elements are returned to the environment during excretion and decomposition of dead organisms.

1. Photosynthesizing plants remove CO2 from the atmosphere. 2. Eating passes carbon compounds along a food chain. 3. Respiration in plants and animals returns CO2 to the atmosphere. 4. Organisms die and decompose. Decomposers (bacteria and fungi) break down dead material and release CO2 via respiration. Combustion of materials (e.g., wood, fossil fuels) releases CO2.

1. Energy from the sun evaporates water from sources such as lakes and oceans. Transpiration also releases water vapor. 2. Water vapor rises, cools, and condenses forming clouds. 3. Precipitation occurs. 4. Water is absorbed by the soil and taken up by roots. Some is used in photosynthesis or becomes part of the plant, entering the food chain. 5. Excretion returns water to the soil. 6. Surface runoff returns to streams, rivers, and eventually the sea.
Drinking water

cards.term: How potable water can be prepared
cards.definition: Desalination
A process that removes salts from saline water
Thermal desalination, Reverse osmosis
Saltwater is boiled. Water evaporates, rises, and condenses down a pipe. This separates pure water from salts.

Saline water is pumped into a vessel containing a partially permeable membrane at high pressure. High pressure forces water molecules to move from an area of low water concentration (high salt concentration) to an area of high water concentration (low salt concentration). Pure water is separated from salts.

cards.term: What plants use to make proteins
cards.definition: Nitrates

cards.term: Why nitrogen can't be used directly by plants to form proteins
cards.definition: Nitrogen is unreactive

cards.term: Types of bacteria involved in the nitrogen cycle
cards.definition: Decomposers, Nitrogen-fixing bacteria, Nitrifying bacteria, Denitrifying bacteria

cards.term: Role of decomposers in the nitrogen cycle
cards.definition: Break down proteins and urea into ammonia. Ammonia dissolves in solution forming ammonium ions.

cards.term: Role of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the nitrogen cycle
cards.definition: Convert nitrogen gas into ammonia. Ammonia dissolves in solution forming ammonium ions.
Soil, Root nodules of legumes

cards.term: Type of relationship between nitrogen-fixing bacteria and legumes
cards.definition: Mutualistic relationship. Plants receive ammonium ions from bacteria. Bacteria gain sugars from the plant.

cards.term: Role of nitrifying bacteria in the nitrogen cycle
cards.definition: Convert ammonium ions into nitrites. Convert nitrites into nitrates.

cards.term: Role of denitrifying bacteria in the nitrogen cycle
cards.definition: Convert nitrates into nitrogen gas

cards.term: Where denitrifying bacteria are commonly found
cards.definition: Waterlogged soils

1. Lighting and nitrogen-fixing bacteria convert nitrogen gas to ammonia, which dissolves to form ammonium ions. 2. Nitrifying bacteria convert ammonium ions to nitrate ions, which are taken up by plants and used to build proteins. 3. Feeding passes nitrogen through the food chain. 4. Organisms die and decompose. Decomposers break down proteins and urea to form ammonia, which dissolves to form ammonium ions. 5. Denitrifying bacteria convert nitrates in the soil back to nitrogen gas.

cards.term: How the amount of nitrates in the soil can be increased
cards.definition: Using fertilisers (e.g., animal manure, compost, artificial fertilisers). Crop rotation replenishes nitrates that may have been depleted by the previous crop (e.g., planting a nitrogen-fixing crop).
The breakdown of dead materials into simpler organic matter

cards.term: How decomposers break down dead matter
cards.definition: Decomposers release enzymes which catalyze the breakdown of dead material into smaller molecules.

cards.term: Factors affecting the rate of decomposition
cards.definition: Oxygen availability, Temperature, Water content

cards.term: Why oxygen is required for decomposition
cards.definition: Most decomposers require oxygen for aerobic respiration

cards.term: How the availability of oxygen affects the rate of decomposition
cards.definition: As oxygen levels increase, the rate of decomposition increases. As oxygen levels decrease, the rate of decomposition decreases.

cards.term: Why decomposition can still occur in the absence of oxygen
cards.definition: Some decomposers respire anaerobically. However, the rate of decomposition is slower as anaerobic respiration produces less energy.

cards.term: How temperature affects the rate of decomposition
cards.definition: Decomposers release enzymes. The rate is highest at 50C (optimum temperature for enzymes). At lower temperatures, enzymes work too slowly, so the rate decreases. At high temperatures, enzymes denature, and decomposition stops.

cards.term: How soil water content affects the rate of decomposition
cards.definition: Decomposers require water to survive. In moist conditions, the rate of decomposition is high. In waterlogged soils, there is little oxygen for respiration, so the rate of decomposition decreases.
Conditions that give a high rate of decomposition: plentiful supply of oxygen, warm, moist, etc.

cards.term: Methods of food storage used to slow down the rate of decomposition
cards.definition: Stored in a fridge/freezer to slow down the activity of microbes. Stored in airtight cans to prevent the entry of microorganisms. High temperatures sterilize cans, destroying any bacteria. Adding salt or sugar kills microbes (lose water by osmosis). Food kept dry to reduce the ability of microorganisms to survive.
A species whose presence or absence in an environment provides indication of environmental conditions e.g. pollution levels

cards.term: Indicator species for identifying polluted water
cards.definition: Bloodworms, Sludgeworms (adapted to live in polluted water)

cards.term: Indicator species for identifying clean water
cards.definition: Freshwater shrimps, Stonefly (sensitive to oxygen concentrations so can only survive in clean water)

cards.term: Indicator species for identifying clean air
cards.definition: Blackspot fungus found on rose leaves (sensitive to sulfur dioxide concentrations so can only survive in clean air)
Used to monitor air pollution

Sensitive to the concentration of sulfur dioxide. Different types of lichens grow in different levels of air pollution (e.g., bushy lichens grow in cleaner air than crusty lichens). Abundance and distribution of lichens indicate levels of pollution.

cards.term: Evaluation of the use of indicator species as a measure of pollution
cards.definition: Cheaper and simpler. Used to monitor pollution levels over long periods of time. However, less accurate than non-living indicators (e.g., electronic meters). Do not provide a definitive figure for pollution levels.
The variety of living organisms in an ecosystem.

Food used to feed the fish and waste can leak into water sources, causing eutrophication. Parasites from fish farms may spread and contaminate surrounding ecosystems. Other organisms may become tangled in netting.

cards.term: How the use of fertilizers affects biodiversity
cards.definition: Excess fertilizer can wash into water sources, causing eutrophication and death of many species, reducing biodiversity.

Fertilizer run-off into rivers and lakes. Nutrients build up in water. Algal bloom blocks sunlight. Aquatic plants cannot photosynthesize - less oxygen produced. They die and decompose. Decomposers further deplete oxygen levels. Animals can no longer respire aerobically so die.

cards.term: How the introduction of non-indigenous species affects biodiversity
cards.definition: They may out-compete native species, causing a reduction in population numbers. Native species may become the prey of non-indigenous species. They may bring new diseases which could kill large numbers of native species, reducing biodiversity.

cards.term: How humans can positively impact biodiversity
cards.definition: Protection of endangered species (e.g., making hunting illegal, breeding programs increase population sizes). Conservation schemes (e.g., national parks, seed banks, zoos). Reforestation. Sustainable farming (e.g., fewer pesticides). Minimizing global greenhouse gas production.
Replanting forests to help restore biodiversity
They prevent species from becoming extinct and increase population numbers, maintaining biodiversity.

Ensures future food requirements can be met, reduces damage to food chains. Increases the likelihood of species adapting to future environmental change. Many plant species are yet to be discovered and may contain chemicals that could be used in future medicines. Safeguarding valuable future resources (e.g., fuels, paper). Aesthetics - culture, ecotourism, etc. Jobs provided by ecotourism, reforestation, and conservation schemes.
Ensuring that populations have access to adequate amounts of safe and nutritious foods
Rising human population, Changing diets, New pests and pathogens, Environmental change, Sustainability

cards.term: How the rising human population affects food security
cards.definition: As human population increases, global food production must also increase in order to meet the growing demand for food.

cards.term: How changing diets affect food security
cards.definition: Greater consumption of meat and fish in wealthier populations. Less energy and biomass available from livestock than crops. Livestock use land for grazing and are fed crops that could otherwise be used for human consumption. Less food is available for humans - reduction in food security.

cards.term: How new pests and pathogens affect food security
cards.definition: Pests and pathogens can reduce or destroy crop yields, negatively impacting food security.

Unsustainable farming methods disrupt food chains, compromising the ability to meet future food requirements. Due to the high input costs, many LEDCs cannot maintain modern farming methods. Using land for biofuel production reduces land available for crops.

cards.term: How environmental change due to human activity affects food security
cards.definition: Emissions of greenhouse gases have been linked to global warming which may affect crop growth. Salinization reduces the agricultural potential of soils.

topics.title: Atomic Structure and the Periodic Table (paper1)

cards.definition: The smallest part of an element that can exist.
A substance consisting of only one type of atom.

cards.term: How are elements listed and approximately how many are there?
cards.definition: They are listed in the periodic table; there are approximately 100.

cards.term: Groups in which elements can be classified based on their properties
cards.definition: Metals and non-metals.

cards.term: New substances formed when elements combine through chemical reactions
cards.definition: Compounds.
Two or more elements combined chemically in fixed proportions which can be represented by formulae.

cards.term: Do compounds have the same properties as their constituent elements?
cards.definition: No, they have different properties.
A combination of two or more elements or compounds not chemically combined together; it does have the same chemical properties.

cards.term: Methods through which mixtures can be separated
cards.definition: Filtration, crystallisation, simple distillation, fractional distillation, and chromatography; they do not involve chemical reactions.
Used to separate liquid from a solution by boiling off the liquid, condensing it, and collecting it, allowing the pure liquid to be retained.
Technique for separation of a solid dissolved in a solvent; involves heating the solution until all the solvent evaporates or allowing the solution to cool to induce crystallization.
Technique for separation of a mixture of liquids based on their different boiling points, utilizing a fractionating column.
Used to separate an insoluble solid suspended in a liquid by passing the mixture through a filter paper, where the solid is retained while the filtrate passes through.

Used to separate a mixture of substances dissolved in a solvent based on differences in their affinity for the solvent; in paper chromatography, substances are separated as the solvent moves through the paper.
Apparatus used for separating immiscible liquids by allowing them to form distinct layers based on their densities, which can then be run off separately.
Model of the atom depicting a ball of positive charge with negative electrons embedded within it.
Model suggesting that electrons orbit the nucleus at specific distances, derived from alpha scattering experiments.

cards.term: Small positive particles discovered in the nucleus
cards.definition: Protons.

cards.term: Evidence provided by James Chadwick's work
cards.definition: The existence of neutrons in the nucleus.
A small central nucleus (made up of protons and neutrons) surrounded by electrons.

cards.term: Relative masses and charges of proton, neutron, and electron
cards.definition: Masses: 1, 1, very small; Charges: 1, 0, -1 (respectively).
They have the same number of electrons and protons.
Approximately 0.1 nanometers (nm).

cards.term: Radius of a nucleus compared to that of an atom
cards.definition: Nucleus: approximately 1 x 10^-15 meters, which is about 1/10000 of the size of an atom.

cards.term: Name given to the number of protons in the nucleus
cards.definition: Atomic number.

cards.term: Particle found in the nucleus of atoms of the same element
cards.definition: Protons.

cards.term: Majority of mass of an atom located
cards.definition: In the nucleus.
The total number of protons and neutrons in an atom.

cards.term: Calculation of number of neutrons using mass number and atomic number
cards.definition: Subtract the atomic number from the mass number.
Atoms of the same element (same proton number) that have a different number of neutrons; they have the same chemical properties due to the same electronic structure.
The average mass value which considers the mass and abundance of isotopes of an element, on a scale where the mass of C-12 is 12.

cards.term: Configurations of He, Be, F, Na, Ca (respectively)

cards.definition: Charged particles formed when atoms lose (positive ions) or gain (negative ions) electrons.

cards.term: Comparison of properties between Metals and Non-metals
cards.definition: Property: Metals - Non-metals; Boiling/melting point: High - Low; Conductivity: Heat and electricity - Don't conduct heat, electricity (with exception of graphite); Appearance: Shiny - Dull; Malleability: Yes - Brittle; Density: High - Low; Oxides: Basic - Acidic.

cards.term: Formation when a metal reacts with a non-metal
cards.definition: An ionic compound (made of positive and negative ions).

cards.term: Formation when a non-metal reacts with a non-metal
cards.definition: A molecular compound containing covalently bonded atoms; atoms share electrons instead of transferring them.

cards.term: Explanation of solute, solvent, solution, miscible, immiscible, soluble, insoluble
cards.definition: Solute: Substance dissolved in a solvent; Solvent: Substance in which the solute is dissolved; Solution: Homogeneous mixture of solute and solvent; Miscible: Substances that mix together (liquids); Immiscible: Substances that do not mix (liquids); Soluble: Able to dissolve in a solvent; Insoluble: Unable to dissolve in a solvent.
Groups.
Periods.

cards.term: Similarity of elements in the same group
cards.definition: They may have similar chemical properties, as they have the same number of outer shell electrons.

cards.term: Difference in energy levels between elements of the same period
cards.definition: They have the same number of energy levels.

cards.term: Occupation of available energy levels by electrons in an atom
cards.definition: The lowest available energy level.
The noble gases.

cards.term: Reason for the periodic table being periodic
cards.definition: Similar properties of elements occur at regular intervals.

cards.term: Effect of elements in the same group having the same number of electrons in their outer shell
cards.definition: They have similar chemical properties.

cards.term: Difference in shells between elements in the same period
cards.definition: They have the same number of shells.

cards.term: Change in shell number down a group
cards.definition: The number of shells increases.

cards.term: Reason for elements being placed in inappropriate groups in early periodic tables
cards.definition: Strict order of atomic weights was followed.

cards.term: Knowledge that allowed explanation for inaccuracies in early periodic tables
cards.definition: Isotopes.

cards.term: Action taken by Mendeleev to overcome problems with the periodic table
cards.definition: Leaving gaps and adjusting the order based on atomic weights.
Metals.
Metals.
Non-metals.
The alkali metals.
All have one electron in their outer shell; have low density; are stored under oil (to prevent reactions with oxygen or water); are soft (can be cut with knife).

cards.term: Reaction of Group 1 elements with non-metals
cards.definition: Formation of ionic compounds which are soluble white solids, sharing similarity due to all having one electron in their outer shell.

cards.term: Reaction of Group 1 elements with water
cards.definition: Release of hydrogen and formation of hydroxides, resulting in alkaline solutions; reactions are vigorous, with fizzing and movement on the water surface.

cards.term: Change in reactivity moving down Group 1
cards.definition: Reactivity increases as atoms get larger and the distance between the nucleus and the outer electrons increases, reducing attraction from the nucleus and making it easier to lose electrons.
- 7 electrons in outer shell; - Coloured vapours; - Diatomic molecules; - Formation of ionic salts with metals; - Formation of molecular compounds with non-metals.

cards.term: Group 7 elements and states of matter of molecules they form
cards.definition: - Fluorine, F: Pale yellow gas. - Chlorine, Cl: Pale green gas. - Bromine, Br: Dark brown liquid. - Iodine, I: Grey solid.

cards.term: Changes in Group 7 moving down the group
cards.definition: - Higher relative molecular mass; - Higher melting and boiling points; - Decreased reactivity, less easily gaining electrons.

cards.term: Colour change seen in reactions of halogens
cards.definition: When chlorine reacts with sodium bromide: Orange color of bromine appears; When chlorine/bromine reacts with sodium iodide: Brown color of iodine appears.

cards.term: Trend in reactivity of halogens in displacement reactions
cards.definition: Reactivity decreases down the group, as larger atoms have weaker attraction to incoming electrons.

cards.term: Comparison between Group 1 metals and Transition metals
cards.definition: Both are heat and electricity conductors, shiny when polished, and form ionic compounds with non-metals. Transition metals have higher densities, higher melting points, are less reactive, and harder than Group 1 metals.
- Ions with different charges; - Coloured compounds; - Catalytic properties.
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed in the process.

cards.term: Flame colours observed when Group 1 metals burn in oxygen
cards.definition: Crimson-red for lithium (Li), Yellow-orange for sodium (Na), Lilac for potassium (K).

cards.term: Properties of Noble gases and trend down the group
cards.definition: Non-metals, gases, low boiling points, unreactive due to full outer shells; boiling point increases down the group as atoms get heavier.

topics.title: Bonding, Structure and the Properties of Matter (paper1)

cards.definition: Ionic bonding is the electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions. It is a relatively strong attraction.

cards.term: How are ionic compounds held together?
cards.definition: They are held together in a giant lattice. It's a regular structure that extends in all directions in a substance. Electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions holds the structure together.

High melting and boiling point (strong electrostatic forces between oppositely charged ions). Do not conduct electricity when solid (ions in fixed positions). Conduct when molten or dissolved in water - ions are free to move.

cards.term: Examples of positive ions and negative ions
cards.definition: Positive: Na+, Mg2+, Al3+, Ca2+, Rb+. Negative: Cl-, Br-, SO4^2-, NO3-, OH- (chloride, bromide, sulfate, nitrate, hydroxide). Ionic compounds are electrically neutral, i.e. positive and negative charges balance each other.

cards.term: How are ionic compounds formed? (MgO case)
cards.definition: Reaction of a metal with a non-metal. Electron transfer occurs - metal gives away its outer shell electrons to non-metal. Mg is in Group II, so has 2 available outer shell electrons. O is in Group VI, so can accept 2 electrons to get a full outer shell configuration. Mg becomes Mg2+ and O becomes O2- (oxide).
Covalent bond is a shared pair of electrons between two atoms.

cards.term: Structure and properties of simple molecular covalent substances
cards.definition: Do not conduct electricity (no ions). Small molecules. Weak intermolecular forces, therefore: Low melting and boiling points.

cards.term: Change in intermolecular forces as the mass/size of the molecule increases
cards.definition: They increase. That causes melting/boiling points to increase as well (more energy needed to overcome these forces).

Polymers are very large molecules (>100s, 1000s of atoms) with atoms linked by covalent bonds. Thermosoftening polymers melt/soften when heated. There are no bonds between polymer chains. Strong intermolecular forces ensure that the structure is solid at room temperature. These forces are overcome with heating - polymer melts.

Solids, atoms covalently bonded together in a giant lattice. High melting/boiling points  strong covalent bonds. Mostly don't conduct electricity (no delocalised electrons). Examples: Diamond, graphite, silicon dioxide.

Diamond: Four strong covalent bonds for each carbon atom. Very hard (Strong bonds). Very high melting point (strong bonds). Does not conduct (no delocalised electrons). Graphite: Three covalent bonds for each carbon atom. Fullerenes: Hollow shaped molecules, based on hexagonal rings but may have 5/7-carbon rings. Nanotubes: Layers of hexagonal rings  cylindrical fullerene with high length to diameter ratio. Layers free to slide as weak intermolecular forces between layers; soft, can be used as a lubricant. Conduct thermal and electricity due to one delocalised electron per each carbon atom. High tensile strength (strong bonds). Conductivity (delocalised electrons). Graphene: A single layer of graphite.
Forces of attraction between delocalised electrons and nuclei of metal ions.

High melting/boiling points (strong forces of attraction). Good conductors of heat and electricity (delocalised electrons). Malleable, soft (layers of atoms can slide over each other whilst maintaining the attraction forces).

cards.term: Alloys and why they are harder than pure metals
cards.definition: Alloys: Mixtures of metal with other elements, usually metals. Different sizes of atoms distort the layers, so they can't slide over each other, therefore alloys are harder than pure metals.
Diamond and sand: Poor conductivity because electrons can't move. Graphite: Good conductivity as free delocalised electrons.
There are no forces between spheres and atoms, molecules, and ions are solid spheres  this is not true.
