The amount of energy needed to change state from solid to liquid or liquid to gas depends on the strength of the forces between the particles of the substance. The nature of the particles involved depends on the type of bonding and the structure of the substance. The stronger the forces between the particles, the higher the melting point and boiling point of the substance.

cards.term: Melting and boiling points of pure substances vs. mixtures
cards.definition: A pure substance will melt or boil at a fixed temperature. A mixture will melt over a range of temperatures.
Solid, liquid, and gas.
Science that studies particles that are 1 - 100nm in size.
Medicine (drug delivery systems), electronics, deodorants, sun creams (better skin coverage and more effective protection against cell damage).
Fine particles (soot), 100-2500 nm diameter. Coarse particles (dust), 2500-10^7 nm diameter.

cards.term: Properties of nanoparticles compared to bulk materials
cards.definition: Nanoparticles have properties different from those for the same materials in bulk due to their high surface area to volume ratio.
The law of conservation of mass states that no atoms are lost or made during a chemical reaction so the mass of the products equals the mass of the reactants.

cards.term: Balanced equation of magnesium reacting with hydrochloric acid
cards.definition: Mg + 2 HCl -> MgCl2 + H2
Average mass of atoms in an element taking into account masses and abundance of its isotopes, relative to 12C.
Sum of RAM's of all atoms in the formula.

cards.term: Explanation for why carbon dioxide and water escape from the test tube
cards.definition: They are both gases.

cards.term: Calculation of mean of magnesium produced

cards.definition: The number of atoms, molecules, or ions in a mole of a given substance. The value of the constant is 6.02 x 10^23.

cards.term: Formula linking mass, molecular mass, and moles
cards.definition: Mass = Mr x Moles

cards.term: Mass of 20 moles of calcium carbonate, CaCO3
Amount of carbon dioxide in moles in 0.32 g of carbon dioxide
Mass of nitrogen needed to form 6.8 tonnes of ammonia
cards.definition: 5.6 tonnes
The reactant that is completely used up in a chemical reaction, limiting the amount of products.

cards.term: Amount of oxygen given off from 40.8 g of hydrogen peroxide
Formula linking concentration, mole/mass, and volume
cards.definition: Concentration (g per dm^3) = Mass (g) / Volume (dm^3)

cards.term: Concentration of sodium hydroxide solution in mol/dm^3
cards.definition: 1.61 mol/dm^3

cards.term: Molar volume of a gas at room temperature and pressure
cards.definition: 1 mole of a gas at room temperature and pressure occupies 24 dm^3.
A technique for finding the concentration of a solution by reacting a known volume of this solution with a solution of known concentration.

1. Rinse the pipette with a solution of unknown concentration. Use the pipette to measure out the known volume of this solution.
2. Add an indicator.
3. Rinse the burette with a solution of known concentration. Discard the liquid. Use a burette to gradually add the solution of known concentration.
4. When the indicator changes color (at the end point), record the volume added.
5. Ensure concordant volume results.
6. Perform suitable calculations to find the concentration.

cards.term: Reasons why it's not always possible to obtain the theoretical amount of product in a chemical reaction
cards.definition:
1. The reaction may not go to completion because it is reversible.
2. Some of the product may be lost when it is separated from the reaction mixture.
3. Some of the reactants may react in ways different from the expected reaction (side reactions may occur).

cards.term: Percentage yield of a product in a chemical reaction
cards.definition: % Yield = (Actual mass of a product / Maximum theoretical mass of product) x 100%

cards.term: Calculation of percentage yield from given data
cards.definition: See calculation steps.

cards.term: Percentage yield of NH3 if 40.5 g NH3 is produced from 20.0 mol H2 and excess N2

cards.definition: A measure of the amount of starting materials that end up as useful products. It is a ratio of the relative formula mass of the desired product to the sum of relative formula masses of reactants.

cards.term: Comparison of atom economies of two reactions
cards.definition: Reaction II has a better atom economy (88.2%).
When a substance gains oxygen
When a substance loses oxygen

The series shows the metals in order of their reactivity. Metals above H in reactivity series react with acid to produce H2. The more reactive the metal is, the quicker and more violent reaction with acid occurs. Metals below H dont react with acids. Not all metals above H react with water - mostly Group I and II metals. Aluminium is the borderline case.
A reaction where a more reactive metal displaces a less reactive metal from a compound
In their natural state

cards.term: Extraction of metals less reactive than carbon
cards.definition: Reduction with carbon. Carbon displaces the metal in a metal oxide - gets oxidised to carbon oxides. Metal from the metal oxide gets reduced to the pure metal.

cards.term: Extraction of metals more reactive than carbon
cards.definition: By electrolysis

cards.term: Definition of oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer
cards.definition: Oxidation  loss of electrons. Reduction  gain of electrons.

cards.term: General equation for a reaction between metals and acids
cards.definition: Metal + acid  salt + hydrogen. Redox reaction, also a displacement reaction.

cards.term: Metals in the reactivity series that will react with acid
cards.definition: Those above hydrogen

cards.term: General equation for a neutralisation reaction
cards.definition: Base + acid  salt + water

cards.term: General equation for the reaction between metal carbonate and acid
cards.definition: Metal carbonate + acid  salt + water + carbon dioxide

cards.term: General equation for the reaction between metal oxides and acids
cards.definition: Metal oxide + acid  salt + water
A reaction where both oxidation and reduction occurs

cards.term: Explanation of oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer in magnesium reacting with hydrochloric acid
cards.definition: Magnesium has lost electrons and thus has been oxidised (Mg to Mg2+). The hydrogen in HCl has gained electrons and thus has been reduced (H+ to H2).
React the excess acid with some insoluble chemical (e.g. metal oxide), filter off the leftovers, crystallise the product

cards.term: What acids and alkalis produce in aqueous solutions
cards.definition: Acids produce hydrogen ions, alkalis produce hydroxide ions

cards.term: Definition of bases, acids, and alkalis
cards.definition: Bases are compounds that neutralise acids, acids produce hydrogen ions in aqueous solutions, alkalis are soluble bases - produce hydroxide ions in aqueous solutions

cards.term: pH scale and what a pH of 7 shows
cards.definition: The measure of acidity/alkalinity of a solution; neutral solution

cards.term: General equation for a neutralisation reaction in a short, ionic form
cards.definition: H+ + OH-  H2O

cards.term: Definition of strong acid and weak acid
cards.definition: Strong acid is completely ionised in aqueous solution; weak acid is only partially ionised in aqueous solution

cards.term: Effect of increasing concentration of H+ on pH
cards.definition: The pH decreases

cards.term: Definition of concentrated acid and diluted acid
cards.definition: Concentrated acid has more moles of acid per unit volume than dilute. It is not the same as strong and weak acid. Concentration refers to whether the acid is completely ionised in water (strong) or only partially (weak).

cards.term: Change in hydrogen ion concentration as pH decreases by one unit
cards.definition: Increases by a factor of 10

cards.term: Names of salts: LiNO3, K2CO3, MgBr2, BaSO4
cards.definition: Lithium nitrate, Potassium carbonate, Magnesium bromide, Barium sulfate

The passing of an electric current through ionic substances that are molten or in solution to break them down into elements; ions are discharged (they lose/gain electrons) at electrodes to produce these
The liquid/solution which conducts electricity
Cathode is the negative electrode, anode is the positive electrode

cards.term: Occurrence at the cathode and anode during electrolysis
cards.definition: Reduction occurs at the cathode. Oxidation occurs at the anode.

cards.term: Element discharged at the cathode in aqueous electrolysis
cards.definition: The less reactive element discharges at the cathode. Hydrogen is produced unless there is a less reactive metal, in which case the said metal is produced. Oxygen is produced at the anode unless the solution contains halide ions, in which case halogen molecules are produced.

cards.term: Manufacturing of aluminium and why it is expensive
cards.definition: Aluminium is made through the electrolysis of aluminium oxide and cryolite. Lots of energy is needed to produce the current in electrolysis which makes this process expensive.

cards.term: Half equations in the extraction of aluminium
cards.definition: Al3+ + 3e-  Al (cathode), 2O2-  O2 + 4e- (anode). Oxygen reacts with C of the anode producing CO2.

cards.term: Use of cryolite in manufacturing of aluminium
cards.definition: It lowers the melting point of aluminium oxide, reducing energy costs

cards.term: Half equations in electrolysis of aqueous Na2SO4
cards.definition: 2H2O + 2e-  H2 (cathode), 4OH-  2H2O + O2 + 4e-(anode)

cards.term: Half equations in electrolysis of molten and aqueous KCl
cards.definition: K+ + e-  K (cathode), 2Cl-  Cl2 + 2e- (anode), 2H2O + 2e-  H2 (cathode), 2Cl-  Cl2 + 2e- (anode), respectively

cards.term: Half equations in electrolysis of aqueous CuBr2
cards.definition: Cu2+ + 2e-  Cu (cathode), 2Br-  Br2 + 2e- (anode)
Energy is conserved in chemical reactions. The amount of energy in the universe at the end of a chemical reaction is the same as before the reaction takes place.

A reaction where energy is transferred to the surroundings so that the surroundings temperature increases  combustion, oxidation reactions and neutralisation (acid + alkali) reactions. Negative sign of energy change.

A reaction where energy is taken in from the surroundings so the surroundings temperature decreases  thermal decomposition, reaction of citric acid and sodium hydrogencarbonate. Positive sign of energy change.
Minimum amount of energy that particles need to react.
Reaction profile is a graph which shows the relative energies of reactants and product, as well as activation energy of the reaction.

cards.term: Chemical reaction in terms of bond energies
cards.definition: Energy is supplied to break bonds and energy is released when bonds are made; exothermic  energy released from forming bonds is greater than that needed to break the bonds; endothermic  energy needed to break bonds is greater than energy released making them.

cards.term: Equation to find enthalpy change in terms of bond energies
cards.definition: Energy of reaction = sum of bonds broken  sum of bonds made.
A cell is composed of two electrodes dipped in an electrolyte solution. It produces electricity from a chemical reaction.
A battery consists of two or more cells connected in series.

cards.term: Determinants of voltage obtained from a cell
cards.definition: Identities of metals used as electrodes and the identity and concentration of an electrolyte.

cards.term: Advantages and disadvantages of using cells and batteries
cards.definition: (+) more or less cheap, some are rechargeable, a convenient source of electrical energy; (-) harmful chemicals.
Rechargeable  chemical reactions are reversed when an external current is supplied; Non-rechargeable  reactants are used up, cannot be recharged.
Fuel cells are supplied by fuel and oxygen to oxidise the fuel to generate electricity.

cards.term: Overall reaction in a hydrogen fuel cell and half equations
cards.definition: Cathode: 2 H2  4H+ + 4e-, Anode: O2 + 4H+ + 4e-  2 H2O; Overall: 2 H2 + O2  2 H2O.

cards.term: Advantages and disadvantages of hydrogen fuel cells
cards.definition: Advantages: no pollutants, no recharging; Disadvantages: flammable, H2 difficult to store, fossil fuel production, toxic chemicals, expensive production of H2 by electrolysis.

topics.title: The Rate and Extent of Chemical Change (paper2)

cards.definition: Rate of reaction = amount (e.g. grams, cm) of reactant used or product formed divided by time. Rate of reaction (mol/s) = Moles of reactant used or product formed divided by time.
Various units for rate of reaction include g/s, cm/s, or mol/s. Generally, rate of reaction is expressed as mass/time, volume/time, or moles/time.

cards.term: Three common ways of measuring rate of reaction
cards.definition:
1. Loss in mass of reactants
2. Volume of gas produced
3. Time for a solution to become opaque

cards.term: Measuring rate by monitoring mass loss
cards.definition: Place the reaction flask on a balance. Record the decrease in mass in time intervals. Plot a graph of mass vs time.

cards.term: Measuring rate by monitoring volume of a gas
cards.definition: Connect a gas syringe to a reaction flask and measure the volume of gas formed in time intervals. Plot a graph of volume vs time.

cards.term: Measuring rate by monitoring the disappearance of a cross
cards.definition: Take a piece of paper, mark a cross (X) on it, and place the reaction flask on the cross. Mix the reagents and measure how long it takes for a cloudy mixture to conceal the cross.

cards.term: Finding rate of reaction at a specific time from a graph
cards.definition: Pick a point corresponding to the time 't' on the graph. Find the tangent to the curve at this point. The tangent represents the rate of reaction at that time. The steeper the tangent line, the faster the rate.

cards.term: Factors affecting the rate of a chemical reaction
cards.definition:
1. Concentration of reactants
2. Pressure of gases (volume)
3. Surface area
4. Temperature
5. Catalysts
Chemical reactions occur only when reacting particles collide with sufficient energy (equal to or greater than activation energy).

cards.term: Effect of increasing temperature on rate of reaction
cards.definition: Increasing temperature leads to faster reaction rates due to higher kinetic energy of particles, resulting in more energetic collisions and increased collision frequency.

cards.term: Effect of increasing concentration on rate of reaction
cards.definition: Increasing concentration of reactants leads to faster reaction rates due to more frequent collisions.

cards.term: Effect of increasing pressure of a gas on rate of reaction
cards.definition: Increasing pressure of reacting gases (or decreasing volume) increases the frequency of collisions, thus increasing the rate of reaction. Note: Volume and pressure are inversely proportional.

cards.term: Effect of increasing surface area on rate of reaction
cards.definition: Increasing surface area of solid reactants leads to faster reaction rates by increasing the frequency of collisions. Smaller pieces have greater surface area.
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction by providing an alternative pathway with lower activation energy. It remains unchanged at the end of the reaction.
A biological molecule that acts as a catalyst in biological systems.
A reaction where the products can react to produce the original reactants.
In a closed system, when the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate and the concentrations of reactants and products remain constant.
If a system at equilibrium experiences a change in conditions, it will shift to counteract that change and restore a new equilibrium.

cards.term: Effect of changing concentration on equilibrium position
cards.definition: Changing the concentration of reactants or products shifts the equilibrium position until a new equilibrium is reached. Increasing reactant concentration favors product formation, and vice versa.

cards.term: Effect of changing temperature on equilibrium position
cards.definition: Increasing temperature favors the formation of products in an endothermic reaction and decreases product formation in an exothermic reaction.

cards.term: Effect of changing pressure on equilibrium position
cards.definition: Increasing pressure shifts the equilibrium towards the side with fewer gas molecules, while decreasing pressure shifts it towards the side with more gas molecules.

cards.term: Effect of catalyst on equilibrium position
cards.definition: Catalysts have no effect on the position of equilibrium as they speed up both forward and backward reactions equally, leading to faster attainment of equilibrium.
A mixture of compounds; a fossil fuel consisting of the remains of ancient biomass. It is a finite resource and cannot be replaced as it is used up.
A compound made up exclusively of hydrogen and carbon atoms.
Saturated hydrocarbons of a general formula CH.
Series of compounds with the same general formula, same functional groups, and similar chemical properties.

Exothermic reaction occurring when hydrocarbons are reacted with oxygen. Complete combustion produces carbon dioxide and water, while incomplete combustion produces carbon or carbon monoxide and water.

First few in the series are gases, then change to liquids, then to solids. Boiling points and viscosity generally increase as molecules get bigger. Volatility and flammability decrease as molecules get bigger. Alkanes exhibit poor reactivity.

Process where crude oil is heated and vaporized, then vapor rises up a fractionating column. The column has varying temperatures, causing hydrocarbons to condense at different heights based on their boiling points. This separates crude oil into fractions of different sizes.
Process where large hydrocarbons are thermally broken down into smaller and useful molecules.
Thermal decomposition.
Reactant heated to vapor, passed over a hot catalyst (catalytic cracking) or heated to vapor, mixed with steam, and heated to high temperatures (steam cracking).
The products, alkanes and alkenes, are used as polymers and starting materials for synthesis.
Unsaturated hydrocarbon containing a C=C bond, with a general formula of CH.
Addition of bromine water, resulting in a color change from orange to colorless.
They burn with smoky flames due to incomplete combustion.
Atoms add across the carbon-carbon double bond, converting it into a single carbon-carbon bond. Examples include hydrogenation, hydration, and addition of halogens.
An organic compound that contains an -OH functional group.

cards.term: Characteristics of methanol, ethanol, propanol, and butanol
cards.definition: Dissolve in water to form a neutral solution, react with sodium to form hydrogen, burn in oxygen, react with carboxylic acids in the presence of an acid catalyst to form esters.
Leads to the formation of carboxylic acids.
Fuels, solvents, and drinks.

cards.term: Conditions for fermentation of glucose and reaction equation
cards.definition: 30 degrees Celsius, aqueous solution of glucose, absence of air, yeast added. Equation: CHO > 2 CHCHOH + 2 CO.
Organic compounds containing a COOH functional group.

Dissolve in water to form an acidic solution, react with metal carbonates to form carbon dioxide, react with alcohols in the presence of an acid catalyst to produce esters, react with metals to give off hydrogen gas.

cards.term: Type of acid for carboxylic acid
cards.definition: Weak acid.

cards.term: Reason for weak acidity of carboxylic acids
cards.definition: They are partially dissociated in water, thus their pH in solution is not as low as a solution of a strong acid of the same concentration.
An organic compound containing a -COO- functional group, formed from carboxylic acid and alcohol in the presence of a sulfuric acid catalyst. Esters often have a fruity smell.
A long chain molecule made by lots of smaller molecules joining together.

cards.term: Formation of polymers containing C=C bond
cards.definition: C=C bonds open up, and many smaller molecules (monomers) join together to form a chain (a polymer). This process is called 'addition polymerization'.

cards.term: Examples of addition polymers and uses
cards.definition: Polyethene - plastic bags, (Poly)tetrafluoroethene (PTFE) - teflon surfaces for use in non-stick kitchenware, (Poly)chloroethene (polyvinylchloride, PVC) - water pipes.

The smallest structure which, upon numerous translations, yields the structure of the polymer. In addition polymers, to draw it, take a monomer, change C=C to C-C, and show additional single bonds extending away from these carbons.

A polymer made in condensation polymerization. In this reaction, many molecules join together, forming the polymer and releasing a small molecule (e.g., HO, HCl). Examples include polyesters and polyamides.
Similar to the ester bond, with O replaced by N, e.g., (C=O)-NH. It contains the C=O group.
An organic compound that contains both a carboxylic acid functionality (COOH) and an amine functional group (NH).

cards.term: Formation of proteins from amino acids and polypeptides
cards.definition: By numerous condensation polymerization reactions; proteins are polymers made of amino acids (monomers). Polypeptides are also made by condensation polymerization of amino acids but are shorter than proteins. Proteins are products of many polypeptide chains bonded together.

Organic molecules made of C, H, and O, biologically relevant such as starch and cellulose. They are polymers made of glucose monomers, with differing structures depending on how the glucose molecules are joined.

Material that makes up chromosomes, cell structures that store genetic information. DNA is made of two polymer chains held together in a double helix, each chain composed of four different monomers - nucleotides.
A single element or compound, not mixed with any other substance.
A mixture of compounds in measured quantities designed as a useful product. Examples include fuels, cleaning agents, paints, medicines, alloys, fertilizers, and foods.

A technique in which a start line is drawn near the bottom of the paper, the mixture is spotted on the line, paper is hung on a rod and placed in a beaker filled with solvent. The solvent travels up the paper, separating the components based on their affinities. The stationary phase is the paper, and the mobile phase is the solvent.
Distance moved by the spot divided by distance moved by the solvent.
Indicates that the compound has a higher affinity for the solvent than for the paper.

cards.term: tests for hydrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and chlorine
cards.definition: Hydrogen: Pop with burning splint. Oxygen: Glowing splint relights. Carbon dioxide: Turns limewater milky. Chlorine: Bleaches damp litmus paper and makes it white.

Lithium compounds produce a crimson red flame. Sodium compounds produce a yellow flame. Potassium compounds produce a lilac flame. Calcium compounds produce an orange red flame. Copper compounds produce a green flame.

Copper(II) forms a blue precipitate. Iron(II) forms a dirty green precipitate. Iron(III) forms a brown precipitate. Aluminum, Calcium, and Magnesium form white precipitates, but only Aluminum dissolves in excess NaOH to form a colorless solution.
Add dilute acid, e.g., HCl. Observing fizzing indicates the release of CO2. Example reaction: Na2CO3 + 2 HCl  2 NaCl + H2O + CO2

Add a solution containing Ba2+ cations, e.g., BaCl2. A white precipitate of BaSO4 forms. Example reaction: K2SO4 + BaCl2  2 KCl + BaSO4. This test can also be thought of as a test for barium (II); adding sulfates results in a white precipitate.
Add a solution of AgNO3 (acidified with HNO3). Chlorides form a white precipitate (AgCl). Bromides form a cream precipitate (AgBr). Iodides form a yellow precipitate (AgI).
Accurate, sensitive, and rapid methods useful when the amount of sample is very small.

An instrumental method used for identifying metal ions in solution or measuring their concentration. A spectroscope measures the exact wavelength of the light emitted by a metal ion, allowing for definite identification. Concentrations are found by measuring the intensity of light emitted.
Cations are positive ions, and anions are negative ions.

cards.term: Proportions of gases in the modern atmosphere
cards.definition: Around 80% of N2, 20% of O2, small quantities of CO2, H2O, and noble gases

cards.term: Description of Earth's early atmosphere and formation
cards.definition: The Earth was hot when it was formed. There was significant volcanic activity, and gases released from these volcanoes included CO2, N2, CH4, NH3, H2O.

cards.term: Increase of oxygen in the atmosphere
cards.definition: Algae and plants produced atmospheric O2 by photosynthesis, gradually increasing O2 levels as more plants produced more oxygen.

cards.term: Decrease of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere
cards.definition: Some CO2 dissolved in oceans forming insoluble carbonates, or taken in by animals for their skeletons, eventually becoming part of sedimentary rock. Some CO2 used in photosynthesis to produce oxygen.

Greenhouse gases in the atmosphere maintain temperatures on Earth by allowing short wavelength radiation from the sun to pass through but absorbing outgoing long wavelength radiation, causing a temperature increase. Examples include water vapor, carbon dioxide, and methane.

cards.term: Necessity of the greenhouse effect for life
cards.definition: The greenhouse effect is necessary to maintain Earth's temperatures at levels suitable for life. Without it, the Earth would be too cold.

cards.term: Human activities leading to an increase in greenhouse gases
cards.definition: Carbon dioxide emissions from combustion and deforestation, methane emissions from increased farming and decomposition in landfills.

cards.term: Potential effects of global climate change
cards.definition: Sea level rise causing flooding and coastal erosion, more frequent and severe storms, changes in rainfall patterns, temperature and water stress for humans and wildlife, changes in food-producing capacity, and shifts in wildlife distribution.
The total amount of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases emitted over the full life cycle of a product, service, or event.

cards.term: Actions to reduce a carbon footprint
cards.definition: Increased use of alternative energy, energy conservation, carbon capture and storage, carbon taxes and licenses, carbon offsetting including tree planting, and achieving carbon neutrality.

cards.term: Problems of reducing the carbon footprint
cards.definition: Scientific disagreement, lack of public information and education, resistance to lifestyle changes, economic considerations, and incomplete international cooperation.
Less soot produced, more heat released per gram of fuel, no production of poisonous carbon monoxide.

Gases released include carbon dioxide, water vapor, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, oxides of nitrogen. Solid particles and unburned hydrocarbons may also be released, forming particulates in the atmosphere.

cards.term: Issues regarding sulfur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen
cards.definition: Cause respiratory problems in humans and contribute to acid rain, which damages plants and buildings.
Particulates such as carbon particles contribute to global dimming by reducing sunlight reaching the Earth's surface, and they cause health problems due to lung damage in humans.
Development that meets the needs of current generations without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

cards.term: Potable water production in the UK
cards.definition: Choosing an appropriate source of fresh water, passing the water through filter beds to remove any solids, and sterilizing to kill microbes.
Chlorine, ozone, or ultraviolet light. Chlorine requires careful monitoring due to its toxicity. Ultraviolet light avoids adding chemicals but is more expensive.
Process carried out by distillation or using membranes such as reverse osmosis, requiring large amounts of energy.
Process where seawater is passed through a membrane allowing only water molecules, requiring high pressure and significant energy.
Urban lifestyles and industrial processes produce wastewater, requiring treatment to remove organic matter and harmful microbes.
Includes screening and grit removal, sedimentation to produce sewage sludge and effluent, anaerobic digestion of sewage sludge, and aerobic biological treatment of effluent.

cards.term: Disadvantages avoided by new mining methods
cards.definition: Avoids digging, moving, and disposing of large amounts of rock associated with traditional mining.
Method using plants to absorb metal compounds from soil, harvested and burned to produce ash containing metal compounds.
Utilizes bacteria to produce leachate solutions containing metal compounds.

cards.term: Advantage and disadvantage of new mining methods
cards.definition: Less energy consumption than traditional methods, can work on low concentration ores, but slower process.
Assessing environmental impact at stages including extracting and processing raw materials, manufacturing and packaging, use and operation during its lifetime, and disposal.
End user reduction, reuse, and recycling of materials to minimize resource use, energy consumption, waste, and environmental impacts.

Advantages include less pollution, conservation of energy, less waste, landfill reduction, and local employment. Disadvantages include collection, transport issues, and difficulty in separating materials.
Corrosion prevented by applying barriers like coatings (greasing, painting, electroplating) to stop contact with air or water.
Uses a more reactive metal to corrode instead of the less reactive metal. For example, zinc used to galvanize iron.
Mixtures of metals, including bronze, brass, gold alloys, aluminium-magnesium alloys, and various steels.
Properties depend on the monomers used and the conditions of production.

cards.term: Structures of thermosoftening and thermosetting polymers
cards.definition: Thermosetting polymers have strong cross-links and don't melt. Thermosoftening polymers have weak intermolecular forces, soften on heating, and can be remoulded.
Soda-lime glass made by heating sand, sodium carbonate, and limestone. Borosilicate glass, made from sand and boron trioxide, melts at higher temperatures.
Made by shaping wet clay and heating in a furnace, used for pottery and bricks.
Fibres or fragments of one material surrounded by a binder/matrix material, used in materials like fibreglass.

cards.term: Key stages of the Haber process
cards.definition: Involves passing purified H2 and N2 gases over Fe catalyst at high temperature and pressure, reaction to form ammonia, liquefaction and removal of ammonia, and recycling of remaining gases. Ammonia used for fertilisers.

cards.term: Compromise in the Haber process conditions
cards.definition: Conditions are a compromise between rate and yield due to the exothermic nature of the reaction. Temperature and pressure are optimized to balance yield and cost.

cards.term: Uses of compounds of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium
cards.definition: Used as fertilisers to improve agricultural productivity, often combined in NPK fertilisers.
Manufactured using ammonia to produce ammonium salts, reacting with acids to produce desired compounds.

cards.term: Utilisation of phosphate rock in fertiliser production
cards.definition: Phosphate rock reacted with acids to produce phosphoric acid and various salts, essential for fertiliser production.

cards.term: John Dalton's theory about the atom - Idea 1
cards.definition: Atoms cannot be created, divided, or destroyed.

cards.term: John Dalton's theory about the atom - Idea 2
cards.definition: Atoms of the same element are exactly the same, and atoms of different elements are different.

cards.term: John Dalton's theory about the atom - Idea 3
cards.definition: Atoms join with other atoms to make new substances.

cards.term: Discovery that caused the original Dalton model of an atom to change
cards.definition: The discovery of subatomic particles.

cards.term: How JJ Thomson discovered the electron
cards.definition: Thomson experimented with a cathode ray tube. The beam moved towards the positively charged plate, so he knew that the particles must have a negative charge.

cards.term: Atomic model proposed by JJ Thomson
cards.definition: Plum pudding model. Negatively charged electrons scattered through a positively charged material.

cards.term: Discovery from Ernest Rutherford's gold foil experiment
cards.definition: Most of the particles passed straight through, suggesting that atoms were mostly empty space. A few particles were deflected or bounced back, indicating a tiny, dense, and positively-charged nucleus.

cards.term: Rutherford's new model of the atom
cards.definition: Mass is concentrated in the central nucleus. Mostly empty space. Electrons travel in random paths around the nucleus.
Small central nucleus made up of protons and neutrons. Electrons orbit (move around) the nucleus in shells.

cards.term: Radius of the nucleus and its comparison to the atomic radius
cards.definition: The radius of the nucleus is 1x10^-15 m, which is 1/10000 of the atomic radius.

cards.term: Relative masses of protons, neutrons, and electrons
cards.definition: Proton: 1, Neutron: 1, Electron: 1/1836

cards.term: Relative charges of protons, neutrons, and electrons
cards.definition: Proton: +1, Neutron: 0, Electron: -1

cards.term: Reason atoms contain equal numbers of protons and electrons
cards.definition: Atoms are stable with no overall charge. Protons are positively charged and electrons are negatively charged, so for the charges to balance, the number of protons and electrons must be equal.

cards.term: Location of the mass of an atom
cards.definition: In the nucleus.

cards.term: Meaning of the atomic number of an atom
cards.definition: The number of protons.

cards.term: Meaning of the mass number of an atom
cards.definition: The mass number is the number of protons and neutrons found in the nucleus of an atom.

cards.term: Statement about the similarity of atoms of the same element
cards.definition: Atoms of the same element have the same number of protons in the nucleus, and this is unique to that element.
Isotopes are atoms with the same number of protons (so they are the same element) but a different number of neutrons. Isotopes of an element have the same atomic number but different mass numbers.

cards.term: Protons, electrons, and neutrons in Boron with atomic number 5 and mass number 11
cards.definition: 5 protons, 5 electrons, 6 neutrons.

cards.term: Reason for relative atomic mass not always being a whole number
cards.definition: Different isotopes of the same element have different mass numbers. The relative atomic mass is an average of the masses of all these isotopes.

cards.term: Values required to calculate the relative atomic mass of chlorine
cards.definition: Mass numbers and relative abundances of all the isotopes of chlorine.

cards.term: Arrangement of elements in Mendeleev's periodic table
cards.definition: Elements arranged with increasing atomic masses. Elements with similar properties put into groups due to periodic trends in chemical properties. Switched the position of some elements. Gaps left for undiscovered elements.

cards.term: How Mendeleev predicted the properties of new elements
cards.definition: Mendeleev left gaps in his periodic table and used the properties of elements next to these gaps to predict the properties of undiscovered elements.

cards.term: Reason for the inaccuracy of Mendeleev's table
cards.definition: Isotopes were poorly understood at the time. Protons and neutrons had not yet been discovered.

cards.term: Arrangement of elements in the modern periodic table
cards.definition: In order of increasing atomic number.

cards.term: Reason elements in the same group have similar chemical properties
cards.definition: Same number of outer shell electrons. Number of outer shell electrons determines how an atom reacts.

cards.term: Information provided by the period (row) number in the periodic table
cards.definition: Elements in the same period have the same number of electron shells. For example, all elements in period 4 have 4 shells of electrons.

cards.term: Information provided by the group (column) number in the periodic table
cards.definition: All elements in the same group have the same number of outer electrons. For example, all elements in group 2 have 2 electrons in their outer shell.

cards.term: Location of metals on the periodic table
cards.definition: Left-hand side.

cards.term: Determination of whether an element is a metal or non-metal
cards.definition: Atomic structures of the elements.

cards.term: Maximum number of electrons allowed in each of the first 3 shells
cards.definition: 1st shell: 2, 2nd shell: 8, 3rd shell: 8

cards.term: Condition for atoms to be most stable
cards.definition: When they have full electron shells.

cards.term: Relation between electron configuration and position in the periodic table
cards.definition: The number of rings is the period. The number of electrons in the outer ring is the group. The total number of electrons is the atomic number.
A bond between a metal and non-metal involving the transfer of electrons.

cards.term: Description of what happens to the metal and non-metal when an ionic bond forms in terms of electrons
cards.definition: The metal atom loses electrons to become a positively charged ion (cation). The non-metal gains electrons to become a negatively charged ion (anion).
An ion is an atom or group of atoms with a positive or negative charge.

cards.term: Explanation of whether a positively charged ion has lost or gained electrons
cards.definition: It has lost electrons. There are fewer negatively charged electrons to cancel out the charge of the positive protons, resulting in an overall positive charge.

cards.term: Protons, neutrons, and electrons in Na+ (Atomic number: 11, Mass number: 23)
cards.definition: Protons: 11, Electrons: 10, Neutrons: 12

cards.term: Protons, neutrons, and electrons in O2- (Atomic number: 8, Mass number: 16)
cards.definition: Protons: 8, Electrons: 10, Neutrons: 8

cards.term: Reason elements in groups 1, 2, 6, and 7 readily form ions
cards.definition: To become more stable and achieve the electron structure of the noble gases (group 8).

cards.term: Type of ions formed by elements in group 1 and 2
cards.definition: Cations (positive). Group 1 metals will form 1+ ions, and group 2 metals will form 2+ ions.

cards.term: Type of ions formed by elements in groups 6 and 7
cards.definition: They are non-metals, so they form anions (negative). Group 6 will form 2- ions, and group 7 will form 1- ions.

cards.term: Meaning if an ionic compound ends in -ide
cards.definition: The compound contains 2 elements.

cards.term: Meaning if an ionic compound ends in -ate
cards.definition: The compound contains at least three elements, one of which is oxygen.
Lattice structure. Regular arrangement of ions. Ions held together by strong electrostatic forces between ions with opposite charges.
Na2O. Charges must balance, so 2 sodium ions are required.
Mg(OH)2. Charges must balance, so 2 hydroxide ions are required.
A bond formed when an electron pair is shared between two atoms.
A molecule.

cards.term: Accuracy of the statement 'Covalent bonds are weak'
cards.definition: FALSE. Covalent bonds are strong.

cards.term: Comparison of size between an atom and a molecule
cards.definition: An atom is smaller. Simple molecules consist of atoms joined by strong covalent bonds within the molecule.

cards.term: Reason for the high melting points of ionic compounds
cards.definition: Strong electrostatic attraction between the positive and negative ions requires a lot of energy to overcome.

cards.term: Conditions under which ionic compounds conduct electricity
cards.definition: When molten or aqueous (dissolved in water) because the ions are charged and free to move. When solid, the ions are fixed in an ionic lattice so can't move.

cards.term: Reason for the low melting and boiling points of simple molecular compounds
cards.definition: They have weak intermolecular forces (forces between molecules) which only require a little energy to overcome.

cards.term: Ability of simple molecular compounds to conduct electricity
cards.definition: No because there are no charged particles.

cards.term: Melting point of giant covalent structures
cards.definition: High because they have lots of strong covalent bonds which require a lot of energy to break.

cards.term: How metals conduct electricity and heat
cards.definition: The positive ions are fixed in a sea of delocalised electrons. These electrons are free to move and carry charge or energy.

cards.term: Accuracy of the statement 'Metals are insoluble in water'
cards.definition: TRUE.

cards.term: Two giant covalent structures formed from carbon atoms
cards.definition: Graphite and Diamond.

cards.term: Structure and properties relating to graphite
cards.definition: Each carbon atom bonded to 3 other carbon atoms. Layers of hexagonal rings of carbon atoms. Weak intermolecular forces between layers. One delocalised electron per carbon atom.

Graphite is soft/slippery because there are only weak intermolecular forces between layers which allow the layers to slide over one another. Graphite conducts electricity because there is one delocalised electron per carbon atom. The delocalised electrons are mobile charges.
All carbon atoms are covalently bonded to four other carbon atoms. No delocalised electrons.
Very hard. Very high melting point. Doesn't conduct electricity as there are no charged particles.
Electrodes because graphite conducts electricity and has a high melting point. Lubricant because it's slippery (the layers in graphite can slide over each other).

cards.term: Use of diamond in cutting tools
cards.definition: It's very hard.
A molecule made of carbon, shaped like a closed tube or hollow ball.
Graphene and C60 (buckminsterfullerene).
Slippery due to weak intermolecular forces. Low melting point. Spherical. Strong covalent bonds between carbon atoms in a molecule. Large surface area.
High melting point due to covalent bonding between carbon atoms. Conducts electricity because it has delocalised electrons.
It is extremely strong and has delocalised electrons which are free to move and carry charge. It is only one atom thick as it is a single layer of graphite.
Long chain molecules formed from many monomers.

cards.term: Bond formed between carbon atoms in polymer molecules
cards.definition: Covalent bonds.
High melting point. High density. Good conductors of electricity. Malleable and ductile. Generally shiny.

cards.term: Explanation of why metals are malleable
cards.definition: The atoms are arranged in uniform rows which can slide over one another.

cards.term: Explanation of why metals can conduct electricity
cards.definition: The electrons in the metal are charges that can move.
Low boiling points. Poor conductors of electricity. Brittle when solid.

cards.term: Limitations of dot and cross, 2D diagrams, and 3D diagrams in representing ionic compounds
cards.definition: Dot and cross: No lattice structure or ionic bonds. 2D diagrams: Only shows one layer, doesn't show formation of ions. 3D diagrams: Shows spaces between the ions, doesn't show charges.

cards.term: Limitations of dot and cross and ball and stick models in representing covalent molecules
cards.definition: Dot and cross: Doesn't show relative sizes of atoms or intermolecular forces. Ball and stick: Bonds shown as sticks rather than forces, doesn't show how covalent bonds form.

cards.term: Calculation of relative formula mass of a compound
cards.definition: Add together all the relative atomic masses of the atoms in the compound.

cards.term: Definition of empirical formula and values used to calculate it
cards.definition: The empirical formula is the smallest whole number ratio of the atoms of each element in a compound. Reacting masses or percentage composition can be used to calculate the empirical formula.
Fe2O3
Actual number of atoms of each element in a compound.

cards.term: Experiment to work out the empirical formula of magnesium oxide
cards.definition: Weigh a sample of magnesium. Heat the sample in a crucible. Weigh the mass of magnesium oxide at the end. Calculate the mass of oxygen (this is the increase of mass). Calculate the moles of magnesium and oxygen using the experimental mass and relative atomic mass. Work out the whole number ratio of the number of moles of magnesium to oxygen.
No matter is lost or gained during a chemical reaction.

cards.term: Total mass of a reaction in a closed system throughout the experiment
cards.definition: Mass stays constant.

cards.term: Total mass of a reaction in an open flask throughout the experiment
cards.definition: Mass decreases as the gas escapes.

cards.term: Mass of oxygen needed in the reaction: Ca + O2 -> CaO, if 52g of calcium reacts with oxygen to form 79g of calcium oxide
cards.definition: Mass of oxygen = 79 - 52 = 27g.

cards.term: Equation linking mass, moles, and relative atomic mass
cards.definition: Mass (g) = Moles x Relative atomic mass (Mr)
Concentration(g/dm^3) = Mass(g)/Volume(dm^3)
The number of atoms, molecules, or ions in one mole of a given substance. The value of the constant is 6.02 x 10^23.

cards.term: Mass of 20 moles of calcium carbonate, CaCO3
cards.definition: Mass (g) = Moles x Relative atomic mass (Mr). Mr = 100. 20 x 100 = 2000 g.

cards.term: Formula linking the Avogadro constant, moles, and number of particles
cards.definition: Number of particles = Avogadro constant x Moles

cards.term: Number of atoms in 3 moles of copper
cards.definition: Number of atoms = Avogadro's constant x Moles = 6.02 x 10^23 x 3 = 1.81 x 10^24

cards.term: Limiting reagent in a chemical reaction
cards.definition: The chemical that is used up first in a reaction, preventing the formation of more product. Typically, an excess of one of the reactants is used to ensure that the other reactant is completely used up.

cards.term: Arrangement and movement of particles in solids
cards.definition: Tightly packed together in a regular arrangement. Vibrate in fixed positions.

cards.term: Arrangement and movement of particles in liquids
cards.definition: Close together but able to move past each other. Vibrate and move around each other.

cards.term: Arrangement and movement of particles in gases
cards.definition: Well separated with no regular arrangement. Vibrate and move freely at high speeds.

cards.term: Relative energies of particles in solids, liquids, and gases
cards.definition: Particles in a solid have the least amount of energy, and particles in a gas have the most energy.
When matter changes from one state to another due to changes in temperature or pressure.

cards.term: State changes from solid to liquid and vice versa
cards.definition: Solid to liquid: Melting; Liquid to solid: Freezing

cards.term: State changes from liquid to gas and vice versa
cards.definition: Liquid to gas: Evaporation; Gas to liquid: Condensation

cards.term: Forces between particles in solids, liquids, and gases
cards.definition: Solids - Strong forces of attraction between particles which keeps them in their fixed positions. Liquids - Weaker attractive forces than in solids. Gases - Weakest intermolecular forces so particles are in random movement.

A physical change involves changes in the forces between particles. The particles themselves remain the same and the chemical properties remain the same. A chemical change affects the chemical properties of the substance.

cards.term: Physical changes are relatively easy to reverse
cards.definition: TRUE. Relatively easy to reverse since no new product is formed during the changes of state.
The term describing when a solid changes straight into a gas.

cards.term: Particles when a solid melts into a liquid
cards.definition: When heated, the particles absorb thermal energy which is converted into kinetic energy. The particles in the solid vibrate more, causing the solid to expand until the structure breaks and becomes a liquid.

cards.term: Particles when a liquid evaporates into a gas
cards.definition: When heated, the particles in a liquid expand, and some particles on the surface gain sufficient energy to overcome the intermolecular forces and evaporate. At the boiling point, all of the liquid particles gain enough energy to evaporate.
Liquid
Contains 2 or more elements or compounds that are not chemically combined together. The chemical properties of each substance in the mixture are unchanged.
A single element or compound, not mixed with any other substance.

cards.term: Using melting point data to distinguish between pure substances and mixtures
cards.definition: Pure substances have a sharp exact melting point whereas mixtures melt over a range of temperatures since they consist of several elements / compounds.
Used to separate a solvent from a solution. It is useful for producing water from salt solution.

cards.term: When is fractional distillation used to separate mixtures?
cards.definition: Fractional distillation is used to separate a pure liquid from a mixture of liquids. These liquids must have different boiling points to be separated.

cards.term: Difference between fractional and simple distillation
cards.definition: Simple distillation is used to separate a solvent from a solution. Fractional distillation is used to separate different liquids from a mixture of liquids, using their different boiling points.

- Oil is heated until it evaporates into the fractionating column. Vapours rise up the fractionating column and condense at the different fractions, depending on the relative boiling point of each substance.

cards.term: Mixtures that can be separated using filtration
cards.definition: Filtration is used to separate an insoluble substance from a solution.

cards.term: How to separate an insoluble substance from a solution using filtration
cards.definition: Place filter paper in a funnel. Pour the solution containing an insoluble substance through the funnel into a conical flask. The insoluble substance will collect on the filter paper and the solution will collect in the conical flask.

cards.term: When is crystallisation used to separate a mixture?
cards.definition: To separate a soluble solid from a solution if the solid decomposes when heated.

cards.term: How to separate a soluble solid from a solution using crystallisation
cards.definition: Pour the solution into an evaporating dish and heat gently. When the crystals start to form, remove the dish from the heat and leave to cool. Once cold, filter the crystals out of the solution and leave them in a warm place to dry.

cards.term: Process used to identify soluble substances in a mixture
cards.definition: Chromatography

cards.term: How does paper chromatography work to separate a mixture?
cards.definition: The mobile phase (solvent) moves through the stationary phase (paper) so anything dissolved in the mobile phase will move with up the paper. Compounds interact differently with each phase so will move different distances through the stationary phase meaning they will be separated.

cards.term: How chromatography shows the composition of a mixture
cards.definition: Different colored substances in the mixture will separate as they have different solubilities in the solvent and will travel at different rates.

cards.term: Why pencil should be used to draw the line along the bottom of the chromatography paper
cards.definition: It will not affect the experiment as it is insoluble in the solvent.

cards.term: Reason for keeping the water (solvent) in the beaker for paper chromatography no deeper than 1 cm
cards.definition: If it is deeper it will wash away the substances placed on the line on the chromatography paper.

cards.term: Reason for using a lid when carrying out paper chromatography
cards.definition: To prevent the solvent from evaporating.

cards.term: Number of spots produced by a pure substance on a chromatogram and difference for an impure substance
cards.definition: Pure substances produce one spot. An impure substance contains more than one compound so will produce more spots (one spot for each chemical).
The Rf value is the ratio between the distance traveled by the dissolved substance (the solute) and the distance traveled by the solvent.
Rf = Distance traveled by substance / Distance traveled by solvent

cards.term: Where to measure the distance moved by a substance on the chromatography paper
cards.definition: Measure from the pencil baseline to the middle of the spot of the substance.

cards.term: How to use chromatography to see if a certain substance is present in a mixture
cards.definition: Run a pure sample of this substance alongside the unknown mixture. If the Rf value of the pure substance matches the value of one of the spots from the mixture, it is likely to be present.

cards.term: Substances with a higher solubility in the solvent will travel further up the chromatography paper
cards.definition: TRUE. They will stay dissolved in the solvent (mobile phase) for longer.

cards.term: Process to separate salt from a mixture of salt and sand
cards.definition: Salt is soluble in water, sand isn't. Add water to the mixture. Filter the solution to remove the insoluble sand. Evaporate the water to collect the salt crystals.

cards.term: How liquids can be separated if they have different densities
cards.definition: If liquids have different densities they will naturally separate into two layers. To separate these layers, use a flask with a tap on the bottom. Open the tap to collect the bottom liquid (has the highest density).
Safe to drink.

cards.term: Process to make waste and groundwater potable
cards.definition: 1. Sedimentation: Large insoluble particles sink to the bottom after the water is left still for a while. 2. Filtration: Removes small insoluble particles by passing the water through layers of sand and filters. 3. Chlorination: Kills bacteria and microorganisms which are too small to be removed by filtration.
Distillation: 1. Filter to remove insoluble particles. 2. Boil. 3. Cool and condense the water vapor.
Extremely expensive as it requires a lot of energy to boil large volumes of water. Wastewater is toxic due to the high concentration of salt so must be disposed of carefully.
Water that has had metallic ions (such as copper or calcium ions) removed.

cards.term: Use of deionised water in experimental analysis
cards.definition: Deionised water is used to prevent ions in the water interacting with the substances under analysis. If water wasn't deionised, false positive results may be produced.

cards.term: Which ions make aqueous solutions acidic?
cards.definition: Hydrogen ions (H+)

cards.term: Which ions make aqueous solutions alkaline?
cards.definition: Hydroxide ions (OH-)
The pH scale ranges from pH 0 to pH 14 and measures the acidity or alkalinity of a solution.

cards.term: What are pH ranges for acids and alkalis? What the OH of a neutral solution?
cards.definition: Acid - Less than pH 7 (pH 1 is strongest). Neutral - pH 7. Alkali - Greater than pH 7 (pH 14 is strongest).

cards.term: What can be used to measure pH?
cards.definition: Universal indicator, pH probe

cards.term: What colour is phenolphthalein in acid and alkali?
cards.definition: Acid - Colourless, Alkali - Pink

cards.term: What colour is methyl orange in an acid and an alkali?
cards.definition: Acid - Red, Alkali - Yellow

cards.term: What colour is blue litmus paper in an acid and an alkali?
cards.definition: Acid - Turns red, Alkali - Stays blue

cards.term: What colour is blue litmus paper in an acid and an alkali?
cards.definition: Acid - Stays red, Alkali - Turns blue

cards.term: Suggest a problem with using universal indicator to test the pH of a solution
cards.definition: The colour of the solution is matched to a pH colour chart. This is quite subjective as people may disagree with which colour the solution matches. It doesn't provide an exact pH value.

cards.term: Acid X has a pH of 1. What can you say about the concentration of hydrogen ions in acid X? (higher only)
cards.definition: There is a high concentration of hydrogen ions in the acid, making it a strong acid. The lower the pH of the acid, the higher the concentration of H+ ions.

cards.term: Alkali Y has a pH of 8.5. What can you say about the concentration of hydroxide ions in alkali Y? (higher only)
cards.definition: There is a low concentration of hydroxide ions in the alkali, making it a weak alkali. The lower the pH of the alkali, the lower the concentration of OH- ions.

cards.term: If pH decreases by one unit, what happens to the concentration hydrogen ions? (higher only)
cards.definition: The hydrogen ion concentration increases by a factor of 10.

cards.term: What is a neutralisation reaction? During an acid-alkali neutralisation reaction, what happens?
cards.definition: A neutralisation reaction is a reaction between an acid and a base. In an acid-alkali neutralisation reaction, H+ ions from the acid react with OH- ions from the alkali to form water.

cards.term: What is the ionic equation for a neutralisation reaction?
cards.definition: H+(aq) + OH-(aq) > H2O(l)

cards.term: What do the terms concentrated and dilute mean when talking about acid? Is this the same as strong/ weak acids? (higher only)
cards.definition: Concentrated acids have more moles of acid per unit volume of water than dilute acids. The concentration of an acid is not the same as strength. Strength refers to whether the acid has completely dissociated in water or not.

cards.term: An acid only partially dissociates in water. What can be said about the strength of the acid? (higher only)
cards.definition: Weak acid
Any substance that reacts with an acid to form salt and water only.

cards.term: True or false? Alkalis are insoluble bases
cards.definition: FALSE. Alkalis are soluble bases.

cards.term: What are the products when an acid reacts with a metal?
cards.definition: Salt and hydrogen. acid + metal  salt + hydrogen

cards.term: What are the products when an acid reacts with a metal oxide?
cards.definition: Salt and water. acid + metal oxide  salt + water

cards.term: What are the products when an acid reacts with a metal hydroxide?
cards.definition: Salt and water. acid + metal hydroxide  salt + water

cards.term: What are the products when an acid reacts with a metal carbonate?
cards.definition: Salt, water and carbon dioxide. Acid + metal carbonate salt + water + carbon dioxide

cards.term: Why are metal oxides normally bases rather than alkalis?
cards.definition: Metal oxides are normally insoluble. Alkalis are soluble.

cards.term: What is the name of the salt formed from magnesium and sulfuric acid?
cards.definition: Magnesium sulfate

cards.term: What is the name of the salt formed from zinc oxide and nitric acid?
cards.definition: Zinc nitrate

cards.term: What is the name of the salt formed from calcium carbonate and hydrochloric acid?
cards.definition: Calcium chloride

cards.term: Describe the chemical test for hydrogen
cards.definition: Insert a lit splint into a test tube of gas. A squeaky pop will be heard if hydrogen is present.

cards.term: Describe the chemical test for carbon dioxide
cards.definition: Bubble the gas through limewater (calcium hydroxide). Limewater turns cloudy if carbon dioxide is present.

cards.term: When a soluble salt is prepared from an acid and an insoluble reactant, why is excess of the insoluble reactant added?
cards.definition: To ensure all the acid reacts.

cards.term: When a soluble salt is prepared from an acid and an insoluble reactant, how and why is the excess reactant removed?
cards.definition: By filtration. It is removed to leave a pure solution of the salt.

cards.term: What method must be used to prepare a salt from an acid and a soluble reactant? Why?
cards.definition: Titration. Since both the reactants are soluble, a titration allows you to combine the reactants exactly and avoid adding an excess of either reactant as this would be hard to remove.

cards.term: Name the method that could be used to prepare a sample of soluble copper sulfate from insoluble copper oxide and sulfuric acid?
cards.definition: Filtration

cards.term: What 3 steps are required when producing a pure dry salt from an acid and alkali?
cards.definition: Complete a titration to find the volume of acid that reacts exactly with a set volume of alkali. Use the results from the titration to mix the acid and alkali in the correct proportions. Evaporate the water from the solution, leaving pure dry salt crystals.

cards.term: Describe how to carry out an acid-alkali titration
cards.definition: 1. Use a pipette to add a measured volume of acid to the conical flask then add a few drops of indicator. Place on a white tile. 2. Fill the burette with the alkali, noting the initial volume. 3. Add the alkali to the conical flask. First complete a rough trial to find the end point (the point at which the indicator first changes colour). 4. Repeat, adding the alkali drop by drop near the end point and swirling the flask constantly to mix. 5. Record the final volume in the burette. Repeat until you have concordant results.

cards.term: Most common chlorides are soluble. What are the two exceptions?
cards.definition: Silver chloride and lead chloride are insoluble.

cards.term: True or false? All nitrates are soluble
cards.definition: TRUE

cards.term: Fill in the gap: All common sodium, potassium and ammonium salts are
cards.definition: Soluble

cards.term: Most common sulfates are soluble. What are the three exceptions?
cards.definition: Lead sulfate, calcium sulfate and barium sulfate are insoluble.

cards.term: Most common carbonates and hydroxides are insoluble. What are the three exceptions?
cards.definition: The carbonates / hydroxides of sodium potassium and ammonium are soluble.

cards.term: What salt is produced when lead reacts with sulfuric acid? Will a precipitate form?
cards.definition: Lead sulfate. A precipitate will form because lead sulfate is insoluble.

cards.term: How could you prepare a pure, dry sample of an insoluble salt?
cards.definition: 1. Mix the two solutions required to form the salt. 2. Filter the mixture using filter paper. 3. The residue on the filter paper is the insoluble salt. 4. Wash the salt with distilled water and leave to dry.
An ionic compound in its molten or aqueous State. Aqueous - dissolved in water.

cards.term: Why can an electrolyte carry charge?
cards.definition: An ionic compound in is molten or aqueous state has mobile ions which can carry charge.
A process which uses electrical energy (from a direct current supply) to decompose electrolytes.

cards.term: What is the cathode and anode?
cards.definition: Cathode - negative electrode. Anode - positive electrode

cards.term: Where do charged ions in the electrolyte move to during electrolysis?
cards.definition: Cations (positive ions) move towards the cathode (negative electrode). Anions (negative ions) move towards the anode (positive electrode).

cards.term: What happens at the anode during electrolysis?
cards.definition: The anions (negatively charged ions) lose electrons to form their elements.

cards.term: What happens at the cathode during electrolysis?
cards.definition: Cations (positively charged ions) gain electrons to form their elements.

cards.term: Name the processes that occur at each electrode during electrolysis (higher only)
cards.definition: Anode (positive) - oxidation. Cathode (negative) - reduction.

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode in electrolysis?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Non metal. Negative electrode: Metal or hydrogen.

cards.term: How can you predict whether a metal or hydrogen will form at the negative electrode?
cards.definition: If hydrogen is above the metal in the reactivity series then the metal will form. If the metal is more reactive than hydrogen then hydrogen will form.

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of copper chloride solution?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Chlorine. Negative electrode: Copper

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of sodium sulfate solution?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Oxygen. Negative electrode: Hydrogen

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of molten lead bromide?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Bromine. Negative electrode: Hydrogen

cards.term: Predict what will be formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of molten zinc chloride
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Chlorine. Negative electrode: Zinc

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of sodium chloride solution?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Chlorine. Negative electrode: Hydrogen

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of water acidified with sulfuric acid?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Oxygen. Negative electrode: Hydrogen

cards.term: What are the half equations for the reactions occurring at the cathode and anode during the electrolysis of copper chloride? (higher only)
cards.definition: Anode: 2Cl-  Cl2 + 2e-. Cathode: Cu2+ + 2e-  Cu

cards.term: What does oxidation mean in terms of electrons? (higher only)
cards.definition: Loss of electrons

cards.term: What does reduction mean in terms of electrons? (higher only)
cards.definition: Gain of electrons

cards.term: Describe how electrolysis of copper sulfate can be used to purify copper
cards.definition: Place 2 copper electrodes into copper sulfate solution. The anode should be impure copper and cathode should be pure copper. Connect to a power supply. The copper in the impure anode is pulled towards the cathode to form pure copper. Impurities form as sludge below the anode. Cu2+ ions from copper sulfate remain in solution.

cards.term: What are the products when a metal reacts with cold water?
cards.definition: Metal hydroxide and hydrogen gas.

cards.term: What are the products when a metal reacts with steam?
cards.definition: Metal oxide and hydrogen gas.

cards.term: Write the chemical equation for the reaction that occurs when calcium reacts with cold water
cards.definition: Ca + 2H2O  Ca(OH)2 + H2

cards.term: Write the chemical equation for the reaction that occurs when zinc reacts with steam
cards.definition: Zn + H2O  ZnO + H2

cards.term: What are the products when a metal reacts with dilute acids?
cards.definition: Salt and hydrogen.

cards.term: If a metal reacts with cold water, what does it suggest about the reactivity of this metal?
cards.definition: It suggests the metal is very reactive as only the most reactive metals can react with cold water.

cards.term: A metal reacts with oxygen but not acid or cold water. What does this suggest about the reactivity of this metal?
cards.definition: Not very reactive, most metals react with oxygen.

cards.term: Name a metal which will not react with water, acid or oxygen
cards.definition: Gold

cards.term: Describe an experiment that uses displacement to compare the reactivity of two metals
cards.definition:
Add a solid metal to a salt solution (the salt must contain a different metal).

If the solid metal is more reactive, it will gradually disappear, displacing the metal that was in the salt solution.

If nothing happens, the metal in the salt is more reactive and can't be displaced.

cards.term: What would you expect to observe when magnesium is added to copper sulfate solution?
cards.definition:
The copper sulfate solution is blue.
Magnesium is more reactive than copper so when magnesium is added the blue solution decolourises and copper coats the surface of the magnesium.

cards.term: Why can a displacement reaction be called a redox reaction? Explain in terms of electron transfer (higher only)
cards.definition:
A redox reaction occurs when reduction and oxidation are taking place in the same reaction.

In a displacement reaction, the more reactive metal atoms lose electrons to form ions (oxidation) and the less reactive metal ions gain electrons to form the element (reduction).

cards.term: Fill in the gap: 'The reactivity of a metal is related to its tendency to form'
cards.definition: Cations (positive ions)

cards.term: Which metals are most easily oxidised?
cards.definition: The metals highest in the reactivity series. More reactive metals are more likely to react with water and dilute acids to form cations.

cards.term: Where are most metals extracted from?
cards.definition: From ores found in the Earth's crust.
A rock which contains metals often chemically combined with other substances.

cards.term: Which metals are found in the earth's crust as uncombined elements?
cards.definition: Unreactive metals

cards.term: Explain what oxidation means in terms of oxygen
cards.definition: Gain of oxygen

cards.term: Explain what reduction means in terms of oxygen
cards.definition: Loss of oxygen

cards.term: Most ores contain metals chemically combined with oxygen. What process must be carried out to extract the metal?
cards.definition: Reduction

cards.term: How can metals be extracted from their ores?
cards.definition:
Reduction with carbon: Can only be done if the metal is less reactive than carbon (links to reactivity series).

Electrolysis: Can be done with all metals, but requires a large amount of energy (high cost).

cards.term: How would you extract iron from its ore?
cards.definition:
Iron is less reactive than carbon so can be extracted by reduction with carbon.

Electrolysis could also be used, but this would use a lot of unnecessary energy (high cost).

cards.term: What is the chemical equation for the reduction of iron with carbon?
cards.definition: 2Fe2O3 + 3C  4Fe + 3CO2

cards.term: How can aluminium be extracted from its ore?
cards.definition:
Aluminium is more reactive than carbon so electrolysis must be used.

When the molten ore undergoes electrolysis, the metal forms at the cathode.

cards.term: When aluminium is extracted from aluminium oxide, why is it first dissolved in molten cryolite?
cards.definition: Aluminium oxide has a very high melting point. It is dissolved in molten cryolite to produce an electrolyte with a lower melting point, reducing energy usage and cost.

cards.term: How can plants be used as an alternative metal extraction method? How does it work? (higher only)
cards.definition:
Phytoextraction:

Plants are grown in areas with metals in the soil. The plants take up metals through their roots and concentrate them in their shoots and leaves. These plants are burned and the metals are removed from the ash.

cards.term: How can bacteria be used as an alternative metal extraction method? How does it work? (higher only)
cards.definition:
Bacterial extraction:

Some bacteria absorb metal compounds. These bacteria produce solutions called leachates containing the metals. Scrap iron can be used to remove the metal from the leachate.

cards.term: What are the limitations of biological methods of extraction? (higher only)
cards.definition:
- Only suitable for low grade ores with smaller quantities of metals.

- Slow processes.

- Require displacement or electrolysis for the final step.

cards.term: How is a metal's relative resistance to oxidation related to its position in the reactivity series?
cards.definition: Oxidation is the loss of electrons. Metals lower in the reactivity series are less reactive. This means they are less likely to form their cations so are more resistant to oxidation.

cards.term: What are the advantages of recycling metals?
cards.definition:
- Economically beneficial because electrolysis is expensive.

- Prevents the detrimental environmental impact of mining and extraction of new metals.

- Less waste produced so less landfill.

- Less energy required compared to electrolysis.

- More sustainable - not using up the finite resources.

- Recycling process provides employment.

cards.term: What is a life cycle assessment?
cards.definition: Analysis of the overall environmental impact that a product may have throughout its lifetime.

cards.term: What different factors does a life cycle assessment of a product consider?
cards.definition:
- Extraction and processing of raw materials.
- Manufacturing.

- Packaging and transportation.

- Use of the product.

- Disposal.

A reaction in which the products can react to form the original reactants.

Denoted by the symbol:

cards.term: How can the direction of a reversible reaction be altered?
cards.definition:
Changing the reaction conditions.

E.g. Temperature, pressure, concentration.

cards.term: What is meant by the term dynamic equilibrium?
cards.definition: Dynamic equilibrium is when the rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the backwards reaction. This means the concentration of reactants and products are constant even though compounds are continually reacting.
A system where nothing is added or removed. All reactants and products remain in the reaction vessel.

cards.term: Why is equilibrium only reached if the reaction takes place in a closed system?
cards.definition: The closed system prevents any reactants and products escaping so that they are able to react continuously.
An industrial process used to produce ammonia (for making fertilisers).

cards.term: Write the chemical equation for the reversible reaction between nitrogen and hydrogen, forming ammonia
cards.definition: N2 + 3H2  2NH3

cards.term: Where are the sources of nitrogen and hydrogen for the Haber process?
cards.definition:
Nitrogen: Extracted from the air.

Hydrogen: Obtained from natural gas.

cards.term: True or false? 'The process used to form ammonia is a reversible reaction that will never reach dynamic equilibrium'
cards.definition:
FALSE

The formation of ammonia is a reversible reaction that will reach dynamic equilibrium in a closed system.

cards.term: What conditions are used for the Haber process?
cards.definition:
- 450C temperature
- 200 atm pressure
- Iron catalyst

cards.term: Explain the effect of increasing the temperature of a reversible reaction if the forward reaction is endothermic (higher only)
cards.definition: The forward reaction is endothermic so increasing the temperature favours the forward reaction. The equilibrium will shift towards the forward reaction and the yield of the products will increase.

cards.term: Explain the effect of increasing the pressure of a reversible gaseous reaction
cards.definition: An increase in pressure will favour the reaction that produces the least number of molecules. The equilibrium position will shift towards the side that produces the fewest gaseous molecules.

cards.term: The equation for the Haber process is N2 + 3H2  2NH3. Explain the effect of increasing the pressure on the yield of ammonia (higher only)
cards.definition: Increasing the pressure will shift equilibrium to the right as there are fewer molecules of gas. The yield of ammonia will increase.

cards.term: The concentration of the reactants are increased during a reversible reaction. What effect will this have on the equilibrium position? (higher only)
cards.definition: The equilibrium will shift to the right so the product yield will increase. This will reduce the effect of the increased concentration of the reactants.

cards.term: If there are equal gaseous molecules of the reactant and product in a reversible reaction, what effect will changing the pressure have on the equilibrium position? (higher only)
cards.definition: No effect

- High melting point.
- High density.
- Form coloured compounds
- Transition metals and their compounds can be used as catalysts.

cards.term: Transition metal used as a catalyst in the Haber process
cards.definition: Iron
Oxygen reacts with the metal to form a metal oxide

cards.term: Why metal corrosion is a redox reaction
cards.definition: The metal loses electrons so is oxidised. Oxygen gains electrons so is reduced.
Rusting is the name specifically given to the corrosion of iron when it reacts to oxygen and water in the air.

cards.term: Substances needed to be excluded to prevent rusting
cards.definition:
Oxygen (O2)
Water (H2O)

cards.term: Methods to exclude oxygen and water to prevent iron rusting
cards.definition:
- Paint the metal.
- Coat the metal in oil/grease.
- Cover the metal in plastic.
- Keep the metal in a vacuum container.

cards.term: Definition of sacrificial protection and how it prevents corrosion
cards.definition: Sacrificial protection is when the metal being protected from rusting is galvanized with a more reactive metal. The outer metal will corrode first and will prevent the corrosion of the inner metal.

cards.term: Metal used in the sacrificial protection of iron
cards.definition: Zinc
A process in which a metal is coated with a layer of another metal.

- To make a metal more resistant to corrosion.
- To improve the appearance of a metal (e.g. silver plated cutlery).

Similar setup to electrolysis: The metal being coated is the cathode. The metal that will form the exterior layer is the anode. The electrolyte solution must contain ions of the metal which will form the outer coating. A power supply is connected to both electrodes.

cards.term: Reason why pure metals are generally very malleable
cards.definition: The atoms lie in uniform rows which are able to slide over one another.
An alloy is a mixture of two or more metals or a metal and another element.

cards.term: How converting a pure metal into an alloy increases its strength
cards.definition: Alloys contain several metals which will have different sized atoms. This distorts the regular arrangement of the atoms so the layers are unable to slide over one another very easily.

cards.term: Reasons why iron is alloyed with other metals to produce alloy steels
cards.definition:
Iron is relatively brittle so it is combined with other elements such as carbon produces a material with more desirable qualities.
- Low carbon steel: Malleable so used for sheeting.
- High carbon steel: Hard so used for cutting tools.
- Stainless steel: Corrosion resistant so used for cutlery.

cards.term: Key property of copper making it suitable for use in electrical cables
cards.definition: Very good electrical conductor.

cards.term: Property of aluminium making it suitable for use in aircraft
cards.definition: Low density

cards.term: Key property of gold making it suitable for use in jewellery
cards.definition: Very unreactive so resistant to corrosion. Jewellery appearance will not be affected over time.

cards.term: Definition of magnalium and its use
cards.definition: Magnalium is an alloy of magnesium and aluminium. It is lighter and stronger than aluminium and more resistant to corrosion. It is used for cars and aircraft.

cards.term: Definition of brass and its use
cards.definition: Brass is an alloy of copper and zinc. Brass is hard and resistant to corrosion. It is used for decorative hardware such as plumbing fittings.

cards.term: Calculation of concentration of a solution in mol dm^-3
cards.definition: Concentration (mol dm^-3) = moles / volume (dm^3)

cards.term: Conversion of concentration in g dm^-3 to mol dm^-3
cards.definition: Concentration (mol dm^-3) = concentration (g dm^-3) / Mr (molecular mass)

cards.term: Description of carrying out an acid-alkali titration to find the concentration of alkali
cards.definition:
