cards.term: What did Copernicus suggest about the universe?
cards.definition: That the sun is at the center and the planets orbit it.

cards.term: What did Galileo contribute to theories about the universe?
cards.definition: He used telescopes to support Copernicus' suggestions about the sun and suggested that moons orbit planets.

cards.term: Describe the orbits of moons, planets, comets, and artificial satellites.
cards.definition: They orbit in an elliptical shape.

cards.term: Explain why for a stable orbit, the radius of orbit must change if the speed changes.
cards.definition: At higher speeds, the object requires a greater centripetal force. For a greater centripetal force, the gravitational force must increase. This is achieved by the radius of the orbit being reduced.

cards.term: Explain how the force of gravity acting on a satellite affects its speed and velocity.
cards.definition: The force can alter its velocity since the direction is continually changing. It can't cause a change of speed since there is no force component in the direction of motion.
The Steady State theory says that the universe has always existed but is expanding and creating matter to counteract the loss in density.
The Big Bang theory states that the universe expanded from a very small dense point about 14 billion years ago.
A perceived increase in the wavelength of light due to the source moving away from the observer.

cards.term: What does red-shift provide evidence for?
cards.definition: The universe is expanding. This supports the Big Bang theory.

cards.term: What does the Big Bang theory suggest?
cards.definition: The entire universe started from a very small, hot and dense region in space.

cards.term: Compare the observed red-shift of two galaxies, one further away than the other.
cards.definition: The galaxy that is further away is traveling faster. The observed red-shift is greater the further away it is.

cards.term: What did scientists observe to provide evidence that the universe is expanding at an ever faster rate?
cards.definition: They observed supernovae, which suggested that galaxies are moving away at an ever faster rate.

cards.term: Prior to observations of supernovae, what was believed about the rate of expansion of the universe and why?
cards.definition: The rate of expansion was expected to occur more slowly. It was thought that gravitational forces would cause this slowing down.
Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation.

cards.term: What does CMBR provide further evidence for?
cards.definition: The Big Bang Theory. It is believed that CMBR originates from radiation produced in the big bang.

cards.term: How does the existence of CMBR support the expansion of the universe?
cards.definition: It is thought that gamma radiation was released in the Big Bang. The expansion of the universe has stretched this radiation, resulting in the microwave radiation present today.

cards.term: What factor determines the type of lifecycle a star undergoes?
cards.definition: The size of the star.

cards.term: Which two phases do all stars of the same or greater size than the sun undergo?
cards.definition: 1. Protostar phase, 2. Main sequence phase.

cards.term: What do stars like the sun become at the end of their life-cycle?
cards.definition: A black dwarf.

cards.term: What two things can stars much bigger than the sun become at the end of their lifecycle?
cards.definition: 1. Neutron star, 2. Black hole.

cards.term: What two phases do stars of similar size to the sun go through between being a main sequence star and a black dwarf?
cards.definition: 1. Red giant, 2. White dwarf.

cards.term: What two phases do stars of greater size than the sun go through between being a main sequence star and a neutron star/black hole?
cards.definition: 1. Red supergiant, 2. Supernova.

cards.term: Describe the transition of the star from the nebula stage to the main sequence.
cards.definition: The nebula increases in size until it is pulled in due to its gravity, causing gravitational potential energy to turn into kinetic energy. The collisions between particles cause this kinetic energy to turn into thermal energy. Eventually, the nebula will become dense and hot enough to begin fusion.

cards.term: What occurs when a star transitions to the main sequence star?
cards.definition: The fusion in the star releases energy. This energy balances out with the gravitational potential energy leaving the star. The star is in equilibrium so will not collapse due to gravity or expand due to radioactive behavior. It is stable.

cards.term: What happens when a star transitions to the red giant stage?
cards.definition: Once all of the hydrogen fuel has been used up, the star begins to fuse helium and other larger nuclei. This causes the star to expand and become a red giant.

cards.term: How does a red giant become a white dwarf?
cards.definition: Once all reactions have taken place, the star's gravity pulls in all of its mass, making a small, dense white dwarf. This will cool down to form a black dwarf.

cards.term: Why are telescopes located outside the Earth's atmosphere?
cards.definition: The Earth's atmosphere absorbs many electromagnetic waves, making it difficult to detect certain waves. Light pollution can make some images less clear. Telescopes in space can operate both night and day.

cards.term: What is the disadvantage of telescopes located outside the Earth's atmosphere?
cards.definition: They are difficult to maintain as they have to be repaired in space (or brought down, which is unreasonably expensive).

cards.term: What are the disadvantages of optical telescopes?
cards.definition: They can only be used at night when the sky is clear. They can't be used when the weather is cloudy etc.

cards.term: Evaluate the use of radio telescopes.
cards.definition: They are not weather dependent; for example, radio waves are not blocked by clouds so can be used in the rain. They are usually large and expensive.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed (it can only be transferred into different forms).

cards.term: Energy changes in ball thrown upwards and then returns to starting position
cards.definition:
Upwards: KE is converted to GPE
Peak: Maximum GPE, zero KE
Downwards: GPE is converted to KE
KE (Kinetic Energy), GPE (Gravitational Potential Energy)

cards.term: Changes in total energy of a kicked ball
cards.definition: The total energy of the system remains constant due to the conservation of energy.

cards.term: Energy changes in a filament light-bulb
cards.definition:
Electrical energy is transferred into light and heat energy
Light is a useful energy form, heat is waste energy

cards.term: Energy transfers for a bungee jumper
cards.definition:
When falling, the GPE is converted to KE of jumper
As the cord tightens, KE is converted and stored as Elastic Potential Energy (EPE)
At lowest point, the jumpers initial GPE equals the EPE stored in the cord

cards.term: Reason for bungee jumper slowing down when cord begins to stretch
cards.definition:
Kinetic energy decreases since it is converted to elastic potential energy
Since KE is proportional to velocity, as KE decreases, so does velocity.

cards.term: Energy changes in a power station
cards.definition:
Heat energy released in the reaction heats water to make steam
Steam moves the turbine, converting kinetic energy
Kinetic energy turns the generator
Electrical energy as the generator generates electricity

cards.term: Ways energy of a system can be changed
cards.definition:
Through work done by forces
Through electrical input
Through heating

cards.term: How energy can be changed through work done by forces
cards.definition: A force which moves an object (kinetic energy) causes work to be done over a distance.

cards.term: Equation for work done on an object
cards.definition:
Work done (J) = force (N) x distance (m)
W = Fd

cards.term: Reason why wasteful mechanical processes cause a rise in temperature of the surroundings
cards.definition: They cause energy to be transferred by heating the surroundings.

cards.term: Equation for kinetic energy and its units
cards.definition:
Energy = 1/2 x Mass x (Velocity)^2
Energy (J), Mass(kg), Velocity(m/s)

cards.term: Equation for gravitational potential energy and its units
cards.definition:
Energy = Mass x Gravitational Field Strength x Height
Energy (J), Mass(kg), Gravitational Field Strength (N/kg), Height (m)
The rate at which energy is transferred (or rate at which work is done).

cards.term: Two equations for power and their units
cards.definition:
power = energy transferred / time
power = work done / time
Energy (J), Work Done (J), Time (s)
Watt (W)
1 Joule per second (J/s).

cards.term: Meaning of a power rating of 10W for an electrical device
cards.definition: It converts 10 Joules of energy every second.

cards.term: Motor A vs. Motor B in terms of power dissipation
cards.definition: Motor A dissipates the most power. The energy transferred is the same but the time taken is less (P=E/t).
The proportion of energy that is converted usefully, rather than wasted/dissipated.
Efficiency = useful energy out / total energy in
Efficiency is a ratio so has no units, but it can be expressed as a percentage.
A push or pull acting on an object due to an interaction with another object.

cards.term: What are the two categories that all forces can be split into?
cards.definition:
1. Contact forces (objects touching)
2. Non-contact forces (objects separated)

cards.term: Give three examples of contact forces.
cards.definition:
1. Friction
2. Air resistance
3. Tension

cards.term: Give three examples of non-contact forces.
cards.definition:
1. Gravitational forces
2. Electrostatic forces
3. Magnetic forces

cards.term: Is force a vector or a scalar quantity? Why?
cards.definition:
Vector
It has both magnitude and direction

A quantity that only has a magnitude
A quantity that isn't direction dependent
A quantity that has both magnitude and direction.

cards.term: Give three examples of vector quantities.
cards.definition:
1. Velocity
2. Displacement
3. Force

Temperature
Time
Mass
Speed
Distance
Energy

Vector arrows
Length indicates magnitude
Arrow indicates direction

cards.term: How can you calculate the resultant magnitude and direction of forces using a scale drawing? (Higher)
cards.definition:
Draw the component forces as scaled arrows, joined tip-to-tail
Draw a line connecting the two open ends.
Measure the length of this line and convert into the magnitude.
Measure the angle between the resultant line and the vertical/horizontal to find the direction.

cards.term: What is an alternative name for the turning effect of a force?
cards.definition: A moment.

cards.term: State the equation used to calculate the moment of a force. Give appropriate units.
cards.definition:
Moment of force = Force x Distance
Moment (Nm), Force (N), Distance (m)

cards.term: What distance measurement is used when calculating a moment?
cards.definition: The perpendicular distance from the pivot to the line of action of the force.

cards.term: If an object is in equilibrium, what can be said about the moments acting on the object?
cards.definition: The clockwise moments are equal to the anticlockwise moments.

cards.term: How do levers make use of moments?
cards.definition: They increase the perpendicular distance of the force from the pivot, so decrease the force needed to produce the same moment.

cards.term: Will this object rotate? If so in which direction?
cards.definition: No. The clockwise and anticlockwise moments are equal, therefore the object remains in equilibrium.

cards.term: How does lubricating levers/gears improve efficiency?
cards.definition: There is less resistance; less energy Is wasted/dissipated (as heat) overcoming frictional forces.

cards.term: What three subatomic components make up an atom?
cards.definition: Electrons, Protons, Neutrons

cards.term: Describe the structure of an atom
cards.definition: Neutrons and protons in the nucleus, Electrons surrounding the nucleus in shells

cards.term: An atom contains two types of charged particles, name both of them and state their charges.
cards.definition: Proton (+1), Electron (-1)

cards.term: In a closed circuit, if there is a potential difference in the circuit there will also be a...
cards.definition: Current
As the rate of flow of charge (or electrons) around a circuit.

cards.term: What are the units of charge?
cards.definition: Coulombs, C.

cards.term: What are the two ways that a component can be connected in a circuit?
cards.definition: 1. Series (Same loop), 2. Parallel (adjacent loop)
Potential difference

cards.term: How does the potential difference across two components vary when connected in series and parallel?
cards.definition: In a series circuit the total P.D is shared between each component. In a parallel circuit the P.D across each component is the same.

cards.term: If two resistors are connected in parallel, what can be said about their combined total resistance?
cards.definition: Their total resistance is less than the smallest of the two individual resistances.

cards.term: If two resistors are connected in series, what can be said about their total resistance?
cards.definition: Their total combined resistance is equal to the sum of the two individual resistances.

cards.term: Where must a voltmeter be placed in a circuit?
cards.definition: In parallel with the component that is being measured.

cards.term: Give an equation relating potential difference with energy transferred and charge.
cards.definition: Potential difference (V) = energy transferred (J) / charge (C)

cards.term: A volt can also be described as a...
cards.definition: Joule per coulomb
The rate of flow of charge.

cards.term: State the equation linking charge, current and time. Give the units for the quantities involved.
cards.definition: Q=I*t Charge (Coulombs), Current (Amperes), Time (Seconds)

cards.term: What can be said about the value of current at any point in a single closed loop?
cards.definition: Current is the same at all points in a closed loop.

cards.term: What two factors does the current in a circuit depend on?
cards.definition: 1. Potential Difference (V), 2. Resistance (R)

cards.term: What equation should be used to calculate potential difference if current and resistance are known? State the units for all 3 quantities.
cards.definition: V=IR Potential Difference (V), Current (A), Resistance ()

cards.term: What is an ammeter and where must it be connected in a circuit?
cards.definition: An ammeter measures current. It is placed in series with the component it is required to measure.

cards.term: What happens when current reaches a junction in a circuit?
cards.definition: Current is conserved; the total current remains the same and is split between the two branches.

cards.term: How does resistance affect current in a circuit?
cards.definition: As the total resistance of a circuit increases, the current flowing through the circuit decreases.

cards.term: How can the current in a circuit be varied?
cards.definition: Using a variable resistor.

cards.term: Give the equation linking current with resistance
cards.definition: p.d. (V) = current (A) x resistance () V=IR

cards.term: How is total resistance affected by two resistors in series?
cards.definition: The total resistance increases; it is equal to the sum of the two resistors.

cards.term: How is total resistance affected by two resistors in parallel?
cards.definition: The total resistance decreases; It is less than the resistance of the resistor with the lowest resistance.

cards.term: What is an 'Ohmic Conductor'? State the condition required.
cards.definition: A conductor for which current and potential difference are directly proportional, Resistance remains constant as current changes, Temperature must be constant

cards.term: List four components for which resistance is not constant as current changes.
cards.definition: 1. Filament lamps, 2. Diodes, 3. Thermistors, 4. Light Dependant Resistors (LDRs)

cards.term: What happens to the resistance of a filament lamp as the temperature increases? Why?
cards.definition: Resistance increases, Metal ions have more kinetic energy, so vibrate more, colliding more frequently with electrons as they flow through the metal. This creates more resistance to current flow.

cards.term: What is different about current flow through a diode?
cards.definition: The current only flows in one direction, Resistance is very high in the other direction, preventing current flow.

cards.term: State what happens to the resistance of a thermistor as temperature increases.
cards.definition: The thermistors resistance decreases.

cards.term: Give two examples of when a thermistor may be used.
cards.definition: 1. In a thermostat to turn a heater on below a certain temperature, 2. In a freezer to turn on a cooler when the temperature becomes too high

cards.term: State what happens to the resistance of an LDR as light intensity decreases.
cards.definition: The LDRs resistance increases.

cards.term: Give an application for a LDR.
cards.definition: Street lamps or night lights. When light levels drop (at night), resistance increases and the light gains sufficient current to turn on.

A diode only allows current to flow in one direction. If current is flowing the right way, the resistance is large for small voltages (up until about 0.6V), but then at higher voltages becomes very small.

cards.term: What electrical component does this graph represent?
cards.definition: Diode

cards.term: What factors affect the energy transferred when charge flows through a component?
cards.definition: Amount of charge, The potential difference across the component

cards.term: Give an equation linking energy, current and p.d., giving all SI units
cards.definition: energy (J) = p.d. (V) x current (A) x time (s) E = VIt

cards.term: Define potential difference in terms of charge.
cards.definition: The work done per unit charge.

cards.term: Give an equation relating potential difference to charge
cards.definition: energy transferred (J) = charge (C) x p.d. (V) E=QV

cards.term: When an electrical current flows through a resistor why does it heat up?
cards.definition: There are collisions between the electrons and the ions in the resistors lattice. This causes a transfer of kinetic energy into thermal energy, which is released into the surroundings.

cards.term: How is total resistance affected by two resistors in series?
cards.definition: The total resistance increases; it is equal to the sum of the two resistors.

cards.term: What are some advantages of the heating effect?
cards.definition: It is useful for appliances such as toasters or electrical fires, where the heat is the desired product.

cards.term: What are some advantages and disadvantages of the heating effect?
cards.definition: The loss of energy as heat energy can make an appliance inefficient. If an appliance overheats it can catch fire or overheat, which could ruin the device or injure the user.

cards.term: The energy transferred per second is also known as...
cards.definition: Power
The rate of energy transfer, or the rate at which work is done.

cards.term: What are the units of power?
cards.definition: Watts, W.

cards.term: Give an equation linking power without p.d., giving all SI units
cards.definition: power (W) = current? (A) x resistance () P=IR

cards.term: Give equations linking power and resistance, including all SI units
cards.definition: power (W) = current? (A) x resistance () P=IR power (W) = p.d.? (V) + resistance () P=V^2/R
Direct Current. This is current which takes a constant value.

cards.term: Is mains electricity an AC supply or a DC supply? What do each of these stand for?
cards.definition: Mains electricity is an AC supply.

cards.term: What is meant by the frequency of a supply?
cards.definition: This is the rate at which an AC current changes.

cards.term: What is the frequency and voltage of the UK mains electricity supply?
cards.definition: Frequency: 50 Hz, Voltage: 230V

cards.term: What type of current do batteries and cells supply?
cards.definition: Direct current.

cards.term: What is the power rating of an appliance?
cards.definition: It shows how much energy a device converts per second.

cards.term: What wires does a typical appliance have?
cards.definition: 1. Live wire, 2. Neutral wire, 3. Earth wire

cards.term: What colour is the live wire?
cards.definition: Brown

cards.term: What colour is the neutral wire?
cards.definition: Blue

cards.term: What colour is the earth wire?
cards.definition: Green and yellow (striped)

cards.term: Explain when the Earth wire does and doesn't carry a current.
cards.definition: Under normal circumstances, no current flows through the Earth wire. Current flows when a fault occurs in the appliance (such as a surge or the casing becoming live).

cards.term: What potential is the neutral wire at?
cards.definition: 0 Volts

cards.term: State the potential difference between the live and earth wires.
cards.definition: 230 Volts

cards.term: What is the purpose of the neutral wire?
cards.definition: To complete the circuit by connecting the appliance back to the mains supply.

cards.term: For metal appliances, where is the Earth wire connected to? Why?
cards.definition: Earth wire is connected to the metal casing of the appliance. If live wire becomes touches the casing, the current will flow through the Earth wire, preventing electrocution.

cards.term: How does a fuse wire stop the device from getting damaged?
cards.definition: When the current becomes too high the fuse wire will melt and break, therefore stopping current from flowing to the appliance and preventing damage.

cards.term: Why is it important to connect a fuse or switch to the live wire?
cards.definition: When the switch is turned off, or when the fuse breaks, it will break the circuit and stop current running through the wire. This provides a method to stop current flowing into the appliance.

cards.term: Why is it dangerous to have a connection between the earth wires and the live wire?
cards.definition: In can result in a current surge, causing electrical shocks.

cards.term: What can happen when insulating materials are rubbed together?
cards.definition: They can become (statically) electrically charged.

cards.term: Why can insulators become electrically charged when rubbed together?
cards.definition: Electrons transfer from one material onto the other. The material gaining electrons becomes negatively charged. The material losing electrons becomes equally positively charged.

cards.term: What would happen when two electrically charged objects are brought close together?
cards.definition: They exert a force on each other.

cards.term: What happens when two identically charged objects are brought close together?
cards.definition: They exert a repulsive force on each other and repel.

cards.term: What happens when two oppositely charged objects are brought close together?
cards.definition: They exert an attractive force on each other and attract.

cards.term: Give an example of a non-contact force.
cards.definition: The repulsive or attractive force acting between two electrically charged objects.

cards.term: Why do we feel an electric shock?
cards.definition: When an object builds up an electrostatic charge, it needs to be earthed via a conductor. Electrons flow to/from the earth to balance the charge. This can also occur if you touch a charged object whilst you are earthed. If earthing occurs through a person/animal, it causes an electric shock.
Clouds can build up an electrostatic charge. When this charge becomes large enough, the clouds discharge via the air to the earth. This is known as lightning.

cards.term: Why does a charged balloon stick to the wall?
cards.definition: When a positively charged balloon is placed next to a wall, the positive charges near the balloon get repelled to other parts of the wall. This leaves an area of the wall with a negative charge, which attracts the positively charged balloon towards the wall, making the balloon stick. (The inverse occurs with a negatively charged balloon).

cards.term: How does earthing remove excess charge?
cards.definition: It provides a path with a low resistance for the electrons to flow either from the device or towards the device to reduce the charge build up.

cards.term: How does static electricity cause danger when fuelling cars?
cards.definition: Static charge can build up due to the friction between the pipes and the fuel. When the charge builds up, a spark may be discharged. The spark could start a fire if it reacts with the flammable fuel. This is resolved by earthing the vehicle and pump.
A region where an electric charge will experience a non-contact force.

cards.term: What direction do the field lines in an electric field point?
cards.definition: In the direction that a positive charge would move (experience a force).

cards.term: Describe the appearance of electric field lines in a parallel field.
cards.definition: Straight lines, which are parallel to each other and point from the positive plate to the negative plate. At the edges, the lines are partially curved.

cards.term: How can you use electric fields to explain static electricity?
cards.definition: The object that is statically charged will generate an electric field. This field attracts the electrons on other objects causing a flow of charge resulting in sparks.

cards.term: At which part of a magnet are the magnetic forces strongest?
cards.definition: The poles of the magnet.

cards.term: What happens when two magnets are brought close to each other?
cards.definition: They exert a force on each other.

cards.term: What type of force is exerted if two like poles of a magnet are brought near each other?
cards.definition: A repulsive, non-contact force.

cards.term: What type of force is exerted if two unlike poles of a magnet are brought near each other?
cards.definition: An attractive, non-contact force.
The region surrounding a magnet where another magnet or magnetic material experiences a non-contact force.

cards.term: What is the difference between a permanent magnet and an induced magnet?
cards.definition: A permanent magnet produces its own magnetic field. An induced magnet becomes magnetic when placed in a magnetic field.

cards.term: What type of force does induced magnetism always cause?
cards.definition: A force of attraction.

cards.term: What is the effect when an induced magnet is removed from a magnetic field?
cards.definition: The induced magnet loses most/all of its magnetism.

cards.term: Give four examples of magnetic materials.
cards.definition:
1. Iron
2. Steel
3. Cobalt
4. Nickel

cards.term: What can always be said about the force between a magnet and a magnetic material?
cards.definition: It is always attractive.

cards.term: How does the strength of a magnetic field alter as you move further away from the magnet producing it?
cards.definition: The magnetic field strength decreases the further you move away.

cards.term: In what direction does a magnetic field point?
cards.definition: In the direction of the force that a north pole would experience if placed in the field. From the north seeking pole to the south seeking pole of a magnet.

cards.term: What does a magnetic compass contain?
cards.definition: A small bar magnet that points in the direction of the Earth's magnetic field.

cards.term: What is produced when current flows through a conducting wire?
cards.definition: A magnetic field is produced around the wire.

cards.term: What determines the strength of the magnetic field around a current-carrying wire?
cards.definition: The magnitude of the current flowing through the wire.

cards.term: Does a high concentration of field lines mean the field is strong or weak?
cards.definition: Strong.

cards.term: True or false: magnetic field lines never cross each other?
cards.definition: True; they never cross, touch or overlap.

cards.term: How is a plotting compass used to map out a magnetic field?
cards.definition: Place a compass (containing a needle magnet) on a piece of paper near the field. Draw an arrow in the direction the compass points. Repeat at different points on the paper. Join the arrows to make a complete field pattern.
A coil of wire which when current passes through creates a strong magnetic field.

cards.term: Describe the magnetic field found inside a solenoid.
cards.definition: Strong and uniform.

cards.term: Is the field on the outside of a solenoid strong or weak? And why?
cards.definition: Weak. The fields from each coil cancel out, making the outside field weak.
A solenoid with an added iron core. Adding the iron core increases the strength of the magnetic field.
When a force is exerted between a magnetic field and a current-carrying conductor placed in that field.

cards.term: What rule is used to determine the force produced by the motor effect? (Higher)
cards.definition: Fleming's Left-Hand Rule

cards.term: When using Fleming's left hand rule what does the forefinger represent? (Higher)
cards.definition: The forefinger points in the direction of the magnetic field.

cards.term: When using Fleming's left hand rule what does the second finger represent? (Higher)
cards.definition: The second finger points in the direction of current flow in the conductor.

cards.term: When using Fleming's left hand rule what does the thumb represent? (Higher)
cards.definition: The thumb points in the direction of the force produced by the motor effect.

cards.term: What factors affect the size of the force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field? (Higher)
cards.definition: The magnitude of the current flowing through the conductor. The strength of the magnetic field that the conductor is placed in.

cards.term: If the direction of current in a current-carrying wire placed in a uniform magnetic field is reversed, what happens to the force? (Higher)
cards.definition: The direction of the force is reversed.

cards.term: If the strength of the current in a current-carrying wire placed in a uniform magnetic field is increased, what happens to the force? (Higher)
cards.definition: The strength of the force is increased.

cards.term: Give the equation linking force, magnetic flux density, current and length (Higher)
cards.definition: force (N) = magnetic flux density (T) x current (A) x length (m). F = BIL

cards.term: What criteria must be met for the equation linking force, magnetic flux density, current and length to hold? (Higher)
cards.definition: The conductor must be at right-angles to the magnetic field it is placed in.

cards.term: What is the unit used for magnetic flux density? (Higher)
cards.definition: Tesla, T

cards.term: If the current and the magnetic field are parallel to each other, which direction would the force act in? (Higher)
cards.definition: No force will act.

cards.term: How does an electric motor work? (Higher)
cards.definition: A coil of wire, carrying a current, is placed in a magnetic field. The forces on the two sides perpendicular to the field experience forces in opposite directions. This causes a rotational effect.

cards.term: How are electric motors kept rotating? (Higher)
cards.definition: A split ring commutator is used. This switches the current direction every half turn, which ensures that the coil keeps spinning.

cards.term: What happens when an electrical conductor moves relative to a magnetic field? (Higher)
cards.definition: A voltage (potential difference) is induced across the conductor.

cards.term: What happens to an electrical conductor when there is a change to the magnetic field that it is placed in? (Higher)
cards.definition: The voltage (potential difference) is also changed.

cards.term: How do you produce an electric current using a magnet and a conductor on a small-scale? (Higher)
cards.definition: Once a voltage is induced, if there is a complete circuit, a current will also be induced.

cards.term: How is electrical current produced on a large-scale? (Higher)
cards.definition: An electromagnet is rotated around a coil.

cards.term: What factors affect the size of an induced voltage? (Higher)
cards.definition: The number of turns on the coil of wire, how strong the magnetic field is, the speed of the movement.

cards.term: What is the requirement for an induced potential difference to cause a current flow? (Higher)
cards.definition: The conductor must form a closed loop or be part of a complete circuit.

cards.term: What can be said about the direction of the magnetic field produced by an induced current? (Higher)
cards.definition: The direction of the field is such that it opposes the change that induced the current. This change is either the movement of the conductor or a change to the field.

cards.term: What are two ways that the generator effect is used to generate different types of current? (Higher)
cards.definition: In an alternator to produce alternating-current, in a dynamo to produce direct-current.

cards.term: How does a dynamo generate current? (Higher)
cards.definition: A coil of wire rotates inside a magnetic field. A commutator is used to ensure it continues rotating in the same direction, therefore keeping the current flowing in the same direction (d.c. current).

cards.term: How is electromagnetic induction used in alternators to generate alternating current? (Higher)
cards.definition: A coil of wire rotates in a magnetic field. The end of this coil is connected to slip rings which will cause the current to change direction while rotating. This means a.c is produced.

cards.term: What electromagnetic effect does a microphone take advantage of and how? (Higher)
cards.definition: The generator effect. It converts the pressure variations in sound waves into alternating current.

cards.term: How do loudspeakers make use of the motor effect? (Higher)
cards.definition: The motor effect is used to convert variations in the current of an electrical circuit into the pressure variations which produce audible sound.

A cone wrapped in wire is connected to an a.c power supply and is placed in a permanent magnetic field. When current flows through the wire, it creates a magnetic field which interacts with the permanent field. This produces a force which causes the cone to vibrate, producing sound.

cards.term: How is the pitch of the sound from a loudspeaker changed? (Higher)
cards.definition: The frequency of the a.c current is altered. This creates a different frequency of vibration in the cone.

cards.term: How do microphones convert sound into electrical signals? (Higher)
cards.definition: Sound produces pressure variations which cause the diaphragm to vibrate. A coil of wire is connected to the diaphragm, so as the diaphragm moves, the coil also moves. Movement in a magnetic field = a p.d. is induced. As there is a complete circuit, a current is also created.

cards.term: Describe the makeup of a basic transformer. (Higher)
cards.definition: A primary coil and a secondary coil of wire wrapped around an iron core.

cards.term: Why is iron used as the core for a transformer? (Higher)
cards.definition: It is easily magnetized.
An alternating current flows through the primary coil. This induces a changing magnetic field in the core. This changing magnetic field induces an emf, which produces a current in the secondary coil.

cards.term: Why must the current flowing through the primary coil of a transformer be alternating? (Higher)
cards.definition: For current to be induced in the secondary coil, the magnetic field in the core must be continuously changing. For the magnetic field to be changing, the current in the primary coil must be alternating.

cards.term: What can be said about the electrical power input and output of a 100% efficient transformer? (Higher)
cards.definition: The electrical power input is equal to the electrical power output.

cards.term: State the power equation for transformers with a 100% efficiency (using voltage and current).
cards.definition: Vp x Ip = Vs x Is

cards.term: On a step-down transformer, does the secondary coil have more or fewer turns? (Higher)
cards.definition: The secondary coil has fewer turns.

cards.term: What is an advantage of a step-down transformer in the national grid?
cards.definition: It means that the voltage can be reduced to a value safe enough to be used in houses.

cards.term: Why is it important to have step-up transformers in the national grid?
cards.definition: It can increase efficiency. For the same power, a higher voltage will lead to a lower current (P=VxI). The lower the current, the less energy that is lost. Used for transmission across power lines.

cards.term: How does a step-up transformer work? (Higher)
cards.definition: The primary coil has fewer turns. An a.c. current produced a magnetic field in the primary coil. The iron core passes the magnetic field to the secondary coil. The magnetic field induces a higher voltage in the secondary coil. Power is conserved, so this produces a lower current.

cards.term: Where are step-up and step-down transformers used in the national grid?
cards.definition: Step-up transformers are used at power stations, whilst step-down transformers are used domestically.
The mass per unit volume of a material. Density (kg/m) = Mass (kg) / Volume (m)
A form in which matter can exist, based on the particle arrangement in a substance.

cards.term: States of matter in order of density
cards.definition: Least dense: Gas, Liquid, Most dense: Solid
The particles have some kinetic energy. They are free to move and can move around in random directions at very slow speeds.

cards.term: Movement of particles in a solid
cards.definition: The particles vibrate around a fixed position as they do not have enough kinetic energy to move freely.

cards.term: Structure of particles in a gas
cards.definition: Particles in a gas have almost no forces between them therefore they are completely free to move, and move at high speeds in random directions.

cards.term: Conserved property during a change of state
cards.definition: Mass

cards.term: Difference between change of state and chemical change
cards.definition: In a change of state, the material can return to having its previous properties if the change is reversed.
The energy stored by the particles. The sum of the total kinetic and potential energies that make up the system.

1. Raise its temperature
2. Change the state of the substance

cards.term: Factors determining temperature change of a system
cards.definition:
1. Mass of substance being heated
2. Type of material (Specific heat capacity)
3. Energy inputted into the system
When a solid turns directly into a gas.

cards.term: Difference between physical and chemical changes
cards.definition: Physical changes can be reversed. Chemical changes cannot be easily reversed.

cards.term: Effect of heating on change of state
cards.definition: Heating matter gives particles more potential energy. This energy is used to break the bonds of attraction, leading to a change of state.

cards.term: Effect of heating on temperature increase
cards.definition: It increases the amount of thermal energy in that substance. It also gives the particles more kinetic energy, meaning they move faster and their temperature increases.

cards.term: Equation for calculating energy change when a substance is heated
cards.definition: E = mcT (Energy in Joules, Mass in kilograms, Specific Heat Capacity in J/kg/C, Temperature change in C)
The amount of energy needed to increase the temperature of 1kg of a substance by 1C.
The amount of energy needed to change the state of 1kg of a substance with no change in temperature.

cards.term: Equation for energy required to change state
cards.definition: Energy (J) = Mass (kg) x Specific latent heat (J/kg). E = mL

cards.term: Pressure of a gas in terms of particle motion
cards.definition: The particles move in random directions. When they collide with the walls of a container they exert a force which acts at a right angle to the container, causing pressure.
Pressure (Pa) = Force (N) / Area (m). P = F/A

cards.term: Factor affecting average kinetic energy of gas molecules
cards.definition: The temperature of the gas. The higher the temperature, the higher the average kinetic energy of the molecules.

cards.term: Effect of increasing temperature on gas pressure at constant volume
cards.definition: Gas pressure will increase as the temperature increases.

cards.term: Explanation for pressure increase with temperature increase at constant volume
cards.definition:
1. Kinetic energy of molecules increases
2. Collisions between molecules become more frequent
3. Greater rate of change of momentum
4. Greater force and therefore pressure

cards.term: Rate of collisions comparison for gases at different pressures
cards.definition: There are more collisions per second in gas A than in gas B. The rate of collisions is higher in A.

cards.term: Force exerted by gas pressure on container walls
cards.definition: The net force acts at right-angles to each surface of the container. The force increases as pressure increases.

cards.term: Effect of increasing volume on gas pressure
cards.definition: Molecules become more spread out so rate of collision decreases. Rate of change of momentum decreases, and so force exerted on container decreases, resulting in a lower pressure.
Pascal (Pa)

cards.term: Effect of doing work on a gas
cards.definition: It increases the internal energy of the gas. This can also lead to an increase of temperature.
-273 C. Particles have no kinetic energy and do not move.

cards.term: Equation for pressure/volume for a gas with fixed mass and constant temperature
cards.definition: P1  V1 = P2  V2

cards.term: Explanation for temperature increase in bike pump when pumped
cards.definition: Work is done on a gas when it is compressed. Doing work on a gas increases its internal energy, so increases the average kinetic energy of the molecules. Temperature increases with an increase of average kinetic energy.

cards.term: How many forces are required to compress, bend or stretch an object?
cards.definition: More than one; it takes multiple forces (in different directions) to deform an object.

cards.term: Explain the relationship between the force applied and the extension of an elastic object.
cards.definition: The extension is directly proportional to the force applied, provided that the limit of proportionality is not exceeded.

cards.term: What is meant by an inelastic (plastic) deformation?
cards.definition: A deformation which results in the object being permanently changed. The object doesn't return to its original shape when the force is removed.

cards.term: State the equation relating force, spring constant and extension. Give appropriate units.
cards.definition: Force = Spring Constant x Extension. Force (N), Spring Constant (N/m), Extension (m).

cards.term: What type of energy is stored in a spring when it is stretched?
cards.definition: Elastic potential energy.

cards.term: What can extension be replaced with in the equation for spring force?
cards.definition: Compression.

cards.term: Differentiate between elastic and inelastic distortion.
cards.definition: An elastic distortion is a temporary change. The object reverts to its original shape once the forces are removed. An inelastic distortion leads to a permanent change in shape. It is irreversible.

cards.term: How can you calculate the work done/stored in stretching a spring?
cards.definition: Energy (J) = % x Spring constant (N/m) x Extension? (m7). E = %kx?

cards.term: When is there a linear relationship between force and extension?
cards.definition: When an object is deforming elastically; when it has not yet reached the limit of proportionality.

cards.term: When is there a nonlinear relationship between force and extension?
cards.definition: When the limit of proportionality has been exceeded, and the object is undergoing plastic deformation.

cards.term: What is meant by the term 'fluid'?
cards.definition: A liquid or a gas.

cards.term: In any fluid, at what angle do the forces due to pressure act on a given surface?
cards.definition: At right angles (normal to) the surface.

cards.term: State the equation used to calculate pressure. Give appropriate units.
cards.definition: Pressure (Pa) = Force (N) / Area (m7?). P=F/A

cards.term: Why does atmospheric pressure vary with the height above the earth's surface?
cards.definition: The number of air molecules decreases the higher you go. This means that the weight of air above a point decreases, meaning the pressure also decreases.

cards.term: True or False? The pressure in a fluid is determined by the fluid and the atmospheric pressure.
cards.definition: True

cards.term: What direction does pressure act in?
cards.definition: All directions.

cards.term: How does pressure in fluids increase with depth? (Higher)
cards.definition: As the depth increases the mass of the liquid above the point also increases. This means that the force produced by that mass also increases. Since the force has increased whilst the area has remained constant, the pressure will increase.

cards.term: Why does pressure in fluids increase with density? (Higher)
cards.definition: As density increases there are more particles in a given volume of the liquid, hence the weight of the liquid is increased. This means that the force of liquid above a certain point is larger. Since the force has increased, the pressure must also increase.

cards.term: What equation shows the magnitude of pressure in liquids at different depths? (Higher)
cards.definition: Pressure (Pa) = Column height (m) x density (kg/m?) x gravitational field strength (N/kg). P = gh

cards.term: Why are objects in a fluid subject to an upthrust? (Higher)
cards.definition: When an object is submerged in fluid, it experiences a higher pressure below it than it does on top of it. This leads to an upwards force called upthrust.

cards.term: Why is the magnitude of the upthrust felt by an object? (Higher)
cards.definition: Upthrust is equal to the weight of fluid displaced by the object.

cards.term: How can you determine if an object will sink or float? (Higher)
cards.definition: If the upthrust is greater than the weight of the object, it will float. If the weight is the greater force, it will sink.

cards.term: Explain why an object with a density more than that of water would never float. (Higher)
cards.definition: Upthrust is equal to the weight of the displaced fluid. If the density of the object is high, there would not be enough volume displaced to produce an upthrust larger than the object's weight. This means that it will sink.
Consists of raw facts and figures without context or meaning.
What exists when data has been given context or meaning.
Space for a single piece of data, each variable has a data type. You can change variables once they have been set.
Space for a single piece of data, each constant has a data type. You cannot change constants once they have been set.
A data type, can be either true or false and requires only one bit of storage.
A data type, a single letter, number, punctuation mark, space etc. - requires one byte.
A data type, stores any number of characters, such as a person\'s name, address and postcode.
A data type, whole numbers, such as a person\'s age or how much stock a shop has.
A data type, decimal numbers, such as distances and fractions.
If you see AND between two Boolean expressions, the whole expression is true only if both of the smaller expressions are true. For example: age <= 16 AND age >= 5
If either of the expressions either side of the OR is true, then the entire expression is true.
Adding NOT to an expression simply makes it the opposite of what it was before. For example: NOT (age <= 11). This covers all other ages, 12 and up.

cards.term: The meaning of the following operators:>=<=!=
cards.definition: >= Greater than or equal to< Less than= Equal to!= Not equal to
An array is a space in memory reserved for more than one item of the same data type.
Table of items and elements, with columns and rows. Data stored in this way can be considered as if it were in a spreadsheet, where each row and each column stands for something.
Records can combine different data types, and each record would be about one person, or one building or one book.

Using data structures instead of lots of individual variables can reduce the amount of code you need to write in order to solve a problem. Arrays also reduce the likelihood of errors occurring, as there are fewer places in the code in which errors could exist.

cards.term: When programs are designed, why are they broken down into smaller tasks and each task is addressed individually?
cards.definition: For large programs, different tasks can be assigned to different programmers, with clear understanding of who is to code what.Each component can be tested separately as it is coded, which means the complete program, when all the parts are assembled, will possibly contain fewer errors.If the program needs updating later, the individual component can be updated, leaving the rest of the program unchanged.
To solve a problem.
A step-by-step set of instructions to allow a computer to solve a problem in a finite number of steps.
Shows how a program, or a potential program, is broken down into individual processes.
A way of showing, within a program, what tasks are to happen in what order. This is done using shapes and arrows.
Used to mark the start and another is used to mark the end of a flowchart.
Input boxes show data entering the system, possibly typed by the user.
Shows which instruction should take place next. --->
Each process contains a single instruction, so complex tasks usually incorporate several processes.
Asks a question, determining which path the program should next take. It is in the shape of a diamond.
When instructions in an algorithm each need to be executed only once, and in the order in which they are written.

When one sequence of instructions or another, but not both, is executed. The sequence that is executed will depend on what happened in earlier instructions. Words such as IF or CASE mean that selection is taking place.
Takes place when one or more instructions are executed more than once. Also known as repetition. It is taking place when program code contains the words LOOP, FOR, WHILE or REPEAT.
Carries out a subtask of a larger task for which the program is responsible. It then returns a value. It also has a data type.
Carries out a subtask of a larger task for which the program is responsible. It does not return a value.
A piece of data that is needed in order for a procedure or function to run. (Input)
What a piece of data is called as it is passed to a function or procedure.
Functions which have been written by other people, you can call them without even seeing the code.

Breaking your program into separate procedures and functions. It can simplify your coded solutions in two ways:You get to choose the name of your procedure/function, which helps you to create code that makes sense. If a particular task is required multiple times, the code for that task can simply be placed into a procedure or function, which can be called multiple times.Since calling a function or procedure only requires a single line, this reduces the amount of code needed, which reduces the likelihood of errors in the code.

The visibility of a variable, constant, function or procedure in a program. When you are writing code you can see or alter some variables and constants, but not others. You can also call some functions or procedures, but not necessarily all of them.
Variables and constants can be local. Only visible within the function or procedure in which it was declared. As soon as the function or procedure ends, the variable/constant is gone.
Variables and constants can be global. They are visible throughout the entire program. This variable/constant is only gone when the program has finished running.
Functions and procedures can be private. This means it can only be called from within the form, or class in which they exist.
Functions and procedures can be public. They can be called from beyond their own form or class.
Happens when you do not follow the rules of the language you are writing in. If your code contains a syntax error, it will either not compile or it will crash when the erroneous line is reached.

Does not cause the program to crash, although it does cause the program to do something it shouldn\'t. It might, for example, produce an incorrect result to a calculation. They are harder to find than syntax errors and they are only usually identified by detailed testing.
Might or might not cause a program to crash at some point, but it will not prevent it from running. The error will not become apparent until the program is executing.
A tool used for checking that a program will behave as you intend it to by examining the value of each variable as it changes. They are usually used to resolve logical errors.
The program is told, rather than to execute some code, to try to execute some code. This would then provide an alternative set of instructions to be followed in case the attempt fails.
In a piece of software, is a fault or error of some kind that prevents the software from working as it should.

The process by which bugs are removed. There are tools available to developers to help identify bugs, break points and variable watch. Trace tables and the use of try catch blocks would be used alongside these tools.

Inserted at a line of source code at which execution will pause (break). The developer can then examine the state of the program at this particular point in execution. Multiple break point can be set throughout the code, which is a useful feature as it allows the developer to view the execution of the program in something resembling slow motion.
Moving from one break point to another, essentially watching program execution in slow motion.
This feature allows the developer to keep track of a variable or expression. This tool allows you to track the life of a variable expression to see if it is correctly manipulated by the program.

A combination of hardware (physical components) and software (the programs) working together to provide a solution to a problem. They are important because they play a part in almost every aspect of human life: in commerce, health care, education and communication. It is important that they are reliable (do what is expected of them) and robust (provide resistance against failure and remain available).

cards.term: Four Key Elements Computer Systems Consist of
cards.definition: Input devices - Are used to get data onto the system, Keyboard, mouse, magnetic tripe reader, light pen, OMR, scanner, OCR, sensors.Output devices - Which present data in a human-friendly form, Monitor, speakers, printer, servomechanism.Storage devices - Used to contain data.Processor - Follows instructions and performs calculations.
Touch screens because you input data by touching the screen and the device outputs data by displaying it on the screen.Games controllers, you input by using the controls and they output by vibrating.

cards.term: The CPU and the Two Main Components
cards.definition: A component that performs calculations and fetches and executes program instructions. There are two main components: The Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) - carries out calculations and numeric functions such as comparing two numbers together to see which is the largest.The Control Unit - Responsible for retrieving data and instructions from the correct location in memory and executing those instructions.

How the processor communicates with other parts of the system. Buses are wires or collections of wires that connect components together. Signals pass between these components which may contain data or instructions.
The clock speed of a CPU is measured in Hertz (Hz). One Hz means one operation per second.

cards.term: Factors which can Influence the Speed of a CPU
cards.definition: The speed of other components, the CPU might be waiting for a hard disk or printer to perform some task before the next instruction is addressed.The size of the cache, the larger the cache, the more it scan store, and the faster the CPU appears to work because it is not waiting as long to receive data or instructions.The number of cores, each core can fetch, decode and execute. More cores mean a faster CPU.
High-speed memory that stores frequently needed instructions or data. Stores copies of data or instructions from the RAM that are accessed very regularly.

Random access memory. The RAM is volatile, when the computer is turned off or subject to a loss of power, the content of the RAM is lost. When a program is loaded from a computer hard disk, its data and instructions are loaded into the RAM.
Read-only memory. Means that the content cannot be edited or deleted. It stores data or instructions that will not need to be updated.

Uses electronic chips as storage but, it is non-volatile. This means it continues to store data without a source of electricity. Flash drives are portable and are often used to transfer data from one computer to another.

Sometimes a computer does not have enough RAM to run programs as it is required to. In these circumstances, the operating system will treat some part of secondary storage as if it were the RAM. This is called virtual memory.
Include the internal hard disk as well as floppy disks, which are no longer widely used.

CDs, DVDs, Blu Ray Disks are written to and read using lasers. The surface of the disk will have billions of locations where holes can be either physically burned by a laser, or not burned, to represent either 1 or 0. Capacity: CDs 700MB, DVDs 4.7GB, Blu-Rays 25GB. Speed is highly variable. Small and light but not as easy to carry as a USB flash drive. Sturdy, although the surface can be scratched and make the data irretrievable. Useful for posting data from one location to another.

Use electronic circuits and no moving parts to store data electronically. Ranges from 1GB to 64GB. Transmits data at a rate of 5 million bits per second. Very small and light, designed to be moved between computers. Sturdy. Used by students who always need to access work on different computers.

Refers to data being stored away from the computer it is accessed on, typically accessible over the internet. Capacity, virtually unlimited. Speed, depends on the internet connection speed but it is generally slower than storing data on the computer which will be used to access it. You can access your data anywhere in the world. Data is backed up multiple times so durability is not an issue.

Keeps programs and data stored when the computer is turned off. Capable of storing more than its main memory. Capacity, variable, data transfer is usually far quicker than from any external device. Difficult and time consuming to move an internal drive from one machine to another. Well protected inside the computer. Most programs are stored on here.

(Size and Example of Storage)Bit - Single binary digit. Either a \'1\' or \'0\'. Nibble - A sequence of four bits. A whole number between 0 and 15.Byte - A sequence of eight bits. An individual keyboard character such as \'k\' or \'#\'.Kilobyte - Approximately 1,000 bytes. A paragraph of text.Megabyte - Approximately 1,000 kilobytes. Around one minute of MP3 music.Gigabyte - Approximately 1,000 megabytes. About 90 minutes of video.Terabyte - Approximately 1,000 gigabytes. Several hundred hours of video.
ASCII characters, requiring only seven bits, need less storage space but can only store 128 different characters.

As a sequence of ASCII characters, every individual character can be stored using its ASCII code.As a series of numbers.There are more commonly stored as numbers, because this requires less storage space and two dates can easily be compared to see which is earlier or later.

An image is divided into pixels. A pixel can only be one colour at a time, and when a picture is saved, the colour of each pixel must be stored in binary. The more bits that are used to store each pixel, the more colours are potentially available.

When converting sound to digital format, two things influence how much storage space is needed:Sampling rate - Refers to how often the computer takes a measure of the sound, including the volume and frequency. A higher sampling rate results in better sound quality, but requires more storage space.Bit rate - How many bits are used to each sample and this can vary widely. Again, higher bit rates result in higher quality of sound but also higher storage requirements.
Spells out what steps take place in the process of developing software and the order in which they take place. There are several models of the life cycle.

The processes happen repeatedly, and in the same order during each cycle. + It is easy to arrange subtasks and set milestones. + Clearly defined stages make management straightforward.- A testable program is not available until late in the cycle.- It is difficult to accommodate change once you have passed the relevant process.

Each process takes place, from top to bottom, to completion before the next process begins. + It is easy to manage, as the whole process is readily divisible into smaller processes.+ It is easily understood and used.- Unsuitable for larger projects or projects with changing requirements.- Not all projects can be so easily broken down into processes like this, some processes may overlap.

Similar to the cyclical mode, except each process is visited multiple times in that sequence. Each time a process occurs, it occurs in a more developed way than the last time it occurred.+ Good approach for larger projects, as changes can be implemented throughout the project.+ A working prototype can be made available fairly early.- Each spiral model approach will be different, meaning less reusability.- Not appropriate for smaller projects where multiple passes may be unnecessary.

The main purpose of this is to examine an existing system to find out whether or not it is worthwhile replacing it with a different system. Replacing a system has certain costs:Money for software developers, hardware etc.Time, designing and installing the new system is time consuming.Human resources, specialist staff are needed to design and install the system and existing staff would need to be retrained to operate it. Benefits of replacing a system:May be possible to do a job faster.May be cheaper to operate, requiring less staff.

The main purpose is to understand the existing system as well as the requirements of the proposed system. The following steps may be taken:Using the current system as a current user might use it.Studying system documentation.Interviews/questionnaires of customers/staff to seek their opinion.Observing the current system in use.Exploring data requirements.Producing diagrams showing processing and entities.

Designing a new system is split into a number of sections. A design is simply a detailed plan for the proposed system.Designing algorithms - They must be well designed otherwise it can affect the speed of a process, such as searching or sorting.Designing HCI - Involves the design of how the computer and human will interact with each other, involving hardware and software.Designing data structures - Records, arrays, variables etc. need to be decide upon.
Is the point at which the program is checked to address two main questions:Does the program do what it was intended to do?Does the program function correctly?

Is the point where at which the user moves from the old system to the new system. There are several ways in which this can take place:Direct - Where the changeover is sudden and complete.Parallel - Both systems run at the same time for a while, this is beneficial because in the event of a problem, the old system is still available for use.Phased - Elements of the new system as introduced one at a time.Pilot - A single department may change to the new system in a company, and then the rest of the organisation would follow later.When choosing, it is important to consider the cost of implementing it and the disruption that could be caused.

When the changeover is complete, the work of the developer is not complete. Maintenance means ensuring the product continues to be beneficial to the customer.Perfective maintenance - Making the system easier to use or adding new features, making the system as good as it can be for the purpose.Adaptive maintenance - Making changes to the system as the needs of the customer change.Corrective maintenance - Solving problems that occurred during the creation of the new system that wee not discovered at the time.

At various points during the life cycle, documentation needs to be provided by the developer for a variety of purposes:Design documentation, of the interface and the processes, are needed by the end user as soon as possible to check what is going to be produced is what is required. Program documentation, including annotated code and design of data structures, must be available to the developer during testing and maintenance.During testing, a log of results will be produced in an ongoing cycle, until the system is deemed to be working correctly.User manuals must be available to the customer to provide details on how to operate the system. Technical manuals are also needed to detail things such as security procedures, backup procedures and system recovery procedures.

One way of developing solutions in which a basic version of the finished product is created quickly. End user uses prototype --> Feedback from end user is obtained --> Prototype is updated.+ Because the end user is always involved, time spent on unnecessary features is minimized.+ There are multiple opportunities for errors to be detected, so they are usually detected sooner. + Testing of the solution can begin far sooner than in the cyclical development model, allowing more time to find errors.- It is quite easy for the solution to become more complex than initial plans.- Beginning the process by producing a prototype might mean the analysis stage is not completed as thoroughly as it should be. - Lots of opportunities exist for the end user to change their minds, which can result in higher costs in terms of money and time.
Solutions can be broken down into modules. This makes the solution easier to understand and allows straightforward distribution of tasks among a team of programmers.

Carried out by the developer. Individual algorithms tested, with the values of variables being traced through the program, often line by line. This type of testing makes use of trace tables, where expected variable values are compared with the actual outcome.
Carried out by prospective purchasers of the finished product. Users use it as they would normally use such a program, reporting any errors back to the developers.
Carried out by the end user. This type of testing is intended to answer the question \'does the program do what I wanted it to do\' rather than \'does the program work\'.

Collection of computers and other hardware that has been connected together in order to allow communication and sharing of resources. Also, networks allow software to be installed and controlled across the network from a single computer, rather than individually on every machine.
Local area network, which might occupy an office or building.
Wide area network, the largest of which is the internet.

Communication - Email, instant messaging and the transferring of files is possible across a network.Sharing of resources - Files on one computer can be accessed by others, multiple computers on a network can share a single printer and within a LAN, a connection to the Internet can be shared.Network management - You may be able to log onto any computer within a LAN and have access to your own files, which is particularly useful in schools and colleges.

Viruses and other malware can only move from computer to computer via shared disks or through a network. A network computer is more likely to become infected compared to a stand alone computer.Failure of a single resource can impact upon all computers on a network. If a logon server fails, it may be nobody can access their account.

All devices are attached to a common connection medium, known as the backbone. Any communication must travel through this medium. A server may be attached, or a printer or a router if the network needs to provide access to the internet. At either end of the backbone is a terminator, which marks the end of a network.
All devices are connected to a single central device, such as a switch or a hub. Communications must go via this central device. Servers, printers and routers would also be connected to this device.

Each device is connected to two other devices, so that the devices and connection media make up a shape of a ring. To communicate with a particular device, a signal often has to pass through several other devices en route.

cards.term: Advantages and Disadvantages of a Bus Topology
cards.definition: Very cheap, as it requires minimal amount of cabling.Easy to add or remove computers.Failure in the main cable will cause failure of the network.The network can be significantly slowed by high network traffic.

cards.term: Advantages and Disadvantages of a Star Topology
cards.definition: If one cable fails, only the device attached to it is isolated from the network.Faults are easy to find.It is easy to add extra devices.The system is secure, as data is only sent to devices that need that data.Lots of cable, which means more expensive to install than other topologies.

cards.term: Advantages and Disadvantages of a Ring Topology
cards.definition: No collisions, as there is typically only one batch of data allowed on the network at any one time.Very high rates of transmission are possible.Failure of a single cable can bring down the entire network.Failure of a single device can bring down the entire network.Security is not ensured, as data passes through other devices en route to its final destination.
Internet Message Access Protocol - handles inbound emails, keeps the client and server in sync and only a copy is downloaded.
Post Office Protocol - used to retrieve email from a server, doesn\'t keep the user and server in sync, after the mail is downloaded it\'s deleted.
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol - used to send emails between servers, directly linked to the DNS.
Fixed field and data types with metadata. Can be queried.
Tables linked by key fields, with a primary key.
A field (or group of fields) that uniquely identifies a given entity in a table
A primary key from one table that is used in another table.
Component of a processor that directs and coordinates most of the operations in the computer.
controls the timing of all computer operations
the pace of the system clock
collection of wires that transmit data from main memory and the CPU
pathway from CPU to memory that carries the memory address, so RAM can fetch the data < unidirectional
used to transfer actual data
carries commands from the CPU and messages from other hardware.
essential software that controls the execution of computer programs and links hardware and software
user management, file management, peripheral management and multitasking
responsible for account control
allocated CPU time for each task and prioritises them / moves necessary parts of an application to memory
uses device drivers that convert peripheral and OS signals
maintains records of all files / manages hard disk and splits it into sectors
high level > machine code works line by line, every time you want to execute the code it must be retranslated, stops when it reaches an error, source code is needed
high level > machine codesource code isn\'t need after translation, error messages are displayed after, translates whole code
assembly code > machine code uses the processor\'s instructions optimisation will occur - removes some detail to improve efficacy
little to no abstraction
specific to a processor and corresponds to its instruction set
specific to hardware, 1 to 1 relationship with machine code
systems software that perform tasks related to managing the computer\'s resources, file management, diagnostics, and other specialised tasks
no central node, each computer is equal and has the ability to be the client or server
A network that uses centrally administered computers, known as servers, to enable resource sharing for and to facilitate communication between the other computers on the network.
ensuring data is correct before processing
ensuring an entity is genuine
how fast signals travel
maximum rate of data transfer
rate of corruption
stimulates an insider attack with some knowledge of the system
stimulates an outsider attack
unpatched software, misconfiguration, social engineering, USB devices, portable devices and eaves dropping
applicationtransport network link
Transmission control protocol - splits data into packets and reassembles them. Acknowledgement is send to the sender when received - or retransmitted. Operates at transport layer
Internet protocol - addresses packets with the source and destination IP addresses. Then at the other end removes IP addresses when received. Operates at the network level.
hyper text transfer protocol - used for accessing a webpage from a web server. Operates at the application layer
legal but they need permissions and notify admins of results
monitor network traffic and filter packets based on rules
Divide and conquer (divide array in half and sort each half, then merge back together)
Changing the data type of a value
when channel frequencies are too close or the same and need to be spread out to prevent inferences.
world wide web - collection of web pages, hosted using HTTP
A number that uniquely identifies each computer or device connected on a network to a geographical location
a mode of data transmission in which a message is broken into a number of parts that are sent independently, over whatever route is optimum for each packet, and reassembled at the destination.
header - information about data; packet number, MAC and IP address data - actual datatrailer - may contain a checksum - validation to error check
remain fixed / better for readability, updates and complier optimisation. need to be declared
performs a specific task, used and reused by \'calling\' and is \'passed in\' through parameters < user written or pre-existing
small sections of code that are used to perform a particular task. procedures return a value and functions don\'t
commercial analysis tool, disaster recovery, fall over(backup devices), design stage planning, audit trails(records of user and system events)
limit user accounts, strong hidden passwords, update and limitation of outrun software.
code reviews, modular testing, established design patterns and models, parameter validation and error handling
all lines are executed
decisions are made that determine execution
code is repeated until a condition is met
- declared inside a method - accessible only within that method-take precedence over global variables
can be used in ANY part of a program
Stored data with a fixed length, same type under an index position (one less than actual position)1D - horizontal2D - horizontal and vertical
characters structured as lines of text - records. must be opened before use and closed afterwards. closing frees resources, prevents corruption and frees buffer.different data types
remainder
whole number
extracts characters from a string between two specified #\'s and returns it as a new string.
gives ASCII characters
gives character code

program runs but does the wrong thing
An error that results when an instruction does not follow the syntax rules or grammar of the programming language.
becomes apparent when the program is executed
Entering data that should be acceptable to the solution.
Values at the limit of what the program should be able to handle
Data that is ridiculous or totally unsuitable.
modifying an input to make it valid
-comments-identifiers-indentation
Binary with a positive or negative sign
1. write it in positive 2. write down until a 13. flip the rest
use for unsigned binary
Used for signed binary numbers. When performing a right shift the bit at the left are replaced by copies of the most significant bit.
American Standard Code for Information Interchange - developed to solve compatibility issues
A character code that enables most of the languages of the world to be symbolized with a special character identification.
an image composed of pixels with a fixed resolution
1. grid is placed over the image2. an average colour is found for each pixel
The number of bits used for each pixel
size (bits) = width x height x depth
data about data

1. samples are taken at sections of the analogue sound 2. converted to digits

The number of bits used per second of audio
sampling frequency x sample size
sampling fr\xc3\xa9quente x sample size x time
A LAN configuration in which all nodes share a common line. data collisios
A LAN configuration in which all nodes are connected in a closed loop. if a node falls the whole network will be affected.

A topology with one central node that has each computer or network device attached to the central node. All data first goes into the central node and then is sent out to its destination. no data collisions, if there\'s a problem with the switch the whole network will go down
full mesh - every node connected to every other node, provides backup but more expensive and complex.
Performs operations on data e.g. Addition, subtraction
Coordinating activities of the CPU
Quick, small stores of data within the CPU
Holds memory address for data or a instruction about to be used by the CPU
Holds actual data or instruction
Stores results of calculations in the ALU
Holds memory address of the instruction for each cycle
The next instruction is retrieved by CPU from main memory
The instruction is broken down and decided so computer can understand
The CPU performs what the instructions told
A computer system built within a large device e.g. Camera, washer, car
Memory loses its data when power of
Memory retains its data when power is lost
